The Training Anthology of Śāntideva
A Translation of the Śikṣā-samuccaya Translated by CHARLES GOODMAN
bslab pa kun las btus pa'i tshig le'ur byas pa/
Root Verses of the Training Anthology
@##/ /rgya gar skad du/ shik+Sha sa muts+tsha ya kA ri kA/ bod skad du/ bslab pa kun las btus pa'i tshig le'ur byas pa/
(Skt. Śikṣā-samuccaya; Tib. bslab pa kun las btus pa)
sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
'di ltar bdag dang gzhan dag kyang / / 'jigs dang sdug bsngal mi 'dod na/ / bdag dang bye brag ci yod na/ / gang de bsrung la gzhan mi bsrung / /
[1] When fear and suffering are disliked By me and others equally, What is so special about me, So that I protect myself and not others?
sdug bsngal mthar 'byin 'dod pa dang / / bde ba'i mthar yang 'gro 'dod pas/ / dad pa'i rtsa ba brtan bya ste/ / byang chub la yang blo brtan bya/ /
[2] Someone who wishes to end suffering And go to the utmost limit of happiness Should securely plant the root of faith, And then fix the mind unwaveringly on Awakening.
byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa ni/ / rgyas par theg pa che las 'byung / / gang gis ltung bar mi 'gyur ba'i/ / gnad kyi gnas rnams 'dir rig bya/ /
[3] To train in the Great Way, From which comes the bodhisattva discipline, You should know its vital points, so as To be without downfalls:
bdag gi lus dang longs spyod dang / / dge ba dus gsum skyes pa rnams/ / sems can kun la btang ba dang / / de bsrung dag pa spel ba'o/ /
[4] Giving away to all sentient beings Your body, your possessions, and your good Gained in the past, present, and future, And protecting, purifying, and enhancing these.
sems can rnams kyis longs spyad phyir/ / lus la sogs pas bsrung bar bya/ / ma bsrungs longs spyod gang las 'ong / / gang mi spyod pa ci zhig sbyin/ /
[5] The body and so on are given For the use of sentient beings. If they are not protected, how can they be used? If they can’t be used, what kind of gift is that?
de bas sems can longs spyod phyir/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen mi gtong zhing / / mdo sde dag la rtag blta bas/ / lus la sogs pa bsrung bar bya/ /
[6] Therefore, you should protect your body and so on, So that they can be useful to sentient beings, By not abandoning your spiritual teacher, And by constantly reading the sūtras.
de la lus bsrung gang zhe na/ / gnod par 'gyur ba spang ba ste/ / de kun gang gis 'thob ce na/ / 'bras bu med pa'i byed spangs pas/ /
[7] Here, what is protecting the body? It is giving up what is harmful. How is this attained? By giving up all fruitless movements.
de yang rtag tu dran pas 'grub/ / dran pa shin tu gus las 'byung / / gus ni zhi ba'i che ba nyid/ / shes par gyur nas brtun pas skyed/ /
[8] You actually do that by being mindful at all times. Mindfulness should come from sharp attention. With effort, this attention Becomes what is called “the greatness of peace.”
mnyam gzhag yang dag ji bzhin du/ / shes par 'gyur zhes thub pas gsungs/ / phyi rol g.yo ba bzlog pa yis/ / sems ni zhi las mi g.yo zhing / /
[9] “Someone absorbed in meditation knows things Just as they are,” said the Sage. When external movements stop, The mind does not move away from resting.
kun du mi rgod 'jam pa dang / / ran cing mnyen par smra ba yis/ / skal can skye bo 'dun par 'gyur/ / gzung bar 'os pa'ang skye bar 'gyur/ /
[10] Someone who is totally free from agitation Speaks gentle, measured, loving words, Attracts worthy people who are ready to learn And arouses their interest.
'di ni gzung 'os ma yin na/ / 'jig rten rgyal ba'i myu gu brnyas/ / thal bas g.yogs pa'i me bzhin du/ / sems can dmyal la sogs par sreg /
[11] Worldly people do not welcome, but treat with contempt, The offspring of the Victors, Who are like fire hidden by ashes, So they burn, in the hells and elsewhere.
de phyir rgyal bas sdom pa'i mdor/ / gang gis sems can ma dad 'gyur/ / de ni bsgrims te rnam spang zhes/ / dkon mchog sprin las bka' stsal to/ /
[12] Therefore, in the Cloud of Jewels, The Victor taught a vow in brief Through which, if you make an effort, You won’t offend sentient beings.
'di ni bdag lus bsrung ba ste/ / sman dang gos la sogs bcas pas/ / bdag la sred pas longs spyad na/ / nyon mongs bcas pa'i ltung bar 'gyur/ /
[13] This is protecting the body, By means of medicine, clothes, and so on; But if it is done to indulge your own craving, It is a downfall induced by reactivity.
legs spyad dag la brtsam par bya/ / thams cad la yang tshod rig bya/ / de ltas bslab pa'i gzhi 'di las/ / de yi longs spyod bsrung mi dka'/ /
[14] For someone who does the right thing, Following the training precepts, Knowing in everything how much is enough, It is not difficult to protect possessions.
rang don rnam smin sred spangs pas/ / dge ba kun du bsrung bar 'gyur/ / 'gyod par yang ni mi bya ste/ / byas par gyur kyang bsgrag mi bya/ /
[15] Protect what is good by being free from craving For results of evolution that benefit yourself. Don’t regret it afterwards, And after you do it, don’t make it publicly known.
rnyed dang bkur stis 'jigs bya zhing / / khengs pa rtag tu spang bar bya/ / byang chub sems dpa' dad bya zhing / / chos la yid gnyis spang bar bya/ /
[16] Beware of money and prestige; Always avoid pride. A bodhisattva should be confident And let go of any dislike for the Dharma.
lus ni rnam par sbyang byas na/ / phan pa'i longs spyod 'gyur ba ste/ / 'bras chan legs par tshos pa dang / / gzegs med lus can phan pa 'dra/ /
[17] The enjoyment of a purified body Is healthy for embodied beings, Just like well-prepared boiled rice Without husk-powder.
ji ltar lo tog btsas khebs na/ / nad kyis zhum zhing rgyas mi 'gyur/ / de ltar sangs rgyas myu gu yang / / nyon mongs khebs na rgyas mi 'gyur/ /
[18] Just as, when grain is covered by grass, It becomes diseased and does not grow; In the same way, the sprout of Buddhahood Doesn’t grow if it is covered by reactive emotions.
lus kyi dag pa gang zhe na/ / sdig dang nyon mongs rnam sbyong yin/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis gsungs tshul du/ / 'bad pa med na ngan 'gror 'gro/ /

[19] What is the purification of the body? It is clearing away vile actions and reactive emotions Through the essential meaning of the fully awakened Buddha’s teachings; But if you make no efforts, you go to the lower realms.
bzod bya thos pa btsal bar bya/ / de nas nags su gnas par bya/ / mnyam par gzhag la brtson bya zhing / / mi sdug la sogs bsgom par bya/ /
[20] Endure patiently. Seek learning, Then dwell in the forest. Make an effort to stabilize attention. Meditate on foulness and so on.
yang dag 'tsho ba sbyangs pa yis/ / longs spyod dag par shes par bya/ / stong pa snying rje'i snying po can/ / bskyed pas bsod nams dag par 'gyur/ /
[21] You should know that possessions are purified By making right livelihood pure. The purification of goodness Happens through motions whose nature is emptiness and compassion.
gzung bar bya ba rab mang la/ / 'di ni nyung na 'dis ci bya/ / shin tu ngoms pa skyed ma yin/ / de phyir 'di ni 'phel bar bya/ /
[22] Those who are to receive are very numerous, And this is small; what use is it? It does not give rise to deep fulfillment; Therefore, it must be enhanced.
de la lus 'phel gang zhe na/ / le lo med dang stobs skyed yin/ / stong dang snying rje'i snying po can/ / sbyin pas longs spyod 'phel bar 'gyur/ /
[23] What is the enhancement of the body? The enhancement of power and diligence. Possessions are enhanced through generosity, Whose nature is emptiness and compassion.
brtson dang bsam pa brtan par yang / / dang po nan tan byas nas ni/ / snying rje mdun du bzhag nas ni/ / dge ba spel la nan tan bya/ /
[24] Making an earnest effort with respect to what has been done and so on, With firm diligence and firm intention, Putting compassion foremost, Make an earnest effort to enhance goodness.
bzang po spyod pa'i cho ga bzhin/ / phyag 'tshal la sogs gus par bya/ / dad pa la sogs rtag tu bsgom/ / byams dang sangs rgyas sogs dran bya/ /
[25] You should perform the ritual of Good Conduct, Performing the reverence and so on with respect, Constantly practicing faith and so on, Lovingkindness, recollection of Buddhas, and the rest.
dus rnams kun du sems can don/ / chos kyi sbyin pa zang zing med/ / byang chub sems ni mdor bsdu na/ / bsod nams 'phel ba'i rgyu yin no/ /
[26] In all postures, for the benefit of sentient beings, Giving Dharma, with no ulterior motive; In brief, Awakening Mind Is the cause of enhancing goodness.
'grub pa yang dag spong rnams te/ / bag yod pa dang ma bral zhing / / dran pa dang ni shes bzhin dang / / tshul bzhin du ni sems pa'o/ /
[27] The accomplishment of the right efforts, Not being separated from heedfulness, With mindfulness, with awareness, And with appropriate reflection.
bslab pa kun las btus pa'i tshig le'ur byas pa/ mkhan po zhi ba lhas mdzad pa rdzogs so// //

f.d: bslab pa kun las btus pa
The Training Anthology of Śāntideva
@##/ /rgya gar skad du/ shik+Sha sa muts+tsha yaH / bod skad du/ bslab pa kun las btus pa/
bam po dang po/
[sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa]
1. The Perfection of Generosity
sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
{HOMAGE TO ALL Buddhas and bodhisattvas!}[1]

gang ma thos pas dmyal ba la sogs g.yang sar ni/ / bsreg la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal mi bzad mtha' yas dag / sems ma zhi ba khyed kyis yang yang myong gyur pa/ / de ni mnyan phyir gus pa shin tu rgya cher bsten/ /

1. Because you didn’t listen to it, all of you have again and again had to experience, with no peace of mind, the intense and unremitting pain of being burned and of other torments in the great abyss, that is, in the hells and other realms like them. So listen to it with most careful attention!

gang thos nas kyang g.yeng ba med pa'i bdag can gyis/ / sdig spong sngon byas mang po ma lus zad byed la/ / sngon chad ma thob pa yi bde ba'ang rab 'thob cing / / bde ba las ni nam yang nyams par mi 'gyur dang / /

2. Those who humbly listen {to it give up} their vile actions, and completely get rid of the many vile actions they have done in the past. They gain happiness that they never had before, do not ever lose the happiness they now have,

rdzogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i bde mchog mi zad dang / / sangs rgyas go 'phang mnyam med phun tshogs thob byed pa/ / shin tu rnyed dka'i rin chen chos de deng thob na/ / legs par brjod pa 'di la dal thob gus par nyon/ /

3. And attain both the supreme and undying happiness of the bodhisattvas and the incomparable fulfillment {of a Buddha.} It is that jewel, the Dharma, which is very hard to find; but today, you have found it. Those who have the opportunity to practice should pay attention and listen to what is said!

khams gsum phan mdzad gcig po de gsung mnyan bya'i phyir/ / lha dang klu dang grub pa dri za gnod sbyin dang / / mkha' lding lha min mi 'am ci dbang 'dre la sogs/ / dgar bcas nyan par mos shing yid dad 'dir shog shig /

4. May the gods and serpent spirits,[i] their minds full of trust, and the lords among celestial musicians, and among forest spirits, garuḍas,[2] titans, and half-humans, come here joyously, thirsting to hear the words of the one who is the sole source of welfare for the threefold world.
bder gshegs chos kyi sku mnga' sras bcas dang / / phyag 'os kun la'ang gus par phyag 'tshal te/ / bde gshegs sras kyi sdom la 'jug pa rnams/ / mdor bsdus don gyi ngag gis brjod par bya/ /

5. After prostrating with respect to the Well-Gone Ones and their heirs, along with their bodies of teaching, and to all those who are worthy of praise, I will present a concise[ii] introduction to the discipline of the heirs of the Well-Gone Ones.
sngon chad ma byung ci yang 'dir brjod med/ / sdeb sbyor mkhas pa'ang bdag la yod min te/ / de phyir gzhan gyi don du bdag mi 'bad/ / rang gi yid la bsgom phyir ngas 'di brtsams/ /
6. Nothing new is said here, and I do not have any literary skill. Therefore, I am not trying to help anyone else; I wish to develop my own mind.
dge ba bsgom phyir bdag gi dad pa'i shugs/ / 'di dag gis kyang re zhig 'phel 'gyur la/ / bdag dang skal ba mnyam pa gzhan gyis kyang / / ji ste 'di dag mthong na don yod 'gyur/ /
7. As I write this, a calm impulse grows in me to cultivate what is wholesome. Also, if someone else with just the same personality as I have were to read this, that person could also benefit.
dal 'byor shin tu rnyed par dka' ba dang / / skyes bu'i don bsgrub 'di ni rnyed gyur pas/ / gal te 'di la phan pa ma bsams na/ / phyis 'di yang dag 'byor par ga la 'gyur/ /

8. The opportunity to practice is very difficult to find. Once you find it, you can bring about what benefits people. If you have it and don’t pay attention to what matters, when will all these conditions come together again?[3]

ji skad du 'phags pa sdong po bkod pa'i mdor 'phags pa rgyal ba'i drod kyi skye mched kyi rnam par thar pa las mi khom pa brgyad las ldog pa yang rnyed par dka'/ mir 'gyur ba yang rnyed par dka'/ dal ba phun sum tshogs pa rnam par dag pa yang rnyed par dka'/ sangs rgyas 'byung ba yang rnyed par dka'/ dbang po ma tshang ba med pa yang rnyed par dka'/ sangs rgyas kyi chos mnyan pa yang rnyed par dka'/ / skyes bu dam pa dang 'grogs pa yang rnyed par dka'/ yang dag pa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnams kyang rnyed par dka'/ yang dag pa'i tshul rjes su bstan pa nye bar sgrub pa yang rnyed par dka'/ yang dag par 'tsho ba yang rnyed par dka'/ mi'i 'jig rten na chos dang rjes su mthun pa'i chos la nan tan byed pa yang rnyed par dka' na zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

[2] As the noble Array of Stalks Sūtra (Gaṇḍavyūha-sūtra) says, in the passage known as the noble Liberation of Jayoṣmāyatana:[4] It is difficult to come back from the eight bad rebirths. It is difficult to be born as a human. Full leisure to practice is difficult to find. The opportunity created by the birth of a Buddha is difficult to find. The opportunity of having intact senses is difficult to find. The opportunity to hear a Buddha’s teachings is difficult to find. The opportunity to associate with a holy person is difficult to find. Genuine spiritual teachers are difficult to find. The opportunity to perfect the practice of genuine religious instructions is difficult to find. Right livelihood is difficult to find. In the world of humans, the opportunity to make an appropriate effort to practice the holy teachings is difficult to find.
de'i phyir rnam pa de lta bu dang phrad pa la brten nas/ / sems can chen po gang la

A great being who has actually obtained a collection of opportunities of this kind ultimately and conventionally, and who wishes for happiness and for relief from the well-known sufferings of cyclic existence, by the power of the Buddha nature[5] may ask this question:
gang tshe bdag dang gzhan dag kyang / / 'jigs dang sdug bsngal mi 'dod pa/ / de tshe de srung gzhan mi gang / / bdag dang bye brag ci zhig yod/ /
[1] When fear and suffering are disliked By me and others equally, What is so special about me, So that I protect myself and not others?[6]
snyam pa de lta bu'i so sor spyod pa skyes nas des bdag dang sems can gyi khams rnams kyi/
On behalf of yourself and of the whole realm of sentient beings,[iii] [you should reflect further]:
sdug bsngal mthar 'byin 'dod pa dang / / bde ba'i mthar yang 'gro 'dod pas/ / dad pa'i rtsa ba brtan byas te/ / byang chub la yang blo brtan bya/ /
[2] Someone who wishes to end suffering And go to the utmost limit of happiness Should securely plant the root of faith, And then fix the mind unwaveringly on Awakening.

'di ltar dkon mchog ta la la'i gzungs las/ rgyal dang rgyal ba'i chos la dad gyur cing / / sangs rgyas sras kyi spyod la dad byed pas/ / byang chub bla na med la dad gyur nas/ / skyes bu chen po rnams kyi sems skye'o/ /

For the Precious Lamp Dhāraṇī (Ratna-ulka-dhāraṇī) says:[7] Because of having faith in the Victorious Ones and their teachings, And by having faith in the practice of the Buddha’s heirs, Because of having faith in the highest Awakening, The mind of a great person is born.
dad pa sngon 'gro ma ltar bskyed pa ste/ / yon tan thams cad srung zhing 'phel bar byed/ / dogs pa sel zhing chu bo rnams las sgrol/ / dad pa bde legs grong khyer mtshon byed cing / /

Faith, coming first, is the mother, Giving birth to all abilities, protecting them and helping them to grow. It drives away doubts and carries you over the flood; [3] Faith shows you the city of peace.
dad pa rnyog pa med cing sems dang byed/ / nga rgyal spong zhing gus pa'i rtsa ba yin/ / dad pa gter dang nor dang rkang pa'i mchog / lag pa bzhin du dge sdud rtsa ba yin/ /
Faith makes the mind pure and clear; Free from conceit, it is the root of respect. Faith is a storehouse of wealth;[iv] it is your best foot. Like a hand, it is the source of all good karma.
dad pa yongs su gtong la dga' bar byed/ / dad pa rgyal ba'i chos la rab dga' skyed/ / dad pa yon tan ye shes khyad par byed/ / sangs rgyas go 'phang ston cing thob byed yin/ /

Faith leads to joy in giving And brings delight in the teachings of the Victorious Ones. Faith makes you distinguished in abilities and pristine awareness,[v] Shows you the state of a Buddha and helps you attain it.
dbang po rno zhing rab tu gsal bar byed/ / dad pa'i stobs la gzhan gyis mi brdzi zhing / / nyon mongs rnam par sel ba'i gzhi rten yin/ / dad pa rang byung yon tan rnams kyang tshol/ /
It clarifies your faculties and makes them sharper. The power of faith cannot be overcome. It is the basis of eliminating the reactive emotions.[vi] Faith seeks out your natural abilities.
dad pa chags pa'i sgo la chags pa med/ / mi dal spong zhing dal ba mchog cig yin/ / dad pa bdud kyi lam las 'da' byed cing / / thar pa'i lam mchog ston par byed pa yin/ /

Those who have faith are not attached to the pleasures of contact. It wards off unfavorable circumstances and is itself the single best opportunity. Faith takes you beyond Māra’s[8] path And shows you the highest path of freedom.
sa bon ma rul yon tan rnams kyi rgyu/ / dad pa byang chub shing ni rnam par skyed/ / ye shes khyad par yon tan 'phel bar byed/ / dad pa rgyal ba thams cad ston byed yin/ /
It is the unspoiled seed, the cause of abilities; Faith grows into the tree of Awakening. It increases the special bliss of pristine awareness;[vii] Faith shows you all the Victorious Ones.
gang dag rtag tu sangs rgyas dad gus bcas/ / de dag tshul khrims bslab pa yongs mi 'dor/ / gang dag tshul khrims bslab pa mi 'dor ba/ / yon tan ldan de yon tan ldan pas bstod/ /

Those who always have faith and devotion to the Buddha Don’t give up on moral discipline and their training. Those who don’t give up on moral discipline and their training Are praised as having abilities by those with abilities.
gang dag rtag tu chos la dad gus bcas/ / de dag rgyal ba'i chos nyan ngoms pa med/ / gang dag rgyal ba'i chos nyan mi ngoms pa/ / de dag chos la mos pa bsam mi khyab/ /

Those who always have faith and devotion to the Teachings Insatiably study the Dharma of the Victorious Ones. [viii] Those who insatiably study the Dharma of the Victorious Ones Have inconceivable confidence in the Dharma.[ix]
gang dag rtag tu dge 'dun dad gus bcas/ / de dag mi ldog dge 'dun dad pa yin/ / gang dag mi ldog dge 'dun rab dad pa/ / de dag dad pa'i stobs kyis mi ldog 'gyur/ /

Those who always have faith and devotion to the religious community [4] Have irreversible confidence in the religious community. Those who have irreversible confidence in the religious community Become irreversible by the power of faith.
gang dag dad pa'i stobs kyis mi ldog pa/ / de dag dbang po rno zhing rab tu gsal/ / gang dag dbang po rno zhing rab gsal ba/ / de dag sdig pa'i grogs po rnam par spangs/ /
Those who become irreversible by the power of faith Have faculties that are sharp and very clear. Those who have faculties that are sharp and very clear Have completely given up bad friends.
gang dag sdig pa'i grogs po rnam spangs pa/ / de dag chos ldan grogs kyis yongs su bzung / / gang dag chos ldan grogs kyis yongs bzung ba/ / de dag dge ba rgya chen sogs par byed/ /
Those who have completely given up bad friends Are surrounded by religious friends. Those who are surrounded by religious friends Gather a huge quantity of what is wholesome.
gang dag dge ba rgya chen sogs byed pa/ / bdag nyid chen po de dag rgyu stobs ldan/ / bdag nyid chen po rgyu stobs gang ldan pa/ / de dag mos pa'i khyad par rgya chen 'gyur/ /
Those who gather a huge quantity of what is wholesome Are great beings who have the power of causes.[x] Those great beings who have the power of causes Have vast confidence of a special kind.
gang dag mos pa'i khyad par rgya che ba/ / de dag rgyal ba kun gyis rtag byin brlabs/ / gang dag rgyal ba kun gyis byin brlabs pa/ / de dag byang chub don du sems kyang skye/ /
Those who have vast confidence of a special kind Always receive energy from all the Victorious Ones. Those who always receive energy from all the Victorious Ones— Awakening Mind arises in them.
gang dag byang chub don du sems skye ba/ / de dag drang srong chen po'i yon tan brtson/ / drang srong chen po'i yon tan gang brtson pa/ / de dag rigs mtho sangs rgyas rigs su skye/ /
Those in whom Awakening Mind arises Strive for the abilities of great sages. Those who strive for the abilities of great sages Having been born once, are born again in the family of the Buddha.
gang dag rigs mtho sangs rgyas rigs skyes pa/ / de dag mnyam zhing sbyor dang mi sbyor spangs/ / mnyam zhing sbyor dang mi sbyor gang spangs pa/ / de dag dad dang bsam pa rnam par dag /

Those who are born again in the family of the Buddha Have stopped trying to get anything or get rid of anything.[xi] Those who have stopped trying to get anything or get rid of anything, Their aspirations are pure, due to confidence.
gang dag dad dang bsam pa rnam dag pa/ / de dag lhag pa'i bsam pa dam pa mchog / gang dag lhag bsam dam pa mchog ldan pa/ / de dag rtag tu pha rol phyin pa spyod/ /
Those whose aspirations are pure, due to confidence— Their higher intention is holy and supreme. Those whose higher intention is holy and supreme Always practice the perfections.
gang dag rtag tu pha rol phyin spyod pa/ / de dag theg pa chen po 'di la zhugs/ / gang dag theg pa chen po 'dir zhugs pa/ / de dag sangs rgyas rnams la sgrub pas mchod/ /
Those who always practice the perfections Have now entered the Great Way. Those who have now entered the Great Way Have begun to revere the Buddhas through practice.
gang dag sgrub pas sangs rgyas mchod byed pa/ / de dag sangs rgyas rjes dran mi phyed 'gyur/ / gang dag sangs rgyas rjes dran mi phyed pa/ / de dag rtag tu sangs rgyas bsam yas mthong / /

Those who have begun to revere the Buddhas through practice Become unshakeable in the practice of recollecting the Buddhas. Those who are unshakeable in the practice of recollecting the Buddhas Always see and think about[xii] the Buddhas.
gang dag sangs rgyas bsam yas rtag mthong ba/ / de la nam yang sangs rgyas mi bzhugs min/ / gang la nam yang sangs rgyas mi bzhugs min/ / de dag bar skabs chos las nyams mi 'gyur/ /
For those who always see and think about the Buddhas, There is never a time when there is no Buddha. Those for whom there is never a time when there is no Buddha Are never without the Dharma.
zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa dang / dad pa'i rtsa ba can gyi yon tan rgya chen po mtha' yas pa zhig der gsungs te/ / de rdzogs nas yang mdor bsdus te gsungs pa/

Those who are never without the Dharma [5] Are always given energy by all the Victorious Ones. This is the detailed explanation of the endless advantages of the root of faith. After concluding this [poem], the text further says:
'di 'dra chos ni gang dag dad gyur pa/ / sems can so so skye bo'i tshogs na dkon/ / gang dag dge bsags bsod nams byas gyur pa/ / de dag rgyu yi stobs kyis 'di la dang / /
Qualities of this kind, such as faith, Are rare among ordinary sentient beings, But those who have gathered good karma and done acts of goodness Have faith, by the power of causes.

gang gA zhing bcu'i rdul snyed sems can la/ / bde ba kun gyis bskal par bsnyen bkur yang / / chos 'dir dad pa'i bsod nams ci 'dra ba/ / bsod nams khyad par de 'dra de la med/ / ces gsungs pa yin no/ /

Those who have served as many sentient beings As there are atoms in ten [Buddha]-fields[xiii] For an entire aeon, providing all forms of happiness, Don’t develop that special kind of goodness That comes from having faith {in this Dharma.}

de skad du chos bcu pa'i mdo las kyang / gang gis 'dren pa nges 'byung ba/ / dad pa theg pa'i mchog yin te/ / de'i phyir blo dang ldan pa'i mis/ / dad pa'i rjes su 'brang ba bsten/ / ma dad pa yi mi dag la/ / dkar po'i chos rnams mi skye ste/ / sa bon me yis tshig pa las/ / myu gu sngon po ji bzhin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Along the same lines, the noble Sūtra on Ten Qualities (Daśa-dharmaka-sūtra) says: Faith is the highest Way By which the Guides go out of cyclic existence. Therefore, an intelligent person Should practice by following faith. In people with no faith Bright qualities[9] do not grow,[xiv] Just as a green sprout Never grows from seeds burned by fire.

de bas ni 'phags pa rgya cher rol pa'i mdo las kyang / kun dga' bo dad pa la sbyor bar bya ste/ 'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa la gsol ba 'debs pa'o zhes bstan to/ / de skad du/ seng ges zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / dad pas mi khom spang bar 'gyur/ /zhes bka' stsal pa yin no/ /

In the noble Detailed Explanation of the Play (Lalita-vistara) Sūtra, we are informed:[10] “Ānanda, one should practice with faith. This is what the Tathāgata directs.” Moreover, in the Inquiry of Siṃha Sūtra (Siṃha-paripṛcchā), the Buddha said: “By faith, one abandons both good and bad rebirths.”

de ltar dad pa'i rtsa ba brtan par byas la/ bsod nams thams cad sdud pa'i phyir na byang chub kyi sems brtan par bya'o/ / ji skad du seng ges zhus pa las/ bcom ldan 'das la rgyal bu seng ges zhus pa/ chos rnams thams cad bsdu ba ni/ / chos gang gis ni thob par 'gyur/ / gang dang gang du skyes pa der/ / sems can rnams ni dga' ba 'thob/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ sems can thams cad thar bya'i phyir/ / byang chub don du sems btud pa/ / des ni chos rnams bsdu ba 'thob/ / des ni dga' ba thob par 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Thus, having made the root of faith stable, the Awakening Mind should be made stable, because it is the sum of all forms of goodness. So, for example, in the noble Inquiry of Siṃha Sūtra, the Prince Siṃha asked the Blessed One: What is the one action That sums up all virtues, So as to be dear to sentient beings Wherever you are born? The Blessed One replied: In order to set free all sentient beings, You should subdue the mind, with Awakening as goal. This is the sum of all virtues. [6] In this way, you will be held dear.

de skad du/ 'phags pa sdong po bkod pa'i mdo las kyang / rigs kyi bu byang chub kyi sems ni sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad kyi sa bon lta bu'o/ / 'gro ba thams cad kyi chos dkar po rnam par 'phel bar byed pas zhing lta bu'o/ / 'jig rten thams cad rten pas sa lta bu'o zhes bya ba nas/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad yongs su srung bas pha lta bu'o zhes bya ba'i bar dang /

Also, the noble Array of Stalks Sūtra praises the Awakening Mind:[11] Noble sir, the Awakening Mind is the seed of all the qualities of a Buddha. It is a field in which all the bright qualities of living beings can grow. Like the earth, it supports the whole world … Like a father, it protects all Bodhisattvas
de bzhin du sbyar te

dbul ba thams cad yang dag par gcod pas rnam thos kyi bu lta bu'o/ / don thams cad yang dag par sgrub pas yid bzhin gyi nor bu'i rgyal po lta bu'o/ / bsam pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pas bum pa bzang po lta bu'o/ / nyon mongs pa'i dgra pham par bya ba la mdung thung lta bu'o/ / tshul bzhin ma yin pa yid la byed pa 'gebs pas go cha lta bu'o/ / nyon mongs pa'i mgo lhung bar byed pas ral gri lta bu'o/ / nyon mongs pa'i shing gcod pas sta re lta bu'o/ / 'tshe ba thams cad las skyob pas mtshon cha lta bu'o/ / 'khor ba'i chu'i nang na gnas pa steng du 'byin pas mchil pa lta bu'o/ / sgrib pa dang khebs pa'i rtsa ba thams cad rnam par 'thor bas rlung gi dkyil 'khor lta bu'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang smon lam thams cad bsdus pa'i phyir mdor bstan pa lta bu'o/ / lha dang mi dang lha ma yin du bcas pa'i 'jig rten la mchod rten lta bu ste/ rigs kyi bu de ltar byang chub kyi sems ni yon tan de dag dang / yon tan gyi bye brag tshad med pa gzhan dang yang ldan no zhes brjod do/ /

Like the god of wealth, it puts an end to all poverty. Like the king of wish-fulfilling gems, it causes all goals to be fully accomplished. Like the magic wishing vase, it causes all intentions to be fulfilled. Like power,[xv] it defeats the enemy, the reactive emotions. Like armor, it shields against inappropriately directed attention. Like a sword, it cuts off the heads of the reactive emotions. Like an axe, it cuts down the tree of the reactive emotions. Like a weapon, it protects against all harms. Like a fish-hook, it takes you up out of the water of cyclic existence. Like a tornado, it tears up and scatters the grass of the distortions and hindrances to attention. Like a summary, it collects together all of a bodhisattva’s practices and aspirations. It is like a holy shrine for the worlds of gods, humans, and titans. Noble sir, the Awakening Mind is endowed with these advantages, And it also has innumerable other special advantages and virtues.

so so'i skye bo la yang byang chub kyi sems skye ste/ 'di tshig tsam ni ma yin no zhes bya bar ji ltar shes she na/ mdo sde du ma mthong ba las te/ re zhig 'phags pa dri ma med par grags pas bstan pa las/ 'jig tshogs la lta ba ri rab dang mnyam pa dran nas byang chub kyi sems skye zhing de las sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams rnam par skye'o zhes ji skad du bstan pa dang / dkon mchog za ma tog gi mdo las kyang / / so so'i skye bo la yang byang chub sems dpa' zhes bya bar shes te/ ji skad du 'jam dpal 'di lta ste dper na ka la bing+ka'i phru gu sgo nga'i sbubs kyi nang na 'dug pa sgo nga ma brtol zhing sbubs nas ma byung yang ka la ping ka'i sgra nyid du 'byin to/ / 'jam dpal de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' ma rig pa'i sgo nga'i sbubs kyi nang na 'dug pa bdag tu lta ba ma brtol zhing khams gsum las ma byung yang sangs rgyas kyi sgra 'di lta ste/ stong pa nyid dang mtshan ma med pa dang smon pa med pa'i sgra 'byin to zhes gsungs so/ / chos thams cad 'byung ba med par bstan pa las kyang / byang chub sems dpa' rgyal ba'i blo gros la sas bar mthongs phye nas de 'chi ba'i dus byas pa dang sems can dmyal ba chen por ltung ste/ de ni stong pa nyid la ma dad cing stong pa nyid du smra ba la khong khro ba byas pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

When an ordinary person arouses the Awakening Mind, how do we know that this [intention] is not mere words?[12] Because many scriptures teach that it is not. For example, we are taught in the Holy Teaching of Vimalakīrti (Vimalakīrti-nirdeśa): “When someone who has a false view of a real self the size of Mt. Meru arouses the Awakening Mind, because of that, the qualities of a Buddha grow in that person.”[13] And the Casket of Jewels Sūtra (Ratna-karaṇḍa-sūtra) declares, “An ordinary person [can] also be a bodhisattva.” As the text says, Mañjuśrī,[14] it’s like this: for example, a baby sparrow that is still inside the enclosed space of the egg, has not broken through the egg, and has not come out from within, but it still produces the call of the sparrow. Mañjuśrī, in the same way, a bodhisattva who is still inside the enclosed space of the egg of ignorance, who has not broken through the view of self, and who has not come out of the threefold world, lets loose the call of the Buddhas, which is this: emptiness, no characteristics, and no aspirations.[15] [7] Also, the Teaching on the Non-Origination of Everything (Sarva-dharma-apravṛtti-nirdeśa) says: “And the earth split open and swallowed the bodhisattva Jayamati, who died and fell down into the Great Hell, for he did not have confidence in emptiness, and he got angry at those teaching emptiness.”[16]

nges pa dang ma nges pa la 'jug pa'i phyag rgya'i mdo las kyang / / phyugs kyi shing rta lta bus 'gro ba'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste dper na skyes bu la la zhig sangs rgyas kyi zhing lnga'i rdul phra rab kyi rdul snyed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams 'da' bar 'dod nas/ des phyugs kyi shing rta la zhon te lam du zhugs nas/ de yun ring pos lam ring por dpag tshad brgyar phyin pa las/ de der rlung gi dkyil 'khor chen pos bzlog nas dpag tshad khrir ded de phyir phul na skyes bu des phyugs kyi shing rtas 'jig rten gyi khams de dag 'da' ba'am bskal pa las brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bskal par yang 'jig rten gyi khams gcig kyang 'da' bar nus sam gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags so/ /

As the Sūtra on the Postures that Do or Do Not Certainly Lead to Awakening (Niyata-aniyata-avatāra-mudrā-sūtra) says,[xvi] The Blessed One asked, “How is a bodhisattva like someone who goes in an ox-cart? For example, suppose someone wanted to travel through as many worlds as there are atoms in five Buddha-fields. He got into an ox-cart and began to follow the road. After a long time, he traveled a long distance, one hundred leagues.[17] A huge tornado struck him there and pulled him back eighty thousand[xvii] leagues. In this way, would it be possible for that man to travel through those worlds in that ox-cart? In fact, during innumerable aeons followed by innumerable aeons, would he be able to travel through even one single world?” Mañjuśrī replied, “No indeed, Blessed One.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ de bzhin du gang la la zhig gis byang chub tu sems bskyed la theg pa chen po mi 'dzin mi klog par/ nyan thos kyi theg pa pa rnams la brten cing de dag dang lhan cig tu sten par byed nyan thos kyi theg pa klog cing kha ton byed dpyod cing khong du chud par byed la/ gzhan dag kyang klog tu 'jug pa nas/ khong du chud par byed pa'i bar du byed pa ni/ de ni des shes rab rtul por 'gyur te/ bla na med pa'i ye shes kyi lam nas slar drangs nas phyir ldog go/ / byang chub sems dpa' 'di'i byang chub kyi sems bsgoms pa las byung ba'i shes rab kyi dbang po dang / shes rab kyi mig gang yin pa de yang rtul por 'gyur zhing nyams par byed de 'di ni phyugs kyi shing rta lta bus 'gro ba'i byang chub sems dpa'o zhes bshad do/ /

The Blessed One said, “In the same way, Mañjuśrī, suppose someone arouses the Awakening Mind, but then doesn’t practice and doesn’t study the Great Way, but associates with those who follow the Way of the Disciples and serves them with respectful offerings. He studies the Way of the Disciples, recites its teachings, analyzes them, and gains an understanding of them. He also teaches the meaning of these teachings to others and helps them to understand. Because of that, his discernment becomes dull. He is pulled backwards from the path to unsurpassed pristine awareness. Whatever faculty of discernment, and whatever eye of discernment, that bodhisattva has gained as a result of meditating on Awakening,[xviii] becomes dull and deteriorates. In this way, a bodhisattva is like someone who goes in an ox-cart.”

de bas na de ltar de dag gi stong pa nyid la mos pa dang theg pa chen po la mngon par dga' ba ni/ mos pas spyod pa yongs su ma rdzogs pa la yang sbyar bar snang na/ mos pa rab la spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la lta ci zhig smos/ de ni dkon mchog sprin las byis pa'i spyod pa dang log par 'jug pa thams cad las 'das par brjod cing / ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs dang rnam par thar pa dang mngon par shes pa dang rig pa grangs med pas rnam par rol pa/ chos mtha' yas pa la dga' zhing mos pas zang zing med pa phyi ma'i mtha'i bskal pa'i mur thug par rnam par mi rtog cing lhun gyis grub pa'i dga' ba'i shugs kyis snang ba thob pa bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du ma dpag tu med par theg pa chen po la zhugs pa'i bsgom pa sna tshogs yongs su rdzogs pa gzhan gyi don gyi nan tan tshar phyin pa/ bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs mngon par bsgrub pa grub pa'i sngon gyi sbyor ba brgya stong phun sum tshogs par brjod do/ /

In this case, then, a bodhisattva has no confidence in emptiness, takes no delight in the Great Way, and does not practice with a confident mind. Forget about acting with confidence beyond measure! [Objection]: The Cloud of Jewels Sūtra (Ratna-megha) says:[18] They are beyond all foolish activities and calamities. They have easy mastery of innumerable forms of meditative absorption, mnemonic powers, freedoms, extraordinary ways of knowing, and forms of awareness. They take delight in endless teachings, and until the end of time, have no desire for material wealth. They have attained brightness through the power of non-conceptual, effortless bliss. They walk the Great Way for a thousand million billion endless aeons. They have fully completed various meditations and utterly devoted themselves to helping others. They have finished gathering the equipment of goodness and pristine awareness. They are perfectly endowed with a hundred thousand spiritual practices that they have already completed.

ci ste 'di drang ba'i don yin na/ ci'i phyir byang chub tu sems bskyed pa gzhan sa 'di la mi 'dod/ 'dir 'dod pa tsam gyis drang ba'i don du byed pa'i bye brag gi rtags kyang mi rnyed do/ / mos pas spyod pa chen po'i chos nyid du gsungs pa las kyang / mos pas spyod pa 'bring dang chung ngu'i rnam pa yang ci nas yod pa nyid du rtogs so/ /

[Reply]: Now, this passage is of provisional meaning. Why not accept at this stage that there are others who adopt the Awakening Mind? There’s no special sign that would make this passage be of definitive meaning just because we want it to be. The sūtra is talking about what it is really like to live your life with unlimited confidence. We know that there are also mediocre and inferior ways of living with confidence.

yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba'i mdo las/ ji skad du bcom ldan 'das byang chub tu sems bskyed pa su'i lags/ rgyal po chen po gang gis lhag pa'i bsam pa ma 'khrugs pa'o/ / gsol pa bcom ldan 'das su'i lhag pa'i bsam pa ma 'khrugs bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po gang gi snying rje chen po skye ba'o/ / gsol pa bcom ldan 'das su'i snying rje chen po skye/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po gang gi sems can thams cad la yongs su mi gtong ba'i sems skye ba'o/ / gsol pa bcom ldan 'das ji ltar sems can thams cad yongs su ma btang ba lags/ bka' stsal pa rgyal po chen po nam bdag bde ba btang ba yin no zhes gsungs pa'i dgongs pa ci zhig yin zhe na/ byang chub kyi sems tsam gyis chog par 'dzin pa rnams snying rje la dga' ba skyed pa'i phyir 'di gsungs te/ dper na gang la rnal 'byor med pa de dag ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa la rab tu byung ba ma yin no zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / de bzhin du 'dir yang byang chub kyi sems gzhan smad par rig par bya'i/ byang chub kyi sems rnam pa gzhan du mi skye ba ni ma yin no/ /

[8] [Objection]: In that case, what is the meaning of the following passage from the Sūtra on the Mysteries of the Tathāgata (Tathāgata-guhya-sūtra)? It reads: THE KING SAID: “Blessed One, who arouses the Awakening Mind?” THE BUDDHA REPLIED: “Your Majesty, whoever has undisturbed higher intention.” “Blessed One, who has undisturbed higher intention?” “Your Majesty, whoever arouses great compassion.” “Blessed One, who arouses great compassion?” THE BLESSED ONE REPLIED: “Your Majesty, whoever does not abandon all sentient beings.” “Blessed One, how does one not abandon all sentient beings?” “Your Majesty, when one abandons one’s own happiness.” [Reply]: The sūtra says this in order to produce joy in compassion among those who are satisfied with the Awakening Mind alone. [This passage should be interpreted] like the passage that says “Those who are not ordained in the Tathāgata’s discipline have no renunciation.”[19] In the same way also here, we should understand the text as criticizing what is contrary to the Awakening Mind. It doesn’t mean that the Awakening Mind never arises in any other case.

ji skad du chos bcu pa'i mdo las/ rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' rigs la gnas pa byang chub tu sems ma bskyed na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'am de bzhin gshegs pa'i nyan thos kyis bskul zhing skyo bar byas/ yang dag par 'dzin du bcug ste bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni byang chub kyi sems la mos pa'i rgyu dang po'o/ / rdzogs pa'i byang chub bam byang chub kyi sems kyi bsngags pa brjod pa thos nas/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni rgyu gnyis pa'o/ / sems can mgon med pa dang skyabs med pa dang dpung gnyen med pa rnams mthong nas snying rje'i sems nye bar gzhag ste bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni rgyu gsum pa'o/ / des de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog yongs su rdzogs pa mthong nas dga' ba bskyed de bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni rgyu bzhi pa'o zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

As the Sūtra on the Ten Qualities says: Noble sir, suppose someone who belongs to the family of the bodhisattvas has not yet aroused the Awakening Mind. The Tathāgata, or a disciple of the Tathāgata, reproves him, teaches him, and inspires him. He arouses his mind for highest genuine full Awakening. This is the first cause for arousing the Awakening Mind. He hears words of praise,[xix] either of full Awakening or of the Awakening Mind. He arouses his mind for highest genuine full Awakening. This is the second cause. When he sees sentient beings who have no protector, no shelter, no refuge, no island, and {no friend to help,} he feels compassion.[xx] He arouses his mind to go as far as highest genuine full Awakening. This is the third cause. When he sees that the Tathāgata is[xxi] perfect in every way, he feels joy. He arouses his mind for highest genuine full Awakening. This is the fourth cause.

byang chub kyi sems de ni rnam pa gnyis te/ byang chub tu smon pa'i sems dang byang chub tu chas pa'i sems so/ / ji skad du sdong po bkod pa'i mdo las/ rigs kyi bu sems can gang dag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu smon pa de dag ni sems can gyi khams na dkon no/ / de bas kyang gang dag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu chas pa'i sems can de dag ni shin tu dkon no zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / de la byang chub tu smon pa'i sems ni ngas sangs rgyas su 'gyur bar bya'o zhes sems smon pa las skyes pa yin te/ 'phags pa dpa' bar 'gro ba'i mdo las/ g.yo byas te byang chub kyi sems bskyed pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi rgyur gsungs na dge ba sna 'ga' byas te sems bskyed pa lta ci smos zhes gsungs so/ /

The Awakening Mind is of two types: the mind aspiring to Awakening, and the mind moving toward Awakening. As the noble Array of Stalks Sūtra says, “Noble sir, in the world of sentient beings, those who aspire in their minds to highest genuine full Awakening are rare. Even rarer are those sentient beings who have set out toward highest genuine full Awakening.” Here the mind aspiring to Awakening, which is the thought “I will become a Buddha,” arises from an aspiration prayer. [9] The Sūtra of Heroic Progress (Śūraṅgama-sūtra) says[20] that even when one has just committed dishonesty, arousing the Awakening Mind is said to be a cause of Buddhahood. How much more so if one has just done even a small wholesome action?

ji skad du bskal pa bzang po'i mdo las/ de bzhin gshegs pa dbyangs byin zhes bya ba la de bzhin gshegs pa skar ma'i rgyal po zhes bya ba ba lang rdzir gyur pas ba gu la'i me tog phul nas dang po byang chub tu sems bskyed do/ / de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa klog gi sgron ma zhes bya ba la de bzhin gshegs pa grags pa thag par gyur pas ras kyi kha tshar phul te/ dang po byang chub tu sems bskyed do/ / de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa 'od mtha' yas zhes bya ba la de bzhin gshegs pa 'od 'phro can grong khyer gyi sprang por gyur pas rtsa'i sgron ma phul te dang po byang chub tu sems bskyed do/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnam par gnon brten zhes bya ba la de bzhin gshegs pa thub dka' shing thun du gyur pas so shing phul te dang po byang chub tu sems bskyed do/ / de bzhin gshegs pa 'jam dpal grags zhes bya ba la de bzhin gshegs pa yon tan rgyal mtshan sman pa'i rgyal por gyur pas skyu ru ra cig phul nas dang po byang chub tu sems bskyed do zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

As the Sūtra on the Fortunate Aeon (Bhadra-kalpika-sūtra) says, The Tathāgata known as Nakṣatrarāja,[21] who was a cowherd at the time, first aroused the Awakening Mind after he gave a betel leaf[xxii] to the Tathāgata known as Ghoṣadatta.[22] In the same way, the Tathāgata known as Yaśas,[23] who was a weaver[xxiii] at the time, first aroused the Awakening Mind after he gave a fringe of cloth to the Tathāgata known as Vidyutpradīpa.[24] In the same way, the Tathāgata known as Arcismant,[25] who was dependent on the city for alms[xxiv] at the time, first aroused the Awakening Mind after he gave a reed lamp to the Tathāgata known as Anantaprabha.[26] In the same way, the Tathāgata known as Duṣpradharṣa,[27] who was a woodcutter at the time, first aroused the Awakening Mind after he gave a tooth-stick to the Tathāgata known as Dṛdha-vikrama.[28][xxv]

des kyang 'khor ba'i bde ba mtha' yas pa bskyed pa'i phyir byang chub kyi sems spyod pa dang bral ba la yang brnyas par mi bya ste/ ji skad du 'phags pa byams pa'i rnam par thar pa las/ rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste dper na rdo rje rin po che ni chag kyang / gser gyi rgyan khyad par du 'phags pa thams cad zil gyis gnon cing rdo rje rin po che'i ming yang mi 'dor la dbul ba thams cad kyang rnam par zlog go/ / rigs kyi bu de bzhin du thams cad mkhyen par sems bskyed pa'i rdo rje rin po che nan tan dang bral yang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi yon tan gyi gser gyi rgyan thams cad zil gyis gnon cing byang chub sems dpa'i ming yang mi 'dor la 'khor ba'i dbul ba thams cad kyang rnam par zlog go zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

You should not despise the Awakening Mind even if it is not accompanied by practice, because it still produces endless happiness within cyclic existence. This is described in the noble Spiritual Biography of Maitreya (Maitreya-vimokṣa): Noble sir, for example, a diamond gem, even if it is broken, is still superior to golden ornaments and overpowers them with brilliance, and is still called a “diamond gem,” and removes all poverty. In just the same way, noble sir, the diamond gem of arousing the mind to complete knowing, even when divided from earnest practice, outshines the golden ornaments that are the abilities of the Disciples and Solitary Sages, and is still called “Awakening Mind,” and removes all the poverty of cyclic existence.

'di las kyang spyod pa dang mi ldan yang byang chub kyi sems ni phan par 'gyur bar shes par bya ste/ gang gi phyir rgyal po la gdams pa'i mdo las/ rgyal po chen po 'di ltar khyod ni bya ba mang byed pa mang ste/ nyin mtshan du thams cad du thams cad rnam pa thams cad du thams cad sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa la yang bslab pa nas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i bar la bslab par mi nus te/ de bas na rgyal po chen po khyod yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub la 'dun pa dang dad pa dang don du gnyer ba dang smon pa/ 'gro yang rung 'greng yang rung 'dug kyang rung nyal yang rung sad kyang rung za yang rung 'thung yang rung rtag par rgyun du dran par gyis la yid la zung ste sgoms shig / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang / 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dang so so'i skye bo thams cad dang bdag gi 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar byung ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad bsdus shing gzhal te rtsis la rjes su yi rang bar gyis shig / rjes su yi rang ba'i mchog nas/ nam mkha' dang 'dra ba dang / mya ngan las 'das pa dang / mtshungs pa'i bar gyis rjes su yi rang bar gyis shig / rjes su yi rang nas sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad la mchod pa bya bar phul cig / phul nas sems can thams cad dang thun mong du gyis shig / de nas sems can thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa'i bar du thob par 'gyur ba dang sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur bar nyin gcig bzhin du dus gsum du bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sngos shig / rgyal po chen po khyod de ltar zhugs na rgyal srid kyang byed la rgyal po'i bya ba yang nyams par mi 'gyur zhing / byang chub kyi tshogs kyang yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

We can also know from the following that the Awakening Mind is beneficial even without practice. The Sūtra of Advice to a King (Rāja-avavādaka Sūtra) says: [10] Your Majesty, since you are busy and have much to do, you are not able wherever you are, in every respect, at all times, and as regards everything, to train in the perfection of generosity, and so on up to: you are not able to train {day and night} in the perfection of wisdom. Therefore, Your Majesty, [arouse] the motivation, the faith, and the aspiration for genuine full Awakening, and whether you are walking, standing, seated, or lying down, and also while waking up, eating, or drinking, constantly and continuously remember, pay attention to, and meditate on them! Reflect on all the wholesome actions of all the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Solitary Sages, Noble Disciples, ordinary people, and yourself, whether past, present, or future; consider them all together, examine them, and then rejoice in them. Rejoice with the highest rejoicing, as vast as the sky, as vast as Nirvāṇa. Then, make offerings to all Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Solitary Sages, and Noble Disciples. Once you have made offerings, make them common to all sentient beings. Then, three times every day, for the sake of highest genuine full Awakening, dedicate the goodness to all sentient beings, for them to attain to complete knowing and be filled with all the qualities of the Buddhas. Your Majesty, if you practice in this way, you will rule, you will not neglect your royal duties, and you will also complete the equipment for Awakening.

mdo sde de nyid las de'i rnam par smin pa yang gsungs pa ni/ rgyal po chen po khyod yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi sems kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i las kyi rnam par smin pas/ lan du mar lha'i nang du skyes lan du mar mi'i nang du skyes te/ lha dang mir skyes pa na thams cad du yang dbang po byed par gyur kyang / da dung rgyal po chen po khyod kyi yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi sems kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i las la bri ba'am/ gang bar mi mngon no/ / de bzhin du sbyar te 'on kyang rgyal po chen po bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi sems gcig gis kyang / sems can thams cad bsgral bar dmigs pa dang / sems can thams cad dgrol bar dmigs pa dang / sems can thams cad dbugs dbyung bar dmigs pa dang / sems can thams cad yongs su mya ngan las bzla bar dmigs pa'i phyir/ dge ba'i rtsa ba grangs med dpag tu med pa sogs par 'gyur na/ gang de ltar mang du byed pa lta ci smos zhes bya ba yin no/ / byang chub kyi sems de yang gzugs kyi sku mthong ba las skyes par de las sngon gyi rtogs pa brjod pa las 'byung ste/ de lta na re zhig smon pa byang chub kyi sems su rig par bya'o/ / ca sar ma chud pa la yang byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa'i dbang du bya ba yod dam med ces bya ba 'di brjod par bya'o zhe na yod par rig par bya ste/ nam mkha'i snying po'i mdo las/ rnyed pa dang bkur sti'i rgyu las rtsa ba'i ltung bar gsungs pa'i phyir/ sa bcu pa'i mdo las ni sa dang po la/ bdag gis sems can 'di dag la yo byad mang po thams cad nye bar sbyin no snyam pa ma gtogs par su las kyang bkur sti ci yang mi 'dod do zhes bstan to/ / de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i sa rab tu dga' ba la mi g.yo ba'i tshul gyis legs par gnas pa yin no zhes gsungs pa dang / yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su nges shing rdzogs pa'i byang chub la shin du gzhol ba yin no zhes kyang gsungs so/ / nam mkha'i snying po'i mdo las kyang / nyan thos kyi theg pa yang de la med na theg pa chen po lta ga la yod ces gsungs la/

The same scripture says what that practice matures into: Your Majesty, through what that Mind of genuine full Awakening, which is wholesome, matures into, you were born many hundreds of[xxvi] times among the gods. You were born many hundreds of times among humans. And in all of your divine and human births, you exercise political power. Your Majesty, this wholesome action of yours, which is the Mind of genuine full Awakening, shows no incompleteness or deficiency. Moreover, Your Majesty, even one single thought of genuine full Awakening, since it is a basis for the salvation of all beings, since it is a basis for the liberation of all beings, since it is a basis for encouraging all beings, since it is a basis for all beings to reach Nirvāṇa, gives rise to an immeasurable, incalculable quantity of what is wholesome. How much more so if one has many such thoughts! The Awakening Mind is also the cause of seeing the physical body of the Buddha. The Pūrvāvadāna teaches that we should understand this to be the Awakening Mind as aspiration. [11] But the following still needs to be explained: Can “someone who has the Bodhisattva vow” refer to a person who hasn’t yet reached the Stages, or not?[29] We should understand that it can, because it says in the Ākāśagarbha Sūtra that “taking wealth and respect as your goal is a root downfall.” But in the Sūtra on the Ten Stages (Daśabhūmika Sūtra),[30] the first Stage is described as follows:[31] “He does not wish for any respect from anyone, thinking instead ‘I should honor all sentient beings with all of the various forms of assistance.’ ” In the same way, the text says “One is well established in the [first] bodhisattva Stage, the Joyous, through the practice of not being moved.” And again it says, “He definitely belongs to the family of the Tathāgatas, having full Awakening as his chief goal.”[32] The Ākāśagarbha Sūtra also says, “If he does not have the Way of the Disciples, how can he have the Great Way?”

de bzhin du/ 'phags pa drag shul can gyis zhus par/ ser snas yongs su dkris pa la yang bslab pa'i gnas bcas pa dang rab tu dga' ba'i sa la bdag tu 'du shes pa dang bral bas bdag la chags pa'ang med na/ yo byad thams cad la chags pa lta ga la yod ces gsungs so/ / de bzhin du mgo la sogs pa sbyin pa yang gsungs te/ de lta bu la sogs pa mdo sde dag tu sar ma chud pa la bslab pa bcas par snang ngo / / gang du byang chub sems dpa'i dbang du byas nas phyir bstan pa der yang goms par byar mi rung ba'am/ dgag pa'i ngag gis byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pas bslab par mi bya bar 'gyur te/ de gnyis med na ni thams cad la bslab par bya'o/ /

In the same way, the noble Inquiry of Ugra (Ugradatta-paripṛcchā) says: “Someone who is ensnared by avarice[xxvii] can also have the training precepts that are taught.” But it is taught, about the [Stage known as the] Joyous: “Since one no longer has any conception of a self, there is no self-love. How could there be any attachment to property?”[33] Therefore, it says about such people that they give away their heads and the like. From these and other passages in the scriptures, we see that someone who has not yet entered the Stages can be included in the training.[xxviii] As for the distinctive instructions for bodhisattvas, a beginning bodhisattva should not attempt to train in whatever cannot be developed by repeated practice or is prohibited. Where these two conditions don’t apply, you should train in everything.

de la yang bslab pa gcig sgrub pa na bslab pa gzhan bsrung ma nus kyang ltung bar mi 'gyur te/ de skad du 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa'i mdo las/ sbyin pa'i dus na tshul khrims la brtul ba btang snyoms la sogs pa rgya cher gsungs pa yin no/ / 'di la lhod par yang mi bya ste/ lhag ma gzhan la mi sgrub pa yang ma yin gyi/ ci nus ci 'os su de bzhin nyid du sgrub po zhes sa bcu pa'i mdo las gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / sdom pa 'di ni bud med nyon mongs pa chung ngu sems byang chub tu mos pa la'ang 'grub ste/ gang gi phyir byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las/ shA ri'i bu chos bzhi dang ldan na byang chub sems dpa'i bden par smra ba yin no zhes bya ba nas brtsams te/ shA ri'i bu 'di la rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed nas/ dge ba'i chos yongs su btsal ba'i don du brtson 'grus brtsams te gnas pa dang zhes gsungs pa yin no/ / 'di las brtsams te lung nod pa thams cad dang / sdom pa bzung ba yang byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i gnas la goms pa lhur byed pa sdom pa dang ldan pa las bya ste/ de ltar byas na de bslab pa las 'das na rab tu ngo mtshar bar 'gyur zhes bla ma la bslus par dogs pa'i 'jigs pa skye ba'am de la nan tan bya mi dgos par dga' ba dang gus pas grub par 'gyur ro/ /

On this topic, if someone is training in and learning one thing, not training in and not repeatedly practicing something else would not be a downfall. As the noble Akṣayamati Sūtra says:[34] “At the time of giving, one is indifferent to developing moral discipline.” And so on. You shouldn’t slack off here, and it’s not that you don’t practice the rest of the training. “Accomplish what you can, and what is appropriate,” is what the Sūtra on the Ten Stages says. [12] This vow can also be taken by women whose reactive emotions are weak and whose minds aspire to Awakening. For the Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas, in the passage that begins “Śāriputra, those bodhisattvas who have four qualities are truthful,” says the following: “On this topic, Śāriputra, a gentleman or lady arouses the Mind for highest genuine full Awakening, begins to practice perseverance, and lives in the search for wholesome states.” And so on; the whole teaching follows. Someone who has a vow, and is putting the repeated practice of the training precepts first, should keep that vow. For if you break the vow, you feel deeply ashamed and also afraid of lying to your spiritual teacher. Through love and devotion, you can keep your vows without effort.[xxix] This is a general characteristic of vows.[xxx]

de bas na byang chub sems dpa' rnams de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyan sngar bslab pa 'di'i nang nas/ bslab pa gang yang rung ba grub par 'dod pas yang dag par len par byed do/ / de ltar na 'di ni sdom pa'i spyi'i chos yin no/ / yang na de lta bu'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen med na phyogs bcu na bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams mngon du bsgoms nas/ sdom pa dang bdag gi stobs dang yang sbyar nas blang ste/ de ltar ma yin na sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang lhar bcas pa'i 'jig rten bslus par 'gyur ro/ / gang gi phyir dam pa'i chos dran pa nye bar gzhag pa'i mdo las/ cung zad cig bsams nas mi sbyin pa ni yi dwags su skye la/ dam bcas nas mi sbyin pa ni sems can dmyal bar 'gro'o zhes gsungs na/ 'gro ba ma lus pa'i bla na med pa'i don dam bcas nas sgrub par mi byed pa lta ci smos/ de bas na chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las kyang / rigs kyi bu byang chub sems dpa' bden pa lhur byed par 'gyur bar bya ste/ rigs kyi bu bden pa yang dag par brjod pa ni chos yang dag par brjod pa'o/ / rigs kyi bu de la bden pa gang zhe na/ gang byang chub sems dpa' bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed nas sems de srog gi phyir yang mi gtong zhing / sems can rnams la yang log par mi byed pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i bden pa'o/ / gang byang chub sems dpa' bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed la sems de phyis yongs su gtong zhing / sems can rnams la'ang log par byed pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i rdzun du smra ba tha ma yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

Hence bodhisattvas, in the presence of the Tathāgatas, wishing to complete the training, correctly take up one of the many forms of training {that is suitable for them.} But if you don’t have a spiritual teacher, you can visualize being in the presence of the Buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions, and then take the vow through your own power. If you then don’t keep it, you have broken your word to all the Buddhas and bodhisattvas, and to the world with its gods. For the Sūtra on the Application of Mindfulness to the Holy Dharma (Sad-dharma-smṛtyupasthāna-sūtra) says: “Someone who thinks about giving even a little bit and then doesn’t give, it is said, will be reborn as a hungry ghost. Someone who declares the intention to give and then doesn’t give will be reborn in the hells. What need even to speak of someone who has promised the highest benefit to all living beings without exception, and then does not actually keep that promise!” Now, as the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together (Dharma-saṃgīti-sūtra) says: Noble sir, a bodhisattva should practice with devotion to truth. The recitation of the Dharma, noble sir, is the recitation of truth. Which truth, noble sir? When a bodhisattva arouses his mind for highest genuine full Awakening, and then does not abandon that intention, even for the sake of his life, and never does wrong to sentient beings, this is a bodhisattva’s truth. But when a bodhisattva has aroused his mind for highest genuine full Awakening, and later abandons that intention and does wrong to sentient beings, this, for that bodhisattva, is an abject lie.

'phags pa blo gros rgya mtsho'i mdo las kyang / blo gros rgya mtsho 'di lta ste dper na rgyal po'am rgyal po'i blon po chen pos grong khyer gyi skye bo thams cad sang zan sbyin no zhes mgron du bos nas yal bar dor te/ bza' ba dang btung ba mi sbyar nas des skye ba'i tshogs de dag thams cad bslus pa yin te/ de dag kyang bza' ba dang btung ba ma thob pas 'phya zhing slar 'dong ba de bzhin du blo gros rgya mtsho byang chub sems dpa' ma rgal ba bsgral ba dang / ma grol ba dgrol ba dang dbugs ma phyin pa dbugs dbyung ba dang yongs su mya ngan las ma 'das pa yongs su mya ngan las bzla ba'i phyir sems can thams cad la dbugs phyung la/ mang du thos pa dang de las gzhan pa dge ba byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos rnams la yang brtson par mi byed na/ byang chub sems dpa' de ni ji skad smras pa de bzhin du byed pa ma yin te/ lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten la slu ba yin no/ / de lta bu sngon sangs rgyas mthong ba'i lha rnams kyis mthong na 'phya zhing gzhogs 'phyas byed la rnam par smod de/ gang dag mchod sbyin bya bar dam bcas pa nyams 'og tu chud par byed pa'i mchod sbyin gyi bdag po de dag ni dkon no/ / blo gros rgya mtsho de lta bas na tshig gang gis lha dang mi dang lha ma yin du bcas pa'i 'jig rten slu bar 'gyur ba'i tshig de lta bu byang chub sems dpas smra bar mi bya'o/ /

The noble Sāgaramati Sūtra also teaches: [13] Sāgaramati,[35] for example, it might happen that either a king or a king’s chief minister would invite all the people of the city to a feast tomorrow, but neglect the preparations and fail to provide food and drink, thereby deceiving all those people. In such a case, not getting anything to eat or drink, they would go away, jeering. In the same way, Sāgaramati, a bodhisattva who does not apply himself to extensive study, and moreover, does not cultivate those virtues that are wholesome and conducive to Awakening, for the sake of bringing over those who have not crossed over, setting free those who are not free, and encouraging all those who are discouraged,[xxxi]—that bodhisattva is lying to the world, including the gods. Thus, the deities who have seen previous Buddhas criticize and ridicule him. It is rare for sacrificial patrons who have announced a great sacrifice to give it up.[xxxii] Therefore, Sāgaramati, a bodhisattva should not say anything by which he would lie to the world, including the gods, humans, and titans.

blo gros rgya mtsho gzhan yang gang la la zhig gis/ byang chub sems dpa' gang la chos kyi don bya bar gsol ba btab pa de la byang chub sems dpa' kho bos khyod kyis chos kyi don 'di yongs su thob par bya'o/ / zhes tshig smras par gyur na/ byang chub sems dpas de la lus ni yongs su gtang bar bya'i sems can slu bar ni mi bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Moreover, Sāgaramati, someone might ask the bodhisattva to confer some benefit that is in accordance with the teachings. In this case, the bodhisattva should not lie; he should do what he has promised, even to the extent of giving away his own body.

de bas na rang gi mthu dang sbyar te dge ba'i rtsa ba gcig tsam yang yang dag par blangs la bsrung bar bya ste/ 'phags pa sa'i snying po'i mdo las ji skad du/ dge ba'i lam bcu po 'di dag gis sangs rgyas su 'gyur gyi gang gis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du tha na dge ba'i las kyi lam gcig tsam yang mi srung la/ 'on kyang tshig 'di skad du nga ni theg pa chen po pa ste nga bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tshol lo zhes zer na/ gang zag de ni shin tu tshul 'chos pa rdzun chen po smra ba/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das thams cad kyi spyan sngar 'jig rten la slu bar byed pa chad par smra ba ste/ de rmongs bzhin du 'chi ba'i dus byed cing log par ltung bar 'gro'o zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Therefore, once you have done even one wholesome action, you should protect it to the extent of your ability. As the noble Kṣitigarbha Sūtra says,[36] Through these ten wholesome courses of action, one becomes a Buddha. On the other hand, anyone who does not protect even one of these wholesome courses of action for as long as he lives, but also claims “I am a practitioner of the Great Way; I seek highest genuine full Awakening”—that person is a consummate rogue, a big liar, someone who lies in the presence of all the Blessed Ones, a materialist. He will die in ignorance; he will fall to the lower realms.

dus ji srid du nus pa de srid du yang dge ba yang dag par blangs te gnas par bya ste/ 'di ni sman gyi bla bai DUr+ya 'od kyi rgyal po'i mdo las blta bar bya'o/ / sems can chen po gang de lta bu thos nas kyang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dka' ba shes rab kyis rtogs par byas nas/ skye bo ma lus pa sdug bsngal las bskyab par khur khyer bar spro ba des ni phyag bya ba dang mchod pa dang / sdig pa bshags pa dang / bsod nams la rjes su yi rang ba dang / sangs rgyas la bskul ba dang / gsol ba gdab pa dang / byang chub tu bsngo ba byas la/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen la gsol ba gdab ste/ de'i tshig gi rjes su brjod pa'am/ yang na bdag nyid kyis brjod pas/ slob dpon dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba zhes smos la/ ji ltar 'jam dpal gyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi yon tan bkod pa'i mdo las/ bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa 'jam dpal gyis sngon gyi tshe'i rtogs pa brjod pa las spyod pa dang ldan par byang chub tu sems bskyed pa de bzhin du sems bskyed par bya'o/ / des 'di skad ces/ /

For as much time as possible, you should practice the wholesome actions that you have taken up. About this, look in the Sūtra on King Bhaiṣajyaguru of the Lapis Lazuli Radiance (Bhaiṣajyaguru-vaiḍūrya-prabha-sūtra):[37] Great beings who, having heard of the bodhisattva’s way of life, and having understood with discernment how difficult it is, bravely take on the burden of saving all those who are suffering, should carry out reverence, offerings, confession of faults, rejoicing in the goodness of others, requesting the Buddhas to teach, imploring them [to remain in cyclic existence] and dedicating goodness to Awakening. Then, they should request [the vow] from a spiritual teacher, saying “Please pay attention, teacher; I am named thus,” and then repeat what that person says; or they should make the vow by themselves. Just as the Blessed One Mañjuśrī aroused the Awakening Mind and undertook the practices in the story of his previous birth in the Sūtra that is a Poetic Description of the Qualities of Mañjuśrī’s Buddha Field (Mañjuśrī-buddha-kṣetra-guṇa-vyūhā-alaṃkāra-sūtra), so in the same way they should arouse the Awakening Mind. For this is what he said:
'khor ba thog ma med pa yi/ / sngon gyi tha ma ji srid pa/ / de srid sems can phan don du/ / spyod pa dpag yas spyad par bgyi/ /
For as long as beginningless cyclic existence has lasted so far, I will carry out practices without limit for the welfare and benefit of sentient beings.
'jig rten mgon po'i spyan snga 'dir/ / byang chub mchog tu sems bskyed de/ / 'gro ba thams cad mgron gnyer nas/ / de dag dbul zhing phongs las dgrol/ /
[14] Here, in the presence of the Lord, I arouse the Mind of highest Awakening. I invite all living beings, and set them free from poverty and misery.
de ring phan chad gal te yang / / bdag gis 'dod chags sems bskyed nas/ / phyogs bcu dag na gang bzhugs pa'i/ / sangs rgyas thams cad bslus par 'gyur/ /
{From today onward, if I arouse a thought of attachment, I have lied to all the Buddhas who dwell in the ten directions.}
byang chub nam zhig thob bar du/ / tha ba'i sems dang gnod sems dang / / phrag dog dang ni ser sna yang / / de ring phan chad mi bya'o/ /
From today until I attain Awakening, I shall not give rise to Malice, hardheartedness, jealousy, or avarice.
tshangs pa'i spyod pa bdag gis spyad/ / sdig pa'i 'dod pa yongs su gtang / / tshul khrims sdom dang nges pa la/ / sangs rgyas rjes su bslab par bya/ /
I shall practice celibacy; I abandon wrongful desires. I shall be a student of the Buddhas; I vow to undertake moral discipline.
bdag 'dir byang chub ring tshul du/ / 'tshang rgyar mos shing spro ba med/ / phyi mthar thug gi bar du yang / / sems can gcig phyir spyad par bgyi/ /
I do not aspire, nor expect, to attain Awakening quickly. I shall stay to the utmost limit for the sake of a single sentient being.
tshad med bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i/ / sangs rgyas zhing ni sbyang bar bgyi/ / phyogs rnams bcu po thams cad du/ / bdag gi ming ni grags par bgyi/ /
I shall purify a field that can’t be measured or imagined. I shall make a name for myself that is renowned in the ten directions.
lus dang ngag gi las rnams kyang / / rnam pa kun du bdag gis sbyang / / yid kyi las kyang sbyang bar bgyi/ / mi dge'i las ni spyad mi bgyi/ / zhes brjod do/ /
I shall purify my words and deeds in every respect. I shall purify my thoughts. I shall do nothing that is wrong.

'di la dus thams cad du sdom pa bzung ba las tshe rabs gzhan du ltung ba 'byung ba'i dogs par yang mi bya ste/ mdo 'di nyid las mi 'khrugs pa'i smon lam snang ba'i phyir ro/ / de las 'di skad du/ ji ltar de bzhin gshegs pa mi 'khrugs pa de sngon byang chub sems dpar gyur pa na tshig 'di skad du/ gal te bdag tshe rabs thams cad du rab tu ma byung na bdag gis sangs rgyas thams cad bslus par 'gyur ro zhes brjod de/ shA ri'i bu byang chub sems dpa' mi 'khrugs pa'i rjes su bslab par bya'o/ / shA ri'i bu de ltar bslabs na byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po tshe rabs thams cad du rab tu 'byung ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa byung yang rung ma byung yang rung / gdon mi za bar khyim gyi gnas nas 'byung ngo / /

On this topic, one should not be afraid to take a vow that lasts for all time, concerned about downfalls that may happen in another life; for the Aspiration Prayer of Akṣobhya says:[38] When the Tathāgata Akṣobhya was still a bodhisattva, he said this: If in all my future births I am not ordained, I will have lied to the Blessed Ones, the Buddhas. Those whose nature is intelligent should purify One life through effort, But they will purify the rest of their lives With the understanding [gained in that way.][xxxiii] Thus, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva should become a student of Akṣobhya. A bodhisattva great being who trains in this way is ordained in all his lives. Whether a Tathāgata has arisen or not, that bodhisattva necessarily goes forth from the household life.
de ci'i phyir zhe na/ shA ri'i bu 'di ltar khyim gyi gnas nas mngon par 'byung ba 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi rnyed pa'i mchog go/ /
Why is this? Because, Śāriputra, going forth from the household life is the highest gain
de bzhin du sbyar te/
chung ma dang bu dang bu mo la de chags par mi 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /
for him there is no craving for wives, sons, or daughters.

ji ltar tshe rabs gzhan du nyes pa 'dir mi 'gyur ba de ltar ni 'di nyid du 'chad par 'gyur bas des na re zhig gzhag go/ / de ltar sdom pa yang dag par bzung ba la ltung ba'i mtshan nyid gang gis brjod pa'i dngos po bdag nyid kyis brtags te spong ba dang / ltung ba'i gzugs brnyan dang ltung ba ma yin pa'i gzugs brnyan la rmongs par mi 'gyur bar ltung ba spyi'i mtshan nyid brjod do/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems can thams cad kyi da ltar dang ma 'ongs pa'i sdug bsngal dang yid mi bde ba thams cad zhi bar bya ba dang / da ltar dang ma 'ongs pa'i bde ba dang yid bde ba thams cad bskyed pa'i phyir/ g.yo med par lus dang ngag dang yid brtson pas nan tan mi byed pa dang / de'i rkyen tshogs pa mi tshol ba dang / de'i bar du gcod pa'i gnyen po la mi 'bad pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang yid mi bde ba chung ngus sdug bsngal dang yid mi bde ba chen po'i gnyen por 'gyur ba mi skyed pa dang / don chen po sgrub pa'i phyir don chung ngu nyams par mi byed pas/ skad cig gcig tsam yang yal bar bor na ltung ba dang bcas pa yin no/ /

[15] Just as, in other lifetimes, problems do not appear in him, in the same way, if the vow does not decay, it remains for as long as this life lasts.[xxxiv] On this topic, for those who have taken the vow, a universal characteristic of downfalls will be stated, so that whenever they perceive anything that has that characteristic, they should abandon it, and so that they will not become confused by merely apparent downfalls, or things that merely appear not to be downfalls. If a bodhisattva does not make a sincere, unwavering effort in thought, word, and deed to stop all the present and future pain and suffering of all sentient beings, and to bring about all present and future pleasure and happiness, or does not seek the collection of conditions for that, or does not strive to prevent what is opposed to that, or does not bring about small pain and suffering as a way of preventing great pain and suffering, or does not abandon a small benefit in order to accomplish a greater benefit, if he neglects to do these things even for a moment, he undergoes a downfall.

mdor na rang gi nus pa'i yul ma yin pa'i bya ba rnams la ltung ba med de/ don dam pa nyid kyis de la bslab pa bcas pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan la ni rang bzhin gyis kha na ma tho ba dang bcas pa nyid du gzung ba kho na'o/ / rang gi nus pa'i spyod yul ma yin pa gang zhig la brtson par byed na ltung bar 'gyur te/ de ni bsam mi dgos par spyir sdig pa bshags pa'i nang du 'dus pas de las grol bar 'gyur ro/ / de dag ni mdor na/ byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i khog pa yin te/ rgyas par ni bskal pa dpag tu med pa mtha' yas par bshad du yod do/ / yang mdor na byang chub sems dpa'i ltung ba rnam pa gnyis te/ ci nus par rigs pa dang ma rigs pa ma brtags par rtsom pa'am rtog pa'am btang snyoms su 'jog pa ni ltung ba dang bcas pa yin no/ / brtags te gar 'os pa las 'da' bar byed na/ tha na gdol pa'i bran gyis dpyas na yang ltung ba dang bcas pa yin no/ /

In brief, in the case of those actions that are not within someone’s power to do, [omitting them] is not a downfall. Because training is useless in such cases, [the concept of] “reprehensible by convention” does not apply. But some maintain that omissions that are reprehensible by nature are downfalls even when unavoidable.[39] On this view, someone could undergo a downfall because of something that is not in the scope of their capacity; this is an unacceptable conclusion. Such an omission should be included in a general confession, but then that person is freed from it. In brief, this is the substance of the training of a bodhisattva. But if it were explained in full detail, the explanation would take innumerable aeons. Alternatively, in brief, there are two kinds of downfalls for a bodhisattva. Someone who begins an action without examining whether it is appropriate to her capacity, not stopping or considering this issue, undergoes a downfall. If, having perceived that some action is appropriate, she neglects to do it, even if she was asked[xxxv] by an untouchable or by a slave,[xxxvi] she undergoes a downfall.
'di gang las shes she na/ lhag pa'i bsam pa bskul ba'i mdo las gsungs pa las shes te/ byams pa rgyu bzhis sangs rgyas thams cad kyis gsungs pa'i spobs par rig par bya'o/ /
How do we know? Because the Sūtra on Exhortation to Higher Intention (Adhyāśaya-saṃcodana-sūtra) says, [16] Moreover, Maitreya, for four reasons, all the words of the Buddha are illuminating.

bzhi gang zhe na/ byams pa 'di la spobs pa don dang ldan pa yin te don med pa dang ldan pa ma yin pa dang / chos dang ldan pa yin te chos ma yin pa dang ldan pa ma yin pa dang / nyon mongs pa 'bri bar byed pa yin te nyon mongs pa 'phel bar byed pa ma yin pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa'i yon tan dang phan yon ston pa yin te 'khor ba'i yon tan dang phan yon ston pa ma yin pa ste 'di bzhis so/ /

What are the four? Here, Maitreya, what is illuminating is true, not false.[xxxvii] It is endowed with the Dharma and not with that which is contrary to the Dharma. It removes reactive emotions and doesn’t promote them. It shows the advantages and benefits of Nirvāṇa, not the advantages and benefits of cyclic existence. These are the four
de bzhin du sbyar te

byams pa gang la la rgyu 'di bzhis spobs sam/ spobs par 'gyur ba de la rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo dad pa dag gis sangs rgyas su 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ / ston par 'du shes byas te dam pa'i chos mnyan par bya'o/ /
Maitreya, whatever in these four ways illuminates or is illuminating, gentlemen or ladies of faith should think of as a Buddha, and then as a teacher; they should listen to this holy teaching.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ byams pa gang cung zad legs par smras pa de thams cad ni sangs rgyas kyis gsungs pa yin no/ / byams pa de la su spobs pa 'di dag la sangs rgyas kyis bshad pa ma yin no/ / zhes spong ba dang gang zag de la zhe sdang ba'i phyir/ de dag la ri mo mi byed na/ des sangs rgyas kyis bshad pa'i spobs pa thams cad spangs par 'gyur ro/ / chos spangs pas chos kyis phongs par 'gyur ba dang mthun pa'i las kyis ngan song du 'gro bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ / yang gang zhig goms pa'i don du 'di shes par 'dod pa des bslab pa kun las btus pa 'di la spyod pa'i sgo tsam bslab pa'i phyir brtson par byas te/ bslab pa la brtson pa 'bras bu shin tu che ba'i phyir ro/ /

Why is that? Maitreya, whatever is well said, all that is the word of the Buddha. Here, Maitreya, whoever rejects these illuminating words with contempt and personal hatred, thinking “these are not the word of the Buddha,” has rejected the illumination which is all the word of the Buddha. As a result of the actions that go along with rejecting the Dharma, that person goes to a bad rebirth. Now whoever wants to practice the Dharma repeatedly and become proficient in it should make an energetic effort to train in what is laid out here in the Training Anthology, putting practice first, since even beginning the training bears great fruit.

rab tu zhi ba'i rnam par nges pa'i cho 'phrul gyi mdo las/ 'jam dpal gang gis/ gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi sangs rgyas rnams las/ sangs rgyas re re la yang gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing nor bu rin po che dbang gi rgyal pos rab tu bkang ste dbul ba phul la de ltar 'bul bas gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi bskal par dbul ba phul ba bas/ 'jam dpal byang chub sems dpa' gzhan gang gis rnam pa 'di lta bu'i chos 'di thos nas phyogs gcig tu song ste 'di ltar sems kyis mngon par rtog cing / 'di lta bu'i chos la bslab par bya'o zhes slob par 'dod na/ des ma bslabs su zin kyang bsod nams ches mang du bskyed de/ byang chub sems dpa' nor bu rin po che dbang gi rgyal po sbyin pa'i bsod nams ni de lta bu ma yin no zhes ji skad du gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

As the Sūtra on the Miracle of Calm Inquiry (Praśānta-viniścaya-prātihārya-sūtra) says, Mañjuśrī, suppose that one bodhisattva filled a number of Buddha-fields equal in number to the sands of the Ganges River with magical gems and jewels, [xxxviii] and then gave them individually to each of many Buddhas equal in number to the sands of the Ganges River, and continued giving gifts in this way[xxxix] for aeons equal in number to the sands of the Ganges River. Now, Mañjuśrī, suppose another bodhisattva, having heard teachings of this kind, reflected on them with a one-pointed mind, thinking “I shall train in teachings of this kind.” Mañjuśrī, even if he does not actually train, because of being motivated to train, greater goodness would arise.
