The goodness that consists in generosity[xl] is not the same.

de bas na de lta bu'i phan yon mthong ba'i byang chub sems dpas ci nas kyang phyir mi ldog par bya ste/ de nyid las 'jam dpal 'di lta ste dper na/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi rdul phra rab kyi rdul snyed kyi sems can de dag las/ sems can re re nas 'dzam bu'i gling la dbang ba'i rgyal por 'gyur te/ de dag thams cad kyis tshig 'di skad ces/ bdag cag gis gang theg pa chen po len pa dang / 'dzin pa dang / klog pa dang / kun chub par byed pa de'i sha las nyi ma re re zhing yang srang lnga lnga sen mos gcad par bya ste/ de tshul de lta bus srog dang dbral lo zhes smra ba la/ 'jam dpal gal te byang chub sems dpa' de de skad smra bas mi skrag mi dngang dngang bar mi 'gyur te/ tha na skrag pa'i sems gcig kyang mi skyed zhum pa med gang ba med the tshom med la phyir zhing chos yongs su gzung ba la brtson te/ klog pa dang kha ton byed pa la brtson par 'gyur ba'i byang chub sems dpa' de ni/ 'jam dpal byang chub sems dpa' sbyin pa la dpa' ba/ tshul khrims la dpa' ba/ bzod pa la dpa' ba/ brtson 'grus la dpa' ba/ bsam gtan la dpa' ba/ shes rab la dpa' ba/ ting nge 'dzin la dpa' ba zhes bya'o/ / 'jam dpal gal te byang chub sems dpa' de gsod pa'i mi de dag la mi khro zhing tha ba dang zhe sdang gi sems mi skyed na/ 'jam dpal byang chub sems dpa' de ni tshangs pa dang mtshungs pa/ dbang po dang mtshungs pa mi g.yo ba yin no zhes ji skad gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Therefore, seeing this kind of benefit, a bodhisattva should not turn away from the training for any reason. As the same sūtra says, On this topic, Mañjuśrī, suppose that there are sentient beings equal in number to the atoms in three billion world-realms, and each one of those sentient beings becomes a mighty king, the supreme ruler of an entire continent. Suppose that all of them were to declare: “If anyone accepts the Great Way, supports it,[xli] speaks about it, understands it and practices it, then every day for a month I will torture him by his fingernails and cut five ounces from his flesh, and in this way I will kill him.” Mañjuśrī, suppose that a bodhisattva hears these words and does not tremble or become terrified, even to the extent of not having a single thought of fear, despair, or doubt, and further, strives to understand the holy Dharma, studies it diligently, and recites it daily. Mañjuśrī, that bodhisattva should be known as a mind-hero, a hero of generosity, a hero of moral discipline, a hero of patient endurance, a hero of perseverance, a hero of meditative stability, a hero of wisdom, a hero of meditative absorption. Mañjuśrī, if the bodhisattva does not get angry at those violent people, nor become enraged, and does not arouse any thought of aggression or anger, then, Mañjuśrī, that bodhisattva is the equal of Brahma, the equal of Indra,[40] unshakeable.
'di las kyang da ltar gyi dus na … bslab pa la … gus par byed pa
Hence, any effort that you make today
[3a] To train in the Great Way

'bras bu rnam par smin pa che ba yin te/ zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las/ / bskal pa bye ba gang gA'i bye snyed du/ / sangs rgyas dag ni bye ba khrag khrig la/ / gdugs dang ba dan mar me'i phreng ba dang / / zas dang skom gyis dad sems mchod byas pas/ / gang gis dam pa'i chos 'di 'jig pa'i tshe/ / bde bar gshegs pa'i bstan pa 'gag pa na/ / nyin zhag dus ni bslab pa gcig bzung ba/ / de bas bsod nams 'di ni khyad par 'phags/ / zhes gsungs te/ de bas na bslab pa la gus par bya'o/ /

[17] will mature into a great fruit. For the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[41] Suppose someone were to attend on ten trillion Buddhas, with a mind full of faith, for aeons equal in number to ten million times the number of grains of sand in the Ganges River, offering them food and drink, umbrellas, banners, and lamps. Alternately, suppose someone, at a time when this holy Dharma has been destroyed and the religion of the Well-Gone One has ceased, were to practice the training for one day and one night. The goodness from the second is more excellent. Therefore, you should make an effort in training!

bcom ldan 'das kyis mdo dag las byang chub sems dpa' bslab pa'i gzhi rnams gsungs te/ 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las/ rigs kyi bu ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' rnams byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i sdom pas bsdams pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' 'di ltar dpyod de so sor thar pa'i sdom pa tsam gyis bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar mi nus kyang / de bzhin gshegs pas gang 'di mdo sde de dang de dag las byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i gnas bcas pa gang yin pa de dag la bdag gis bslab par bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa rgya cher ji skad gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / de ltar rgya cher gsungs pas/ bdag lta bu blo zhan pas byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa shes par dka' bas na/

The training precepts of a bodhisattva are stated {by the Blessed One} in the scriptures. As the noble Cloud of Jewels (Ratna-megha-sūtra) says, Noble sir, how are bodhisattvas bound by the bodhisattva vow? Here a bodhisattva reflects as follows: “I cannot awaken to highest genuine full Awakening with only the vows of individual liberation. Now, whatever behaviors and training precepts for a bodhisattva are made known[xlii] by the Tathāgata in all the scriptures, I should train in them all.” For people like me, who are of weak intellect, the bodhisattva vow may be difficult to understand.
So the root verse says:
byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa ni/ / rgyas par theg pa che las 'byung / /
[3b] From which comes the bodhisattva discipline,
de la ji ltar byang chub rigs she na/ /
What is related to that?
gang gis ltung bar mi 'gyur ba/ / gnad kyi gnas rnams 'dir rig bya/ /
[3c–​d] You should know its vital points, so as to be without downfalls.
gnad kyi gnas de dag kyang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ /
And what are those vital points, which are stated in the scriptures for the benefit of those who are pleased with the Great Way?[xliii] They are:
bdag gi lus dang longs spyod dang / / dge ba dus gsum skyes pa rnams/ / sems can kun la btang ba dang / / de bsrung dag pa spel ba'o/ /
[4] Giving away to all sentient beings Your body, your possessions, and your good Gained in the past, present, and future, And protecting, purifying, and enhancing these.

'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa bsdus pa yin te/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' rnams bsgom pa glod na yang ltung bar 'gyur ba ni/ byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa'i mdo las gsungs pa bzhin te/ byang chub sems dpa' sems can thams cad kyi phyir/ sdug bsngal zad par 'gyur ba'i lam gang bzung ba de/ byang chub sems dpa' 'dzin cing gnas pas bskal pa bye ba 'das nas/ tha na 'dug pa tsam gyis bde ba 'dod pa'i sems cig skyes na yang / de la yang byang chub sems dpas 'di ltar sems bskyed par bya ste/ bdag 'di ltar 'dug pa ni sems can thams cad la gnong skur ro zhes so/ /

This is a summary of the bodhisattva’s vows. If you slack off from the repeated practice of these, that is judged to be a downfall. As the Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas (Bodhisattva-prātimokṣa) says, The path a bodhisattva follows leads to the end of suffering for all sentient beings. If a bodhisattva who has undertaken that path and has been living it for ten million aeons should have a single thought of desire for personal happiness, even so much as a thought of sitting down, then that bodhisattva should arouse this thought: “I have undertaken this; by sitting down I would abandon it and harm all sentient beings.”

'dul ba yongs su dag pa'i mdo las kyang / 'jam dpal gyis smras pa/ lha'i bu mtshams med pa gang dag dang ldan na/ byang chub sems dpa' myur du bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya ba'i mtshams med pa ni 'di lta ste/ lnga gang zhe na/ lha'i bu nam byang chub sems dpa' lhag pa'i bsam pas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed nas bar ma dor nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi sar sems mi bskyed na lha'i bu 'di ni mtshams med pa dang po'o/ / bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtang bar sems bskyed la bar ma dor ser sna'i sems dang lhan cig mi gnas pa 'di ni lha'i bu mtshams med pa gnyis pa'o/ / sems can thams cad bdag gis bskyab par bya'o zhes de ltar sems bskyed la bar ma dor zhum par mi byed pa 'di ni lha'i bu mtshams med pa gsum pa'o/ / chos thams cad ma skyes ma 'gags par khong du chud par bya'o zhes de ltar sems bskyed la bar ma dor lta bar gyur pa'i nang du ma ltung ba 'di ni lha'i bu mtshams med pa bzhi pa'o/ / skad cig ma gcig dang ldan pa'i shes rab kyis chos thams cad mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar bya'o zhes de ltar sems bskyed la thams cad mkhyen pa nyid ma thob par bar ma dor mi 'dug cing rgyun mi gcod pa 'di ni lha'i bu mtshams med pa lnga pa'o zhes bya ba'o/ / de lta bas na lus dang longs spyod dang bsod nams rgyun mi 'chad par gtang ba dang bsrung ba dang dag pa dang spel ba ci rigs par bsgom par bya'o/ /

{In the Sūtra on the Fully Pure Monastic Code (‘dul ba yongs su dag pa’i mdo)}, Mañjuśrī said: [18] Divine prince, there are these five practices with immediate results.[42] Bodhisattvas who have the practices with immediate results will quickly awaken to highest genuine full Awakening. What are the five? Divine prince, when a bodhisattva has aroused the Mind and is intent on highest genuine full Awakening, and meanwhile does not think about the stages of Disciples and Solitary Sages, this, divine prince, is the first practice with immediate results. When someone has aroused the intention of renouncing everything and does not, in the meantime, with a greedy mind, give away only half, this, divine prince, is the second practice with immediate results. When someone arouses the thought “I will save all sentient beings,” and in the meantime does not sit down, this, divine prince, is the third practice with immediate results. When someone arouses the thought “I will fully know that everything has no arising or ceasing,” and in the meantime does not flee into the shelters of false views, this, divine prince, is the fourth practice with immediate results. If someone arouses the thought “With wisdom that comes together in a single moment, I will completely awaken to everything,” and meanwhile, until reaching complete knowing, does not stop and does not break the continuity of practice, this, divine prince, is the fifth practice with immediate results. Therefore, in this way, you should practice without interruption, giving away, protecting, purifying, and enhancing your bodies, possessions, and goodness, as appropriate.

de la re zhig gtang ba'i phyir yongs su 'dzin pa'i nyes pa bsgom pa'i sgo nas 'dod chags dang bral ba bskyed cing gtong ba'i phan yon yang bsgom mo/ / zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las ji skad du/ / rul par gyur pa'i lus 'di dang / / srog kyang g.yo ba dbang med cing / / rmi lam sgyu ma 'dra ba la/ / byis pa 'di dag chags pas na/ / shin tu ma rungs las byas te/ / sdig pa'i dbang du song ba dang / / mi mkhas 'chi bdag bzhon pas song / / de dag mi bzad sems dmyal 'gro/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

On this topic, if your goal is to give things away, arouse disenchantment by meditating on the problems caused by ownership, and also, meditate on the benefits of renunciation. As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says, Those fools who are attached to this completely putrid body, Without life or power of movement,[xliv] like a dream or an illusion, Act in extremely violent ways, governed by the power of delusion;[xlv] Then, once their minds have gone on the path of death, they go to terrible hells.

de skad du sgo mtha' yas pa bsgrub pa'i gzungs las kyang / sems can gang dag kha cig rtsod 'gyur ba/ / de yi gzhi rtsa yongs su 'dzin pa ste/ / de ltas gang la sred par 'gyur ba spongs/ / sred pa spangs ba byas na gzungs su 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ / byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las kyang / shA ri'i bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' ni chos thams cad la gzhan gyi 'du shes bskyed de dngos po ci yang mi len to/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ len pa ni 'jigs pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

In the same way, the Dhāraṇī that Opens Doors without Limit (Ananta-mukha- nirhāra-dhāraṇī) says, When sentient beings quarrel, whoever they may be, the root cause is a sense of ownership. Therefore, abandon whatever arouses craving! For the one who has abandoned craving gains mnemonic powers.[xlvi] The Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas recounts that: [19] Moreover, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva thinks of everything as belonging to someone else, and doesn’t own anything. Why? Because ownership is fear.

drag shul can gyis zhus pa las kyang / gang byin pa de ni yang bsrung bar bya ba ma yin pa'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni bsrung bar bya ba'o/ / gang byin pa de ni srid pa zad par 'gyur ba'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni srid pa rnam par 'phel ba'o/ / gang byin pa de ni yongs su mi 'dzin pa'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni yongs su 'dzin pa dang bcas pa'o/ / gang byin pa de ni 'jigs pa med pa'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni 'jigs pa dang bcas pa'o/ / gang byin pa de ni byang chub kyi lam nye bar ston pa'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni bdud kyi phyogs nye bar ston pa'o/ / gang byin pa de ni zad mi shes pa'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag par gyur pa de ni zad par gyur pa'o/ / gang byin pa de ni bde ba'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni kun bsrung dgos pas sdug bsngal ba'o/ / gang byin pa de ni nyon mongs pa spong bar 'gyur ba'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni nyon mongs pa 'phel bar byed pa'o/ / gang byin pa de ni longs spyod chen por 'gyur ba'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni longs spyod chen por mi 'gyur ba'o/ / gang byin pa de ni skyes bu dam pa'i las so/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni skyes bu ngan pa'i las so/ / gang byin pa de ni sangs rgyas thams cad kyis bsngags pa'o/ / gang khyim na gzhag pa de ni byis pa'i skye bos bsngags pa'o zhes bya ba nas/

The noble Inquiry of Ugra also says, What is given no longer needs to be protected. What remains in the house must be protected. What is given is for the destruction of craving.[xlvii] What remains in the house increases craving. What is given is not owned. What remains in the house is owned. What is given is free from fear. What remains in the house is a cause of fear. What is given supports the path to Awakening. What remains in the house supports Māra. What is given is imperishable. What remains in the house perishes. What is given leads to happiness. What remains in the house leads to suffering, because you have to protect it. What is given helps to abandon reactive emotions. What remains in the house increases reactive emotions. What is given leads to great enjoyment. What remains in the house doesn’t lead to great enjoyment. Giving things away is the act of a holy person. Keeping things in the house is the act of a bad person.[xlviii] Giving things away leads to having the mind of a holy person. Keeping things in the house leads to having the mind of a bad person. Giving things away is praised by all the Buddhas. Keeping things in the house is praised by foolish people …

gal te des bu la lhag par sdug pa bskyed la de bzhin du sems can gzhan la ma yin na des spyo ba gsum gyis rang gi sems la spyo bar bya ste/ gsum gang zhe na/ byang chub ni sems snyoms pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yin gyi sems mi snyoms pa'i ma yin no/ / byang chub ni yang dag par sbyor ba'i byang chub sems dpa' yin gyi ldog par sbyor ba ni ma yin no/ / byang chub ni tha dad pa med par spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' yin gyi tha dad du spyod pa ni ma yin pa ste spyo ba gsum po 'di dag gis rang gi sems la spyos nas/ bu de la mi sdug pa'i 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ / 'di ni mi sdug pa ste/ bdag gi snying du sdug pa yin na/ gang bdag gis de'i don du bu de la ni lhag par sdug pa bskyed la sems can gzhan la ni de lta ma yin pas sangs rgyas kyis bka' stsal pa'i bslab pa dang 'gal bar 'gyur ro/ / bdag gis de'i phyir dge ba'i rtsa ba la yang gnod pa byas srog la yang bag med de gnod par 'gyur bas 'di ni bdag la gnod par byed pa'o/ / bdag de'i phyir byang chub kyi lam dang mi mthun pa'i lam la spyod pas/ 'di ni bdag la phyir rgol ba'o snyam du 'du shes gsum po de dag bskyed par bya'o/ / des bu de rgyur byas te/ ji lta ji lta bur bu de la sdug par sems pa dang ldan pa bzhin du sems can thams cad la byams pa bskyed pa dang / bdag phangs par sems pa dang ldan pa bzhin du byams pa bskyed pa/ de lta de lta bur de sems bskyed par bya'o/ /

Now, if he feels excessive love for his son and doesn’t feel the same for other sentient beings, he should admonish his mind in three ways. Which three? “Awakening is for a bodhisattva whose mind is impartial, not for one whose mind is partial. Awakening is for a bodhisattva whose endeavor is correct, not for one whose endeavor is perverse.[xlix] Awakening is for a bodhisattva who doesn’t discriminate, not for one who discriminates.” After admonishing his mind in these three ways, he should arouse a conception of his son as an enemy, as follows: “This person is an enemy of mine, not a friend. I feel excessive love for that son for whose benefit I have neglected the training taught by the Buddha; I don’t feel the same way about other sentient beings.”[l] Then, after thinking of his son as an adversary in this way, he should arouse a third conception: “Just as I feel love for my son, in the same way I should arouse lovingkindness towards all sentient beings, filled with love for them as my children. I should arouse lovingkindness towards all sentient beings, loving them as I love myself.”

de yang 'di ltar 'di yang gud nas 'ongs la bdag kyang gud nas 'ongs mod kyi sems can thams cad kyang sngon bdag gi bur gyur la bdag kyang sems can thams cad kyi bur gyur te/ 'di la ni bdag gi'am gzhan gyi'am su'i sems can gang yang med do snyam du tshul bzhin du brtag par bya'o/ / khyim bdag de ltar byang chub sems dpas dngos po gang la yang bdag gi snyam du yongs su gzung bar mi bya chags par mi bya'o/ / g.yo dang sred pa'i bag la nyal mi bya'o/ / khyim bdag gal te byang chub sems dpa' khyim pa'i drung du slob pa 'ongs la/ dngos po zhig bslangs pa las/ gal te des dngos po ma btang na/ des 'di ltar dngos po 'di btang yang rung ma btang yang rung ste/ bdag ni dngos po 'di dang gdon mi za bar 'bral bar yang 'gyur te/ mi 'dod bzhin du 'chi bar yang 'gyur zhing dngos po 'dis bdag 'dor/ bdag gis kyang dngos po 'di 'dor gyis/ dngos po 'di btang la yid dga' ba dang / snying po blangs te 'chi ba'i dus bya'o/ / 'di yongs su btang na bdag 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe sems kun nas zin te gnas par mi 'gyur te/ 'dis ni bdag 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe dga' ba dang mchog tu dga' ba dang rangs pa dang 'gyod pa med pa skye bar 'gyur snyam du sems nges par bsam par bya'o/ /

And he should thoroughly consider the matter as follows: “I have come from somewhere else; this person has come from somewhere else. All sentient beings have also been my sons before, and I have been the son of all sentient beings. There is no sentient being in this world who is either mine, or a stranger; I should think of them all impartially …” [20] For thus, leading merchant, a householder bodhisattva should not develop a sense of ownership or a sense of ‘mine’ toward any property, nor clinging, nor addiction, nor the propensity to craving. Leading merchant, if a householder bodhisattva is approached by a beggar who asks him for some property, and if he has not yet given his property away, he should not reflect in his mind, “Should I give this property away or not?” {Instead, he should definitely think,} “I will inevitably lose this property. Death will come whether I want it to or not. This property will abandon me, and I will abandon it. If I give this property away, I will die having gotten from it what actually matters. And if I give this away, at the time of my death it will not obsess my mind. Instead, at the time of my death, it will give rise to pleasure, joy, and the absence of regret.”

gal te de ltar bsams kyang / dngos po de gtong ma nus na des slong ba la kun go bar bya ba gsum gyis go bar bya ste/ bdag ni da dung mthu chung zhing dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su ma smin te/ theg pa chen po la las dang po pa dang bdag ni ma gtong ba la sems kyi dbang du gyur pa dang bdag nyid ni nye bar len pa'i lta ba dang bcas pa dang bdag tu 'dzin pa dang bdag gir 'dzin pa la gnas pa lags kyi/ skyes bu dam pa bzod par mdzad cing yongs su gdung bar mi mdzad du gsol/ ji ltar khyod dang sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ba de ltar bdag gis bgyi'o/ / de ltar bsgrub po/ / de ltar brtson 'grus brtsam mo zhes khyim bdag de ltar byang chub sems dpa' khyim pas slong ba la kun go bar bya ba gsum gyis go bar bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / slong ba la kun go bar byed pa 'di yang byang chub sems dpa' de la ma dad pa'am byang chub sems dpa' la slong ba ma dad par gyur pa'i nyes pa gzhan spang ba'i phyir gsungs par zad kyi/ ser sna'i kha na ma tho ba med pa ni ma yin te/ bcom ldan 'das kyis byang chub sems dpa' rnams la 'di smod do/ /

If he reflects in this way, but is still not able to give away the property, he must explain four things[li] to the beggar. Which four? “I am weak, and my wholesome actions have not matured. I am a beginner in the Great Way, and have not yet gotten my mind under control for giving. I am attached to false views and am stuck in thoughts of ‘me’ and ‘mine.’ Please be patient, good man; do not be distressed. I will act, I will practice, I will strive with perseverance in such a way that your wishes, and those of all beings, will be completely fulfilled.” Thus indeed, leading merchant, should he speak to that beggar. This explanation is given so that the bodhisattva will not have any unkind feelings towards the beggar, nor the beggar towards the bodhisattva. Avarice is reprehensible. In the case of bodhisattvas, it was condemned by the Blessed One.

byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las ji skad du/ shA ri'i bu chos 'di bzhi ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams la med do/ / bzhi gang zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams la g.yo med do/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la ser sna med do/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la phrag dog dang phra ma med do/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar mi nus snyam pa'i zhum pa'i sems med do/ / shA ri'i bu gang la chos bzhi po 'di dag yod pa de la ni mkhas pa rnams kyis/ kye ma'o 'di ni tshul 'chos pa'o/ / kye ma'o 'di ni kha gsag can no/ / kye ma'o 'di ni chos las nyams pa'o/ / kye ma'o 'di ni kun nas nyon mongs pa'i chos can no/ / kye ma'o 'di ni 'jig rten gyi zang zing lhur byed pa'o/ / kye ma'o 'di ni zas dang gos ched cher byed pa'o zhes rig par bya'o/ / shA ri'i bu de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni sems dpa' ba yin te/ lag pa'i bar du yongs su gtong ba yin/ rkang pa yongs su gtong ba dang / sna yongs su gtong ba dang / mgo yongs su gtong ba dang / yan lag dang nying lag yongs su gtong ba dang / bu yongs su gtong ba dang / bu mo yongs su gtong ba dang / chung ma yongs su gtong ba dang / dga' ba yongs su gtong ba dang / nor yongs su gtong ba dang / bde ba yongs su gtong ba dang / khyim yongs su gtong ba dang / gnas yongs su gtong ba dang / yul yongs su gtong ba dang / rin po che yongs su gtong ba dang / bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtong ba yin no zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

As the Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas says, Śāriputra, these four qualities are not found in bodhisattvas. Which four? In bodhisattvas there is no deceit. In bodhisattvas there is no avarice. In bodhisattvas there is no envy or slander. One does not find bodhisattvas completely absorbed in the despairing thought, “I cannot awaken to highest genuine full Awakening.” Śāriputra, someone in whom these four qualities are found should be known thus by the wise: “Alas, this person is a rogue. Alas, this person is a braggart. Alas, this person’s virtues are gone. Alas, this person is completely subject to reactive emotions. Alas, this person longs for worldly belongings. Alas, this person is mainly interested in food and clothing.” [21] Indeed, Śāriputra, bodhisattvas are mind-heroes, inasmuch as they give away their own hands; they give away their feet; they give away their noses; they give away their heads; they give away their major and minor body parts; they give away their sons; they give away their daughters; they give away their wives; they give away their pleasures; they give away their retinues; they give away their minds; they give away their happiness; they give away their homes; they give away their property; they give away their land; they give away their wealth; they give away everything they have.

de skad du sred med kyi bus zhus pa las kyang / dngos po gang la de gtong ba'i sems mi skye ba dang gtong ba'i blo mi 'jug pa'i dngos po de bsrel bar mi bya'o/ / yongs su 'dzin pa gang la spang ba'i sems mi skye ba'i/ yongs su 'dzin pa de yongs su gzung bar mi bya'o/ / gang slong ba de dag gis bslangs na yongs su gtong ba'i blo skye bar 'gyur ba'i g.yog de lta bu bcang bar mi bya'o/ / rgyal srid de gzung bar mi bya'o/ / longs spyod de dag dang rin po che de dag bcang bar mi bya'o/ / dngos po gang la byang chub sems dpa' yongs su mi gtong ba'i blo skye bar 'gyur ba yin na/ nor gyi dngos po gang yang rung ba'i bar du bcang bar mi bya'o/ /

In the same way, the Inquiry of Nārāyaṇa (Nārāyaṇa-paripṛcchā) also says, Don’t appropriate anything if you can’t arouse the thought of giving it away. Don’t own any property if you can’t arouse the thought of giving it up. Don’t take on servants if you wouldn’t think of giving them away if a beggar asked for them. Don’t accept royal power, or possessions, or wealth, or any property whatsoever, if you can’t arouse the thought of giving them away.

rigs kyi bu byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos 'di ltar sems bskyed par bya ste/ bdag gi lus 'di yang sems can thams cad la byin zhing yongs su btang na/ phyi rol gyi dngos po rnams lta ci smos te/ sems can gang dang gang la ci dang ci dgos par 'gyur ba de dang de dag la de dang de sbyin no/ / yod de yod na lag pa 'dod pa la lag pa sbyin no/ / rkang pa 'dod pa la rkang pa/ mig 'dod pa la mig sbyin no/ / sha 'dod pa la sha / khrag 'dod pa la khrag / rkang 'dod pa la rkang / yan lag dang nying lag 'dod pa la yan lag dang nying lag / mgo 'dod pa la mgo yongs su btang ste/ phyi rol gyi dngos po dag 'di lta ste/ nor dang 'bru dang gser dang dngul dang rin po che dang rgyan dang rta dang glang po che dang shing rta dang bzhon pa dang grong dang grong khyer dang grong rdal dang ljongs dang rgyal srid dang yul 'khor dang rgyal po'i pho brang 'khor dang yul 'khor dang tshong dus dang bran pho smos dang las byed pa dang zho shas 'tsho ba dang bu dang bu mo dang g.yog rnams lta ci smos te/ sems can gang dang gang la gang dang gang gis ci dang ci dgos par 'gyur ba/ sems can de dang de dag la de dang de yod pa sbyin no/ / ci nas sems can 'di dag yongs su bsdus pas/ bdag byang chub thob pa'i chos shes par 'gyur ro snyam nas/ sems can la phan gdags pa dang sems can la snying rje ba dang sems can la snying brtse ba'i phyir/ 'gyod pa med cing mya ngan du mi byed pa dang / rnam par smin pa la re ba med par yongs su gtong ngo / / chags pa med par sbyin no/ /

Indeed, noble sir, a bodhisattva great being should arouse the following thought: “I have given away and offered this, my body, to all sentient beings; how much more so any external property! If any sentient being needs anything for any reason, whatever it might be, if it exists, I will give it to that being. I will give my hand to whoever needs a hand. I will give my foot to whoever needs a foot. I will give my eye to whoever needs an eye. I will give my flesh to whoever needs flesh. I will give my blood to whoever needs blood. I will give my major and minor body parts to whoever needs major and minor body parts. I will give my head to whoever needs a head. What need is there even to speak of external property, such as money, grain, gold, silver, gems, jewelry, horses, elephants, chariots, vehicles, villages, cities, towns, provinces, kingdoms, palaces, servants, workers, employees, sons, daughters, and entourage members? If any sentient being needs anything for any reason, whatever it might be, if it exists, I will give it to that being. I will give without sorrow and without regret.[lii] I will give without longing for the karmic result. I will give impartially, with kindness towards sentient beings, with compassion for sentient beings, with love for sentient beings, thinking, ‘How may I myself, together with all these sentient beings, come to know Awakening?’ ”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rigs kyi bu dper na/ rtsi'i sdong po ni rtsa ba nas blangs kyang rung / sdong po las blangs kyang rung / yal ga las blangs kyang rung / shun lpags las blangs kyang rung / lo ma las blangs kyang rung / me tog dang 'bras bu dang snying po las blangs kyang rung ste/ de 'di ltar bdag rtsa ba nas blangs so/ / bdag gi rtsa ba nas blangs so/ / bdag gi snying po'i bar du blangs so snyam du rnam par rtog pa mi 'byung mod kyi/ rnam par rtog pa med bzhin du sems can rab 'bring tha ma rnams kyi nad med par byed do/ / rigs kyi bu de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos kyang 'byung ba chen po bzhi'i lus 'di la rtsi'i sdong po bzhin du 'du shes bskyed cing sems can gang dang gang dag la ci dang ci dgos pa khyer te/ lag pa 'dod na lag pa rkang pa 'dod na rkang pa khyer cig ces snga ma bzhin du gsungs so/ /

For example, noble sir, if people were taking the root of a medicine tree, or if people were taking the trunk, the branches, the bark, or the leaves, or if people were taking the flowers, or the fruits, or the sap, the tree would not have any thought such as: “They are taking my root … they are taking my sap.” Moreover, the tree would not think of the sentient beings whose diseases are cured as superior, mediocre, or inferior. In the same way, noble sir, a bodhisattva great being should conceive of this physical body as medicine, thinking “Whatever sentient beings have a use for any part of it, whoever they are, let them take from me whatever it is that they need: a hand if they need a hand, a foot if they need a foot,” and so on as before.

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las kyang / lus 'di bdag gis sems can thams cad kyi bya ba ci yod pa de la dengs par bya ste/ dper na sa'i khams dang chu'i khams dang me'i khams dang rlung gi khams dang 'byung ba chen po bzhi po 'di dag sgo sna tshogs dang rnam grangs sna tshogs dang dmigs pa sna tshogs dang yo byad sna tshogs dang longs spyod sna tshogs kyis sems can rnams nye bar longs spyod par byed pa de bzhin du/ bdag gis kyang 'byung ba chen po bzhi'i khog pa'i lus 'di sgo sna tshogs dang rnam grangs sna tshogs dang dmigs pa sna tshogs dang yo byad sna tshogs dang longs spyod sna tshogs kyis rgya cher sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho bar bya'o snyam ste/ de don gyi dbang 'di mthong bas/ lus sdug bsngal bar yang so sor rtog la sems can la blta ba'i phyir lus sdug bsngal bas kyang yongs su mi skye'o zhes bstan to// //

The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra also teaches: [22] “I should throw this body into the needs of all sentient beings, whatever they may be. For example, the four external elements, earth, water, fire, and air, are useful to sentient beings in various ways, providing various forms of happiness, various services, and various necessities in various aspects and from various points of view. In the same way, I will make this body, a big pile of the four elements, extensively useful to sentient beings in various ways, through various actions and services, providing various necessities and various forms of happiness.” Regarding the body as dedicated to this goal, [a bodhisattva] looks at physical pain and is not distressed, but takes care of sentient beings.[liii]
bam po gnyis pa/
bdag dang longs spyod dang bsod nams btang ba ni/

'phags pa rdo rje rgyal mtshan gyi mdo las gsungs so/ / de ltar byang chub sems dpa' bdag nyid sems can thams cad la gtong ba ni/ dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad kyis phan 'dogs pas sems can thams cad la dge ba'i rtsa ba dag gis sems par byed pa dang / bdag nyid mar me dang 'dra bar sems can thams cad la nye bar gzhag pa dang / bdag nyid bde ba dang 'dra bar sems can thams cad la byin gyis brlabs pa dang / bdag nyid chos kyi skye gnas dang 'dra bar 'gro ba thams cad yang dag par 'dzin pa dang / bdag nyid snang ba dang 'dra bar sems can thams cad kyi rjes su 'gro ba dang / bdag nyid 'gro ba thams cad kyi gzhir 'gro ba dang / bdag nyid dge ba'i rtsa ba'i rkyen du gyur par mthong ba dang / bdag nyid 'gro ba thams cad kyi rjes su 'gro ba dang / bdag nyid mdza' bo dang 'dra bar sems can thams cad la nye bar sbyor ba dang / bdag nyid sems can thams cad la lam dang 'dra bar ston pa dang / bdag nyid sems can thams cad kyi bla na med pa'i bde ba'i yo byad du yongs su sbyor ba dang / bdag nyid nyi ma dang 'dra bar 'jig rten kun du mtshungs par byed pa dang sems can thams cad la bdag nyid de lta bu'i chos dang ldan par rab tu sbyin par byed pa dang / 'jig rten thams cad na bdag nyid ci 'dod pa bzhin du bya ba la dbang du gyur par mthong bas 'jig rten kun tu bdag nyid mchod rten gyi mchog tu 'gyur bar bya ste bdag nyid 'gro ba thams cad kyi mchod rten du mthong ba dang / 'jig rten kun du sems mnyam par bsgrub pa dang /

The noble Vajra Flag Sūtra (Vajra-dhvaja-sūtra) also says, [23] Bodhisattvas give themselves to all sentient beings. They pay attention to their wholesome actions, and through all those wholesome actions, they benefit all sentient beings. Like a lamp, they lead all sentient beings. Like happiness, they give energy to all sentient beings. Like the womb of everything, they carry all that lives. Like light, they accompany all sentient beings. They see themselves as like a chair for all that lives. They accompany the whole world as a contributing condition of wholesome actions. They join together with all sentient beings like a friend. Like a path, they show all sentient beings the way to the highest happiness. They prepare for all sentient beings the equipment for reaching the highest happiness. Like the sun, they treat all living beings as equals. Though they have the teachings, they ask for teachings on behalf of all sentient beings. They see themselves as obedient, under the control of the needs of the whole world. They see all living beings as holy shrines, and will themselves become the highest holy shrines for the entire world. They help the whole world to achieve mental balance.

bdag nyid 'gro ba kun du yo byad thams cad kyi mu stegs su mthong ba dang / bdag nyid 'jig rten thams cad la bde ba sbyin par so sor rtogs pa dang / bdag nyid 'gro ba kun gyi sbyin bdag tu mos pa dang / bdag nyid 'jig rten kun gyi shes pa dang 'dra bar byas pa dang / bdag nyid byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang ldan par bskyed pa dang / bdag nyid ji skad smras pa de bzhin du byed pa la 'jug pa dang / bdag nyid thams cad mkhyen pa'i go cha bgos par so sor rtogs pa dang sngon mgron du gnyer ba'i sems can rjes su skyong ba dang / bdag nyid nan tan la gnas par byed pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i gtong ba'i sems yid la byed cing sems can thams cad la bdag nyid skyed mos tshal dang 'dra bar lta ba dang / 'jig rten thams cad la bdag nyid chos kyi dga' ba dang 'dra bar ston pa dang / bdag nyid sems can thams cad la yid bde ba sbyin pa nyid du gnas pa dang / bdag nyid dga' ba mtha' yas pa bskyed par 'gro ba thams cad la gtong zhing 'jig rten kun du bdag nyid dkar po'i chos skye ba'i sgo lta bur yongs su 'dzin pa dang / bdag nyid sems can thams cad la sangs rgyas kyi byang chub sbyin par smon lam 'debs pa dang / skye dgu thams cad la bdag nyid pha dang 'dra bar 'jug pa dang / sems can gyi khams thams cad du yo byad thams cad ma tshang ba med par bya ba'i phyir bdag nyid rab tu gnas pas yin no/ /

They see themselves as fords, providing all kinds of assistance. They regard themselves as giving happiness to the whole world. They are committed to being generous donors to all that lives. They make themselves like knowledge to the entire world. They become dedicated to the bodhisattva’s way of life. They engage the practice of doing exactly what they say they will do. They regard themselves as well equipped with the equipment for complete knowing. They protect sentient beings as if they were invited guests.[liv] They establish themselves in the practice. They develop the bodhisattva’s attitude of renunciation in their minds. They see themselves as like a garden for all sentient beings. They show themselves to the whole world as being like the joy of the Dharma. They live giving happiness to all sentient beings. They give endless pleasure to all that lives. They hold themselves up to the whole world as a door to all bright qualities. They aspire to give the Awakening of the Buddhas to all sentient beings. They become like the parents of all creatures. They establish themselves fully in the world of sentient beings, so that no necessities of any kind will be lacking.

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' bdag nyid g.yog tu sbyin par byed pa na/ slong ba dag la dga' ba yid la byed pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ sa la stan 'ding ba'i stan lta bu'i sems dang ldan par bya ste/ sa dang 'dra bar sdug bsngal thams cad bzod pa yid la byed pa bsgrub cing / sems can thams cad kyi rim gro bya ba la ngal ba med pa'i yid dang ldan pa/ byis pa'i skye bos sbyar ba'i nyes byas dang du blang ba la brtan zhing sran thub pa'i rang bzhin can legs par gnas pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba la mngon par brtson zhing sems can gyi khams thams cad kyi rim gro bya ba la rab tu zhugs pas yin no/ / slong ba 'ongs pa dag la rna ba'am sna yongs su gtong ba na/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pas zin cing de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs kyis rigs mtho ba las byung ba'i sems dang ldan pa dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad rjes su dran pa'i gnas pa las byung ba dang / 'jig rten gsum po thams cad snying po med pa las snying por rtog pa dang / rang gi lus la ma chags pa'i rgyu dang ldan pa dang / gnas med pa'i sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad kyi rjes su dran pa la gnas pa dang / snying po med pa'i lus las snying po blang ba'i bsam pa dang ldan pas yin no/ /

In this way, bodhisattvas give themselves away as servants. They are humble towards beggars.[lv] Spreading their mats on the earth, they make their minds like mats. They make an effort in attention to endure all pain, like the earth. They serve sentient beings without getting tired. They are untroubled by the misdeeds of foolish people, because they have stable patience. They work on their wholesome actions. Without being prompted, they serve all the world-realms.[lvi] They give away their ears and noses to any beggars who approach. They hold the bodhisattva’s way of life and have the minds of those born into the lofty family of the Tathāgatas. They live in the practice of recollecting all the bodhisattvas. They understand the value of the three worlds, which have no value. They are not attached to their own bodies. They live in the practice of recollecting all the qualities of the homeless Buddhas. They have the intention to gain the value of this valueless body.[43] …

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' lce blangs ma thag tu tshig 'jam zhing dga' bar 'gyur ba byams par spyod pa'i sems kyis rgyal po la 'os pa'i seng ge'i khri bzang po la bzhag nas/ slong ba de la mngon par smra ste/ sems ma khros par byas/ sems ma smas pa dang / sems ma nyams pa dang / sems bdag nyid chen po'i rigs kyis mtho ba dang / sems sangs rgyas kyi gdung las byung ba dang / sems ma rnyogs pa'i rgyud dang mthu stobs chen po bskyed pa dang / sems lus la ma chags pa dang / sems kha bzhin la mngon par ma zhen cing / pus mo'i lha nga btsugs pa'i lus su byas te/ rang gi kha nas lce phyung la slong ba'i lus la gtad de tshig 'jam zhing mnyen la dga' bar 'gyur ba byams pa nye bar spyod pa 'byin cing / khyod nga'i lce khyer la ji ltar khyod dga' bar 'gyur ba dang / yid dga' ba dang / yid bde ba dang / rab tu dga' zhing rangs pa dang / mos pa skye bar 'gyur bar ci 'dod pa bzhin gyis shig ces zer ro/ / de mgo yongs su gtong ba na chos thams cad kyi mchog mgo lta bu'i ye shes la 'jug cing / sems can thams cad kyi yongs su bskyab pa'i mgos byang chub khong du chud par byed pa dang / 'gro ba thams cad kyi mchog dpe med pa'i ye shes mgo lta bu mngon par 'dod pa dang / kun mkhyen pa'i mgo thob pa/ ye shes kyi rgyal po la mos par byed pa dang / chos thams cad kyi dbang phyug gi mgo mtha' yas pa yongs su rdzogs par 'dod cing / slong ba mtha' yas pa dga' bas yongs su khyab pa'i sems kyis yin no/ /

[24] In this way, when the bodhisattva was asked for his tongue, he sat down on an auspicious lion throne worthy of a king. With lovingkindness, intending to give, he spoke to that beggar in a lovely and courteous voice, pleased, with a mind free from anger, with a mind free from weeping, with a mind free from agitation, with the greatness of mind of a lofty family, with a mind born from the lineage of the Buddhas, with a mind and personality not subject to rolling around, with great mental power and force, with a mind not clinging to the body, with a mind free from grasping. He knelt down, pulled his tongue from his mouth, and in a submissive posture uttered these gentle, mild, joyful words, full of lovingkindness and politeness:[lvii] “Take my tongue, and do whatever you wish with it—whatever brings you joy, pleasure, happiness and gladness.” … When bodhisattvas give away their heads, they enter into pristine awareness, which is like the head, the highest of all virtues. They move towards Awakening, the head that saves all sentient beings … They wish to attain the highest incomparable pristine awareness that is the head of the whole world. They have confidence in the king of pristine awareness, so as to attain what is supreme throughout all of space.[lviii] They want to perfect the unlimited headship, the highest lordship over everything. Their minds have expanded because of the joy of limitless beggars.

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' slong ba dag la lag pa dang rkang pa yongs su gtong ba na dad pa'i lag pa dang ldan pa dang / rjes su phan 'dogs par spyod pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i rtsal gyis gtong ba'i lag pa brkyang zhing / sbyin pa la mngon par dga' bar lag pa yongs su gtong ba dang / rten chen po la rkang pa 'dor ba dang byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la mos pa dang / tshor bas ma nyams pa'i sbyin pa'i mthus sems bskyed pa dri ma med par gnas shing / ye shes yongs su dkris pa med pa dang / chos kyi lus rgyun mi 'chad pa mi shigs pa mi chod pa'i lus dang ldan pa/ bdud thams cad kyis mi bskyod pa/ sems dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis nye bar brtan zhing 'phel ba/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang / spyod pa gcig tu gnas shing gtong ba gcig pus nges par 'byung bas yin no/ /

In the same way, when bodhisattvas give away their hands and feet, they have the hands of faith. They have the extended hands of resourceful giving and conduct that helps others. They have the hands of the lion-like courage of the bodhisattvas’ great generosity.[lix] They have the hands of taking joy in giving. They have the feet of great stability. They are committed to the bodhisattvas’ way of life. Through the power of generosity and kindness, they are not overpowered by sensations. They vow to arouse the stainless Mind. They know that pristine awareness is unfettered, and that the Dharma body is never broken, cut, or injured. Since their minds have been made stable by spiritual teachers, they cannot be moved by all the demons. Their intentions are exalted, they remain in a single practice, and through generosity alone, they are certain to be free someday.

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' rang gi lus dral te slong ba dag la khrag 'byin pa na/ byang chub kyi sems kyis rab tu dga' ba dang / sems byang chub kyi spyod pa 'dod pa dang / sems tshor bas yongs su ma zin pa dang / sems slong ba thams cad 'dod pa dang / sems yongs su len pa thams cad la mi sdang ba dang / sems byang chub sems dpa'i gtong ba'i lam thams cad du zhugs pa dang / sems rang gi lus la mi lta zhing mi ldog la rgyun mi 'chad pas rang gi lus kyi khrag sbyin par byed do/ /

In the same way, when bodhisattvas tear their own bodies to give blood to beggars, they rejoice in the Awakening Mind. They aspire to the way of life that leads to Awakening.[lx] Their minds are not overcome by sensations. They long for people to ask them for things. They have no hatred in their minds towards the recipients. They follow all the bodhisattvas’ paths of renunciation. Their minds do not care about their own bodies; they do not turn back and do not break the continuity of practice. They give away blood from their own bodies.

ye shes kyi skye mched kyi sems theg pa chen po la zhugs pa/ yid ches pa dang / yid 'dod pa dang / yid tshim pa dang / yid rangs pa dang / yid mgu ba dang / yid dga' ba dang / yid bde ba dang / yid dang bar gyur te/ rab tu dga' zhing mos pa dang / rangs pa dang / yid bde ba skyes pas yin no/ / slong ba rnams la rang gi lus las sha yongs su gtong ba na dge bar gtong ste/ slong bar 'dod pa'i tshig gis khyed nga'i lus las sha dang rkang ci dgos pa sbyin/ khyer cig ces slong ba de dag la smra zhing / dga' ba mtshungs pa med pa rnam par spel ba'i gtong ba'i sems dang / byang chub sems dpa' mkhas pa'i tshogs kyis bsten pa'i dge ba'i chos thams cad kyi grogs su gyur pa dang / 'jig rten gyi dri ma bsal ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa mchog rab dang / byang chub sems dpa'i mnyam pa nyid kyis brin pa'i sbyin pa rtsom pa chen po yid kyis 'dod par gyur pa dang / bslong ba thams cad yi mi chad par sbyin pa btang ba'i dngos po dag gis shin tu so sor brtags pa'i las kyi rnam par smin pa'i rkyen dang / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad mngon du 'gyur ba'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi rgyan bkod pa'i mchod pa dang / 'gro ba thams cad la mngon du phyogs pa'i snying rje chen pos yongs su skyob pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi byang chub mngon du gyur pa'i stobs bcu rnam par spyod pa dang / 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar byung ba'i byang chub sems dpa' thams cad mngon du gyur pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba gcig gis rim gror bya ba dang / mi 'jigs pa thams cad mngon du gyur pa'i khyu mchog dang seng ge'i sgrar sgrogs pa dang / dus gsum mngon du gyur pa'i dus thams cad mnyam pa nyid du shes pa dang / 'jig rten thams cad mngon du gyur pa phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa'i bskal par brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam dang / yongs su yi ma chad pa mngon du gyur pa'i mi skyo ba'i sems bskyed pas yin no/ / byang chub sems dpa' slong ba dag la rang gi snying gtong ba na/ sems sbyin pa'i rigs la bslabs pa dang / sems pha rol tu phyin pa la sgrub pa dang / sems byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa thams cad la mi rgod par shin tu gnas pa dang / sems rten du gyur bas slong ba thams cad la ri mor byed pa dang / lhag pa'i bsam pa yongs su sbyong ba dang / 'gro ba thams cad yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir smon lam chen po la zhugs pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la gnas pa dang / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid la 'jug cing smon lam ma btang bas yin no/ /

[25] With minds engaged in the sphere of the pristine awareness of the Great Way; with minds that have not lost the Great Way;[lxi] with aspiring minds; with satisfied minds; with pleased minds; with joyful minds; with minds full of lovingkindness; with clear minds; with happy minds; with joy, pleasure, and gladness, they give away marrow[lxii] and flesh from their own bodies to beggars. With the virtue of renunciation, with longing for people to ask for things, they say these words to beggars: “Sirs, I give you the flesh and marrow that you need from my body. Take it!” They speak with compassion, with equal and increasing pleasure, and with mental renunciation.[lxiii] They are served by the bodhisattva’s wise group of followers, namely, all wholesome qualities.[lxiv] Having thrown away all worldly filth, they have the best and highest intentions. They have attained all the impartiality of the bodhisattvas. They have the aspiration to begin the practice of great generosity.[lxv] Their thoughts are not disturbed by beggars. They have no regard for property that can be given away, nor for the results of the process of the evolution of actions.[lxvi] They do not turn their faces away from the universe; instead, they revere the magnificent arrangements of the ornaments of all the Buddha-fields, and directly facing all living beings, they protect them with compassion. Directly facing the awakening of all Buddhas, they practice the ten powers[44].[lxvii] Directly facing all the bodhisattvas of the past, present, and future, they serve them all with a single wholesome action. Directly facing all forms of fearlessness, they utter the roar of bulls or lions. Directly facing the three times, they know that all times are the same. Directly facing the whole world, they adopt the aspiration prayer to persevere for aeons, to the utmost end of time. Directly facing freedom from weariness, they arouse a mind that is free from fatigue.[lxviii] When bodhisattvas give away their own hearts to beggars, they have the intention to train in the tradition of generosity. They have the intention to achieve the perfection [of generosity.] They have the intention to live fully in the peace of mind of the generosity of all bodhisattvas. They have the stable intention to provide for all beggars. They purify their higher intention. They undertake the great aspiration prayer in order to help all living beings to mature. They reside in the bodhisattva’s way of life. They gather the equipment[lxix] and do not abandon the aspiration to enter into complete knowing.

de slong ba dag la rgyu ma dang / mkhal ma dang / mchin pa dang / glo ba sbyin pa ni/ slong ba la rab tu dang ba dang / dga' ba'i rnam pa'i mig dang / byang chub sems dpa' las byung ba'i byams pa dang / mi ngal ba'i yid la byed pa'i gtong ba dang / snying po med pa'i lus las legs par brtags pa'i snying po len pa'i sems dang / mthar dur khrod du 'gro bar lus rjes su dran pa'i yid la byed pa dang / lus gzhan la rag las par yid la bya ba dang / mi rtag pa nyid kyis zin pa'i lus dang / gzhan gyi zas su sems pas lus la spyang ki dang / ce spyang dang / wa dang / khyi'i zas su rtog cing / de ltar chos yid la byed pa la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa'/ slong ba de dag la mig mi 'dzums shing sems 'di ltar bskyed de/ gal te bdag gis slong ba 'di la lus las rgyu ma dang / mkhal ma dang / mchin pa dang / glo ba byin kyang rung gal te ma byin kyang rung ste/ mthar tshe zad na 'di ni mi rtag ste tha ma dur khrod du 'gro'o zhes de ltar yid la byed par tshim par byed pa'i rgyud dang / de lta bu'i chos shes pa'i bsam pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi 'du shes su gnas pas slong ba la lta ba dang / snying po med pa'i lus las snying po len 'dod pa yin no/ / chos 'dod pas rang gi sha sen mo dang bcas pa gtong ba na yang / de ltar dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su sngo bar byed do/ / lus btang ba byas nas/

[26] They give away their livers, kidneys, and lungs to beggars, looking favorably on the beggars,[lxx] with eyes that look clear and pleased, with bodhisattva skill,[lxxi] with love, with minds that are not agitated, with renunciation, having thoroughly reflected on the body, which has no value,[lxxii] looking at those beggars with unblinking eyes. They reflect as follows, directing attention to the body: “If I give to this beggar the intestines, a liver, a kidney, or a lung from this body, I will die as a result. But this body is not permanent. It will end up in the charnel-ground.[lxxiii] {In the end, this body will be eaten by others: it will be eaten by jackals, foxes, and dogs. In the end it is impermanent; it goes to others.}” Pleased by this way of looking at the matter, having an intention based on knowing the Dharma in this way, governed by the thought of their spiritual teachers, seeing the beggars, wishing to gain the value of this valueless body, desiring the Dharma, they give away pieces of their own flesh, then dedicate that wholesome action. This completes the presentation of the gift of the body.

longs spyod dang bsod nams btang ba ni de nyid las byung ba/ de ltar byang chub sems dpa' sbyin gnas dang len pa sna tshogs phyogs gzhan dang gzhan nas 'ongs pa'i gang zag dang / slong ba phongs pa dang bkren pa mang po tshad med pa byang chub sems dpa'i sgra thos te 'ongs pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' la re ba'i skabs kyis 'ongs pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa dang sngon gyi smon lam thos pa rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa'i sbyin pa dang smon lam gyi sems kyis mgron du gnyer ba rnams dang / thams cad gtong du re ba'i yid can rnams 'ongs pa mthong nas/ slong ba la ri mor bya bas mi ngoms pa'i sems kyis slong ba 'ongs pa rnams la bzod pa gsol ba'i sems dang ldan pas bdag nyid phyogs de dag tu song la khyed 'ongs pa'i nyon mongs par mi 'gyur bar ri mor bya ba zhig na zhes des spyi bos gtugs te bzod pa gsol lo/ / slong ba thams cad la bzod pa gsol khrus byas lus ngal sos par byas nas/ yo byad ci 'os pa sbyin par byed de/ 'di lta ste/ nor bu'i shing rta 'dzam bu'i gling na bzang ba'i na chung rin po ches yongs su gang ba dang / 'di lta ste/ gser gyi shing rta yul gyi na chung rin po che rnam par dag pas yongs su gang ba dang / 'di lta ste bai DUr+ya'i shing rta glu dbyangs dang sil snyan rjes su mthun pa len pas gang ba dang / de bzhin du shel gyi shing rta bu mo rin po che bzhin bzang zhing cha byad sdug gus shin du brgyan pa gzugs blta na sdug cing tshul mkhas pas gang ba dag sbyin par byed do zhes gsungs pa dang /

The same text [the Vajra Flag Sūtra] also discusses giving up your possessions and goodness, as follows: In this way, various people who are worthy receivers of the bodhisattva’s generosity come from all directions: innumerable beggars, and the poor and destitute, come when they hear the words of the bodhisattva. They come hoping for gifts from the bodhisattva. They come for the opportunity the bodhisattva has created.[lxxiv] They come, having heard about the bodhisattva’s aspiration prayer whose foremost element is generosity. They come, invited by the thought of the bodhisattva’s aspiration prayer. The bodhisattva, wishing to give up everything to those who have desires and intending to give so as to satisfy all the beggars, wishing also to ask forgiveness from the beggars who have come, says: “I myself shall provide you who have come to this place with whatever you might want, so that you don’t feel sorry for coming.” He prostrates to them and then asks forgiveness of all the beggars. Then he bathes them and allows them to rest. He then gives them whatever material gifts they wish for, namely: jeweled chariots, complete with the most beautiful girls in all of India;[lxxv] golden chariots completely full of the most pure, bejeweled girls in the region; lapis lazuli chariots; melodious songs complete with the sound of musical instruments; crystal[lxxvi] chariots complete with bejeweled girls with beautiful faces and excellent costumes, very well-adorned, pleasant to look at and skilled.[lxxvii]

de bzhin du de nyid las/ nor bu'i shing rta glang po che cang shes rin po che thams cad kyi dra bas g.yogs pa dang ldan pa phrugs su mthun pas 'dren pa dag rab tu sbyin par byed/ tsan+dan gyi shing rta rin po che'i 'phang lo dang rtsibs sbyar ba/ rin po che'i seng ge'i khri btsugs pa/ rin po che'i gdugs sna tshogs kyis khebs pa/ rgyal mtshan dang ba dan gyis phyogs bzhir brgyan pa/ spos sna tshogs kyis shin tu bdugs shing spos kyi snying po'i byug pa thams cad kyis legs par byugs pa me tog gi bkod pa rnam par bkram pa/ bu mo brgya stong rin po che'i tha gus 'dren pa/ mi ldog mi 'gyur bar 'gro zhing drag thal ma khyer bar 'byor ba nas/ spos kyi ngad yid du 'ong zhing rjes su mthun pa dang / bu dang bu mor bcas pa'i smra ba nye bar sbyor ba dang ldan pa/ spos kyi phye ma sna tshogs gtor bas gtsang sbrar byas pa dag sbyin par byed do zhes gsungs pa dang /

Along the same lines, the same text teaches: [27] Or [the bodhisattvas] give jeweled chariots covered by nets of various gems, equipped with well-bred elephants and other draught animals; sandalwood chariots with jeweled wheels,[lxxviii] drawn by chariot-horses, resting on jeweled lion-thrones, shaded by marvelously arranged parasols of various gems, shaded with jeweled canopies decorated with banners and flags at the four corners, scented with various perfumes and perfume essences, well anointed with all unguents and strewn with marvelous arrangements of flowers, pulled by a hundred thousand girls using strings of jewels and equipped with even-tempered, strong draught animals who go without getting turned around, giving off charming, pleasant scents, with pleasant greetings from sons and daughters,[lxxix] furnished with aromatic powders whose scents are manifold and diverse.[lxxx]

de bzhin du gzhan yang de nyid las/ bdag nyid sems can thams cad la gtong ngam/ sangs rgyas thams cad la rim gror bya bar 'bul lam/ rgyal srid yongs su gtong ngam/ mkhar ram/ grong khyer ram/ rgyal po'i pho brang rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par spud pa'am/ g.yog thams cad kyang slong ba rnams la ci rigs par yongs su gtong ngam/ slong ba dag la bu dang bu mo dang chung ma sbyin par byed dam/ khyim thams cad btang ba nas/ longs spyod dang longs su spyod pa thams cad sbyin par byed do/ / de bzhin du skom sbyin pa dang / ro'i sbyin pa yang byang chub sems dpas sbyin par byed pa na/ bzang zhing rnam pa sna tshogs pa rgya che ba gtsang ba rnam pa tha dad pa kha ba dang tsha ba dang bska ba dang / lan tshwa'i ro mchog sna tshogs dang ldan pa shin tu tshim par byed pa'i ro bro ba mang po dang ldan pa dang / khams 'khrugs pa snyoms par byed pa/ lus dang sems kyi stobs ston pa/ dga' ba dang mos pa dang mchog tu dga' ba dang / bde ba skyed par byed pa nas/ pha rol gyi gnod par byed pa sel ba/ nad thams cad zhi zhing nad med pa bskyed pa dag sbyin par byed do/ /

The same text also says: They personally offer acts of veneration, either to all sentient beings or to the Buddhas. Or they give away kingdoms,[lxxxi] or cities, or royal palaces decorated with all ornaments. Or, when it is appropriate, they give away to beggars their entire retinue, or they give away their sons, daughters, and wives. Or they give away all their houses, and all their luxuries and comforts. In the same way, bodhisattvas give gifts of drinks and of food: good food, of various kinds, plentiful and clean; having all the best, highly satisfying, diverse flavors, such as pungent, salty, spicy, and astringent; having the diverse tastes that people like; restoring balance whenever the elements in the body are disturbed; supporting mental and physical strength; leading to pleasure, calmness, joy, and health;[lxxxii] counteracting external harms;[lxxxiii] curing all diseases and producing health. This is the kind of food that they give.

de bzhin du gos sbyin pa dang / me tog sbyin pa dang / spos sbyin pa dang / byug pa sbyin pa dang / phreng ba sbyin pa dang / mal cha sbyin pa dang / gnas sbyin pa dang / rten sbyin pa dang / mar me sbyin pa dang / na ba'i gsos sman sbyin pa dang / yo byad nas kha zas rnam pa sna tshogs yo lang cher bshams pa dag byang chub sems dpas sbyin par byed do/ / bzo sna tshogs su byas pa'i sder gyi snod sna tshogs pa tshad med pas spras pa rnam pa du ma dang / dbyig dang gser dang dngul gyi phye ma rnams/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dag la dbul ba na/ sbyin pa'i gnas bsam gyis mi khyab par mos so/ / 'di dag byang chub sems dpa' dkon mchog la dbul na/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen shin tu rnyed dka' bas sems bskyed pas dbul la/ / 'phags pa'i dge 'dun la 'bul na sangs rgyas kyi chos nye bar brten pa'i phyir dbul lo/ / gang zag gam nyan thos sam rang sangs rgyas dag la 'bul na/ 'phags pa'i yon tan la shin tu dang ba'i sems kyis 'bul lo/ / pha ma la sbyin na bla ma la sri zhu dang rim gro bya ba'i sems kyis sbyin no/ / slob dpon dang bla ma dang sbyin pa'i gnas de dang de dag la 'bul na/ bla ma'i tshogs kyis bstan pa bslab pa la 'jug go/ / dbul po dang phongs pa dang slong ba dag la gos dang zas sbyin pa na/ sems can thams cad la khong khro ba med pa'i mig dang / byams pa yongs su bsgoms pas sbyin par byed do/ /

In the same way, they give away clothes, flowers, perfumes, ointments, garlands, beds, houses, shelter, and lamps. They give away the monastic requisite of medicine to cure the sick. They give away large quantities of various different supplies. They give away various dishes for cooking, as well as innumerable decorated drinking cups and bowls full of gems and gold and silver dust.[lxxxiv] [28] They give these things to the Blessed Ones, the Buddhas, who are worthy of gifts to an inconceivable degree, with a devoted mind. Or they give to those jewels, the bodhisattvas. Or they give to the community of Noble Ones, knowing that a spiritual teacher is very difficult to find. Or they give to anyone who supports the religion of the Buddha. Or they give to the Disciples and Solitary Sages, with a mind of great faith in the abilities of these Noble Ones. Or they give to their parents. Or, wishing to hear teachings, they give to gurus and spiritual teachers who are worthy of gifts, with the intention of doing service to them. With the equipment provided by the guru, they train in the teachings.[lxxxv] Or they give food and clothing to the poor, to the destitute, and to beggars, not looking on any sentient being with dislike, since they have cultivated lovingkindness
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' glang po che cang shes yan lag bdun rab tu gnas pa/ lo drug lon pa so drug yod pa spu mdog pad+ma 'dra ba/ gdong rnam par dag pa gser gyi rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ lus gser gyi dra bas g.yogs pa/ sna rin po che'i rgyan sna tshogs kyis g.yogs pa/ bkod pas spras pa/ gser gyis g.yogs pa/ blta na sdug pa dpag tshad stong du mi ngal bar 'gro zhing rgyu ba sbyin par byed do/ / rta cang shes pa zhon na bde zhing lus bde ba dang ldan pa/ bang phun sum tshogs pa/ phyogs bzhir bgrod pa bkur ba'i mgyogs pa dang ldan pa/ zas phun sum tshogs pa/ lha'i mtshungs pa med pa'i rgyan thams cad dang ldan pa dag sbyin par byed do/ /

Bodhisattvas give away well-bred[lxxxvi] elephants, whose seven body parts are well formed, sixty years old,[lxxxvii] having six tusks, lotus-colored, with clean faces, decorated with golden ornaments, their bodies covered in gold braid, their trunks covered with various jeweled ornaments marvelously arranged, covered with gold, of beautiful and elegant appearance, able to go a thousand leagues without getting tired. Or they give away well-bred horses, which give happiness and pleasure to the rider, with perfect speed,[lxxxviii] travelling quickly in the four directions, of the ideal height, beautiful and elegant as if divine, with all their ornaments.

de dag sbyin zhing gtong ba na gus pas skye bo bla ma dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang pha ma dang dbul po dang phongs pa dang slong ba dang len pa'i 'gro ba thams cad la lhug par gtang ba'i sems dang gzung ba med pa'i sems nas/ snying rje chen pos phyogs su khyab pa'i rgyud kyis gtong ba chen po tshad med pa byang chub sems dpa'i yon tan dag la nan tan byed pa dang / rigs btsun pa byang chub sems dpa'i bsam pa yongs su spyod cing sbyin par byed do/ /

They give them away and renounce them, with devotion, to their gurus and spiritual teachers, to their parents, to the poor, to the destitute and to beggars, and to all that lives. They give with free and generous minds, with minds that let go and do not grasp,[lxxix] with fully developed great compassion, making an earnest effort to attain the abilities of a bodhisattva’s immeasurable great renunciation. They give while purifying the higher intention that is worthy of a bodhisattva.

de ltar sems can dag la stan sbyin zhing gtong na rgyal po'i khri bzang po bai DUr+ya'i rkang pa can/ seng ges brten pa gser gyi tha gu dang rin po che'i dra ba'i bla re dang gos 'jam po du ma bting ba nye 'khor spos kyi snying po thams cad kyis shin tu dri zhim par byas pa/ nor bu'i rgyal po sna tshogs kyi rgyal mtshan du ma bsgreng ba/ rin po che bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du ma'i rgyan bkod pa/ gser gyi dra ba'i bla re bres pa/ gser gyi dril bu g.yer kha'i dra ba 'khrol ba'i sgra yid du 'ong ba'i dbyangs 'byung ba/ rin po che'i 'bru bye ba khrag khrig phrag bcus kun nas bskor te rnam par phye bas shing tu 'phags shing blta na mdzes pa/ srog chags bye ba khrag khrig grangs med pas kun nas blta ba/ gdugs kheb gcig gis sa chen po thams cad skyong bar dbang bskur ba rgyal srid kyi dbang phyug thams cad la dbang ba'i stan du bya ba/ de la 'dug cing 'khor lo thogs pa med pas bskyang ba dang chis bya ba la rgyal po'i bka' thams cad nyams pa med par nyan pa de lta bu'i sten gyi rnam pa sbyin par byed do/ /

In the same way, bodhisattvas give away and renounce chairs: royal thrones, with feet of lapis lazuli, supported by lions, with cushions covered with gems and gold braid, strewn all around with many soft cloths, made very fragrant with all kinds of perfume essences, with many raised banners decorated with royal gems, with marvelous arrays of a hundred thousand quintillion[xc] gem ornaments, covered with canopies draped with gold braid, with nets of golden bells and bangles that make an enchanting ringing sound. Each throne is covered with a parasol.[xci] All those who sit on such seats are anointed with royal sovereignty over all the lords of the entire earth, and turn the wheel of government without obstruction; their commands are heard accurately, and they act as overlords with all royal power.[xcii] And so on up to:

de ltar byang chub sems dpa' gdugs rnams sbyin pa na/ rin po che chen po'i bkod pas rab tu brgyan pa/ rin po che'i yu ba can dril bu g.yer kha'i dra bas kun nas khebs pa rin po che'i srad bu dang rna rgyan dang mgul rgyan gyi phreng bas khugs can du gyur pa/ nor bu dang bai DUr+ya'i phreng ba mngon par dpyangs pa/ nye 'khor na dga' ba'i dbyangs dang yid du 'ong ba'i sgra 'byung ba/ gser gyi dra ba rnam par dag pas nang logs khebs par byas pa/ rin po che'i thur ma'i rgyan brgya stong bres pa nor bu rin po che'i mdzod kun du 'dzin pa/ a ka ru dang / tsan+dan dang / spos kyi dam pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du mas nye 'khor dri zhim por bsgos shing bdugs pa/ 'dzam bu'i chu bo'i gser ltar 'od gsal zhing dag pa/ rgyan bye ba khrag khrig mtha' yas pas brgyan pa'i gdugs de 'dra ba rnams dang / de bas kyang ches lhag pa'i gdugs bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du ma dang / /kha na ma tho ba med pa'i sems kyis sbyin par byed cing /

[29] In the same way, bodhisattvas give away and renounce parasols, elaborately decorated with marvelous arrays of large gems, having jeweled handles, covered with nets of bells and bangles, with garlands of jewel earrings and necklaces wrapped all around them, with strings of gems and lapis lazuli hanging down, making delightful and enchanting sounds. The insides are covered with completely pure gold braid. Each parasol has a hundred thousand gem-decorated spokes and comes with a treasury of gems. They are scented with aloe,[xciii] sandalwood, and many hundred thousand quadrillions of the best perfumes, all clothed in and scented by fragrant odors. They are radiant and pure like the finest gold.[45] With indifferent minds, bodhisattvas give away, renounce, and pour forth innumerable hundreds of thousands of quadrillions of parasols of this kind, each with a hundred thousand quadrillion ornaments, and even better ones.

sems can thams cad kyi gtso bo mngon du gyur pa'am/ de bzhin gshegs pa yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa'i mchod rten brgyan pa'i phyir ram/ chos btsal ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen nam/ byang chub sems dpa' chos smra ba btsun par bya ba dag gam/ pha dang ma'am dge 'dun dkon mchog gam sangs rgyas thams cad kyis bstan pa nas/ len pa po thams cad kyi bar dag la 'bul ba dang yongs su gtong ba dang ster bar byed pa dang / sbyin par byed pa na/ de dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag 'di ltar yongs su bsngo ba ste zhes gsungs pa dang / re zhig ji ltar yongs su bsngo ba dang por/ dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad kyi skabs nas ji skad du/ smon lam 'di lta bu yang 'debs te/ ci nas dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di dag rnam par dag par chos kyi mtha' klas par 'gro ba thams cad la nye bar 'tsho ba dang phan par gyur cig / des na dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di dag gis sems can thams cad kyi sems can dmyal ba'i ngan song rgyun chad par gyur cig / dud 'gro'i skye gnas pa dang / gshin rje'i 'jig rten gyi sdug bsngal ba'i phung po rnam par log par gyur cig ces smon lam 'debs so/ /

These bodhisattvas present them either to the best of sentient beings whom they themselves encounter; or to the Tathāgatas who have passed into Nirvāṇa, to ornament their holy shrines; or to their spiritual teachers, in order to seek teachings; or to worthy bodhisattvas who teach the Dharma; or to their own parents; or to that jewel, the community; or to the whole Buddhist religion; or, finally, {they let gifts fall in the midst of} all those who will accept them, {and provide for their needs.} When they give in this way, they dedicate those wholesome actions as follows, according to the first dedication formula. Just as was taught in the introduction, with all their wholesome actions, they make a vow, thinking: “How can these wholesome actions, these pure virtues, nourish and benefit all living things, so that these wholesome actions will put an end to bad rebirths in the hells for all sentient beings? How can they be set free from animal wombs, and from the world of Yama,[46] and from this mass of suffering?”

dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag yongs su bsngo ba na/ dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag 'di ltar yongs su bsngo ste/ dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis bdag sdug bsngal gyi phung po bzlog pa'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi gnas su gyur cig / nyon mongs pa thams cad las yongs su dgrol ba'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi skyob par gyur cig / 'jigs pa thams cad las bsrung ba'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi skyabs su gyur cig / sa thams cad kyi rjes su 'gro ba'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi rten du gyur cig / shin tu grub pa dang bde ba thob par bya ba'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi dpung gnyen du gyur cig / rab rib med pa'i ye shes kun du bstan pa'i phyir sems can thams cad la snang bar gyur cig / ma rig pa'i mun pa bzlog pa'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi sgron mer gyur cig / shin tu rnam par dag pa la rab tu dgod pa'i phyir sems can thams cad la gsal bar byed par gyur cig / chos nyid bsam gyis mi khyab pa la gzud pa'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi 'dren par gyur cig / sgrib pa med pa'i ye shes kyi phung po nye bar bstan pa'i phyir sems can thams cad kyi yongs su 'dren par gyur cig /

When they dedicate their wholesome actions, they do so as follows: “By this wholesome action, may I be a resting place for all sentient beings, in order to stop this mass of suffering. May I be a protector for all sentient beings, so that they let go of all reactive emotions. May I be a refuge for all sentient beings, in order to protect them from all forms of fear. May I be a path[xciv] for all sentient beings, so that they arrive at all the Stages. May I be a friend and ally[xcv] for all beings, so that they attain unlimited peace.[xcvi] May I be sight for all sentient beings, so that they see with pristine awareness, free from eye disease.[xcvii] May I be a lamp for all sentient beings, to put an end to the darkness of ignorance. May I be a ray of light for all sentient beings, in order to establish limitless purity. May I be a guide for all sentient beings, so that they enter the teaching and way of life[xcviii] that the intellect can’t figure out. May I be a leader for all sentient beings, in order to show them all the aspects of undistorted pristine awareness.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de yang bsam pa thag pa nas yongs su bsngo ba'i tshig tsam gyis ni ma yin no/ / de yang dga' ba'i sems kyis yongs su bsngo'o/ / mgu ba'i sems kyis yongs su bsngo'o/ / dang ba'i sems dang / rab tu dga' ba'i sems dang / mnyen pa'i sems kyis yongs su bsngo'o/ / byams pa'i sems dang / mdza' ba'i sems dang / phan gdags pa'i sems dang / phan pa'i sems dang / bde ba'i sems kyis yongs su bsngo'o/ /

[30] Due to their higher intention, they dedicate goodness in this way—and not in words alone. They dedicate goodness with exalted minds, with minds that are delighted, confident, joyful, and loving, with their minds full of lovingkindness, full of love, full of kindness, full of well-being, and happy.

de 'di ltar yongs su bsngo ste/ bdag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis sems can thams cad kyi 'gro ba rnam par dag par gyur cig / skye ba rnam par dag par gyur cig / bsod nams kyi che ba'i bdag nyid yongs su dag par gyur cig / zil gyis mi non par gyur cig / yongs su zad pa med par gyur cig / thub par dka' ba'i sems dang ldan par gyur cig / brjed pa med par gyur cig / rtogs pa dang blo gros dang / nges pa dang ldan par gyur cig / blo tshad med pa dang ldan par gyur cig / lus kyi las dang ngag gi las dang yid kyi las yon tan gyi rgyan thams cad yongs su rdzogs pa dang ldan par gyur cig / bdag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis sems can de dag thams cad sangs rgyas thams cad mnyes par byed par gyur cig / mnyes par byas nas kyang mi mnyes par mi byed par gyur cig / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag thams cad la dad pa mi phyed pa thob par gyur cig / de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas de dag las chos bstan pa nyan par gyur cig / mnyan nas kyang the tshom thams cad rnam par ldog par gyur cig / ji ltar thos pa bzhin 'dzin par gyur cig / bzung nas kyang sgrub pa rdzogs par byed par gyur cig / de bzhin gshegs pa de dag thams cad sten par byed par gyur cig / sems las su rung ba yang thob par gyur cig / kha na ma tho ba med pa'i las rnams yang dag par sgrub par byed par gyur cig / bdag nyid dge ba'i rtsa ba chen po rnams la 'jog par gyur cig / shin tu dbul ba thams cad rnam par bzlog par gyur cig / nor bdun rnyed pa yongs su rdzogs par gyur cig / sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rjes su slob par gyur cig / dge ba'i dbang po thob pa rtogs par gyur cig / rgya chen po la mos pa mnyam pa nyid yongs su sgrub par gyur cig / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi go skabs thob par gyur cig / 'gro ba thams cad la thogs pa med pa'i mig skyed par gyur cig / mtshan thams cad rgyan gyis brgyan pa'i lus rdzogs par yongs su thob par gyur cig / yon tan thams cad kyi rgyan dang ldan pa'i ngag yongs su dag pa yongs su 'dzin par gyur cig / dbang po bsdams pa dang / stobs bcu dang ldan pa'i sems dge ba yang dag pa bsgrub par gyur cig / mi rten par gnas pa yongs su rdzogs par gyur cig / sangs rgyas thams cad bde ba'i yo byad gang dang ldan pa'i bde ba'i yo byad de sems can thams cad kyis thob par gyur cig ces bstan pa dang /

[31] They dedicate goodness in the following way: “May this wholesome action of mine purify the paths of all sentient beings. May it purify their births. May it purify their greatness of goodness. May they not be overpowered. May they not be exhausted. May they have unconquerable minds. May they have undistracted mindfulness. May they have knowledge, intelligence, and confidence. May they have limitless intelligence. In thought, word, and deed, may they fully perfect all the abilities that are ornaments. By this wholesome action of mine, may all sentient beings please all the Buddhas, and having pleased them, may they not then do anything displeasing. May they come to attain stable faith in those Blessed Ones, the Buddhas. From those Tathāgatas, those Saints, the genuinely and fully Awakened, may they hear teachings, and then completely get rid of all their doubts. May they remember what they have heard. Keeping it in mind, may they completely put it into practice. And may they study under those Tathāgatas. May their minds be fit for the task. May they correctly carry out blameless actions. May they perform great wholesome actions. May they get rid of their extreme poverty and obtain and fully complete the Seven Riches.[47] May they train under all the Buddhas. May they attain the faculties of goodness. May they fully attain balanced confidence in the exalted. May they gain access to the pristine awareness of complete knowing. May they develop the unobstructed eye that sees all living beings. May they attain[xcix] a perfect body ornamented with the marks of a great person. May they have the ornaments of all abilities and purity of speech.[c] With restrained senses, may they gather the ten powers and attain mental health. May they perfect the unattached life. Whatever causes of happiness all Buddhas have, may all sentient beings attain those causes of happiness.”

de bzhin du yongs su bsngo ba drug pa las gsungs pa'i tshul gyis yongs su bsngo ba ste/ sems can thams cad chags pa med par zhugs pa'i sems dang ldan zhing ye shes kyi zas can du gyur cig / zas la zhen pa med cing zas yongs su shes pa dang ldan pa dang / dga' ba za zhing zang zing med pa'i zas dang ldan pa nas/ 'dod pa la sred pa rab tu ldog pa'i bar du gyur cig / sems can thams cad chos kyi khu shugs dang ldan pa'i sprin las char 'bebs pa dang / chos kyi dga' ba bla na med pas sems kyi rgyun tshim par gyur cig / sems can thams cad ro bro ba thams cad la chags pa med cing ro la mtshan mar mi 'dzin par gyur cig /

In the same way, he dedicates in the sixth manner stated, as follows: “May all beings live on pristine awareness and have minds endowed with detachment. May they make an effort in paying attention to food. May they live on not coveting and eat bliss. May they live on spirituality and completely turn away from desire and craving. May the nectar of the Dharma rain down from clouds on all sentient beings, and may they be delighted by the unexcelled joy of the teachings. May all beings taste the best of all flavors,[ci] but may they not be attached to any concepts about flavor.

sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la sems 'jug pa dang / theg pa ma nyams pa dang ldan pa dang / theg pa mchog dang ldan pa dang / theg pa dam pa dang ldan pa dang / theg pa myur ba dang ldan pa dang / theg pa stobs chen po dang ldan par gyur cig / sangs rgyas la dga' ba 'thob cing sems can thams cad kyis mthong na ngoms mi shes par gyur cig / sems can thams cad dge ba'i bshes gnyen mthong zhing sems kyi rgyud la gnod pa med par gyur cig / sems can thams cad kyi dug sel ba'i sman gyi rgyal po lta bur snang zhing sems can thams cad nyon mongs pa'i dug bzlog par gyur cig / sems can thams cad kyi mun pa dang rab rib kyi ling tog sel ba'i phyir/ sems can thams cad kyis nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor shar ba lta bur mthong bar gyur cig /

May they reflect on all the teachings of the Buddhas; and may they find the fortunate Way, the highest Way, the best Way, the swift Way, the Great Way.[cii] May all sentient beings be loved by the Buddhas and have an insatiable wish to see them. May all sentient beings not be agitated during audiences with spiritual teachers. May all sentient beings look healthy, like Bhaiṣajyarāja; and may they counteract the poison of the reactive emotions. May all sentient beings appear like the risen disk of the sun, clearing up the darkness, vitreous floaters, and cataracts[ciii] of everyone.”
