ces de ltar bdag nyid nges par brtags nas rang gi bsam pa dang mthun par brjod par bya ste/ sems can thams cad mngon par mdzes pa mthong bar yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad tshul khrims kyi dri dang ldan pa dang mi chod pa'i tshul khrims dang / byang chub sems dpa'i pha rol tu phyin pa dang ldan pa'i tshul khrims can du gyur cig / sems can thams cad gtang ba thams cad yongs su gtong ba can du gyur te sbyin pas bsgos par gyur cig / sems can thams cad mi 'khrugs pa'i sems rnyed cing bzod pas bsgos par gyur cig / sems can thams cad brtson 'grus chen po'i go bgos shing brtson 'grus kyis bsgos par gyur cig / sems can thams cad da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas mngon sum du bzhugs pa'i ting nge 'dzin thob cing bsam gtan gyis bsgos par gyur cig / sems can thams cad byang chub sems dpa' yongs su bsngo bas bsgos par gyur cig / sems can thams cad dkar po'i chos thams cad kyis bsgos par gyur cig / sems can thams cad ye shes chen po thob par bya ba'i phyir mi dge ba'i chos thams cad spangs shing lha'i mal cha thob par gyur cig / sems can thams cad so so'i skye bo ma yin pa'i byang chub kyi sems kyis bsgos pa'i phyir 'phags pa'i mal cha thob par gyur cig / sems can thams cad 'khor bar gtogs pa'i sdug bsngal thams cad yongs su spang ba'i phyir bde ba'i mal cha thob par gyur cig / sems can thams cad chos la reg pa dang ldan zhing nyams bde ba'i mal cha thob par gyur cig /

[32] One should definitely understand all this, and then, in a manner appropriate to one’s own practice,[48] one should recite: “I dedicate goodness so that all sentient beings look splendid. I dedicate so that they look happy and so that they look beautiful. I dedicate so that they appear as they wish; so that they appear to be rejoicing; so that they don’t look depressed; and so that they appear as Buddhas.[civ] May all beings have the fragrance of moral discipline—moral discipline that cannot be broken—the moral discipline that is one of a bodhisattva’s perfections. May all sentient beings be clothed in generosity, giving away everything that one should renounce. May all sentient beings be clothed in patient endurance,[cv] having developed an unshakeable intention. May all beings be clothed in perseverance, armored in the Way of great perseverance. May all beings be clothed in meditative stability[cvi] and attain the meditative absorption of resting face to face with the Buddhas of the present.[49] May all sentient beings be clothed in the dedication of goodness of the bodhisattvas. May all sentient beings be clothed[cvii] in all bright virtues, having abandoned all unwholesome qualities. May all sentient beings attain divine rest,[cviii] so that they can reach great pristine awareness. May all sentient beings attain the rest of the Noble Ones, because of being clothed in the Awakening Mind that goes beyond the ordinary. May all sentient beings rest peacefully, because of completely abandoning all the suffering of wandering in cyclic existence. May they satisfy their desire for the Dharma {and be able to rest with the happiness of religious experience.}

sems can thams cad yon tan gyi gnas dang legs par ldan zhing gnas dang gnas las bskyod de sangs rgyas kyi gnas bla na med pa dang mi 'bral zhing / sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su dag pa snang ba la gnas par gyur cig / sems can thams cad sangs rgyas la nye bar brten cing gnas par gyur cig / sems can thams cad sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la snang ba mtha' yas pa thob par gyur cig / sems can thams cad chos kyi dbyings thams cad gcig tu rgyas par 'gengs shing thogs pa med pa'i snang ba can du gyur cig / sems can thams cad de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku thob cing lus la nad med par gyur cig / sems can thams cad rnam par mi 'khrugs pa'i chos can du gyur cing sman gyi rgyal po lta bur gyur cig / sems can thams cad 'gro ba gso ba la zhugs shing thogs pa med pa'i sman gyi rgyal po lta bur gyur cig / sems can thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa'i nad med pa thob cing nad dang zug rngu 'gags par gyur cig / sems can thams cad bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du sman sbyor byed par gyur cig / 'gro ba thams cad kyi sman la mkhas par gyur cig /

May all sentient beings move from their homes into pure and splendid Buddha fields, well endowed with good dwellings, the mansions where Noble Ones dwell, the unsurpassed, imperishable abodes of Buddhas. May all sentient beings live relying on the Buddhas. May all sentient beings have limitless visions[cix] of all the qualities of the Buddhas. May all sentient beings illuminate the whole universe with unobstructed splendor. May all sentient beings have healthy bodies, attaining the bodies of the Tathāgatas. May all sentient beings be completely free from disturbances, like Bhaiṣajyarāja. May all sentient beings be like efficacious medicine trees,[cx] having taken on the task of healing all living things. May all sentient beings destroy all sickness and pain, attaining the health of complete knowing. May all sentient beings become skilled in medicine, able to bring about through practical application of medicine whatever cures they intend to achieve.

sems can thams cad kyi nad thams cad bzlog pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad mthu dang stobs yongs su mi zad pa'i lus dang ldan par yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad khor yug gi ri ltar brdzi ba med pa'i lus kyi stobs dang ldan par yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad stobs thams cad kyis brtan pa la chog mi shes par yongs su bsngo'o/ /

I dedicate goodness in order to end all the illnesses of all sentient beings. I dedicate so that all sentient beings will have bodies of limitless strength and power. I dedicate so that they gain bodily strength that cannot be crushed, like the Cakravāla Mountains.[50] I dedicate so that all sentient beings will not be satisfied with relying on brute strength.

sems can thams cad snod tshad med par gyur cig / sems can thams cad nam mkha'i khams ltar rgya che ba dang / dran pa'i dbang po dang ldan pa dang / 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i tshig thams cad bzung zhing blang ba la dran pa rmongs pa med par gyur cig / sems can thams cad 'das pa dang ma byon pa dang da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas thams cad kyi byang chub la dad pa mi phyed pa mchog 'dzin cing dge ba rnam par dag pa'i snod du gyur cig / sems can thams cad sangs rgyas kyis kun du 'gro ba 'thob cing dga' dgur 'gro bar gyur cig / sems can thams cad sems can kun la khong khro ba med pa dang ldan pa'i sems su gyur cig / sems can thams cad lhun gyis grub par sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad yongs su khyab par 'gro zhing sems kyi skad cig gcig la chos kyi dbyings thams cad non par gyur cig / sems can thams cad ngal ba med pa'i yid kyi lus thob cing ngal ba dang dub pa med par 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du 'gro bar gyur cig / sems can thams cad byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa thams cad rjes su tshol zhing bde bar 'gro ba la 'jug par gyur cig /

[33] May all sentient beings be flawless vessels [for the Dharma,] vast like the realm of space and endowed with the faculty of memory. May they accept all the worldly and transcendent teachings, and because of remembering and accepting them, may they never be ignorant. May all sentient beings meditate on what is beautiful and pure;[cxi] may they have unswerving faith in the Awakening of all Buddhas of the past, present, and future. May all sentient beings attain the all-pervading stage of Buddhahood and have all their desires fulfilled.[cxii] May all sentient beings have minds that are free from any anger towards anyone. May all sentient beings effortlessly see all Buddha fields, stepping over everything in one moment of thought. May all sentient beings attain the mental body that is not subject to fatigue, and be able to go to all the world-realms without getting tired.[51] May all sentient beings walk in happiness, pursuing all aspects of a bodhisattva’s way of life.

dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis sems can thams cad byas pa gzo ba dang byas pa rjes su skyong bas dge ba'i bshes gnyen mi gtong ba'i sems mi 'dor bar gyur cig / sems can thams cad dge ba'i rtsa ba mthun par 'dzin pas dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnams dang don gcig par gyur cig / sems can thams cad dge ba'i bshes gnyen bsten pa phun sum tshogs pa la gnas pa sems su 'jug pa'i dge ba'i bsam pa can du gyur cig / sems can thams cad smon lam gcig tu gyur te dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i las kyi rnam par smin pa rnam par dag par gyur cig / sems can thams cad theg pa chen po la zhon zhing yang dag par zhugs nas thogs pa med par thams cad mkhyen pa'i mthar 'gro bar shog shig / sems can thams cad dge ba'i rtsa bas shin tu khebs shing sangs rgyas thams cad kyis mngon sum du bsrung ba dang yongs su sba ba thob par gyur cig / sems can thams cad yon tan dang ye shes kyis mngon par khebs shing nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa thams cad las ldog par gyur cig / sems can thams cad legs par byas pa rnam par ma 'khrugs shing dkar po'i chos can du gyur la sangs rgyas kyi chos kyi rgyun nyams pa med par gyur cig / sems can thams cad stobs bcu'i bla re dang ldan zhing gdugs lta bur gyur cig / sems can thams cad byang chub kyi khri stan shin du thob par gyur cig / sems can thams cad sangs rgyas rnam par rol pa'i seng ge'i gdan khri thob cing 'gro ba thams cad kyis blta ba'i 'os su gyur cig ces gsungs pa yin no/ /

By this wholesome action, may all sentient beings remember what their spiritual teachers have done for them, and protect those achievements, so that they never even think of giving up their teachers. May all sentient beings perform similar wholesome actions as their spiritual teachers and share the same aims with them. May all sentient beings have good aspirations and dwell in the perfect completeness {of the teachings} because of following their spiritual teachers and living with them. May all sentient beings have one single vow and be purified by the maturation of their spiritual teachers’ wholesome actions. May all sentient beings correctly enter into and travel on the Great Way, and without encountering obstacles, may they reach the destination of complete knowing. May all beings perform wholesome actions; may they obtain the protection of all the Buddhas.[cxiii] May all sentient beings be covered with abilities and pristine awareness, having turned away from reactive emotions and secondary reactive emotions.[cxiv] May all sentient beings not break or throw away their bright qualities; may the continuity of the Buddhas’ virtues[cxv] be unimpaired in them. May all sentient beings have the ten powers, which are like an umbrella or a canopy. May all sentient beings attain the throne of unlimited Awakening. May all sentient beings attain a Buddha’s mighty lion throne and gaze down upon all living things.
'phags pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi mdo las kyang / bdag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba'am chos la mkhas pa gang yin pa de sems can thams cad kyi nye bar 'tsho bar mi 'gyur bar ma gyur cig ces gsungs so/ /
The noble Gaganagañja Sūtra also says, “May I not have any wholesome action, any knowledge of the teachings, or any skill, that is not used to nourish all sentient beings.”

'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba btang ba ni/ 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las/ dge ba'i sems dang sems las byung ba rnams rjes su dran la rjes su dran nas kyang byang chub tu yongs su bsngo ba la mkhas pa 'di ni 'das pa la mkhas pa'o/ / gang ma 'ongs pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba nges par sems shing byang chub la mngon du phyogs pa'i las la sems pas bdag la dge ba'i sems bskyed pa 'byung ba gang yin pa de dag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu yongs su bsngo'o zhes gsungs so/ / de ltar goms pa'i sems las byung bas thams cad btang ba la mos pa yongs su rdzogs nas gtong ba'i sems kyi shugs dang 'brel pas lus yongs su btang bas yongs su 'dzin pa thams cad gtong ba ni/ yongs su 'dzin pa'i rtsa ba las byung ba'i sred pa'i sdug bsngal las rnam par grol ba la grol ba zhes bya'o/ / bar du yang bskal pa gzhal du med cing grangs med par 'jig rten pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i bde ba phun sum tshogs pa khyad par du 'phags pa rnam pa sna tshogs mtha' yas pa yang myong bar 'gyur ro/ / rang gi lus la sogs pa mchil pa'i gzan lta bur bdag longs spyod par mi 'dod pa des kyang gzhan dag drangs nas sgrol lo/ / de'i phyir 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las kyang sbyin pa ni byang chub sems dpa'i byang chub po zhes gsungs so/ /

As for giving away your past and future good, the noble Akṣayamati Sūtra says: [34] Remembering wholesome thoughts and mental states, and having remembered them, dedicating them to Awakening—this is skill in relation to the past. Thinking, “Whatever wholesome thoughts will arise in me in the future, and whatever wholesome actions I will definitely know, awaken to, or pay attention to, I dedicate them to highest genuine full Awakening”—this is skill in relation to the future. In this way, by fully perfecting your commitment[cxvi] to giving away the mental states you have developed, through the strength you gain through thoughts of renunciation, and by giving away your body, you let go of all forms of grasping. Someone who is free from the suffering of existence[cxvii] whose roots are all forms of grasping is said to be “free.” In the meantime, during countless aeons, you experience endless types of worldly and transcendent happiness and success as they rain down. And, having baited the iron hook of desire with your own body and with the pleasures you no longer want, you pull others out and save them as well. As the Cloud of Jewels says: “For a bodhisattva, generosity is Awakening.”
bslab pa kun las btus pa las sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'i le'u ste dang po'o// //
Discipline
tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa

d.crumb: 2. dam pa'i chos yongs su bzung ba

f.d: [dam pa'i chos yongs su bzung ba'i le'u ste gnyis pa]
2. Upholding the Holy Dharma
de ltar lus la sogs pa btang ba 'di dag kyang bsrung bar bya ste/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar/ /
THE THINGS SUCH as your body and so on that you are going to give away—you also need to protect them. Why? Because—

sems can rnams kyis longs spyad phyir/ / lus la sogs pa sbyin par bya/ / ma bsrungs longs spyod ga las 'ongs/ / gang mi spyod pas ci zhig sbyin/ / de bas sems can longs spyod phyir/ / lus la sogs pa bsrung bar bya/ /

[5] The body and so on are given For the use of sentient beings. If they are not protected, how can they be used? If they can’t be used, what kind of gift is that? [6ab] Therefore, you should protect your body and so on, So that they can be useful to sentient beings.

byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las/ shA ri'i bu gzhan bsrung ngo snyam na bdag bsrung bar bya'o/ / de bzhin du shA ri'i bu byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po phan pa 'dod pa dang ldan pas srog gi phyir yang sdig pa'i las mi byed do zhes bya ba'i bar du gsungs so/ / khyim bdag dpal byin gyis zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / khur gyi don du shing rta ltar chos kyi blo 'ba' zhig gis gzung bar bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / de bzhin du 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa'i mdo las kyang / sems can la lta bas lus kyi sdug bsngal gyis yongs su mi skye'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas says: Śāriputra, people who think “I will protect others” should protect themselves. Bodhisattvas[i] who have this kind of desire to help others don’t carry out vile actions even at the cost of their own lives. Also, the Inquiry of Vīradatta (Vīradatta-paripṛcchā) says, “Hold on to [the body] as if it were a cart, for the sole purpose of carrying loads, with thoughts of Dharma.”[ii] Similarly, the Akṣayamati Sūtra says, “They don’t grow weary because of bodily pain, thinking of sentient beings.”[iii]

lus la sogs pa de ltar bskyang zhe na/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen mi gtang zhing / sdong po bkod pa'i mdo las/ 'phags pa dpal 'byung gis ji skad bstan pa lta bu ste/ rigs kyi bu dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis yang dag par zin pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni ngan 'gror mi ltung ngo / / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis bsams pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa dang 'gal bar mi byed do/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis bskyangs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni 'jig rten las mngon par 'phags pa yin no/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen la bsnyen bkur byas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni spyod pa thams cad la mi brjed par spyod pa yin no/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis yongs su bzung ba'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni las dang nyon mongs pa rnams kyis thub par dka' ba yin no/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen ni bya ba dang bya ba ma yin pa rnams khong du chud par byed pa'o/ / bag med pa'i gnas las yang dag par bzlog pa'o/ / 'khor ba'i grong khyer nas 'don pa'o/ /

[35] And how should you protect your body and so on? By not abandoning your spiritual teacher. As the Noble One Śrīsaṃbhava said in the noble Array of Stalks Sūtra,[1] Noble sir, bodhisattvas who relate appropriately to a spiritual teacher don’t fall into bad rebirths. Those who pay attention to their spiritual teacher don’t transgress against the bodhisattva training. Those who are protected[iv] by a spiritual teacher rise up out of the world. Those who respectfully attend a spiritual teacher practice all aspects of the bodhisattva’s way of life without getting distracted. Those who are sustained by a spiritual teacher are not easily overcome by karma and reactive emotions. Spiritual teachers make you understand {what to do and} what not to do, and restrain you from the causes of heedlessness. They let you out of the city of cyclic existence.

rigs kyi bu de lta bas na de ltar yid la bya ba rgyun mi 'chad pas dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnams kyi drung du 'gro bar bya'o/ / khur thams cad bkur bas yongs su mi skyo ba'i phyir sa lta bu'i sems dang / mi phyed pa'i phyir rdo rje lta bu'i sems dang / sdug bsngal thams cad kyis mi bsgul ba'i phyir khor yug lta bu'i sems dang / las thams cad nyams su blang ba la mi smod pas 'jig rten gyi bran lta bu'i sems dang / nga rgyal dang che ba'i nga rgyal rnam par spong bas phyag dar blta bu'i sems dang / khur lci ba bkur bas theg pa lta bu'i sems dang / mi khro bas khyi lta bu'i sems dang / 'gro zhing 'ong bas yongs su mi skyo bas gru lta bu'i sems dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi ngor lta bas bu mdzangs pa lta bu'i sems kyis dge ba'i bshes gnyen la bsnyen bkur bya'o/ /

[36] Therefore, noble sir, continuously reflecting in this way, you should approach spiritual teachers. Respectfully honor them with a mind like the earth, which bears all burdens without being shaken; with a mind like a diamond, whose intention is unbreakable; with a mind like a great mountain range, not trembling before any kind of pain. Respectfully honor them with a mind like a servant to the world, taking up all kinds of work and not putting anyone down; with a mind like a wearer of rags,[v] free from pride and arrogance; with a mind like a vehicle, carrying heavy burdens to the end;[vi] with a mind like a dog, not getting angry; with a mind like a ship, not getting tired while going and coming; with a mind like a good son, gazing at the face of the spiritual teacher.

rigs kyi bu khyod kyis rang la ni nad pa'i 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen la ni sman pa'i 'du shes dang / rjes su bsten pa la ni sman gyi 'du shes dang / nan tan nyams su blangs pa la ni nad 'tsho ba'i 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis rang la ni 'jigs pa'i 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen la ni dpa' bo'i 'du shes dang / rjes su bstan pa la ni mtshon cha'i 'du shes dang / nan tan la ni dgra sel ba'i 'du shes bskyed par bya'o zhes bya ba'o/ /

Noble sir, you should think of yourself as a sick person, of your spiritual teachers as doctors, of the practice instructions as medicine, and of spiritual practice as the cure for the disease. And you should think of yourself as a coward, of your spiritual teachers as heroes, of the practice instructions as weapons, and of spiritual practice as the destruction of your enemies.

yang de nyid las dge bsnyen ma mi g.yo ma'i rnam par thar pa las kyang / rigs kyi bu dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis rjes su bstan pa la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams thugs mnyes par 'gyur ro/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi tshig dang mi 'gal bar gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la thams cad mkhyen pa nye bar 'gyur ro/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi tshig la the tshom med pa la dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnams nye bar 'gyur ro/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen yid la byed pa dang ma bral ba la don thams cad mngon du 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

In the same text, in the “Liberation of the Laywoman Acala” chapter, this is described further:[2] Noble sir, when a bodhisattva carries out a spiritual teacher’s practice instructions, the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, are pleased. When a bodhisattva does not disobey the words of a spiritual teacher, complete knowing becomes imminent. When someone does not doubt the words of a spiritual teacher, all spiritual teachers come close. When someone pays attention to a spiritual teacher, all benefits are within sight …

de nyid kyi phyir 'phags pa nor bzang gis dge slong rgya mtsho'i rgyal mtshan gyi rkang pa gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te/ lan brgya stong du mar bskor ba byas nas dge slong rgya mtsho'i rgyal mtshan la btud de phyag 'tshal nas/ yang dang yang blta zhing yang dang yang mngon par blta ba dang / phyag bya ba dang / rab tu 'dud pa dang / gus par bya ba dang / rim gror bya ba dang / yid la bya ba dang / bsam pa dang / bsgom pa dang / yongs su bsgom pa dang / ched du brjod pa ched du brjod pa dang / ngo mtshar du bya ba dang / yon tan mngon du bya ba dang / rjes su bsngags pa dang / rjes su 'brang bar bya ba dang / rjes su dran par bya ba dang / brtan par bya ba dang / mi gtong ba dang / yid la bsam pa dang / nye bar 'brel par bya ba dang / smon lam gyi rjes su 'jug par bya ba dang / mthong bas dga' ba dang / dbyangs kyi mtshan ma gzung ba dang / gzugs kyi rjes su bsam pa dang / ming yongs su gzung ba'i rjes su song ba'i sems dang ldan par bya ba dang / kha dog dang dbyibs rjes su dran par bya ba dang / ye shes kyi yul rjes su bsam pa dang / ting nge 'dzin gyi yul la rjes su 'jug par bya ba dang / smon lam gyi yul la rjes su 'brang bar bya ba dang / spyod yul gyi yul rnam par dpyad par bya ba dang / ye shes kyi snang ba yongs su gzung bar byed cing dge slong rgya mtsho'i rgyal mtshan gyi drung nas song ngo / /

For this reason, the noble Sudhana saluted the monk Sāradhvaja’s[3] feet with his head, and did many hundreds of thousands of circumambulations. He gazed upon the monk and prostrated to him; he looked at him over and over while continually prostrating, paying homage and bowing down; he paid attention to his teachings, reflected on them, meditated on them and contemplated them; he made an inspired utterance and cried out in admiration.[vii] He thought about the teacher’s abilities, praised them, brought them to mind without fear, and went over them in his mind, forming a close connection with them, making the recollection firm and not abandoning it.[viii] He made a vow. He rejoiced at the sight of the teacher, noticing the distinctive characteristics of his voice.[ix] He departed from the presence {of the monk Sāradhvaja.}…[4]

de bzhin du dge ba'i bshes gnyen las 'ongs pa'i thams cad mkhyen pa nyid la yang dag par blta zhing gdang mchi mas gang bar ngus te/ dra byi la sprin la lan brgya stong du mar bskor ba byas nas yang dang yang bltas te phyag 'tshal zhing dra byi la sprin gyi drung nas song ngo / /

[37] In this way, coming away from the spiritual teacher, seeing the teacher’s complete knowing, crying with a tearful face, {he did many hundreds of thousands of circumambulations, looking at the teacher over and over and prostrating to him.} Then he departed from the presence of Megha the Dravidian.[5]

byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las kyang / shA ri'i bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' ni/ mkhan po dang slob dpon la gus pas gang yongs su mi gtong pa'i rin po che de 'jig rten na med do/ / gang lus kyis rim gro mi bya ba de med do/ / gang rkang pas gtong ba la mi spro ba de med do/ / gang ngag gi las la mi spro ba de med do/ /

The Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas also says, Śāriputra, out of desire for the teaching, there is no treasure in the world that bodhisattvas would not give up; there is no bodily service they would not do; there is no errand they cannot run; there is no action of speech they cannot perform, out of respect for their spiritual and academic teachers
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ chos 'di ni 'ching ba thams cad gcad par 'gyur ba'o/ / chos 'di ni skye ba dang rga ba dang na ba dang 'chi ba dang mya ngan dang smre sngags 'don pa dang sdug bsngal ba dang yid mi bde ba gcod par 'gyur ba'o snyam nas rin po che'i sems bskyed do/ / chos 'di ni sems can thams cad kyi nad nye bar zhi bar byed par 'gyur bas bdag gis sems can thams cad kyi nad nye bar zhi bar byed pa'i chos 'di lta bu 'dod par bya'o snyam mo zhes gsungs so/ /

Why is this? They turn toward this teaching in order to cut off their fetters. They turn toward this teaching in order to cut off birth, old age, illness, and death, sorrow and lamentation, pain and suffering. They think of the teaching as a treasure. They turn toward this teaching, thinking of it as medicine to cure all the sickness of all sentient beings.

khyim bdag drag shul can gyis zhus pa las kyang khyim bdag gal te byang chub sems dpa' lung klog pa dang kha ton bya ba don du gnyer bas sbyin pa dang tshul khrims dang bzod pa dang brtson 'grus dang bsam gtan dang shes rab dang ldan pa'am byang chub sems dpa'i lam gyi tshogs sogs pa dang ldan pa'i tshig bzhi pa'i tshigs su bcad pa su las mnyan tam lung mnos sam blangs pa'i slob dpon de la des chos kyi gus pa bya'o/ / ming dang tshig dang yi ge ji snyed kyi tshigs su bcad pa de bstan pa de snyed kyi bskal par gal te slob dpon de la g.yo med par rnyed pa dang bkur sti dang mchod pa thams cad kyis rim gro dang bsnyen bkur byas kyang khyim bdag da dung slob dpon la slob dpon gyi gus pa yongs su rdzogs pa ma yin na chos kyi gus pa lta ci smos zhes gsungs so/ /

Furthermore, the Inquiry of Ugra says, Leading merchant, if a bodhisattva, while studying, hears from someone else, recites after her, or learns from her a single verse of four lines having to do with generosity, moral discipline, patient endurance, perseverance, meditative stability, and wisdom, or having to do with gathering the equipment for the bodhisattva path,[x] then he should pay religious respect to that teacher. Suppose he sincerely serves and attends that teacher for one aeon for every verse he learned, or one aeon for every line, or word, or letter, with all material gifts, honor, and veneration. Even then, leading merchant, the ordinary respect he owes to that teacher is not completed; what need even to speak of religious respect?

shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa brgyad stong pa las kyang / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis dge ba'i bshes gnyen la shin tu gus pa bskyed par bya'o/ / phangs par bya'o/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu de lta bu'i rang bzhin gyi yon tan dag dang bla ma la gus pa yid la byed pa dag dang ldan pas song nas mthar gyis grong khyer gzhan zhig tu phyin pa dang / de'i grong bar gyi tshong 'dus kyi dbus su phyin nas de 'di snyam du sems te/ 'di ltar bdag gi lus btsongs la/ de'i rin gyis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags la bkur sti bya'o/ / yun ring po nas bdag gi lus stong zhig cing zad de btsongs so/ / 'khor ba dpag tu med pa nas 'dod pa'i phyir 'dod pa'i rgyus yang dang yang sems can dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal dpag tu med pa dag myong yang 'di lta bu'i chos kyi phyir ram 'di lta bu'i sems can chen po dag la bkur sti bya ba'i phyir ma yin no snyam mo/ /

The Perfection of Wisdom in Eight Thousand Lines says:[6] [38] Noble sir, you should respect and cherish your spiritual teachers. Indeed, the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita[7] was a man of that kind, having abilities, paying respectful attention to spiritual teachers. As he was travelling from place to place in due order, he arrived at another city. When he arrived in the middle of the marketplace of that town, this thought occurred to him: “Suppose I were to sell my body, and with the price it would fetch, do honor to the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata? In fact, for a long time, during immeasurable cyclic existence, countless thousands of bodies of mine have been broken, have wasted away, and have been sold, {and I have experienced the immeasurable suffering of the hells,} for the sake of desire, because of desire. On the other hand, I have not [made any such sacrifices] in order to develop virtues,[xi] or in order to show respect to great beings.”
de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngus grong bar gyi tshong 'dus kyi dbus su 'dug ste/ mi su 'dod mi su 'dod ces sgra bsgrags shing skad kyis thos par bos so/ /
Then the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita, standing in the middle of the marketplace, called out in order to make his voice heard: “Who wants a man? Who wants a man?”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de nas bdud sdig can gyis ci nas bram ze dang khyim bdag de dag gis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngus mi su 'dod mi su nga nyo bar 'dod ces zer ba'i sgra mi thos par 'gyur ba de lta bur yongs su bsgribs so/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu gang gi tshe bdag nyo ba ma rnyed pa de'i tshe phyogs gcig tu song nas mchi ma phyung ste 'di ltar bdag gi lus btsongs la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags la bkur sti bya snyam na/ lus nyo ba yang bdag gis ma rnyed de/ kye ma bdag ni thob pa ngan pa thob bo snyam nas/ de nas lha'i dbang po brgya byin 'di snyam du sems te/ de ltar byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu 'di lta ste chos 'dod pa'i phyir bdag gi lus yongs su gtang bar lhag pa'i bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa yin nam ma yin pa/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu la bdag gis sad par bya'o snyam ste/ lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis bram ze'i khye'u'i cha byad du mngon par sprul nas/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu ga la ba der song ste 'ongs nas/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu la 'di skad ces smras so/ / rigs kyi bu khyod 'di ltar yid mi dga' zhing yid gdung la mchi ma 'byung ba ci nyes/ des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u nga ni chos 'dod pa'i phyir bdag nyid btsongs te/ chos la mchod pa bya bar 'dod na/ lus nyo ba de ngas ma rnyed nas de la nga 'di snyam du sems so/ / kye ma nga ni bsod nams chung bas 'di ltar lus btsongs te/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la mchod par bya ba dang / 'phags pa byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags la yang bkur sti bya snyam na bdag gi lus nyo ba ma rnyed do snyam mo/ /

Then the wicked Māra came near, and completely obscured Sadāprarudita’s calls {of “Who wants a man? Who wants to buy me, a man?”,} so that the Brahmins and leading merchants did not hear him. When he could not find a purchaser for himself, he walked away from that place, cried out, and began to weep, saying “Oh no! This is a misfortune, that I cannot find anyone to buy this body, {so as to show respect to the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata.}” {Then Indra, king of the gods, had this thought: “The bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita, for the sake of his desire for the Dharma, wishes to give up his own body—but is this higher intention fully complete or not? I will test the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita.}[8] So Indra, king of the gods, appeared in the form of a young Brahmin boy, and spoke to the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita as follows: “Noble sir, why do you stand here with a distressed mind, with a sorrowful mind, crying tears?” Sadāprarudita said, “Young Brahmin, I am trying to sell this body out of desire for the Dharma, so that I can perform religious worship. But I cannot find a buyer for it.”[xii]

de nas bram ze'i khye'u des byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu la 'di skad ces smras so/ / rigs kyi bu nga la mis ni bya ba med kyi/ nga mchod sbyin zhig byed de der mi'i snying dang khrag dang rus pa dang rkang dag nga la dgos na de rin gyis nyor byin cig ces byas pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu 'di snyam du sems te gang bdag gis bram ze'i khye'u des/ snying dang khrag dang rus pa dang rkang nyo ba rnyed pa 'di ni bdag gis rnyed pa'i mchog legs par rnyed do/ / bdag ni shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang thabs mkhas pa la yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro snyam nas/ des sems dga' ba dang sems bde ba dang sems rab tu dga' bar gyur nas/ bram ze'i khye'u la 'di skad ces smras so/ / bram ze'i khye'u nga'i lus 'di las khyod gang 'dod pa sbyin no/ / des de la 'di skad ces smras so/ / rigs kyi bu khyod rin du ci 'dod pa sbyin no zhes byas pa dang / des de la 'di skad ces smras so/ / bram ze'i khye'u khyod kyis gang yongs su gtang ba de nga la byin cig / de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngus mtshon rnon po thogs nas/ lag pa g.yas pa phug ste khrag gzags so/ / brla g.yas pa sha med par btogs nas rus pa gcog tu rtsig pa'i drung du song ngo / /

[39] Then that young Brahmin said to the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita, “Noble sir, I have no use for a man myself, but my father is going to perform a sacrifice, and for that we need a human heart, blood, bones, and marrow. Will you give me these things for a price?” The bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita thought, “This is a good find for me![xiii] I will completely develop the Perfection of Wisdom and skill in means, because I have found a buyer for my heart, blood, bones, and marrow.” With a pleased mind, with a prepared mind, with a joyful mind, he said to the Brahmin boy, “Young Brahmin, I will give you from my body whatever you have a use for.” {He asked, “For what price will you sell these things?” “Young Brahmin, give me whatever you will pay.”} Then the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita, wielding a sharp knife, pierced his right arm so that the blood flowed out.[xiv] He cut the flesh off his right thigh and went up to a wall to break his bones against it.

de nas tshong dpon gyi bu mo zhig khang pa'i yang thog na 'dug pa des/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu brla'i sha med par btogs nas/ rus pa gcog tu rtsig pa'i drung du song ba mthong nas de 'di snyam du sems te/ rigs kyi bu 'di ci'i phyir bdag nyid la bdag nyid 'di lta bu'i na tsha byed pa bdag rigs kyi bu de'i drung du song ste dri'o snyam nas tshong dpon gyi bu mo de byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu ga la ba der song ste phyin nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu la 'di skad ces smras so/ / rigs kyi bu khyod ci'i phyir khyod bdag nyid la 'di lta bu'i na tsha dag byed/ khrag dang rus pa dang rkang 'dis ci zhig bya/ rtag tu ngus bu mo de la 'di skad ces smras so/ / bram ze'i khye'u 'di la btsongs te/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la mchod par bya'o/ / 'phags pa byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags la yang bkur sti bya'o/ /

Just then, the daughter of a guild president[9] who was standing on the upper roof of her mansion saw the bodhisattva Sadāprarudita.[10] That guild president’s daughter then approached the bodhisattva Sadāprarudita and said, “Noble sir, why do you injure yourself in this way? {What will you do with this blood, bone, and marrow?” Sadāprarudita said to the girl, “I’m selling this to a young Brahmin, so that I can venerate the Perfection of Wisdom and show respect to that Noble One, the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata.”}[xv]

de nas tshong dpon gyi bu mo des byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu la 'di skad ces smras so/ / rigs kyi bu khyod 'di ltar bdag gi snying dang khrag dang rus pa dang rkang yang btsongs te rigs kyi bu de la bkur sti bya bar 'dod pa/ khyod la yon tan gyi rnam pa ci zhig 'grub par 'gyur/ des de la smras pa bu mo rigs kyi bu de gang la ngas bslab par bya ba'i shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang thabs la mkhas pa dag ston par 'gyur te/ de la ngas bslabs na bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas nas sems can thams cad kyi rten du 'gyur ro/ /

Then that girl, having heard this religious intention, said “{Noble sir, when you sell your own heart, blood, bones, and marrow in this way, to show respect to him,} what kind of abilities will you develop?” He said to her, “Young woman, I will train with that gentleman, and he will teach me the Perfection of Wisdom and skill in means. As a result of that training, {I will attain highest genuine full Awakening} and become a refuge for all sentient beings.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de nas tshong dpon gyi bu mo des byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu la 'di skad ces smras so/ / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis 'di ltar chos rgya chen po 'di dag yongs su brjod pa ni ngo mtshar te/ rigs kyi bu chos 'di lta bu re re'i phyir yang bskal pa gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed du lus yongs su gtang bar bya ba yin na gcig lta ci smos te/ de tsam du khyod kyis chos 'di dag rgya cher yongs su brjod na rigs kyi bu khyod gang gis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags la bkur sti bya ba'i gser ram nor bu'am mu tig gam bai DUr+ya'am zhes bya ba nas bdag kyang khyed kyis stsal ba'i g.yog mo lnga brgya 'di dag dang lhan cig tu chos 'phags la mchod pa bgyi ba'i slad du mchi'o zhes bya ba'i bar du rgya cher sbyar ro/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags stan las langs te/ bdag gi khyim du zhugs pa dang zhes bya ba nas/ lo bdun gyi bar du ting nge 'dzin gcig la snyoms par zhugs te zhes bya ba'i bar dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu yang lo bdun gyi bar du 'dod pa'i rtog pa ma byung / gnod sems kyi rtog pa ma byung / rnam par 'tshe ba'i rtog pa ma byung / ro la brkam pa ma skyes te/ gzhan du ni byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags nam ldang bar gyur/ bdag cag kyang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags kyi chos kyi khri gang la rigs kyi bu de 'dug nas chos ston par 'gyur ba'i chos kyi khri bshams na/ bdag gis sa phyogs 'di chag chag ma btab kyis legs par byugs la me tog sna tshogs gtor te/ sa phyogs gang du byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang thabs mkhas pa rab tu ston par 'gyur ba der legs par byug par bya'o snyam mo/ /

Then the guild president’s daughter said to the bodhisattva Sadāprarudita, “Amazing, noble sir! The teachings you speak of are beautiful and lofty. Noble sir, for the sake of even one teaching of this kind, you should give up all your bodies for as many aeons as there are sands in the Ganges River. {How much more so should you give up just this body!} That is how beautiful and lofty the teachings you speak of are. But on the other hand, noble sir, I will give you whatever you need to show respect to the bodhisattva Dharmodgata: gold, gems, pearls, or lapis lazuli, as much as you need. And I will go with you, and my five hundred servant women will come too, and together we will venerate the bodhisattva Dharmodgata.” …[11] [40] Then the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata rose from his seat and went to his own house.[12] For seven years, he was in a state of equilibrium, resting in a single meditative absorption. During those seven years, the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita did not arouse any thoughts of sensual desire, nor any thoughts of malice, nor any thoughts of violence. He did not arouse any greed for tastes, other than this thought: “When the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata gets up, we will prepare a Dharma throne for him where that gentleman will sit and teach the Dharma. We will sprinkle the ground around the throne with water, and moisten it well, and we will strew it with various flowers.”[xvi]

tshong dpon gyi bu mo la sogs pa bu mo lnga brgya de dag dang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu'i rjes su slob cing spyod lam gnyis kyis dus 'da' bar byed pa bya ba thams cad kyang de'i rjes su 'jug go/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngus lha'i sgra thos te/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags ni zhag bdun na ting nge 'dzin las langs te/ langs nas kyang grong khyer gyi dbus su 'dug ste chos ston par 'gyur ro zhes grag nas/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu lha'i sgra de thos pa dang / dga' mgu yid rangs rab tu mgu zhing dga' ba dang yid bde ba skyes te/ tshong dpon gyi bu mo la sogs pa bu mo lnga brgya dang / sa phyogs de phyags nas/ chos kyi khri rin po che thams cad kyis spras pa bshams so/ / de nas bu mo de dag gis rang rang gi bla gos phud de stan gang la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags 'dug nas chos ston par 'gyur ba der bting ngo / /

During that time the five hundred women led by the guild president’s daughter, following the bodhisattva Sadāprarudita, spent their time in only two bodily postures.[13] Then the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita heard a voice from the sky, saying “Seven days from now, the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata will arise from meditative absorption and go to the middle of the city. He will sit down there and teach the Dharma.” When he heard that voice, the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita was overwhelmed with joy, bliss, and happiness. He swept the ground there, and then, along with the five hundred women led by the guild president’s daughter, he prepared a Dharma throne made of the seven precious substances. {Then the five hundred women, thinking, “This is the seat where Dharmodgata will sit and teach the Dharma,” took off their upper robes and laid them down there.}

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngus sa phyogs der chag chag gdab par 'dod na/ bdud sdig can gyis chu thams cad mi snang bar byas nas/ ci nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngus chu ma rnyed nas yid mi dga' zhing sems sdug bsngal te sems gzhan du 'gyur ba dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba nub par 'gyur ba dang / mchod pa de yang mi mdzes par bya ba'i phyir chu de dag mi snang bar byas nas/ kun du chu btsal na ma rnyed do/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu 'di snyam du sems te/ bdag gi lus phug la khrag gis sa phyogs 'di chag chag gdab po/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sa phyogs 'di ni rdul che ste/ rdul gyi khams 'di nas byung bas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'phags kyi lus la phog na mi rung na/ bdag gi lus gdon mi za bar 'jig pa 'dis ci zhig bya/ bdag gi lus 'di lta bu'i bya ba la zhig pa ni bla'i/ nus pa med pa'i bya ba la 'dod pa'i phyir 'dod pa'i gzhis 'khor ba dag na bdag gi lus brgya stong mang po de lta bu'i gnas su zhig pa ni cir yang mi rung ngo snyam mo/ /

[41] Then the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita wanted to sprinkle that place on the ground, but when he looked around in the vicinity, he could not find any water, because the wicked Māra had made all the water invisible. He did this so that Sadāprarudita, not finding any water, would experience mental pain and suffering or change his mind, so that his wholesome actions would disappear or would not shine forth. But then this thought occurred to the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita: “What if I cut my own body and sprinkle this place with blood? For what reason? This place on the ground is very dusty. May no dust from here fall on the body of the bodhisattva great being Dharmodgata! What can be done with this body, which will inevitably die? It is better that my body be destroyed through an action of this kind, and not through an action that does not accomplish anything. While going around in measureless cyclic existence, many thousands[xvii] of bodies of mine have been broken again and again for the sake of sensual pleasures, because of sensual pleasures. {To die for any reason of that kind makes no sense.} But if my bodies will now be broken again in the same way, may they be broken for the sake of Dharma!”[xviii]

de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngus mtshon rnon po blangs te/ bdag gi lus kun du phug nas rang gi khrag gis sa phyogs de khor yug tu chag chag btab bo/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu'i rjes su slob pa tshong dpon gyi bu mo la sogs pa bu mo lnga brgya po de dag thams cad kyis kyang mtshon rnon po blangs te rang rang gi lus phug nas rang rang gi khrag gis sa phyogs de chag chag btab ste/ gang de dag la bdud sdig can gyis dge ba'i phyogs kyi bar chad bya bar glags rnyed par mi 'gyur bas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rtag tu ngu dang bu mo de dag sems gzhan du 'gyur ba med do zhes gsungs so/ /

Then the bodhisattva great being Sadāprarudita, wielding a sharp knife, pierced his own body all over. He sprinkled that place on the ground with his blood. The women did the same. And in the minds of Sadāprarudita and those women, there was no disturbance where the wicked Māra could find an entrance.

de bas na chos bzhi pa'i mdo las kyang / dge slong dag byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos dge ba'i bshes gnyen srog gi phyir yang yongs su gtang bar mi bya ba dang / zhes gsungs so/ / de ltar dge ba'i bshes gnyen mi btang bas bdag la sogs pa bsrung ba la sogs pa bya'o/ /

The Sūtra on Four Qualities (Catur-dharmaka-sūtra) also says: “Monks, as long as her life lasts, a bodhisattva should not abandon her spiritual teacher, even if her life is at risk.” In this way, you should protect your body and so on,
mdo sde dag la rtag blta bas/ / lus la sogs pa bsrung bar bya/ /
[6cd] By not abandoning your spiritual teacher, and by constantly reading the sūtras.

mdo sde dag la blta bas kyang ste/ byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i gzhi rnams ni phal cher mdo sde dag las snang ste/ mdo sde de dang de dag las byang chub sems dpa'i kun du spyod pa dang byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'i gzhi rnams bcas so zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / de lta bas na de ma bltas na ltung ba 'byung ba yang mi shes pas mi spong bar 'gyur bas rtag tu mdo sde blta ba la gus par bya'o/ / des na 'dis ni dge ba'i bshes gnyen mi gtang ba dang / mdo sde blta bas dam pa'i chos yongs su gzung bar brjod pa yin no/ /

It is said that a bodhisattva’s training precepts are mostly found in sūtras; and in all those sūtras, the practices of bodhisattvas and the training precepts of bodhisattvas are declared. Since this is the case, if you don’t read them, downfalls could arise, and because of ignorance, you may not develop renunciation. So you should always pay attention[xix] when reading the sūtras. Everything of this kind, such as not abandoning the spiritual teacher and reading the sūtras, is called “upholding the holy Dharma.”[xx]

'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las/ rigs kyi bu 'on kyang yi ge'i nges pa'i tshig gang dag gis brjod du med pa 'dus ma byas kyi chos de bsnyad pa'i yi ge'i nges pa'i tshig de dag gang len pa dang / 'dzin pa dang / ston pa dang / rab tu shes par byed pa dang / 'jog pa dang / rnam par 'grel pa dang / rnam par 'byed pa dang / gsal bar byed pa dang / yang dag par rab tu ston pa 'di ni dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa zhes bya'o/ /

As the noble Sāgaramati Sūtra says, Whatever[xxi] words and explanations[xxii] he uses to point to the inexpressible[xxiii] Dharma, remembering those words and explanations, teaching them to others,[xxiv]—this is called “upholding the holy Dharma.”

rigs kyi bu gzhan yang chos smra ba gang dag mdo sde 'di lta bu 'di dag 'dzin pa dang / ston pa dang sgrub pa snying por byed pa'i chos smra ba de dag la gang bsnyen pa dang brten pa dang bsnyen bkur byed pa dang ldan pa dang rim gro byed pa dang / gus par byed pa dang / zhes byed pa dang / bsti stang byed pa dang / kun tu srung ba dang / sbed pa dang / yongs su 'dzin pa dang / gos dang zas dang mal cha dang na ba'i gsos sman dang yo byad sbyin pa dang / legs so zhes bya ba sbyin pa dang / rje bo ltar kun tu bsrung ba dang / dge ba kun tu bsrung ba dang / bsngags pa brjod pa dang / mi snyen pa 'chab pa 'di yang dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa'o/ /

Moreover, noble sir, as for those Dharma teachers who teach scriptures of this kind[xxv] and practice them to the core, studying with such teachers; relying on them; showing them respect and devotion; paying attention to them;[xxvi] protecting them; upholding them; giving them necessities, including robes, food, bedding, and medicine for the sick; saying “sādhu”;[14] protecting their supremacy;[xxvii] protecting their virtuous lives; speaking their praises; concealing their faults—all of this is also upholding the holy Dharma
de bzhin du sbyar te/
rigs kyi bu gzhan yang rtsod pa med pa lhur len pa dang / chos ma yin pas rtsod pa rnams chos dang mthun par tshar gcod pa 'di yang dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa'o/ /
[42] Moreover, noble sir, while being preeminently free from strife, to defeat those opposed to the Dharma in debate, in a way harmonious with Dharma, is also upholding the holy Dharma.

rigs kyi bu gzhan yang zhe sdang med pa'i rgyud dang / sems can thams cad bsdu ba dang rab tu thar bar bya ba'i blo dang zong zing med pa'i sems kyis gzhan dag la chos sbyin pa 'di yang dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa'o/ /

Moreover, noble sir, if your personality is free from hatred and your mind is free from desire,[xxviii] if your intention is to liberate all beings, giving Dharma teachings to others is also upholding the holy Dharma.
de bzhin du sbyar te/
rigs kyi bu gzhan yang gang chos mnyan pa'i rgyu'am chos bstan pa'i rgyur tha na gom pa gcig 'dor ram tha na dbugs gcig 'byin tam rngub kyang rung ste/ 'di yang dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa'o/ /

Moreover, noble sir, to walk even a single step, to draw in or let out even one single breath, either for the purpose of listening to the Dharma or for the purpose of teaching the Dharma, is also upholding the holy Dharma
rigs kyi bu gzhan yang gang chos thams cad yongs su mi 'dzin cing mi len pa 'di yang dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa zhes bya'o/ /
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rigs kyi bu kye ma'o sems 'di ni phyin ci log gi yul la rab tu 'phyar ba ste/ gang de zlog pa dang yongs su bsrung ba dang rtse gcig tu 'gyur ba dang dul ba dang zhi ba dang nye bar zhi ba dang / 'dul ba 'di ni dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa zhes bya'o/ /

Alas, noble sir! Your mind has gone astray among objects. Turning the mind back, guarding it, helping it to become one-pointed, taming it, calming it, pacifying it, and disciplining it—this is upholding the holy Dharma
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /
rigs kyi bu gzhan yang chos gang gis chos gang 'byung ba'i chos de yongs su mi 'dzin pa dang mi len pa 'di ni dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa bzhin no/ /
Moreover, noble sir, whenever a quality produces effects contrary to Dharma, not upholding that quality, and not taking it up, is also upholding the holy Dharma.

de la chos smra ba la brten pa la sogs pas dge ba'i bshes gnyen mi gtang ba dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi mtshan nyid ni bshad zin to/ / de'i phyir dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa 'di med na/ srung bar mi 'gyur dag par mi 'gyur/ 'phel bar mi 'gyur la/ de'i phyir de yang byang chub sems dpar mi 'gyur bas/ nges par dam pa'i chos yongs su gzung bar bya'o/ /

Here, relying on a Dharma teacher and so on, as above, is called “not abandoning your spiritual teacher”; and this relationship defines what it is for someone to be your spiritual teacher. Therefore, without upholding the holy Dharma in this way, there can be no protection, no purification, and no enhancement. And then you are not a bodhisattva. So upholding the holy Dharma is necessary work.

dpal phreng seng ge sgra'i mdo las kyang / / bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed gang lags pa de dag ni smon lam chen po gcig gi nang du 'ub cing 'dus te rjes su zhugs pa lags te 'di lta ste dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin par ro/ / bcom ldan 'das de ltar na dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa ni yul chen po lags so zhes gsungs so/ /

The Lion’s Roar of Queen Śrīmālā (Śrīmālā-siṃhanāda-sūtra) says:[15] Blessed One, the bodhisattva vows, as numerous as the grains of sand in the Ganges River, are all gathered together in, included in, and based on one great vow, which is upholding the holy Dharma. Blessed One, upholding the holy Dharma is a great matter.[16]

yang de nyid las/ lha mo 'di lta ste dper na skyes bu stobs chen po dang ldan pas/ gnad du mi drag par bsnun na yang gnod par 'gyur zhing mi bde bar byed do/ / lha mo de bzhin du dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa chung ngus kyang bdud sdig can la gnod par 'gyur zhing mya ngan skyed de smre sngags 'don par byed par 'gyur ro/ / lha mo 'di ltar dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa chung ngus kyang bdud sdig can la gnod par 'gyur zhing sdug bsngal bskyed de/ smre sngags 'don par byed pa de lta bu'i chos gzhan ni ngas gcig kyang ma mthong ngo zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text also says: [43] Your Majesty, for example, even if a man is very strong, a blow at a vital point can injure him and cause him distress. In the same way, Your Majesty, when someone upholds even a small part of the holy Dharma, the wicked Māra is injured, feels sorrow, and cries out. Your Majesty, I do not see any other single wholesome state that can injure the wicked Māra in the same way, bring him sorrow and, make him cry out, like upholding even a small part of the holy Dharma.[17]

yang de las/ lha mo 'di lta ste dper na ri'i rgyal po ri rab kyi gnam 'phang dang zheng rgyas ri nag po thams cad zil gyis mnan nas kun du thal le zhing mngon par thal le 'dug go/ / lha mo de bzhin du theg pa chen po pa lus dang srog la mi lta ba gzung ba med pa'i sems dang ldan pa'i dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pas kyang / theg pa chen po pa theg pa la gsar du yang dag par zhugs pa lus dang srog la lta ba dang bcas pa rnams kyi dge ba'i chos thams cad zil gyis gnon no zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

The same text also says: Your Majesty, for example, Mt. Meru, the king of mountains, predominates over all the multitude of mountains,[xxix] outshines them, and manifestly exceeds them, both in height and in width. In the same way, Your Majesty, when a practitioner of the Great Way who has no regard for her own body or life and whose mind does not grasp at anything upholds the holy Dharma, she outshines all the wholesome states of those who are newly practicing the Great Way and still care about their bodies and lives.[18]
de skad du 'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / /
In the same way, the noble Sāgaramati Sūtra also says:
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / rgyal ba rnams kyis yongs su gzung bar 'gyur/ / lha dang klu dang mi'am ci rnams dang / / bsod nams ye shes kyis ni yongs su gzung / /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Will be protected by the Victors, By the gods, the serpent-spirits, and the half-humans; They will be protected by goodness and pristine awareness.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / dran ldan blo gros ldan zhing blo ldan 'gyur/ / shes rab rgya chen kun nas ye shes ldan/ / mkhas pa bag chags bcas pa'i nyon mongs spong / /

{Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Become mindful, intelligent, and clever; They have extensive wisdom and utterly pristine awareness, Are learned, and give up reactive emotions along with their underlying patterns.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / de la bdud kyis skyon chags rnyed mi 'gyur/ / de la 'gyod dang de bzhin dogs pa med/ / de la bcings med sgrib pa cung zad med/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / zhing stong dag tu nam yang mi skye ste/ / skye ba kun du des ni rgyal ba mthong / / mthong nas de la dad pa rab tu 'thob/ /
Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Are never born in empty fields;[19] In all their births, they see the Victors, And having seen them, have faith in them.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / chos kyi bdag nyid chen po skye dran 'gyur/ / yang dang yang du rab tu 'byung ba thob/ / spyod pa yongs dag sgrub pa snying por byed/ /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Have the qualities of greatness and remember their past lives; They accept ordination again and again. Their lives are pure and they focus on practice.
de bzhin du sbyar te/
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / tshul khrims thob pas 'phags pa'i chos spyod pa/ / mkhas pa mngon shes lnga la myur du reg / ma sman bsam gtan rnam par thar pa thob/ /

{Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Attain moral discipline and practice the qualities of Noble Ones. They are learned and quickly reach the five superknowledges. They attain freedom and meditative stability that are not inferior.[xxx]
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / de ni zab chos rtogs par khong du chud/ / sangs rgyas spyod yul stong nyid the tshom med/ / sems can bdag med par yang mos par 'gyur/ /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Know that they have realized the most profound matters. They have no doubts about emptiness, the sphere of activity of the Buddhas. They are confident that there is no self in sentient beings.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / de ni so so yang dag rig pa 'thob/ / 'jigs med shes rab rno zhing chags med dag / de ni srog chags kun gyi the tshom gcod/ /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Will each attain correct knowing. Their wisdom is fearless and sharp, free from any attachment. They remove all of the doubts of all living beings.}
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / mkhas pa de ni gzungs rnams thob par 'gyur/ / bskal pa brgyar yang gang thos chud mi za/ / spobs dang ldan zhing chags pa med par 'gyur/ /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Are learned; they attain mnemonic powers. [44] Their good[xxxi] is not exhausted during a hundred aeons. They have presence of mind and are free from attachment.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / de la mkhas pa rtag tu dga' bar 'gyur/ / lha dang lha min mi ci'i yid du 'ong / / de la sangs rgyas bu gcig bzhin du bstod/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / brgya byin tshangs pa de bzhin 'jig rten skyong / / 'khor los sgyur dang mi yi rgyal por 'gyur/ / bde dang yid bdes byang chub de 'tshang rgya/ /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Become Indras, or Brahmās, or World-Protectors,[20] Or they become human kings, or emperors of the world, Or happily awaken to the happiness of Awakening.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / de lus sum cu rtsa gnyis mtshan ldan zhing / / mkhas pa yan lag smad pa med par 'gyur/ / de la lta bas ngoms par yong ma 'gyur/ /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Have the thirty-two marks of a great person on their bodies. They are learned and free from physical disabilities. People just never get enough of seeing them.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / gang yang chos kyi phyag rgya 'di ston pa'i/ / dge ba'i bshes gnyen de la dkon mi 'gyur/ / chos mdzod zad mi shes pa nyan par byed/ /

{For those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas And have taught this Dharma seal, For these spiritual teachers, nothing at all is difficult to obtain; Others will hear teachings from their inexhaustible treasuries of Dharma.[xxxii]
de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / lus dang ngag dang yid kyang rnam par dag / tshul khrims ting 'dzin shes rab rnam par dag / rnam grol ye shes shin tu rnam par dag /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Are fully pure in thought, word, and deed. Their moral discipline, meditative absorption, and wisdom are fully pure. Their liberation and pristine awareness are utterly pure.}

de bzhin gshegs pa'i dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa/ / de ni byang chub sems brjed 'gyur ba med/ / pha rol phyin pa spyod dang 'gal mi 'gyur/ / dge ba brgya rnams kyis kyang rab tu gzung / / zhes 'byung ngo / /

Those who have sustained the holy Dharma of the Tathāgatas Do not forget about the Awakening Mind And do not violate the practice of the perfections. When the topic is presented in full, they have hundreds of wholesome qualities.[xxxiii]
tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i le'u las/ dam pa'i chos yongs su bzung ba'i le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //

d.crumb: 3. chos smra ba la sogs pa bsrung ba

f.d: [chos smra ba la sogs pa bsrung ba]

d.crumb: 3. Protecting the Dharma Teacher and so on

f.d: 3. Protecting the Dharma Teacher and so on
gsum po rnams kyi bsrung ba la sogs pa'i thabs ni spyir bshad zin te/ bsrung ba la sogs pa brjod par bya'o/ /
THE SKILLFUL MEANS for protecting have been stated in general. However, they must be discussed individually.
de la lus bsrung gang zhe na/ gnod 'gyur spong ba gang yin pa'o/ /
[7ab] Here, what is protecting the body? It is giving up what is harmful.[i]

de la zhes bya ba ni dam pa'i chos 'dzin par gnas pa ni/ ji ltar gzhan nyams par mi byed pa de ltar de'i lus bsrung ba dpyad par bya ba yin no/ / gnod par 'gyur ba spong ba 'di yang 'phags pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi mdo las/ byang chub sems dpa' dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa la brtson pa rnams kyis/ /

When you live upholding the holy Dharma, you don’t harm others; in just the same way, you should think about protecting your own body. [45] Giving up what is harmful was explained by the bodhisattvas intent on sustaining the holy Dharma in the noble Gaganagañja Sūtra:
bcom ldan rkang gnyis dam pa ni/ / mya ngan 'das slad bdag cag rnams/ / lus dang srog tu bcas btang ste/ / dam pa'i chos ni gzung bar spro/ /
Blessed One, when the best of bipeds Has entered Nirvāṇa, we are capable Of sustaining the holy Dharma, Without regard for our bodies and lives.
rnyed dang bkur sti spangs nas su/ / rten pa kun kyang rab spangs te/ / sangs rgyas ye shes ston byed pa'i/ / chos 'di yongs su mi gtong ngo / /
dam pa'i chos ni gzung slad du/ / gshe dang mi snyan 'tshe ba dang / / ngan du smra ba'i tshig rnams kyang / / bzod pas de dag dang du blang / /
Criticisms and slanderous claims And offensive words We will endure with forbearance Because we accept the holy Dharma.
tshul 'di rab tu bzung nas su/ / co 'dri ba dang bsdigs pa dang / / mi bsngags pa dang mi snyan pa/ / de dag thams cad bzod par bgyi/ /
Mocking laugher and ridicule, Insulting words of any kind[ii]— All these we will endure, Sustaining this way of life
de bzhin du sbyar te/
dge slong rgyal po rab 'khrug cing / / de ltar rab tu ma rungs pa/ / rnam par 'jig tshe sems can phyir/ / bdag cag dam chos gzung bar bgyi/ /
During very terrible times When kings and monks are in turmoil, In ages of destruction, for the sake of sentient beings, We will sustain the holy Dharma.
mdo sde gang dag rab zab cing / / rnam grol 'bras bur ldan pa rnams/ / rab tu 'dzin par mi bgyid de/ / de dag sna tshogs gtam rnams bgyid/ /
Those who receive the profound scriptures Whose result is freedom Will not be able to understand them; They will say very strange things
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
tshul 'di rab tu bzung nas su/ / gang dag chos la mi gnas pa'i/ / sems can rnams la byams par bgyi/ / de dag la ni snying rje'ang bgyi/ /
While sustaining this way of life We will develop lovingkindness For those who are not committed to the Dharma, And we will have compassion for them.
sems can rnyed dang 'dod gnas pa/ / tshul khrims 'chal pa mthong nas su/ / de yi 'gro ba cir 'gyur zhes/ / mchi ma'ang rab tu dbyung bar bgyi/ /
When we see morally undisciplined sentient beings Who are committed to desire and greed, We will shed tears for them, [46] Meditating on their rebirths, which could be anywhere.[iii]
dam pa'i chos la skur 'debs pa/ / de dag 'phral du mthong na yang / / de dag gshe bar mi 'gyur bas/ / ring nas byams pa btsal bar bgyi/ /
If we suddenly see someone Who deprecates the holy Dharma, May he not get angry at us! We will wish him lovingkindness from afar.
rab tu bsdams nas ngag gi las/ / nyams kyis ci nus bsrung bar bgyi/ / sdig pa la ni rab gnas pa/ / de la glo bur gtam mi bgyi/ /
As much as possible, we will guard Our acts of speech, keeping them under control. We will not speak harshly To those who are committed to their own wrong actions.
nor sbyin de bzhin bsti stang gis/ / mi rnams yongs su smin bgyis nas/ / yang dag sdig med spyod yul gyi/ / slad kyis de dag bskul bar bgyi/ /
With gifts and also with acts of respect, We can help people like that to become more mature, And then we will inspire them To appropriate spheres of activity, free from vile actions.
khyim dang sten pa kun spangs te/ / don nyung ba dang bgyid nyung ba/ / bas mtha' dgon pa'i spyod yul la/ / ri dwags bzhin du 'gyur ba bgyi/ /
Though born in houses,[iv] We will become like deer, Dwelling in wilderness retreats, With little wealth and few obligations
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
dul ba dang ni zhi ba dang / / grol nas grong du zhugs nas kyang / / sems can gang dag chos tshol ba/ / de la bdag cag chos bstan to/ /
Once we are disciplined, peaceful, and free, We will enter the village And teach those sentient beings Who are searching for the Dharma.[v]
chos 'dod par ni rtogs nas su/ / shin tu ring du'ang mchi bar bgyi/ / chos la dga' zhing mos rnyed nas/ / lus can rnams kyi don kyang bgyi/ /
{Once we know that someone wants teachings, We will go even a great distance. Taking delight in the Dharma, having found religious commitment, We will help embodied beings.
sems can rnams kyi 'khrul mang po/ / de dag mngon du mthong nas kyang / / chos dang nges pa rab gnas nas/ / bdag la rab tu brtag par bgyi/ /
Having seen clearly The many forms of confusion of sentient beings, Living with confidence in the Dharma, We will completely understand ourselves.}
bsti stang bgyis dang ma bgyis pa/ / ri rab lta bur gyur nas su/ / 'jig rten gyis ni mi gos pa/ / 'jig rten 'dren par 'gyur bar bgyi/ /
Whether others show us respect or not, Having become like Mt. Meru,[vi] Not stained by the world, We will become guides for the world.
dge slong tshul las nyams rnams kyi/ / mi snyan pa dag rtogs nas kyang / / las ni bdag gir bya bar bgyi/ / de dag las ni smin ma 'gyur/ /
When we hear criticisms of Monks who have broken their vows, May those actions become ours; [47] May their actions not evolve into results.
chos rnams la ni gnas pa la/ / deng la de 'dra'i chos rnams ni/ / ji lta bur yang yod med ces/ / gshed ma dag kyang 'gyed par 'gyur/ /
We will be generous even to executioners, But as for the principles they live by, Principles like that will not Be found in us, not in any way.[vii]
bdag cag ming gi dge sbyong ste/ / dge sbyong yon tan med do zhes/ / yang dag bskul ba thos pa dang / / mdo sde 'di ni spong bar 'gyur/ /
“We are called ‘monks,’ But we do not have the abilities monks should have”— Some people, when they hear truthful admonitions like this, Will throw away this scripture.
sna dang rna chad de dag ni/ / me long dga' bar mi 'gyur ltar/ / yang dag bskul ba thos pa dang / / de dag dam chos spong bar 'gyur/ /
Just as people whose noses and ears have been cut off Don’t enjoy looking in a mirror, When they hear truthful admonitions, They will reject the holy Dharma.
dge slong gang dag dam pa'i chos/ / rab tu 'dzin pa 'byung 'gyur ba/ / de dag de bzhin tshul 'chos te/ / gang yang chos 'di mi nyan to/ /
At that time, those monks who will Have received the holy teachings Will be hypocrites of that kind;[viii] They won’t listen to any of this Dharma.
rgyal po rnams kyang bslu bar bgyid/ / skye bo chen po 'byed 'gyur yang / / sangs rgyas kyis ni byin brlabs kyis/ / sems can de dag chos nyan 'gyur/ /
Kings will also be deceived,[ix] And the population will be divided. But by the power of the Buddha, Some sentient beings will hear the Dharma.
dus ngan de tshe bdag cag rnams/ / sems can dag la phan slad du/ / lus dang srog kyang rab btang ste/ / dam pa'i chos ni gzung bar bgyi/ / zhes brjod pa yin no// //
In that dark age, In order to help sentient beings, Even in bodily pain,[x] having given up our bodies and lives, We will sustain the holy Dharma.[xi]
bam po gsum pa/
'phags pa dam pa'i chos pad ma dkar po las kyang / /
Also, the noble Lotus Sūtra (Saddharma-puṇḍarīka)[1] says:
cho ga spyod yul bsrung bya zhing / / 'du 'dzi med la gtsang bar bya/ / rgyal po dang ni rgyal bu dang / / 'dres byed rtag tu spang bar bya/ /
They should guard their way of life and sphere of activity. They should be solitary and pure. They should always avoid making friends [48] With princes and kings;
rgyal po'i zhabs 'bring gang yin dang / / gdol pa zol ba chang 'tshong dang / / mu stegs can ni de dag dang / / rnam pa kun du 'dris mi bya/ /
They should not make friends, in any way, With the attendants of kings, With untouchables, boxers,[xii] Bartenders, and non-Buddhists.
dge slong 'dul dang lus gnas la/ / dgra bcom snyam du sems byed cing / / nga rgyal can rnams brten mi bya/ / tshul khrims 'chal rnams rnam par spang / /
They shouldn’t study with those arrogant monks, Learned in the scriptures and the monastic code, Believed by others to be Saints; And they should completely avoid immoral monks.
dgod cing smra ba'i spyod yul can/ / dge slong ma rnams rtag tu spang / / mi brtan par ni mngon pa yi/ / dge bsnyen rnams kyang spang bar bya/ /
They should always avoid those nuns Who spend their time on laughter and idle chitchat; They should avoid lay people, Or publicly associating with anyone.
bud med ma ning sems can gang / / de dang 'dris byed rnam par spang / / khyim rnams su ni mna' ma dang / / gzhon nu ma rnams spang bar bya/ /
They should avoid making friends with intersex persons.[xiii] In families, they should avoid Young women[xiv] and girls, And should not engage in conversation with them at all,
khams dang legs par dri byed pa/ / de dag nam du'ang dga' mi byed/ / phag 'tshong pa dang shan pa dang / / 'dris par byed pa rnam par spang / /
Except to ask kindly about their welfare.[xv] They should completely avoid making friends With pork-butchers and sheep-butchers.
de bzhin du sbyar te/
gang dag bud med gso byed dang / / gar mkhan gyad dang sil khrol ba/ / gang gzhan de dang 'dra ba spang / / de dag rnams dang 'dris byed spang / /
They should avoid making friends With those who keep women, With dancers, athletes, and musicians, [49] And other people of that sort.
res ma'i gtso mo bsten mi bya/ / ji snyed longs spyod 'tsho ba gzhan/ / shin tu dga' ba de dag kyang / / rnam pa kun du yongs su spang / /
They shouldn’t associate with madams, Or any people who get their livelihood from sex; They should completely avoid Any interaction with them.
mkhas pas bud med rnams la yang / / gang gi dus na chos 'chad pa/ / der ni gcig pu mi 'gro ste/ / dgod cing 'dug par mi bya'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
And when they are learned, Teaching the Dharma to women, They should not go there alone, Nor sit around laughing.

'di ni gnod pa gzhan yin te/ 'di lta ste bdud kyi las so/ / shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las/ byang chub sems dpa' theg pa la yang dag par zhugs nas ring po ma lon pa de la bdud sdig can shin tu brtson par byed ces gsungs pa dang /

As for other things that are harmful, the actions of Māra are described in the Perfection of Wisdom: “The wicked Māra will make his most powerful effort against a bodhisattva who has not been practicing the Way for long.”

de nyid las/ kun dga' bo gzhan yang gang gi tshe byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la brtson par byed pa de'i tshe/ bdud sdig can rnams ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po 'di nur ba dang spu zing zhes byed par 'gyur zhig gu/ gang gis na 'di bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub las sems bskyed pa gcig tsam la yang 'bri bar 'gyur zhig gu snyam nas byang chub sems dpa' mtho btsams pa nye bar sgrub po/ / 'jigs pa kun du ston te/ phyogs phyogs su skar mda' gtong ngo / / phyogs sreg pa 'byin zhing kun du ston to zhes bya ba dang / gzhan yang rnam par shes pa la 'du shes pas yi ger 'dri ba nas kun chub par byed pa'i bar du byed cing 'di la bdag cag gis ro myang ba mi rnyed do/ / zhes stan las langs te 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du glal ba dang / steg pas kun chub par byed pa'i bar du byed par 'gyur ba ni bdud kyi las so/ /

The same text says: Moreover, Ānanda, at the time when a bodhisattva great being begins to practice the Perfection of Wisdom, Māra and his demons cause him to feel sorrow and know fear.[xvi] They make meteors fall in all directions and fire appear in the sky, thinking “May this bodhisattva great being be discouraged; may his hair stand on end! May the mind he has aroused for highest genuine full Awakening decay!” {Māra makes trouble for him. [If] he conquers him,} then those who can read the thoughts of others will write this down and understand it. Thinking “We will get no taste here,” they will stand up from their seated posture and walk away, yawning and mocking him, fully understanding what has happened. This is Māra’s doing.

de bzhin du ljongs dang grong la sogs pa la rnam par rtog pa dang / de bzhin du mkhan po dang slob dpon dang pha ma dang blon po dang nye du dang snag gi gnyen mtshams yid la byed pa dang / de bzhin du chom rkun yid la byed pa dang / de bzhin du gos la sogs pa yid la byed pa 'byung ngo / / gzhan yang chos smra ba ni shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa zab mo 'di yi ger bri ba nas/ bklag pa'i bar la 'dun par gyur la/ chos nyan pa ni le lo can du gyur pa dang / de las bzlog pa dang / chos smra ba ni yul gzhan du 'gro bar 'dod la chos nyan pa ni de lta ma yin pa yang

In this way, mistaken thoughts[xvii] arise about people and villages. One’s attention turns to spiritual and academic teachers, parents, siblings, friends, family members, and relatives. In this way thoughts about robbers arise, and thoughts about robes and so on. [50] Moreover, a Dharma teacher will become motivated to write and speak about this profound Perfection of Wisdom, but the Dharma students become lazy. Discord arises between them. The Dharma teacher wants to go someplace else, but the students do not
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /
chos smra ba ni 'dod pa che la chos nyan pa ni 'dod pa chung ba yang
The Dharma teacher has great aspirations, but the students have small aspirations.[xviii]
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /
mdor na chos smra ba dang chos nyan pa gnyis kyis mi 'dzom par 'gyur ba de dag thams cad bdud kyi las yin no zhes gsungs so/ /
In brief, any disagreement between the teacher and the students is Māra’s doing.
'phags pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi mdo las kyang / de ltar mi dge ba'i chos kyi rjes su 'jug pa dang dge ba'i chos spong ba de dag thams cad ni bdud kyi las so zhes gsungs so/ /
The noble Gaganagañja Sūtra also says: “Whenever someone indulges in unwholesome qualities and abandons wholesome qualities, all that is Māra’s doing.”

'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / bcom ldan 'das gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' dgon pa par gyur te/ bas mthar gnas mal bca' bar mngon par dga' zhing 'dod pa chung la chog shes pa ste rab tu dben pa/ khyim pa dang rab tu byung ba rnams dang mi 'dre la de don nyung ba dang bgyi ba nyung bas bde bar gnas te g.yo ma mchis kyang / mang du thos pa yongs su btsal ba dang / sems can yongs su smin par bgyi ba dang / chos nyan pa la brtson pa mi gnas pa dang / chos kyi gtam dang don rnam par nges pa'i gtam gyi bar la rgyun dgum par sems te yongs su 'dri ba'i rang bzhin can ma lags/ dge ba ci zhig tshol ba la mi brtson/ de dgon pa la gnas pa dang / gcig pur dga' bas nyon mongs pa rnams kun du mi rgyu ste/ de kun nas ldang ba gnon pa tsam gyis dga' ba thob cing bag la nyal yang dag par gzhom pa'i slad du lam bsgom par mi bgyid de/ de ni bdag gi don dang / gzhan gyi don gyi slad du brtson par mi 'gyur ba 'di ni/ bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa'i dgon pa la gnas pa dang rab tu ldan pa'i bdud kyi lcags kyu ste bdun pa'o/ /

The noble Sāgaramati Sūtra also says: Moreover, Blessed One, sometimes bodhisattvas live in wilderness retreat, taking delight in solitary resting places,[xix] having few desires, contented, alone, associating neither with lay people nor with monks. Because of having few goals and few duties, they live happily {and are undisturbed.} They do not become involved in seeking great learning, and do not help sentient beings to mature. They don’t think about approaching their contemporaries in order to hear the Dharma, or converse about the Dharma, or to talk about fully ascertaining the meaning of the Dharma. They don’t think of any questions to ask.[xx] They do not make an effort to seek for what is wholesome. Because of dwelling in the forest and taking delight in solitude, they do not put their reactive emotions into practice. They are content with merely stopping these emotions from welling up, and do not do any meditation on the path of rooting out reactive patterns. In this way they neither practice for their own benefit nor for the benefit of others. Blessed One, for a bodhisattva living in wilderness retreat, this is the seventh iron hook of Māra
de bzhin du sbyar te/

bcom ldan 'das gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i bshes gnyen ltar bcos pa'i sdig pa'i grogs po gang dag de la bsdu ba'i dngos po rnams las 'dun pa bzlog pa dang / sems can yongs su smin par bgyid pa las 'dun pa bzlog pa dang / dam pa'i chos yongs su bzung ba las 'dun pa bzlog pa dang / bsod nams kyi tshogs las 'dun pa bzlog pa dang / rab tu dben pa la sbyor ba dang / don chung zhing bgyid pa nyung ba la sbyor ba dang / nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dang ldan pa'i bka' mchid de la rgyun du mang du ston pa dang / theg pa chen po dang ldan pa'i bka' mchid de la mi ston pa dag la bsnyen cing bsten te/ bsnyen bkur bgyid pa dang / gang gi tshe byang chub sems dpa' dben par gnas pas theg pa chen po las ldang ba'i tshe/ byang chub sems dpa' gdon mi za bar zhal ta byed par bya'o zhes byang chub sems dpa' zhal ta bgyid pa'i dri ma la sbyor ba dang / gang gi tshe byang chub sems dpa' zhal ta bgyid pa'i dri ma la sbyor ba de'i tshe dben pa la sbyor zhing de la 'di skad du byang chub ni byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus brtsams pa yin gyi le lo can ni ma yin no/ / gal te khyod bskal pa brgyad dam bcus bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs ma rgyas na phyis khyod bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar mi nus so zhes mchi la/ bcom ldan 'das de la byang chub sems dpa' gang sgyid lug nas 'bras bu thob par bgyid pa'i gnas mchis nas/ bcom ldan 'das 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i bshes gnyen ltar bcos pa'i bdud kyi lcags kyu ste bcu pa'o/ /

[51] Moreover, Blessed One, sometimes a bodhisattva spends time with bad friends who appear to be spiritual teachers, studies under them. and attends upon them respectfully. They discourage her from developing the methods of attracting people, from gathering the equipment of goodness, and from upholding the holy Dharma, and then consign her to solitude. They consign her to having lowly goals and lowly things to do. They continually give her teachings having to do with Disciples and Solitary Sages. Whenever the bodhisattva should be living in solitude and making progress in the Great Way, they assign her to work.[xxi] She is required to do this work. And whenever the bodhisattva should be applying herself to work, they consign her to solitude. And they tell her, “Awakening is for bodhisattvas who have developed perseverance, not for those who are lazy. If you do not awaken fully to highest genuine full Awakening during the next eight or nine[xxii] aeons, you will no longer be able to awaken fully to highest genuine full Awakening.” Blessed One, in this case, the bodhisattva becomes discouraged and leaves the abode in which she could have attained the result of Nirvāṇa.[xxiii] Blessed One, for a bodhisattva, such counterfeit spiritual teachers are the tenth iron hook of Māra.
