de las gzhan pa byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa'i gang zag dag bdud kyi lcags kyus zin pa chos ngan pa la spyod pa de dag la dga' ba rnyed pa dang de dag kyang de bzhin du de'i rjes su 'jug par gyur pa dang / de dman pa la bsten cing khyad par dang bral bas 'di lta ste/ zhan pa'i 'gro ba blun pa 'on pa lkugs pa'i 'gro ba 'gro ba dman pa nyid du mchi bar 'gyur te 'di ni bdud kyi lcags kyu bcu gcig pa'o zhes gsungs te/ gang gis de ltar brtson 'grus shin tu brtsams pa skyo bar gyur pas/ rtag tu byang chub sems dpa'i dngos po nyid du mi 'gyur ba'o/ / de bas na dkon mchog sprin las/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa'i spyod lam thams cad du brtson 'grus rtsom pa na/ ci nas lus skyo bar mi 'gyur ba dang sems skyo ba mi 'gyur ba de ltar rtsom ste 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i rtag pa'i brtson 'grus zhes bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Alternately, someone enjoys spending time with other people who are following the bodhisattva way but who have been pierced by Māra’s iron hooks, and who live in accordance with perverse qualities. In this way that person becomes like them, and because of associating with the lowly and not attaining excellence, goes to a low rebirth, becoming weak, stupid, deaf, or dumb. This is the eleventh iron hook of Māra. Therefore, in those who have developed perseverance, because of disenchantment with the world, the state of being a bodhisattva is always present. As the Cloud of Jewels says, “Here bodhisattvas show perseverance in all forms of practice. As they develop it, they do not give rise to any weariness of body, nor to any weariness of mind. This is said to be the continuous perseverance of a bodhisattva.”

gang gis skyo bar 'gyur ba'i brtson 'grus te ci 'dra ba zhig yin zhe na/ gang 'di stobs chung ba las lci ba'am dus ring por rtsom pa'am mos pa yongs su ma smin pa rnams bya dka' ba'i las rtsom pa ste dper na rang gi sha sbyin pa la sogs pa lta bu'o/ / 'dis sems can rnams la lus byin zin mod kyi/ 'on kyang dus ma yin par yongs su spyad pa las bzlog par zad de/ gzhan du na sems can de dag la byang chub sems dpa' skyo bar gyur pas/ byang chub kyi sems kyi sa bon chud za ba'i phyir 'bras bu'i phung po chen po chud za bar 'gyur ro/ /

What kind of perseverance is it by which one becomes weary? This is when someone of little capacity takes on heavy actions at the wrong time, when religious commitment is not fully mature, undertaking difficult actions such as giving one’s own flesh and so on. [In one sense] a bodhisattva has already given away his body to sentient beings. But he turns back from actually doing it at the wrong time. Otherwise, the bodhisattva would become weary, and because the seed of Awakening Mind would go to waste, a great multitude of fruits would be lost to sentient beings.

de'i phyir 'phags pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi mdo las/ dus ma yin par 'dod pa ni bdud kyi las so zhes gsungs so/ / dus ma yin zhes te lus gtang ba'i sems mi bskyed pa nyid kyang ma yin te/ goms pa ma brtsams pa'i phyir nam yang sbyin par mi bya bar 'gyur ro/ / de lta bas na de ltar dran pa nye bar gzhag nas byang chub kyi sems yongs su smin pa dang 'gal ba dang gti mug gis rang gi don la gnod pa dang / sha za ba dang las byed pa rnams la lus bsrung bar bya'o/ / dper na sman shing ljon pa blta sdug pa/ / rtsa ba la sogs spyad 'os sa bon ni/ / sbyin yang dus min spyad las bsrung bya ba/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas sman shing de bzhin no/ / mdor bsdu na bdud kyi las 'di ni gnod pa yin no/ /

Now, the Gaganagañja Sūtra says: “Untimely expectations are Māra’s doing.” You shouldn’t arouse the thought of giving your body at the wrong time. When you have not even begun to actually have proficiency, you should never give away [the body.][xxiv] Therefore, having applied mindfulness in this way, you should protect the body from what stops the full maturation of Awakening Mind, from delusion, and from what kills your own welfare. You should protect the body for the work it can do, and for the benefit of flesh-eaters. For example, just as the roots and seeds, and so on, Of a beautiful medicine tree Even if given away, should be protected from untimely consumption, It’s just the same with the medicine tree of full Awakening. These, in brief, are the harmful actions of Māra.

'di rnam par spang ba ni dkon mchog sprin gyi mdo las/ rigs kyi bu ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' bdud kyi las yongs su spong ba'i thabs la mkhas pa yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' mi dge ba'i bshes gnyen thams cad kyi thams cad du yongs su spong ngo / / mi mthun pa'i yul na gnas pa dang 'jig rten rgyang pan pa'i gsang tshig bsten cing sgom pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti dang mchod pa dang rim gro la chags pa thams cad nas thams cad du yongs su spong ngo / / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang gzhan dag byang chub kyi phyogs kyi lam gyi bar du gcod pa de dag kyang thams cad nas thams cad du yongs su spong ngo / / de dag gi gnyen po yang bsten to zhes gsungs so/ /

As for giving these up, the Cloud of Jewels Sūtra says, [52] Noble sir, this being so, how are bodhisattvas skilled in the methods of giving up the actions of Māra? Here bodhisattvas give up[xxv] bad friends completely and in every way. They completely give up living in unsuitable places; relying on and cultivating the schemes[xxvi] of materialists; money and prestige; the worship and service offered by others; and any attachment to the respect they receive.[xxvii] As for the other secondary reactive emotions that are obstacles to the path that leads to Awakening, they completely give them up in every way, and practice the remedies to them.

de nyid las mi dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi mtshan nyid gsungs pa/ tshul khrims nyams pa'i gang zag rnam par spangs pas sdig pa'i grogs po yongs su spangs par rig par bya'o/ / de bzhin du lta ba nyams pa dang cho ga nyams pa dang 'tsho ba nyams pa'i gang zag rnam par spangs pa dang / 'du 'dzi la dga' ba'i gang zag rnam par spangs pa dang / le lo can gyi gang zag rnam par spangs pa dang / 'khor ba la dga' ba'i gang zag rnam par spangs pa dang / byang chub la rgyab kyis phyogs pa'i gang zag rnam par spangs pa dang / khyim pa dang bsten pa rnam par spangs pas/ sdig pa'i grogs po yongs su spangs par rig par bya ste/ rigs kyi bu des de dag yongs su spong ba'i tshe/ gang zag de dag la sdang ba'i sems bskyed par mi bya'o/ / khong khro ba'i sems dang brnyas pa'i sems bskyed par mi bya'o des 'di ltar bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang sems can rnams ni/ / khams so so ba bsten te/ bsten par gyur nas chud za bar 'gyur ro zhes bka' stsal to/ / de bas na bdag gis bsten pa yongs su spang bar sems nye bar gzhag par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text states the distinguishing characteristics of bad friends: “Giving up[xxviii] bad friends” should be understood to mean avoiding people whose moral discipline is degenerate. It also means avoiding people whose views are degenerate, whose way of life is degenerate,[xxix] or whose livelihood is degenerate; avoiding people who delight in social interactions; avoiding lazy people; avoiding people who take delight in cyclic existence; avoiding people who turn their backs on Awakening; avoiding social interactions with householders—this is the meaning of giving up bad friends. But, noble sir, even when you are trying to avoid them, you should have no thoughts of hostility towards those people, nor of anger, nor any thoughts of contempt. You should fix your thoughts in a different way, as follows, for the Blessed One said: “Due to their traits of character, sentient beings give rise to sensual desires and so on, are born, mix socially with each other, and because of social interactions, they are destroyed.[xxx] Therefore I avoid social interactions.”

byang chub kyi sems brjed pa 'di yang gnod pa yin te/ de'i rgyu ni dkon mchog brtsegs pa las/ 'od srungs byang chub sems dpa' chos bzhi dang ldan pa'i byang chub kyi sems brjed par 'gyur te/ bzhi gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ mkhan po dang slob dpon dang bla ma dang / sbyin gnas la slu ba dang / gzhan 'gyod pa med pa dag la 'gyod pa nye bar sgrub pa dang / theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i sems can rnams la bsngags pa ma yin pa dang mi snyan pa dang brjod pa ma yin pa dang / tshigs su bcad pa ma yin pa 'byin pa dang / sgyu dang g.yos gzhan la nye bar spyod kyi lhag pa'i bsam pas ma yin pa zhes gsungs so/ /

To forget the Awakening Mind is also harmful. The causes of doing so are stated in the Heap of Jewels: [53] Kāśyapa,[2] a bodhisattva who has four qualities will forget the Awakening Mind. What are the four? Lying to spiritual and academic teachers who are worthy of honor; causing others to feel remorse about doing the right thing; making slanderous statements against the fame and reputation of those who are practicing the Great Way; acting dishonestly towards others, not out of higher intention.[3]

'di rnam par spang ba yang de nyid las/ 'od srungs byang chub sems dpa' chos bzhi dang ldan na skye ba thams cad du skyes ma thag tu byang chub kyi sems mngon du 'gyur te/ byang chub kyi snying po la 'dug gi bar du bar ma dor brjed par mi 'gyur ro/ / bzhi gang zhe na 'di lta ste/ srog gi phyir ram tha na bzhad gad kyi phyir yang shes bzhin du rdzun gyi tshig mi smra ba dang / sgyu dang g.yo med par sems can thams cad kyi drung na lhag pa'i bsam pas gnas pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la ston par 'du shes skyed cing de dag gi yang dag pa'i bsngags pa phyogs bzhir brjod pa dang / sems can gang rnams yongs su smin par byed pa de dag thams cad kyang nyi tshe ba'i theg pa mi 'dod par bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub yang dag par 'dzin du 'jug pa ste/ 'od srungs bzhi po de dag go zhes gsungs so/ /

How to give those up is stated in the same text: Kāśyapa, a bodhisattva who has four qualities will come face to face with the Awakening Mind in all births, just by being born, and never forgets it until sitting on the seat of Awakening. Which four? Never telling a deliberate lie even to save your own life;[xxxi] out of higher intention, staying free from dishonesty in the presence of all sentient beings, not even giving them so much as a derisive look; thinking of all bodhisattvas as teachers and speaking their praises in all the four directions; and as for those sentient beings you are helping to mature, encouraging them all not to aspire to limited Ways, but to seek highest genuine full Awakening. These, Kāśyapa, are the four qualities.

seng ges zhus pa las kyang / gang zhig chos kyi sbyin pa la/ / nam yang bar chad mi byed pa/ / de ni des na rab myur bar/ / 'jig rten mgon dang phrad par 'gyur/ / de bzhin du/ chos kyi sbyin pas skye ba dran/ / gzhon nu de ltar shes par gyis/ / zhes gsungs pa dang /

The Inquiry of Siṃha also says, Someone who never creates obstacles To the gift of Dharma, Thereby, very quickly, Will meet the Lord of the World.[4] Young man, you should know That by giving Dharma, you become able to remember your previous lives.[xxxii]

de skad du de nyid las/ skye ba kun du byang chub sems/ / rmi lam na yang sems de ni/ / 'dor mi 'gyur na ma nyal tshe/ / smos ci 'tshal bar gang gis 'gyur/ / bka' stsal pa/ grong dang grong khyer rnams su yang / / gang du gnas pa'i yul rnams su/ / byang chub la ni yang dag 'dzud/ / des na sems 'dor mi 'gyur ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text says, Such people do not lose touch with the Awakening Mind In any of their births, Not even in dreams; How much more so while they are in the waking state? And it says, While in these resting places, And in towns and cities, You reflect on Awakening And therefore don’t lose touch with the [Awakening] Mind.
'phags pa 'jam dpal gyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi yon tan bkod pa'i mdo las kyang / byang chub sems dpa' chos bzhi dang ldan na smon lam mi 'dor ro/ /

The Sūtra that is a Poetic Description of the Qualities of Mañjuśrī’s Buddha Field (Mañjuśrī-buddha-kṣetra-guṇa-vyūhā-alaṃkāra-sūtra) also says, A bodhisattva who has four qualities does not lose touch with the vow:
de bzhin du sbyar te/

nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ phrag dog dang ser sna yongs su spangs pa yin/ pha rol gyi 'byor pa mthong na yid dga' ba yin no zhes gsungs pa dang / dkon mchog brtsegs pa de nyid las/ spyod lam thams cad du byang chub kyi sems yongs su sbyong ba dang byang chub kyi sems sngon du 'gro ba dang zhes gsungs pa gang yin pa 'di ni 'dir byang chub kyi rgyur shin tu gsal ba nyid do/ /

having defeated pride, completely giving up envy, completely giving up greed, and rejoicing when seeing the good fortune of others.[xxxiii] [54] The way not to lose the vessel[xxxiv] of Awakening Mind is stated most clearly in the Heap of Jewels: “In all one’s activities, training in Awakening Mind and being guided by Awakening Mind.”

de skad du zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las kyang / khyed la mos bya khong du chud par bya/ / ji lta ji ltar mang du mis brtags na/ / de la gnas pa'i rnam par rtog pa des/ / de lta de ltar de la sems gzhol 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ / spro ba med pa yang gnod pa ma yin te/ /

For the Candrapradīpa Sūtra reads as follows:[5] I declare, and I proclaim to you: As someone reflects [on the abilities of a Buddha,] The mind tends toward him, Moved by these acts of reflection. Becoming disheartened is also harmful.

de spang ba ni dkon mchog sprin las mthong ste/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' 'di snyam du mir gyur pas ni byang chub thob par dka' la/ bdag gi brtson 'grus 'di yang chung zhing zhan te/ bdag ni le lo can no/ / byang chub ni mgo dang gos la me 'bar ba bzhin du bskal pa mang po bskal pa brgya phrag mang po bskal pa stong phrag mang po bskal pa brgya stong phrag mang por bsgrub dgos pas bdag ni de lta bu'i khur bkur bar mi spro'o snyam du sems mi bskyed de/ 'on kyang byang chub sems dpa' ni 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas gang dag mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa de dag dang / gang dag mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya ba de dag dang / gang dag mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ba de dag kyang / tshul 'di 'dra ba dang lam 'di 'dra ba dang brtson 'grus 'di 'dra bas mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas nas/ mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya/ mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur zhes bya ba nas/ de bzhin gshegs pa de dag kyang de bzhin gshegs par gyur pa sha stag las mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa ma yin gyis/ bdag kyang ci nas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ba'i sems can thams cad dang thun mong gi brtson 'grus dang / sems can thams cad la dmigs pa'i brtson 'grus kyis bdag gis kyang de lta de ltar brtsal lo 'bad do zhes gsungs so/ /

In the Cloud of Jewels we see how to avoid this: Here a bodhisattva does not think: “For one who has been born among humans, Awakening is difficult to attain, and I have little perseverance. I am lazy. To attain Awakening you have to practice as if your head and clothes were on fire for many aeons, many hundreds of aeons, many thousands of aeons, {many hundreds of thousands of aeons.} I cannot bear[xxxv] such a burden!” Instead, the bodhisattva should think: “Those who have awakened completely, the Tathāgatas, Saints, genuinely and fully awake, and those who are awakening completely, and those who will awaken completely: it was by this kind of training, by this kind of path, and by this kind of perseverance that they awakened completely, are awakening completely, and will awaken completely. They did not awaken completely while already being Tathāgatas! In just the same way I shall strive, and in just the same way, I shall practice diligently; with perseverance that is shared with all sentient beings, with perseverance that takes all sentient beings as its reference point, I will completely awaken to highest genuine full Awakening.”

gzhan yang gnod pa ni dkon mchog brtsegs pa las mthong ste/ sems can yongs su smin par ma byas pa rnams la yid rton pa byang chub sems dpa'i 'khrul pa dang / sems can snod du ma gyur pa rnams la sangs rgyas kyi chos rgya chen po ston pa byang chub sems dpa'i 'khrul pa dang / rgya chen po la mos pa'i sems can rnams la theg pa dman pa ston pa byang chub sems dpa'i 'khrul pa dang / yang dag par nye bar gnas pa'i sems can tshul khrims dang ldan pa dge ba'i chos can rnams la brnyas shing tshul khrims 'chal pa sdig pa'i chos can sdud pa ni byang chub sems dpa'i 'khrul pa zhes bya'o/ /

Other harmful actions are indicated in the Heap of Jewels: For a bodhisattva, having faith in sentient beings who are immature is a mistake. Teaching the lofty Dharma of the Buddhas to sentient beings who are not ready is a mistake. Teaching the Lesser Way[6] to sentient beings who have confidence in what is lofty is a mistake. For a bodhisattva, dishonoring those established in right mindfulness,[xxxvi] those who are morally disciplined, and those who have spiritual virtues through all forms of immorality and wrongdoing is a mistake.

mos pa med pa yang gnod pa yin te/ /'phags pa yul 'khor skyong gi mdo las kyang / / sangs rgyas la yang mos pa yod min la/ / chos dang tshogs la de ni mos pa med/ / bslab dang sbyang ba rnams la de mi mos/ / sdig pa'i blo can ngan song gsum phyogs pa/ / de ni mi nang 'di nas shi 'phos nas/ / las kyi dbang gis mi mkhas rnam par rmongs/ / dmyal ba'am 'on te dud 'gro'i 'gro rnams sam/ / yi dwags 'gro ba rnams su sdug bsngal rnyed/ / ces ji skad gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

Lacking religious commitment is also harmful. As the Rāṣṭrapāla Sūtra says:[7] Those who have no religious commitment to the Buddha Have no religious commitment to the Dharma and the community. They have no commitment to vows or to training; With their minds full of vile actions, their faces are turned toward the lower realms. [55] Once they have fallen from the human realm at death, By the power of karma, ignorant and bewildered, Now in the hells, now among animals, Now among hungry ghosts, they find suffering.

de rnam par spangs pa ni dkon mchog brtsegs pa'i mdo las mthong ste/ chos zab mo gang dag de'i blos mi rtogs pa de la sangs rgyas kyi byang chub ni mtha' yas shing / sems can mos pa tha dad pa rnams la de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis chos bstan pa 'jug ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa nyid kyis mkhyen gyi bdag gis ni mi shes te/ de bzhin gshegs pa nyid dbang du gyur pa yin no zhes byas nas mi spong ngo zhes bya ba'o/ / zhal ta byed pa'i tshe don ma yin pa rnam par spang ba la mkhas par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las/ chos dang mthun pa dang chos nyan pa dang de bzhin gshegs pa mchod pa la zhal ta bya bar bstan to/ / de la zhal ta bya ba gang yin pa ni rin po che'i phung po'i mdo las gsungs te/ de la dge slong zhal ta byed pas dge slong gi dge 'dun thams cad kyi sems mgu bar bya'o/ / de la dge slong dgon pa pa bas mtha'i gnas mal bsten pa gang yin pa de dag ni dge slong zhal ta byed pas thams cad du las su bsko bar mi bya'o/ / gal te dge slong dgon pa pa la dge 'dun gyi bya bar gtogs pa slob pa'i las res bab na/ dge slong zhal ta byed pa des las de bdag gis bya'o/ / yang na dge slong gzhan zhig bskos la las de byed du gzhug ste/ dge slong dgon pa pa la gnod par mi bya'o/ / de la dge slong bsod snyoms spyod pa gang yin pa de la dge slong zhal ta byed pa des kha zas bsod pa bgo bsha' bya'o/ /

In the Heap of Jewels, we see how to abandon this condition: “In those deep places where the intellect cannot penetrate, only the Tathāgata has eyes to see. The Tathāgata alone knows; I do not know. The Awakening of the Buddhas is without limit. Towards beings with their various degrees of religious commitment, the Dharma teaching of the Tathāgatas proceeds.” When you have formed this thought, don’t throw it away! When it is time for work, you should be skilled at avoiding what is harmful. The Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas teaches the meaning of “work” in the context of listening to the Dharma in an appropriate manner and worshipping the Tathāgatas. And on this topic, the Multitude of Jewels Sūtra (Ratna-rāśi-sūtra) says about work: While working, a monk should please the whole monastic community. A worker monk should not give any work assignments at all to monks who live in wilderness retreat in remote areas. If a retreat practitioner should happen to be assigned any of the trainee tasks that are part of the community routine, the worker monk should do those tasks himself. Alternately, he should ask another monk to do them; the retreat practitioner should not be disturbed. When another monk has just gone begging for food, the worker monk should distribute the good-quality food he has gathered.

'od srungs de la dge slong gang rnal 'byor spyod pa gang yin pa de dag la/ dge slong zhal ta byed pas mthun pa'i 'tshog chas dang na ba'i gsos sman dang yo byad rnams sbyin par bya'o/ / dge slong rnal 'byor spyod pa des phyogs gang la gnas pa'i sa phyogs der dge slong zhal ta byed pa des sgra chen po dang skad drag po mi dbyung zhing byed du'ang mi gzhug go/ / dge slong zhal ta byed pas dge slong rnal 'byor spyod pa de bsrung zhing mal cha yang sbyar bar bya'o/ / kha zas bsod pa dang yi gar 'ong pa dang rnal 'byor spyod pa'i sa dang mthun pa'i bza' ba dang bca' ba rnams sbyin par bya'o/ /

[56] On this topic, Kāśyapa, if another monk is doing spiritual practice, the worker monk should provide appropriate assistance, such as medicine and other necessities. In the place where the spiritual practitioner monk is staying, the worker monk should not make loud noises.[xxxvii] The worker monk should protect the spiritual practitioner monk. He should prepare a bed and a seat for him, and give him good-quality, pleasing food as a support for the stages of spiritual practice
de bzhin du sbyar te/

dge slong gang dag mang du thos par byed pa la brtson pa de dag spro ba bskyed par bya zhing / de dag la bsrung ba'i bar du bya'o/ / chos smra ba'i dge slong gang yin pa de dag las su mi bsko bar bya'o/ / chos nyan pa la brtson par 'gyur ba'i bar du bya'o/ / 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor bsham par bya'o/ / 'bel ba'i gtam gyis dkyil 'khor rnam par sbyang bar bya ba nas de la legs so zhes bya ba mang bar 'gyur ba'i bar du bya'o/ /

When some monks are making an effort to develop great learning, the worker monk should encourage them, protect them, and so on. As for the monks who are Dharma teachers, the worker monk should act as an usher for them.[xxxviii] He should encourage the Dharma students. He should set up the meeting circle, thoroughly clean the lecture circle, and say the word “Sādhu!” many times
de bzhin du sbyar te/

dngos po gang la yang dbang bya ba'i 'du shes bskyed par mi bya'o/ / bya ba ji tsam du chung ba yang dge 'dun gyi gros bzhin bya zhing rang dgar mi bya'o/ / dge 'dun gyi phyogs bzhi'i dge 'dun gyi dang mi bsre ba'i bar du bya ste/ bzlog pa yang de bzhin no/ / de bzhin du mchod rten gyi dang phan tshun bsre ba yang bkag go/ / gal te phyogs bzhi'i dge 'dun la brel phongs su gyur la dge 'dun gyi rnyed pa che bar gyur na dge slong zhal ta byed pa des dge slong gi dge 'dun bsdus la gros mthun par bgyis te/ dge 'dun gyi rnyed pa las phyogs bzhi'i dge 'dun la bshug par bya'o/ /

He should not develop a sense of ownership towards any property at all. No matter how small the task, he should do it according to the decision of the assembled community and not his own wishes. He should not mix together the property of his own monastic community with the property of the other communities in the four directions, or conversely. To combine the property of different stūpas is also forbidden. If the communities in the four directions are in need, and the wealth of his own community is abundant, then if the assembled community can reach a consensus on the matter, the worker monk should meet the needs of the communities in the four directions with the wealth of his own community.

mchod rten zhig ral du gyur na yang de bzhin du bya'o/ / sbyin pa po dang sbyin bdag la gsol ba thob la mchod rten gso bar bya'o/ / 'od srungs gal te mchod rten gyi rnyed pa ji ltar mang du gyur du zin kyang de dge slong zhal ta byed pas dge 'dun dang phyogs bzhi'i dge 'dun la bshug par mi bya ste/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ dad cing dang ba mang po dag gis mchod rten la phul ba ni tha na ras kyi kha tshar gcig tsam gang yin pa de yang lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten gyi mchod rten yin na/ rin po che'am rin po cher smos pa dag lta smos kyang ci dgos/ / mchod rten la gos phul ba gang yin pa de ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten de nyid du rlung dang nyi ma dang char bas dengs kyang bla'i mchod rten la phul ba'i gos dang zong gser du bsgyur du mi rung ste/ mchod rten la ni mchod rten gyi zong cis kyang brel phongs pa med do/ /

If a stūpa has been destroyed, the rule is that he should go back to the donors or patrons of the stūpa and rebuild it. Kāśyapa, even if a stūpa’s wealth is great, the worker monk should not let his own community, or the communities in the four directions, have any of it. Why is this? When even so much as a single cotton thread[xxxix] has been offered to a stūpa with faith, with great faith, [the thread itself] becomes a holy shrine for the world and its gods; how much more so for gems, or other items regarded as valuable! When a robe is given to a stūpa, at that holy place of the Tathāgata it should waste away in the wind, sunshine, and rain. A robe that belongs to a stūpa should not be traded for gold. Stūpa property does not have any price, and a stūpa does not need anything.

'od srungs dge slong gi zhal ta byed pa gang la la zhig tshul khrims dang ldan pa sbyin pa'i gnas rnams la sems khros sam dbang byed cing bsgo blag byed na de mi dge ba'i las des sems can dmyal bar 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te mi'i 'jig rten du 'ongs na yang bran dang gzhan gyi las byed par 'gyur ba dang khu tshur dang thal lcag dang lag cha bsnyems pas brdegs pa dang phrad par 'gyur ro/ /

[57] Kāśyapa, if a worker monk with an angry mind gives orders in a lordly way to morally disciplined people who should be honored, by that unwholesome action he goes to the hells. If he comes to the human world, he becomes a servant who has to work for others; he is punched, struck, and violently beaten
de bzhin du sbyar te/

dge slong la chad pas gcod pa dang / 'jigs par byed pa dang bsdigs pa dang / dus ma yin par mngag pa dang dus ma yin par bsgo bar byed na/ de mi dge ba des nyi tshe ba'i sems can dmyal ba phur pa mang po zhes bya ba der skye bar 'gyur te/ phur pa stong gi bar dag gis lus la zug cing / 'bar rab tu 'bar la/ kun tu rab tu 'bar bar 'gyur ro/ /

If he inflicts punishments on other monks, frightens them and threatens them, assigns tasks at the wrong times, and gives untimely orders, then by those unwholesome actions he is reborn in the ephemeral hell named Bahuśaṅku, “Many Spikes.” His body is pierced by a thousand spikes, catches fire, blazes, and burns very strongly
de bzhin du sbyar te/
lce'i tshad dpag tshad brgya par 'gyur zhing de'i lce'i dbang po de la lcags phur brgya stong kun tu 'bar ba dag gis 'bugs par 'gyur ro/ /
His tongue is a hundred leagues long. Into that sense-organ, his tongue, many hundreds of thousands of blazing iron spikes are stabbed.

'od srungs dge slong zhal ta byed pa gang la las dge 'dun gyi rnyed pa 'dus shing 'dus pa gzhag ste dus dus su mi sbyin zhing mtho btsams la gces nas sbyin pa dang kha cig la ma byin na de mi dge ba'i rtsa ba des yi dwags kyi skye gnas rkyag 'jim byin pa nub ces bya ba der skye bar 'gyur ro/ / der yi dwags gzhan gyis kha zas blangs te de la bstan na/ de bstan pa'i tshe/ mig gnyi ga mi 'dzums par zas de la blta zhing bkres pa dang skom pas nyen pa'i sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba myong gi lo brgya stong du yang zas de ni thob par mi 'gyur ro/ / ji ste brgya la brgya lam na zas de thob kyang ngan skyugs dang rnag khrag tu 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

Kāśyapa, if a worker monk receives community property and puts it together into a collection, but then doesn’t give it out at the appropriate time, cherishes it or gives it out with contempt, or doesn’t give any to some one person, then due to that unwholesome action he is reborn in a place of dung and clay, the hungry ghost realm known as Jaṅghā. There, when other hungry ghosts get some food, they show it to him. He sees the food with unblinking eyes, and is filled with the pain of hunger and thirst; but not even in a thousand years does he get any of that food. If, by some rare chance, he gets some food, it turns into dung,[xl] pus, and blood.

dge 'dun bsrungs kyi rtogs pa brjod pa las kyang gnod pa gsungs te/ dge 'dun bsrungs khyod kyis sems can rtsig pa lta bu gang dag mthong ba de rnams ni sngon dge slong yin te/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi rtsig ngos la ngar snabs kyis ma rungs par byas pas las de'i rnam par smin pas rtsig pa dang 'dra bar gyur to/ / dge 'dun bsrungs khyod kyis sems can ka ba 'dra ba gang dag mthong ba de rnams kyang sngon dge slong yin te/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi ka ba ngar snabs kyis ma rungs par byas pas de'i phyir ka ba 'dra bar gyur to/ / dge 'dun bsrungs khyod kyis sems can shing lta bu dang lo ma lta bu dang me tog lta bu dang 'bras bu lta bu gang dag mthong ba de rnams kyang sngon dge slong yin te/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi shing dang lo ma dang me tog dang 'bras bu rnams gang zag gis yongs su spyad par spyad pas na de'i phyir shing dang lo ma dang me tog dang 'bras bu lta bur gyur to/ / khyod kyis sems can thag pa lta bu dang phyags ma lta bu gang dag mthong ba de rnams kyang sngon dge slong yin te/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi thag pa dang phyags ma gang zag gis yongs su spyad par spyad pas na de'i phyir thag pa lta bu dang phyags ma lta bur gyur to/ /

The Spiritual Biography of Saṃgharakṣita (Saṃgharakṣita-avadāna) also discusses what is harmful: [58] Saṃgharakṣita, those sentient beings that you saw looking like walls were formerly monks. They defiled the community’s walls with their phlegm. By the evolution of that action, they appear as if they were walls.[xli] Saṃgharakṣita, those sentient beings that you saw looking like pillars were also formerly monks. They defiled the community’s pillars with their phlegm. For that reason, they appear as if they were pillars. Saṃgharakṣita, those sentient beings that you saw looking like trees, leaves, flowers, and fruits were also formerly monks. They used trees, leaves, flowers, and fruits belonging to the community for individual consumption. For that reason, they appear as if they were trees, leaves, flowers, and fruits. Those sentient beings that you saw looking like ropes and brooms were also formerly monks. They used ropes and brooms belonging to the community for individual consumption. For that reason, they appear as if they were ropes and brooms.

khyod kyis sems can gzhong pa lta bu gang mthong ba de sngon dge tshul ba yin te/ de gzhong pa 'khru zhing 'dug pa dang / dge slong dag cig glo bur du lhags te/ de dag gis de mthong nas dris pa dge tshul pha ci deng dge 'dun la skom lta yod dam/ de ser snas non pa'i sems kyis smras pa/ ci gzhong pa bkrus pa'ang ma mthong ngam skom 'thungs zin to/ / de dag gis dus yol zin pa lta snyam du bsams nas re ba chad de dman zhing yi bsad pa'i bzhin gyis dong ngo / / de ni las de'i rnam par smin pas gzhong pa lta bur gyur to/ /

The sentient being that you saw looking like a bowl was formerly a novice monk. He was washing a bowl.[xlii] Some monks happened to walk by and saw him. They asked, “Novice, will this drink be for the community?” With his mind overcome by stinginess, he said: “Don’t you see that I have washed the bowl? The drink has been drunk.” Thinking “The time has passed,” they became despondent and, speaking with low, sad voices, walked away. By the evolution of that action, he appears as if he were a bowl.

khyod kyis sems can gtun lta bu gang mthong ba de yang sngon dge slong yin te/ de la lhung bzed kyi las shig byung ba de'i tshe/ dge tshul pha dgra bcom pa gcig cig la dam gzhag pa'i las res bab nas de la des smras pa/ dge tshul pha tshigs ma cung zhig rdungs la kho bo la byin/ des smras pa gnas brtan bdag brel gyis cung zhig gzhes shig / slad kyis brdungs te gsol lo zhes byas pa dang / de khros nas smras pa/ dge tshul pha gal te kho bo gtun la reg tu rung na ni/ khyod nyid kho bos gtun gyi nang du bcug ste brdungs na tshigs ma nyung zad brdungs pa lta ci smos/ / dge tshul pha des de kun nas dkris pa drag pos dkris par rig nas/ gal te bdag gis de la lan blan na de bas kyang khros par 'gyur ro snyam nas kha rog ste 'dug go/ / gang gi tshe de kun nas dkris pa dang bral bar gyur pa de'i tshe de'i gan du song nas smras pa/ gnas brtan khyod kyis kho bo su lags mkhyen tam/ des smras pa shes te khyod ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srungs kyi bstan pa la rab tu byung ba'i dge tshul lo/ / kho bo ni dge slong gnas brtan no/ / dge tshul phas smras pa/ de lta yin du zin kyang kho bos ni rab tu byung nas bya ba gang yin pa de byas so/ / ci zhig byas/ nyon mongs pa spangs so/ / 'ching ba mtha' dag bcad do/ / bcings pa las rnam par grol lo/ / khyod kyis ni zhe gcod pa'i ngag gi las smras kyi nyes pa la nyes par mthol cig / 'on tang las de yongs su byang zhing bsrabs te/ yongs su zad par 'gyur ro/ / des kyang nyes pa la nyes par bshags so/ / las des na gtun lta bur gyur to/ /

[59] The sentient being that you saw looking like a mortar was also formerly a monk. He was engaged in making begging-bowls. A novice monk who was a Saint was there working with a [mortar and] pestle.[xliii] The monk said to him, “Novice monk, pound a little oil-cake paste and give it to me.” He replied, “Elder, wait just a moment; I am busy. Later I will pound it and give it to you.” The monk angrily said, “Novice, if I have to touch this mortar, I will throw you in and pound you—what need even to speak of a little oil-cake paste!” The novice thought, “This man is totally wrapped up in intense anger. If I answer him, he will only become more angry.” He remained silent. When the monk’s anger had departed, the novice approached him and said, “Elder, do you know who I am?” The monk replied, “I know you as an ordained novice monk of the genuinely and fully Awakened Buddha Kāśyapa. And I am an elder monk.” The novice monk said, “If so, then I have done what there was to do in taking ordination. What have I done? I have stopped all reactive emotions. My fetters are completely severed, and I am completely free from fetters. You have spoken harshly; confess this wrongdoing as wrongdoing! In this very way, indeed, will that action be used up, weakened, and exhausted.” He did not confess that wrongdoing as wrongdoing. Because of that action, the monk appears as if he were a mortar.

khyod kyis sems can phru chen lta bu gang dag mthong ba de dag ni sngon dge slong rnams kyi rim gro ba rung ba byed pa yin te/ de dag sman 'tshed pa'i tshe dge slong rnams kyis mi snyan pa smras pas de dag sems 'khrugs nas phru chen bcag pas de'i phyir phru chen lta bur gyur to/ / khyod kyis sems can rked par chad la skud pas thogs par gang mthong ba de yang sngon dge slong yin te/ / rnyed pa 'dzin par byed pa ni/ / de ser snas non pas dus bsnor te dbyar gyi gang yin pa de ni dgun gyir byas dgun gyi gang yin pa de ni dbyar gyir byas pas las de'i rnam par smin pas rked par chad la skud pas thogs shing 'gro'o zhes bya ba'o/ /

The sentient beings that you saw looking like cooking-pots were formerly attendants waiting upon monks. While preparing medicines by cooking them, they were addressed offensively by monks. Disturbance arose in their minds and they broke the cooking-pots. For that reason they appear as if they were cooking-pots. The sentient being that you saw severed at the waist and held together by string was also formerly a monk, wealthy and grasping. Overcome by avarice, [he embezzled community wealth, and covered this up by] mixing up the accounts. What was supposed to be for the summer he wrote down as being for the winter; what was supposed to be for the winter he wrote down as being for the summer. By the evolution of that action, his waist is severed, and he goes around held together by string.
chos smra ba la sogs pa bsrung ba'i le'u ste gsum pa'o// //
[gnod pa spang ba]
4. Giving Up What Is Harmful

gzhan yang mdo sde dag las gnod pa chen po dag gsungs te/ re zhig 'phags pa nam mkha'i snying po'i mdo las/ rigs kyi bu rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bo nas dbang bskur ba'i rtsa ba'i ltung ba lnga ste/ rtsa ba'i ltung ba de dag gis rgyal rigs spyi bo nas dbang bskur ba dge ba'i rtsa ba sngon bskyed pa thams cad thal bar rlog ste/ pham par gyur cing lha dang mi'i bde ba'i gnas thams cad las lhung nas ngan song du 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / lnga gang zhe na/ rigs kyi bu rgyal rigs spyi bo nas dbang bskur bas mchod rten gyi rdzas 'phrog gam dge 'dun gyi dang phyogs bzhi'i dge 'dun la phul ba 'phrog gam 'phrog tu 'jug pa 'di ni rtsa ba'i ltung ba dang po'o/ /

THE SCRIPTURES DESCRIBE other very harmful things. For example, the Ākāśagarbha Sūtra says: Noble sir, there are five[i] root downfalls of a crown-anointed warrior-noble,[1] by which a crown-anointed warrior-noble utterly destroys all his previously planted wholesome actions; he is defeated, and leaving behind all the happy states of gods and humans,[ii] goes to the lower realms. What are the five? Noble sir, if a crown-anointed warrior-noble seizes the property of a stūpa, or the property of a religious community, or either himself seizes or orders others to seize the property of the religious communities in the four directions, this is the first root downfall.

gang yang chos spong zhing 'gog tu 'jug ste/ nyan thos nges par 'byung ba bshad pa'am/ rang sangs rgyas nges par 'byung ba bshad pa'am/ theg pa chen po'i nges par 'byung ba bshad pa spong zhing 'gog tu 'jug pa 'di ni rtsa ba'i ltung ba gnyis pa'o/ /

[60] Alternately, if he rejects the Dharma that was proclaimed for the liberation of the Disciples, or for the liberation of the Solitary Sages, or for the liberation found in the Great Way, if he rejects and denies any of these teachings, this is the second root downfall.

gang yang nga'i phyir rab tu byung ste skra dang kha spu bregs nas gos ngur smrig gyon pa/ bslab pa gzung yang rung ma gzung yang rung / tshul khrims 'chal pa yang rung tshul khrims dang ldan pa yang rung ste/ de'i gos ngur smrig 'phrog gam khyim na gnas par byed du 'jug gam lus la lag chas bsnun nam btson rar 'jug gam srog dang bral bar byed du 'jug pa 'di ni rtsa ba'i ltung ba gsum pa'o/ /

Alternately, as for anyone who is ordained in my religion, with his head and face shaven and wearing saffron robes—whether he is engaged in training or not, whether he is morally disciplined or immoral—taking away his saffron robes, or forcing him to become a layman, striking him on the body with weapons, putting him in prison, or depriving him of life: this is the third root downfall.

rgyal rigs gang yang ched du bsams te/ ma'i srog gcod pa dang pha dang bcom ldan 'das kyi nyan thos dgra bcom pa'i srog gcod pa dang / dge 'dun mthun pa 'byed pa dang / ched du bsams te yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la ngan sems kyis khrag 'byin pa ste/ mtshams med pa'i las lnga po 'di dag las gang yang rung ba'i las byed pa 'di ni rtsa ba'i ltung ba bzhi pa'o/ /

Alternately, suppose that a warrior-noble intentionally deprives his mother of life, or his father, or deprives of life a Saint who is a disciple of the Blessed One, or breaks up a united religious community, or, moved by anger, intentionally sheds the blood of a Tathāgata, a Saint, genuinely and fully awake. Carrying out any one of these five actions of immediate retribution is the fourth root downfall.[2]

rgyal rigs gang yang rgyu med par smra bar gyur la/ 'jig rten pha rol pa g.yel te/ mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam yang dag par bzung nas gnas shing sems can gzhan mang po dag kyang mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam yang dag par 'dzin du 'jug ste/ 'dul zhing 'dzud la 'god pa 'di ni rtsa ba'i ltung ba lnga pa'o/ /

Alternately, suppose that a warrior-noble denies causality and becomes indifferent to the next world. He lives his life accepting the ten unwholesome courses of action as correct.[3] He gets many other people to accept the ten unwholesome courses of action as correct, teaches these actions, trains people to practice them, and establishes them in their practice. This is the fifth root downfall
de bzhin du sbyar te
gang yang grong 'joms pa dang ljongs 'joms pa dang grong khyer 'joms pa dang / yul 'khor 'joms par byed pa 'di yang rtsa ba'i ltung ba'o/ /
Alternately, causing division in a village, causing division in a region, causing division in a city, causing division in a country: this is the sixth root downfall
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa las dang po pa rnams kyi rtsa ba'i ltung ba brgyad de rtsa ba'i ltung ba de dag gis theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa las dang po pa 'khrul pa rnams dge ba'i rtsa ba sngon bskyed pa thams cad thal bar rlog ste pham par gyur cing / lha dang mi'i theg pa chen po'i bde ba'i gnas las lhung nas ngan song du 'gro bar 'gyur/ yun ring por 'khor ba na 'khor bar 'gyur/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ /

There are eight root downfalls of gentlemen or ladies who are practicing the Great Way as beginners. Those who mistakenly commit one of these eight root downfalls utterly destroy all their previous wholesome actions. They fall from their status and are defeated; leaving behind the happy states of gods and humans on the Great Way, they go to the lower realms, and remain in cyclic existence for a long time without a spiritual teacher.

brgyad gang zhe na/ sems can gang dag sngon nyes par spyad pa'i rgyus snyigs ma lnga dang ldan pa nyon mongs pa can gyi 'jig rten gyi khams 'dir skyes pa de dag ni dge ba'i rtsa ba chung ba ste/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen la brten nas theg pa chen po mchog tu zab pa 'di nyan to/ / rigs kyi bu blo chung ngu de dag kyang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems skyed par byed la de dag gi nang nas byang chub sems dpa'i las dang po gang dag stong pa nyid dang ldan pa'i mdo sde mchog tu zab pa 'di nyan pa dang lung nod pa dang klog pa dang kha ton byed pa de dag ji ltar thos pa dang ji ltar chub par byas pa de bzhin du/ snga ma'i blo dang 'dra ba gzhan dag gi mdun du/ don bzang po dang tshig 'bru bzang po rgyas par dran par byed cing rab tu ston la/ de dag ni nan tan tu ma sbyangs pa'i byis pa so so'i skye bo dag ste/ mnyan nas skrag cing dngang ste dngang bar 'gyur zhing / de dag dngangs nas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi sems las phyir log ste nyan thos kyi byang chub la smon na 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa'i rtsa ba'i ltung ba dang po ste/ rtsa ba'i ltung ba des rigs kyi bu de dge ba'i rtsa ba sngon skyes pa thams cad thal bar rlog ste pham par gyur cing mtho ris dang thar pa'i bde ba'i gnas las ltung ba dang de'i byang chub kyi sems kyang bslus shing ngan song du 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / de lta bas na byang chub sems dpa' sems can gzhan dag dang gang zag gzhan rnams kyi bsam pa dang bag la nyal shes par byas la/ bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du sems can rnams la bags kyis chos bstan par bya ste/ dper na rgya mtsho chen por bags kyis 'jug pa bzhin du bya'o/ /

[61] What are the eight? Sometimes, when beings, due to their previous bad conduct, are born in this reactive world with its five types of degeneration, though their wholesome actions are few, by relying on a spiritual teacher, they hear this supremely profound Great Way. These gentlemen, although they have limited intellect, arouse their minds for highest genuine full Awakening. Beginner bodhisattvas then let them hear the supremely profound scriptures that have to do with emptiness, give them reading transmission,[iii] and explain the scriptures to them. Since they have not done spiritual practice with earnest effort, but are foolish ordinary people, when they hear these teachings, they are frightened and terrified, and they panic. Out of panic, they turn back from highest genuine full Awakening and vow to follow the Way of the Disciples.[iv] This is the first root downfall of beginner bodhisattvas, by which they utterly destroy all their previously planted roots of good, fall from their status, are defeated, and leave behind the happiness of heaven and of final liberation. Their Awakening Mind becomes a lie, and they go to the lower realms. Therefore, a bodhisattva great being should first get to know the mental dispositions and personalities of other people, and then, according to their dispositions, should teach them the Dharma in stages, and at the right time—just as, for example, one enters the great ocean at the right time
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa kha cig la 'di skad du khyod kyis pha rol tu sbyin pa drug la spyod pa spyad par mi nus/ khyod kyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar mi nus kyi/ khyod nyan thos kyi theg pa dang rang sangs rgyas kyi theg par myur du sems skyed cig dang / des na khyod 'khor ba las nges par 'byung ngo zhes smras pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa'i rtsa ba'i ltung ba gnyis pa ste/ gong du ji ltar smos pa'i bar du'o/ /

Or suppose a beginner bodhisattva says to someone: “You cannot lead the way of life based on the six perfections. You cannot fully awaken to highest genuine full Awakening. You should quickly arouse your mind to the Way of the Disciples or the Way of the Solitary Sages. In this way, you will be assured of release from cyclic existence.” And so on, as before. This is the second root downfall of beginner bodhisattvas.

gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa kha cig la 'di skad du kye so sor thar pa dang 'dul ba'i tshul khrims la legs par bsrungs pas ci zhig bya/ khyod myur du bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed la theg pa chen po lhogs shig dang / des na khyod kyis nyon mongs pa'i rkyen gyis lus dang ngag dang yid rnams kyis mi dge ba'i las gang bsgrubs pa de dag rnam par smin par mi 'gyur bar dag par 'gyur ro zhes smra ba 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i las dang po pa'i rtsa ba'i ltung ba gsum pa ste gong du ji skad smos pa'i bar du'o/ /

Or suppose a beginner bodhisattva says to someone: “Oh, what’s the use of protecting moral discipline in the Vows of Individual Liberation and the monastic code? Arouse your mind quickly for highest genuine full Awakening! Study the Great Way![v] Any unwholesome actions of thought, word, and deed that you commit because of reactive emotions will be purified by that course of study, and will not evolve into anything.” And so on, as before. This is the third root downfall of a beginner bodhisattva.

rigs kyi bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pas kha cig la 'di skad du rigs kyi bu dag khyed nyan thos kyi theg pa'i gtam ma nyan cig / ma klog cig / gzhan dag la lung ma 'bogs shig / nyan thos kyi theg pa'i gtam chobs shig / des ni khyod kyis 'bras bu chen po rnyed par mi 'gyur zhing gzhi des ni khyed kyis nyon mongs pa mthar 'byin par mi nus kyi/ theg pa chen po'i gtam 'di nyid la dad par gyis shig / theg pa chen po nyon cig / theg pa chen po lhogs shig / gzhan dag la yang lung phog shig dang des na khyed kyis ngan 'gro dang ngan song gi lam thams cad zhi bar 'gyur bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyang myur du mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ro zhes smras la/ gal te de dag gis de'i tshig bzhin du mnyan te 'di 'dra ba'i lta bar gyur pa blangs na gnyis ka la yang rtsa ba'i ltung bar 'gyur te/ de ni byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa'i rtsa ba'i ltung ba bzhi pa'o/ /

Or suppose, noble sir, that a beginner bodhisattva says to some people: “Noble sirs, avoid any discourse about the Way of the Disciples! Don’t listen to it, don’t study it, and don’t explain it to others.[vi] Protect yourself against any discourse about the Way of the Disciples! You will not get any great fruit from that, and on that basis you cannot put an end to reactive emotions. Have faith in discourse about the Great Way. Listen to it, study the Great Way, and explain it to others. In this way you will block all the roads to bad rebirths and the lower realms, and you will quickly awaken fully to highest genuine full Awakening.” If [the beginner] wins someone over to a false view of the kind expressed in these words, they both undergo a root downfall. This is the fourth root downfall of a beginner bodhisattva.

gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa dag lce gnyis byed pa yin te/ gzhan du ston cing brjod pa dang sgra dang tshigs su bcad pa dang 'thob pa dang bkur sti'i phyir theg pa chen po 'di tshig tu 'don pa dang / kha ton byed pa dang / klog pa dang ston pa dang / thos pa tsam gzhan la yang ston la/ 'di skad du bdag ni theg pa chen po pa yin gyi gzhan ni ma yin no zhes smra zhing / gzhan dag gis pha rol po gang dag las longs spyod dang yongs su spyod pa rnyed par 'gyur ba de'i rkyen gyis/ 'thob pa dang bkur sti'i phyir de dag gzhan la phrag dog byed de/ de dag 'khrugs par 'gyur zhing / de dag gi bsngags pa ma yin pa brjod do/ / smod do/ /bshung ngo / /rnam par smod do/ / de dag la 'dud pa de rnams la yang phrag dog gi rgyus bdag bstod cing mi'i chos bla ma bdag nyid la sgrogs so/ / de'i phyir de dag dngos po des pham par 'gyur zhing theg pa chen po'i bde ba las lhung ste/ de dag la lci ba chen po'i ltung ba de 'byung zhing / des na ngan song du 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / dper na mi la la zhig rin po che'i gling du 'gro bar 'dod nas gru las rgya mtshor zhugs la/ de rgya mtsho chen po'i nang du bdag nyid kyis gru bshig nas de nyid du 'chi bar 'gyur ba de bzhin du/ byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa theg pa chen po'i rgya mtshor 'jug par 'dod pa gang dag phrag dog gi rgyus de dang de smra ste de'i rkyen gyis de dag dad pa'i gru zhig nas shes rab kyi srog dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa byis pa de dag la phrag dog gi rgyu dang rdzun gyi rkyen gyis lci ba chen po'i ltung ba 'byung ste/ 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa'i rtsa ba'i ltung ba lnga pa'o/ /

[62] Or suppose beginner bodhisattvas become double-tongued and teach falsely. For the sake of fame, reputation, and praise, and for the sake of money and prestige, they first study, recite, and memorize [the texts of] the Great Way, then explain to others and teach what they have merely studied [and not practiced.] They say: “We are followers of the Great Way; others are not.” Because of their desire for money and prestige, when other people get luxuries and comforts, [the beginners] are envious of them, and grow angry. They speak in an uncomplimentary way, put people down, insult and disparage people, and praise themselves. Out of envy, they advertise themselves as having superhuman abilities. Because of that action, they are defeated, and fall from the happiness of the Great Way. They undergo a downfall induced by reactivity, and go to the lower realms. For example, suppose someone sets out on the ocean to sail to the Island of Jewels on a boat. While out on the great ocean, he breaks up his own boat and sinks to his death. In just the same way, when beginner bodhisattvas wishing to set out on the great ocean of abilities[vii] speak in such a way because of envy, because of that they break up the boat of faith and lose the life of wisdom. In this way, foolish beginner bodhisattvas undergo downfalls induced by reactivity, with envy as the cause and with lies as the condition. This is the fifth root downfall of a beginner bodhisattva.

gzhan yang ma 'ongs pa'i dus na khyim na gnas pa dang rab tu byung ba las dang po pa'i byang chub sems dpa' dag byang chub sems dpa' nan tan du sbyangs pa mkhas pa skyes bu chen po gzungs dang bzod pa dang ting nge 'dzin gyi sa la legs par sbyang ba byas pa rnams kyi spyod yul mdo sde zab mo stong pa nyid dang ldan pa gang yin pa theg pa chen po'i mdo sde de dag 'dzin cing tshig tu 'don la kha ton byed cing gzhan dag la yang rgya cher klog cing rab tu ston to/ / chos 'di dag ni kho bo nyid kyi blos rtogs nas kho bo snying rje bas de bzhin du khyod la bstan gyi khyod kyis kyang ci nas 'di sangs rgyas kyi chos zab mo rnams la mngon sum du 'gyur ba de ltar sgoms shig / de ltar byas nas khyod da ltar kho bo bzhin du ye shes mthong bar 'gyur ro zhes smra'i 'di skad du kho bos mdo sde zab mo zab pa 'di lta bu 'di bklags pa tsam gyis bstan par zad kyi mngon sum du byas nas ni ma yin no zhes ni mi smra ste rnyed pa dang bkur sti'i phyir bdag 'tshong zhing / de'i rkyen gyis dus gsum du gshegs pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang 'phags pa'i gang zag thams cad kyi spyan sngar nyes pa dang bcas pa yin te lci ba chen po'i ltung bar 'gyur ro/ / theg pa chen pos lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten bslus par 'gyur ro/ / de ni nyan thos kyi theg par yang mi 'gyur na theg pa chen po la 'jug pa'i khyad par 'thob pa lta smos kyang ci dgos/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub lta smos kyang ci dgos dper na mi la la zhig 'brog dgon pa chen por chas la bkres pa dang skom pas nyen nas de der kha zas kyi phyir 'bras bu chen po'i shing la 'dzegs la/ dri phun sum tshogs pa dang ro phun sum tshogs pa ma myangs par 'bras bu chen po'i shing bor te/ dug gi shing la 'dzegs nas dug shing gi 'bras bu zos la zos nas kyang 'chi ba'i dus byas pa ltar gang zag de yang de dang 'dra'o zhes smra'o/ / de dag rnyed par dka' ba'i mi rnyed la rnyed nas kyang dge ba'i bshes gnyen la brten te theg pa chen po la 'jug par 'dod la/ rnyed pa dang bkur sti'i rgyus bdag la bstod cing gzhan la smod pas lci ba chen po'i ltung ba 'di lta bu 'di byung ste/ ltung ba lci ba des mkhas pa thams cad kyis smad par gyur pa ngan song du 'gro ba'i mi gang zag de lta bu ni rgyal rigs dang bram ze dang rje'u rigs dang / dmangs rigs thams cad kyis bsten par bya ba ma yin no/ / gang de la brten pa de ni mkhas pa thams cad kyis spang bar 'gyur te/ 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa'i rtsa ba'i ltung ba drug pa'o/ /

[63] Moreover, noble sir, in the future there will be lay and ordained beginner bodhisattvas who will memorize profound scriptures having to do with emptiness, scriptures intended for bodhisattvas who are very learned and have practiced with earnest effort the mnemonic powers, patient endurance, and the stages of meditative absorption. These beginners will recite and study those scriptures and quote long passages from them to others. Then they will declare: “I have awakened to these teachings in my own mind, and now, out of compassion, I am teaching them to you. You should now put into practice just what you see in these profound teachings.[viii] When you have done this, you will come to see pristine awareness, just as I have.” They will not say, “I will explain these extremely profound teachings that I know by study alone and not by direct experience.” For the sake of money and prestige, they sell themselves. Because of that, they are guilty in the eyes of {the Tathāgatas,} the genuinely fully awakened Saints existing in the three times, and the bodhisattvas, and all the Noble Ones. They undergo a downfall induced by reactivity, and lie to gods and humans about the Great Way. They do not even have the Way of the Disciples—how could they possibly have the special accomplishments that come from engaging the Great Way? How could they possibly attain highest genuine full Awakening? For example, suppose someone wandering in a great forest was tormented by hunger and thirst. He climbed a great fruit tree. But, leaving behind that tree and its plentiful fruit, not having experienced the wonderful scent and flavor of that fruit, he climbed a poison tree, ate its poisonous fruit, and then died. Those people, I say, are similar to him, in that, having found a human birth that is so difficult to obtain, they wish to enter the Great Way by relying on a spiritual teacher. Then, for the sake of money, prestige, and fame,[ix] they present a false image of themselves and disparage others, and thus undergo a downfall induced by reactivity. Because of that downfall induced by reactivity, they are utterly despised by all the learned, and they go to the lower realms. All warrior-nobles, Brahmins, merchants, and laborers[4] should not associate with people of that kind. Anyone who does associate with them becomes guilty in the eyes of all the learned. Noble sir, this is the sixth root downfall of a beginner bodhisattva.

rigs kyi bu gzhan yang ma 'ongs pa'i dus na/ rgyal rigs rnams kyi mdun na 'don gdol pa dang / blon po gdol pa dang shor ba gdol pa dang blon po mkhas pa'i nga rgyal can nor che ba longs spyod che ba dag 'byung ste/ de dag sbyin pa las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po rnam pa mang po dag la snang ste/ gtong bas rgyags shing dregs pa de dag nga rgyal dang rgyags pa dang dregs pa dang / rgyal rigs dang dge sbyong dang rgyal rigs rnams 'byed pa'i dbyen byed cing de dag rgyal rigs la brten nas dge sbyong rnams la chad pas gcod du 'jug chad pas nor 'phrog tu 'jug ste/ gnod pa des dge sbyong de dag gang zag gi'am dge 'dun gyi'am phyogs bzhi'i dge 'dun gyi'am mchod rten gyi dag dge sbyong rnams rkur bcug nas de dag la gsug tu 'bul lo/ / gdol pa de dag gis kyang rgyal rigs de dag la 'bul bar 'gyur te de dag gnyi ga la rtsa ba'i ltung bar 'gyur ro/ / 'di ni rtsa ba'i ltung ba bdun pa'o/ /

Moreover, noble sir, in the future there will be family priests of warrior-nobles who are really untouchables; ministers who are untouchables; military officers[x] who are untouchables—fools who think they are wise men, of great wealth, with lavish lifestyles. They will show the world great meritorious acts of generosity. Drunk with the intoxication of giving things away, puffed up with the intoxication of pride, they will divide the religious wanderers[5] from the warrior-nobles and the warrior-nobles from each other. Through their influence with the warrior-nobles, they cause the religious wanderers to be beaten and violently seize their wealth. By this use of violence, the [ministers] force the monks to offer them personal property, the property of the religious community, the property of the religious communities in the four directions, stūpa property, or other property stolen by religious wanderers, as bribes. The untouchables will then give that to the warrior-nobles. Both groups will undergo a root downfall. {This is the seventh root downfall.}

rgyal rigs gdol pa de dag kyang dge sbyong rnams la rab tu sdang bar 'gyur te/ chos 'di lta bu ni chos ma yin par 'dogs shing chos spangs nas chos ma yin pa la 'jog par 'gyur ro/ / mdo sde dang 'dul ba dang bslab pa la mi lta zhing / nag po bstan pa dang chen po bstan pa spangs te/ snying rje chen po'i tshul dang shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i bslab pa dang / thabs la mkhas pa'i bslab pa dang mdo sde gzhan dag las bslab pa bstan pa de dag kyang spangs nas chos 'di lta bu dang ldan pa'i dge slong rnams la gtse ba'i phyir bka' khrims gang gis dge slong rnams la gnod par 'gyur ba dang / zhi gnas dang lhag mthong dang mthun pa'i rnal 'byor yid la byed pa 'dor bar byed pa dang / 'phya ba dang gnod pa mang du 'gyur ba'i khrims 'cha' bar byed do/ / rgyu des na dge slong rnams nye bar ma zhi ba'i nyon mongs pa rnams nye bar zhi bar mi 'gyur bslabs par mi 'gyur ro/ / de'i tshe dge slong de dag bsam pa nyams par 'gyur/ tshul khrims nyams par 'gyur/ cho ga nyams par 'gyur/ lta ba nyams par 'gyur ro/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sgyid lug par 'gyur ba dang / bya ba mang bar 'gyur ba dang / dge sbyong ma yin par dge sbyong du khas 'che ba dang / tshangs par spyod pa ma yin par tshangs par spyod par khas 'che zhing lung bong ltar spyod pas so/ / reg par bya ba'i chos ston pa de dag lhag par rgyal rigs 'khor dang bcas pas bkur sti byas par 'gyur rim gro dang mchod pa byas par 'gyur ro/ / de dag kyang khyim pa rnams la dge slong spong ba la brtson pa rnams kyi bsngags pa ma yin pa brjod par 'gyur ro/ / rgyal rigs 'khor dang bcas pa de yang dge slong spong ba la brtson pa rnams la rab tu sdang bar 'gyur 'phya bar 'gyur te/ des na dge slong spong ba la brtson pa rnams kyi longs spyod dang nye bar spyod pa gang yin pa de dge slong kha ton byed pa la dga' ba rnams la byin par 'gyur te/ de dag gnyi ga la yang rtsa ba'i ltung bar 'gyur ro/ /

[64] The warrior-nobles and untouchables will hate the religious wanderers. They will call the Dharma “contrary to the Dharma,” and having thrown away the Dharma, they will put into effect what is contrary to the Dharma. They will pay no attention to training in the sūtras and the monastic code, and will throw away the Timely Teaching and the Great Teaching.[6] They will throw away training in the eye of great compassion, in the Perfection of Wisdom, and in skillful means, and all the forms of training taught in other scriptures. With the premeditated goal of causing harm, they will give the monks rules of conduct that will harm them. They will make them discard resting meditation, insight meditation, and the application of attention to meditation practice. They will put into place rules that give rise to a great deal of malice and harsh words.[xi] For that reason, the monks’ reactive emotions that have not already been pacified will not become pacified; nor will they become weaker. The monks’ aspirations will be corrupted; their moral discipline will be corrupted; their rituals will be corrupted; and their views will be corrupted. For that reason they will become lazy and gluttonous.[xii] They will claim to be religious wanderers when they are not; they will claim to be celibate when they are not; they will behave like animals.[xiii] They will teach questionable Dharma. The warrior-noble and his retinue will greatly honor them, esteem them, and worship them. In front of lay people, they will slander the monks who practice renunciation. Then the warrior-noble and his retinue will be very hostile to the monks who practice renunciation and ridicule them. They will take the possessions of the monks who practice renunciation and give them to the monks who are satisfied with just studying. All of them undergo a root downfall.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ dge slong bsam gtan pa ni zhing dam pa yin gyi/ klog pa dang zhal ta byed pa la gnas pa dang klog pa la brtson pa ni ting nge 'dzin dang gzungs dang bzod pa'i sa rnams kyi snod du gyur pa'am shin tu sbyin gnas su gyur pa'am/ snod du gyur pa dang / 'jig rten la snang bar byed pa'am lam nye bar ston par byed pa'am las kyi zhing dang nyon mongs pa'i zhing las sems can rnams sgrol ba dang mya ngan las 'das par 'gro ba'i lam la 'jog pa ma yin pa'i phyir te/ rigs kyi bu brgyad po 'di dag ni rtsa ba'i ltung ba'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Why is this? A monk who meditates is a good field. It is not by relying on study and work—it is not by any form of study—that someone gets a share in the stages of meditative absorption, mnemonic powers, and patient endurance, or becomes worthy of reverence, an appropriate object of gifts. [Those who have these qualities] bring light to the world; they show people the path. They lead sentient beings out of the field of karma and the field of reactive emotions, and set them on the path that leads to Nirvāṇa. These, noble sir, are the eight root downfalls.

'di dag gis nges par 'byung ba yang mdo 'di las gsungs pa ni/ gal te byang chub sems dpa' de dag byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po nam mkha'i snying po'i ming thos nas ngan song du ltung bas 'jigs pa'i phyir mthong bar 'dod cing rtsa ba'i ltung ba 'chags par 'dod la/ gal te de dag byang chub sems dpa' nam mkha'i snying po la phyag 'tshal zhing de'i ming yang brjod na/ rigs kyi bu de dag gi mdun du skal pa ji lta ba bzhin du de rang gi gzugs kyis gnas par 'gyur te/ bram ze'i gzugs nas bu mo'i gzugs kyi bar gyis mdun du gnas par 'gyur ro/ / byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa de la ltung ba ji lta bu byung ba de dag 'chags su 'jug go/ / de thabs la mkhas pa zab mo dang / theg pa chen po la spyad pa'ang nye bar ston to/ / phyir mi ldog pa'i sa'i bar la yang rab tu 'jog go/ /

The same sūtra lays out how {to confess these downfalls and thus} to be freed from them: [65] If those bodhisattvas who have heard the name of Ākāśagarbha should wish to see him, or want to confess a root downfall from fear of falling into the lower realms,[xiv] if they reverentially salute the bodhisattva Ākāśagarbha and call his name, then according to their karmic fortune, he will appear to them, either in his own supreme form, or in the form of a Brahmin, and so on up to: in the form of a young girl, he will stand before them. Then the beginner bodhisattvas confess those downfalls to him, just as they were committed. [Ākāśagarbha] then teaches them profound skill in means and the practice of the Great Way. He establishes them in the Stage of Non-Regression[7]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gal te de la gsol ba 'debs pa gang yin pa de dag la mngon du ston par mi byed na byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa nyes pa dang bcas pa des tho rangs langs la shar phyogs su bltas te 'dug la bdug pas bdug par bya/ lha'i bu skya rengs la gsol ba gdab par bya ste/ tshig 'di skad du skya rengs skya rengs snying rje chen po skal ba chen po khyod 'dzam bu'i gling du shar ma thag tu snying rjes bdag la khebs par mdzad du gsol/ / nam mkha'i snying po snying rje chen po dang ldan pa la yang bdag gi tshig gis myur du bskul te thabs gang gis bdag ltung ba 'chags par 'gyur ba dang / theg pa chen po 'phags pa la thabs dang shes rab 'thob par 'gyur ba'i thabs de dag bdag gi rmi lam du bstan du gsol zhes smras pa/ de'i tshe de mal du gnyid log par bya ste 'dzam bu gling 'dir skya rengs shar ma thag tu byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po nam mkha'i snying po dang phrad par 'gyur te/ byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa de'i rmi lam du de'i gzugs mdun du 'dug ste rtsa ba'i ltung ba de dag 'chags su 'jug go/ / de la theg pa chen po'i thabs kyi thabs shes pa 'di lta bu yang bstan te/ thabs shes pa la mkhas pa des byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa des de nyid du byang chub kyi sems mi brjed pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin 'thob po/ / theg pa chen po la brtan por gnas par yang 'gyur ro zhes bya ba la sogs pa yin no/ /

If he does not answer their prayer by letting them see his beautiful face, then each beginner bodhisattva who has committed an offense should rise just before dawn, and facing toward the east, should make the earth fragrant with incense, and then pray to the Divine Prince Dawn with the following words: “Dawn, Dawn, of great compassion and great fortune, you are famous on Earth.[xv] Right away, cover me with compassion. Quickly inform the greatly compassionate Ākāśagarbha of my message, which is: In a dream, please teach me some means by which I can confess my downfall, and can regain the skillful means and the wisdom of the noble Great Way.” Then he should return to bed and go back to sleep. In this way, as soon as the dawn comes, he can meet the bodhisattva Ākāśagarbha in his own form, right here on Earth. Then the beginner bodhisattva, standing before him, confesses that root downfall through the skillful means of the Great Way.[xvi] Then in this manner [Ākāśagarbha] teaches him a certain kind of skill, by means of which that beginner bodhisattva then and there attains a meditative absorption named “Not Forgetting the Awakening Mind,” and becomes very firmly established in the Great Way …

yang na mdo sde de nyid las gsol ba gdab pa'i sngags sngar smos pa gang yin pa des cho ga 'di byas te de las 'di skad du byung ngo / / dgon pa'am nags 'dab bam bla gab med par a ka ru'am rgya spos sam dus kyi rjes su 'brang bas bdugs la thal mo sbyar te phyogs dang phyogs mtshams kun du yan lag lngas phyag byas la/ sngags kyi tshig 'di dag brjod par bya'o/ / 'di lta ste/

Alternately, the mantra of petitionary prayer that was set out earlier in this sūtra should be recited, as part of a certain ritual, which is as follows: In the forest, in a grove, or in a clearing, make the place fragrant with aloe-wood[xvii] or tagara incense or kālānusāri incense, place your palms together in reverence, and bow in all the cardinal directions and the intermediate directions, doing a five-part reverence. Then speak these mantra words, which are:

su smri sha su smri sha / kA ru Ni ka / tsa ra tsa ra/ bi tsa ra bi tsa ra/ sany+tsa ra/ kA ru Ni ka / mu ra mu ra be ga d+hA ri/ mA tsa le/ b+hu dzA sha ta/ kA ru Ni ka / tsin+ta ma Ni pU rA ya/ kA ru Ni ka sarba sha me s+thA pa ya/ A dz+nyA d+hA rI s+phu gung s+phu gung / ru ti bi be ka gu/ driSh+Ti bi be kaM gu/ pU ra ya kA ru Ni ka / pU ra yan+tu ma ma sarba A sha / sarba pa thaM tsa/ a sho ka ga ti swA hA/

[66] sumṛśa sumṛśa kāruṇika cara tura vicara saṃcara kāruṇika murara murara vegadhāri namucame bhujyata kāruṇika cintāmaṇi pūraya kāruṇika sarvāśāṃ me sthāpaya ājñādharī sphu (x7) ra rativiveka (x7) dṛṣṭiviveka (x7) pūraya kāruṇika pūrayantu mamāśāṃ sarvathā cāśokagati svāhā.[8]

cho ga ni snga ma bzhin no/ / nad dang sdug bsngal thams cad dang 'jigs pa thams cad dang yo byad kyis phongs pa thams cad bsal ba dang 'dod pa thams cad sgrub pa'i phyir bya'o/ / gal te rgyal rigs la sogs pa byang chub sems dpa' yin na ji ltar de dag gi ltung ba nges shing gzhan dag ni ma nges ji ste de dag sdom pa can ma yin na ni/ de dag gis ltung bar ji ltar rnam par gzhag cing / sdom pa can dag nyes pa des zin par yang ji ltar 'gyur zhe na/ 'di ni nyes pa med de gang du gang dag la mang du 'byung ba de dag la der rang gi ming nas smos te bstan nas 'jigs pa bskyed pa'i phyir bzlog go/ / thams cad kyis kyang phan tshun du ltung ba thams cad spang bar bya'o/ / rang bzhin gyis kha na ma tho ba che bas na gang gi yang dag par ma blangs ba na yang skal ba med pa dang dge ba'i rtsa ba 'chad par 'gyur ba des sdom pa can la shin tu ches 'gyur te de ltar dpyad pas chog go/ /

Then repeat the ritual, as before. Recite this mantra to clear away all disease, pain, fear, and want, and to make all your wishes come true. If warrior-nobles and other lay people are bodhisattvas, how can there be a rule regarding downfalls for them, any more than for anyone else? They are not bound by vows—how can there be a settled rule about downfalls as regards them? Or, because of this difficulty, should they be regarded as also bound by vows? There is no problem here. They will be afraid of hearing their names spoken in accusation where many of them gather together, and so they will all mutually[xviii] restrain one another from downfalls. Now, as for what is seriously reprehensible by nature, by which you become outcast and unfortunate, with your wholesome actions cut off—with respect to that, everyone is very much like those who have vows. That’s enough analysis of this topic!

thabs la mkhas pa'i mdo las kyang rtsa ba'i ltung ba gsungs te/ rigs kyi bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' so sor thar pa'i bslab pa la slob cing bskal pa brgya stong du rtsa ba dang 'bras bu za bar gyur la/ sems can rnams kyis legs par smras pa dang nyes par smras pa bzod kyang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dang ldan pa'i yid la byed pas gnas na 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i ltung ba lci ba'o/ / rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste dper na nyan thos kyi theg pa can la rtsa ba'i ltung ba byung na phung po de nyid kyis yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba'i skal ba med do/ / rigs kyi bu de bzhin du ltung ba ma bshags shing nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas yid la byed pa de ma spangs na sangs rgyas kyi sa la yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba'i skal pa med do zhes 'byung ngo / /

The Skill in Means Sūtra (Upāya-kauśalya-sūtra) mentions another root downfall:[9] Suppose, noble sir, a bodhisattva trains for a hundred thousand aeons in the discipline of the Vows of Individual Liberation while eating only roots and fruits, patiently endures all the praise and criticism of everyone, and spends all that time on the forms of training in attention that are appropriate for Disciples and Solitary Sages. This, for a bodhisattva, is a downfall induced by reactivity. Noble sir, for example, someone following the Way of the Disciples who undergoes a root downfall does not then have the right karmic conditions to be completely freed from the aggregates. In the same way, a gentleman who has not confessed this downfall and has not abandoned those forms of training in attention that are appropriate for Disciples and Solitary Sages does not have the right karmic conditions to become completely free through the stages of Awakening.
rtsa ba'i ltung ba 'di dag bde blag tu gzung ba dang 'ga' zhig gi lugs gnas par bya ba'i phyir bsdu ba'i tshig le'ur byas pa dag brjod par bya'o/ /
So that the reader can easily understand and remember these root downfalls, I will summarize them in verse:[10]
dkon mchog gsum gyi dkor 'phrogs pa/ / phas pham pa yi ltung bar 'dod/ / dam pa'i chos ni spong byed pa/ / gnyis par thub pas gsungs pa yin/ /
Someone who steals property from the Three Jewels Is defeated; this is held to be a downfall. Rejecting the holy Dharma Is the second downfall proclaimed by the Sage.

tshul khrims 'chal pa'i dge slong la'ang / / ngur smrig 'phrog dang brdeg pa dang / / btson rar 'jug par byed pa dang / / rab tu byung las 'bebs pa dang / / mtshams med lnga po byed pa dang / / log par lta ba 'dzin pa dang / / grong la sogs pa 'jig pa yang / / rtsa ba'i ltung bar rgyal bas gsungs/ /

blo sbyangs ma byas sems can la/ / stong pa nyid ni brjod pa dang / / sangs rgyas nyid la zhugs pa dag / rdzogs pa'i byang chub zlog pa dang / / so sor thar pa yongs spangs te/ / theg pa chen la sbyor ba dang / / slob pa'i theg pas chags la sogs/ / spong bar 'gyur ba min zhes 'dzin/ /

pha rol dag kyang 'dzin 'jug dang / / rang gi yon tan brjod pa dang / / rnyed pa dang ni bkur sti dang / / tshigs bcad rgyu yis gzhan smod dang / / bdag ni zab mo bzod pa'o zhes/ / log pa nyid ni smra ba dang / / dge sbyong chad pas gcod 'jug dang / / dkon mchog gsum gyi sbyin byed dang / / sbyin pa len par byed pa dang / / zhi gnas 'dor bar byed pa dang / / yang dag 'jog gi longs spyod rnams/ / kha ton byed la sbyin pa rnams/ /
de dag rtsa ba'i ltung ba ste/ / sems can dmyal ba chen po'i rgyu/ / rmi lam 'phags mkha' snying po yi/ / mdun du 'dug ste bshags par bya/ /
These are root downfalls, Causes of rebirth in the great hells. Confess these in a dream While standing before the noble Ākāśagarbha.

byang chub sems ni yongs 'dor dang / / chags dang ser sna mi zad pas/ / slong la sbyin par mi byed dang / / bsgrims te dga' bar byed pa na/ / sems can la ni mi bzod par/ / khros pas sems can brdegs pa dang / / nyon mongs pa dang gzhan mthun pas/ / chos ltar bcos pa brjod pa'o/ /

'phags pa sa'i snying po'i mdo las kyang / tshangs pa chen po gang de'i phyir rab tu byung ba/ tshul khrims 'chal pa sdig pa spyod pa'i/ dge slong mdongs pa shing rul pa lta bur gyur pa/ dge sbyong ma yin pa la dge sbyong du khas 'che ba/ tshangs par spyod pa ma yin pa la tshangs par spyod par khas 'che ba/ nyon mongs pa sna tshogs kyis bshig pa ltung ba pham pa yin yang tshul khrims 'chal pa sdig pa spyod pa'i dge slong de de'i tshe na yang lha thams cad dang mi rnams kyi bar dang bsod nams kyi gter dag gi bar ston pa dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen yin no/ / de snod du gyur pa ma yin du zin kyang / skra dang kha spu bregs te gos ngur smrig bgos pa dang spyod lam bstan pa'i rgyu des kyang sems can mang po dag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba sna tshogs ston par byed pa dang bde 'gro'i lam ston pa yin no/ / de lta bas na nga'i phyir rab tu byung ba tshul khrims dang ldan pa'am tshul khrims 'chal pa yang rung ste/ gang nga'i phyir rab tu byung ba la 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po yang chos dang mthun pas kyang lus la chad pas gcod pa dang btson rar 'jug pa dang yan lag dang nying lag gcod pa dang srog gcod du mi gnang na chos ma yin pa lta ci smos/ chos 'dul ba la shi ba lta bur brjod du zin na gang zag de gi wang dang gla rtsi dang mtshungs so zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Kṣitigarbha Sūtra also says: [68] Great Brahma, suppose a monk ordained in my name is immoral, having a lifestyle full of vile actions, merely perceived as a monk,[xix] rotten, not a religious wanderer but claiming to be one, not celibate but claiming to be, sunk, fallen, defeated, overcome by various reactive emotions. Even so, at the same time, that immoral monk, whose lifestyle is full of vile actions, is someone who shows storehouses of goodness to all gods and all humans; he is a spiritual teacher. He is not a worthy recipient, by far; but because of his shaven head and face, his saffron robe, and his outward behavior, he encourages the development of various virtuous actions in many sentient beings, and teaches the path to happiness. Therefore, when someone is ordained in my name, whether morally disciplined or immoral, I do not authorize even a world-emperor, even when acting justly, to strike him with a weapon on his body, to throw him into prison, to cut off his major or minor body parts, or to kill him—not to speak of doing so unjustly! Someone who does so is said to be “dead” in this religion,[11] and becomes like bright-yellow gallstone paste, or musk.[12]

yang de nyid las/ nga'i phyir rab tu byung ba snod du gyur tam snod du ma gyur kyang rung ba rnams la gang dag 'tshe ba de dag thams cad ni dus gsum du gshegs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad la shin tu nyes pa dang bcas pa yin no/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba chad pa dang rgyud tshig pa dang mnar med par gzhol ba yin no zhes gsungs pa dang / yang de nyid las/ 'di lta ste/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyis byin gyis brlabs pa'i gos ngur smrig 'di ni thar pa'i rgyal mtshan yin no zhes gsungs pa dang / yang de nyid las de'i tshe nyan thos khrag khrig brgya stong mang po dang / byang chub sems dpa' khrag khrig brgya stong mang po dag sngon byas pa'i las kyi sgrib pa 'di lta bu bcom ldan 'das la 'chags te/ btsun pa bcom ldan 'das bdag cag gis ni sngon gyi de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi gsung rab la snod du gyur pa dang snod du ma gyur pa rnams dang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi nyan thos kyi theg pa can gyi gang zag la smad do/ / bshungs so khros so/ / bsngags pa ma lags pa dang mi snyan pa'i bka' mchid brjod do/ / las kyi sgrib pa des na bdag cag ngan song gsum du sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba drag po mi bzad pa rnam pa mang po myong ngo / /

The same text says: All those who will harm people ordained in my name, {whether worthy or unworthy,}[xx] they are all very guilty to the Buddhas of the three times. Their roots are cut off; their series have been burned; they will go to Avīci.[13] The same text also says: “This saffron robe is blessed by all the Buddhas; it is the flag of freedom.” And it says: At that time, many tens of thousands of billions[xxi] of disciples and many tens of thousands of billions of bodhisattvas confessed the karmic distortions they had previously created to the Blessed One, saying, “Revered Blessed One, in the past we ourselves despised, disparaged, got angry at, and uttered uncomplimentary and defamatory words about people, some worthy and some unworthy, belonging to the Way of the Disciples of the Buddhas, following the doctrine of previous Tathāgatas. Because of these karmic distortions, in the three lower realms we experienced various sharp, unbearable painful sensations
de bzhin du sbyar te/

bdag cag las kyi sgrib pa'i lhag ma de da ltar bcom ldan 'das la 'chags so/ / kha cig ni bdag cag gis bcom ldan 'das kyi nyan thos rnams la tshig gis bsdigs so/ / spyos brgyad do zhes 'dzer to/ / kha cig ni bdag cag gis bcom ldan 'das kyi nyan thos snod du gyur pa dang / snod du ma gyur pa rnams la brdegs/ bsnun to zhes 'dzer to/ / kha cig ni bdag cag gis bcom ldan 'das kyi nyan thos kyi gos phrogs so zhes 'dzer to/ / kha cig ni bdag cag gis bcom ldan 'das kyis nyan thos rnams kyi longs spyod pa dang yongs su spyod pa rnams phrogs so zhes 'dzer to/ / kha cig ni bdag cag gis bcom ldan 'das kyi phyir rab tu byung ba rnams khyim par phab ste/ gnas ma lags pa thob par bgyis so zhes 'dzer to/ / kha cig ni bcom ldan 'das bdag cag gis sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi nyan thos snod du gyur pa dang snod du ma gyur pa nongs pa ma mchis pa rnams khri mon du stsal te bdag cag las kyi sgrib pa des bskal pa mang por ngan song gsum du sdug bsngal drag po mi bzad pa rnam pa mang po myong ngo zhes 'dzer to/ /
