Now, in the presence of the Blessed One, we will confess whatever is left of these karmic distortions.” [69] Some say, “We rebuked and reviled disciples of the Blessed One.” Some say, “We struck worthy and unworthy disciples of the Blessed One.” Some say, “We stole monastic robes.” Some say, “We stole the possessions and belongings of disciples of the Blessed One.” Some say, “We forced those ordained in the name of the Blessed One to become lay people, then put them into difficult situations.” Some say, “Blessed One, we put disciples of the Blessed Ones, the Buddhas, who were guilty of offences, some of them worthy and some unworthy,[xxii] into prison. By that karmic distortion, during many aeons in the lower realms, we experienced various sharp, unbearable painful sensations.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

bdag cag da ltar las kyi sgrib pa'i lhag ma de bcom ldan 'das la 'chags so/ / slan chad kyang sdom par bgyid do/ / bdag cag la thugs brtse ba'i slad du bcom ldan 'das kyis gzung du gsol/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bdag cag ngan song mi bzad pa las gdon du gsol zhes rgya cher gsungs so// //

“In the presence of the Blessed One, we confess whatever is left of these karmic distortions, and for the future we make a vow. Out of compassion for us, may the Blessed One accept our confession; may he save us from endless vile actions.”[xxiii]
bam po bzhi pa/
A detailed explanation follows.[xxiv]

rab tu byung ba'i bar du gcod pa'i mdo las kyang gnod pa gsungs te/ ming chen khyim pa chos bzhi dang ldan na skye ba de dang der mi dal ba rnyed par 'gyur/ dmus long dang blun pa dang lce med pa dang gdol par 'gyur/ nam du yang bde bar mi 'gyur/ skur pa 'debs pa mang bar 'gyur/ za ma dang ma ning dang / rtag par bran dang bud med du 'gyur/ khyi dang phag dang bong bu dang rnga mo dang / sbrul gdug par 'gyur ro/ / bzhi gang zhe na/ ming chen 'di la khyim pa sngon gyi rgyal ba rnams la lhag par byas pa'i sems can rnams kyi mngon par 'byung ba'i sems dang rab tu 'byung ba'i sems dang 'phags pa'i lam gyi sems kyi bar chad byed pa 'di ni dang po'o/ / gzhan yang nor la chags shing bu la chags nas las kyi rnam par smin pa la yid mi ches te/ bu'am bu mo'am chung ma'am nye du'i tshogs dbang phyug gi gnas la 'khod pa rab tu 'byung ba'i bar chad byed pa 'di ni gnyis pa'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The Sūtra on Obstacles to Ordination (Pravrajya-antarāya-sūtra) mentions other harmful things: Mahānaman, lay people who do any of four things lose their favorable opportunities. [In their future lives,] they are born blind, or profoundly retarded, or lacking tongues, or as untouchables. Or they become severely depressed, or insulted by everybody, or intersex persons, or lifelong servants, or women. They are born here and there as dogs, pigs, donkeys, camels, and poisonous snakes. What are the four things? Mahānaman, a lay person creates obstacles for beings who have done service to previous Victors, obstructing their intention to leave the world, their intention to take ordination, and their intention to follow the noble Path. This is the first. Alternately, a lay person who is eager for wealth and eager for children, not trusting the evolution of actions, and being in a position of authority in the family, creates obstacles to ordination for a son, or a daughter, or a wife, or any relative. This is the second.

gzhan gnyis ni dam pa'i chos spong ba dang / dge sbyong dang bram ze rnams la khong khro ba'o/ / mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam gyi gnod pa ni dam pa'i chos dran pa nye bar gzhag pa las/ rnam par smin pa drag po gsungs pa lta bur blta ste/ de las cung zad tsam zhig brjod par bya'o/ / srog gcod pa'i rnam par smin pa nyung zad cig smos pa 'di lta ste/ me lce la rgyu ba zhes bya ba'i bya ni gang dag me'i rtse mo la gnas kyang mi 'tshig pa ste/ shin tu dga' zhing sems can dmyal ba pa rnams kyi mgo brtol nas khrag 'thung ngo / / thod pa'i phrag na rgyu ba zhes bya ba'i bya ni gang dag glad pa brtol nas rab tu 'bar zhing glad rgyas 'thung ba'o/ / lce'i sha za zhes bya ba'i bya ni gang dag lce dral nas mngon du za ba ste/ lce de zos shing zos nas yang skye ste/ pad ma'i 'dab ma bas kyang 'jam mo/ / de ltar don dang mthun pa'i ming can no/ / so 'byin zhes bya ba dang / mgul pa'i mid pa 'dren zhes bya ba dang / glo ba la gnas pa dang / pho ba za ba dang / mchin pa bzlog pa dang / rgyu ma'i nang spri za ba dang / sgal tshigs la dga' ba zhes bya ba dang gshis kyi gsang ba pa zhes bya ba'i bya rnams ni gang dag gshis thams cad phye ste gshis kyi bu ga brtol nas bu gar zhugs te ngu bzhin pa rnams kyi rkang gi snying khu 'thung ba'o/ / khab kyi bu ga zhes bya ba'i bya ni gang dag khab lta bu'i mchus khrag 'thung ba'o/ / de bzhin du rus pa'i phrag na gnas pa dang / pags pa dag za ba dang / sder mos 'brad pa dang / tshil za ba dang / rgyus pa 'don pa dang / skra shad 'dzings pa zhes bya ba'i bya rnams ni gang dag skra rtsa nas 'don pa'o/ / de ltar de mnar med pa'i phyogs gcig na bya 'dab 'jigs zhes bya ba dpag tshad sum 'bum par gyur te bya de dag dang sems can dmyal ba'i bya gzhan dag dang lhan cig tu de la lo brgya stong du mar za yang yang skye'o/ /

The other two are rejecting the holy Dharma and hostility to religious wanderers and Brahmins. The Sūtra on the Application of Mindfulness to the Holy Dharma shows the horrifying results of the evolution of the harm caused by the ten unwholesome courses of action. Just a small fraction of these results are well explained in the sūtra. This includes just a small part of the results of the evolution of murder. As it says, [70] For example, there are the birds called Flame-Walkers. Even when they go into the middle of the flames, they are not burned. They joyfully split open the skulls of the hell-beings and drink their blood. Then there are the birds called Skull-Enterers. They split open the heads, pierce the brains, and drink from the blazing heads. Then there are the birds called Tongue-Eaters. Having torn the tongues apart, they eat them right there. Once a hell-being’s tongue has been eaten, it grows back again, very tender like a lotus-petal. In the same way, there are other accurately named birds called Tooth-Tearers, Windpipe-Tearers, Lung-Dwellers,[xxv] Stomach-Eaters, Spleen-Destroyers, Entrail-Devourers, and Backbone-Walkers.[xxvi] The birds named Hidden-Vitals-Eaters cut holes in all the vital points of the body, and through them drink the pith of the marrow of the screaming hell-beings. The birds named Needle-Piercers have beaks like needles through which they drink blood. Similarly, there are the Joint-Eaters, the[xxvii] Skin-Eaters, the Claw-Rippers, the Fat-Eaters, and the Muscle-Tearers.[xxviii] The birds named Hair-Tanglers[xxix] rip out the hair by its roots. Such is the region of Avīci Hell named Bird Terror Wing, three hundred thousand leagues in extent. Together with many other hell-beings,[xxx] [the murderer] spends hundreds of thousands of years there, is eaten, and is reborn again.

de brgya la zhig na de las thar kyang de sdug bsngal mang por bskor te/ sa phyogs gnyis pa g.yang sa'i ngam grog ces bya ba der 'gro zhing mgon tshol skyabs tshol dpung gnyen tshol lo/ / khor yug tu me'i phung po bcu gcig gis bskor te/ las kyi zhags pas bcings shing grogs med la/ dgra rnams kyis khor yug tu bskor te dgon par phyin te/ de sngar gyi sems can dmyal ba'i tshogs thams cad pas ches lhag pa'i sdug bsngal rnyed cing ngam grog rab lhung zhes bya ba'i g.yang sa'i phyogs su rgyug ste/ ltung nas rkang pa shin tu zhu'o/ / bteg na ni yang shin tu gzhon zhing shin tu 'jam par skye la tshor ba drag po mi bzad pa rnams kyis nyen to/ / de ltar 'jigs pas dkrugs pa'i bzhin du gyur nas rkang lag dang yan lag dang nying lag thams cad rab tu zhu ba de la sa phyogs der ngam grog ces bya ba'i g.yang sa 'byung ste/ de phyogs der lhung zhing ngam pa nas dpag tshad sum 'bum du yang g.yang du lhung zhing / yang las kyis byas pa'i rlung gis 'debs so/ / de lhung ba na bya kang ka dang khwa dang / bya rgod dang 'ug pa rnams za'o/ / de ltar de bteg cing lhung ba ni lo brgya stong phrag du ma 'da' bar 'gyur ro/ / brgya la zhig na de nas thar kyang yongs su bskor ba'i 'khor lo'i mtshan ma'i phrag ces bya ba'i phyogs su rgyug ste/ sa phyogs der yang 'khor lo rdo rje'i lte ba can me lce rnon po 'bar ba myur du bskor ba'i 'khor lo stong 'byung bar 'gyur te/ de der song ma thag tu lus la 'khor lo de dag bab nas 'khor ro/ /

When, by some rare chance, he gets out of there, wandering around in great pain,[xxxi] seeking protection, seeking refuge, seeking rescue,[xxxii] he goes toward a second region, named Fallen into the Abyss. He is surrounded on all sides by eleven masses of flames, friendless, bound by the noose of karma, encircled by enemies, in a disastrous situation. In great distress due to the multitude of hell-beings everywhere around, he runs toward the region named Fallen into the Abyss. At every step his foot is consumed by fire. When he lifts his leg, it grows back, extremely tender and soft, overpowered by sharp, unbearable sensations. In this way, as he cries out in terror, and his limbs and major and minor body parts are consumed by flame, the region named Fallen into the Abyss comes into sight, and he falls down into it. Once he has fallen into the abyss, he falls three hundred thousand leagues. Meanwhile, he is tossed upwards by a wind created by karma. While falling, he is eaten by herons, crows, vultures, and owls. In this way, being tossed upwards and then falling again, many hundreds of thousands of years pass. [71] When, by some rare chance, he gets out of there, wandering around, he runs to a region called Hole of Hooked Wheels.[xxxiii] In that region, thousand-spoked wheels with adamantine hubs become visible, fiercely blazing and quickly rolling. As soon as he arrives there, the wheels strike his body and roll over him
de bzhin du sbyar te/
yan lag so so thams cad kyang bshig nas bsreg go/ / de'i rkang mthil nas ni gsal shing gis 'bigs so/ /
The wheels tear off every one of his limbs and burn him, and stakes pierce the soles of his feet.

de ltar gnad 'joms pa'i ri la gnad 'joms pa'i srog chags su gyur pa rnams kyis phyi nang rdul phra rab tsam yan chad kyang zos par 'gyur ro/ / zos shing zos nas kyang yang shin tu gzhon par skye'o/ / shin tu gzhon sha can nyid kyis kyang sdug bsngal drag po 'byung bar 'gyur te/ zos shing zos nas kyang de la sha ches che bar skye bar 'gyur te/ srog gcod pa byas shing bsags pa de'i 'bras bu ni de yin no/ / ma byin par len pa'i rnam par smin pa gsungs pa/ nyes par byas pa'i las kyi mtha' byed pa de/ mgal me bskor ba dang sprul pa dang dri za'i grong khyer dang smig rgyu lta bu'i nor gyi rnam pa chen por gyur pa rin po che dang gos dang nor dang 'bru mang po mthong ste/ chags pas zil gyis non cing las kyis rmongs par gyur pa de 'di ni bdag gi yin no snyam du sems te/ de ltar rmongs pa sdig pa byed pa de/ me mdag dang lci skam gyi me rab tu 'bar ba 'bogs nas/ nor yod pa der brgyugs pa dang / der gshin rje'i mi las kyis byas pa rnams kyis bzung nas mtshon cha 'bar ba'i nang du khrid de yan lag dang nying lag thams cad gshegs gtubs nas/ bsregs te rus pa 'ba' zhig lus par byed de/ de lta bu'i gnas su son kyang de'i chags pa thog ma med pa nas zhugs pa de yongs su 'bri bar mi 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'o/ / 'dod pas log par g.yem pa'i dbang du byas te/ de ltar sdig pa byed pa de mtshon cha'i nyam nga ba de las thar nas me mdag dang lci skam gyi mer 'bogs te/ las kyis bskos pa'i sa phyogs log par mthong ba zhes bya ba gzhan du 'gro'o/ / der yang dran pa nyams par gyur pa des sngon gang dag mthong ba lta bu'i bud med las kyis byas pa dag mthong ste/ mthong nas kyang de'i 'dod chags thog ma med pa'i dus nas goms pa'i me 'byung ngo / / de bud med de dag ga la ba der brgyugs pa dang / las kyis byas pa'i lcags kyi rang bzhin gyi mi de dag gis de bzung ste/ bzung nas kyang kha'i mchu la sogs pa ci nas lus de la lhag ma yungs 'bru tsam yang mi lus pa de ltar za yang yang skye'o yang za'o/ / de tshor ba drag po mi bzad pa myong yang 'dod chags kyi me de las mi ldog ste bud med de dag ga la ba der yang rgyug go/ / de'i gnod pa de ni 'dod chags kyi me ji lta ba de ltar mi gnod pa ma yin no/ / rdo rje dang lcags kyi bud med de dag kyang lus rab tu 'bar zhing me lce 'khrug pas mi de bzung nas sems can dmyal ba pa de'i lus thams cad bye ma bcangs pa bzhin du bkrum yang slar 'byung ste snga ma bzhin no/ /

The mountain called Destroying the Vitals is similar; the living things who inhabit the mountain devour him inside and outside, down to the very atoms. Once eaten, he is born again, very young, and because of being very young, he feels even more intensely painful sensations. When he is eaten, his body is reborn even larger than before. Those who commit murder receive this result. The results of evolution of taking what is not given are stated as follows: When he goes to the end of that ruinous action, [the thief] sees an illusion that appears to be a great collection of wealth—gems, clothing, money, and grain—but is in fact like a wheel of flames,[14] a city of gandharvas,[15] or a mirage. Overcome by greed and deluded by karma, he thinks, “This is mine!” Deluded in this way, the one who has acted vilely crosses over a blazing fire of dry dung and hot coals,[xxxiv] and runs up to that wealth. There Yama’s men, who are created by karma, seize him, and in a blaze of swords, cut his body in pieces. Then they burn the body, leaving only the bones. But even though it has brought him to a situation like this, the greed that has existed in him for beginningless time does not diminish. About sexual misconduct, the text says: [72] When he somehow gets out of [the region called] Beset with Swords, the one who has acted vilely crosses the fire of dry dung and hot coals. Driven to wander by karma, he arrives at a region named Deceptive Appearance. He sees women created by karma; he has seen others like them before, but has lost his memory. When he sees them, the fire of attraction that has been habituated in him since beginningless time flares up, and he runs towards those women. But they are made of iron, created that way by karma. They seize him, and starting with the lips, they devour him, leaving nothing behind, not even [a remnant] the size of a mustard-seed. He is born again, and again he is eaten. He experiences harsh, unbearable sensations, but because of them, the fire of attraction does not cease; instead, he runs towards those women even more, and the pain he suffers doesn’t interfere with the fire of attraction. Those women of iron and adamant, their bodies burdened with blazing garlands,[xxxv] crush that hell-being like a handful of sand. He is born again, and so on as before
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
rnam pa kun tu nor 'jig dang / / ngan song rtsa ba bud med yin/ / mi gang dag ni bud med 'dod/ / de dag bde bar ga la 'gyur/ / zhes bya ba nas/ /
Women are the root of the lower realms; They destroy your wealth in every way. Men who are subject to women— How could they possibly be happy? …
bud med phung bar byed pa ste/ / 'jig rten 'di dang pha rol phung / / gal te bdag la phan 'dod na/ / de bas bud med rnam par spang / / zhes bya ba'i bar du gsungs so/ /
A woman is the greatest of all disasters In this world and the next. Therefore, if a man wants to be happy, He should give up women.

rdzun du smra ba'i dbang du byas te/ de gshin rje'i mi de dag gis bzung ste/ bzung nas kyang de'i kha phye nas de nas lce 'dren te/ las kyi dbang dang rdzun du smra ba de'i 'bras bus lce dpag tshad lnga brgya par 'gyur te/ de'i lce 'byung ba'i dus na gshin rje'i mi dag gis lcags kyis rab tu 'bar ba la bldag tu 'jug go/ / las kyis byas pa'i gshin rje'i thong lcags 'bar ba dang ldan pa stong yang 'byung zhing glang bu stobs dang ldan pa rnams kyis de'i lce la rmo bar 'gyur te/ der rnag dang khrag dang srin bu 'dzag pa'i chu 'bab par 'gyur ro/ /

About lying, the text says: Yama’s men seize him, and forcing open his mouth,[xxxvi] pull out his tongue. By the power of karma, as the result of that lie, his tongue becomes five hundred leagues long. As soon as it comes out, Yama’s men force the tongue down[xxxvii] onto the ground of blazing iron. A thousand ploughs[xxxviii] appear, made of blazing iron. Mighty oxen propel them onto his tongue. Rivers of oozing pus and blood, full of worms, flow out
de bzhin du sbyar te

lce de yang lha rnams kyi mig ji lta ba de bzhin du shin tu gzhon pa nas/ de tshor bas nyam thag pa zhes bya ba'i bar du ste/ 'khun cing ngu la ku co 'don kyang de la sdug bsngal sel ba su yang med do/ / zhes rgya cher gsungs pa dang / de ltar tshor ba drag po myong ba lce de la lo brgya stong du mar lce rmo bar 'gyur zhing de'i lce de ji ste na dmyal ba pa'i kha'i nang du chud par 'gyur ro/ / de 'jigs pas dkrugs pa'i bzhin du gyur cing gar bab bab tu 'bros so/ / me mdag dang lci skam gyi me'i nang du nub cing tshig la de de ltar sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag pa na/ skyabs med dpung gnyen med cing gshin rje'i mi lag na tho ba dang ral gri thogs pa dag 'byung ste/ de dag gis mi de'i klad pa nas rkang pa'i bar du phye mar rlog go zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa yin no/ /

And that tongue is very tender, just like the eye of one of the gods. He groans, cries, and calls out from the pain, but none of his pain is relieved. As he experiences unbearable sensations in this way, his tongue is ploughed for many hundreds of thousands of years, until somehow he gets his tongue back into his mouth. [73] Then, crying out due to fear, he flees this way and that at random, sinking into the fire of hot coals and dry dung. As he is afflicted by pain[xix] in this way, with no refuge, with no friend to help, to make matters worse, Yama’s men appear with hammers and swords in their hands. They pulverize him from head to feet. And so on.

phra ma byed pa'i rnam par smin pa ni rdzun du smra ba dang mthun no/ / lce dpag tshad sum brgya par 'gyur te zhes bya ba ni bye brag ste/ gshin rje'i mi snying rje med pa de dag gis lce rab tu 'bar ba la bzung nas gshegs par byed do/ / wa dag kyang phyogs gzhan nas za zhing mchog tu drag pa'i sdug bsngal myong la ngu zhing ku co 'don to/ / lce med pas sgra mi gsal lo zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / ngag rtsub mo'i rnam par smin pa gsungs pa ni/ de dag gis de'i kha phye nas lce bzung ste/ bzung nas kyang mtshon rnon pos bcad de/ de nyid kyi zas su slar yang khar bcug la de yang bkres pas nyam thag cing bkres pa'i rang bzhin gyis rang gi khrag dang kha chu 'dzag pa dang lce de nyid za'o/ / lce de yang bcad cing bcad nas kyang las kyi dbang gis slar yang skye zhing / de sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag pas sa la 'dre ldog cing ku co 'don to/ / de ltar sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag cing mig gi 'bras bu yongs su 'gyur la sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag pa dman pa grogs med pa gcig pur gyur pas rang gis byas pa la spyod pa de la gshin rje'i mi rnams kyis rjes su bstan pa'i tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/

The results of evolution of divisive speech are similar to those for lying, with the difference that his tongue is three hundred leagues long. Moreover: Yama’s men pick up swords and[xl] cut up his tongue; jackals take it away and eat it. He experiences extremely harsh sensations, cries out, and makes noise, but unclearly, because of lacking a tongue. The results of evolution of harsh speech are stated: They force open his mouth and seize his tongue, then cut it up with sharp swords. Then they throw the pieces back into his mouth as food. Tormented and emaciated by hunger, even though it is flowing with his own blood and saliva, he eats his own tongue. Then, by the power of karma, the tongue grows back and is cut again. Tortured by the pain, he rolls around on the ground, writhes, and cries out. His eyes turn back into his head, and as he suffers, sick, friendless, and completely alone, experiencing the results of what he himself did, Yama’s men admonish him with this verse:
khyod kyis lce yi gzhu yis ni/ / rtsub mo zhes ni gang brjod pa/ / ngag gi mda' rnon 'phangs gyur pas/ / de yi 'bras bu 'di 'ongs so/ / zhes bya ba'o/ /
You have come here as a result of The sharp arrow of speech that you shot From the bow of the tongue, Which is known as “harsh speech.”

tshig 'khyal ba'i rnam par smin pa gsungs pa ni/ de'i lce de zangs rab tu 'bar bas bsreg go/ / lce bsregs nas mgul pa bsreg go/ / mgul pa bsregs nas snying bsreg go/ / snying bsregs nas rgyu ma bsreg go/ / rgyu ma bsregs nas pho ba bsreg go/ / pho ba bsregs nas kyang thur du 'byung ngo / / gshin rje'i mis tshigs su bcad pa/ / snga phyi'i tshig ni ma 'brel cing / / don med pa dang 'chal gyur la/ / ma 'brel khyod kyis gang smras pa/ / de yi 'bras bu 'dir 'ongs so/ / gang dag bden par mi smra zhing / / kha ton lhur len mi byed pa/ / de la mkhas pas lcer mthong gi / sha dum nyid du min nam ci/ / zhes bya ba'o/ /

The results of evolution of idle chitchat are stated: [74] The blazing melted copper[xli] burns his tongue, and when his tongue is consumed, it burns his throat. When his throat is consumed, it burns his heart. When his heart is consumed, it burns his intestines. When his intestine is consumed, it burns his abdomen.[xlii] When his abdomen is consumed, it goes out by the lower parts. Yama’s men recite this verse: You have come here as a result of The irrelevant words you have spoken, Of no significance, unrelated to what came before or after, And without any benefit— A tongue which does not speak the truth And is not intent on recitation— Why wouldn’t the learned see it As just a piece of meat?

brnab sems kyi rnam par smin pa gsungs pa ni/ de la las kyis byas ba'i rdzas gzhan gyis yongs su bzung ba gso ba gsog snying po med pa mthong nas las kyis bskul ba rmongs pa de 'di snyam du 'di ni bdag gi yin no snyam du sems te/ de nas sems can dmyal ba pa de rdzas ga la ba der brgyug go/ / sems can dmyal ba des nor gang mthong ba de ni brnab sems zhes bya ba yid kyis mi dge ba kun tu bsten cing bsgoms la mang du byas pa de'i 'bras bu yin te/ de ltar mthong ba na brnab sems mang ba de'i lag nas mtshon cha 'byung ste/ des der brgyugs pa dang sems can dmyal ba pa gzhan de dag gi lag nas kyang mtshon cha rnams 'byung ste/ de dag dang de mtshon chas 'thab pa la ci nas lus la sha yungs 'bru tsam yang mi lus pa de ltar bzhar te keng rus nyi tshe lus par byed do/ /

The results of evolution of covetousness are stated: He sees great wealth, created by karma, owned by someone else, which is mere appearance, void, and without essence. Incited and confused by karma, he thinks, “This should be mine!” Then that hell-being runs to the place where that wealth is. As a result of having studied, habituated, and repeatedly practiced the unwholesome state of covetousness, he sees the hell inaccurately.[xliii] Because of his great covetousness, a sword appears in his hand, and he runs with it. Then swords appear in the hands of the other hell-beings nearby. He fights them with the sword until they have cut all the flesh from his body, not leaving intact even pieces the size of mustard-seeds, and reduced his body to a fragmentary skeleton.
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
gzhan dag 'byor pa mthong nas ni/ / bdag gir gyur cig snyam bsams pa/ / brnab sems yang dag bskyed gyur pa/ / las de'i 'bras bu 'ongs pa yin/ / zhes bya ba'o/ /
Meanwhile, all the others {have also seen the riches, and they too} think, “This should be mine!”[xliv] Such is the result of the poison of covetousness.

gnod sems kyi 'bras bu gsungs pa ni/ las kyis bskyed pa'i seng ge dang gzig dang sbrul khro bas zil gyis non pa rnams de'i mdun na 'dug pa de dag gis de 'jigs skrag nas gar bab bab tu bros kyang mi dge ba'i las kyis de 'bros ji ltar nus/ de dag gis de bzung ste bzung nas kyang thog mar klad pa la za ba nas sbrul mche ba gdug pa rnams kyis rtsib logs kyi bar du bzung zhing za la stag rnams ni rgyab nas za bar 'gyur ro/ / rkang pa ni mes bsregs so/ / gshin rje'i mi rnams kyang rgyang ring po nas mda' 'phen to zhes rgya cher ro/ / log par lta ba'i 'bras bu ni dpag tu med pa gsungs te mdor bsdus nas brjod pa ni mtshon cha'i char dang / mtshon rtse gcig pa dang / rdo rje'i char dang / gnam lcags dang / rdo'i char rnams kyis btab cing me'i phung po bcu rnams dang kha nas bkres pa dang skom pa'i me 'byung bas kyang rgyun tu sreg go zhes bya'o/ / 'dod pa ni gnod pa thams cad kyi rtsa ba ste/ de dag gis shin tu yid 'byung bar bya'o/ / ji ltar 'di nyid las/ me thab ces bya ba'i sems can dmyal ba yod de/ der las gang gis sems can rnams skye zhe na/ gang dge sbyong ma yin pa la dge sbyong du khas 'che zhing bud med kyi glu dang gar dang rgyan rnams kyi sgra thos pa dang dgod pa dang 'jo ba dang rtse ba rnams thos nas/ tshul bzhin ma yin pa yid la byed pas 'phangs pa'i blos khu ba 'chor par 'gyur ro/ /

The results of evolution of malice are stated: In front of him stand lions, tigers, and snakes, created by karma, overcome with wrath. Frightened, in this way and that he tries to escape from them, but how could he possibly escape his own vile actions? They seize him and devour him, beginning with his head. The snakes bite him with their poisonous fangs, over and over, all around the ribs. The tigers devour him from the back forward. The flames burn his feet.[xlv] And Yama’s men also shoot arrows at him from far away. [75] And so on at length. The results of wrong views, on the other hand, are said to be immeasurable.[xlvi] But the text summarizes them: Swords, iron clubs, diamonds, iron meteorites, and rocks rain down and strike him.[xlvii] Eleven[xlviii] masses of flame enter his mouth, and the fires of hunger and thirst burn without interruption. “Sensual desires are the root of everything harmful”—so you should become disenchanted with them. As it says in the same text, There is a hell named “The Bowl of Fire.” Which actions cause sentient beings to be born there? Someone who is not really a religious wanderer, but claims to be one, hears[xlix] the sounds of women’s singing, dancing, and ornaments, of their laughter, play, and amusement. While his mind is distracted and he is applying attention inappropriately, semen comes out
de bzhin du sbyar te/

der sems can dmyal ba pa de dag lcags kyi char pas yan lag dang nying lag thams cad phye mar rlog la me ma mur gyi char gyis kyang sreg cing 'tshig go zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa bzhin no/ / de ltar sngon 'dod pa nyams su blangs pa dran pas pad ma zhes bya ba'i sems can dmyal ba gsungs te/ myong ba rmi lam du dran pas kyang der sems can dmyal ba pa de dag phru ba rnams su btso zhing gzhong khong du lcags kyi gtun rnams kyis brdung ngo zhes rgya cher ro/ / de de ltar lha'i bu mo 'dod pa'i phyir tshangs par spyod pa yongs su bsngo bas na/ pad ma chen po zhes bya ba'i sems can dmyal bar gsungs te/ de na tsha sgo can gyi 'bab chu dba' rlabs can zhes bya ba 'bab ste/ 'bab chu de la nya gang yin pa de dag ni sems can dmyal ba pa de dag go/ / rus pa gang yin pa de dag ni rdo ba'o/ / 'jim pa gang yin pa de dag ni skra'o/ / 'dam rdzab gang yin pa de dag ni sha'o/ / chu gang yin pa de dag ni ro nye bskol ba'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / de bzhin du skyes pas skyes pa la 'khrig pa log par bcug pa'i chad pa'i bye brag dpag tu med par brjod do/ / de bzhin du byis pa rnams la log par 'jug pa yang tsha sgo can gyi chus khyer ba'i khye'u dag mthong nas de dag gis de la bos pa dang / de byis pa de dag la shin tu sdug par sems pa dang ldan zhing mya ngan dang sdug bsngal gyi shugs kyis chu der 'jug go/ / ba dang rta rgod ma dang ra mo dang lug mo la sogs pa la yang de bzhin te/ 'dod pa la log par g.yem pa ni rang bzhin gyis kha na ma tho ba dang bcas pa rnam par smin pa shin tu drag par gsungs so/ / dud 'gro la 'dod pa bsten pa de ni mi dge bas sprul pa'i lcags kyi ba dang rta rgod ma la sogs pa 'bar ba de dag nyid kyi skye gnas kyi lam nas 'jug ste de dag gi ltor me mdag rab tu 'bar ba'i phung pos yongs su gang bar de lo brgya stong mang por 'tshed cing sreg go zhes te rgya cher de nyid du blta'o/ / de bzhin du gzhan gyis nyal po byas zin pa'i dge slong ma rnams la log par zhugs pa rnams kyi chad pa yang sems can dmyal ba chen por bshad do/ / rang gi chung ma la skye gnas kyi lam ma yin par byas pa yang de bzhin no/ / gzhan gyi chung ma la nan gyis byas pa dang mi dbang ba'i bu mo la byas pa yang de bzhin no/ / bsnyen gnas la gnas pa rnams la byas pa yang de bzhin no/ / bla ma rnams kyi chung ma la byas pa yang de bzhin no/ / gnyen du 'thams pa rim gro byas pa rnams la log par zhugs pa'i chad pa yang drag cing dpag tu med de/ sems can dmyal ba chen po yin par bshad do/ /

There all the major and minor body parts of the hell-beings are pulverized by a rain of iron, cooked, and burned by a rain of hot coals. And so on. Similarly, a hell called “Lotus” is said to result from the practice of remembering the taste of past sensual pleasures, and from remembering them while dreaming: “There those hell-beings are cooked in earthen pots. In iron basins they are struck with pestles.” And so on at length. In the same way, someone who dedicates the goodness arising from celibacy[l] to the desire for celestial nymphs[16] goes to the hell named “Great Lotus:” There an acid river flows, named “Turbulent.”[li] In that river, instead of stones, there are bones. Instead of water-plants, there are hairs. Instead of mud, there is flesh. Instead of water, there is boiling copper.[lii] Instead of fish, there are hell-beings. Similarly, the immeasurable distinctive results of the crime of child abuse[17] are described: Due to his crimes committed with young boys, he sees illusory children in the acid river. They call to him invitingly. Because of the distress and suffering caused by his strong attraction and attachment to those boys, he dives into the river. In the same way, the very harsh results of the evolution of sexual misconduct with cows, mares, she-goats, sheep, and so on, which is reprehensible by nature, are described: [76] He who practices bestiality enters those cows, mares, and so on, made of heated iron[liii] and created by unwholesome actions, through the path of the vagina. In their bellies, which are filled with heaps of hot coals, he is cooked and burned for many hundreds of thousands of years. You should read the description in full. In the same way, people who commit offences with nuns, even those previously ruined by others, are described as going to the great hells. Similarly, those who enter their own wives by paths other than the vagina; those who lead away the wives of others by force and enter them, or enter girls who are engaged to be married; or similarly, women who have taken a one-day vow of chastity, or the wives of one’s spiritual teachers, or relatives, who should be embraced and honored[liv]—the harsh, immeasurable results of offences with them are described as occurring in the great hells.

'khrig pa bdun dang ldan pa'i mdo las kyang / bram ze 'di la kha cig bdag tshangs par spyod par khas 'che zhing de bud med dang gnyis kyis gnyis mi sbyor yang bud med la mig gis gzugs la nges par sems shing blta ste/ des de'i ro myang zhing rtog la zhen te/ lhag par zhen nas gnas pa 'di ni bram ze tshangs par spyod pa 'khrig pa'i chos dang ldan pa yin gyi mi ldan pa ma yin te/ tshangs par spyod pa yongs su ma dag par spyod pa'o/ / de bzhin du bud med dang lhan cig rtse ba dang ca co 'don pa nyams su len pa yang tshangs par spyod pa yongs su ma dag pa'o zhes gsungs pa dang / bud med kyis bsnyen bkur byas pa nyams su len pa yang de bzhin no/ / rtsig pas chod pa'am yol bas chod pa'i bud med kyi rgyan dang glu dang gar la sogs pa'i sgra nyams su len pa'ang de bzhin du 'khrig pa dang ldan pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ / pha rol po 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga dang ldan pa la bltas nas nyams su len pa yang de bzhin no/ / lha la sogs pa'i gnas su tshangs par spyod pa yongs su bsngo ba yang de bzhin te 'khrig pa'i chos dang ldan pa yin gyi mi ldan pa ma yin no zhes gsungs so/ / de'i phyir de ltar dran pa dang smon pa'i yul du gyur pa 'dod pa de dag ni gnod pa byed pa nyid do/ /

The Sūtra about Seven Forms of Sexual Intercourse (Sapta-maithuna-saṃyukta-sūtra) also says: Brahmin, suppose someone claims to be celibate, and in fact does not actually copulate with women. On the other hand, he sees women’s bodies and thinks about them, enjoys doing so, and is very attached to that experience, remaining in such thoughts. Brahmin, he is called a celibate who is engaged in intercourse, not disengaged, and his celibate lifestyle is impure. In the same way, if he plays with women and enjoys talking happily together, his celibate lifestyle is said to be impure. If he enjoys[lv] being honored by women, it’s the same. And if he enjoys the sound of women’s dancing and singing,[lvi] and so on, while separated from them by a wall or a curtain, he is also said to be engaged in intercourse. It’s the same if he enjoys looking at external things that arouse the five cords of sensual pleasure. And if he dedicates the goodness arising from celibacy[lvii] to states such as the god-realm, he is also engaged in intercourse, not disengaged. Therefore, if you remember sensual pleasures and make them the objects of your hopes, they will harm you.

de'i phyir 'dod pa la gdams pa'i mdo las/ dge slong 'dod pa rnams las sems zlog shig / lam 'di ni 'jigs pa dang bcas pa'o/ / rab tu 'jigs pa dang bcas pa'o/ / tsher ma dang bcas pa'o/ / thibs po dang bcas pa'o lam gol ba'o/ / lam ngan pa'o/ / lam kha brag go/ / skyes bu dam pa ma yin pas bsten pa'o/ / khyod 'di ltar 'dod pa rnams ni ro myang ba chung ba ste/ bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang sdug bsngal mang ba gnod pa mang ba 'khrugs pa mang ba ste 'di la ni nyes dmigs mang ngo / / dge slong dag 'dod pa rnams ni nad dang 'bras dang zug rngu dang sdig pa dang srid pa'i rtsa ba dang sha dang bcas pa'i mchil pa lta bu yin la/ 'dod pa dag ni 'chi ba mi rtag pa sogs rdzun pa slu ba'i chos can te/ 'dod pa rnams ni rmi lam lta bu yin zhing 'di dag ni byis pa 'drid pa'o zhes gsungs pa snyam du mi sems sam/

So the Sūtra that Warns about Sensual Pleasures (Kāma-apavādaka-sūtra) says: [77] Monk, turn away your mind from sensual pleasures! That path is fearful and full of terrors, full of thorns, full of dark places, the wrong path, a bad path, a rocky road[lviii] followed by bad people. That path is not followed by holy people. Why don’t you think: “The Blessed One has said, ‘Sensual pleasures offer little enjoyment and cause great suffering, many calamities and many frustrations. Their disadvantages are great. Monks, sensual pleasures are like a disease, a tumor, an arrow, a crime, the root of crime,[lix] and a baited fish-hook. Sensual pleasures are perishing, impermanent, void, false, and deceptive, like dreams, and they lure foolish people.’ ”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

dper na ri dwags bshor ba'i khog tshe dang / bya bshor ba'i rgya dang / nya bshor ba'i dol dang / spre'u bshor ba'i rnyong dang / phye ma leb bshor ba'i me'i phung po ji lta bar 'dod pa rnams kyang de bzhin no/ /
Sensual pleasures are like a trap for catching deer,[18] a net for catching birds, a fish-net for catching fish, a snare for catching monkeys, and a mass of flames for catching moths
de bzhin du sbyar te/

'dod pa tshol zhing spyod pa na yun ring por seng ge rnams kyi khar chud pa'i mtha' yang mi mngon pa nas ba lang gsod cing ba lang gi sha za ba rnams kyi khar chud pa'i bar gyi mtha' yang mi mngon no/ / sbal pa dag tu gyur nas sbrul rnams kyi khar chud pa'i bar gyi mtha' yang mi mngon no/ / yun ring por 'dod pa bsten pa na chom rkun yin zhes bzung nas mgo bcad pa'i mtha' yang mi mngon no/ / gzhan gyi chung ma la 'phyo ba dang rkun po dang grong 'joms pa dang ljongs 'joms pa dang mdud pa 'grel ba'i bar yin no zhes bzung nas mgo bcad pa'i mtha' yang mi mngon no/ / sdug bsngal drag pa rtsub pa mi bzad pa nyams su myong ba'i khrag gzags shing bab pa ni rgya mtsho chen po bzhi'i chu bas kyang mang ngo / /

Those who live by the search for sensual pleasures spend a long time falling into the mouths of lions, and no end is ever in sight. They kill cows, and then [in later lives] fall into the mouths of beef-eaters, and no end is ever in sight. They become frogs, fall into the mouths of snakes, and no end is ever in sight. Those who indulge in sensual pleasures commit theft, are caught, and have their heads cut off, and the whole time no end is ever in sight. They seduce the wives of others, commit robbery, destroy villages or whole regions, and break people out of jail;[lx] they are caught and have their heads cut off, and the whole time no end is ever in sight. They experience sharp, severe, bitter pain; more blood is shed from them than there is water in the oceans
de bzhin du sbyar te/

lus nyes dmigs mang ba 'di ni rus pa 'dus pa/ chu rgyus kyis sbrel ba/ shas glan pa/ pags pas dkris shing phyi rol g.yogs pa/ bu ga che chung can/ srin bu'i tshogs gnas pa/ sems can rnams la gnod pa/ nyon mongs pa'i chos rnams kyi gnas yin no/ / lus 'di la nad kyi rnam pa 'byung ba 'di lta ste/ mig nad dang rna nad nas gzhang 'brum dang phol mig dang mtshan bar rdol gyi bar dag go/ /

[78] This body has many miseries. It is a heap of bones, held together by tendons,[lxi] smeared with flesh, covered and wrapped on the outside with skin, perforated with holes, swarming with a mass of worms,[lxii] harmful to sentient beings, a basis for karma and reactive emotions. Various diseases arise in this body, from eye-disease and ear-disease to hemorrhoids, ulcers, and anal fistulas[lxiii]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

lus kyi kun tu gdung ba rnams dang / lus kyi sdug bsngal dang / lus kyi 'khogs pa dang / sgu ba dang / sgur ba dang / spyi cer dang / skra skya dang / gnyer ma mang ba dang / dbang po rnams yongs su smin pa dang / yongs su 'jig pa dang / 'du byed rnams rnyings par gyur pa dang / shag shig tu gyur pa nas 'dzag pa dang / rab tu 'dzag pa dang / smad pa'i bar gyi lus 'di lta bu 'di ni bsten pa'i 'os ma yin no/ /

bodily distress, bodily pain, bodily decrepitude, being stooped, being bent over, baldness, grey hair, many wrinkles, gradual change and loss of the senses, and the aging and decay that happen to all compounded things. This body that is leaking and dripping fluids is not worth trying to protect, not if the purpose is to indulge!
de bzhin du sbyar te/

dge slong khyod kyis 'dod pa dag yod pa gang yin/ khyod gang la rab tu chags/ khyod ji ltar bcings shing brgyal te zhen cing lhag par zhen par gyur/ nam nga yongs su mya ngan las 'das shing dam pa'i chos kyang nub par gyur la/ khyod kyang 'dod pa rnams bsten nas rnam par ltung bar song ba na nam zhig dga' ba dang 'chi ba las bdag thar par gyur/ dge slong chog gi 'dod pa rnams las sems zlog shig / 'di ni 'dod pa btsal ba'i dus ma yin gyi chos btsal ba'i dus yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

Monk, what peace is there for you in sensual desires?[lxiv] Who is seducing you? How have you gotten like this, fettered, unconscious, and extremely attached? When I have passed into Nirvāṇa, and the holy Dharma has disappeared, you, because of indulging in sensual desires, will have gone to a bad rebirth. When will you free yourself from old age and death? Monk, enough! Turn away your mind from sensual desires. This is not the time to search for sensual pleasures. This is the time to search for the Dharma.

khyim bdag drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / des 'dod pa la log par g.yem pa spang bar bya ste/ bdag gi chung mas chog par 'dzin pa dang / gzhan gyi chung ma la 'dod pa med pa dang / ma chags pa'i mig gis blta ba dang yid byung ba'i yid dang 'dod pa dag ni shin tu sdug bsngal ba'o snyam du ma chags pa'i yid la byed pa la brtson par bya'o/ / de gang gi tshe rang gi chung ma la rnam par rtog pa byung ba de'i tshe yang nyon mongs pa'i dbang du gyur pas na/ des rang gi chung ma la mi sdug par rjes su lta ba dang / skrag pa'i yid kyis 'dod pa bsten par bya'i zhen pas zin bzhin du ni ma yin te/ rtag tu mi rtag pa dang / bdag med pa dang mi gtsang ba'i 'du shes su bya'o/ / des de ltar dran pa nye bar gzhag nas ci nas yid kyi dgu la yang 'dod pa spyad par mi bya na/ mtshan gnyis sprad pa'am yan lag ma yin par 'jug pa lta ci smos te/ bdag gis de ltar bya'o snyam mo zhes gsungs pa dang /

The Inquiry of Ugra also says: He should abstain from sexual misconduct, satisfied with his own wife,[lxv] not longing for the wives of others, looking around with an eye free from attraction and a disenchanted mind. He should frequently attend to and reflect on the thought, “Sensual desires are perpetual suffering.”[lxvi] When thoughts of sensual desire arise in him towards his own wife, and he comes under the influence of reactive emotions, then, seeing the foulness of his wife and with a frightened mind, he should not be bound by attachment to engaging in sensual pleasures, and should always reflect on impermanence, nonself, and impurity. And he should direct his mind as follows: “I should not engage in sensual pleasures even in my thoughts. How much less should I engage in erotic love or the contact of sexual organs?”[lxvii][19]

yang de nyid las byang chub sems dpas rang gi chung ma la 'du shes gsum bskyed par bya ste/ gsum gang zhe na/ 'di ni dga' zhing rtse ba'i grogs yin gyi 'di 'jig rten pha rol gyi grogs ni ma yin no/ / 'di ni bza' ba dang btung ba'i grogs yin gyi/ 'di las kyi rnam par smin pa myong ba'i grogs ni ma yin no/ / 'di ni bde ba'i grogs yin gyi 'di sdug bsngal gyi grogs ni ma yin no snyam pa'o zhes bya ba nas yang gsum ste/ tshul khrims kyi bar du gcod par 'du shes pa dang / ting nge 'dzin gyi bar du gcod par 'du shes pa dang / shes rab kyi bar du gcod par 'du shes pa'o/ / yang gsum ste/ chom rkun du 'du shes pa dang / btson srung du 'du shes pa dang / sems can dmyal ba'i srung mar 'du shes pa'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text says: A bodhisattva should think about his wife in three ways. What are the three? She is my companion in pleasure and play; she is not my companion in the next world. She is my companion in eating and drinking; she is not my companion in experiencing the evolution of actions. She is my companion in happiness; she is not my companion in suffering. And another three: he should conceive of her as an obstacle to moral discipline, as an obstacle to meditative stability,[lxviii] and as an obstacle to wisdom. And another three: he should conceive of her as a thief, as a prison-guard,[lxix] and as one of the guards of Hell.[20]

bu mo zla mchog gis zhus pa las kyang bshad de/ de nas bu mo zla mchog gis skye bo phal po che brgyug pa de mthong ma thag tu/ de'i tshe nam mkha' bar snang la shing ta la'i srid du mngon par 'phags te 'dug nas/ skye bo phal po che de la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

The Inquiry of the Young Woman Candrottarā (Candrottarā-dārikā-paripṛcchā) says: [79] Then the young woman Candrottarā, seeing the great crowd of men running towards her, immediately rose into the air to the height of a palm tree, sat down, and then addressed that great crowd of men in verses, as follows:
gser gyi kha dog lta bur rab 'bar zhing / / yid du 'ong ba'i bdag lus 'di la ltos/ / kye ma rab tu lus mdzes 'di lta bu/ / chags pa'i sems dang ldan la yod re skan/ /
Behold my enchanting body, Shining and glowing, the color of gold! Alas! Someone whose mind is full of attraction Will definitely not have such a beautiful body.

gang dag yul rnams la ni chags med cing / / me mdag lta bur 'dod pa rab spong dang / / dbang po drug po sdom pas bsdams pa dang / / gang dag tshangs spyod rnam par dag spyod dang / / gang dag gzhan gyi chung ma mthong gyur na/ / ma dang sring mo'i 'du shes skyed byed pa/ / de dag mdzes shing blta na sdug pa dang / / rtag par mchog tu yid du 'ong bar 'gyur/ /

But those who give up sensual desires, which burn like a pit of coals, Who are not greedy for objects, Who have disciplined the six senses by a vow, And practice fully pure celibacy— Those who, when they see the wives of others, Think of them as mothers or younger sisters, They become good-looking and attractive, Always enchanting in the highest degree.

grong khyer 'di la kun du gsal bltas dang / / bdag spu khung nas spos ngad gang byung ba/ / bdag gis 'dod chags sems kyis de ma bsgrubs/ / 'di ni sbyin dang dul ba'i 'bras bu yin/ / bdag la 'dod chags sems ni skye ba med/ / 'dod chags bral ba la yang chags mi skyed/ / ji ltar bden par shes kyi log min par/ / bdag gi mdun bzhugs thub dbang 'di dpang yin/ /

This city of the body, whose appearance is completely clear, The fragrant perfume which wafts from my pores, Are not the result of a mind tormented by attraction, But of generosity and of discipline. Thoughts of attraction do not arise in me; Attraction does not arise in those who are free from attraction. The best of sages stands before me as my witness that I know the truth as it is, not inaccurately.
khyod ni sngon chad bdag gi phar gyur cing / / bdag kyang khyed cag rnams kyi mar gyur la/ / ming sring dag dang phar yang gyur gyur na/ / ma la 'dod chags sems ni su zhig skyed/ /
In the past, you were my fathers, And I was your mother. I was brother, sister, and father to you at different times; Who would be attracted to his mother?
bdag gis sngon chad khyed rnams thams cad bsad/ / bdag kyang khyed kyis sngon chad gshegs shing gtubs/ / kun kyang phan tshun dgra dang gsod pa yin/ / khyed cag ji ltar 'dod chags sems kyang skyed/ /
I have murdered all of you before, And you, sirs, have slaughtered me in the past; When we are all enemies and murderers of each other, How could thoughts of attraction arise?
'dod chags can ni gzugs dang ldan mi 'gyur/ / 'dod chags sems ldan bde 'gror 'gro ma yin/ / 'dod chags sems ldan mya ngan 'das mi 'gro/ / de lta bas na 'dod chags yongs su spang / /

People don’t become beautiful because of attraction. Those who have minds full of attraction don’t go to a good rebirth. Nor do those who have minds full of attraction reach Nirvāṇa. Therefore, completely give up attraction!
'dod pa'i rgyus ni sems can dmyal bar ltung / / 'dod chags kyis ni yi dwags dud 'gror 'gyur/ / gang dag 'dod chags sems ni ldan pa rnams/ / grul bum gnod sbyin lha mi sha zar 'gyur/ /

For the sake of sensual pleasures, people fall into hells; Due to attraction, they become hungry ghosts or animals. Those who have minds full of attraction [80] Become trolls, forest spirits, titans, or goblins.
'dod chags kyis ni mi sdug gzugs can dang / / lce med pa dang gyol dang zhar bar 'gyur/ / gang dag smad pa'i spyad pa spyod byed pa/ / de dag rnam pa sna tshogs skyon ldan 'gyur/ /
Those who lead a vile life of sensual pleasures Come to have all kinds of defects: Because of attraction, they become one-eyed, Lame, lacking tongues, and ugly.
'khor los sgyur ba nyid ni thob pa dang / / sum cu rtsa gsum dbang phyug brgya byin dang / / tshangs dang dbang ldan dbang sgyur gang yin pa/ / de ni tshangs spyod rgya chen spyad pas gyur/ /
Those who live the vast practice of celibacy Attain the state of world-emperors, Or become powerful gods: Indras, or the Thirty-Three, Brahmas, Īśvaras, Vaśavartins, and others.
'dod la brkam pa rtag tu dmus long dang / / 'on pa glen pa phag dang rnga mo dang / / lung bong spra'u dang glang chen ba lang dang / / stag dang rta dang phye leb sbrang mar 'gyur/ /
Those who crave sensual pleasures always become Blind from birth, deaf, or retarded, Dogs, pigs, camels, donkeys, monkeys, Elephants, horses, cows, tigers, butterflies, and bees.[lxx]
gang dag tshangs spyod rgya cher spyad pa ni/ / rgyal po dga' dang ldan pa nyid du 'gyur/ / tshong dpon khyim bdag blon po rnams su'ang 'gyur/ / bde dang yid bde ba yang 'phel bar 'gyur/ /
Those who live the vast practice of celibacy Become exalted kings, Distinguished guild presidents, leading merchants, and ministers, And their pleasure and happiness go on increasing.

'dod pa'i khol po rnams ni gshegs shing gtub/ / du bas bdug cing bcing dang brdeg pa dang / / bsdigs dang mgo dang rna ba lag pa dang / / mig dang sna dang rkang pa'ang bcad phyung 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Those who are slaves to sensual desires will have their feet cut off; They will be bound in places full of smoke, beaten, Mocked, and boiled in pots,[lxxi] And their heads, ears, hands, and eyes will be cut off and destroyed.[lxxii]

bad sa'i rgyal po 'char byed kyis zhus pa las kyang smad de/ / rma mthong nas ni sbrang ma brgyug pa dang / / mi gtsang mthong nas lung bong brgyug pa dang / / phyugs kyi sha phyir khyi yang brgyug pa ltar/ / mi mkhas bud med dga' ba de bzhin brgyug /

The Inquiry of King Vatsa of Udayana (Udayana-vatsa-rāja-paripṛcchā) also criticizes sensual pleasures: When he sees a wound, he runs to it, like a fly. When he sees impurity, he runs to it, like a donkey. Just as a dog runs to a slaughterhouse for the sake of meat— [81] That is what they are like, ignorant men who take delight in women.
byis pa rnams ni ma rig bsgribs/ / mun pa'i phung pos kun tu bsgribs/ / bud med chags pa de bzhin rmongs/ / ngan skyugs gnas la bya khwa bzhin/ /
Those fools are obscured by ignorance, Completely covered by a mass of darkness. Attached to women, they are infatuated Like crows drawn to filth.[lxxiii]
ngan 'gror gang dag zhugs pa dang / / myong ba'i 'du shes chags byed de/ / ngan skyugs gnas su srin bu 'dra/ / de dag bdud kyi spyod yul yin/ /
Greedy for an idea of enjoyment, Living in filth like worms, They are in Māra’s domain And are travelling towards the lower realms.
ngan skyugs bum pa ri mo can/ / gang dang gang du snang ba yang / / gcin dang bshang bas gang ba dang / / rkyal pa rlung gis gang ba bzhin/ /
It’s like a brightly painted chamber-pot Which is seen here and there, Full of piss and filth, Or a bellows full of air.
snabs dang mchil ma kha chu dang / / bad kan rnag dang glad rgyas dang / / byis pa rnams kyi lus las ni/ / dri nga 'dzag ste sbrang rtsi bzhin/ /
With their heads wet, Giving off mucus and phlegm, eager for snot, Bad-smelling substances Flow from the bodies of fools, like honey.
rus pas rgyas gyur kha sgo can/ / pags dang sha la sogs pas dkris/ / lus 'di phol mig 'dra ba ste/ / smad pa yin zhing dri nga can/ /
This contemptible body, smelling like raw meat, Full of bones, with the mouth as a door, Bound around with flesh and skin, Is similar to a boil.
dper na phol mig rma kha ni/ / srog chags sna tshogs rnams kyis gang / / de bzhin du ni lus 'di yang / / mi gtsang sna tshogs snod yin no/ /
Like an open wound on the mouth Filled with various insects— That’s how this body is, A receptacle for various kinds of impurity.
lto ni gnye mas gang ba ste/ / mtsher pa dang ni glo ba dang / / mkhal ma khrag dang mkhris pa dang / / glad rgyas rus pa rkang gis gang / /
It is full of intestines, the stomach, the rectum, The liver, the lungs, the heart, Kidneys, blood, bile, Brains, bones, and marrow.[lxxiv]
gang dag khong na gnas pa ni/ / srin bu'i grong khyim brgyad khri yin/ / gti mug dra bas bsgribs pas na/ / byis pa rnams kyis mi shes so/ /
A family of eighty thousand worms Live in the entrails, But fools do not see them, [82] Covered by delusion’s net.
bu ga'i sgo ni dgu dag nas/ / mi gtsang rnag dang dri nga 'dzag / smra ba dang ni mthong bas kyang / / byis pa dag ni mtshan mar 'dzin/ /
From the mouths of nine wounds Stinking impurities flow out, But fools grasp onto signs In words and appearances.
byis pa ngan skyugs spyod yul can/ / mchil ma dang ni snabs za ba/ / chags par 'gyur nas phyogs gang zhing / / kun tu smad pa mi shes so/ /
These fools, who spend their time on filth, Who eat mucus and saliva, As was said before, don’t know That the place they’re attracted to is reviled by everyone.
sbrang ma rnams kyis rma mthong ltar/ / smad pa'i gnas la chags par byed/ / mchan khung gnyis nas rdul 'dzag cing / / btsog pa'i dri ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
Like flies who see a wound, They are attracted to what is contemptible. Sweat comes from their armpits And they give off foul odors.

gang gis ngan 'gror 'gro ba yi/ / nyes par byed pa'i las byed cing / / 'dod pa dman pa bsten pa dang / / dman pa'i chos rnams sten byed pa/ / shes rab 'chal pa mnar med song / / sdug bsngal tshor ba myong bar 'gyur/ / ngan skyugs bzhin du dri nga zhes/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis bud med smad/ /

They do vile actions Through which they go to the lower realms. Indulging low sensual desires And low qualities, The unwise go to Avīci And feel painful sensations. The Buddhas criticized women For being foul-smelling, like dung.

de lta bas na dman pa ni/ / bud med dman pa rnams dang 'dre/ / byis pa gang zhig ngan skyugs kyi/ / rkyal pa thogs nas khyim du 'gro/ / las ni ci 'dra byed pa yi/ / 'bras bu yang ni de 'dra thob/ / ces gsungs so/ /

Therefore, only lowly men Have intercourse with women, who are lowly. Like some fool who goes into a house While carrying a bag of filth, Whatever kind of actions you do, You get results of the same kind.

yang de nyid las gsungs pa/ sdug bsngal bas btsal ba'i longs spyod bdag rang gso ba'i phyir bsgrubs pa dag dge sbyong dang bram ze rnams dang / bkren pa dang sdug phongs pa dang slong ba rnams la sbyin pa gtong bar mi nus te/ bud med kyi dbang du gyur cing / bud med kyi thul 'og tu chud la bud med kyis tshar chod pa bud med kyis 'khol ba rnams ni/ bud med la dga' ba de nyid kyis de gso ba'i phyir sbyin pa gtong bar mi nus tshul khrims yang dag par 'dzin mi nus so/ / de de la chags pas bud med kyis spyo ba'ang bzod bsdigs shing lta ba dang brgyad pa'ang bzod do/ / bud med kyis bsdigs pa'i mi de zhum zhing sro shi la de'i gdong du blta ste 'dod pa'i rgyu dang 'dod pa'i gzhi'i dbang du song ba yin no/ / rgyal po chen po 'di ni 'dod pa la brkam pa ngan skyugs kyi sgo la gdu ba mi gtsang ba la dga' ba shes bzhin med par spyod pa'i mi'i skyon yin no/ /

The same text says: [83] Out of the wealth they have earned with painful effort for their own livelihood, they cannot give gifts to religious wanderers and Brahmins, or to the destitute, the wretched, the poor, and beggars, because they are subjugated by women, conquered by women, controlled by women, slaves to women. Because of their love for women, they have to nourish them, and so they cannot give generously or undertake moral discipline. A man who is full of attraction puts up with women’s scolding; he puts up with their ridicule, stares, and criticisms. When he is mocked by a woman, that man is discouraged and depressed, but he still looks to her for happiness. For the sake of sensual pleasures, he is subordinated to the person who is the source of those pleasures. Your Majesty, a man who ardently longs for sensual pleasures, who sees filth as the highest happiness, who delights in impurity, and who lives his life without awareness, has this problem
de bzhin du sbyar te/
'di 'dra thos kyang skyo ba dang / / yid 'byung mi 'gyur de dag ni/ / rab tu rmongs nas bud med dang / / phyir zhing sten par byed par 'gyur/ /
Even when they hear teachings like these, Disgust and disenchantment don’t arise in them. Being totally ignorant, they spend Even more of their time with women.[lxxv]
btsog cing shin tu smad bya ba/ / 'dod pa sdug bsngal sten byed cing / / chos thos nas ni rab rmongs shing / / legs par smras zhes smra bar byed/ /
They spend their time on painful sensual desires Which are defiled and contemptible, But, very confused about their own welfare, They hear the Dharma and say, “Well spoken!”
de yi sems ni mo phyir song / / byi ba la ni byi la bzhin/ / rgyal bas bshad pa thos nas ni/ / yud tsam zhig ni yid 'byung 'gyur/ / de nas de ni yang 'khrug ste/ / dper na drag po'i dug dang 'dra/ /

A man’s mind goes towards women Like a cat’s to mice.[lxxvi] When he hears what the Victor said, He feels disenchanted just for a moment; Then attraction swells up in him again, Like poisonous venom.[21]

ji ltar phag ni yud tsam zhig / sngangs shing skrag par gyur kyang ni/ / ngan skyugs mthong bar gyur pa dang / / de ni brkam pa skyed pa bzhin/ / de ltar byis pa bde 'dod pa/ / rgyal ba'i bstan pa spangs nas su/ / gang gis ngan 'gror 'gro ba yi/ / 'dod pa dman pa sten par byed/ /

Just as a pig becomes frightened And is afraid for just a moment, But once he sees some filth, He starts to be greedy for it, In the same way, these fools, who want to be happy, Having left behind the Victor’s teaching, Indulge in low sensual pleasures By which they go to the lower realms.
'dod pa rnams la chags zhen nas/ / shin tu sdig pa'i las byas te/ / tshul khrims ldan la skur ba ni/ / phyi nas ngan 'gror 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
Heedless and full of attraction for sensual pleasures, They perform serious vile actions, And deprecate people who have moral discipline;[lxxvii] Afterwards, they go to the lower realms.
skyes bu gang zhig chos tshul 'di 'dra ba/ / rigs nas bud med rnams la bag byed pa/ / des ni mtho ris lam yang rtag par sbyangs/ / de la byang chub rab mchog dkon ma yin/ /
A man who has found a teaching like this one Should not trust women.[lxxviii] The path to Heaven is always clear for him, And Awakening, the supreme benefit, is not hard for him to get.
dal rnyed shes rab ldan gyur cing / / 'di 'dra ba yi chos thos pa/ / 'dod pa thams cad 'dir spangs te/ / mkhas pa rab 'byung mngon par 'byung / / zhes gsungs so/ /
Discerning that he has found a favorable opportunity And hearing Dharma of this kind, Giving up all sensual pleasures right here and now, [84] An intelligent man would go forth into ordination.

rab tu zhi ba rnam par nges pa'i cho 'phrul gyi mdo las kyang gnod pa gzhan gsungs te/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la las 'dzam bu'i gling pa'i sems can thams cad kyi srog bcad dam de dag gi bdog pa thams cad phrogs pa bas/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang gzhan zhig gis byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i rtsa ba gcig gis sems bskyed pa/ tha na dud 'gro'i skye gnas su song ba la zan changs cig sbyin pa dang ldan pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba'i bar chad byas na/ de de bas ches sdig pa grangs med par skyed do/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sangs rgyas 'byung ba skyed pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba'i bar chad byed par gnas pa'i phyir ro/ / 'jam dpal byang chub sems dpa' gang la la gzhan gyi khyim rnams su byang chub sems dpa' la phrag dog dang ser sna byed na/ des de'i tshe gzhi de las 'jigs pa chen po gsum shes par bya ste/ gsum gang zhe na sems can dmyal bar skye ba'i 'jigs pa dang / dmus long gis 'jigs pa dang / yul mtha' 'khob tu skye ba'i 'jigs pa zhes bya ba'o/ /

The Sūtra on the Miracle of Calm Inquiry (Praśānta-viniścaya-prātihārya-sūtra) discusses something else that is harmful: Mañjuśrī, if some gentleman or lady were to kill all the sentient beings in India or rob them of everything they have, and if some other gentleman or lady were to create an obstacle for a bodhisattva who has done even a single wholesome action—even one who has been reborn as an animal, and has only the goodness created by giving away one single mouthful of food—for the second, incalculably more vileness flows forth than for the first. Why is this? She stands as an obstacle to the wholesome actions[lxxix] that give rise to the emergence of the Buddhas. Mañjuśrī, anyone in other families[lxxx] who arouses envy and stinginess toward a bodhisattva should, at that time, expect[lxxxi] three dangers. Which three? The danger of being born in hell, the danger of being born blind, and the danger of being born in a barbaric land.[22]

yang gsungs pa/ / mi gang de la dga' bar mi byed cing / / yod pa min dang bsngags pa mi smra dang / / mi gang khros nas mi snyan smra ba'am/ / yang na de la 'khrug pa byed pa dag / sems can dmyal bar skye 'gyur te/ / lus ni chen por gyur nas su/ / de yis sdug bsngal myong 'gyur te/ / yid rab mi bde ma rungs 'gyur/ /

And the text says: Anyone who acts in an unfriendly way towards him Or says uncomplimentary things about him, whether true or not, Or anyone who slanders him out of anger Or tries to pick a fight with him, That wicked person will be born As a hell-being with a large body And experience painful sensations, His mind plunged into depression.
dpag tshad lnga brgya'i tshad tsam du/ / de yi lus ni skye bar 'gyur/ / sdig pa'i las kyis rtag tu khyi/ / bye bas bskor nas za bar 'gyur/ /
The slanderer’s body becomes Five hundred leagues in length; Due to his vile actions, over and over again He is surrounded and continually eaten by ten million dogs;[lxxxii]
bskal pa dag ni du mar yang / / lus ni dpag tshad lnga brgyar 'gyur/ / de la mgo yang lnga brgya ste/ / de las nyung bar mi 'gyur ro/ /
For many aeons His body is five hundred leagues long. On his body are no fewer Than five thousand[lxxxiii] heads;

mgo rnams re re dag la yang / / lnga brgya'i lce las mi nyung ste/ / lce gcig la yang thong gshol ni/ / lnga brgyar tshang ste mi nyung ba/ / 'bar bas de la rmo byed de/ / skur 'debs brdegs pa'i las kyis so/ /

In each and every head There are no less than five hundred tongues; On each and every tongue There are five hundred blazing mouths;[lxxxiv] They are all ploughed [85] Because of the vile words he said.

tshig rtsub dag ni smras pas ni/ / shin tu tsha bar sreg par 'gyur/ / gang dag sdom par mi byed cing / / byang chub sems dpa' gnod byed pa/ / de ni sems can dmyal rnyed de/ / dud 'gro'i skye gnas 'gro bar 'gyur/ /

Those who harm bodhisattvas[lxxxv], Those who speak harsh words And those who don’t keep their vows Are burned in agonizing pain, Afflicted by the sharp pain of fire.[lxxxvi] Rebirths as animals or in the hells Are easy for them to find.[lxxxvii]

tshul 'di spong bar byed pa ni/ / bskal pa bye ba stong rnams dang / / brgya dang khrag khrig rnams su yang / / mnar med par ni sdug bsngal rnyed/ / de nas shi 'phos rab gdug cing / / shin tu mi bzad sbrul du 'gyur/ /
Those who reject this religion, For tens of billions of aeons, And then for tens of trillions, They suffer in Avīci. When they have died there, they become terrifying snakes Of fearsome poison;
bkres shing skom pas mngon gzir kyang / / shin tu mi bzad las rnams byed/ / bza' ba rnyed kyang sdig pa yis/ / nam yang tshim par mi 'gyur ro/ /
Overpowered by hunger and thirst, They do very terrible things, And even when they get food and drink,[lxxxviii] They are never satisfied.

gal te de nas shi 'phos nas/ / mi yi nang du skyes na yang / / yid mi gzhungs shing dmus long 'gyur/ / gnod par sems shing sdom pa med/ / nyes pa'i tshig rnams smras nas ni/ / 'phags pa mnyes par mi byed pa/ / mi yi nang nas shi 'phos nas/ / slar yang ngan 'gror 'gro bar 'gyur/ / bskal pa bye ba stong rnams su/ / nam yang sangs rgyas mthong mi 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

If they die there And are reborn among humans, They are blind from birth and dishonest, Full of malice and without vows. Those who have said disrespectful words About Noble Ones, the ill-spoken, When they have died among humans, They go to the lower realms, And for ten billion aeons Never see a Buddha.

yang de nyid las/ 'jam dpal byang chub sems dpas byang chub sems dpa' la khong khro ba'i sems bskyed pa'am/ brnyas pa'i sems bskyed pa ji tsam pa de snyed kyis bskal par byang chub sems dpa' des sems can dmyal ba pa rnams su gnas par go cha bgo bar bya'o/ / 'jam dpal byang chub sems dpa' la skur pa btab pa ma gtogs par byang chub sems dpa' las gzhan gang gis kyang log par ltung bar mi nus so/ / 'jam dpal 'di lta ste/ dper na nor bu rin po che rdo rje ni rdo rje nyid ma gtogs par shing ngam bong ba'am dbyug pa'am rdo ba'am mtshon chas bcag par mi nus so/ / 'jam dpal de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' yang byang chub sems dpa' la skur ba btab pa ma gtogs par las gzhan gyis log par ltung bar byed mi nus so zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text says, [86] Mañjuśrī, a bodhisattva who arouses thoughts of anger or contempt towards another bodhisattva should prepare to spend an aeon in the great hells for each of those thoughts. Mañjuśrī, there is no other action by which bodhisattvas can fall as they can by disparaging another bodhisattva. For example, Mañjuśrī, a precious diamond gem cannot be cut by anything else, such as a stick, a lump of earth, {a club, a stone, or a weapon,} except for another diamond. In just the same way, Mañjuśrī, there is no other action by which bodhisattvas can fall as they can by disparaging another bodhisattva.

dad pa'i stobs bskyed pa la 'jug pa'i phyag rgya'i mdo las kyang / 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis khros nas phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi sems can thams cad btson ra mun nag dag tu bcug pa bas/ rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la khros te byang chub sems dpa' la rgyab kyis phyogs te 'dug nas ma rungs pa 'di mi blta'o/ / zhes zer na 'di ni de bas sdig pa ches grangs med par skyed do/ / 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis 'dzam bu'i gling gi sems can thams cad kyi bdog pa thams cad phrogs pa bas/ gzhan gang gis byang chub sems dpa' ji lta bu yang rung ba la smad na 'di ni de bas ches sdig pa grangs med par skyed do zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Sūtra on the Posture for Beginning to Generate the Power of Faith (Śraddhā-bala-ādhāna-avatāra-mudrā-sūtra) also says: Mañjuśrī, suppose a gentleman or lady were to get angry and throw all the sentient beings in all the world-realms in the ten directions into dark dungeons. Now suppose another gentleman or lady were to get angry at a bodhisattva and stand facing away from her, thinking “I don’t see that horrid person.” The second would generate incalculably more vileness than the first. The same text says: Mañjuśrī, suppose someone were to rob all the sentient beings in India of everything they have. And suppose someone else should condemn a bodhisattva—whatever he might be like. The second would generate incalculably more vileness than the first.

yang de nyid las/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis mchod rten gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed bshig pa dang bsregs pa bas/ rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gzhan gang zhig gis theg pa chen po la mos pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la gnod sems dang tha ba dang khro ba'i sems bskyed de gshe ba dang mi snyan par smra na 'di ni de bas ches sdig pa grangs med par skyed do/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' las sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams nges par 'byung la/ sangs rgyas las mchod rten rnams dang lha'i rigs thams cad kyi bde ba'i yo byad thams cad 'byung ngo / / byang chub sems dpa' la bsti stang ma byas pa ni sangs rgyas thams cad la bsti stang ma byas pa yin no/ / byang chub sems dpa' la bsti stang byas pa ni sangs rgyas thams cad la bsti stang byas pa yin no/ / sangs rgyas thams cad la mchod pa bla na med pas mchod pa byed 'dod pas byang chub sems dpa' rnams mchod par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text says: Mañjuśrī, suppose some gentleman or lady were to throw down and burn stūpas equal in number to the sands of the Ganges River. And suppose another gentleman or lady, having become angry and enraged and feeling malice towards a bodhisattva committed to the Great Way, should shout at and criticize that bodhisattva. The second generates incalculably more vileness than the first. Why is that? The Blessed Ones, the Buddhas, come from bodhisattvas; and from the Buddhas come stūpas, and all the causes of happiness, and all the classes of gods. When you show disrespect to a bodhisattva, you show disrespect to all the Buddhas. But when you show respect to a bodhisattva, you show respect to all the Buddhas. Someone who wants to worship the Buddhas with the Supreme Worship must also worship the bodhisattvas.

de ltar mchod pa'i rnam par smin pa ni rab tu zhi ba rnam par nges pa'i cho 'phrul gyi mdo las kyang / gang zhig chos dang ldan pa ni/ / chos smra de dag srung byed pa/ / ngan 'gro rnams ni kun spangs nas/ / brgya byin rdzu 'phrul chen por 'gyur/ / tshangs pa dga' ldan 'thab bral dang / / dbang byed par yang de 'gyur ro/ /

The result of the evolution of this kind of worship is described in the Sūtra on the Miracle of Calm Inquiry: He who, in a way consistent with the Dharma, Provides protection for Dharma teachers, Leaving the lower realms behind, Becomes Śakra, the king of the gods,[lxxxix] And Brahmā, and one of the Yāma gods, And a Vaśavartin, and a Tuṣita god, again and again.

gal te mir ni gyur na yang / / rtag tu 'khor los sgyur bar 'gyur/ / tshong dpon dang ni khyim bdag 'gyur/ / rtag tu skyid cing nor chen 'gyur/ / ji ltar gang gA'i bye snyed kyi/ / bskal pa de snyed rtag tu yang / / 'jigs med dran pa phun sum tshogs/ / bde dang ldan zhing gnod pa med/ / ces gsungs so/ /

If he is born among humans, He always becomes a world-emperor, A guild president, or a leading merchant, [87] Always prosperous and of great wealth. For aeons equal in number To the sands of the Ganges. He has wisdom and mindfulness,[xc] Happiness and freedom from harm.

phan pa byed pa dang gnod pa byed pa bsam pa 'di byang chub sems dpa' gang gi dbang du byas she na/ so so'i skye bo nyid kyi dbang du byas pa ste/ dad pa'i stobs skyed pa la 'jug pa'i phyag rgya'i mdo las ji skad du/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis sems can 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi rdul snyed dag la bskal pa gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed du nyin gcig bzhin lha'i zas ro brgya dang ldan pa byin pa dang de bzhin du lha'i gos rnams sbyin pa byin pa bas rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gzhan gang zhig gis dge bsnyen ston pa gzhan la mi brten pa dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam dang ldan pa zhig la/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi bslab pa la bslabs pa'o snyam du bsams nas nyin gcig zan cig byin na 'di ni de bas ches bsod nams grangs med par skyed do/ / 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis dge bsnyen ston pa gzhan la mi brten pa dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam dang ldan pa 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi rdul snyed dag la/ bskal pa gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed du nyin gcig bzhin lha'i zas ro brgya dang ldan pa byin pa dang de bzhin du lha'i gos rnams sbyin pa byin pa bas rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gzhan gang zhig gis dge slong gcig la nyin gcig zan cig byin na/ 'di ni de bas ches bsod nams grangs med par skyed do zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Now in these reflections about harms and benefits, what kind of bodhisattva is being referred to? Just an ordinary person.[23] As it says in the Sūtra on the Mudrā of Entering the Generation of the Power of Faith, Mañjuśrī, suppose a gentleman or a lady were, every day, to give divine food of a hundred tastes and divine clothes to as many sentient beings as there are atoms in all the world-realms, and continued giving like this for oceans of aeons equal in number to the sands of the Ganges river. Now suppose another gentleman or lady were to give one single day’s food to a lay Buddhist who has no other teacher [than the Buddha] and who practices the ten wholesome courses of action,[xci] thinking “He is trained in the training of the Buddha, the Blessed One.” The second would generate incalculably more goodness than the first. Mañjuśrī, suppose a gentleman or lady were, every day, to give divine food of a hundred tastes and divine clothes to as many lay Buddhists[xcii] who practice the ten wholesome courses of action as there are atoms in all the world-realms, and continued giving like this for aeons equal in number to the sands of the Ganges river. Now suppose another gentleman or lady were to give one single day’s food to a monk. The second would generate incalculably more goodness than the first.

nges pa dang ma nges pa la 'jug pa'i phyag rgya'i mdo las kyang / 'jam dpal yongs su brtag pa nye bar bzung ste/ gal te phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi sems can kun gyi mig phyung bar gyur la/ yongs su brtag pa nye bar bzung ste rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang gis byams pa'i sems kyis sems can de dag thams cad la mig de dag bskyed pa bas/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gzhan gang gis theg pa chen po la mos pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la dad pa'i sems kyis blta na/ 'di ni de bas ches bsod nams grangs med par skyed do/ / 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la las phyogs bcu'i sems can btson rar bcug pa thams cad btson ra nas bton te/ 'khor los sgyur ba'i bde ba'am tshangs pa nyid kyi bde ba la bkod pa bas/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gzhan gang gis theg pa chen po la mos pa la dang ba'i sems kyis lta 'dod par gyur cing de'i bsngags pa yang brjod na/ 'di ni de bas ches bsod nams grangs med par skyed do zhes gsungs so/ /

The Sūtra on the Postures that Do or Do Not Certainly Lead to Awakening also says, Mañjuśrī, to take a hypothetical case,[xciii] suppose that all the sentient beings in the ten directions were to have their eyes ripped out, and suppose, hypothetically, that some gentleman or lady, moved by lovingkindness, were to make all their eyes grow back. Now suppose another gentleman or lady were to look upon and trust a bodhisattva who has confidence in the Great Way. The second would generate incalculably more goodness than the first. [88] Alternately, suppose that all the sentient beings in the ten directions were in prison, and some gentleman or lady were to let them out and establish them in the happiness of a world-emperor.[xciv] Now suppose another gentleman or lady were to trust someone who has confidence in the Great Way, long to see him, and speak favorably about him. The second would generate incalculably more goodness than the first.[xcv]

de skad du sa'i snying po'i mdo las kyang / btsun pa bcom ldan 'das rgyal rigs dge ba'am blon po dge ba'am shor ba dge ba'am dge sbyong dge ba'am bram ze dge ba gang zhig gzhan srung ba dang bdag srung ba dang 'jig rten pha rol srung ba dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bstan pa dang / nyan thos snod du gyur pa dang snod du ma gyur pa yang rung skra bregs nas gos ngur smrig gi tshal bu bgos pa yongs su srung ba dang / nyan pa dang / mchod pa dang / nyan thos kyi gtam dang / rang sangs rgyas kyi gtam dang / theg pa chen po'i gtam nyan pa dang / theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i gang zag tshul khrims dang ldan pa yon tan gyis phyug pa grol ba dang / rigs pa'i spobs pa can dag la mchod pa dang / de dag dang lhan cig tu dga' ba dang rtse ba dang yongs su 'dri ba dang yongs su 'drir 'jug pa dang de dag las mnyan cing bya'o snyam du sems zhes bya ba nas/

In the same way, the Kṣitigarbha Sūtra also says, “Revered Blessed One, a warrior-noble who is virtuous, or a king’s minister who is virtuous, or a scholar[xcvi] who is virtuous, or a religious wanderer who is virtuous, or a Brahmin who is virtuous, protects others, protects himself, and protects the next world. Suppose someone protects {the Disciples} [ordained] in the religion of the Blessed One, whether worthy or unworthy, including anyone who at least has a shaven head and wears a tattered monastic robe, listens to them, venerates them, and listens to teachings appropriate for Disciples and Solitary Sages and to teachings about the Great Way. Suppose that person spends time with people who are practicing the Great Way, morally disciplined, rich in abilities, having the illumination of practice and the illumination of freedom;[xcvii] he has fun with them, jokes around, asks questions, engages in dialogue, and reflects on what he has heard from them and what he should do about it
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de'i sdig pa ji tsam zhig 'byang bar 'gyur/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste dper na mi la la zhig skyes la/ des 'dzam bu'i gling thams cad rin po che sna bdun gyis bkang ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das bzhugs pa rnams la dbul ba phul la nyi ma gung gi dus su yang de bzhin phye ma red kyi dus su yang de bzhin 'bul zhing / rnam grangs 'dis lo brgya stong du 'di ltar dbul ba phul na/ 'di ji snyam du sems mi de bsod nams mang du bskyed dam/ gsol pa/ btsun pa bcom ldan 'das mi de bsod nams kyi phung po mang po grangs ma mchis dpag tu ma mchis pa skyed do/ / de'i bsod nams kyi phung po ni de bzhin gshegs pa ma gtogs par gzhan gang gis kyang tshad gzung bar nus pa ma lags so/ /

Blessed One, how much vileness does he get rid of in this way?” The Blessed One replied, “Noble sir, for example, suppose someone were to fill all of India with the seven precious substances and offer them all as gifts to presently living Buddhas, Blessed Ones. Suppose he did this every day at noon and in the evening, and continued to make offerings in this way for one hundred thousand years. What do you think, noble sir—would that person generate a great deal of goodness?” He said, “Revered Blessed One, that man would generate a great mass of goodness, immeasurable and incalculable. No one but the Tathāgata himself could understand the magnitude of that mass of goodness.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal rigs dge ba'am zhes bya ba nas gong du ji skad smos pa'i bar du de bzhin du sbyar te/ de bsod nams kyi phung po shin tu mang du skyed pa nas/ bsod nams kyi phung po shin tu yangs pa dang shin tu tshad med pa dang shin tu grangs med pa'i bar du skyed do/ / gang zhig lnga brgya pa tha ma la nga'i dam pa'i chos kyi tshul srung ba de ni bdag srung ba dang gzhan srung ba dang 'jig rten pha rol srung ba dang nga'i bstan pa srung ba dang / nyan thos snod du gyur pa'am snod du ma gyur pa yang rung skra bregs te gos ngur smrig bgos pa rnams yongs su srung ba dang / mi 'tshe ba nas rang gi yul 'khor dang gzhan gyi yul 'khor gyi bar du 'phel bar byed pa dang / ngan song zad par byed pa dang / lha'i gnas 'phel bar byed pa dang / tshe ring du skyong ba dang / rang gi nyon mongs pa dang gzhan gyi nyon mongs pa rnams sel ba dang / rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi lam pha rol tu phyin pa drug ston pa dang / ngan song thams cad rnam par spong ba dang / 'khor ba ni ring du mi 'khor ba dang / rtag tu dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnams dang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams dang phrad cing / rtag tu dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnams dang mi 'bral bar 'gyur ro/ / ji ltar bsams pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing du ring po mi thogs par bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ro/ /

[89] The Blessed One said, “But, noble sir, a warrior-noble who is virtuous—and so on, as was said before—generates more goodness; he generates a vastly greater, immeasurably greater, incalculably greater mass of goodness. When anyone, during the final five hundred years,[24] protects the practice of my holy Dharma, he protects himself, protects others, protects the next world, protects my religion, and also protects my Disciples, whether worthy or unworthy, including anyone who at least has a shaven head and wears the monastic robe, and does not harm them. He causes his own country and other countries to prosper. He puts an end to the lower realms, attains the god realm, and ensures a long life. He clears away his own reactive emotions and the reactive emotions of others. He supports[xcviii] the six perfections of the path to Awakening. He leaves behind all bad rebirths, and does not wander in cyclic existence for a long time. He always meets with spiritual teachers, with Buddhas, Blessed Ones, and with bodhisattva great beings, and pays careful attention to them.[xcix] He is never without a spiritual teacher. He appears in whatever Buddha fields he wishes, and after a short time, will awaken to highest genuine full Awakening.”

de nas lha'i dbang po thams cad 'khor dang bcas pa nas sha za'i dbang po'i bar du 'khor dang bcas pa stan las langs te/ bcom ldan 'das ga la ba de logs su thal mo sbyar ba btud nas 'di skad ces gsol to/ / btsun pa bcom ldan 'das da ltar dang ma 'ongs pa'i dus lnga brgya pa tha ma'i bar du rgyal rigs dge ba rnams dang khyim bdag dge ba'i bar dag dang

Then the kings of gods with their retinues, and so on up to the goblin kings with their retinues, rose up from their seats, respectfully saluted the Blessed One with their palms together, and said, “Revered Blessed One, as for those who, now and in the future, up to the final five hundred years, namely, warrior-nobles who are virtuous, and so on up to leading merchants who are virtuous
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ltar dam pa'i chos srung ba dang de ltar dkon mchog gsum gyi rigs 'bar bar bgyid pa'i rgyal rigs dge ba nas khyim bdag dge ba'i bar de dag la bdag cag 'khor dang bcas pa thams cad kyis kyang rnam pa bcu'i bar gyis bsrung bar bgyi/ yongs su bskyang bar bgyi 'phel bar bgyi'o/ /
