including those who protect the true Dharma, and those who make the family of the Three Jewels shine … all of us, along with our retinues, will protect those warrior-nobles who are virtuous, and those leading merchants who are virtuous, and so on, in ten ways; we will defend them and help them to flourish.

bcu gang zhe na/ de'i tshe 'phel bar bgyi ba dang / tshe'i bar chad kyang chos kyis bzlog par bgyi ba dang / bro nad ma mchis pa dang / 'khor dang bcas pa dang / chos kyi phung po dang / longs spyod pa dang / dbang phyug dang / snyan pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen rnams dang / shes rab phun sum tshogs pa yang 'phel bar bgyi ba ste/ bcu po de dag gis bsrung bar bgyi'o/ / zhes rgya cher gsungs so/ / de ltar na sar ma chud pa rnams la yang rnam par smin pa 'di rgya cher blta bar bya'o/ /

What are the ten ways? We will increase their lifespan. We will remove obstacles to their long life through Dharma. We will increase their health, retinue, wealth,[c] possessions, political power, fame, connections with spiritual teachers, and their wealth of wisdom. These are the ten.” And so on at length. This detailed explanation of results of evolution should be understood to apply to those who have not yet entered the Stages.
spyan ras gzigs kyi mdo las kyang / / srog chags kun la phan pa'i phyir/ / byang chub tu ni sems bskyed nas/ / 'jig rten mgon gyi mchod rten la/ / su zhig skor bar byed pa ni/ /

The Avalokanā Sūtra also says: For the welfare and benefit of all living things, Those who arouse the mind for full Awakening, and then At stūpas of the Protector of the World Perform circumambulations:[25]
skye ba dag ni thams cad du/ / byang chub spyad pa spyod pa'i tshe/ / dran dang ldan zhing blo gros ldan/ / bsod nams ldan zhing 'jigs med 'gyur/ /
{In all their births When they practice, they will practice for Awakening; They will be mindful and intelligent, [90] Have goodness and be fearless.}[ci]

zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs nas bka' stsal pa/ sangs rgyas sras po de dag la/ / mi gang mi dga' byed pa der/ / lha dang mi ni spangs nas su/ / de dag sems dmyal spyod yul 'gyur/ / zhes rgya cher gsungs so/ /

And so on. After praising the benefits in detail, the Buddha said: But those who do unpleasant things To these heirs of the Buddhas Leave behind the gods and humans And spend their time in the hells. And so on at length.
gong ma bzhin du 'dir yang khyad par gyi rgyu gang yang bstan par mi nus te/ de ltar dpyad pas chog go/ /
Just as before, we should not understand there to be any restriction of the scope of these statements [to noble bodhisattvas only.][cii] This matter has now been analyzed sufficiently.

las kyi sgrib pa rnam par dag pa'i mdo las kyang / sgrib pa'i sgra ni gnod par gsungs te/ 'jam dpal sgrib pa zhes bya ba ni/ 'dod chags sgrib pa/ zhe sdang sgrib pa/ gti mug sgrib pa/ sbyin pa sgrib pa/ tshul khrims sgrib pa/ bzod pa sgrib pa/ brtson 'grus sgrib pa/ bsam gtan sgrib pa/ shes rab sgrib pa'o/ /

In the Sūtra on Clearing Away Karmic Distortions (Karma-āvaraṇa-viśuddhi-sūtra), harmful things associated with the term “distortion” are discussed: Mañjuśrī, attraction is said to be a distortion. Aversion is a distortion. Delusion is a distortion. Generosity can be distorted. Moral discipline, forbearance, perseverance, meditative stability and wisdom can all be distorted
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'jam dpal byis pa so so'i skye bo rnams sbyin pa byin pa'i tshe ser sna can rnams la ma dad par byed de/ de dag ma dad pa des khong khro ba'i sems bskyed pa nas/ khong khro ba'i tha ba'i skyon des sems can dmyal ba chen po rnams su skye'o/ /

Why is this? Foolish ordinary people, while giving gifts, distrust stingy people. Due to this lack of trust, they arouse thoughts of hostility. Because of the problems associated with the reactivity of this hostility, they are born in the great hells.

de dag tshul khrims srung ba'i tshe 'chal pa'i tshul khrims can la smod cing gshe la de dag gis mi snyan par smra'o/ / de dag las de dag gi skyon thos nas skye bo mang po ma dad par byed do/ / de dag ma dad pa des na ngan 'gror 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ /

When they are protecting their moral discipline, they condemn and denounce people whose moral discipline is lax, and they say uncomplimentary things about them. Because of having heard about these problems, they distrust most people, and because of this lack of trust, they go to the lower realms.

de dag bzod pa sgom pa'i tshe bdag cag ni bzod pa dang ldan pa yin/ de dag gzhan ni gnod sems kyi sems dang ldan pa yin no snyam du bzod pa'i rgyags pas bag med par 'gyur te/ bzod pa'i rgyags pas bag med pa de dag bag med pa'i rtsa ba las byung ba'i sdug bsngal rnams myong bar 'gyur ro/ /

When they are developing patient endurance, they become intoxicated with patient endurance, puff themselves up with pride, and become heedless, thinking “We are teachers of patient endurance.[ciii] Now, those others have thoughts of malice.” Because they are intoxicated with patient endurance, suffering arises from this intoxication.

de dag brtson 'grus rtsom pa'i tshe dge slong 'di dag ni le lo can du gnas pa mngon par mi brtson pa dad pas byin pa yongs su spyod pa ste/ 'di dag ni chu phor gang gi 'os kyang ma yin no snyam du bdag la bstod de/ de dag brtson 'grus rtsom pa des bdag la bstod cing gzhan la smod pa de dag ni byis pa yin no zhes nga smra'o/ /

When they are developing perseverance, they praise themselves and disparage others, saying “Those monks are lazy. They hang out, don’t work hard, and eat the gifts of the faithful. They don’t even deserve a bowl of water!” In this way, on account of their perseverance, they praise themselves and disparage others. I say they are fools.

de dag bsam gtan la mnyam par 'jog pa'i tshe bsam gtan dang snyoms par 'jug pa des 'dod pa skyed cing de dag 'di snyam du sems te/ bdag cag ni ting nge 'dzin la gnas pa yin/ dge slong 'di dag gzhan ni sems g.yeng bar gnas pa yin te/ 'di dag ni sangs rgyas su ga la 'gyur zhes rgya cher ro/ /

While they are resting the mind in meditation, they begin to have an eager desire for meditative stability and meditative absorption. They think, “We rest in meditative absorption, but those other monks live with distracted minds. How could they become Buddhas?”

chos thams cad 'byung ba med par bstan pa las kyang / byang chub sems dpa' la ltung bas gleng na byang chub dang ring bar 'gyur ro/ / las kyi sgrib pa yang yongs su 'dzin to/ / phrag dog gis gleng na byang chub dang ring bar 'gyur ro/ / spyod lam gyis gleng na byang chub dang ring bar 'gyur ro/ / gal te byang chub sems dpas byang chub sems dpa' la dman pa'i 'du shes dang bdag la rgya che ba'i 'du shes bskyed pa bdag smas pa dang las kyi sgrib pa yongs su 'dzin to/ / gal te de byang chub yongs su mi gtong na 'di la byang chub sems dpas byang chub sems dpa' la gdams pa dang rjes su bstan pa'i tshe ston pa'i 'du shes nye bar gzhag ste gdams par bya/ rjes su bstan par bya'i byang chub sems dpas byang chub sems dpa' la brnyas pa'i sems bskyed par ni mi bya'o/ / lha'i bu ji ltar byang chub sems dpa' cig shos la brten nas byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di chad pa de lta bu ni gang na yang med do zhes gsungs so/ / byang chub tu sems ma bskyed pa'i sems can byang chub kyi skal ba can la yang brnyas pa bkag na byang chub tu sems bskyed pa lta smos kyang ci dgos/ dpa' bar 'gro ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi mdo las/

And so on at length. The Teaching on the Non-Origination of Everything also says: [91] When someone accuses a bodhisattva of a downfall, Awakening is far away, and a karmic distortion forms.[civ] When someone makes an accusation out of envy, Awakening is far away. When someone accuses another of bad behavior, Awakening is far away. When {bodhisattvas} form a conception of other bodhisattvas as lower and themselves as higher, they harm themselves, and karmic distortions form in them. Bodhisattvas who still have some things to learn, who still need admonition themselves, even when they are instructing other bodhisattvas and explaining things to them, should nevertheless think of them as teachers; they should never arouse a thought of contempt towards any bodhisattva who has not given up on Awakening. Divine Prince, there is nothing that can destroy a bodhisattva’s wholesome actions like interacting with other bodhisattvas. It is forbidden to despise even those who have not aroused Awakening Mind, inasmuch as they are destined someday to awaken—how much more so for someone who has aroused Awakening Mind! As the Sūtra on the Meditative Absorption of Heroic Progress says,[26]

blo gros brtan pa/ de la byang chub tu sems ma bskyed par lung bstan pa gang zhe na/ blo gros brtan pa 'di la gang zag la la zhig 'gro ba lnga'i 'khor bar yang na sems can dmyal ba'am/ yang na dud 'gro'i skye gnas sam/ yang na gshin rje'i 'jig rten nam/ yang na lha'am/ yang na mir skyes par gyur la/ gang zag de yang dbang po rno ba rgya chen po la mos pa yin no/ de la de bzhin gshegs pas rab tu mkhyen te/ skyes bu gang zag 'di ni bskal pa 'di snyed bskal pa brgya phrag 'di snyed bskal pa stong phrag 'di snyed bskal pa brgya stong phrag 'di snyed bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong phrag 'di snyed na byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ro zhes bya ba nas/

“Dṛḍhamati,[27] what is a prophecy of Awakening for someone who has not aroused Awakening Mind? Here, Dṛḍhamati, someone is born in cyclic existence, with its five realms: perhaps in the hells, or in the animal realm, or in the world of Yama, or among the gods, or perhaps among humans.[28] And this person has sharp faculties and lofty religious commitment. About her, the Tathāgata knows: “This person, after a thousand million billion aeons, will arouse her mind for highest genuine full Awakening … and one hundred thousand countless aeons after that, will fully awaken.”[cv]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

blo gros brtan pa de ni byang chub tu sems ma bskyed par lung bstan pa zhes bya'o/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa 'od srungs chen pos 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das bdag cag deng slan chad sems can thams cad la ston par 'du shes bskyed par bgyi'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sems can gang la byang chub tu yongs su smin pa'i dbang po rnams mchis pa dang gang la ma mchis pa 'tshal bar 'jug pa de bdag cag la ma mchis pa'i slad du ste/ bcom ldan 'das bdag cag la 'tshal ba ma mchis pas sems can de lta bu dag la smin pa'i 'du shes bskyed na/ des bdag cag smas par 'gyur ro/ /

Dṛḍhamati, this is known as a prophecy of Awakening for a bodhisattva who has not yet aroused Awakening Mind.” [92] Then the venerable Mahākāśyapa[29] said this to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, from this day forward, we should develop a conception of all sentient beings as our teachers. Why is this? We don’t have the ability to know which sentient beings have the faculties that cause Awakening to mature in a bodhisattva, and which ones don’t. Blessed One, if we, not knowing this, were to conceive of such beings as lesser than us, we would suffer for it.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'od srungs legs so legs so/ / tshig 'di ni legs par smras pa'o/ / 'od srungs ngas don gyi dbang 'di mthong nas dge slong dag nga'am nga dang 'dra bas gang zag gi drod gzung gi / gang zag gis gang zag la drod mi gzung ngo / / dge slong dag gang zag gis gang zag la drod bzung na smas par 'gyur bar shes par gyis shig ces khyod la de lta bu'i chos bstan te/ 'od srungs bstan pa des byang chub sems dpa' 'am nyan thos kyis 'di na byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag yid du 'ong zhes sems can thams cad la ston par 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ / des na der bdag bsrung bar bya'o zhes ji skad gsungs pa bzhin no/ / gang la nges par byang chub 'thob pa'i mtshan ma yod pa de la brnyas pa shin tu bsrung bar bya ste/ dam pa'i chos pad ma dkar po'i mdo las/

The Blessed One said, “Good, good, Kāśyapa! You have spoken well. Kāśyapa, it was with this point in mind that I taught you the Dharma as follows: ‘Monks, don’t analyze other people. Monks, someone who tries to analyze other people will suffer for it. Only I, or someone like me, can judge a person.’[cvi] Kāśyapa, because of this teaching, a bodhisattva or a Disciple should conceive of all sentient beings as teachers, since some of them might belong to the bodhisattva way.[cvii] In this way, you protect yourself in that situation.” But as for people who show signs that they will definitely attain Awakening, you should be very careful to guard against treating them with contempt. As the noble Lotus Sūtra says,

sa dang so phag las ni brtsigs pa yi/ / rgyal ba'i mchod rten dga' bzhin byas pa dang / / de phyir sa rdul phung po dag las kyang / / mya ngan dgon pa dag tu byas pa dang / / byis pas rtsed mor de dang de dag tu/ / gang gis rgyal ba de phyir mchod rten dag / bye ma las ni phung por byas pa yang / / de rnams kyis kyang byang chub thob par 'gyur/ / zhes bya ba nas/

Those who joyfully make stūpas of the Victor Out of earth and bricks, Or who make heaps of dust As Nirvāṇa stūpas in the forest,[cviii] And even those children who, while playing, Make heaps of sand in various places As stūpas for those Victors— [93] They will all attain Awakening …
gang gis rtsig ngos gzugs kyi ri mo dag / bsod nams brgya mtshan yongs su rdzogs pa'i sku/ / bdag gis bris sam 'dri ru bcug kyang rung / / de dag thams cad byang chub thob par 'gyur/ /
Those who make murals Of entirely perfect bodies with the one hundred marks of goodness, Whether they paint them themselves, or get others to paint them, They will all attain Awakening.

skyes bu rgan nam 'on te gzhon nu'ang rung / / gang dag la la de ni slob pa'i tshe/ / rtsed mo dga' dang bsang ba byed pa na/ / rtsig ngos sen mo shing bus gzugs bris pa/ / de dag thams cad byang chub thob par 'gyur/ / zhes bya ba'i bar du'o/ /
Those people, whether old or young, Who, while training, or for fun,[cix] Make images on walls By painting them, or with their fingernails, or with pieces of wood— They will all attain Awakening
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
…[cx]

bde bar gshegs pa rnams la mchod pa'i phyir/ / gang dag lcags kyi sil khrol brdung bcug dang / / chu la brdabs dang thal mos brdabs pa dang / / yid du 'ong zhing snyan pa'i glu dbyangs dang / / ring bsrel de dag rnam mang mchod byas pa/ / de dag thams cad 'jig rten sangs rgyas 'gyur/ /

Those people who, in order to worship the Well-Gone Ones, Strike cymbals together, Clap their hands, or beat water to make sounds, Or sing sweet and enchanting songs well, They will all become Buddhas.

bde gshegs ring bsrel la ni cung zad dang / / sil snyan gcig brdungs pa yi sgra phyung ngam/ / me tog gcig tsam gyis ni mchod pa dang / / bde gshegs gzugs dang rtsig ngos bris pa la/ / 'khrug bzhin pa yi sems kyis mchod na yang / / de dag rim gyis sangs rgyas bye ba mthong / /

Those who strike a cymbal or make a single sound, Or who offer a single flower in worship To the relics of the Well-Gone One, even if the relics are small, {And those who have made an image of a Well-Gone One or painted one on a wall, [94] Even if they worship with distracted minds,}[cxi] Will see ten million Buddhas, one after another.

mchod rten de la gang gis thal mo sbyar/ / yongs su tshangs pa'am thal mo ya gcig gam/ / yang na mgo bo skad cig btud pa dang / / de bzhin lan cig lus kyang btud pa dang / / gang gis ring bsrel gnas pa de dag la/ / g.yeng ba'i sems kyis phyag 'tshal sangs rgyas zhes/ / tshig gcig lan 'ga' brjod par byas pa yang / / de dag kun gyis byang chub mchog 'di thob/ /

Also, those who have placed their hands together in reverence Or raised one hand in salutation to a stūpa[cxii] Or have bowed their heads for one moment, Or bowed down once with their bodies, And those who, in the places where there are relics, Even with a distracted mind, have once said[cxiii] “Homage to the Buddha,” They have all attained the highest Awakening.[cxiv]

de tshe bde bar gshegs pa de dag ni/ / mya ngan 'das sam yang na bzhugs kyang rung / / sems can gang gis chos 'di'i ming thos pa/ / de dag thams cad byang chub thob par 'gyur/ / zhes ji skad gsungs pa bzhin no/ /
No matter whether the Well-Gone Ones have all passed into Nirvāṇa Or are still living, Those sentient beings who so much as hear the name of this religion Will all attain Awakening.

snying rje chen po'i mdo las kyang / 'di lta ste dper na nya pa mchil pa thogs pas nya bshor ba'i phyir mchil pa gzan ma dang bcas pa mtsho chen por bcug la de bcug pa de nyas mid par gyur na/ nya de mtsho chu'i nang na 'phyo yang de srad bu sra ba yu ba skam sa la btags pas brtod pa zhes brjod par bya ste/ nya ba mchil pas 'chor bar 'ongs nas srad bu thangs zhes byed pa las nya zin par shes te des srad bu drangs nas de skam la phyung ste dga' mgur spyod do/ /

The Sūtra on Great Compassion (Mahā-karuṇā-sūtra) also says: [95] For example, suppose that a fisherman, in order to catch fish, were to throw a baited fish-hook into a lake, and it was immediately swallowed by a fish. Even as the fish is still swimming in the water of the lake, the fisherman drives his fishing-rod firmly into the dry ground; we can say that the fish is bound with the line. The fisherman who has come with his line now knows, “That fish is caught.” Pulling him out with the line, he can put him onto dry land so as to do whatever he wants with him, including eat him.

de bzhin du sems can gang dag bcom ldan 'das la dad pa'i sems kyis dge ba'i rtsa ba bskyed na/ tha na dad pa'i sems gcig bskyed na yang sems can de dag nyes par byas pa'i las kyi sgrib pas mi dal ba rnams su skyes su zin kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis sangs rgyas kyi ye shes dang bsdu ba'i dngos po'i srad bus sems can de dag bzung nas 'khor ba'i mtsho chu las bton te mya ngan las 'das pa'i thang la 'jog go zhes gsungs so/ /

In the same way, as for those beings who carry out wholesome actions out of trust in the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones—even as little as one single trusting thought, and even if those beings, due to the karmic distortions caused by their ruinous actions, have been born into situations without the opportunity to practice—the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, catch them with the fishing-line of the Buddhas’ pristine awareness and the ways of attracting people, pull them out of the water of the lake of cyclic existence, and set them on the dry ground of Nirvāṇa.

de lta bas na de dag la ston pa'i 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ / pha rol phyag 'tshal ba'i tshe 'di gsar bu yin yang / byang chub kyi sems kyi stobs bskyed pas phyag bya ba'i 'os yin no snyam du bsams la yid kyis phyag byas te/ dper na dra byi la sprin byang chub sems dpa' chen po yin yang gsar bu 'phags pa nor bzang la lus thams cad kyis gtugs nas phyag byas pa lta bu dang lhag pa'i bsam pa bskul ba la sogs pa las kyang byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag thams cad la phyag bya bar gsungs pa lta bu yin te/ 'di ni nges pa'i don yin no/ /

Therefore, think of [all sentient beings] as your teachers. Pay homage to them externally, and while doing so, think that, through the power of arousing the Awakening Mind, even a beginner is worthy of homage. For example, Megha the Dravidian, even though he was a great bodhisattva, prostrated to a beginner, the noble Sudhana, with his whole body, and paid homage to him. This passage is of definitive meaning. And sūtras such as the Exhortation to Higher Intention say that you should pay homage to all those who practice the bodhisattva way.
phyag bya ba dang phyag byed pa gnyis gcig la bsdu ba ji ltar mi 'gal zhe na/ phan tshun phyag bya bar dmigs pa'i phyir ro/ / nyams su blangs pa med pas bsod nams ma yin par yang mi 'gyur ro/ /

[OBJECTION]: If the person to whom homage should be paid and the person who is required to pay homage to the other are the same person, how is that not a contradiction? [REPLY]: They should mutually pay homage to each other. And if you don’t do it sincerely, there is no goodness.[cxv]
ci sangs rgyas rnams kyang de lta'am zhe na ma yin te/ thug pa med pa dang gcig dma' bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /
[OBJECTION]: Does this apply to Buddhas also? [REPLY]: No, because there would be an infinite regress, and because no Buddha is inferior to any other.

'phags pa rnam par 'thag pa thams cad bsdus pa'i mdo las kyang gnod pa gsungs te/ 'jam dpal dam pa'i chos spong ba'i las kyi sgrib pa ni phra'o/ / 'jam dpal gang la la de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs pa'i chos las/ la la ni bzang bar 'du shes la la ngan par 'du shes na dam pa'i chos spong pa'o/ / dam pa'i chos spangs pas de bzhin gshegs pa la skur pa 'debs pa yin/ dge 'dun la ngan du brjod pa yin no/ / 'di ni rigs pa'o 'di ni mi rigs pa'o zhes zer na de dam pa'i chos spong ba yin no ngas 'di na nyan thos kyi theg pa dang ldan pa'am rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa dang ldan pa'am theg pa chen po dang ldan par chos tha dad par bstan pa gang yang med na/ mi blun po de dag nga'i chos 'di la 'di ni nyan thos rnams la bshad pa 'di ni rang sangs rgyas rnams la bshad pa'o zhes tha dad du 'byed de/ de tha dad pa'i 'du shes kyis dam pa'i chos spong ba yin no/ /

The noble Sūtra that is a Compendium on the Spaciousness of Everything (Sarva-dharma-vaipulya-saṃgraha-sūtra)[cxvi] discusses something else that is harmful: Subtle indeed, Mañjuśrī, is the karmic distortion of rejecting the holy Dharma! Mañjuśrī, those who develop a conception that, of the Dharma proclaimed by the Tathāgata, some is good and some is bad, are rejecting the holy Dharma. And by rejecting the holy Dharma, they have deprecated the Tathāgata and insulted the religious community. Those who say, “This is reasonable, but this is unreasonable,” are rejecting the holy Dharma. I did not teach separate Dharmas for the Way of the Disciples, the Way of the Solitary Sages, and the Great Way. But deluded people make my Dharma out to be divided: “This was taught for disciples, that for solitary sages, and this for bodhisattvas.”[cxvii] By thinking of it as diverse in this way, they are rejecting the holy Dharma.

'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa'o 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa ma yin no zhes zer na dam pa'i chos spong ba yin no/ / chos smra ba la spobs pa yod do zhe'am/ spobs pa med do zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / chos ni chos ma yin par ston to zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / sangs rgyas 'byung ba med par gzungs thob pa med do zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ /

[96] Those who say, “This is the bodhisattva training, but this is not the bodhisattva training,” are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who say, “The Dharma teacher is illuminating” or “is not illuminating” are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who say, “The Dharma is being taught in a way contrary to Dharma”[cxviii] are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who say, “At a time when the Buddha has passed away, it is not possible to attain mnemonic powers,” are rejecting the holy Dharma.

chos smra ba la gzungs thob pa med do zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / chos smra ba'i spyod pa la sun 'byin na chos spong ba yin no/ / chos smra ba sgrub pa phun sum tshogs pa ma yin no zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / bag med par gleng na chos spong ba yin no/ / spyod lam gyis gleng na chos spong ba yin no/ / spyod pa dang tshul khrims nyams pas gleng na chos spong ba yin no/ / spobs pas go bar mi byed do zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / chos rnams kyi snang ba legs par ma bshad do zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / khong du ma chud pas tshig dang tshig tu 'gal bar byas so zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / yi ge'i ming gis de bzhin gshegs pa'i bka' la 'jug go zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ /

Those who say, “The Dharma teacher cannot attain mnemonic powers,” are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who find fault with the Dharma teacher’s way of life are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “The Dharma teacher’s spiritual accomplishments are not completely perfect,” are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who accuse him of heedlessness are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who accuse him of bad behavior are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who accuse him of faults in his way of life[cxix] and of lacking moral discipline are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who say, “He does not illuminate things and help others to understand them,” are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who say, “His presentation of the Teachings is not eloquent”[cxx] are rejecting the holy Dharma. Those who say, “If you listen carefully, his words contradict each other,” are rejecting the Dharma.[cxxi] Those who say, “He engages only with the literal meaning of the Tathāgata’s teaching,” are rejecting the Dharma.

mdo sde dang mdo sder 'gal bar byas so zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no tshigs su bcad pa dang tshigs su bcad pa 'gal bar bya'o zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / don la la la mos shing la la la ma mos so zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / chos 'chad pa'i tshe gtam gzhan du bsgyur na chos spong ba yin no/ / dkrugs ma byed na chos spong ba yin no/ / kun du rtog pas smra na chos spong ba yin no/ / 'di la spyad 'di la mi spyad ces zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / 'di ni legs par gsungs pa 'di ni legs par gsungs pa ma yin no zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / 'dis ni sangs rgyas kyi gsung gi dam tshig smras so 'dis ni sangs rgyas kyi gsung gi dam tshig ma smras so zhes zer na chos spong ba yin no/ / 'jam dpal de ltar na ji tsam du cung zad 'gal bar byed pa de tsam du chos spong ba yin no/ / dge slong ngam dge slong ma'am/ dge bsnyen nam dge bsnyen mas chos smras pa la 'di ni 'di 'dra'o zhes sems sam smra na thams cad dam pa'i chos spong ba yin no zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ /

Those who say, “He interprets one sūtra as contradicting another,” are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “He interprets one verse as contradicting another verse,” are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “He has confidence in some of the meaning, but in some of it, he has no confidence,”[cxxii] are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “When explaining the Dharma, he makes it mean something different from what it should,” are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “He gets everything mixed up,” are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “He speaks only from conceptual thinking,” are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “His conduct is appropriate in this respect, but inappropriate in that respect,” are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “This was well spoken,[cxxiii] but that was not well spoken,” are rejecting the Dharma. Those who say, “His conduct is inappropriate,” are rejecting the Dharma.[cxxiv] Those who say, “Here he expressed commitment to the word of the Buddha, but here he did not express commitment to the word of the Buddha,” are rejecting the Dharma. Mañjuśrī, if in this way people contradict even something minor, to that extent they are rejecting the Dharma. Any monk, nun, Buddhist layman or laywoman, who thinks or says “The Dharma teacher is this” or “is like this,” is rejecting all of the holy Dharma.

yang de nyid las gsungs pa/ rigs kyi bu de bzhin gshegs pa mya ngan las 'das pa na 'ga' zhig mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du sems can rnams la chos ston par byed pa na 'khor de las sems can kha cig ba spu zing zhes byed dam kha cig mchi ma 'byung ba de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i mthus gyur pa yin no/ / de la skyes bu blun po byang chub sems dpa' ma yin par byang chub sems dpar khas 'che ba dang byang chub sems dpa' sun 'byin pa chos rku ba tshul 'chos pa de dag 'di skad ces ston pa rnams la 'dis ci zhig rtogs zhes zer ba la sogs pa la yang

And the same text says, [97] Noble sir, when the Tathāgata has passed into Nirvāṇa, whenever anyone illuminates[cxxv] the Dharma through teaching it to religiously committed sentient beings, if there is even one being in that assembly whose body hair stands on end or who sheds a single tear, that is brought about by the power of the Tathāgata. Then deluded people who are not bodhisattvas but who claim to be, who disgrace the name of “bodhisattva,” hypocrites who steal the Dharma, will say this about those who teach the Dharma: “What do they know?”[cxxvi]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gang dag byang chub sems dpa' rnams la brnyas pa de dag ni sems can dmyal ba na gnas pa'i mthar phyin par nga mi smra'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ gang byang chub sems dpa' chos smra ba la brnyas pa de ni sangs rgyas la smod pa yin no/ / de ni chos spong ba yin no/ / de ni dge 'dun la bshung ba yin no/ / gang chos smras pa la smod pa de ni sangs rgyas la mi gus pa yin no/ / gang chos smra ba la mi gus pa de sangs rgyas mthong bar mi 'dod pa yin no/ / gang chos smra ba mthong bar mi 'dod pa de sangs rgyas la mi snyan par brjod pa yin no/ / gang chos smra ba la mi snyan par brjod pa de sangs rgyas yongs su gtong ba yin no/ / gang sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la khong khro ba'i sems su byed pa yang

As for those who treat bodhisattvas with contempt, I don’t declare any limit to the amount of time they might spend in the hells. Why is this? Any bodhisattva who criticizes a Dharma teacher is insulting the Buddha, rejecting the Dharma, and denigrating the community. Whoever shows disrespect to a Dharma teacher shows disrespect to the Buddha. Whoever does not want to see the Dharma teacher does not want to see the Buddha. Whoever says uncomplimentary things about the Dharma teacher says uncomplimentary things about the Buddha. Whoever gets angry at a bodhisattva, even one who has just aroused the Awakening Mind for the first time, has completely rejected the Buddha[cxxvii]
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

byams pa byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis byang chub kyi phyir pha rol tu phyin pa drug yang dag par bsgrub pa gang yin pa de la mi blun po de dag 'di skad du/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa nyid byang chub sems dpas bslab par bya ba'i pha rol tu phyin pa lhag ma rnams kyis ci zhig bya zhes zer zhing / de dag pha rol tu phyin pa gzhan la sun 'byin par sems na/ ma pham pa 'di ji snyam du sems/ ka shi'i rgyal por gyur pas phug ron gyi phyir khra la rang gi sha byin pa de 'chal pa'i shes rab can yin nam/

“Maitreya, to anyone who is correctly practicing all of the six perfections for the sake of Awakening, those deluded people say: ‘A bodhisattva should train only in the perfection of wisdom. What use are the other perfections?’ They regard the other perfections as contemptible. What do you think, Ajita[30]—was that king of Kāśi lacking in wisdom when, for the sake of a dove, he gave his own flesh to a hawk?”

byams pas gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ byams pa ngas byang chub sems kyi spyod pa spyad pa na pha rol tu phyin pa drug dang ldan pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba gang dag sgrub pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag gi gnod par gyur tam/

Maitreya said, “No indeed, Blessed One.” The Blessed One said, “Maitreya, when I was leading the bodhisattva’s way of life and performing wholesome actions that pertain to the six perfections, were those wholesome actions harmful to me?”

byams pas gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ ma pham pa khyod kyis bskal pa drug cur sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yang dag par bsgrubs/ bskal pa drug cur tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / bskal pa drug cur bzod pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa dang / bskal pa drug cur brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / bskal pa drug cur bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / bskal pa drug cur shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yang dag par bsgrubs pa de la/ mi gti mug can de dag 'di skad du/ 'di lta ste/ byang chub ni stong pa nyid kyi tshul du tshul gcig pa yin no zhes zer na de dag spyod pa yongs su ma dag pa yin no zhes bya ba la sogs pa 'byung ngo / /

Maitreya said, “No indeed, Blessed One.” The Blessed One said, “Ajita, for sixty aeons you correctly practiced the perfection of generosity; for sixty aeons, the perfection of moral discipline; for sixty aeons, the perfection of patient endurance; for sixty aeons, the perfection of perseverance; for sixty aeons, the perfection of meditative stability; and for sixty aeons, you correctly practiced the perfection of wisdom. Nevertheless, these deluded people say: ‘Awakening is attained by one method alone, namely, the method of emptiness.’ Those who say this will not be purified by this way of life.”
le'u bzhi pa'o// //
bam po lnga pa/

d.crumb: 5. tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i gnod pa rnam par spang ba

f.d: [tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i gnod pa rnam par spang ba]

d.crumb: 5. Giving Up What Is Harmful through the Perfection of Moral Discipline

f.d: 5. Giving Up What Is Harmful through the Perfection of Moral Discipline

gnod pa mdo tsam bshad zin te/ de rnams spang bar bya ba'i thabs ni lhag pa'i bsam pa bskul ba'i mdo las/ las dang po pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis gnod pa rnam pa 'di lta bu dag thos nas skrag ste/ yi dam blangs par gsungs pa de bzhin du bya'o/ / de dag gis ni 'di skad ces

[98] WHAT IS HARMFUL has been briefly explained. Some methods for giving up harmful things are in the Sūtra on Exhortation to Higher Intention: Beginner bodhisattvas who hear about what is harmful and are afraid[i] should keep their commitments[ii] as they have undertaken them. In this way, [one group of beginners] said:
bcom ldan 'das deng slan chad bdag cag de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyan sngar yi dam 'di lta bur bca' bar bgyi'o/ /
“Blessed One, in the presence of the Tathāgata we make a commitment [we will keep] from this day forward.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag gi ltung ba mad dam mi mad kyang rung ste/ gleng na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /

Blessed One, if from this day forward we accuse any lay or ordained person belonging to the bodhisattva way[iii] of a downfall, no matter whether accurately or inaccurately, we will have lied to the the Tathāgata, the Saint, the genuinely and fully awake Buddha.[iv]

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag la brnyas sam de la mi snyan par brjod pa na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /

Blessed One, if from this day forward we treat people belonging to the bodhisattva way with contempt and say uncomplimentary things about them, we will have lied to the Tathāgata, the Saint, the genuinely and fully awake Buddha.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag khyim pa'am rab tu byung ba yang rung ste/ 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga la rtse zhing yongs su spyod pa mthong nas ma dad par bgyid dam ma rangs pa'i sems bskyed dam ma gus pa'i sems bskyed dam de la ston par 'du shes ma bskyed na/ bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /

Blessed One, if from this day forward we see anyone belonging to the bodhisattva way, whether lay or ordained, playing around and having fun with the pleasures of the five senses, and if as a result we have no faith in him, are offended, arouse disrespectful thoughts and do not conceive of him as a teacher, we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad mdza' bshes kyi khyim mam/ slong mo ster ba'i khyim gyi rgyus byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag rnams kyi lus la gnod pa'am/ sems la gnod pa bgyis na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /

Blessed One, if, from this day forward, for the sake of our friends and relatives or the families who support us, we harm people who belong to the bodhisattva way either physically or emotionally, we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag mthong na yid du mi 'ong ba'i tshig gcig tsam zhig smras na yang bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /
Blessed One, if from this day forward we see anyone belonging to the bodhisattva way and address that person with even one unpleasant word, we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum du byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag la phyag ma bgyis na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /
Blessed One, if from this day forward we do not do homage to people belonging to the bodhisattva way three times each day and three times each night, we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad brtul zhugs de yang dag par blang ba'i slad du rgyal srid thob pa'am nor thob pa'am lus dang srog kyang yongs su ma btang na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /

Blessed One, if, from this day forward, we are not willing, for the sake of our commitment to this vow, to give up an opportunity to get a kingdom, or an opportunity to get wealth, or even our bodies and lives, we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad nyan thos kyi theg pa pa'am rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa pa'i gang zag la brnyas te bdag cag ni ches drag gi / de dag ni de lta ma yin no snyam na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /

Blessed One, if from this day forward, we treat people belonging to the Way of the Disciples or the Way of the Solitary Sages with contempt, thinking ‘We are special; they are not,’ we will have lied to the Tathāgata.
bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad dma' ba'i sems dang gdol ba'i sems dang khyi'i sems lta bur gnas par ma bgyis na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /
Blessed One, if from this day forward we do not live with humble minds, like untouchables,[v] we will have lied to the Tathāgata.
bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad bdag la bstod cing gzhan la smad na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /
Blessed One, if from this day forward we boast about ourselves or put others down, we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad gnod sems dang / rtsod pa'i 'jigs pas bskul ma thag tu dpag tshad dam dpag tshad brgyar ma byol na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /
Blessed One, if from this day forward we are not willing to go one league or a hundred leagues to avoid malice and quarrels,[vi] we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad bdag nyid tshul khrims dang ldan par khas 'che 'am/ mang du thos pa dang / sbyangs pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa'am yon tan gang yang rung ba zhig gis bdag brjod na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa la bslus par 'gyur ro/ /

Blessed One, if from this day forward we claim that we have moral discipline, or are learned, or follow intense practices,[1] or proclaim that we have any other abilities whatsoever, we will have lied to the Tathāgata.

bcom ldan 'das gal te bdag cag gis deng slan chad dge ba mi spyoms shing sdig pa mi 'chab par gnas par ma bgyis na bdag cag gis de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la bslus par 'gyur ro zhes smras pa dang /
Blessed One, if from this day forward we do not hide our virtues and expose our vile actions to view, we will have lied to the Tathāgata, the Saint, the genuinely and fully awake Buddha.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de'i tshe bcom ldan 'das kyis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po byams pa la bka' stsal pa/ byams pa rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang las kyi sgrib pa spang bar 'dod pas/ ji ltar rigs kyi bu 'di dag gis byas pa de bzhin du yi dam du bca'o zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

[99] Then the Blessed One declared to the bodhisattva great being Maitreya: “Maitreya, a gentleman or lady who wants to throw away karmic distortions should make the same kind of commitment as was made by these gentlemen.”

chos thams cad 'byung ba med pa bstan pa las kyang / nyin dang mtshan mo de bzhin lan gsum du/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la mgos phyag 'tshal/ / rtag tu 'dod bzhin spyad pa spyod pa na/ / de dag 'khrul pa tsam yang mi btsal lo/ / gang tshe 'dod pa'i yon tan lngas rtse mthong / / de las 'khrul pa ci yang mi btsal te/ / byang chub spyod mchog yon tan mtha' yas pa/ / de la de dag re zhig reg snyam bsam/ / rigs pa'i rim dang bya ba'i rim gyis ni/ / rgyal bar 'gyur gyi thang cig gis mi 'gyur/ / bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig mang zhig na/ / de dag go cha 'jug 'gyur gzhan du min/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

The Teaching on the Non-Origination of Everything also says: In this way, three times daily and nightly You should prostrate with your head to the bodhisattvas. At all times you should live in accordance with your intention And not desire any kind of deviation from that. When you see someone enjoying the pleasures of the senses You should still not desire any deviation towards that. Instead, you should think, with respect to that person, “May he also, in time, touch The best way of life, whose advantages are endless, that leads to Awakening.” Through the stages of reasoning and the stages of practice[vii] People become Victors, and not through just one aspect of that. During many millions of billions of aeons They are able to put on the armor, but not otherwise.

de nyid las rigs kyi bu gang dag las kyi sgrib pa 'di lta bu gnod par 'gyur ba de dag gis byang chub sems dpa' cig shos kyi bslab pa thams cad log par mi bsgrub par mi bya'i de'i bya ba thams cad la mos par byas te/ 'di snyam du sems can gyi spyod pa ni shes par dka' bas bdag gis pha rol gyi sems mi shes so snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o/ / rigs kyi bu de bzhin gshegs pas don gyi dbang 'di gzigs nas gang zag gis gang zag gi drod mi gzung gi / nga'am gang nga dang 'dra bas gang zag gi drod gzung ngo zhes de skad du chos ston to/ / rigs kyi bu gang bdag bsrung bar 'dod pa de su'i spyod pa yang rnam par dbye bar mi byed do/ / 'di ni 'di 'dra'o 'di ni 'di 'dra'o zhes gzhan la dpyas par mi bya'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos la nyin mtshan du chos kyis yongs su dga' ba'i yid kyis brtson par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text says, [100] Noble sir, those who are still being harmed by karmic distortions in this way should not find fault with[viii] any aspect of the way of life of other bodhisattvas. Instead, they should have complete confidence in the actions [of those other bodhisattvas,] and they should think: “The ways of life of sentient beings are difficult to know about. I can’t read other people’s minds.” Noble sir, the Tathāgata sees this accurately and teaches the Dharma as follows: “One person should not judge another.[ix] Only I, or someone like me, can judge a person. Noble sir, those who want to protect themselves should not analyze anybody else’s way of life. They shouldn’t pick out the faults of others: ‘He’s this way, she’s that way.’ They should apply themselves to practicing the teachings of the Buddha day and night, their minds rejoicing in the Dharma.”

de skad du sa'i snying po'i mdo las kyang / de nas de'i mod la sems can mkhas pa brgya stong mang po stan las langs te/ bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der logs su thal mo sbyar ba btud nas 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bdag cag btsun pa bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar smon lam 'di skad ces 'tshal te/ btsun pa bcom ldan 'das bdag cag yun ring po ji srid du 'khor ba na 'khor ba de srid du/ bzod pa ma thob par rgyal po'i gnas 'thob par ma gyur cig / blon po'i gnas su ma gyur cig / grong khyer gyi gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / grong gi gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / grong rdal gyi gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / mdun na 'don gyi gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / shor ba'i gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / ded dpon gyi gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / mkhas pa'i gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / dge sbyong gi gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / khyim bdag gi gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / khab so pa'i gtso bo'i gnas su ma gyur cig / bdag cag bzod pa ma thob kyi bar du bdag cag gzhi gang las sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi bstan pa la las shin tu mi bzad pa 'di lta bu 'phel bar gyur pa/ sems can rnams kyi bdag po'i bar gyi gnas dag thams cad du thob par ma gyur cig ces rgya cher gsungs so/ /

In the same way, the Kṣitigarbha Sūtra tells this story: Then many hundreds of thousands of learned sentient beings stood up from their seats.[x] They bowed to the Blessed One with their hands joined together, and said: “Revered Blessed One, in your presence we make this vow. Revered Blessed One, for as long as we are wandering in cyclic existence, until we attain patient endurance, may we not gain the position of a king, nor the position of a minister, nor the position of a mayor, nor the position of a village head, nor the position of the chief official in a market, nor the position of a king’s principal advisor,[xi] nor the position of leader among scholars,[xii] and so on up to: may we not gain the position of principal caravan leader,[xiii] nor the position of school principal, nor the position of a leader of religious wanderers, nor the position of a chief among leading merchants, nor the position of a chief among family men. For as long as we have not attained patient endurance, may we not gain any position of leadership of any kind among sentient beings in which we might act against the religion of the Buddhas and accumulate karma that would be extremely difficult to bear.”[xiv]
zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las kyang / gzhon nur gyur pa de dag ni/ / sdig pa mi byed yongs med de/ / phyi ma'i dus na de dag dang / / khyod ni sten par ma byed cig /

And so on at length. The Candrapradīpa Sūtra also says this about giving up what is harmful:[xv] Some young people Aren’t afraid of doing any vile action at all. In the future, Don’t spend time with people like that!
smra ba dang ni gtam gyis la/ / de dag la ni ri mor gyis/ / byang chub dam pa'i don gyi phyir/ / zhum pa med par bkur sti gyis/ /
But if you do talk with them, Treat them with respect; Speak politely and fearlessly, [101] For the sake of the highest Awakening.
lo grangs du lon kun dris la/ / de dag rgan par gyur na yang / / de la ri mo legs gyis la/ / rkang pa la yang mgos phyag 'tshol/ /
When you ask questions of those advanced in years, Those who are older than you are, Show them sincere respect And prostrate with your head at their feet.
byang chub snying po rnams bltas na/ / de dag 'khrul pa mi blta'o/ / de la khong khro mi bskyed cing / / rtag tu byams pa'i sems su bya/ /
If you focus your attention on Awakening, You won’t pick out their faults. Don’t get angry at them; Always be kind.
gang gi 'khrul pa ci mthong yang / / de dag nyes pa mi bsgrag ste/ / ci 'dra ba yi las byas pa/ / 'bras bu de 'dra thob par 'gyur/ /
If you do see any confusion in them, Don’t publicize their faults. Whatever kind of action you do, You get a result of the same kind.
zla ba'i bzhin ni 'dzum bzhin du/ / rgan rabs dang ni gsar bu la/ / rtag tu gsong por smra ba dang / / des shing nga rgyal bcom par bya/ /
With a smile like a crescent moon Among the old and the young, Always be polite and calm,[xvi] Having struck down pride.
gos rnams dang ni zas dag gis/ / de dag la ni phan gdags shing / / 'di dag thams cad 'dren 'gyur zhes/ / de ltar khyod kyis sems zhog shig / ces gsungs so/ /
You should help others With robes and alms-food. Keep it in mind that They will all become Guides.

byang chub tu sems bskyed pa la gang zhig dad pa dang gus pa mi bskyed pa des bdag ngan 'gror ltung bas 'jigs pa las bsrung ba dang tshe 'di dang tshe gzhan la mchog tu dga' ba myong bar bya ba dang / rang gi sems kyi rnyog pa gdang ba dang sems dge ba dang las su rung ba thob par bya ba'i phyir sdong po bkod pa'i mdo las/ bcom ldan 'das 'phags pa byams pas 'phags pa nor bzang gi ched du byang chub tu sems bskyed pa'i yon tan ji skad brjod pa de bzhin du bsgom par bya ste/

Some people don’t trust or respect those who arouse Awakening Mind. In order to protect themselves from the danger of falling into the lower realms, to experience the greatest joy in this and other lives, to clear up the muddy water of their minds, and to make their minds healthy and suitable for work, they should meditate on the advantages of arousing Awakening Mind that were proclaimed by the noble Maitreya to the Blessed One in the noble Array of Stalks with reference to the noble Sudhana:[2]
'dis ni rga dang nad kyis mnar ba yi/ / srog chags sdug bsngal brgya yis gtses pa rnams/ / skye shi mya ngan 'jigs pas gdungs mthong nas/ / de dag don du snying rje'i sems kyis spyod/ /

He sees living beings tormented by old age and disease, Attacked by a hundred forms of suffering. Made miserable by fear and sorrow due to birth and death – And lives for their benefit, practicing compassion.
'gro ba rgyud lnga'i 'khor lo'i dkyil 'khor du/ / sdug bsngal 'khrul 'khor btsir ba'i 'gro mthong nas/ / sdug bsngal 'khrul 'khor 'khor lo 'joms pa yi/ / ye shes rdo rje sra ba 'di tshol lo/ /

He sees the world crushed by the machine of suffering, Going around on the wheel of the five realms, And he will smash the machine of suffering and the wheel of the realms [102] With the solid vajra[3] of pristine awareness.
'dod chags zhe sdang rtsa sdong tsher ma can/ / lta chags rtsa mang yongs su 'dzin pa yi/ / sems can zhing ni yongs su sbyang ba'i phyir/ / shes rab gshol brtan bzang po 'di tshol lo/ /

In order to purify a field for sentient beings That is now full of the grass, stumps, and thorns of attraction and aversion And overgrown with the abundant vines[xvii] of attachment and false views, He seeks the mighty plow of wisdom.
gti mug ma rig thibs po'i bsam pa can/ / 'gro ba shes rab mig stor dmigs med pa/ / de la phyogs bde ston pa'i mthu yod pa'i/ / 'gro ba'i ded dpon bzang por 'di 'gyur ro/ /

Living beings are in the dark abyss of ignorance and delusion; Their eyes of wisdom have been put out, and they have no guide. He has the power to show them the direction that leads to peace;[xviii] He will be a caravan-leader for the world.
bzod pa'i go bgos rnam thar bzhon pa zhon/ / shes rab ral gri mya ngan dgra 'joms pas/ / mi 'jigs sbyin pa'i dpa' bor gyur pa 'di/ / 'gro ba rnams kyi lam ston 'gyur ba yin/ /

He wears the armor of patient endurance and rides the vehicle of freedom. With the sword of pristine awareness, he attacks the enemy, emotional reactions.[xix] He will become a hero, giving safety to the world, And a guide to show the world the path.
'di ni chos kyi gru rab sbyor ba ste/ / ye shes rgya mtsho'i lam la bslabs pa'o/ / zhi ba rin chen mchog gi gling skyel ba/ / 'di ni khams gsum mtsho yi skya ba 'dzin/ /

He makes ready the boat of Dharma, Having learned well the route on the ocean of pristine awareness That leads to the supreme treasure island of peace; On the ocean of the three worlds, he holds the rudder.[xx]
ye shes 'od zer smon lam dkyil 'khor can/ / sems can kun gyi gnas su snang byed pa'i/ / chos dbyings mkha' la 'od chen rab ldan par/ / 'di ni sangs rgyas nyi mar 'char bar 'gyur/ /
With the disk of the vow whose radiance is pristine awareness, Illuminating all the homes of sentient beings, In the sky of the realm of totality,[xxi] He will rise as a sun, a Buddha.
byams pa'i dga' ldan ting 'dzin ngad bsil ba'i/ / sems can kun la snyoms sems 'od bzang la/ / dkar po'i chos kyi dkyil 'khor yongs rgyas pa'i/ / sangs rgyas zla bar 'di ni 'char bar 'gyur/ /

With the coolness of lovingkindness which is like sandalwood,[xxii] With the wondrous light of a mind that sees all sentient beings as equal, With a vast disk filled with bright qualities, He will rise as a moon, a Buddha.
bsam pa'i gzhi rten brtan la rab gnas pa/ / byang chub spyod pa rim gyis 'phags pa bsten/ / chos kun rin chen 'byung gnas ldan pa yi/ / ye shes rgya mtsho'i mchog tu 'di 'gyur ro/ /

Resting most firmly on the basis of aspiration, Having ascended through the stages of the awakening way of life in due order, He will become the supreme ocean of pristine awareness, The source of everything valuable.
byang chub sems kyi klu yi dbang pos phyung / / chos kyi dbyings kyi mkha' la mngon par 'phags/ / dkar po'i 'bras bu'i lo thog 'phel byed pa'i/ / 'di ni 'gro bar chos sprin char 'bebs 'gyur/ /

Born from the Awakening Mind that is like a king of serpent-spirits,[4] [103] Visibly rising up in the sky of the realm of totality, He will become a Dharma cloud raining down on the world And help a harvest of good fruits to grow.
dag pa'i snying po dri bsung mun sel ba/ / byams pa'i snum yod dran pa'i snod brtan la/ / dri med byang chub sems med 'od bzang ba'i/ / chos kyi mar me 'di ni 'bar byed 'gyur/ /

With faith as its wick, destroying the darkness of the three types of impurity, With lovingkindness as its oil, held in the vessel of stable mindfulness, Beautifully radiant with the stainless flame of Awakening Mind, He will blaze forth as a lamp of the Dharma.
byang chub sems ni med mer snying rje skad/ / byams pa rdos pa mi g.yo bsam pa mkhregs/ / byang chub yan lag mthar gyis byung ba yi/ / sangs rgyas sras su 'di ni yang dag skye/ /

The zygote of Awakening Mind and the embryo of compassion, The fetus of lovingkindness and the unborn child of unshakeable intention— The limbs of Awakening appear in due order, And life grows in the womb of the Buddhas.[xxiii]
bsod nams snying po mngon par 'phel bar byed/ / ye shes snying po yongs su sbyong bar 'gyur/ / 'di ni shes pa'i snying po 'char bar byed/ / smon lam ji bzhin snying po yang dag byung / /
He will nurture the embryo of goodness, Purify the embryo of wisdom,[xxiv] And cause the embryo of pristine awareness to ascend— The embryo will be born, just as in his aspiration prayer.
snying rje byams pas sprul pa 'di 'dra ba/ / sems can dgrol blos phan pa'i bsam ldan pa/ / rnam dag yid can 'di ni ci 'dra ba/ / de 'dra'i 'gro ba lha dang mi bcas dkon/ /
Armored in compassion and lovingkindness,[xxv] Aspiring to benefit sentient beings and intending to set them free— Living beings with such pure minds Are rare in this world, among gods or humans.
'di 'dra'i bsam pa rab tu rtsa brtan pa/ / 'di 'dra'i sbyor ba brtan pas rnam 'phel zhing / / srid gsum log par byed pa 'di 'dra ba'i/ / ye shes 'bras can shing chen 'byung ba dkon/ /
Having its roots firmly planted in aspiration, Nourished by determined practice, Capable of shading the three worlds— Such a great fruit-bearing tree of pristine awareness is extremely rare.
'di ni yon tan kun grub don du gnyer/ / chos rnams thams cad yongs su dris par mos/ / the tshom thams cad rnam par bsal don du/ / le lo med par bshes gnyen thams cad bsten/ /
In order to develop all abilities, In order to inquire about all the teachings, In order to completely clear away all doubts, [104] He will study with all spiritual teachers without getting tired.
'di ni bdud kyi dkrugs ma nyon mongs 'joms/ / 'di ni lta ba'i dri ma sred pa sel/ / 'di ni 'gro ba thams cad dgrol la brtson/ / mkhas pa 'di ni rtag tu khyad par tshol/ /

He defeats reactive emotions and Mara’s strife. He clears away the impurity and craving that come from false views. He is intent on setting all living beings free. He is always an exceptional scholar![xxvi]
yon tan lam la nor bzang 'di gnas pas/ / 'di ni ngan song thams cad sbyong bar 'gyur/ / mtho ris lam yang nye bar ston par gyur/ / thar pa'i lam du 'gro ba 'dzud par 'gyur/ /
Such a man—{Sudhana}—living on the path of abilities Will clear away all the lower realms, Show the path to heaven, And lead the world on the path to freedom.
'di ni 'gro rgyud kun gyi sdug bsngal sel/ / 'di ni 'gro rgyud kun gyis bde ba stobs/ / 'di ni srid pa kun gyi zhags pa 'thub/ / srid pa'i 'gro rgyud thams cad sel bar 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
He sets others free from the suffering of all the realms And bestows on them the happiness of all the realms. He cuts the noose of all existence And clears away the realms of rebirth.

de ltar bsgoms pas 'dis gnod pa rnam par spang sla bar 'gyur ro/ / de skad du lhag pa'i bsam pa bskul ba'i mdo las kyang / gnod pa rnam par spang ba gsungs te/ byams pa byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag chos bzhi dang ldan na/ phyi ma lnga brgya pa tha ma la dam pa'i chos rnam par 'jig pa'i tshe/ ma snad cing ma smas la bde bar yongs su thar bar 'gyur ro/ /

If you meditate in this way, it will be easy to give up what is harmful. The Sūtra on Exhortation to Higher Intention also says about giving up what is harmful: Maitreya, if people who follow the bodhisattva way have four qualities, then in the final five hundred years, at the time of the destruction of the holy Dharma, they will not be killed or injured, will live happily and will attain freedom.

bzhi gang zhe na/ bdag gi 'khrul pa la so sor rtog pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i gang zag gzhan gyi nyes pa mi gleng ba dang / mdza' bshes kyi khyim dang slong mo ster ba'i khyim la mi lta ba dang / yid du mi 'ong ba'i tshig spong ba ste/ byams pa chos bzhi po de dag dang ldan na zhes bya ba snga ma bzhin no/ / yang bzhi ste/

What are the four? Reflecting individually on one’s own mistakes; not accusing others who follow the bodhisattva way of downfalls; not paying special attention to one’s friends, family, or circle of supporters; and abstaining from unpleasant speech.[xxvii] If they have these four … and so on as before. And there are another four.

bzhi gang zhe na/ thos pa nyung ngu'i sems can yongs su spang ba dang / 'khor mi bsdu ba dang / bas mtha'i gnas mal bsten pa dang / bdag dul ba dang zhi gnas kyi rnal 'byor la brtson pa ste bzhi po de dag go zhes bya ba dang /

What are the four? Avoiding uneducated people, not gathering adherents, living in wilderness retreat, and taming oneself and making an effort to practice resting meditation. If they have these four … And so on at length.

yang de nyid las byams pa byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pas shes rab kyi stobs bskyed pa thob pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti yongs su spang ba dang rnyed pa dang bkur sti'i nyes pa mthong bar bya'o/ /
The same text says: [105] Maitreya, beginner bodhisattvas should attain the strength of wisdom, should give up money and prestige, and should see the disadvantages of money and prestige
de bzhin du sbyar te

'du 'dzi la dga' ba yongs su spang ba dang 'du 'dzi la dga' ba'i nyes pa mthong bar bya'o/ / smra ba la dga' ba yongs su spang ba dang / smra ba la dga' ba'i nyes pa mthong bar bya'o/ / gnyid la dga' ba yongs su spang ba dang / gnyid la dga' ba'i nyes pa mthong bar bya'o/ / las la dga' ba yongs su spang ba dang las la dga' ba'i nyes pa mthong bar bya'o/ / spros pa la dga' ba yongs su spang ba dang spros pa la dga' ba'i nyes pa mthong bar bya ste/

They should give up social interactions[xxviii] and should see the disadvantages of taking delight in social interactions. They should give up taking delight in talking and should see the disadvantages of taking delight in talking. They should give up taking delight in sleep and should see the disadvantages of taking delight in sleep. They should give up taking delight in working and should see the disadvantages of taking delight in working. They should give up taking delight in conceptual elaboration and should see the disadvantages of taking delight in conceptual elaboration
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

byams pa 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni 'dod chags bskyed pa yin par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni dran pa 'joms par byed par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni rnyed pa dang / ma rnyed pas khengs pa dang 'dud par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni gti mug bskyed par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni bdag gi don sgrub pas khyim la ser sna byed pa dang chags pa byed par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni g.yo skyed par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni 'phags pa'i rigs bzhi yongs su spong pas ngo tsha mi shes pa dang / khrel med pa bskyed par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni sangs rgyas thams cad kyis ma gnang bar brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni nga rgyal dang rgyags pa dang dregs pa bskyed par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni bla ma rnams la khyad du gsod par brtag par bya'o/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni bdud kyi phyogs yin pa dang gcig tu bag med pa'i rtsa ba yin pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni dge ba'i rtsa ba 'phrog pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni glog dang 'khor lo dang lce 'bab pa lta bu dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni sbags pa mang pos sbags pa dang / mdza' bshes kyi khyim dang slong mo ster ba'i khyim la lta ba dang yid mi bde ba bskyed pa dang / blo rnam par 'khrug par byed pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni sdug pa'i dngos po rnam par 'gyur bar byed pa'i phyir mya ngan skyed par byed pa dang / dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bzhi rjod par byed pa dang / dkar po'i chos nyam chung bar byed pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni yang dag par spong ba bzhi yongs su nyams par byed pa dang / rdzu 'phrul dang mngon par shes pa yongs su nyams par byed pa dang / sngar bkur sti byed pa la phyis bkur sti mi byed par byed pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni mi mdza' ba dang gnas par byed pa dang mdza' bo spong ba dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni pha rol 'drid pas smad 'tshong ma 'dra ba dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni bsam gtan dang tshad med pa yongs su spang ba dang / sems can dmyal ba dang dud 'gro'i skye gnas dang / gshin rje'i 'jig rten du ltung bar byed pa dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni lhas byin dang lhag spyod kyi cho ga dang mthun par brtag par bya'o/ / byams pa byang chub sems dpa' rnyed pa dang bkur sti la nyes dmigs gang dag brtag par bya ba ni 'di lta bu 'di dag go/ /

On this topic, Maitreya, bodhisattva great beings should fully understand that money and prestige give rise to attraction. They should fully understand that money and prestige destroy mindfulness. They should fully understand that money and prestige lead to exhilaration and depression due to getting or not getting things. They should fully understand that money and prestige give rise to delusion. They should fully understand that money and prestige create attachment and greed for the home life. They should fully understand that money and prestige give rise to dishonesty by causing people to promote their interests through tricky ways of soliciting gifts.[xxix] They should fully understand that money and prestige cause one to abandon the four noble traditions[5] and lead to shamelessness and having no sense of decency. In the same way, they should fully understand that money and prestige are condemned by all the Buddhas. They should fully understand that money and prestige lead to pride and intoxication, that people who have money and prestige look down on spiritual teachers, and that money and prestige are on Māra’s side. Money and prestige invariably lead to heedlessness and steal your wholesome actions. Money and prestige are like lightning, like wheels, like thunderbolts.[xxx] Money and prestige are desired greedily with much greed, lead to paying special attention to friends, family, and one’s circle of supporters, produce suffering, and bewilder the intellect. Because all things that are dear are subject to change, money and prestige cause sorrow. Money and prestige completely steal the four applications of mindfulness, weaken your bright qualities, and cause you to lose the four right efforts.[6] They cause you to lose miracle powers and higher knowing. Earlier prestige is a cause of later infamy. Money and prestige cause you to give up your friends and associate with your enemies. Money and prestige lure other people, just like a whore. Money and prestige cause you to leave behind meditative stability and the immeasurables, and make you fall to the hells, the animal world, or the world of Yama. They should fully understand that money and prestige cause you to become like Devadatta and Udraka.[7] Maitreya, bodhisattvas should fully understand that the disadvantages of money and prestige are of this kind.

brtags nas kyang 'dod pa chung bar bya'i yongs su gdung bar ni mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ byams pa 'dod pa chung ba la skyon 'di lta bu 'di dag med pa'i phyir te/ de'i phyir sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams la bar chad med pa yin/ khyim pa dang rab tu byung ba dag yid byung bar mi 'gyur ba yin/ lha dang mi rnams bsam pa yongs su dag par bya ba'i phyir gnas pas rjes su bsrung bar 'os pa yin/ ngan 'gro log par ltung ba thams cad kyis skrag pa med pa yin/ bsdigs pa dang bral bas zil gyis mi non pa yin/ bdud kyi yul las yongs su grol bas mi 'phrogs pa yin/ sdug bsngal thams cad kyis mi tshugs pa yin/ lha dang mi rnams kyis mngon par 'dod par bya ba yin/ bsam gtan la goms par byed par gnas pas gsal ba yin/ g.yo dang sgyu spangs pa dang 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga la skyon du lta bas bag yod pa yin/ 'phags pa'i rigs la gnas pas ji skad smras pa de bzhin byed pa yin/ mkhas pa rnams dang tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams kyis 'dod pa yin te/ byams pa phan yon 'di lta bu 'di dag shes nas byang chub sems dpa' mkhas pas rnyed pa dang bkur sti thams cad spong ba'i phyir lhag pa'i bsam pas 'dod pa chung ba la gnas par bya zhing 'dod pa chung ba la brten par bya'o zhes bya ba'o/ /

[106] Understanding this, they should not see having few desires as something painful, but instead should take delight in having few desires. Why is that? Because, Maitreya, for those who have few desires, problems of this kind don’t arise, and for them there are no obstacles [to developing] the qualities of a Buddha. Lay people and monks are not disgusted with them. Because they live in the aspiration to complete purity, they become worthy of being protected by gods and humans. They do not have to be afraid of falling into the lower realms, and because they are unafraid, they are not outshined by anyone.[xxxi] Since they are completely free from the objects of Māra, they cannot be bound.[xxxii] They cannot be harmed by any form of misfortune. Gods and humans long for them. They live in the repeated practice of meditative stability. They are clear, giving up cunning and fraud. They are mindful, seeing the problems with the pleasures of the five senses. They live in the noble traditions and practice what they preach. The learned and their companions in the celibate life long for them. Maitreya, knowing about all these benefits, a learned bodhisattva who has higher intention should take delight in having few desires, practice having few desires, and leave behind all money and prestige.

'du 'dzi la dga' ba'i dbang du byas te gsungs pa/ 'dod chags spangs shing zhe sdang rab spangs nas/ / rnal 'byor can ni 'du 'dzir mi gnas te/ / de ni de la gzhol zhing de la 'bab/ / nyes pa des na dga' bar byed mi 'gyur/ /

About social interactions, the text says: A spiritual practitioner[8] who has fully given up attachment and aversion Does not participate in social interactions. People sink down into them and become addicted to them; Therefore, you shouldn’t take delight in them.
dgod dang bzhad gad de bzhin rnam rtog pa/ / 'di dag thams cad 'du 'dzi rnams las byung / / snying po med pa'i 'du 'dzi su byed pa/ / de ni yang longs spyod cing ma bsdams yin/ /

Frivolity, laughter, and conceptual thinking All arise from social interactions. Those who engage in social interactions that have no value Have no discipline and indulge in all kinds of actions.[xxxiii]
byis pa dag ni 'jig rten smra la dga'/ / byis pa de dag mchog gi gtam las nyams/ / zhe sdang 'phel zhing rnam rtog shas kyang che/ / nyes pa des ni de la mi chags so/ /

Fools who delight in worldly talk,[xxxiv] [107] Like the fools they are, abandon the highest teachings. Anger increases and conceptual thinking is abundant; Because of this disadvantage, don’t get attracted to it!
rigs pa ma yin smra la dga' bskyed nas/ / dge slong thos pa rnam par 'phel mi byed/ / de lta bas na mi rigs smra spongs la/ / chos la rtag tu dga' ba thob par gyis/ /
Monks who delight in inappropriate speech Do not grow in learning. Therefore, give up inappropriate speech And always take delight in the Dharma.
byang chub mngon par 'dod phyir nga yis ni/ / rang gi yan lag lan stong snyed du btang / / chos nyan pas ni nga la ngoms med na/ / de dag chos nyan pa la skyo bar 'gyur/ /
Out of longing for Awakening, I gave away my limbs[xxxv] a thousand times; I never get enough of listening to the Dharma, But they get tired of listening to the Dharma.
rigs min smra dang dam pa ma yin smra/ / rnam pa kun du yongs su spang bar bya/ / bskal pa brgya phrag du mar gang dkon pa/ / chos kyi dam pa de la dga' skyed cig /

You should completely give up in every way Inappropriate speech or speech that is contrary to your training. Take delight in the supreme Dharma, Which is difficult to find even in many hundreds of aeons!
yon tan 'dod pa nags na gnas pa yis/ / pha rol dag gi skyon la brtag mi bya/ / bdag ni khyad par 'phags shing bdag mchog ces/ / de snyam du ni sems bskyed mi bya'o/ /
If you live in the forest and want to develop abilities, Don’t think about the problems of others. “I am excellent! I alone am the best!” [108] Don’t indulge in thoughts like these.
rgyags 'di bag med kun gyi rtsa ba ste/ / dge slong dman la brnyas par yong mi bya/ / bskal pa gcig gis thar pa thob mi 'gyur/ / 'di ni bstan pa 'di la go rim yin/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

de nyid las smra ba la dga' ba'i dbang du byas te gsungs pa/ thos pas rgyags nas gus par mi 'gyur te/ / rnam par 'byed pa'i smra ba rnams la chags/ / brjed par 'gyur zhing shes bzhin med par 'gyur/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /
nang gi sems las shin du ring bar 'gyur/ / lus dang sems kyang rab sbyangs ma yin 'gyur/ / khengs pa dang ni 'dud pa mang por 'gyur/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /
byis pa dam pa'i chos bsam rab tu nyams/ / sems ni mi mnyen shin tu rtsub par 'gyur/ / zhi gnas lhag mthong dag dang rab tu ring / / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /

A fool who loses all reflection on the holy Dharma Has a mind that is not flexible, but becomes extremely rough, And is far away from both insight meditation and resting meditation. These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking.
rtag tu bla ma dag la gus pa med/ / spags pa'i gtam dag la ni dga' ba skyed/ / snying po med la gnas shing shes rab nyams/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /

He never has respect for spiritual teachers; He takes delight in conversations about worldly things;[xxxvii] Lacking in wisdom, he spends time on things that don’t matter. These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking.
de ni lha tshogs rnams kyis mi bkur zhing / / de tshe de la 'dod pa yang mi skyed/ / de ni so so yang dag rig las nyams/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /
He is not honored by the assemblies of gods, Nor do they feel any longing to see him;[xxxviii] He has no special knowledge. [109]These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking.
gang dag lus ni mngon sum mang yod pa/ / mkhas pa de dag gis ni spyo bar 'gyur/ / de yi srog ni don med 'gyur ba ste/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /
All he cares about are pleasures you can perceive through the senses; The learned criticize him, And his life is useless to him. These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking.
bdag ni bsgrubs nyams da ni ci bya zhes/ / 'chi ba'i dus tshe byis pa mya ngan byed/ / gting rnyed ma gyur shin tu sdug bsngal 'gyur/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /

At the time of death, the fool is miserable:[xxxix] “I have no accomplishments. What do I do now?” Not having found a way across,[xl] he suffers greatly. [110] These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking.
rtswa bskyod bzhin du 'gul zhing g.yo ba ste/ / de ni de ltar the tshom 'gyur du nges/ / de ni nam yang blo brtan mi 'gyur te/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /
gar mkhan ltad mo'i khrom nang 'dug pa zhig / dpa' bo gzhan gyi yon tan rjod byed la/ / bdag nyid bsgrub las nyams par 'gyur ba bzhin/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /

Like an actor, he stands in the middle of the stage[xli] Recounting the abilities of others who are heroes. He himself is totally lacking in accomplishments. These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking.
de ni g.yo ldan yang zhing re bral 'gyur/ / phyi phyir zhing ni rnam par 'gyed pa rtsom/ / 'phags pa'i dam pa'i chos las rab tu ring / / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ /

He is dishonest, contemptible,[xlii] and without any hope. He starts quarrels[xliii] again and again. He is far from the Dharma of the Noble Ones. These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking.
mthu chung bsti stang gis ni dgar 'gyur te/ / mi shes ldan pa 'khrug cing rnam par 'gyur/ / spre'u ltar de yi sems ni g.yo bar 'gyur/ / smra la dga' ba'i nyes pa 'di dag go/ / zhes bya ba dang /
He has no stability: He rejoices when he is honored, And being ignorant, when offended, he shakes. His mind jumps around like a monkey. These are the disadvantages of delighting in talking
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[xliv]
yun ring dus nas smra la dga' bas na/ / de ni bdag nyid dga' ba mi 'thob po/ / tshig gang dga' ba mtha' yas 'thob 'gyur ba/ / tshig gcig tsam zhig bsams kyang mchog yin no/ /
Someone who has been delighting in talking for a long time Does not find bliss and happiness within. Better to reflect on just one verse On the path where one attains endless bliss.
bu ram shing shun snying po ci yang med/ / dga' bar bya ba'i ro ni nang na 'dug / shun pa zos nas mis ni bu ram ro/ / zhim po rnyed par nus pa ma yin no/ /
The husk of the sugarcane has no juice; The delightful taste is within. Someone who eats the husk cannot [111] Get any of the delicious sugarcane juice.
ji ltar shun pa de bzhin smra ba ste/ / ro lta bu ni 'di la don sems yin/ / de lta bas na smra la dga' spangs te/ / rtag tu bag yod byos la don soms shig / ces gsungs so/ /
In this case, talking is like the husk And the juice is like reflection on the meaning. Therefore, give up delight in talking And always mindfully reflect on the meaning!

gnyid la dga' ba'i nyes pa'i dbang du byas te/ gang zhig rmugs dang gnyid la dga' 'gyur ba/ / de ni gti mug dra ba chen po 'phel/ / de ni lta ba rnyed nas the tshom 'gyur/ / de la lta gyur gzhan yang mang du 'byung / /
gang zhig rmugs dang gnyid la dga' 'gyur ba/ / de ni shes rab shin tu nyam chung 'gyur/ / de yi blo yang yongs su nyams par 'gyur/ / ye shes las ni rtag tu de nyams 'gyur/ /
Their wisdom becomes very weak. Intellect is left behind; they have none. They give up pristine awareness forever As long as they don’t progress beyond pleasant snoozing.
gang zhig rmugs dang gnyid la dga' 'gyur ba/ / mi shes le lo snyom las shes rab 'chal/ / de la mi ma yin pas glags rnyed de/ / nags na gnas pa'i tshe ni 'tshe bar 'gyur/ /

They are born lazy, ignorant, not brilliant, without wisdom, Or they go to nonhuman rebirths, And are harmed while living in the forest [as animals][xlvi] Because they don’t progress beyond pleasant snoozing.
gang zhig rmugs dang gnyid la dga' 'gyur ba/ / de ni dge sems rtag tu mi 'dod de/ / de ni chos la 'dun pa skyed mi byed/ / phyir zhing chos ma yin la de dga' 'gyur/ /

Their wholesome thoughts are useless to them,[xlvii] As they have no motivation for Dharma And they have very strong desires for what is contrary to Dharma Because they don’t progress beyond pleasant snoozing.
gang zhig rmugs dang gnyid la dga' 'gyur ba/ / de ni rmongs shing chos la 'dun pa nyams/ / byis pa yon tan kun las yongs su nyams/ / dkar po 'joms shing mun par 'gro bar 'gyur/ /

They are confused, abandon all motivation for the holy Dharma, [112] And leave behind all abilities, the fools. They destroy what is bright and go towards the darkness Because they don’t progress beyond pleasant snoozing.
gang zhig rmugs dang gnyid la dga' 'gyur ba/ / 'jigs par 'gyur zhing sems kyang rab tu zhum/ / de ni rtag par mchog tu dga' mi 'gyur/ / gnyid kyis non pa lus kyang lhod par 'gyur/ /
They are not clever and their minds are soft.[xlviii] They never feel the highest joy. Overcome by sleep, their limbs are loose Because they don’t progress beyond pleasant snoozing.

gang zhig rmugs dang gnyid la dga' 'gyur ba/ / bdag nyid mi shes le lo can gyur nas/ / brtson 'grus stobs dang ldan la phrag dog byed/ / brtson 'grus ldan pa rnams la mi snyan smra/ / zhes bya ba dang /

Knowing that they themselves are lazy,[xlix] They envy those who have powers of perseverance, And say uncomplimentary things about those who persevere, Because they don’t progress beyond pleasant snoozing.
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gang zhig sdug bsngal mun pa kun 'jig cing / / ngan song yongs spongs rtsa bar gyur pa dang / / sangs rgyas kun gyis bsngags par 'gyur ba yi/ / brtson 'grus 'phags pa de la rtag tu brtan/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
The destroyer of the darkness of all forms of suffering, The root of leaving behind the lower realms, Which is always praised by all the Buddhas— Always rely on that noble perseverance!
las la dga' ba'i dbang du byas nas/ bla mas bskul na bka' blo mi bde zhing / / rjes su bstan pa mthun par 'dzin mi byed/ / de ni myur du tshul khrims nyams par 'gyur/ /

About delighting in working, the text says: He is often criticized and scolded by spiritual teachers; He understands the circumambulation, but not the practice instructions.[l] He quickly loses his moral discipline.
nyes pa 'di dag las la dga' ba'i yin/ / khyim na gnas pa'i las rnams rtag sems pas/ / de ni rtag tu gdung bar 'gyur ba ste/ / bsam gtan dang ni spong ba de mi byed/ /

These are the disadvantages of delighting in working. He is uneasy all the time, Always thinking about the activities of lay people; But the jobs of people who’ve given up on meditation are not what he should do.[li]
nyes pa 'di dag las la dga' ba'i yin/ / de yi 'dod chags shas ni che bar skye/ / de ni ro bro rnams la chags shing zhen/ / de ni ngan ngon tsam gyis dgar mi 'gyur/ /

These are the disadvantages of delighting in working. Powerful thoughts of attraction for tastes [113] Arise in him, bewilder him, and swallow him up. He is not satisfied with anything here at all.[lii]
nyes pa 'di dag las la dga' ba'i yin/ / de ni 'khor mang po la dga' 'gyur te/ / de nyams na ni shin tu sdug bsngal 'gyur/ / de ni bong bu bzhin du 'dre bar 'gyur/ /
These are the disadvantages of delighting in working. He is greatly pleased with a big assembly, And suffers when he is deprived of one. He is like a rutting donkey.
nyes pa 'di dag las la dga' ba'i yin/ /
These are the disadvantages of delighting in working
de bzhin du sbyar te/
nyin dang mtshan mo sems gzhan med par ni/ / zas dang gos la rgyun du sems par byed/ / de ni rtag tu yon tan 'dod ma yin/ / nyes pa 'di dag las la dga' ba'i yin/ /
Day and night he has no other thought Than food and clothing,[liii] which he constantly thinks about. He never aspires to any abilities. These are the disadvantages of delighting in working.
de ni 'jig rten pa yi bya ba 'dre/ / rigs pa min pa'i smra ba rnams la dga'/ / rigs pa'i smra la de ni dga' mi 'gyur/ / nyes pa 'di dag las la dga' ba'i yin/ /
He asks for worldly tasks to do And delights in irrational speech, But has no delight in hearing about anything rational. These are the disadvantages of delighting in working
de bzhin du sbyar te/
