de nas bcom ldan 'das la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po byams pas 'di skad ces gsol to/ / gang dag mchog gi chos yongs su spangs nas las ngan pa rnams rtsom pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de dag ni shes rab shin tu chung zhing shes rab rnam par nyams par 'gyur ba lags so/ / de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po byams pa la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ byams pa de de bzhin te ji skad smras pa de de bzhin no/ / gang dag mchog gi chos yongs su spangs nas las ngan pa rnams rtsom pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de dag ni shes rab shin tu chung bar 'gyur ro/ / byams pa khyod la bstan to/ / khyod kyis khong du chud par bya'o/ / gang dag la brtson pa med pa dang / bsam gtan med pa dang / spong ba med pa dang / kha ton bya ba dang mang du thos pa yongs su tshol ba med pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de dag ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa la rab tu byung ba ma yin no/ / byams pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa ni bsam gtan dang spong bas rab tu phye ba/ ye shes kyis 'dus byas pa ye shes kyis mnyam par gzhag pa/ mngon par brtson pas rab tu phye ba yin gyi khyim pa'i las kyi mtha' dang zhal ta byed pas rab tu phye ba ni ma yin no/ / mi rigs pa la brtson pa dang 'khor ba la mngon par dga' ba rnams kyi las ni 'di yin te/ 'di ltar zhal ta byed pa dang 'jig rten pa'i bya bas gzings pa ste/ de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis 'dod pa bskyed par mi bya'o/ /

[114] Then the bodhisattva Maitreya said to the Blessed One, “Blessed One, those unwise bodhisattvas who will leave behind the highest teachings and take up lowly tasks will certainly be totally lacking in wisdom.” The Blessed One replied to the bodhisattva great being Maitreya as follows: “Thus it is, Maitreya; it is just as you say. Those bodhisattvas who will leave behind the highest teachings and take up lowly tasks will be totally lacking in wisdom. But also, I declare to you, and you should fully understand, that those bodhisattvas who have no spiritual practice, no meditative stability, no renunciation, no daily recitation, and no effort to acquire great learning, are not genuinely ordained in the religion of the Tathāgata. Maitreya, the religion of the Tathāgata is defined by meditation and renunciation, conditioned by pristine awareness, and defined by working hard at meditation practice and becoming absorbed in pristine awareness. It is not defined by work or by the actions of lay people. These are the actions of those who try hard to do things that don’t make sense, and who delight in cyclic existence—namely, work, and getting tangled up in worldly activities. A bodhisattva should not aspire to be like them!”[liv]

byams pa zhal ta byed pa la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gal te rin po che sna bdun gyi mchod rten rnams kyis stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'di bkang yang des nga mnyes par byas par mi 'gyur rim gro byas par mi 'gyur bsti stang byas par mi 'gyur ro/ /

“Maitreya, if a bodhisattva who takes delight in work should fill this entire world-realm, with its three thousand myriad worlds, with stūpas made of the seven precious substances, I would not be pleased by that, nor would I have been worshipped or honored by that
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

de la zhal ta byed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' 'dzam bu'i gling yongs su gang ba de dag gis/ lung 'bogs pa dang kha ton la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gcig la rim gro dang bsnyen bkur bya'o/ / lung dbog pa dang kha ton la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' 'dzam bu'i gling gi tshad rnyed kyis/ nang du yang dag 'jog la mngon par brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gcig la rim gro dang bkur sti bya'o/ /

Suppose India were completely full of worker bodhisattvas. All of them should do homage to one bodhisattva who is focused on teaching and study. Now suppose there were as many bodhisattvas focused on teaching and study as there are people in India. All of them should do homage to a bodhisattva who is making an effort in solitary meditation[9]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di lta ste shes rab kyi las 'di ni bya dka' ba'i las yin no bla ma'o/ / bla na med pa'o 'jig rten gsum po thams cad las khyad par du 'phags pa'o/ / mngon par 'phags pa'o/ / byams pa de lta bas na byang chub sems dpa' brtson pa 'dod pa dang / brtson 'grus rtsom par 'dod pas shes rab la brtson par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

For what reason? This work, the work of wisdom, is difficult to do; it is superior, unsurpassed in the three worlds, excellent and exalted. Therefore, Maitreya, a bodhisattva who wants to work hard, who wants to develop perseverance, should work on wisdom.”

spros pa la dga' ba'i dbang du byas nas/ / de ni mi khom brgyad dang ring mi 'gyur/ / de ni dal ba phun tshogs mchog mi 'gyur/ / de la gnod pa 'di dag rtag 'byung ste/ / spros spyod de yi nyes pa de dag go/ /

About delighting in conceptual elaboration,[10] the text says: The eight unfavorable conditions are not far away from you, And you don’t have the perfect opportunity to practice. These harms always happen to you. These are the disadvantages of spending time on conceptual elaboration
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
mkhas pas nyes 'di yang dag rig nas ni/ / spros pa thams cad yongs su spang bar bya/ / spros spyod dag ni gnod pa rnyed par sla/ / de lta bas na spros la gnas mi bya/ /

A learned person who correctly understands these disadvantages Should completely leave behind all conceptual elaboration. Harmful things are easy to find for those who spend time on conceptual elaboration; [115] Therefore, don’t live in conceptual elaboration.
gang na spros pa'am rtsod pa yod pa las/ / dpag tshad brgya yi pha rol 'gro ba mchog / gang na nyon mongs yod pa de dag tu/ / yud tsam zhig kyang gnas shing 'dug mi bya/ /
It’s best to go a hundred leagues away From a place where there are quarrels and conceptual elaboration. You should not live, or stay even for a moment, In places that arouse reactive emotions.
rab byung don 'dod yon tan 'dod pa rnams/ / sdang ba'i sems kyis rtsod par ma byed cig / gang gi don du spros pa 'di 'byung ba/ / khyed la zhing med zhing las tshong bya med/ /

If you want the benefits of ordination, and you aspire to abilities, Don’t get into quarrels because of angry thoughts. You don’t have a field, or agricultural work to do, or a business For which conceptual elaboration might be helpful.
khyed la chung ma bu dang bu mo med/ / khyim dang gnyen gyi tshogs kyang yod pa min/ / bran pho dran mo med cing dbang phyug med/ / rab tu byung nas rtsod par ma byed cig /
zhi zhing rab tu zhi bas bsten pa yi/ / ngur smrig gos dag dad pas blangs nas ni/ / zhi zhing rab zhi nye bar zhi bar byos/ / spros pa rnam par spongs la bzod pa skyed/ /
Out of faith, you have put on the saffron robes. You should be attended by peace and calm; Be peaceful, calm, and tranquil, Give up conceptual elaboration and develop patience.
mi bzad sems ni sbrul gdug 'dra bar srungs/ / spros la spyod pa sems can dmyal ba dang / / dud 'gro gshin rje'i yul dang ring mi 'gyur/ / de lta bas na bzod dang brtson 'grus skyed/ /

Guard against the poisonous snake of violent thoughts! The hells, the animal realm, and the world of Yama Are not far away if you spend your time on conceptual elaboration. So have patient endurance and develop perseverance
de bzhin du sbyar te/
theg pa'i stobs 'di yis ni dag 'gyur zhing / / las kyi sgrib pa ma lus byang nas ni/ / stobs dang bcas shing bzhon bcas bdud thul cig / bstan pa gang yin des ni bzod pa skyed/ / ces gsungs so/ /

Those who have gained purity through this practice And completely thrown away all karmic distortions, Who conquer Māra, his power and his vehicle— [116] Only in those, the brave, does patient endurance arise.

gnod pa rnam par spang ba mdor bstan pas byams pa de lta bas na byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'i rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mos phyi ma lnga brgya tha ma la dam pa'i chos rnam par 'jig pa'i tshe/ ma snad cing ma smas la bde bar yongs su thar bar 'dod pa dang las kyi sgrib pa thams cad byang bar 'dod pas/ 'du 'dzi med pa la dga' ba dang dgon pa dang nags dang / bas mthar gnas pa la brtson par bya zhing / mngon par mi brtson pa'i sems can yongs su spang ba dang / bdag gi 'khrul pa la blta ba dang / gzhan gyi 'khrul pa la mi blta ba dang / cang mi smra ba la dga' ba dang / shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la gnas pa la brtson par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text summarizes the topic of giving up what is harmful: Now therefore, Maitreya, gentlemen or ladies who belong to the bodhisattva way and live during the final five hundred years, at the time of the decay of the holy Dharma, who want to live happily, not be harmed or hunted down, and who aspire to find freedom and clear away all karmic distortions, should take delight in solitude, and live in the forest, in wilderness retreat, and in remote hermitages.[lv] Leaving behind those sentient beings who clearly aren’t making any effort, they should look hard at their own mistakes and overlook the mistakes of others.[lvi] They should delight in silence. They should delight in making an effort to rest in the perfection of wisdom.

'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las kyang / gnod pa rnam par spangs pa gsungs pa ni/ nam de'i don grub par gyur gyi bar du bsod snyoms la spyod de gzhan du na gnas gang na khyi za ba'am ba drus ma'am dud 'gro'i skye gnas su gtogs pa rang bzhin gyis ngang tshul ngan pa'i srog chags sam/ bud med dang skyes pa dang khye'u dang bu mo kyal ka bya ba'i bsam pa can dag yod pa'am smad pa'i gnas de dag thams cad nas thams cad yongs su spong zhes bya ba ste/ 'dis ni tshe 'di la yang gnod par 'gyur ba rnam pa de lta bu ma spangs na ltung bar 'gyur ro zhes bstan par 'gyur ro/ / 'di lta bu la sogs pas gnod pa rnam par spang ba gang yin pa/ /

About giving up what is harmful, the noble Cloud of Jewels says: Their duty extends as far as they go for alms. Everywhere else, they completely avoid places where there are untouchables, or dogs,[lvii] or young calves, or people who are immoral by nature, or those in the animal realm, or women, men, boys, or girls who intend to harm others;[lviii] and they completely avoid despised places. The text also teaches: “If someone does not avoid seeing something which is harmful to see, that person undergoes a downfall.” In accordance with all of this, the verse says, about giving up what is harmful:
de kun gang gis 'thob ce na/ / 'bras bu med pa'i byed spong bas/ /
[7cd] How is this attained? By giving up all fruitless movements.

'di la 'bras bu ni gzhan gyi don bya ba ste/ de'i don du gang spyod par mi 'gyur ba de ni 'bras bu med pa yin pas yongs su spang bar bya ba yin te/ zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las/ lus kyi sdom pa'i skabs nas ji skad du lag pa mi rgod rkang pa mi rgod cing rkang lag bsdams pa zhes bya ba'i bar du gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

The measure of the “fruit” is benefit to others. Any movement that does not result in benefit to others should be given up as fruitless. As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says, in the section on bodily discipline: “Someone whose hands and feet are disciplined does not fidget with the hands and does not fidget with the feet.”

de skad du chos bcu pa'i mdo las kyang / lag pa bskyod pa dang rkang pa bskyod pa dang kun du rgyug pa dang yongs su rgyug pa dang mchong ba dang rkyal ba 'di ni lus kyi gnas ngan len zhes bya'o zhes bstan to/ /

The Sūtra on Ten Qualities also teaches: “Waving the hands around; waving the feet around; running flat out; running around; jumping; and swimming—this is called taking up inferior bodily postures.”[lix]

'phags pa chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las kyang / ji ltar byang chub sems dpa' rnams gzhan gyi don bya ba las las gzhan mi byed pa de lta bu gsal bar yongs su bstan te/ bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi lus kyi las gang ci yang rung / ngag dang yid kyi las gang ci yang rung / de thams cad ni sems can thams cad la lta bas 'jug go/ / snying rje chen po'i dbang du 'gyur ba'o/ / sems can la phan pa'i gnas kyi rgyu'o/ / sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa las 'byung ngo / / de'i phan pa'i bsam pa 'di lta bus 'du shes 'di lta bur 'gyur te/ gang sems can thams cad la phan pa sgrub pa dang bde ba sgrub pa'i sgrub pa de bdag gis sgrub po snyam mo/ /

[117] The noble Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together makes it quite clear that bodhisattvas don’t do anything except what benefits others: Blessed One, all the actions of bodhisattvas in thought, word, and deed, whatever they might be, are all done with a view to sentient beings, by the power of great compassion, in order to benefit sentient beings, arising from the higher intention to promote the welfare and happiness of all sentient beings. Intending to bring about their welfare, bodhisattvas think: “I will accomplish whatever will bring welfare and happiness to all sentient beings.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/
skye mched rnams la grong stong lta bur so sor rtog pa sgrub kyang skye mched yongs su dor bar yang mi 'tshal lo zhes gsungs so/ /
It is an accomplishment to understand the spheres individually as being like an empty town;[11] but they should not wish to leave the spheres behind.

'phags pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi mdo las kyang / 'di lta ste dper na bu ga nas rlung 'jug pa de bzhin du gang dang gang nas sems la skyon byung ba de dang de nyid nas bdud kyis glags rnyed do/ / de lta bas na byang chub sems dpa' rtag tu sems la skyon med par bya'o/ / de la sems la skyon med pa ni 'di yin te/ 'di ltar rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i stong pa nyid yongs su rdzogs pa'o zhes gsungs so/ / rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i stong pa nyid de gang zhe na/ gang 'di byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa yongs su mi gtong bas dngos po thams cad stong pa nyid du goms par byed pa'am goms par byas pa ste/ de ni gtsug na rin po che'i mdo las rgya cher bstan to/ /

The noble Gaganagañja Sūtra also says: Just as, for example, through a hole the wind enters, in just the same way, wherever there is a flaw in the mind, there Māra finds an opportunity. Therefore, a bodhisattva’s mind should always be flawless. What is this flawless mind? It is emptiness, together with knowing that is totally complete in all respects. Now, what is this emptiness that has what is best in all respects? This is meditating on, or having already meditated on, the emptiness of all that is, without rejecting any aspect of the bodhisattva’s way of life. This is explained in detail in the Sūtra on the Jewel at the Crown of the Head (Ratna-cūḍa-sūtra.)[12]

de skad du blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las kyang / sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos rnams spang ba'i phyir 'dun pa skyed do zhes bya ba'i skabs de nas/ gang ting nge 'dzin gyi phung po la g.yeng bar 'gyur ba sems g.yeng bar byed pa gzhan dang gzhan gang yang rung ste/ de ni ting nge 'dzin gyi g.yeng ba zhes bya'o zhes bya ba nas 'di dag ni sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos rnams zhes bya'o zhes bya ba'i bar du gsungs so/ /

As the Akṣayamati Sūtra says, Someone generates the motivation to leave behind all vile, unwholesome states. In this case, whatever distractions there are that interfere with the various forms of meditative absorption, and whatever other things there might be that function as hindrances to meditative absorption, those are called “enemies of meditative absorption.”[lx] Those are all vile, unwholesome states.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i gnod pa rnam par spang ba zhes bya ba ste le'u lnga pa'o// //
[lus bsrung ba]
6. Protecting the Body
'bras bu med pa'i spyod pa rnam par spang ba bshad zin to/ / de ji ltar 'grub ce na/ smras pa/
GIVING UP FRUITLESS activities has been explained. But how do you actually do that? The verse says:
de yang rtag tu dran pas 'grub ces bya'o/ /
[8a] You actually do that by being mindful at all times.

dran pa bcu gnyis po 'di dag ni 'bras bu med pa'i spyod pa spong bar 'gyur ba ste/ 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i bka' las mi 'da' bar srung zhing rnam par smin pa la gus par bya ba'i dran pa dang / lus thams cad mi g.yo ba'i ngo bo nyid du gnas par bya ba'i dran pa dang / sems can gyi don bya ba na yan lag gang mkho ba de la dran pa brtan pas bltas te mi g.yo bar gzhag la mos pa gzhan gyi kha na las par byas pas brtan pa thams cad kyi spyod pa dran pa dang / gsar bu'i 'jigs pa dang dga' ston la sogs pa dang 'brel ba'i gus par bya ba la lus bskyod pa'i dran pa dang / spyod lam bzhi bya ba la spyod pa'i dran pa dang / skabs skabs su spyod lam 'khrugs pa bsrung ba'i phyir spyod lam phun sum tshogs par bya ba la blta ba'i dran pa dang / smra ba'i dus la bab pa na ma dad pa dang / rgod pa dang khros pa dang nye mgon gyi phyogs su lhung ba la sogs pa'i dbang gis rkang lag dang mgo dang gdong gi 'gyur ba shin tu mi mdzes par 'gyur ba bsdams pa'i dran pa dang / nyan pa la brjod par bya ba gang yin pa de sgra ji tsam gyis don rtogs par 'gyur ba'i sgra de las lhag par smra bar mi bya ba'i dran pa dang / gzhan dogs par 'gyur ba'i nyes pa byung zhing ma bslabs pa'i skye bo dang phrad de nyam nga ba na rang gi sems dang bar bya ba de la bsgrim pa'i dran pa dang / sems nang du lhag mthong dang zhi gnas kyi ka ba la rtag tu gdags pa'i dran pa dang / yang nas yang du sems kyi gnas pa la so sor brtags pa'i dran pa dang / skye bo phal po che tshogs pa na gang yang rung phal cher ma shor du zin kyang ji skad bstan pa bzhin du dran pa bsrung ba de la bsgrim pa'i dran pa ste/ de ltar dran pa de dag gis 'bras bu med pa'i spyod pa rnam par spang ba 'grub po/ /

There are twelve forms of mindfulness for giving up fruitless activities. They are: the mindfulness of respecting the evolution of actions and protecting your state of obedience to the instructions of the Tathāgata; the mindfulness of resting in the essential stillness of the entire body; the mindfulness of the stable commitment, in everything you do, to take it as your principal goal in life to remain motionless, with very stable mindfulness, not using your limbs except for the benefit of sentient beings; the mindfulness of guarding your body, as with the fear that beginners feel, so as to be respectful at festivals and so on;[i] the mindfulness that watches when you move among the four bodily postures; the mindfulness that, from time to time, looks at the correctness of your physical posture, so as to prevent any disturbance in physical posture; the mindfulness that stops contortions of the hand, feet, head, or mouth, which can be extremely ugly, due to the influence of excessive frivolity, excitement, partiality, and so on, while you are speaking; the mindfulness of listening, and speaking only loudly enough so that others can understand and no more loudly than that; the mindfulness of maintaining the clarity of your own mind when meeting and conversing with untrained people, sensing the danger of creating doubt in others; the mindfulness of always keeping the rutting elephant of the mind tied to the pillar of resting meditation;[ii] the mindfulness of observing, from moment to moment, what is happening in your mind; and the mindfulness of focusing on staying mindful of the teachings and not slipping away from them when among crowds of regular people. Through these forms of mindfulness, you can actually give up fruitless activities. [119] Also,
dran pa de yang shin tu gus las 'byung /
[8b] Mindfulness should come from sharp attention.[iii]
de la gus pa ni bya ba rnams la snying nas mngon du phyogs par te khyad du gsod pa'i gnyen po yin no/ /
With your whole being, you should turn your attention towards the action you are doing. This is the remedy for clumsiness.[iv] And,
gus pa de ni zhi ba'i che ba nyid/ / shes par gyur na brtun pa skye/ /
[8c-d] With effort, this attention becomes what is called “the greatness of peace.”

zhi ba zhes bya ba de gang zhe na/ 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa'i mdo las/ zhi gnas su bstan pa gang yin pa ste/ de de la zhi gnas mi zad pa gang zhe na/ gang sems zhi ba dang / rab tu zhi ba dang / nye bar zhi ba dang / mi g.yeng ba dang / dbang po bsdams pa dang / mi rgod pa dang / mi 'phyar ba dang / mu cor mi smra ba dang / mi brtan pa med pa dang / mi g.yo ba dang / nges pa dang / bsrungs pa dang / cang shes pa dang / las su rung ba dang / rtse gcig pa dang / gcig pur dga' ba dang / 'du 'dzi rnam par spong ba dang / dben pa la dga' ba dang / lus dben pa dang / sems bslad pa med pa dang / dgon pa la phyogs shing yid la byed pa dang / sdig pa 'dod pa ma yin pas na spyod lam bsrung ba'i bar dang / dus shes pa dang / tshod shes pa dang / ran pa shes pa dang / rigs pa shes pa dang / mgu sla ba dang / gso sla ba zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ / zhi ba de'i che ba nyid ji lta bu zhe na/ yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du shes pa bskyed nus pa ste/ 'di ltar/

What is meant by the term “peace” here? It’s the resting meditation[1] taught in the noble Akṣayamati Sūtra: What is unbreakable resting meditation? It is mental peace, calm, tranquility, not getting distracted, discipline of the senses, absence of agitation, absence of dullness,[v] not wavering,[vi] not trembling, gentleness, protection, the mind being suitable for work, having a knowing quality, one-pointedness, living alone, giving up social interactions, delighting in solitude, secluded in body and mentally free from confusion, directing attention towards the wilderness retreat, having few desires,[vii] and so on up to: protecting your bodily posture, knowing the right time, knowing the right opportunity, knowing how much is enough, knowing freedom, being contented and easily satisfied, and so on. Then what is the “greatness” of this peace? It’s the ability to generate knowledge of things just as they are. Because
mnyam gzhag yang dag ji bzhin du/ / shes par 'gyur zhes thub pas gsungs/ /
[9a-b] “Someone absorbed in meditation knows things Just as they are,” said the Sage.

chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las ji skad du/ yid mnyam par bzhag pas yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du mthong bas byang chub sems dpa' sems can rnams la snying rje chen po 'jug go snyam mo/ / de yang 'di snyam du sems te/ bdag gis sems can thams cad la ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo 'di dang chos thams cad yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du mthong ba 'di grub par bya'o snyam mo/ / de snying rje chen po des bskul bas lhag pa'i tshul khrims dang / lhag pa'i sems dang / lhag pa'i shes rab la bslab pa yongs su rdzogs par byas nas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya'o/ / de lta bas na bdag gis tshul khrims la mi g.yo ba dang / mi lhod par gnas par bya'o zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / zhi ba'i che ba nyid 'di dag dang gzhan ngan song la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal mtha' yas pa las yang dag par 'da' ba dang 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i bde ba phun sum tshogs pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'i bdag nyid 'di rtogs nas/ kun du 'bar ba'i khyim gyi nang du chud pa chu bsil ba 'dod pa bzhin du de 'dod pas brtun pa bsgom par bya ste/ des ni bslab pa rnams la gus par 'gyur zhing de las kyang dran pa nye bar 'jog la dran pa nye bar bzhag pas ni 'bras bu med pa rnam par spong bar byed cing 'bras bu med pa rnam par spangs pa gang yin pa de la gnod pa mi 'byung ngo / / de lta bas na lus bsrung bar 'dod pas dran pa'i rtsa ba btsal te rtag tu dran pa nye bar gzhag par bya'o/ /

As the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together says, [120] A mind absorbed in meditation sees things just as they are. In a bodhisattva who sees things as they are, great compassion unfolds for sentient beings. Such a person thinks, “I should bring it about that all sentient beings see everything just as it is as a result of meditative absorption.” Moved by that great compassion, this person quickly completes the training in higher moral discipline, higher thought, and higher wisdom, and awakens fully to highest genuine full awakening. “Therefore, I should be well established in moral discipline, not moving, never slacking off.” In this way, one should reflect on the greatness of resting meditation for oneself and others, and in order to go beyond endless suffering in the lower realms and elsewhere, and for the sake of obtaining for oneself to the fullest extent endless, excellent worldly and transcendent happiness and success, one should practice diligently and longingly, like someone in a burning house longing for cool water. In this way, sharp attention arises in training. From this, in turn, arises mindfulness. Applying mindfulness, [the practitioner] gives up what is fruitless. And when someone gives up what is fruitless, what is harmful cannot arise for that person. Therefore, those who want to protect the body should seek out the root of mindfulness, and then should always apply mindfulness.

de bas na drag shul can gyis byin pas zhus pa las/ byang chub sems dpa' khyim pa'i dbang du byas te gsungs pa/ des 'bru'i chang dang sbyar ba'i chang myos par 'gyur ba'i btung ba spang bar bya ste/ de ra ro ba med pa dang myos pa med pa dang 'khrul pa med pa dang / tshig mi 'chal ba dang mi 'phyar ba dang mi rgod pa dang mi g.yeng ba dang dran pa nye bar gnas pa dang shes bzhin dang ldan par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / de nyid las rab tu byung ba'i byang chub sems dpa'i dbang du byas te dran pa dang shes bzhin ni mi g.yeng ba'o zhes gsungs so/ /

About lay bodhisattvas, the Inquiry of Ugra says: “They should abstain from beer, wine, and liquor,[viii] which are causes of heedlessness, and be sober, not intoxicated, not befuddled, steady, not agitated, not talkative, neither excited nor dull, mindful, and aware.”[2] And it says about ordained bodhisattvas, “They are not distracted from mindfulness and awareness.”

de la dran pa ni 'phags pa gtsug na rin po che'i mdo las/ dran pa gang gis nyon mongs pa thams cad 'byung bar mi 'gyur ba dang / dran pa gang gis bdud kyi las thams cad kyi go skabs mi 'byed pa dang / dran pa gang gis lam gol ba dang lam ngan par mi 'gro ba dang / dran pa sgo ba lta bu gang gis sems dang sems las byung ba'i chos mi dge ba thams cad kyi skabs mi 'byed pa 'di ni yang dag pa'i dran pa zhes bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / shes bzhin ni shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las gsungs te/ spyod na yang bdag spyod do zhes rab tu shes so/ / 'greng na yang bdag 'greng ngo zhes rab tu shes so/ / 'dug na yang bdag 'dug go zhes rab tu shes so/ / nyal na yang bdag nyal lo zhes rab tu shes so/ / de'i lus ji lta ji lta bur gnas par gyur ba de lta de lta bur rab tu shes so/ /

The noble Sūtra on the Jewel at the Crown of the Head says about mindfulness: The mindfulness that stops the active manifestation of all reactive emotions; the mindfulness that provides no entry point for any of the actions of Māra; the mindfulness that prevents you from falling into wrong paths and bad paths; the mindfulness that, like a doorkeeper, does not open up any opportunity for unwholesome thoughts and mental states—this is called right mindfulness. Awareness is explained in the Perfection of Wisdom: When walking, she knows “I am walking.” When standing, she knows “I am standing.” When lying down, she knows “I am lying down.” When sitting down, she knows, “I am sitting down.” However her body is positioned, she knows it to be just that way
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de 'gro ba dang 'ong ba na yang shes bzhin du spyod pa yin no/ / lta ba dang / rnam par lta ba dang bskum pa dang / myang ba dang chos gos snam sbyar dang thang ba dang lhung bzed dang chos gos gyon pa dang za ba dang 'thung ba dang 'cha' ba dang gnyid dang snyom pa bsal ba dang 'ong ba dang 'gro ba dang 'greng ba dang 'dug pa dang gnyid kyis log pa dang / gnyid kyis ma log pa dang smra ba dang cang mi smra ba dang / nang du yang dag 'jog pa shes bzhin du spyod do zhes gsungs so/ /

When going or coming, she practices with awareness. When looking, retracting the limbs, extending the limbs,[ix] carrying the begging-bowl and wearing the monastic outer robes, inner robes and shawl, when eating, drinking, chewing, getting rid of sleepiness and fatigue, coming and going, standing and sitting down, falling asleep and waking up, speaking and remaining silent, and while doing solitary meditation, she practices with awareness.

tshul khrims ni ting nge 'dzin 'grub pa yin te/ zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las ji skad du/ / nyon mongs med pa'i ting 'dzin myur thob ste/ / 'di ni tshul khrims rnam dag phan yon no/ / zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / de bas na ting nge 'dzin gyi rgyu'i sbyor ba gang ci yin pa de dag ni tshul khrims kyi nang du 'dus par shes so/ / de lta bas na ting nge 'dzin don du gnyer bas dran pa dang shes bzhin gyi ngang tshul can du bya'o/ /

[121] Moral discipline helps create the conditions for stable attention. As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[x] You attain stable attention quickly. This is a benefit of pure, spotless moral discipline. So we should understand that whatever forms of effort are causes of stable attention are included in moral discipline. Therefore, someone who is aiming for stable attention should practice the moral discipline of mindfulness and awareness.
de bzhin du tshul khrims don du gnyer bas kyang ting nge 'dzin la 'bad par bya ste/ mdo de nyid las ting nge 'dzin gyi phan yon gyi skabs nas/
In the same way, someone who is aiming for moral discipline should also make an effort at stable attention; for the same sūtra says, while discussing the advantages of meditative stability:[xi]

de ni cho ga med ma yin/ / cho ga dag la rab tu gnas/ / spyod yul la ni rnal 'byor pa/ / spyod cing spyod yul ma yin spong / / yongs su gdung ba med par gnas/ / dbang po bsrung zhing bsdams pa yin/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Such a person does not act badly, But is well established in good conduct. The spiritual practitioner stays in the right domain, Gives up inappropriate activities, And lives free from burning desire, Disciplined, with the senses protected.

tshul khrims dang ting nge 'dzin gcig gis gcig 'phel bar byed pa 'di gnyis kyis kyang sems yongs su sbyong ba yongs su 'grub po/ / byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa 'di ni/ 'di lta ste/ sems yongs su sbyong ba'o/ / 'di ni chos thams cad kyi rtsa ba yin te/ 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las sems ni chos thams cad kyi sngon du 'gro ba ste sems yongs su shes na chos thams cad yongs su shes par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba dang / /

Moral discipline and stable attention reinforce each other. The two together make it possible to embrace experience completely.[xii] This is itself the training of the bodhisattva: namely, the transformation of the mind that is rooted in the welfare of all sentient beings.[xiii] For the noble Cloud of Jewels says, “All that we are arises from our minds.[3] If the mind is known, everything is known.” And also,

yang 'jig rten sems kyis khrid pa ste/ / sems kyis sems ni mi mthong ngo / / dge ba'am 'on te mi dge ba'i/ / las ni sems kyis bsags pa yin/ / sems ni mgal me bzhin du 'khor/ / sems ni rlabs dang 'dra bar g.yo/ / sems ni nags kyi me bzhin sreg / sems ni chu chen bzhin du skyed/ / des de ltar brtags pas sems la dran pa nye bar gzhag par gnas te sems kyi dbang du mi 'gro'i sems de'i dbang du 'gro'o/ / sems de'i dbang du gyur na chos thams cad la dbang du gyur pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

[122] The world is led by the mind. Mind does not see mind. Karma is gathered by the mind, either good or bad. The mind wavers like a flame.[xiv] The mind wanders like a horse. {The mind fluctuates like a wave.} The mind burns like a forest fire.[xv] The mind carries you away like the great water. When you reflect thoroughly on the mind like this, and live well established in mindfulness, you do not move under the control of the mind. Rather, the mind moves under your control. And if the mind is under control, everything is under control.

chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las kyang / byang chub sems dpa' rnam par gnon pa'i blo gros kyis gsol pa/ chos chos zhes bgyi ba'i chos gang lags pa de ni yul na mi gnas phyogs na mi gnas te gzhan du na chos ni rang gi sems la rag las so/ / de lta bas na bdag gis rang gi sems shin tu gzung ba dang / shin tu mthar thug pa dang / shin tu thul ba dang / shin tu mnyam par brtsam pa dang / shin tu tshar gcad par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sems gang na yod pa de na yon tan dang nyes pa rnams yod kyi/ sems med pa la ni yon tan dang nyes pa rnams med do snyam ste/ de la byang chub sems dpa' nyes pa rnams las sems bzlog nas yon tan rnams la 'jug ste/ de lta bas na chos ni sems la rag las byang chub ni chos la rag las zhes bgyi'o/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di ni chos yang dag par 'dzin pa lags te/ bde bar mngon par rdzogs par byang chub par 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

Similarly, the noble Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together also says: The bodhisattva Mativikrama[4] said: “What we call ‘Dharma’ is not located in a place, or in a direction, other than this: Dharma depends on your own mind. Therefore, I should keep my own mind well in hand,[xvi] well-controlled, well-tamed, and well-balanced. Why? Where the mind is, there are abilities, and there are problems. Mindless things have no abilities and no problems. Here a bodhisattva turns the mind away from problems and towards abilities. As it is said, ‘Dharma depends on the mind; Awakening depends on Dharma.’ Blessed One, in undertaking this Dharma, one turns towards Awakening to happiness.”

'phags pa sdong po bkod pa'i mdo las kyang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa thams cad ni rang gi sems la brten te/ sems can thams cad yongs su smin par bya ba dang gdul ba ni rang gi sems la brten to/ /

This is also described in the noble Array of Stalks: The whole of the bodhisattva’s way of life is based on your own mind. The monastic code, and helping all sentient beings to mature, are based on the mind
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rigs kyi bu bdag 'di snyam du sems te/ dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad kyis rang gi sems nye bar brtan par bya'o/ / chos kyi sprin rnams kyis rang gi sems yongs su brlan par bya'o/ / sgrib par 'gyur ba'i chos rnams las rang gi sems yongs su sbyang bar bya'o/ / brtson 'grus kyis rang gi sems brtan par bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa brjod pa yin no/ /

Noble sir, this is what I think: you should support your mind with all wholesome actions. Clouds of dharma should rain down on your mind. You should purify your mind of distorted states. You should make your mind stable with perseverance. [123] And so on.

de bzhin du de nyid las/ 'phags pa nor bzang lha mo sgyu ma mthong bas brkam par gyur pa la/ grong gi lha mo rin chen mig gis de mthong ba'i don du 'di skad ces rjes su bstan te/ rigs kyi bu khyod kyis 'khor ba'i yul thams cad la dga' bar mi gnas pas sems kyi grong khyer yongs su bsrung ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i stobs bcu la lhag par dmigs pas sems kyi grong khyer brgyan pa la brtson par gyis shig /

Similarly, in the same text, when the noble Sudhana wanted to see Queen Māyā,[5] so that he could see her, the city goddess Ratnanetrā[6] gave him this teaching:[7] Noble sir, you should make an effort to guard the city of the mind through what is wholesome, by living while not taking delight in any of the objects of cyclic existence. Noble sir, you should make an effort to decorate the city of the mind by taking as your objective the ten powers of a Tathāgata.

rigs kyi bu khyod kyis phrag dog dang ser sna dang g.yo dang bral bas sems kyi grong khyer yongs su sbyang ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin nges par rtogs par bya bas sems kyi grong khyer gyi yongs su gdung ba rab tu zhi bar bya ba la brtson par gyis shig /

Noble sir, you should make an effort to clean up the city of the mind by removing envy, greed, and dishonesty.[xvii] {Noble sir, you should make an effort to pacify all forms of suffering in the city of the mind by knowing for certain the nature of everything.}

rigs kyi bu khyod kyis thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi tshogs la brtson 'grus chen po'i shugs rnam par spel bas sems kyi grong khyer rnam par spel ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis ting nge 'dzin dang snyoms par 'jug pa dang bsam gtan dang / rnam par thar pa dang chos kyi gzhal med khang yangs pa'i rnam par spyod pa la dbang bsgyur bas sems kyi grong khyer dang gnas kyi mdzod brgyan pa dang bsrung ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor yang dag pa sgrub pa'i sa thams cad kyi shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa rab tu thob par btsal bas sems kyi grong khyer snang bar bya ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad yang dag par 'byung ba'i thabs kyi lam gyis rang gi sems kyi grong khyer nye bar bstan pa la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis byang chub sems dpa' kun du bzang po spyad pa spyod pa'i smon lam mngon par bsgrub pa'i sems rnam par dag pas sems kyi grong khyer gyi ra ba brtan pa mngon par bsgrub pa la brtson par gyis shig /

Noble sir, you should make an effort to expand the city of the mind by expanding the energy of great perseverance that seeks the equipment for complete knowing.[xviii] Noble sir, you should make an effort to decorate and protect the storehouses of faith in the city of the mind through stable attention, balanced meditation, meditative stability, freedom, and the immeasurable quality of the Dharma, manifesting unrestricted conduct. Noble sir, you should make an effort to illuminate the city of the mind by seeking to fully attain the Perfection of Wisdom of all the Stages, and by correctly setting up the maṇḍala of the assembly of all the Tathāgatas. Noble sir, you should make an effort to instruct the city of the mind by the path of the correct methods of all the Tathāgatas. You should make an effort to fully stabilize the city of the mind by making the mind completely pure through accomplishing the aspiration prayer of Samantabhadra’s way of life, just as he did.

rigs kyi bu khyod kyis nyon mongs pa dang bdud kyi rigs kyi sdig pa'i grogs po dang bdud kyi 'khor gyis mi choms par bya bas sems kyi grong khyer rgal dka' ba dang mi shigs pa mngon par bsgrub pa la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis byams pa chen po 'gro ba thams cad la rgyas par dga' bas sems kyi grong khyer rab tu rgyas par bya ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis mi dge ba'i chos thams cad kyi gnyen po chos kyi gdugs yangs pa bsgrub pas sems kyi grong khyer rab tu dga' ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis phyi nang gi dngos po 'gro ba thams cad la bstabs pa'i phyir sems kyi grong khyer gyi sgo dbye ba la brtson par gyis shig / rigs kyi bu khyod kyis mi dge ba'i chos kyi rgyud thams cad mi srid par bya bas sems kyi grong khyer rab tu mkhrang bar mngon par bsgrub pa la brtson par gyis shig /

Noble sir, you should make an effort to make the city of the mind difficult to attack and difficult to besiege by demolishing [your relationships with] bad friends who are very reactive, belonging to Māra, members of Māra’s circle.[8] Noble sir, you should make an effort to extend the city of the mind by radiating great lovingkindness to all living beings. Noble sir, you should make an effort to shade[xix] the city of the mind by setting up the remedy for all unwholesome qualities, the broad canopy of the Dharma. Noble sir, you should make an effort to open the gates of the city of the mind in order to[xx] give everything, both internal and external, to all living things. Noble sir, you should make an effort to make the city of the mind stable and strong by not allowing any unwholesome qualities to become habituated in your personality
ces bya ba nas/

rigs kyi bu de ltar sems kyi grong khyer rnam par dag par bya ba la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad bsgrub pa 'thob par nus so/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar sems kyi grong khyer yongs su dag pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de'i mdun na ni sangs rgyas mthong bar bya ba la sgrib pa'am chos mnyan par bya ba la sgrib pa'am sgrib pa thams cad mi gnas so zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ / de lta bas na sems yongs su sbyang bar bya ba de nyid byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa yin no/ / zhes bya ba 'di rnam par gnas pa yin no/ /

Noble sir, a bodhisattva who makes an effort to purify the city of the mind in this way can perform all wholesome actions. Why is this? No distortions can survive in the presence of a bodhisattva who has purified the city of the mind in this way: neither the distortions that stop you from seeing a Buddha, nor the distortions that stop you from hearing the Dharma, nor any others. Therefore it was said that transforming the mind is itself the bodhisattva’s training. And this is steadiness of mind.
mi g.yo ba'i sems dang ldan pa de ni/
unswerving mind:
phyi rol g.yo ba bzlog pa yis/ / sems ni zhi gnas mi g.yo 'gyur/ /
[9c-d] When external movements stop, The mind does not move away from resting.

shes bzhin med pa'i gzhan gyi dbang du gyur cing brjed ngas pa ni 'dod pa'i dmigs pa las gzhan du khrid pa'i phyir sems g.yo bar 'gyur ro/ / gang gi tshe dran pa dang shes bzhin dang ldan zhing phyi rol du g.yo ba bzlog par gyur pa de'i tshe de'i dbang du gyur pas dmigs pa gcig la btags pas ji srid du 'dod pa de srid du gnas la/ de las kyang snga ma bzhin du phan yon rgya cher 'byung ngo / / las dang po pa yin du zin kyang sems can gyi don la bzod pa nyid de dad par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / ji lta zhe na/

[124] When you are not aware and so are under the control of others, and when you lack mindfulness, the mind is led elsewhere and moves away from the desired object. But when external movements are stopped by means of mindfulness and awareness, then by the power of that practice, the mind stays tied to a single object for as long as you want. And then all the benefits explained at length above will apply. Also, even if you are a beginner, the forbearance that benefits sentient beings arises, because others come to trust you. How?
kun du mi rgod 'jam pa dang / / ran cing mnyen par smra ba yis/ / skal can skye bo 'dun par 'gyur/ / gzung bar 'os pa'ang skye bar 'gyur/ /
[10] Someone who is totally free from agitation Speaks gentle, measured, loving words, Attracts worthy people who are ready to learn And arouses their interest.[xxi]

'di lta ste/ sems can 'dun par bya ba de nyid byang chub sems dpa'i bya ba yin te/ chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las/ byang chub sems pa 'phags pa mthong dgas gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' ci nas sems can rnams kyis mthong ma thag tu dga' bar 'gyur ba de lta de ltar bsgrub par bgyi'o/ / de ci'i slad du zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa'i bgyi ba gzhan ma mchis kyi sems can yongs su smin par bgyi bar byas te/ bcom ldan 'das 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i chos yang dag par brjod pa lags so zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / de ltar ma byas na ci nyes she na smras pa/

And this is exactly the bodhisattva’s job, namely, attracting other people. As the noble bodhisattva Priyadarśana clarified in the noble Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together, “Blessed One, a bodhisattva should behave in such a way that sentient beings feel confidence as soon as they see her. Why is this? Blessed One, a bodhisattva has no other task than attracting sentient beings.[xxii] For a bodhisattva, helping others to mature is ‘chanting the Dharma together.’ ”[xxiii] What’s the problem with not doing this? The author says:
de ni gzung 'os ma yin na/ / thal bas g.yogs pa'i me bzhin du/ / 'jig rten rgyal ba'i myu gu brnyas/ / sems can dmyal la sogs par sreg /
[11] Worldly people do not welcome, but treat with contempt, The offspring of the Victors, Who are like fire hidden by ashes, So they burn, in the hells and elsewhere.
sngar ji skad du bstan pa yin no/ /gang gi phyir de nyid la brnyas pa de nyid gnod pa yin te/ /
As described previously. Since contemptuous behavior is harmful in this way,
de phyir rgyal bas sdom pa'i mdor/ / gang gis sems can ma dad 'gyur/ / de ni bsgrims te rnam spang zhes/ / dkon mchog sprin las bka' stsal to/ /
[12] Therefore, in the Cloud of Jewels, The Victor taught a vow in brief Through which, if you make an effort, You won’t offend sentient beings.

ji skad du/ byang chub sems dpa'i yang dag par spyad pa de gang zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' gang gi phyir de la sems can rnams ma dad par 'gyur ba'i gnas ma yin par mi spyod/ yul ma yin par mi spyod/ dus ma yin par mi smra ba yin/ dus mi shes pa ma yin yul mi shes pa ma yin/ tshod mi shes pa ma yin te/ de sems can rjes su bsrung ba dang bdag gi byang chub kyi tshogs yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir/ spyod lam phun sum tshogs shing 'jam par smra ba dang / dal bus smra ba dang / 'du 'dzi mi mang ba dang / rab tu dben pa la mngon par phyogs pa dang / bzhin gyi mdangs rab tu dang ba yin zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

As the text says, [125] What are those bodhisattva practices? Here a bodhisattva does not hang out in the wrong place at the wrong time.[xxiv] He doesn’t talk at the wrong time. He isn’t someone who doesn’t know the right time, or someone who doesn’t know the right place, {or someone who doesn’t know how much is enough.} He doesn’t do anything that could be a reason for sentient beings to mistrust him; in order to protect sentient beings and complete the equipment for Awakening for himself, he makes his behavior totally perfect, speaks gently, speaks slowly, doesn’t spend a lot of time on social interactions, turns his face towards solitude, and has a very serene face.[xxv]

de bas na chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las kyang / gang sems can srung ba de tshul khrims srung ba yin no zhes bstan to/ / tshul 'dis ni dogs par 'gyur ba'i bud med dang lhan cig tu dben pa'i gnas la sogs par gnas par mi bya'o zhes 'jig rten bsrung ba mdzad par gyur to/ / de ltar na longs spyod pa'i chu'am thang la gcin dang phyi sa dang mchil ma dang rnag la sogs pa smad pa rnams dben yang rung mi dben yang rung ste lha dang mi'i sems bsrung ba'i phyir mi 'dor ro/ /

Now, the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together teaches: “Whoever protects sentient beings protects moral discipline.” You should protect people by [following rules] such as not staying in private with doubtful women.[xxvi] In the same way, you shouldn’t release urine, feces,[xxvii] phlegm, pus, or anything else that disgusts people into water-pots[xxviii] that are used for drinking, either in private or in public, so as to protect the minds of gods and humans.
dam pa'i chos dran pa nye bar gzhag pa las kyang / lkog tu lhag mar byas te/ lhag ma mi za ba dag la byin na yi dwags kyi 'gro bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

The Application of Mindfulness to the Holy Dharma says, “When you [eat] in private and there are leftovers, giving them to those who do not want to eat leftovers leads to rebirth as a hungry ghost.”[xxix]

de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las kyang / ma dad pa spang ba'i phyir mdun du so shing bza' bar mi bya mchil ma dor bar mi bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / gus pa dang 'dzem par bya ba'i cho ga 'di ni tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa nyi tshe la bya ba ma yin gyi thams cad du bya bar blta'o/ / mdo 'dir ni de dag gi mdun du byas na nyes pa shin tu lci ba'i 'jigs pa bstan pa'i phyir tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa'i ched du bstan pa yin te/

In the same way, the Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas describe carrying oneself in a way that doesn’t offend others: “Don’t chew on a toothpick in front of other people, or spit it down in front of others for fun.”[xxx] And you should do things respectfully and modestly in this way around everyone, not just celibate practitioners. But the sūtra refers to[xxxi] celibate practitioners so that you see the danger of downfalls towards them, which are very grave.

ji ltar 'di nyid las sgra drag po mi bya'o zhes gsungs pa'i cho ga 'di nyi tshe ba ma yin pa bzhin no/ / de skad du tshangs pas zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / bag sar bzhin du bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / de bzhin du so sor thar pa las/ 'jig rten ma dad par byed par bstan pa brtags te bsal bar bya'o/ / de la re zhig / kha bkang ba dang sgrar bcas dang / / kha gdangs nas ni bza' mi bya/ / rkang pa brkyang ste mi 'dug cing / / lag pa mnyam du mi mnye'o/ /

As the same text says, “You shouldn’t speak loudly.” Again, this way of acting is not restricted in scope. In the same way, the Inquiry of a Brahmā (Brahma-paripṛcchā) also says, “A bodhisattva should not act like an executioner.”[xxxii] And the Vows of Individual Liberation also say to look for whatever offends people and avoid that.[xxxiii] In that context, Don’t eat with a full mouth, or noisily, with your mouth wide open. Don’t sit with your legs stretched out, or rub them with your hands.
de bzhin du rang gis kyang brtags pa dang / mthong ba dang thos pas 'jig rten ma dad par 'gyur ba bsrung bar bya'o// //
[126] Thus, you should guard against anything that you have seen, heard, or suspected to offend people.[xxxiv]
bam po drug pa/
ma dad par byed pa'i tshig spang ba ni bla ste dran pa bskul ba tsam gyi phyir bstan par bya'o/ /
“Avoiding offensive words and actions is not easy!” This was taught in order to urge you to be mindful.

'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las/ tshig zhum pa med pa yin/ tshig sub sub po med pa yin/ tshig nog nog po med pa yin/ 'bar bar byed pa'i tshig med pa yin/ co 'dri ba'i tshig med pa yin/ 'dod chags kyi rjes su chags pa'i tshig med pa yin/ phal pa'i tshig med pa yin/ kun du ma bsrungs ba'i tshig med pa yin/ gnod sems 'bar ba'i tshig med pa yin/ 'thab pa dang rtsod pa dang 'gyed pa'i tshig med pa yin/ thob kyis 'jal ba'i tshig med pa yin/ tshig 'gyur ba med pa yin/ tshig mi brtan pa med pa yin/ mu cor smra ba'i tshig med pa yin/ gar gyi ltad mo lta ba'i tshig med pa yin/ ngor skur pa 'debs pa'i tshig med pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Sāgaramati Sūtra teaches, Don’t speak timidly. Don’t speak haltingly.[xxxv] Don’t speak in a slippery way.[xxxvi] Don’t be unrestrained in speech. Don’t be led to speak by attraction. Don’t speak obscurely. Don’t speak unguardedly. Don’t speak out of malice or excitement. Don’t speak unsteadily, or with a quavering voice. Don’t speak deceitfully. Don’t speak so as to attempt to discredit an eyewitness.[xxxvii]

'phags pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba'i mdo las kyang / zhi ba'i blo gros byang chub sems dpa'i ngag ni chags pa'am sdang ba'am/ rmongs pa'am/ nyon mongs pa'am/ thogs pa'am/ nye bar thogs pa'am/ rang gi phyogs bstod pa'i tshig gam/ gzhan gyi phyogs tshar gcod pa'i tshig gam/ bdag bstod pa la rjes su chags pa'i tshig gam/ gzhan gyi bstod pa la bar du gcod pa'i tshig gam/ kha 'og tu lus 'khrus par mi byed pa'i tshig gam/ mngon pa'i nga rgyal gyis brda sprod pa'i tshig mi 'byin zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

The noble Sūtra on the Mysteries of the Tathāgata also says, Noble sir,[xxxviii] a bodhisattva’s speech is not based on attraction, aversion, or delusion; it is not reactive, or of fractured grammar.[xxxix] [Bodhisattvas] would not utter words praising their own side, or chastising the other side, or words of attachment to their own reputation, or words harmful to the reputation of others, or words making promises that won’t be kept,[xl] or words that are expressed in an arrogant way.

'phags pa sa bcu pa'i mdo las kyang / ngag gang dag yid du mi 'ong bas snying na bar byed cing / gdung bar byed pa dang / bdag gi rgyud dang gzhan gyi rgyud ma rung bar byed pa'i tshig gi rnam pa de lta bu spangs te/ ngag 'di 'jam pa dang mnyen pa dang / yid du 'ong ba dang / rdzun ma yin pa dang / rnar snyan pa dang / snying du sdug pa dang / grong khyer ba dang / skye bo mang po'i yid du 'ong ba dang / yid dga' bar byed pa dang / yid tshim par byed pas bdag gi rgyud dang gzhan gyi rgyud dang bar byed pa dang / lan legs par ldon pa'i tshig dang / dus su smra ba dang / yang dag par smra ba dang / chos smra ba dang / rigs pa smra ba dang / 'dul ba smra ba de lta bu'i tshig brjod de/ de tha na bzhad gad du bya ba'i tshig yongs su spang bar bya ba yang yongs su spong na/ tshig gis gzhan rnam par g.yeng ba lta ci smos zhes bya ba'i bar du gsungs so/ /

The noble Sūtra on the Ten Stages also says,[9][xli] [127] They give up speech which is displeasing and harms their own minds and the minds of others. They speak loving words, gentle, enchanting, sweet, endearing, causing others to listen intently, causing well-being, pleasing to the ear, going to the heart, loving, positive, clear, comprehensible, audible, not attached, agreeable to many people, dear to many people, listened intently to by many people, praised by the intelligent, bringing well-being and happiness to all sentient beings, making the mind jump up, delighting the mind, causing joy in their own minds and in those of others, pacifying attraction, aversion, delusion, and all reactive emotions—this is how they speak. They leave behind talking about history and about the past.[xlii]
'phags pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi mdo las kyang / bla ma'i ngag mi gcog pa dang pha rol gyi tshig mi zlog pas tshig gzung bar 'os par 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /
The noble Gaganagañja Sūtra also says: “By not disobeying the words of their spiritual teachers, and by not disregarding the words of others, they become people who speak clearly.”

chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las/ byang chub sems dpa' nam mkha' mdzod kyis gsol ba las kyang / byang chub sems dpa'i gang gis sems can rnams la gnod par 'gyur ba'i tshig de smra bar mi bgyi'o/ / gang gis gzhan la gdung bar 'gyur ba'i tshig de smra bar mi bgyi'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' gang gzhan gyis 'tshal bar mi 'gyur ba'i tshig de smra bar mi bgyi'o/ / gang gzhan gyi don ma lags pa dang / don ma mchis pa'i tshig de smra bar mi bgyi'o/ / gang sems can rnams kyi snying la mi 'bab pa dang / 'khor go ba ma lags pa dang rnar mi snyan pa'i tshig de smra bar mi bgyi'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together also says, The bodhisattva Gaganagañja said: “A bodhisattva should not say anything that would cause harm to others. A bodhisattva should not say anything that would be distressing to others. A bodhisattva should not say something that the other person would not understand.[xliii] A bodhisattva should not say something of no benefit just in order to talk. A bodhisattva should not say something from which no one learns anything.[xliv] A bodhisattva should not say things that don’t go to the hearts of sentient beings, that are not urbane,[xlv] or that are not pleasant to hear.”

mdor na gzhan dad par mi 'gyur ba bsrung bar bya bar 'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las bstan te/ gzhan yang theg pa chen po sdud par 'gyur ba'i chos gcig ste/ bdag gis 'khrul pa la rtog pas sems can thams cad rjes su srung ba'o zhes bya'o/ / gang gis sems can thams cad srung bar byed pa

The noble Sāgaramati Sūtra summarizes the topic of guarding against offense to others: “There is another single quality that collects together the whole Great Way—protecting all sentient beings by looking closely at your own confusion.”
'di ni bdag lus bsrung ba ste/
[13a] This is protecting the body,
ci nas gzhan dag gis ma rung bar mi 'gyur ba dang ci nas gzhan dag rung bar mi 'gyur ba'o/ / gzhung rgyas pa 'di'i don bsdus pa 'di ni byang chub sems dpas yid kyis rtag tu gzung bar bya ste/ /
So that you do not harm others, and so that others do not harm you. A bodhisattva who is going for alms[xlvi] should always keep in mind the text’s detailed explanation of that:

shin tu nges shing rab dad dang / / brtan zhing gus bcas zhe sar bcas/ / ngo tshar bcas shing 'jigs bcas dang / / zhi zhing gzhan dga' byed la brtson/ / phan tshun mi mthun byis pa yi/ / 'dod pa rnams kyis mi skyo zhing / / nyon mongs skyes pas 'di dag gi/ / sems 'di yin snyam brtser ldan dang / / kha na ma tho med dngos la/ / bdag dang sems can dbang byas nas/ / sprul pa bzhin du nga med par/ / yid ni rtag tu gzung bar bya/ / zhes bya ba'o/ /

Very stable and confident, Steady, with attention and respect, Modest and cautious, Peaceful, intent on service to others, {Not upset by the mutually contradictory Desires of foolish people, Thinking that these are born from reactive emotions And with love,} Attending to blameless objects, At the disposal of myself and sentient beings, Free from conceit, like an illusion, I will always hold this mind.[10]
ci bdag bsrung ba 'di de tsam du zad dam zhe na ma yin no/ / 'o na ci zhe na/ /
Is this all there is to protecting the body? No. What more is there, then?
sman dang gos la sogs bcas pas/ /
[13b] By means of medicine, clothes, and so on.
de la sman ni rnam pa gnyis te/ gtan du ba'i sman dang na ba'i rkyen sman no/ / de la gtan du ba'i sman gyi dbang du byas te/ 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las/
There are two kinds of medicine: everyday medicine, and medicine for the sick. About everyday medicine, the noble Cloud of Jewels says:

bsod snyoms de las cha gcig ni tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams kyi spyir gzhag go/ / gnyis pa ni sdug bsngal ba rnams kyi spyir gzhag go/ / gsum pa ni sems can log par ltung ba rnams kyi spyir gzhag go/ / cha bzhi pa ni bdag za'o/ / de za ba na 'dod chags med par za ste chags par ma yin brkam par ma yin zhen par ma yin gyi gzhan du na ji tsam du lus gnas par 'gyur ba dang 'tsho bar bya ba'i phyir za ste/ ji ltar ha cang yang nyams dma' ba dang ha cang yang lus lci bar mi 'gyur ba de ltar za'o/ /

[128] From that alms-food, make one share for your companions in the celibate life, a second for the suffering, and a third for the fallen; eat the fourth yourself. Eat it without attraction, without greed, without desire, without attachment; eat enough to preserve and nourish the body. Eat in such a way that you do not become excessively thin or excessively heavy of body.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ ha cang yang nyams dmas na ni dge ba'i phyogs la rgyab kyis bltas par 'gyur ro/ / lus ha cang yang lcis na ni gnyid kyis non par 'gyur ro/ / de bas na bsod snyoms de zos nas dge ba'i phyogs la mngon du phyogs par bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

Why? Because if you are excessively thin, you turn your face away from what is wholesome. And if your body is too heavy, you are overcome by sleepiness. When you have eaten the alms-food in this way, turn your face towards what is wholesome.

'phags pa rin po che'i phung po'i mdo las/ des grong ngam grong khyer ram grong rdal du bsod snyoms spyod pa na chos kyi go cha bgos la bsod snyoms spyad par bya'o/ / de la chos kyi go cha gang zhe na/ mig gis yid du 'ong ba'i gzugs rnams mthong na rjes su chags par mi bya'o/ / yid du mi 'ong ba'i gzugs rnams mthong na khong khro bar mi bya'o/ / de bzhin du sgra dang dri dang ro dang reg pa yid du mi 'ong ba dang / yid du 'ong ba rnams la rjes su chags pa dang khong khro bar mi bya'o/ / dbang po shin tu bsdams pa dang mig mi g.yeng ba dang gnya' shing gang tsam du blta ba dang dul ba dang cang shes kyi sems dang sngon yid la byed pa'i chos mi 'dor ba dang zang zing gis ma 'bags pa'i rgyud kyis bsod snyoms spyad par bya'o/ / mthar chags su bsod snyoms blang bar bya'o/ / gang nas bsod snyoms rnyed pa der rjes su chags par mi bya'o/ / gang nas ma rnyed pa der yang khong khro bar mi bya'o/ / khyim bcur bslangs pa las khyim bcu gcig pa las bsod snyoms ma rnyed na yang yongs su yi chad par mi bya'i/ de 'di snyam du bram ze dang khyim bdag 'di dag ni bya ba mang ba dag yin pas de dag gis bdag la sbyin par nges pa med de de dag bdag la sems pa yang ngo mtshar che na bsod snyoms sbyin pa lta smos kyang ci dgos snyam pa'i 'du shes bskyed par bya ste/ des de ltar yongs su yi chad pa med par bsod snyoms spyad par bya'o/ /

The Multitude of Jewels also says: Someone going for alms in a village, town, or city should go for alms wearing the armor of the Dharma. What is the armor of the Dharma? When he sees unappealing forms, he should not be averse to them; when he sees appealing forms, he should not be attached to them. Similarly with appealing and unappealing experiences of hearing, smell, taste, and touch: he should not get attached to them or try to push them away. With the senses very disciplined and eyes lowered, looking forward the length of a wooden yoke, with a tamed and well-bred mind, not letting go of his previous application of attention to the Dharma, with a mind that doesn’t get scattered onto worldly things,[xlvii] he should go for alms. He should beg for alms in an appropriate order.[xlviii] He should not get attached to those who give him alms, or arouse hostility towards those who do not. If, after having begged at ten houses, he does not get any alms even from the eleventh house, he should not be discouraged, and should think: “These Brahmins, leading merchants, and religious wanderers[xlix] are so busy, they certainly [have no time] to give to me. It’s a wonder that they notice me at all! How much less so would they give me any alms.” Not discouraged in this way, he should go for alms.

sems can gang dag de'i mig lam du snang bar gyur pa skyes pa dang bud med dang khye'u dang bu mo dang tha na dud 'gro'i skye gnas su song ba de dag la yang byams pa dang snying rje'i sems bskyed par bya'o/ / ji nas kyang sems can gang dag bdag gi mig lam du snang bar gyur pa'am bsod snyoms sbyin pa de dag mtho ris su 'gro bar 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o/ / de ltar brtson par bya'o/ / des bsod snyoms ngan nam bzang yang rung blangs te/ grong ngam grong khyer ram grong rdal 'di na bdag gi bsod snyoms 'di la bgo bsha' bya dgos pa'i sems can dbul po su yod snyam du phyogs bzhi kun du blta bar bya'o/ / gal te sems can dbul po zhig mthong na des bsod snyoms de la bgo bsha' bya'o/ / gal te sems can dbul po ma mthong na des 'di ltar gang dag bdag gi mig lam du snang bar ma gyur te/ mi snang ba'i sems can de dag la bsod snyoms kyi thog ma'i cha skal sbyin gyi byin nas len pa dag yongs su spyod cig snyam du sems bskyed la/ des bsod snyoms de khyer te dgon pa'i gnas der song la lhung bzed dang lag pa bkrus te/ dge sbyong gi spyod pa dang cho ga dang ldan pa'i spyod pa bzang pos byin gyis brlabs la des skyil mo krung bcas te bsod snyoms de bza' bar bya'o/ /

And as for those sentient beings who come into his field of vision, women, men, boys, and girls, even including animals, he should arouse thoughts of lovingkindness and compassion towards them all, thinking “I should act so that all those sentient beings who come into my field of vision or give me alms will go to good rebirths;[l] I will attain this kind of practice.” [129] Whether the alms-food he receives is of good quality or of poor quality, he should look around to all four directions, thinking, “In this village, town, or city, who is a poor person, with whom I can share this alms-food?” If he sees a poor person, he shares his alms-food with that person. If he does not see any poor people, he should think, “There are unseen sentient beings who do not come into my field of vision. I give them the best share of this alms-food. May they accept it and eat it!” Carrying the alms-food, he should go to the forest. He should wash his hands and begging-bowl, and receive energy from whatever rituals of purification are appropriate for the life of religious wanderers; then, sitting in meditation posture, he should eat the alms-food
de bzhin du sbyar te/

zas zos nas 'di snyam du lus 'di la srin bu'i rigs brgyad khri yod pa dag 'di'i mthus bde bar gnas par gyur cig / da lta ni 'di dag zang zing gis bsdu bar bya'o/ / byang chub thob nas ni chos kyis bsdu bar bya'o snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o/ / gal te de'i nyung bar gyur na des 'di snyam du kha zas nyung bas ni bdag gi lus yang bar 'gyur/ spong ba bzod par 'gyur/ bdag gi bshang gci 'byung ba nyung bar 'gyur/ bdag la dad pas byin pa chung bar 'gyur/ bdag gi lus yang ba dang sems yang bar 'gyur/ bdag rmugs pa dang gnyid chung bar 'gyur ro snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o/ / de bzhin du sbyar te/ gal te des bsod snyoms mang zhig rnyed na de la yang ran par bza' bar bya'o/ / dor ba'i chos nyid du yang bya ste/ bsod snyoms de las rdo leb gang yang rung ba'i steng du gtor la 'di snyam du gcan gzan dang bya'i tshogs gang la la zang zing gi zas 'dod pa byin nas len pa de dag byin pa'i sbyin pa byin pa 'di la zo zhig snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

While eating, he should arouse this thought: “In this body, there are eighty thousand species of tiny animals. Through this [food,] may they live feeling healthy and happy. Right now, I will bring them together through food. But when I have attained Awakening, I will bring them together through Dharma.” Now, if he has only a little alms-food, he should think: “By eating only a little food, my body will be light, and I will have the peace of renunciation. My production of feces and urine will be small. The gift of faith given to me will also be small. My body and mind will be light, and I will have little fatigue and sleepiness.” Now when he has a lot of alms-food, he should still eat moderately, let some of it fall to the ground, and then scatter some of the alms-food on top of a flat stone, thinking, “Whatever groups of wild animals or flocks of birds are looking for food, may they receive and eat this gift.”
yang bka' stsal pa/ des kha zas bzang po rnams la ro bro ba'i 'du shes thams cad kyi thams cad du bskyed par mi bya'o/ /
Moreover, the text says: [130] He should not develop any conceptions at all about tastes…[li]

des 'di ltar bdag gis gdol bu lta bu dang lus dang sems gtsang mar bya'i kha zas kyis lus gtsang mar ni mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ zas bzang po ji snyed cig zos kyang de thams cad ni tha mar rnag tu zag go/ / tha mar mi mthun no/ / tha mar dri nga ba'o/ / de lta bas na bdag gis zas bzang po 'dod par mi bya'o snyam du bslab par bya'o/ /

and should think, “I should be like an untouchable boy; I should [try to] have a pure mind and body, but should not [try to] have pure food. Why? No matter how much good-quality food is eaten, in the end it all turns into bad-smelling, embarrassing bodily fluids.[lii] Therefore I should not long for good-quality food.”
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

des 'di ltar sems bskyed par bya ste/ bdag la skyes pa bsod snyoms ster gyi bud med ni ma yin no zhe'am/ bdag la bud med bsod snyoms ster gyi skyes pa ni ma yin no zhe'am/ bdag la khye'u bsod snyoms ster gyi bu mo ni ma yin no zhe'am/ bdag la bu mo bsod snyoms ster gyi khye'u ni ma yin no zhe'am/ bdag gis bzang po rnyed kyi ngan pa ni ma yin no zhe'am/ bdag gis bsti stang du byas nas rnyed kyi bsti stang ma byas par ni ma yin no zhe'am/ bdag gis bde blag tu rnyed kyi sha thang bar ni ma yin no zhe'am/ bdag la skyes pa dang bud med dang / khye'u dang bu mo rtsi bar 'gyur ro zhe'am/ phyin ma thag tu bdag la sems par 'gyur ro/ / bdag sdod dgos par 'gyur ram/ shin tu bsdogs pa rnyed par 'gyur ram/ bdag gis bzang po ro sna tshogs dang ldan pa rnyed par 'gyur gyi dbul po'i zas lta bu ngan pa ni rnyed pa ma yin no snyam du des mi dga' ba yid la byed pa thams cad bskyed par mi bya'o/ /

He should not arouse such thoughts as these: “A man is giving me alms-food, not a woman. A woman is giving me alms-food, not a man. A boy is giving me alms-food, not a girl. A girl is giving me alms-food, not a boy. I am getting good-quality food, not poor-quality. They are giving it to me respectfully, not disrespectfully. I receive alms easily, not with difficulty. As soon as I arrive, may they pay attention to me, and may they not give me any excuses![liii] {I have to wait. Or,} I find things well-prepared. I get good-quality food with a variety of tastes, not inferior food like what poor people eat. May they all come out to meet me—women, men, boys, and girls.” He should not arouse any of these unwholesome thoughts
de bzhin du sbyar te/

sems can phal cher ni ro la brkam ste/ zas kyi phyir sdig pa'i las rnams byas nas sems can dmyal bar skye'o/ / gang dag chos shes pa mi brkam pa ma zhen pa ro la mi gdu ba lce'i dbang po chog shes pa zas ngan ngon ji tsam gyis kyang 'tsho ba de dag ni shi 'phos te shi ba'i dus byas nas mtho ris su skye bar 'gyur/ lha dang mi rnams kyi nang du bde 'gror 'gro bar 'gyur/ lhar skyes nas bdud rtsi za bar 'gyur ro/ / 'od srungs de ltar na bsod snyoms spyod pa'i dge slong gis ro la sred pa zlog ste/ sems nges par sems pas lhad zan zhag bdun lon pa za yang yi 'chad par mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ lus gso ba dang 'phags pa'i lam gyi tshogs bsags pa'i don du bdag gis zas bza'o snyam pa'i phyir ro/ /

Most sentient beings are greedy for tastes; for the sake of food, they commit vile actions and are born in the hells. But those who {know the Dharma} are contented, not greedy, free from longing; they do not bow down to the sense of taste, but are contented and can be nourished even with very low-quality food. When they die and transmigrate, they are born in heaven; they go to good rebirths among gods and humans. Once born as gods, they eat ambrosia. Therefore, Kāśyapa, a monk who goes for alms turns away from craving for tastes. His mind understands; he does not become depressed even if he happens to eat dirty porridge for a week.[liv] Why is this? {Because he thinks,} “I should eat food in order to nourish my body and in order to sustain the {noble} path.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

'od srungs gal te sprin 'dus shing char 'bab ste/ bsod snyoms spyod pa'i dge slong bsod snyoms la 'jug mi nus pa'i dus kyi tshe/ byams pa'i zas kyi go bgo ste/ chos sems pa yid la byed pa la gnas nas zhag gnyis sam zhag gsum zhig zan chad na/ 'di ltar yi dwags gshin rje'i 'jig rten pa nyes par byed pa'i las byas pa gang dag lo brgyar yang mchil ma'i thal ba 'ga' bza' mi rnyed pa dag kyang yod de/ de lta bas na bdag tshul bzhin du chos sems pa la gnas pas/ lus nyam chung ba'am sems nyam chung ba bskyed par mi bya ste/ bkres pa dang skom pas ji mi snyam par bya'o/ / 'phags pa'i lam bsgom pa la brtson 'grus rgyun mi 'chad par bya'o snyam du 'du shes bskyed par bya'o/ /

[131] Kāśyapa, if clouds gather and rain falls,[lv] and a monk cannot go for alms, then, well-equipped with the food of lovingkindness, he should live applying attention to reflection on the Dharma. If there is no food for two or three days,[lvi] he should think, “In the world of Yama, there are hungry ghosts who have acted badly, and who don’t even get a morsel of mucus to eat for a hundred years. As I live reflecting appropriately on the Dharma, I will not give in to weakness of body or to weakness of mind. I will reside like a native in hunger and thirst,[lvii] and will not slack off from the perseverance of meditating on the noble path.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

khyim gang na bsod snyoms gtsang ma byed pa'i khyim der stan la 'dug ste bsod snyoms gtsang ma byed ma zin gyi bar du chos kyi gtam brjod par bya'o/ / de nas bsod snyoms de blangs la stan las langs te 'gro bar bya'o/ /

In a house where pure alms-food is being prepared, he should sit down and talk about the Dharma for as long as it takes to get the food ready. When he gets that alms-food, he should stand up from his seat and depart.

'od srungs bsod snyoms spyod pa'i dge slong gis 'khong bar mi bya/ kha gsag mi bya/ tshul 'chos par mi bya'o/ / de la 'khong ba gang zhe na/ gang gzhan dag la tshig 'di skad du smra ba ste/ bdag gi bsod snyoms ni ngan pa'o bdag gi bsod snyoms ni rtsub pa'o/ / bdag gis sngon 'di lta bu dang ma 'grangs par ma zos so/ / bdag gi bsod snyoms ni skye bo mang po dang thun mong du byas so/ / bdag gis nyung zhig zos te bdag ma 'grangs pas bdag gi lus nyam chung ngo zhes bya ba ste 'di ltar 'khong ba'i mtshan ma gang ci yang rung ba 'di lta bu 'di ni sems kyi tshul 'chos pa zhes bya ste/ dge slong bsod snyoms spyod pas de dag thams cad mi bya'o/ / gang lhung bzed du 'ongs pa ngan kyang rung bzang yang rung nyung yang rung mang yang rung gtsang yang rung mi gtsang yang rung ste de bza' bar bya'o/ / yongs su gdung ba med pa dang / bsam pa yongs su dag pa dang / chos nges par sems pa mang ba dang / lus gso ba dang 'phags pa'i lam nye bar bstan pa'i phyir des bsod snyoms bza' bar bya'o zhes bya ba'o/ /

Kāśyapa, a monk going for alms should never engage in hinting, boasting,[lviii] or hypocrisy. Here, what is hinting? When someone speaks words such as these to others: “My alms-food was low-quality; my alms-food was coarse. I did not get to eat as much as I wanted. My alms-food was shared with many people. I ate little, and I am hungry; {my body is weak.}” Anything like this that has the characteristics of hinting is called “mental hypocrisy.” A monk going for alms shouldn’t do anything like that, but should have equanimity. He should eat whatever falls into the begging-bowl, poor-quality or good-quality, {a small amount or a large amount,} clean or dirty, without mental distress, with pure intentions and with great confidence in the Dharma. He should eat alms-food in order to nourish the body and support the noble path.

de skad du drag shul can gyis byin pas zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / gang la la bsod snyoms blangs te/ bdag dang gzhan gyi don rdzogs par byed nus na ngas byang chub sems dpa' de mgron du 'gro bar gnang ngo zhes gsungs so/ / de ltar re zhig rtag tu ba'i sman gyis lus bsrung bar bya ba yin no/ / de la yang nya dang shas ni ma yin te/ lang kar gshegs pa'i mdo las bkag pa'i phyir te/ 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa' snying brtse ba'i bdag nyid can gyis sha thams cad mi bza'o zhes bshad do/ /

The noble Inquiry of Ugra also says: “I permit bodhisattvas to go as guests to any place where, by accepting alms-food, they can benefit both themselves and others.”[lix] [132] In this way, you should protect the body with everyday medicine. But not with fish or meat, because that is forbidden in the Sūtra on Entering Laṅka (Laṅka-avatāra-sūtra.)[11] For that text says:[12] I say that a compassionate bodhisattva should not eat any meat
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
'khrul pa dang ni gnyen bshes dang / / khu chu khrag las byung ba'i phyir/ / 'byung po rnams ni dngang 'gyur bas/ / rnal 'byor can gyis sha mi bza'/ /
Spiritual practitioners should give up the meat Of beings who tremble with fear, Who arose from [drops of] semen and blood, Born from a mother, because of unchastity.
sha rnams dang ni sgog btsong dang / / chang dag rnam pa sna tshogs dang / / ke'u dang sgog skya de bzhin du/ / rnal 'byor can gyis rtag tu spang / /
Spiritual practitioners should always give up Meat and onions, Liquor of all kinds, Leeks and garlic.
'bru mar gyis kyang byugs pa spang / / khri la brten pa'i sems can rnams/ / bu ga bu gar 'jig 'gyur phyir/ / khri la nyal bar mi bya'o/ /
They shouldn’t smear their bodies with sesame oil[13] Or sleep on a bed of nails, Because doing so frightens The insects who live inside.
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
khe yi phyir ni sems can gsod/ / sha yi phyir ni nor sbyin byed/ / de dag gnyi ga sdig pa can/ / ngu 'bod byed la sogs par btso/ /
Some sell animals for profit. Others pay money for meat, {Cook animals and make them cry out.[lx] Both of them act in a vile way.}
gang gis thub pa'i tshig 'das te/ / bsam pa ngan pas sha za na/ / 'jig rten gnyis ni gzhig pa'i phyir/ / shAkya'i bstan las brtul zhugs blangs/ /
Those who disobey the word of the Sage By foolishly eating meat, Are destroyed in both this world [and the next,] As if they were prepared for sacrifice in the religion of the Śākyan.
shin tu mi bzad dmyal bar yang / / sdig pa'i las can de dag 'dong / / ma rungs ngu 'bod la sogs su/ / sha za de dag btso bar 'gyur/ /
Having committed vile actions, they go To the most terrifying hell; In the Raurava hell, among those screaming, The meat-eaters are cooked.
rnam gsum dag pa'i sha rnams ni/ / ma brtags pa dang ma blangs dang / / ma bskul ba yang spong med pas/ / de bas sha ni mi bza'o/ /
As for meat that is pure in the three respects, Not suspected [to have been killed just for you,] asked for, or requested— There is none;[lxi] Therefore, you shouldn’t eat meat.
rnal 'byor can gyis sha mi bza'/ / nga dang sangs rgyas dag gis bshad/ / sems can gcig la gcig za ba/ / sha za dag gi rigs su skye/ /
Spiritual practitioners should not eat meat, Which was forbidden by me and all the Buddhas; Sentient beings who eat each other Are born in families of eaters of raw flesh (…)
dri mi zhim zhing smad pa dang / / smyon pa rnams su skye bar 'gyur/ / gdol pa sme sha can rigs dang / / btso blag mkhan du yang yang skye/ /
They are born bad-smelling, contemptible, [133] And also insane; They are born in untouchable and low-caste families Or as lowly corpse-burners,[lxii] again and again.
mkha' 'gro'i rigs kyi skye gnas dang / / sha za'i rigs su skye bar 'gyur/ / mi yi tha ma de dag ni/ / srin po byi la'i mngal du skye/ /
They are born in the wombs of ḍākinīs[14] And in meat-eating families; The most wretched of humans, they are born In the wombs of bears and cats.[lxiv]
glang po rtsal dang sprin chen dang / / mya ngan 'das dang sor phreng dang / / lang kar gshegs pa'i mdo las kyang / / ngas ni sha yang rnam par spangs/ /
In the Elephant’s Girth [Sūtra], in the Great Cloud, In the Nirvana [Sūtra] and the Āṅgulimālika [Sūtra] And in the Sūtra on Entering Laṅka, I have forbidden[lxiii] meat.
sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' dang / / nyan thos rnams kyis smad pa la/ / ngo mi tsha bar za ba ni/ / rtag tu smyon par skye bar 'gyur/ /
It is forbidden by Buddhas, By bodhisattvas, and by Disciples; Those who shamelessly eat [meat] Are always born insane.
sha la sogs pa spang ba'i phyir/ / bram ze'i rigs dang rnal 'byor can/ / shes rab can dang nor ldan par/ / de dag rnams ni skye bar 'gyur/ /
But those who give up eating meat Are born among Brahmins Or in families of spiritual practitioners, Both intelligent and wealthy.
mthong dang thos dang dogs pa yis/ / sha rnams thams cad rnam par smad/ / sha zan rigs su skyes pa yi/ / rtog ge ba rnams mi shes so/ /
Those who have seen, heard, or suspected Should give up meat completely. Logic-choppers who are born in meat-eating families Don’t understand this.
ji ltar 'dod chags thar pa la/ / bar chad byed par 'gyur ba bzhin/ / de ltar sha dang chang la sogs/ / bar chad byed par 'gyur ba'o/ /
Just as desire Becomes an obstacle to freedom, In the same way, you should Create obstacles for meat, liquor, and so on.
ma 'ongs pa yi dus na ni/ / sha za gti mug smra ba dag / sha ni sdig med rung ba'o zhes/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis bshad ces zer/ /
In the future, meat-eaters Whose doctrines are confused will say: “Meat is suitable and blameless, [134] And permitted by the Buddhas.”
zas la sman dang 'dra ba dang / / bu yi sha dang mtshungs par yang / / ran pa dang ni mi 'phrod par/ / rnal 'byor can gyis zas la spyod/ /
It’s like eating as medicine The flesh of your own son. A spiritual practitioner who goes out for alms Should be moderate [and avoid] what is inappropriate.
seng ge dag dang stag rnams dang / / wa la sogs dang 'grogs 'gyur bas/ / ngas ni byams pas gnas pa la/ / rtag par rnam pa kun du smad/ /
I have forbidden [meat] in every way For those who abide in lovingkindness And live together in one place With lions, tigers, deer, and so on.[lxiv]
thar pa'i chos dang 'gal ba'i phyir/ / mi rnams dngang bar 'gyur ba'i sha/ / de phyir bza' bar mi bya ste/ / 'di ni 'phags pa'i rgyal mtshan no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
Therefore, you shouldn’t eat meat Which causes agitation[lxv] among people And opposes the qualities that lead to freedom. Indeed, this is the flag of the Noble Ones.

ye shes ldan gyi le'u las/ sha za ba gang 'byung ba de ni don chen por bsgrub pa'i phyir nyes pa med de/ de las 'di skad du/ dge slong 'di ni 'chi ba'i dus bgyis na/ / 'dzam bu'i gling du ting 'dzin sgra yang ni/ / sems can rnams la rtag tu nub par 'gyur/ / 'dis gsos pas ni ting 'dzin rnams kyang thob/ / ces gsungs so/ /

On the other hand, meat-eating is discussed in the chapter on Jñānavatī,[15] [which teaches that] if it leads to a great benefit, there is no problem. For the text says this: If this monk had died, Even the word “meditative absorption” [would have disappeared] From India, and sentient beings would have gone into continual decline. By nourishing himself with this [meat,] he has attained meditative absorption.[lxvi]
de ni snying rje chen po la mngon par brtson pa ste/ de la byams pa med du mi dogs pas nyes pa med do/ /
[135] He is manifestly intent on great compassion. Also, there is no doubt that he possesses lovingkindness. So there is no problem.
