'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las/ dur khrod pas sha dang 'bags pa med par bya'o zhes gsungs pa gang yin pa de ni de las gzhan pa'i rang bzhin can gyi sems can gyi don du bstan pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dul ba las de la rnam pa gsum yongs su dag pa zos na spang ba'i bar chad du mi 'gyur ro zhes gang gnang ba de ni yongs su spangs pas dag par lta ba rnams kyis mngon pa'i nga rgyal bsal ba dang / skal ba yod kyang de la chags pas bstan pa la 'jug mi nus pa spang ba'i phyir ro/ / de skad du lang kar gshegs pa'i mdo las kyang /

The noble Cloud of Jewels says, “A charnel-ground practitioner should eat meat and be free from pollution.”[lxvii] Such a practitioner’s nature is different; the purpose is to benefit sentient beings. Also, in the monastic code, the permission that says “if one eats meat that is pure in the three respects, no obstacle that needs to be abandoned will arise,” the intention is to get rid of the arrogance of those attached to false views about purity, and also so that those who are worthy, but are attached to meat, will be able to enter the religious life. For the Sūtra on Entering Laṅka says,

bstan pa brjod pa de dang de las bslab pa'i gzhi rim par bca' ba skas kyi gdang bu bre ba'i tshul du rnam pa gsum bcas nas de'i ched du byas pa rnams kyang bkag ste/ de nas tha na rang shi ba bcu'i sha yang bkag go zhes gsungs so/ / rtag tu ba'i sman bshad zin to/ / na ba'i gsos sman yang brjod par bya ba nyid do/ / bdag gi don dang tshangs par spyod pa gnas par bya ba'i phyir nyan thos kyi 'dul ba las kyang / lhung bzed dang chos gos kyang btsongs la lus bsrung bar gsungs na/ skye bo dpag tu med pa yongs su bskyab pa'i rgyu byang chub sems dpa'i lus lta ci smos te/ dal ba'i dga' ba phun sum tshogs pa 'di lta bu ni rnyed par dka'o/ / de rab tu bstan pa'i phyir/ bcom ldan 'das kyis de dang der bdag nyid sman la nye bar sbyor bar bstan to/ /

When the teachings were given, the training precepts were put in place gradually, like the steps of a staircase.[lxviii] At first, meat that was [impure in one of] the three respects was forbidden. Later on, eating the ten types of meat, even from animals that have died naturally, was forbidden. Everyday medicine has been explained. Medicine to heal the sick remains to be discussed. In the monastic code of the Disciples, for the sake of the celibate life and for the practitioner’s own benefit, it is permitted to sell one’s begging-bowl and monastic robe if this is necessary to sustain the body. How much more would this be so for the body of a bodhisattva, and for the sake of saving innumerable people! A favorable moment to practice, complete with all the resources and opportunities, is difficult to find. And in order to demonstrate this, the Blessed One himself appeared to take medicine.

'phags pa dkon mchog sprin gyi mdo las kyang / de nam tshod bzung bar gyur pa de'i tshe/ nyi tshod yod dam med kyang rung ste/ de dag gi lus gso ba'i yo byad 'di lta ste/ mar ram/ 'bru mar ram/ sbrang rtsi'am/ bu ram mam/ rtsi'i khu ba 'am/ sdong po'i khu ba 'am/ 'bras bu'i khu ba de lta bu dag bzar mi rung ste/ gzhan za ba mthong na yang khong khro ba'i sems dang 'jungs pa'i sems kyang mi bskyed do/ / yang gal te zas phyis mi len pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de ji lta bu'i nad kyis srog gi bar chad du 'gyur ba 'am/ dge ba'i phyogs kyi bar chad du 'gyur te/ nad tshabs che na des 'gyod pa med cing the tshom med par byas la des sman yin par sems nye bar bzhag ste sbyang bar bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Cloud of Jewels Sūtra says, [136] When it is not the right time,[lxix] whether or not foods to sustain their bodies are available, such as butter, vegetable oil, root extracts, stalk extracts, or fruit extracts,[lxx] it is not appropriate for them to eat such foods; and if they see others eating them, they should have no thoughts of anger or covetousness. But on the other hand, if a bodhisattva should become ill in the afternoon, after having eaten the one daily meal, in such a way that the sickness becomes a threat to life or an obstacle to what is wholesome, then without any remorse, and without any doubt, having firmly established the thought “This is medicine,” the bodhisattva should eat, on a case-by-case basis.

gos kyi longs spyod kyi sbyor ba ni drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i mdo las bstan te/ ngo tsha zhing 'dzem pas khrel yod pas dkri ba dang / sha sbrang dang sbrang bu dang rlung dang nyi ma dang sdig sbrul gyis reg par 'gyur ba g.yogs pa dang / dge sbyong gi rtags brtan pa dang / ngur smrig de dag ni lha dang mi dang lha ma yin du bcas pa'i 'jig rten gyi mchod rten no snyam nas mchod rten gyi phyir yang dag par gzung bar bya ba dang / de dag ni yid byung ba dang 'dod chags dang bral bas kha dog bsgyur ba yin gyi/ 'dod chags kyis kha dog bsgyur ba ma yin pa dang / 'di dag ni nye bar zhi ba dang mthun pa yin gyi nyon mongs pa 'bar ba dang mthun pa ma yin pa dang / ngur smig 'di dag gis dkris shing g.yogs nas sdig pa las ldog par bya ba dang / legs par bya ba'i las bya ba dang / chos gos kyis cha sbyor ba la brtson pa ma yin pa dang / ngur smrig 'di dag 'phags pa'i lam gyi tshogs dang mthun pa yin par shes nas skad cig gcig la yang rnyog pa dang 'grogs par mi bya bar ngur smrig rnams bcang bar bya ba ste zhes gsungs so/ /

The Inquiry of Ugra has this to say about wearing and using clothes: Clothes should be worn out of a sense of decency, and to avoid embarrassment; in order to conceal the private parts; {to protect against flies, flying insects, wind, sun, scorpions, and snakes}; and to show the mark of a religious wanderer. Knowing that these robes are a holy shrine to the world, including the gods, humans, and titans, one should wear them correctly, intending them to be a holy shrine. They are dyed with liberation and freedom from desire, not with attraction.[lxxi] They are conducive to peace of mind, not to stimulating emotional reactions. By wearing these robes, we will become people who have turned away from vile actions and people who do good deeds, not people who put a lot of effort into decorating their robes. Since we know that these robes are conducive to gathering the equipment for the noble Path, we will act in such a way that, as we wear these robes, we will not be impure even for one moment.

'di la chad pa ni rin po che'i phung po'i mdo las/ 'od srungs gang dag lhod cing yang dag par mi sdom pa dang dge sbyong gi yon tan gyi chos 'di dag las nyams pa lus la ngur smrig dag 'chang ba rnams ni de la gus pa mi skyed do/ / 'od srungs de la dge sbyong gi kha dog dang gzugs can la gnod pa byed pa zhes bya ba'i nyi tshe ba'i sems can dmyal ba yod do/ / 'od srungs nyi tshe ba'i sems can dmyal ba der dge sbyong gi gzugs su gyur bzhin du gos 'bar ba dag dang mgo 'bar ba dag dang lhung bzed 'bar ba dag dang stan 'bar ba dag dang mal cha 'bar ba dag gnod pa byed de/ de dag gi longs spyod dang yongs su spyad pa gang ci yod pa de thams cad 'bar rab tu 'bar te kun tu rab tu mched cing 'bar la de me lce gcig tu gyur te/ dge sbyong gi kha dog dang gzugs kyis gnod pa de dag myong bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

On this topic, the Multitude of Jewels Sūtra states, [137] Kāśyapa, some people wear the monastic robes on their bodies, but due to pride they are undisciplined,[lxxiii] and they ignore the qualities and abilities that a religious wanderer should have, so that no one respects them. For them, Kāśyapa, there is an ephemeral hell called “Counterfeit Religious Wanderer.”[lxxiv] Kāśyapa, those who counterfeit the appearance of religious wanderers create the causes for the burning clothes, burning begging-bowls, burning seats, and burning beds[lxxv] in that hell. Whatever luxuries and comforts they have there are burning, blazing, one single flame. There, those counterfeit religious wanderers experience painful sensations.

'phags pa dkon mchog sprin gyi mdo las kyang / byang chub sems dpa' bla gab med pa la lus na'am lus kyis mi nus par gyur na des gtsug lag khang du gnas te/ 'di snyam du nyon mongs pa'i gnyen po'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa'i sbyangs pa'i yon tan bcas te ci nas kyang bdag gtsug lag khang na gnas bzhin du nyon mongs pa rnams spong bar 'dod pa ste de ltar bya ste/ gtsug lag khang de la yang chags pa mi skyed de zhen par mi bya'o snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de 'di ltar sems te sbyin pa'i bdag po rnams la phan gdags par bya'i bdag cag gis bdag nyid gso bar ni mi bya'o snyam mo zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Cloud of Jewels Sūtra also says, If a bodhisattva living in the open air should become too sick or weak of body to continue doing so, he should live in a monastery, and should think this: “The Tathāgata established the intense practices[16] as a remedy for reactive emotions. I shall act in such a way that, while living in a monastery, I will make an effort to leave reactive emotions behind. And I will arouse no attraction for that monastery, nor any clinging.” And he should think, “We should do this in order to benefit the donors, not in order to nourish ourselves.”[lxxvi]

yang de nyid las/ de dag nyal ba na glo g.yas pas nyal bar byed de rkang pa'i steng du rkang pa bzhag nas/ lus chos gos dag gis shin tu g.yogs shing / dran pa dang shes bzhin dang ldan bzhin du snang ba'i 'du shes dang ldang ba'i 'du shes su nyal bar byed de gnyid kyi bde ba la chags par mi byed do/ / snyes pa'i bde ba la yang ma chags te/ gzhan du na de dag ji tsam du 'byung ba chen po rnams gnas shing 'tsho ba'i phyir nyal bar byed la rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad pa yang dge ba'i phyogs la mngon du phyogs pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ / phyogs 'dis yongs su spyad pa thams cad sems can gyi don du byin gyis brlab par bya ste/ des na/

The same text says, While lying in bed, they lie on their right sides, with one foot placed on top of the other, with their bodies properly covered with their monastic robes, mindful and aware, knowing when to get up and when it will be light.[lxxvii] They should not be attached to the pleasure of lying down or the pleasure of sleep, but should seek only to rest and refresh the physical body. By lying in this orientation, {they should not break the continuity of practice and} should joyfully promote the welfare of sentient beings.
bdag la sred pas longs spyad na/ / nyon mongs bcas pa'i ltung bar 'gyur/ /
[13c-d] But if it is done to indulge your own craving, it is a downfall induced by reactivity.

zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las ji skad du/ / de dag kha zas ro zhim bsod pa dag / rnyed nas rnal 'byor mi brtson za zhing 'thung / / de dag la ni zas de gdug par 'gyur/ / ba lang phru gus pad rtsa ma bkrus bzhin/ / zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says[lxxviii], When they get delicious, good-quality foods, they make no effort at spiritual practice, but eat.[lxxix] That food becomes harmful to them, like unwashed lotus-root to a calf.[lxxx]

'phags pa rin po che'i phung po'i mdo las kyang / / bcom ldan 'das kyis dad pas byin pa yongs su spyod pa yongs su bstan pa dang / de nas 'khor de nyid nas rnal 'byor spyod pa'i dge slong nyis brgyas chos kyi rnam grangs 'di thos nas rab tu ngus te mchi ma zag cing tshig 'di skad ces bcom ldan 'das bdag cag ni gum yang rung ste 'bras bu ma thob kyi bar du dad pas stsal ba'i bsod snyoms cig tsam yang yongs su spyad par mi bgyi'o zhes smras so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ skyes bu dam pa dag legs so legs so/ / ngo tsha shes pa dang 'gyod pa dang ldan pa dang 'jig rten pha rol du kha na ma tho bas 'jigs par lta ba rnam pa 'di lta bu dag gis gsung rab 'di mdzes so/ / 'od srungs ngas dge slong gnyis la dad pas byin pa gnang ste/ gnyis gang zhe na/ ldan pa dang grol ba'o/ / dge slong dag dge slong ldan pa rnal 'byor spyod pa nga'i bstan pa la zhugs pa 'du byed thams cad mi rtag par mthong / 'du byed thams cad sdug bsngal bar rig / chos thams cad la bdag med par mos/ mya ngan las 'das pa zhi bar rtogs pas ni ri rab tsam gyi khams dag gis dad pas byin pa yongs su spyad kyang de'i yon tan shin tu yongs su dag par 'gyur ro/ /

Also, in the noble Multitude of Jewels Sūtra, the Blessed One taught about eating the gifts of the faithful: [138] Now in that very assembly, two hundred spiritual practitioner monks wept when they heard this Dharma discourse, and they said: “Blessed One, we may die, but until we attain the fruits of practice, we will not eat even one morsel of alms-food that is a gift of the faithful.” The Blessed One said, “Good, good, gentlemen! These words are appropriate for those who feel shame and remorse, and who see fear in the next world due to reprehensible actions. On the other hand, Kāśyapa, I allow the gifts of the faithful to two kinds of monks. Which two? The one who is practicing and the one who is free. Monks, if a monk who practices, is a spiritual practitioner, carries out my training, sees all conditioned things as impermanent, knows the suffering in all conditioned things, has confidence that there is no self in anything, and longs for[lxxxi] the peace of Nirvāṇa,[17] should eat an amount of gifts of the faithful the size of Mt. Meru, that [action] is completely pure and worthy of reverence.

sbyin pa po dang sbyin bdag gang dag las dad pas byin pa yongs su spyad pa de las de dag gi bsod nams kyi rnam par smin pa 'byor pa chen po dang phan yon chen por 'gyur ro/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ dge slong dag rdzas las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po rnams las gang byams pa'i sems la snyoms par 'jug pa de mchog yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'od srungs dge slong gang zhig sbyin pa po dang sbyin bdag gi chos gos dang bsod snyoms dang mal cha dang yo byad rnams yongs su spyad nas sems rnam par grol ba tshad med pa la snyoms par 'jug na sbyin pa po dang sbyin bdag de'i rnam par smin pa yang tshad med par shes par bya'o/ / 'od srungs stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams na yod pa'i rgya mtsho chen po rnams ni yongs su zad par 'gyur yang srid kyi de'i bsod nams kyi rgyu mthun pa ni yongs su zad par gang yang mi 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

And for those donors and patrons whose gifts are eaten, there is a great prize, a vast amount of goodness that results from the evolution of that. Why is this? Because, of all the bases for goodness that consist of material things, the highest are those which [support someone in] attaining the mind of lovingkindness. Kāśyapa, when a monk obtains robes, alms-food, {beds, and other necessities} from a donor, a patron, and after consuming them, attains immeasurable mental freedom,[lxxxi] for that donor, that patron, an immeasurable result of evolution of goodness may be expected. Kāśyapa, it is possible that all the great oceans in the three-million-fold world-realm might dry up, but the flow of goodness from that action could never dry up.”

de ltar bsod snyoms la 'gro bar rtsom mam/ zas za bar rtsom pa dang / sbyin pa po la phan gdags pa dang / lus kyi srin bu bsdu ba dang / sems can thams cad kyi don grub pa ste gnas gsum la dran pa nye bar gzhag nas/ dam pa'i chos yongs su gzung ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i bka' bsgrub pa dang / bya ba thams cad la dran pa dang ldan par bya'o/ / sogs pa zhes bya ba ni gsang sngags rnams kyis kyang yongs su bsrung bar bya'o/ / de la thog mar re zhig dkyil 'khor dang dam tshig gi phyir/ dam tshig gsum gyi rgyal po las 'byung ba'i rig sngags 'di brjod par bya'o/ /

In this way, when starting out on alms-round and when beginning a meal, you should apply mindfulness to three topics: the benefit to the donors, the community of worms in the body, and bringing about benefits to all sentient beings. You should uphold the holy Dharma, fulfill the instructions of the Tathāgatas, and be mindful in everything you do.[lxxxii] [139] And you should carry out protection using mantras. In this case, for the benefit of the assembly of the maṇḍala, you should recite the awareness formula stated in the Rulers of the Three Sacred Commitments (Tri-samaya-rāja.) It is:

na ma sarba bud d+ha bo d+hi sa twA nAM/ oM bi ra dzi bi ra dzi/ ma hA badzri/ sa ta sa ta/ sA ra te sA ra te/ tra yi tra yi/ bi d+ha ma ni/ saM b+hany+dza ni/ ha ra ma ti/ sid d+ha a gre traM swA hA/
namaḥ sarva-buddha-bodhisattvānām[18] oṃ viraji viraji mahācakra-viraji sata sata sārata sārata trapi trapi vidhamani sabhajani saṃbhajani taramati siddha agre tvaṃ svāhā.[19]

'dis dkyil 'khor thams cad du zhugs par 'gyur ro/ / yang na de bzhin gshegs pa'i snying po brgya stong bzlas na 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dkyil 'khor thams cad du zhugs par 'gyur ro/ / de gang zhe na/

Through this [mantra], you are introduced into all the maṇḍalas.[20] Alternately, you should recite the Heart of the Tathāgata eight thousand times, so as to be introduced into all worldly and transcendent maṇḍalas. And what is that?

na ma s+t+rai ya d+h+wi kA nAM ta thA ga tA nAM/ sarba tra a pra ti ha tA bA p+ti d+harma tA ba li nAM/ aM aHsa ma sa ma/ sa man+ta to& nan+ta tA bAb+ti shA sa ni/ ha ra ha ra/ sma ra sma ra Na/ bi ga ta/ rA ga bud d+ha d+harma te/ sa ra sa ra/ sa ma ba lA/ ha sa ha sa/ tra ya tra ya/ ga ga na ma hA ba ra lak+Sha Ne/ dz+wa la dz+wa la na sA ga re swA hA/

namas-traiyadhvikānāṃ[lxxxiii] tathāgatānāṃ sarvatra-apratihata-avāpti- dharmatā-balinām[21] oṃ asamasama samantato’nantana-avāpti-śāsani hara hara smara smaraṇa vigata-rāga-buddha-dharmate sara sara samabalā hasa hasa traya traya gagana mahācala-rakṣaṇa jvala jvalana sāgare svāhā.
'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku yin te 'di la gus pa bla na med par bya'o/ / 'dis las dang po pa dag kyang sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi mdzad pa mtha' yas pa byed par 'gyur ro/ /
This [mantra] is the body of all the Tathāgatas. One should develop the highest respect for it. Through it, even beginners perform limitless Buddha deeds for sentient beings.

'di nyid bdud la sogs pa dang ma rungs pa thams cad las srung bar byed pa'i mchog yin no/ / thal mo brdabs pa 'am/ thal ba 'am/ yungs kar ram/ chu'am/ lta ba'am/ yid kyis kyang mtshams gcod par byed do/ / nad kyis btab na sman nam chu la sngags kyis btab ste btung ngo / / yang na mchod rten nam sku gzugs sam dam pa'i chos kyi glegs bam la nags kyi me tog sems mnyam par gzhag ste 'bul zhing zla ba phyed sbyor ba byas na nad chen po dag las thar bar 'gyur ro/ / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la dmigs pa dang sems can thams cad la dmigs pa dang sems can thams cad kyi don bya bar 'dod pa'i sems kyis bzang po'i spyod pa mngon du bya bas bzlas brjod bya'o/ / cho ga 'di ni cho ga 'di'i mjug nas 'byung ngo / / dam tshig gsum gyi bzlas brjod byed pas ni khrus ma byas kyang nyes pa med do/ / lhag ma dang mi gtsang bas kyang nyes pa med do/ / phyag rgya 'dra ba dag mi bza'o mi bgom mo khri la nyal bar mi bya'o/ / chang mi btung ngo / / mos pas spyod pa'i bslab pa'i gzhi dag las mi g.yo ba dang the tshom med na sngon dang tshul ngan par gyur kyang 'grub bo/ / mkhas sam mi mkhas kyang rung ste nges par 'grub bo/ /

[140] This [mantra] gives the highest degree of protection from Māra and from all other hostile forces. With blows of the hand, or with ashes, with mustard seed, with water, with the gaze, or with the mind, you define the ritual boundaries. Someone who is sick should drink medicine or water that has been consecrated with mantras. Alternately, that person should rest attention in meditation on a holy shrine, an image,[lxxxv] or a book of the holy Dharma. If this is done for two weeks, such a person will be set free even from grave illnesses. Reflecting on all Buddhas and bodhisattvas, wishing for the welfare of all sentient beings, and doing good deeds, you should repeat the previous formula. The following is the conclusion of the ritual. According to tradition, you should recite the three sacred commitments; if you don’t {bathe,} there is no problem. Even if what is left over is not pure, there is no problem. Don’t eat using the hand gestures; don’t look at them in order to evaluate them; don’t sit on a high seat; don’t become intoxicated. If you are immovable in the training precepts, your religious commitment and your way of life, and free from doubt, then even if you were immoral before, you will get results. Whether you are educated or not, you will definitely get results.
de skad du de nyid las/ / gang zhig byang chub sems brtan zhing / / blo gros chags pa med pa dang / / the tshom dag kyang mi byed pa/ / des 'di nges par 'grub par 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
The same text says, Awakening Mind should be stable, And the mind should be unattached. Someone who has no doubts Will certainly get results.

byang chub kyi sems brten pa ni 'dir so so'i skye bo'i sems stobs dang ldan par nges par bya ba'i phyir gsungs kyi sar chud pa'i dbang du byas pa ni ma yin te/ 'di ltar de nyid las/ slar dbyung bar bya ba dang / snang bar bya ba thob par 'dod pa dang / mun pa chen po'i khrod nas snang bar 'jug par 'dod pa dang / log par ltung bas lhag par bsgrub par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / de bzhin du bdag lta bu bsod nams chung ngu la 'grub par ga la 'gyur zhes sems zhum pa bkag go/ / sa la gnas pa ngan 'gro las shin tu 'das pa spro ba'i rlabs mang ba bsod nams kyi phung po dpag tu med pa bstsags pa la ni gong du smos pa'i nyes pa nyid mi srid do/ / 'di la ma shes nas sngags rnams yi ge lhag par brjod kyang nyes pa med do/ / nyungs kyang nyes par mi 'gyur ro/ / cho ga nyams kyang nyes par mi 'gyur ro/ / 'on kyang dad pa'i shugs dang byang chub kyi sems kyi shugs dang / rang gi don dor ba'i shugs brtsan par bya ste/ rnam par mi rtog par brjod na gdon mi za bar tshe 'di nyid la byang chub sems dpa' mthong ba dang ci 'dod pa yang 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / yang na rdo rje 'dzin thams cad kyi sngags 'dis bsrung bar bya'o/ /

na ma s+t+rai ya d+h+wi kA nAM/ ta thA ga tA nAM/ sarba badzra d+ha rA nAM/ oM tsa Na ra la tsa Na ra la/ ba la ba la/ badzra badzra shAn+ta ne shAn+ta ne/ pha la na pha la na/ ba ra ba ra/ mA ra mA ra/ badzra d+ha la/ s+phu Ta s+phu Ta/ la li ta shi kha ra/ sa man+ta badzrI Ni/ dz+wa la ne dz+wa la ne/ na mo stu ste/ a gro&gra shA sA kA nAM/ ra Na ra Na/ hUM hUM s+pho Ta s+pho Ta badzrot+ta me swA hA/

namas-trayadhvikānāṃ tathāgatānāṃ sarvavajradharāṇāṃ[22] caṇḍāla caṇḍāla cala cala vajra vajra śāntana śāntana phalana phalana cara cara māraṇa māraṇa vajradā laphaṭ lalita-śikhara samanta-vajriṇi jvala jvala namo’stu te agra-ugra-śāsanānām raṇaṃ raṇaṃ haṃ phula sphāṭa vajrottame svāhā.

'di bton pa tsam gyis bgegs dang / rnam par log 'dren thams cad mi 'ong ngo / / lha dang klu la sogs pa thams cad kyis mi bzod do/ / bza' ba dang btung ba dang mal cha dang mchod pa'i yo byad rnams kyang sngags chu'am/ blta ba'am yid kyis bsrung ngo / / yang na mi g.yo ba'i snying pos de thams cad bya'o/ / de ni 'di yin te/

[141] If you simply repeat this, all obstructing spirits and false guides[lxxxvi] do not approach. Gods, serpent spirits, and so on will not overpower you. You should protect your food, drink, beds and seats, clothes,[lxxxvii] and ritual offerings with mantra-consecrated water, the gaze, or the mind. Alternately, do all this with the essence mantra of Acala, which is:
na maHsa man+ta badzra NAM traT/ a mo g+ha tsaN+Da/ ma hA ro Sha Na s+pho Ta ya/ hUM b+h+ra ma ya b+h+ra ma ya/ hUM traT/ hAM mAM oM ba lan+da de te dzo ma li ni swA hA/

'dis kham dang po la lan brgyad bsngags la sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi sman gyi rgyal po nyid du bsams te bza'o/ / dug gzhil ba ni 'di lta ste/
Before you eat your first morsel of food, recite this eight times, and remember the Buddhas, the bodhisattvas, and Bhaiṣajyarāja. The Antidote to Poisons is as follows:

i li mit+te/ ti li mit+te/ i li mi li mit+te/ ti li mi li mit+te/ dum be dum be/ du bA lI/ du ma he/ dus+se/ tak+ke/ tak+ka ra Ne/ ma ma meM ma ma ma ra Ne/ kaSh+mI ra/ muk+te/ i li ti li me/ a g+ha ne/ A g+ha nA g+ha ne/ i li i li ye/ mi li mi lI ye/ a ga i ya/ a a i yi/ shwe te/ shwe te tuN+De/ a nA nu rak+te/ a ru ruk+ke/ trAM oM/ bi sha ni ke ta ni swA hA/
ilimitte tilimitte ilitilimitte dumbe duḥse duḥsālīye dumbālīye takke tarkkaraṇe marmme marmaraṇe kaśmīre kaśmīra-mukte aghane aghanaghane ilimilīye akhāpye apāpye śvete śvetatuṇḍe anānurakṣe svāhā.

gang zhig rig sngags 'di lan cig thos pas kyang de la sbrul gyis mi za'o/ / de'i lus la dug gis mi tshugs so/ / sbrul gang de la za ba de'i mgo ardza ka'i dog pa bzhin du tshal pa bdun du 'gas so/ / su rig sngags 'di 'chang ba de la ji srid 'tsho'i bar du sbrul gyis mi za'o/ / de'i lus la dug gis mi tshugs so/ / gsang sngags kyi tshig 'di dag sbrul gyi mdun du gdon par mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sbrul 'chi bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / 'di lta ste/

Those who hear this awareness formula even once will not be bitten by snakes for seven years. No poison can harm their bodies. And if a snake were to bite them, the snake’s head would split into seven pieces, like the seed-pod of the Arjaka plant. Those who recite this awareness formula are not bitten by snakes as long as they live. No poison can harm their bodies. And you shouldn’t say these mantra words in the presence of a snake, because the snake would die. It is:

i la la/ tsi la la/ tsak+ko bAk+ko/ ko DA/ ko DI ti/ ku ra DA/ ku ra DI ti/ po DA/ po DI ti/ pu ru dA/ pu ru DA+e ti/ mo TA/ mo DI te/ ni ku ru DA/ ni ku ru DA ti/ mu ru DA/ mu ru DI ti/ nim mu ru DA/ nim mu ru DI ti/ phu ru De/ phuT+Ta ra he/ phuT+Ta ra he/ phuT+Ta d+dan+ta ra he/ phuT+Ta d+dan+ta ra he/ na ga ra he/ na ga TaT+Tan+da ha re/ sarba ha re/ sarba ta TaT+Tan+da ha re/ ats+tshe/ ats+tshe/ ats+tsha le/ tsha la bi Shi/ shI te shI ta/ bat+tA le/ mA tA le/ ha le ha le/ ha la ha la/ ha la le/ i la le/ ke pa tsa le/ mi la le/ dan+ti dan+ti/ ta Ta ta Ta/ s+phu Ta s+phu Ta/ phaT phaT swA hA/

[142] illā cillā cakko bakvo koḍā koḍeti nikuruḍā nikuruḍeti poḍā poḍeti moḍā moḍeti puruḍā puruḍeti phaṭa rahe phuṭaṭaṇḍa rahe nāga rahe nāga-ṭaṭaṇḍa rahe sarpa rahe sarpa-ṭaṭaṇḍa rahe acche chala viṣaśāte śītavat-tāle halale halale taṇḍi taṇḍi taḍa taḍa tāḍi tāḍi mala mala sphuṭa sphuṭa phuṭu phuṭu svāhā.

dge slong dag de ltar na dug sel gyis 'byung po 'dus pa thams cad la rig sngags brjod pa de dag thams cad ni de bzhin no/ / gzhan ma yin pa de bzhin no/ / yang dag pa'o/ / bden pa'o/ / ma nor ba'o/ / phyin ci ma log pa'o/ /

Monks, in this way, the awareness formula {that clears away} poison is spoken to the whole assembly of spirits.[lxxxviii] It is true, not false, accurate, not inaccurate, not a lie, not deceptive. It is:
idaṃ viṣam-aviṣaṃ bhavatu dātāraṃ gacchatu daṃṣṭāraṃ gacchatu agniṃ gacchatu jalaṃ gacchatu sthalaṃ gacchatu stambhaṃ gacchatu kuḍyaṃ gacchatu bhūmiṃ saṃkrāmatu śāntiṃ gacchatu svāhā.[23]

dug 'di mi 'dug par gyur cig / sbyin par byed pa'i gan du song shig / 'dzin pa'i gan du song shig / me'i nang du song shig / chu'i nang du song shig / thang la song shig / ka ba'i nang du song shig / rtsig pa'i nang du song shig / nam mkha' la song shig / sa'i nang du song shig / zhi bar gyur cig swA hA/

May this poison not be poisonous. May it go to the giver! May it go to the fang! May it go into the fire! May it go into the water! May it go into the open plain! May it go into a pillar! May it go into a wall! {May it go into the sky!} May it go into the earth! May it be pacified! Amen.
rkun po la sogs pa bzlog pa'i phyir 'od zer can bzlas par bya'o/ /
In order to turn back thieves and so on, you should repeat the Mārīcī, which reads:
pad+mA kra ma si/ pa rA kra ma si/ a pa rA kra ma si/ u da ma si/ na da ma si/ ni re ma si/ arka ma si/ orma si/ ba na ma si/ gul+ma ma si/ tsai ba ra ma si/ An+ta ra d+ha na ma si
parākramasi udayamasi vairamasi arkamasi markamasi vanamasi antardhānamasi
* swA hA/

pathe me rakṣa utpathe me rakṣa janato me rakṣa caurato me rakṣa rājato me rakṣa siṃhato me rakṣa vyāghrato me rakṣa nāgato me rakṣa sarpato me rakṣa sarvato me rakṣa rakṣa rakṣa māṃ sarvasattvāṃś-ca sarvabhayebhyaḥ sarvopāye sopasargebhyaḥ svāhā.[24] auṃ-śvaḍili auṃ-śvaḍili sarvaduṣṭānāṃ granthiṃ vandāmi svāhā.

lha mo 'od zer can bdag lam du skyobs shig / lam log pa las skyobs shig / bdag skye bo'i 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag rgyal po'i 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag rkun po'i 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag klu'i 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag glang po'i 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag seng ge'i 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag stag gi 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag sbrul gyi 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag me'i 'jigs pa las skyobs shig / bdag phyir rgol ba dang grogs po ngan pa thams cad las skyobs shig / 'khrugs pa dang ma 'khrugs pa dang / nyams pa dang ma nyams pa dag tu yang bdag la srungs shig / bdag la srungs shig srungs shig /

Protect me on the path. Protect me from wrong paths. Protect me from humans. Protect me from thieves. Protect me from kings. Protect me from lions. Protect me from tigers. Protect me from serpent-spirits [or elephants?]. Protect me from snakes. Protect me from everything. Protect, protect me, and all sentient beings, from all dangers and from all harms, using all means, amen.
'di lta ste/ A lo/ /ta lo/ /ka lo/ /ko li/ ats+tshin+te/ tats+tshit+te/ bdag la 'tshe ba dang 'jigs pa dang / nad thams cad las srungs shig srungs shig swA hA/
dkon mchog gsum la phyag 'tshal lo/ / lha mo 'od zer can la phyag 'tshal lo/ / lha mo 'od zer can gyi snying po brjod par bya'o/ / 'di lta ste/
Homage to the Three Jewels. Homage to Goddess Mārīcī. I recite the essence mantra of Goddess Mārīcī, which is:[lxxxix]

oM bat+tA li/ ba rA li/ ba rA ha mu khi/ sarba duSh+TA na/ ni bA rA ya/ ban d+ha ban d+ha/ ban d+ha mu khi/ dzam+b+ha ya/ staM b+ha ya/ mo ha ya swA hA/ oM mA rI ts+yai swA hA/ oM ba ra le/ ba da le/ ba rA ha mu khi/ sarba duSh+TA na/ ban d+ha ban d+ha swA hA/
battāli badāli badāli barāli varāha-mukhi sarvaduṣṭānāṃ nivāraya bandha-mukhaṃ svāhā.

'jigs pa thams cad las bsrung ba'i phyir rig sngags 'chang ba'i sde snod las 'byung ba'i rig sngags tshe rabs mtha' yas pa dran par 'gyur ba'i rgyu mthu che ba yi ge lnga bcu rtsa bdun po 'di la yang sbyar bar bya'o/ / 'di lta ste/

You should also use this fifty-seven syllable[xc] awareness formula of great power, found in the scriptural collection of the awareness holders,[25] the cause of remembering an unlimited number of past lives, in order to provide protection against all dangers. It is:

aT+Te/ baT+Te/ naT+Te ku naT+Te/ Ta ke Tha ke/ Tha ra ke Tha ke/ u ru ma ti/ ru ru ma ti/ tu ru hi li mi li/ sarba nya tsa bi pa dag+ga/ na mo saM/ pa saM ma saM bud d+hA NAM/ sid d+han+tu me man+t+ra pa daiHswA hA/
aṭṭe baṭṭe naṭṭe kunaṭṭe ṭake ṭhake ṭharake urumati rurumati turuhili mili sarvajñodupadagga namo sabbasammasaṃbuddhāṇaṃ[26] sajjñantu me mantapadāḥ svāhā.
'di ni bdag lus bsrung ba ste/ sman dang gos la sogs bcas pas kyang / sems can gyi don byed pa'i dran pa sngar byas la bya'o/ /
[143] This is said to be the protection of the body by means of medicines, clothes, and so on. It must be done only after being mindful of the welfare of all sentient beings.
bdag la srid pas longs spyod na/ / nyon mongs bcas pa'i ltung bar 'gyur/ /
[13c-d] But if it is done to indulge your own craving, It is a downfall induced by reactivity.

zhes bya ba la/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad sems can thams cad la gtang ba de la/ gal te brjed nas gzhan gyi rdzas bdag gso ba'i sred pas spyad na nyon mongs pa can gyi ltung bar 'gyur ro/ / ji ste sred pa ni med la gzhan la chags sam sems can gyi bya ba brjed nas spyod na nyon mongs pa can ma yin pa'i ltung bar 'gyur ro/ / gzhan gyi rdzas su 'du shes la bdag gi phyir spyod na brkus pa'i ltung bar 'gyur ro/ / rin thang tshang na so sor thar pa las pham par 'gyur ro/ / bdag po dang bcas pa'i longs spyod rnams kyis bdag po dang bcas pa'i lus bsrung ngo snyam pas spyad na nyes pa med de/ bran rtag tu rje bo'i las byed pa gang gis 'tsho ba bdag gi rdzas yod pa ni ma yin no/ / chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las kyang / sems can thams cad kyi ci bya ba thob par bya ba'i phyir byang chub sems dpa' bran lta bu bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / shin tu rje bo'i don la brtson pa'i bran gyis rje bo na ba la sogs pas rmya ba'i blo can gyis gnang ba med par spyad kyang nyes pa med do/ / de ltar spyod pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i thad du 'ga' zhig gis de kho na mi rigs par ma dad par bya ba ni mi rigs te/ gtong ba'i sems ngo mtshar chen po can yongs su mi shes pa'i phyir ro/ / tshul 'di la ni 'ga' zhig gis the tshom bya bar mi rigs so/ / thams cad gtang ba ni bcom ldan 'das kyi zhal nas gsungs pas gong du bshad pa yin no/ / de ltar na lus bsrung ba ni sems can gyi don nyid du bstan pa de/ gsal bar rtogs par bya ba'i phyir rigs pa 'di gsal bar byas su zad kyi rang dgar byas pa ni ma yin no/ /

Whatever a bodhisattva uses is all for the sake of sentient beings. If you, forgetfully and out of craving, consume the property of others in order to support yourself, you undergo a downfall induced by reactivity. If you do so free from craving, or out of attachment to others, mindful of what needs to be done for sentient beings, you do not undergo a downfall induced by reactivity.[xci] If you consume what you believe to be the property of others for your own benefit, you undergo the downfall of stealing. If the value of the goods exceeds the stated threshold,[xcii] in the Vows of Individual Liberation, you are defeated. But if, as a servant of sentient beings, you simply protect your body with the property of your masters, sentient beings, there is no problem. For it is not always the case that a servant doing work for his master owns the property with which he works. And the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together says, “A bodhisattva should be like a servant, doing whatever needs to be done for all sentient beings.” And if a servant who is totally focused on benefiting the master, but is afflicted by illness and so on,[xciii] should eat even without informing the master, there is no problem. And if you find out about any incident in which a bodhisattva has acted in this way, it is not reasonable for you to mistrust that person, because you do not know whether [that bodhisattva] has given up thoughts of greed.[xciv] Nor is it reasonable to have any doubts about this line of argument, for the Blessed One himself has proclaimed the renunciation of everything. And protecting the body in this way is said to be only for the benefit of sentient beings. This line of argument is given only in order to clarify this point, and not with a view to your own welfare.

f.d: [longs spyod dang bsod nams bsrung ba]
7. Protecting Possessions and Goodness
de ltar re zhig lus bsrung bar rig par bya'o/ / longs spyod bsrung ba brjod par bya'o/ / zhes bya ba ste/
PROTECTING THE BODY should be understood in the manner just explained. But protecting possessions remains to be discussed. On that topic:
legs spyad dag la brtsam par bya/ / thams cad la yang tshod rig bya/ / de ltar bslab pa'i gzhi 'di las/ / de yi longs spyod bsrung mi dka'/ /
[14] For someone who does the right thing, Following the training precepts, Knowing in everything how much is enough, It is not difficult to protect possessions.

drag shul can gyis zhus pa las kyang / shin tu brtags te las byed pa dang legs par bya ba'i las byed pa zhes bslab pa'i gzhi gsungs pas longs spyod rnams bzhag nyes pa dang ma brtags pa dang g.yel ba bkag pa grub pa yin no/ / zhi gnas kyi skabs nas kyang tshod shes pa dang rigs pa shes par gsungs te/ des na gang 'di longs spyod chung ngu dang ngan pas kyang dgos pa 'grub pa lta na bdag gam gzhan dag gis kyang rung ste/ longs spyod mang po dang bzang po chud gson pa la yal bar mi dor ba de grub pa yin no/ /

[144] For the Inquiry of Ugra states this training precept: “Their actions are well thought through and well done.” In this way they overcome difficulty in giving up possessions, too much consideration for possessions, and carelessness with possessions.[i][1] After doing meditation, such a person is said to know what is appropriate and how much is enough. Therefore, it is proven that, for the small enjoyment of some misdeed, you should not destroy the greatest, highest enjoyments that result from yourself or others doing what there is to do.

de bas na drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / bu dang chung ma dang bran pho dang bran mo dang las byed pa dang zho shas 'tsho ba rnams yang dag par yongs su spyad pa zhes gsungs te/ ci nas kyang bdag dang gzhan gyi byang chub kyi phyogs dang thos pa la sogs pa'i bar chad du 'gyur ba'i gtong ba'am mi gtong ba gnyi ga mi bya'o/ / sems can gyi don la nus pa che ba'am nus pa mtshungs pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i lhag pa'am/ mtshungs pa'i dge ba'i bar chad byed pa'i gtong ba dang / mi gtong ba mi bya bar grub pa yin no/ / 'di la dgongs nas/ byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las kyang bstan te/ shA ri'i bu byang chub sems dpa'i khyim gyi gnas nas mngon par byung ba byang chub kyi yan lag la mngon par brtson pa gang yin pa des ji ltar sbyin pa sbyin par bya/ sbyin pa ji tsam zhig sbyin par bya/ sbyin pa'i rang bzhin ci 'dra ba zhig sbyin par bya/

The Inquiry of Ugra also says, “By correctly giving wealth to sons, wives, male and female servants, employees, and hired laborers.”[2] In this way, whether you have renounced possessions or not, they will not create obstacles to the study and other practices that are conducive to the Awakening of yourself and others. And if renouncing, or not renouncing, would create obstacles to the achievement of an equal or greater good[ii] by a bodhisattva of greater power to help sentient beings, or equal power, you should not do it. This is proven. In the Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas, the following was taught to the community:[iii] Śāriputra, when bodhisattvas have gone forth from the home life and are making an effort at the aspects of Awakening, how should they give gifts? Which gifts should they give? What kind of gifts should they give?
de bzhin du sbyar te/

chos sbyin pa dang chos kyi sbyin bdag tu bya'o/ / shA ri'i bu byang chub sems dpa' khyim pa gang gis sangs rgyas kyi zhing gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed dag rin po che sna bdun gyis rab tu bkang ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams la dbul ba phul ba bas/ shA ri'i bu rab tu byung bar gyur pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang zhig tshig bzhi pa'i tshigs su bcad pa gcig bstan na 'di ni de bas ches bsod nams mang du bskyed de/ shA ri'i bu de bzhin gshegs pas ni rab tu byung bas zang zing gi sbyin pa byin par ma gnang ngo / /

They should be givers of Dharma, donors of Dharma. And, Śāriputra, suppose a lay bodhisattva filled Buddha fields as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River with the seven precious substances, and gave them as gifts to the Tathāgatas, the Saints, the genuinely and fully awake Buddhas. Śāriputra, if an ordained bodhisattva should publicly proclaim one four-line verse, more goodness would flow from that. Śāriputra, the Tathāgata did not permit ordained persons to give worldly things as gifts
de bzhin du sbyar te/

shA ri'i bu/ gang gis lhung bzed du 'ongs pa lhung bzed du chud pa'i rnyed pa chos dang mthun pa chos kyis rnyed par gyur na/ des tshangs pa mtshungs par spyad pa rnams dang thun mong du bza' bar bya'o/ / gal te la la zhig 'ongs nas lhung bzed dang chos gos slong la gal te sangs rgyas kyis gnang ba'i chos gos gsum las lhag par gyur na ji ltar btang ba bzhin du sbyin par bya'o/ / gal te de la chos gos nyung bar gyur na gang la brten te/ tshangs par spyod pa la gnas pa de ni yongs su gtong bar mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pas chos gos gsum gtang bar mi bya'o zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / shA ri'i bu gal te byang chub sems dpas chos gos gsum yongs su gtang ste/ slong ba po gtso bor byed par gyur na des 'dod pa chung ba bstan pa ma yin no/ / shA ri'i bu byang chub sems dpas gang khyim gyi gnas nas mngon par byung ba des chos la brten par bya ste/ des de la mngon par brtson par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Indeed, Śāriputra, if religious wealth, harmonious with the Dharma, were to come into someone’s begging bowl, that person should consume that in common together with his companions in the religious life. [145] Now suppose someone comes and asks him for his begging-bowl or monastic robe. If he has extra, over and above the three-piece robe permitted by the Buddha, he should give it away. On the other hand, if, [were he to give,] he would not have the robe on which his celibate life is based, he should not give it away. Why? The Tathāgata has said, “The three-piece robe should not be abandoned.” Śāriputra, if, after giving away his three-piece robe, a bodhisattva should have to focus on begging for another one, he would not be able to practice having few desires. Instead, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva who has gone forth from the home life should practice Dharma, and should be intent on that.

gzhan du na sems can gcig bsdu ba'i phyir sems can gyi tshogs chen po dang / sems can des kyang byang chub sems dpa'i bsam pa yongs su sbyar bar bya ba'i bar chad byas pas/ don chen po dmas par byas par 'gyur ro/ / de bas na dge ba'i phyogs rgya chen po rnam par spangs pas ma bsrungs pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar re zhig gtong ba bkag go/ / mi gtong ba dgag pa ni/ 'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / theg pa chen po'i bar du gcod pa'i rnyed pa mang po ji skad gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / bdag gi cho gar bstan pa gang yin pa de byang chub sems dpa' gzhan la yang bsgrub par bya'o zhes bya bar ci mngon zhe na/ 'phags pa drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i mdo las bstan pa'i phyir te/ gzhan gyi bya ba byas shing rang gi bya ba yongs su gtang bar bya'o zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / de skad du dri ma med par grags pas bstan pa'i mdo las kyang /

Otherwise, for the sake of one action that attracts someone, due to creating an obstacle to carrying out the bodhisattva’s aspirations for a great multitude of sentient beings, and for that same sentient being, a great benefit would be lost. Therefore, since a great good is being given up, this is said to be a mistake. Sometimes, giving something away is prohibited. But sometimes, not giving something away is prohibited. For example, in the noble Sāgaramati Sūtra, having a lot of wealth is mentioned among obstacles to the Great Way. But you might ask, “How could someone who has taught this rule with respect to himself establish it with respect to another bodhisattva?”[iv] Because the Inquiry of Ugra teaches, “He does what needs to be done for others, and leaves aside what needs to be done for himself.”[3] In the same way, the Holy Teaching of Vimalakīrti also says:
'khor ba'i 'jigs pas skrag pas ci la brten par bya/ smras pa/ 'jam dpal 'khor ba'i 'jigs pas skrag pa'i byang chub sems dpas sangs rgyas kyi che ba nyid la brten par bya'o/ /

[MAÑJUŚRĪ]: On what should someone who is afraid of the dangers of cyclic existence rely? [VIMALAKĪRTI]: Mañjuśrī, a bodhisattva who is afraid of the dangers of cyclic existence should rely on the greatness of the Buddha.
smras pa/ sangs rgyas kyi che ba nyid la gnas par 'dod pas ji ltar gnas par bya/ smras pa/ sangs rgyas kyi che ba nyid la gnas par 'dod pas sems can thams cad mnyam pa nyid la gnas par bya'o/ /

[MAÑJUŚRĪ]: Where should someone stand who wishes to stand in the greatness of the Buddha? [VIMALAKĪRTI]: Someone wishing to stand in the greatness of the Buddha should stand in equanimity toward all sentient beings.
smras pa/ sems can thams cad mnyam pa nyid la gnas par 'dod pas gang du gnas par bya/ / smras pa/ sems can thams cad rab tu thar bar bya ba la gnas par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

[MAÑJUŚRĪ]: Where should someone stand who wishes to stand in equanimity toward all sentient beings? [VIMALAKĪRTI]: Someone who wishes to stand in equanimity toward all sentient beings should live to set all sentient beings free.[4]

de skad du chos yang dag par sdud pa las/ byang chub sems dpa' ded dpon gyis gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' ni thog ma kho nar sems can thams cad byang chub par 'tshal bar bgyi ste bdag nyid ni ma lags so zhes bya ba nas/ bcom ldan 'das 'di ni chos yang dag par brjod pa lags so zhes bya ba'i bar du gsungs so/ /

As the bodhisattva Sārthavāha[5] said in the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together, “Blessed One, when a bodhisattva longs for Awakening first of all for all sentient beings, not for himself … this, Blessed One, is chanting the Dharma together.”[v]

gtang bas de'i rang gi don bya ba med par grub mod kyi/ 'on kyang sems can gyi don nyams pas 'jigs pa'i phyir skal ba med pa'i sems can la rang gi khur khas 'che bar mi byed do/ / gang du sems can gyi don nyams par ma mthong ba der rang gis byas sam gzhan gyis 'gro ba la phan par spyad par bye brag ci yod na/ de byang chub sems dpa' gzhan gyi dge ba sgrub pa'i phyir/ rang gi dge ba mi 'dor/ ci ste bdag ngan 'gro'i sdug bsngal gyis 'jigs na cig shos kyang sdug bsngal de nyid kyis 'jigs so/ / ji ste de sdug bsngal bas bdag la gnod pa med do snyam du yal bar 'dor na gong du smos pa'i mdo rnams las 'byung ba bzhin du nyes pa dang bcas par 'gyur ro/ /

[146] It is only by giving things up that his own welfare is accomplished.[vi] Nevertheless, for fear of losing benefits for sentient beings, he does not place his own burden on unworthy sentient beings. But where no benefits to sentient beings will be lost, what difference does it make if the welfare of the world is promoted by him or by somebody else? Suppose that he fails to discard what is wholesome of his own in order to bring about what is wholesome for other bodhisattvas. Well, if he fears the suffering of the lower realms for himself, what others fear is also suffering. If he is indifferent, thinking “That suffering has nothing to do with me,”[vii] then as the sūtras say, he undergoes a downfall.

yang dkon mchog brtsegs pa'i mdo las/ 'od srungs bzhi po 'di dag ni byang chub sems dpa' ltar bcos pa'o zhes bya ba las brtsams te/ bdag gis bde ba don du gnyer ba yin te sems can gyi sdug bsngal bsal ba don du gnyer ba ma yin pa'o zhes gsungs so/ / de lta bas na drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i tshul ltar snga ma yin bzhin du bdag la smad par bya'o/ /

In the Heap of Jewels Sūtra, in the passage starting “Kāśyapa, there are these four kinds of counterfeit bodhisattvas,” one type are described as “having their own happiness as their goal, and not having the goal of taking away the suffering of all sentient beings.” Therefore, you should criticize the self using the method from the Inquiry of Ugra, as described previously.[6]

byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa 'di ni chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las/ 'phags pa rtsom pa med kyis ji skad bstan pa lta bu ste/ rigs kyi bu sgrub pa la gnas par ji ltar rig par bya/ smras pa/ gang sems can rnams la log par mi sgrub pa'o/ /

In the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together, the noble Nirārambha gave teachings as follows: [SUBHŪTI]: How can we know that gentlemen are established in virtuous behavior? [NIRĀRAMBHA]: When they do no wrong to sentient beings.
smras pa/ sems can rnams la log par mi sgrub pa ji lta bu/ smras pa/ gang sems can rnams la byams pa chen po dang snying rje chen po mi 'dor ba'o/ /
[SUBHŪTI]: How do they do no wrong to sentient beings? [NIRĀRAMBHA]: They do not abandon {great} lovingkindness and great compassion.

rab 'byor gyis smras pa/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi byams pa chen po gang yin/ smras pa/ gang lus dang srog dang dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad sems can thams cad la sbyin zhing lan du phan 'dogs par re ba yang med do/ /

[SUBHŪTI]: What is the great lovingkindness of the bodhisattvas? [NIRĀRAMBHA]: When they give their bodies, their lives, and all their wholesome actions to all sentient beings, and do not hope to get anything in return.
smras pa/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi snying rje chen po gang yin/ smras pa/ gang thog ma kho nar sems can thams cad byang chub par 'dod kyi bdag ni ma yin pa'o zhes bya'o/ /
[Subhūti] What is the great compassion of the bodhisattvas? [NIRĀRAMBHA] When they long for Awakening for sentient beings first, not for themselves.

yang de nyid las/ snying rje chen po ni byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa thams cad kyi rtsa ba'o zhes gsungs so/ / byang chub sems dpa' don du gnyer ba gang yang rung bas don du gnyer bar bya ba yin pa'i phyir na/ gang gis sbyin pa po yon gnas chen pos don chen po sbyin pa las bsod nams kyi rgya mtsho'i phung po chen po snang bar 'gyur ba 'di ni gdon mi za bar bcom ldan 'das kyis bzlog par bya ba ma yin pa dang / gdon mi za bar bstan to zhes bya bar yong nges pa yin te/ de lta ma yin na ni phongs pas 'chi bar 'gyur ba 'ba' zhig tu zad do/ / rab tu zhi ba rnam par nges pa'i cho 'phrul gyi mdo las/

And the same text says, “Great compassion is the root of the whole training of a bodhisattva.”[viii] That [generosity] which takes as its goal the goals of a bodhisattva, whatever they might be—through which, for the donor, by giving a great benefit to someone who is greatly to be honored, a mass of goodness like a great ocean comes to appear—undoubtedly that was not forbidden by the Blessed One! If it were, the poor would simply die.[ix] Now, as for what is taught in the Sūtra on the Miracle of Calm Inquiry, namely—

rgyal po chen po khyod kyis lo stong gi 'god pa gang yin pa de dag thams cad bsdoms te/ dge slong gcig la byin par gyur cing / de bzhin du thams cad dge slong thams cad la so sor byin par gyur la/ gang yang lung 'bogs pa dang kha ton la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gus pa dang bcas pa chos 'dod pa zhig gis dad pas byin pa chen po la 'os pa blangs te/ 'di ltar sbyin pa 'dis bdag gis chos yongs su btsal ba brtsam mo snyam du sems bskyed na/ dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di la gtang bar bya ba'i chos yongs su gtang ba des brgya'i char yang nye bar mi 'gro'o zhes gang bstan pa de ni khyim gyi bde ba la chags pa'i dbang du byas nas gsungs pa ste/ sngar bstan pa'i tshul gyis nyes pa ci yang med do/ longs spyod bsrung ba mdo tsam bstan zin to/ / bsod nams bsrung ba brjod par bya ste/ de la/

Your Majesty, suppose that you were to take your own allowance for expenses for a hundred thousand years,[x] and give it all as the maintenance for one single monk[xi] and then give the same individually to all the monks. And suppose there were one bodhisattva, making an effort at studying and teaching, respectful, longing for the Dharma, who, having received food that is the gift of the faithful, should think, “With this, I will carry on the search for the Dharma.” The quality of generosity and giving things away does not approach even one-hundredth part of that goodness. —that is taught in order to clear away attachment to the pleasures of home life. It’s not that there is any problem with the first course of action. Protecting possessions has been explained in brief. Protecting goodness now needs to be explained. On this topic,
rang don rnam smin sred spangs pas/ / dge ba kun tu bsrung bar 'gyur/ /
[15a-b] Protect what is good by being free from craving For results of evolution that benefit yourself.

sred med kyi bus zhus pa las ji skad du/ de rgyal srid kyi phyir tshul khrims mi srung / mtho ris kyi phyir ma yin/ brgya byin gyi phyir ma yin/ tshangs pa'i phyir ma yin/ longs spyod kyi phyir ma yin/ dbang phyug gi phyir ma yin/ gzugs kyi phyir ma yin/ kha dog gi phyir ma yin/ snyan pa'i phyir ma yin no/ /

[147] As the Inquiry of Nārāyaṇa says, They guard moral discipline, but not for their own sake, nor for the sake of heaven, nor for the sake of becoming Śakra,[7] nor for the sake of enjoyment, nor for the sake of political power,[xii] nor for the sake of beauty, nor for the sake of physical appearance, nor for the sake of fame
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

dmyal ba'i 'jigs pas 'jigs nas tshul khrims bsrung ba ma yin/ de bzhin du dud 'gro'i skye gnas dang gshin rje'i 'jig rten gyis 'jigs skrag pas tshul khrims bsrung ba ma yin te/ gzhan du na sangs rgyas kyi tshul la dgod pa'i phyir tshul khrims bsrung ba nas/ sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde ba grub pa dang bde ba don du gnyer bas tshul khrims srung ngo / /

They guard moral discipline, but not for fear of hell … not for fear of the animal world,[xiii] do they guard moral discipline. Rather, they guard moral discipline in order to establish the way of the Buddha … they guard moral discipline with the goal of welfare, happiness, and the peace of spiritual practice[xiv] for all sentient beings
de bzhin du sbyar te/
tshul khrims kyi phung po de lta bu dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de chos bcu las yongs su nyams par mi 'gyur ro/ / bcu gang zhe na/
Those who are endowed with all aspects of moral discipline of this kind do not lose ten virtues. What are the ten?

'di lta ste/ 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal srid las yongs su mi nyams te de la yang bag yod cing byang chub 'dod pa yin/ brgya byin las yongs su mi nyams te de la yang bag yod cing byang chub 'dod pa dang / sangs rgyas mthong bar 'dod pa yin/ de bzhin du tshangs pa dang / sangs rgyas mthong ba mi phyed pa thob pa dang / chos nyan pa las yongs su mi nyams pa nas ji ltar thob pa'i chos bsgrub pa la nan tan byed pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i yi dam gyi bar las yongs su mi nyams pa dang / spobs pa rgyun mi 'chad pa dang / dge ba'i chos thams cad don du gnyer ba dang / bsam gtan las yongs su mi nyams pa'o/ /

They are these: They do not lose the position of a world-emperor, and while in that position, are not heedless, long for Awakening, long to see a Buddha. In the same way, they do not lose the state of a Brahmā, and are able without interruption to see the Buddhas and hear the Dharma … They make an earnest effort to put into practice the teachings as they have heard them,[xv] and do not lose the bodhisattva vow. Because they have continuous illumination, they do not lose the meditative stability that has all wholesome states as its goal
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ltar tshul khrims kyi phung po la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po ni lha rnams kyis rtag tu phyag byas pa yin/ klu rnams kyis rtag tu bsngags pa yin/ gnod sbyin rnams kyis rtag tu phyag byas pa yin/ dri za rnams kyis rtag tu mchod pa yin/ klu'i dbang po dang lha ma yin gyi dbang po rnams kyis rtag tu rjed pa yin/ bram ze dang rgyal rigs dang tshong dpon dang khyim bdag rnams kyis rtag tu gsol ba yin/ mkhas pa rnams kyis rtag tu 'gro bar bya ba yin/ sangs rgyas rnams kyis rtag tu dgongs pa yin/ lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten gyis ston pa dang mtshungs par bkur ba yin/ sems can thams cad la snying brtse ba yin no/ /

When bodhisattva great beings live with all aspects of moral discipline in this way, gods always pay homage to them. Serpent-spirits always praise them.[xvi] Celestial musicians always make offerings to them. Kings of serpent-spirits and titan kings always honor them. Brahmins, warrior-nobles, guild presidents, and leading merchants always respect them. Learned people always approach them. The Buddhas always notice them. The whole world, including the gods, honors them as teachers. They have compassion for all sentient beings
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

'gro ba bzhir mi 'gro ste/ bzhi gang zhe na 'di lta ste/ sems can yongs su smin par bya ba ma gtogs par mi khom pa'i 'gro bar mi 'gro ba dang / sangs rgyas med pa'i zhing gi 'gro bar mi 'gro ba dang / log par lta ba can gyi rigs su skye ba'i 'gro bar mi 'gro ba dang / ngan 'gro'i 'gro ba thams cad du mi 'gro ba'o zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / de ltar sngar btang ba'i bsod nams nyon mongs pa'i dbang gis yang len pa bsrung bar bya'o/ / bsod nams byin pa'i bsod nams gang yin pa de las gzhan gyi don las ma gtogs pa rnam par smin pa mi 'dod par bya'o/ / gzhan yang bsod nams bsrung bar 'dod pas/

There are four kinds of rebirths to which they do not go. What are the four? Except in order to help sentient beings to mature, they do not go into situations with no opportunity to practice. They do not go into worlds with no Buddha. They do not go into families that hold wrong views. They do not go to any bad rebirths. In the same way, you should protect the goodness arisen from previous giving from being taken away by the power of the reactive emotions. But you should not hope for any result of evolution from the goodness that comes from giving away your goodness, other than for the benefit of others. Moreover, if you want to protect your goodness,
'gyod par yang ni mi bya ste/ /
[15c] Don’t regret it afterwards.

drag shul can gyis zhus pa las ji skad du/ byin nas 'gyod pa'i sems bskyed par ni mi bya'o zhes gsungs pa lta bu ste/ mjug mthu chung bar byas pas mthu chung bar 'gyur te/ 'gyod pas sdig pa zad pa bzhin du bsod nams kyang zad par 'gyur bar dgongs pa'o/ /

[148] As the Inquiry of Ugra says, “And having given, you should not arouse thoughts of repentance.”[8] If you make the end weak, the whole action will become weak.[xvii] And when you repent, goodness decays, just as vile actions would. This is the intended meaning.
byas par gyur kyang bsgrags mi bya/ /
[15d] And after you do it, don’t make it publicly known.

bcom ldan 'das kyis rnam grangs du mar dge ba mi spyoms pa dang / sdig pa bshags pa gsungs so/ / de la yid mi bde ba'i phyir sdig pa ni/ bshags pas zad par 'gyur ro/ / bsod nams ni de ltar zad par mi 'gyur te/ yid bde ba'i phyir yang mi zad de/ sems can gyi don gyi phyir zang zing med pa'i sems kyis bsgrags pa ni nyes pa med do/ / dkon mchog sprin las ji skad du/ sman pa'i dpes bdag bstod pa nyes pa med par bstan pa lta bu'o/ / yang bsod nams bsrung bar 'dod pas/ /

For the Blessed One often praised hiding your virtues and confessing your vile actions. Here whatever is publicly known will diminish. Vile actions diminish through suffering, and goodness, through happiness.[xviii] But to talk about it with a mind free from worldly desires, in order to benefit sentient beings, is not a downfall. As it says in the Cloud of Jewels, “For example, it is taught that letting people know you are a doctor is not a problem.” Again, if you want to protect goodness,
rnyed dang bkur stis 'jigs bya zhing / / khengs pa rtag tu spang bar bya/ / byang chub sems dpa' dang bya zhing / / chos la yid gnyis spang bar bya/ /
[16] Beware of money and prestige; Always avoid pride. A bodhisattva should be confident And let go of any dislike for the Dharma.[xix]

'di ni dkon mchog brtsegs pa las rab tu bstan te/ 'od srungs byang chub sems dpa' chos bzhi dang ldan pa'i dge ba'i chos skyes shing byung ba rnams yongs su zad par 'gyur te dge ba'i chos de dag gis rgyas par mi 'gyur ro/ / bzhi gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ mngon pa'i nga rgyal gyis 'jig rten rgyang 'phen pa'i gsang tshig tshol ba dang / rnyed pa dang bkur sti la lhag par zhen pas khyim la lta ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' la rnam par sdang zhing skur pa 'debs pa dang / ma thos pa dang ma zin pa'i mdo sde rnams spong ba'o zhes bstan to/ /

The Heap of Jewels says this: Kāśyapa, bodhisattvas with four characteristics will completely lose whatever wholesome states they have gained and developed, and their wholesome states will not grow. What are the four? They are: Being proud, and seeking the tricks of materialists; coveting money and prestige, and looking towards the home life; deprecating another bodhisattva out of hatred; and rejecting scriptures just because you have never heard them or been taught them before.

'phags pa thams cad yod par smra ba rnams kyi gzhung las kyang / dge slong dag dge slong gis 'di ltar skra dang sen mo'i mchod rten la yan lag thams cad kyis phyag 'tshal te sems dang bar byed pa la ltos/ / btsun pa de lta lags so/ /

In the noble Monastic Code[xx] of the Sarvāstivādins,[9] we read: [LORD BUDDHA]: Do you see, monks, that monk who, with a mind full of faith, prostrated with his whole body to this stūpa containing hair and nails? [MONKS]: Yes, Revered One.

dge slong dag dge slong 'dis sa ji tsam zhig non pa'i 'og dpag tshad brgyad khri bzhi stong na yod pa'i gser gyi 'khor lo la thug pa'i bar na bye ma ji snyed yod pa de snyed du dge slong 'dis 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal srid stong 'gyur du longs spyod par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba nas de nas tshe dang ldan pa nye ba 'khor gyis/ bcom ldan 'das ga la ba de logs su thal mo sbyar ba btud de/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ /

[LORD BUDDHA]: Monks, that monk [xxi] will enjoy as many thousands of lives as a world-emperor as there are grains of sand in the earth, from here to the sphere of gold eighty thousand leagues down.… Then the venerable Upāli,[10] {standing to one side,} bowed to the Blessed One with his palms together, and said to the Blessed One,

bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong gi dge ba'i rtsa ba de lta bur che bar gsungs na bcom ldan 'das dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag gang du bsrabs pa dang yongs su byang ba dang yongs su zad par 'gyur/ nye ba 'khor ji ltar tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pas tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa la rma byung ba dang rmas par byas pa de lta bu ni ngas ma mthong ste/ nye ba 'khor des dge ba'i rtsa ba chen po 'di dag bsrabs pa dang yongs su byang ba dang yongs su zad par 'gyur ro/ / nye ba 'khor de lta bas na ci nas 'gal ba la yang sems kyis gnod par mi bya na rnam par shes pa dang bcas pa'i lus lta smos kyang ci dgos zhes 'don to/ /

[149] [UPĀLI]: The Blessed One has said that that monk’s wholesome actions are great. Blessed One, where do these wholesome actions diminish, give out, and finally come to be exhausted? [LORD BUDDHA]: Upāli, I do not see any decay or destruction so powerful as when companions in the celibate life arouse angry thoughts[xxii] towards each other. Then, Upāli, these great wholesome actions diminish, give out, and finally come to be exhausted. Therefore, Upāli, you should train in such a way that you do not harm anyone who opposes you, even in your mind—how much less should you do so intentionally with the body![xxiii]
'phags pa 'jam dpal rnam par rol pa'i mdo las/ khong khro ba khong khro ba zhes bya ba ni bskal pa brgyar bsags pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba 'joms pas de'i phyir khong khro ba zhes bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Sūtra on Mañjuśrī’s Display of Power (Mañjuśrī-vikrīḍita-sūtra) also says: “ ‘Hatred, hatred’—wholesome actions accumulated over a hundred aeons are destroyed [pratihanti,] therefore we call it ‘hatred’ [pratigha].”

'phags pa sdong po bkod pa'i mdo las/ mtshan mo'i lha mo sems can kun skyob pa'i dpal gyis sngon gyi rtogs pa brjod pa bsnyad pa las kyang / de dag phan tshun brnyas pa'i mi dge ba 'dus pas tshe'i tshad kyang nyams par 'gyur/ kha dog dang stobs dang bde ba las kyang yongs su nyams par 'gyur zhes gsungs so/ /

And in the noble Array of Stalks, in the story told by the goddess of the night named Samantasattvaparitrāṇyojaḥśrī, this is stated:[11] “Because of the unwholesome action of taking delight in despising[xxiv] each other, they lost their length of life. They lost their beauty, their power, and also their happiness.”[xxv]
'dir ni brgya lam na yang khengs par mi bya'o zhes rab tu bstan pa'i phyir rtag tu zhes brjod do/ / rnyed pa dang bkur sti ni ji ste na khas blang bar bya ste/ dkon mchog sprin las ji skad du/

Now, in order to teach that you should never under any circumstances be proud, the verse says “Always [avoid pride.]” But in some cases, you should accept money and prestige. As the noble Cloud of Jewels says,

'di la byang chub sems dpa'i rin po che'i phung po ri rab tsam thob na yang len to/ / dngos po ngan pa zhig thob na yang len to/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de 'di ltar sems te sems can 'di dag ni ser sna can brkam pa 'dod pas bkol ba 'jungs pa yin te/ rgyu de dang rkyen de dang gzhi des chu'i phung po chen pos non pa bzhin du 'khor ba'i rgya mtshor 'byung nub byed pa de dag la yun ring por don dang phan pa dang bde ba chen por 'gyur ro snyam ste/ de blangs nas bdag gir mi byed chags pa'i sems mi bskyed do/ / gzhan du na sems can thams cad dang thun mong du sangs rgyas dang chos dang dge 'dun dag la yang bya ba byed do/ / sems can sdug bsngal ba rnams la yang phan par byed do/ / sbyin pa'i bdag po de yang gzengs bstod pa dang shin tu dga' bar byed do zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

[150] Here a bodhisattva obtains and accepts a heap of jewels the size of Mt. Meru; or if some inferior property is offered, also accepts that. Why is that? She thinks, “These sentient beings are greedy, avaricious, overpowered by desire. Because of that, for that reason, and on that basis, they are as if submerged in a vast mass of water, rising up and sinking down in the ocean of cyclic existence. This [gift] will be for their welfare, benefit, and happiness for a long time.” She accepts everything, but doesn’t regard it as her own. She arouses no greedy thoughts towards it, other than for benefits common to all sentient beings. She uses it to carry on the work of the Buddha, the Dharma, and the religious community, and to meet the needs of all suffering sentient beings. She incites the donors to give, and rejoices in that.
de bzhin du de nyid las/ sbyin pa des khengs par yang mi 'gyur zhes gsungs so/ / yang de nyid las/
And the same text says, “She does not become proud because of that generosity.” The same text also says,

gal te yang rgyu de dang rkyen de dang gzhi des grags pa dang sgra dang tshigs su bcad pa zhig byung yang des khengs par mi 'gyur nga rgyal mi skye rgyags pa mi skye ste de 'di snyam du sems so/ / ring por mi thogs par grags pa dang sgra dang tshigs su bcad pa 'di su la nye bar gnas pa dang / su dag gis nye bar gnas par byas pa dang / grags pa dang sgra dang tshigs su bcad pa gang zhig nye bar gnas pa 'di gsum gang yang thams cad du thams cad med par 'gyur na de la mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can su zhig mi rtag cing mi gnas pa'i chos mi brtan pa yid brtan du mi rung ba dag la dga' ba'i sems bskyed pa'am/ khengs par 'gyur ba'am/ nga rgyal dang rgyags pas dregs par 'gyur snyam ste/ de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' rnyed pa dang bkur sti dang grags pa dang sgra dang tshigs su bcad pa rnams la dran pa shin tu nye bar gzhag cing gnas so zhes gsungs so/ / gzhan yang dman pa'i yid kyis gdol bu lta bur 'jig rten na spyod pa yin/ rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par bsod snyoms slong ba'i 'du shes nye bar gzhag pas dman zhing dman pa'i yid kyis nga rgyal dang rgyags pa dang dregs pa dang bral ba rnams yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

Now if because of that, for that reason, and on that basis, she gains fame, reputation, and praise, in that case she does not become arrogant, proud, or full of herself. She thinks, “This fame, reputation, and praise will not remain for a long time. Who can hold on to them? Whatever fame, reputation, and praise I have will utterly cease to be. Given that, what educated person would be joyful about things that are impermanent, unstable, not lasting, and unreliable, or become arrogant, proud, or full of herself?” In this way indeed, a bodhisattva lives while carefully applying mindfulness to money and prestige, fame, reputation, and praise. Moreover, the text says, “They live like an untouchable child in the world, humble, with humble minds. Since they always remember begging for alms-food, they are humble, with humble minds, without pride, not full of themselves, not haughty.”[xxvi]

yang gsungs pa/ rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' khyim gyi gnas nas mngon par byung ste rab tu byung nas bdag gi grogs po dang blon po dang gnyen bshes dang snag gi gnyen mtshams la shi ba dang 'dra'o zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ bdag gi gzugs mi sdug par khas blangs shing bdag gis gos kha dog mi sdug pa bgos te tshul gzhan du bsgyur ro zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ sprang ba'i rgyu sprang ba'i phyir mgo bregs shing lag na lhung bzed thogs nas grong nas grong du 'gro'o zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ gdol bu dang 'dra bar dman pa dman pa'i sems kyis bsod snyoms kyi phyir 'gro'o zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ bdag ni bsod snyoms pa ste bdag gi 'tsho ba gzhan la rag lus so zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ brnyas pa'i bsod snyoms ngan ngon len to zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ bdag gis slob dpon dang bla ma dang sbyin pa'i gnas rnams mnyes par bya dgos so zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ bdag gis tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams la 'di lta ste/ cho ga dang spyod yul dang kun spyod pa de dang des mgu bar bya'o zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ sangs rgyas kyi chos ma thob pa rnams thob par bya'o zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin/ sems can khros pa dang gnod sems rnams kyi nang na bzod pa mang bar bya'o zhes nga rgyal bcom pa yin no zhes gsungs so// //

Moreover, the text also says, [151] Here, noble sir, an ordained bodhisattva who has gone forth from the home life thinks, “I am like a dead person to friends, companions, relatives, and family members.” Pride is defeated. “Ugliness has come to join me; I am clothed in discolored garments, and my other decorations are gone.” Pride is defeated. “With a shaven head, with bowl in hand, I go from house to house in order to get alms, for the sake of alms.” Pride is defeated. “Humble, with a humble mind, like an untouchable child I go for alms.” Pride is defeated. “I am a mendicant, disciplined by a vow, and I depend on others for my livelihood.” Pride is defeated. “I should be devoted to my spiritual and academic teachers, and to all those worthy of respect.” Pride is defeated. “All of my conduct, behavior, and activities should be pleasing to my companions in the celibate life.” Pride is defeated. “I will attain the awakened qualities that I don’t yet have.” Pride is defeated. “I will live among angry, malevolent sentient beings with much patient endurance.” Pride is defeated.[xxvii]
bam po bdun pa/

'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / de lus yongs su dag pa yin te/ lus mtshan gyis legs par brgyan pa dang / lag pa dang rkang pa 'jam zhing mnyen pa dang / bsod nams kyi rgyu mthun pa'i lus shin tu rnam par phye ba dang / dbang po ma tshang ba med pa dang / yan lag dang nying lag thams cad yongs su rdzogs pa yin yang / gzugs kyis rgyags shing dregs pa med pa yin te/ lus che ba'i tshul dang ldan pa ma yin no/ / de chos gzung bar bya ba'i phyir sems can ci tsam du dman pa gzugs ma tshang ba rnams la yang 'dud do rab tu 'dud do zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Sāgaramati Sūtra also says, He is pure of body, his body well ornamented with the marks of a great person, with soft and supple hands and feet, with a well-proportioned[xxviii] body that is appropriate to the goodness that is its cause, with faculties free from all defects, with all major and minor body parts intact. But he is not intoxicated by his own beauty; nor is he devoted to the practice of decorating the body.[xxix] Because he upholds the Dharma, he bows down even to lesser sentient beings, of flawed appearance, and greets them respectfully.

yang de nyid las bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na gang gi tshe rgya mtsho chen po mchis par 'gyur ba de'i tshe gzhol ba'i phyogs na mchis par 'gyur ro/ / de gzhol ba'i slad du chu klung thams cad dang chab mig dang 'bab chu thams cad tshegs chung ngus der 'bab bo/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' nga rgyal ma mchis pa bla ma dang sbyin gnas la gus pa la yang tshegs chung ngus chos zab mo'i sgo rnams rna ba'i dbang po la grag par 'gyur zhing dran pa la yang gnas par 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das de lta bas na byang chub sems dpa' nga rgyal gyis khengs nga rgyal gyis rengs par gyur te/ bla ma dang sbyin gnas rnams la kun du mi 'dud cing 'dud par mi bgyid la rab tu mi 'dud na/ bcom ldan 'das kye ma'o byang chub sems dpa' 'di ni nga rgyal gyi lcags kyus zin par rig par bgyi'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Moreover, the same text says, For example, Blessed One, suppose there is an area of land that is lower than the great ocean. Into that place, because it is so low, all the rivers and all the streams of water could easily flow. In the same way, Blessed One, a bodhisattva who is free from pride and respectful towards spiritual teachers and those worthy of honor easily hears all those profound Dharma topics, and they remain in the memory. Therefore, Blessed One, suppose that a bodhisattva is proud, conceited, and stiff with pride, and does not bow down to spiritual teachers and those worthy of honor and greet them respectfully. Blessed One, alas! We should understand that this bodhisattva has been pierced by Māra’s iron hooks.[xxx]

'phags pa 'jig rten las 'das pa'i le'u las kyang / kye rgyal ba'i sras bcu po 'di dag ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi nga rgyal gyi las so/ / bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ bla ma dang sbyin gnas dang slob dpon dang pha ma dang dge sbyong dang bram ze dang yang dag par song ba dang yang dag par zhugs pa rnams la mi gus pa ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ / chos smra ba dang / khyad par can gyi chos khong du chud pa dang / chos rgya chen po ston pa dang theg pa chen po la zhugs pa dang 'byung ba'i lam gyi tshul shes pa dang / gzungs dang mdo sde la shin tu byang ba rnams la mi 'dud de/ khengs shing 'gying la chos dang chos smra ba la gus pa mi skyed cing sri zhu dang zhes mi byed pa ni/ nga rgyal gyi las so/ /

And the noble Chapter on the Transcendent (Lokottara-parivarta) says, O heir of the Victor, there are for bodhisattvas these ten actions of Māra. What are the ten? Being disrespectful to spiritual teachers, those worthy of honor, academic teachers, parents, religious wanderers and Brahmins, when they are departing correctly or arriving correctly, is an action of Māra. They do not bow down to Dharma teachers who have exceptional qualities, who teach the lofty Dharma, who travel the Great Way, who know the methods of the path to Nirvāṇa, who have the dhāraṇīs and the kings of scriptures. Haughty and stubborn, they feel no respect for the Dharma teacher, have no desire to hear and feel no wonder.[xxxi] This is an action of Māra.

chos mnyan pa dang yang dag pa'i gtam bya bar 'dug pa na/ chos kyi shugs rgya chen po skyes kyang la la zhig 'di la dad pa skyes par 'gyur du 'ong snyam ste chos smra ba la legs so zhes bya ba sbyin par mi byed pa ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ / mngon pa'i nga rgyal bskyed nas bdag gi gzengs bstod cing pha rol khyad du gsod pa dang bdag shes pa la mi 'jug cing sems kyi nges par sems pa mi skyed pa ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ / lhag pa'i nga rgyal bskyed nas shes shing rtogs bzhin du bsngags par 'os pa'i gang zag rnams kyi bsngags pa 'chab pa dang mi snyan par brjod cing gzhan gyi yon tan bsngags pas yid mi dga' bar 'gyur ba ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ /

[152] While sitting and listening to a Dharma talk, even when they feel vast enthusiasm for Dharma, they do not say “Sādhu” to the Dharma teacher, thinking “May no one praise him!”[xxxii] This is an action of Māra. They become arrogant, praise themselves, and condescend to others. They gain no self-knowledge and do not develop the mind that knows directly. This is an action of Māra. They become conceited and, not knowing, not understanding, they conceal the praiseworthy qualities of people who are worthy of praise. They say uncomplimentary things about them, and never praise the abilities of others.[xxxiii] This is an action of Māra.

'di ni chos so/ /'di ni 'dul ba'o/ /'di ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi bka' yin no zhes bya bar yang dag par shes la/ gang zag la zhe sdang zhing chos la zhe sdang ba dang dam pa'i chos spong ba dang gzhan dag kyang rtsod du 'jug cing ldog par byed pa ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ / stan mthon po 'dod pa dang gces te las su mi bsko ba'i chos tshol ba dang gzhan gyi rim gro bya bar sdod cing mngon par dga' ba dang gnas brtan rgan po tshangs par spyod pa yun ring du spyad pa rnams la mi ldang zhing mi su ba dang bsnyen bkur mi byed pa ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ / bzhin khro gnyer can du byas shing mi 'dzum pa dang / tshig 'jam zhing mnyen pa med la rtag tu khengs pa'i sems kyis glags lta skabs tshol ba ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ /

They know, “This is the Dharma; this is the monastic code; this is the genuine word of the Buddha.”[xxxiv] But because of personal animosity, they develop animosity towards the Teachings. They reject the holy Dharma, {enter into debate with others}, and mislead them. This is an action of Māra. They seek to think of themselves as superior,[xxxv] and do not try to follow the rules about being careful and attentive. They approach others; they shout. They do not wait upon elders, senior monks who have practiced celibacy for a long time, and do not stand up respectfully to greet them. This is an action of Māra. They have frowning faces, not smiling faces, and do not speak gently. With their minds always hard, they look for vulnerable points and try to find opportunities to harm others. This is an action of Māra.

mngon pa'i nga rgyal can du lhung zhing mkhas pa'i gan du mi 'gro mi bsnyen mi bsten bsnyen bkur mi byed yongs su mi 'dri zhing dge ba ni ci mi dge ba ni ci/ ci byas na yun ring por don dang phan pa dang bde bar 'gyur/ ci byas na yun ring por gnod pa dang mi phan pa dang mi bde bar 'gyur zhes mi 'dri ste/ de rmongs pa las ches rmongs par gyur nas/ gti mug gis blong zhing nga rgyal gyis brgyal te 'byung ba mi mthong ba ni nga rgyal gyi las so/ /

Having fallen into arrogance, they do not approach the learned. They do not study with them, attend upon them, or ask them questions. They do not inquire about what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, about what should be done, about what, when done, would bring about welfare, benefit, and happiness for a long time, or about what, when not done, would bring about harm, suffering, and living badly for a long time. They are stupid, and they become stupider. Controlled by delusion, they hold on to pride. They see no way out. This is an action of Māra.

mngon pa'i nga rgyal gyis zil gyis non pas sangs rgyas 'byung ba mnyes par mi byed pa dang sngon gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba zad par byed pa dang gsar mi skyed pa dang / bshad par mi bya ba 'chad pa dang 'thab mo byed cing rtsod pa mang bar gyur te/ 'di lta bu'i chos la gnas pas 'dod rgyal chen por lhung ba'i gnas su gyur kyang / byang chub kyi sems kyi stobs skyed pas dbang phyug thob par 'gyur yang / des bskal pa brgya stong du sangs rgyas 'byung ba yang mi mthong na chos nyan par lta ga la 'gyur te 'di ni nga rgyal gyi las bcu pa'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras byang chub sems dpa' dag gis nga rgyal gyi las bcu po de lta bu de dag yongs su spangs nas/ ye shes kyi las bcu thob par 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

Overcome by pride, they don’t even care about whether a Buddha arises. Their previous wholesome actions are exhausted, and they don’t plant new ones. They teach improperly. They start quarrels and get into a lot of disputes. They live in these kinds of qualities, in situations where they would fall into serious errors. On the other hand, because of the efficacy of arousing the Awakening Mind, they attain positions of political power. For a hundred thousand aeons they do not meet with the arising of a Buddha, much less the opportunity to hear the Dharma. This is the tenth action of Māra. Heir of the Victor, those bodhisattvas who leave behind these ten actions of Māra attain ten forms of knowing.
de nyid las sems can thams cad la nga rgyal med pa zhes ye shes kyi las legs par bshad do/ /
And the same text says: “Freedom from pride towards all sentient beings evolves out of [these] forms of knowing.”[xxxvi]

'phags pa yul 'khor skyong gis zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / rmongs pa de dag nga rgyal dbang gis na/ / ngan song pa dang mi khom skye ba dang / / dbul dang dman pa'i rigs su skye ba dang / / dmus long mdog ngan mthu chung nyid 'dzin byed/ / ces gsungs so/ /

chos yang dag par sdud pa las kyang / sems can gyi zhing ni byang chub sems dpa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing ste/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing gang las sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams 'thob par 'gyur ba de la log par bsgrub pa mi rigs so snyam mo/ / de yang 'di snyam du legs par spyad pa dang nyes par spyad pa thams cad ni sems can la brten nas 'byung ngo / / nyes par spyad pa la brten nas ni ngan song rnams 'byung ngo / / legs par spyad pa la brten nas ni lha dang mir 'gyur ro snyam mo zhes gsungs so/ /

And the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together says, “The field of sentient beings is a bodhisattva’s Buddha field from which the qualities of a Buddha are attained. It is not appropriate to do anything wrong there.” And they think, “Everything that is done well or badly happens in dependence on sentient beings. Based on what is badly done, the lower realms unfold; based on what is well done, the god and human realms.”
