de bas na dkon mchog ta la la'i gzungs las kyang / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag 'di la byang chub sems dpa' las dang po pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni sems can rnams la thog ma nyid du sems rnam pa bcu bskyed de/ rnam pa bcu gang zhe na 'di lta ste/ phan pa'i sems dang / bde ba'i sems dang / snying brtse ba'i sems dang / mnyen pa'i sems dang / sdug pa'i sems dang / phan gdags pa'i sems dang / kun du srung ba'i sems dang / snyoms pa'i sems dang / slob dpon gyi sems dang / ston pa'i sems te/ sems rnam pa bcu po 'di dag bskyed do zhes gsungs so/ /

Therefore, the Precious Lamp Dhāraṇī says, Heirs of the Victor, bodhisattvas who are arousing the Mind for the first time[xxxviii] should, at the beginning, arouse ten thoughts towards all sentient beings. What are these ten thoughts? They are: thinking of their welfare, thinking of their happiness, thinking of them with love, thinking of them tenderly, thinking of them as dear, thinking of them with kindness, thinking of protecting them, thinking of them as equal, thinking of them as teachers, thinking of them as instructors. They should arouse these ten thoughts.

dad pa'i stobs bskyed pa la 'jug pa'i phyag rgya'i mdo las/ bdag nyid ni sems can thams cad kyi slob mar khas len pa la gnas shing sems can gzhan dag kyang slob mar khas len pa la gzhag go snyam du dbugs dbyung ba rnyed do/ /

The Sūtra on the Posture for Beginning to Generate the Power of Faith also says: “They arouse enthusiasm, thinking, ‘I myself agree to live as a student of all sentient beings, and I will induce others to agree to be students of all sentient beings’
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[xxxix]

rnam par 'dud pa dang rab tu 'dud pa la gzhag go snyam du dbugs dbyung ba rnyed do/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de la rnam par 'dud pa dang rab tu 'dud pa ni sems can thams cad la nga rgyal med pa nyid do/ / de bzhin du 'phags pa dri ma med par grags pas bstan pa las kyang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su dag par skye bar bya ba'i phyir sems can thams cad la ston pa ltar gces par byed ces gsungs so/ / stan 'ding ba dang rkang pa 'khru ba la sogs pa'i las byed pa na yang 'jig rten ma dad par 'gyur ba bsrung ba'i phyir/ sems kyis gces pa dang gus par bsam pa goms par bya'o/ /

‘I live in the practice of bowing down to and respectfully greeting sentient beings,’ ” and so on as before. Here, by bowing down and respectfully greeting all sentient beings, you are free from pride. In the same way, the Holy Teaching of Vimalakīrti says, in the chapter on the Purification of the Buddha-Field, “[Bodhisattvas] should love all sentient beings as their teachers. In order to protect the trust people have in them, they should set up seats for, and wash the feet of, women, or those who have no opportunity to practice, or those who are fallen; and they should develop thoughts of love and respect.”[13]

'phags pa sdong po bkod pa'i mdo las kyang gsungs te/ des seng ge'i khri chen po de la 'dug ma thag tu skye bo mang po de dag mngon du phyogs par 'gyur te thal mo sbyar nas rgyal po de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
[154] For the Array of Stalks says,[14] He sat down on that great lion throne. Immediately the multitude faced him, placed their palms together, and reverentially saluted that king
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rgyal po chos thams cad kyi nga ro'i gdugs kyi dkyil 'khor rab tu sgrogs pa des slong mo pa de dag mthong ba'i mod de la de'i rgyus ches dga' bar gyur gyi/ bskal pa tshad med pa'i mthas klas par zhes bya ba nas/ gnas gtsang ma'i lha'i rnam par thar pa zhi ba'i bde ba la gnas pa thob pas ni ma yin no zhes bya ba'i bar du'o/ / rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste/ dper na/ skyes bu sred pa la spyod pa pha ma dang phu nu dang bu sring dang mdza' bo dang blon po dang gnyen bshes dang bu dang bu mo dang chung ma dang yun ring mo zhig tu bral ba la 'brog dgon par 'khyams te/ de dag mthong bar 'dod pa las de dag dang phrad na de dag mthong bas mi ngoms shing dga' ba dang chags pa chen po skye bar 'gyur ro/ / rigs kyi bu de bzhin du rgyal po chos thams cad kyi nga ro'i gdugs kyi dkyil 'khor rab tu sgrogs pas slong mo pa de dag mthong bar gyur pa'i mod la dga' ba'i shugs chen po skyes so/ / sems kyi dga' ba'i ro bde ba dang ldan par gyur to/ / sems spro ba'i shugs rab tu byung ngo zhes bya ba nas/ slong mo pa de dag la bu gcig pa'i 'du shes skyed pa'i phyir ro/ / pha ma'i 'du shes dang sbyin pa'i gnas kyi 'du shes dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi 'du shes dang / dkon pa'i 'du shes dang / dka' ba byed pa'i 'du shes dang / gces spras byed pa'i 'du shes dang / phan 'dogs pa dam pa'i 'du shes dang / byang chub kyi lam nye bar ston pa'i 'du shes dang / mkhan po'i 'du shes dang / ston pa'i 'du shes skyed pa'i phyir te zhes bya ba'i bar du gsungs so/ /

Indeed, as soon as he saw those petitioners, King Sarvadharmanirnādacchatramaṇḍalanirghoṣa[15] was delighted, even more so than if he had attained imperial power over the three-thousand-fold world-system for immeasurable aeons … more than if he had gained rulership for countless aeons among the gods who live purely and have the doors to peace and freedom.[xl] Noble sir, for example, when a man who acts out of craving wanders in the wilderness and is separated for a long time from his parents, brothers, sisters, close friends, companions, relatives, sons, daughters, and wives, he wants to see those people; if he were to meet them, then from that, great bliss and attachment would arise, and he wouldn’t be able to get enough of seeing them.[xli] Noble sir, in the same way, King Sarvadharmanirnādacchatramaṇḍalanirghoṣa felt great bliss and enthusiasm as soon as he saw those petitioners. He experienced mental satisfaction and happiness, great thoughts and exalted enthusiasm … He thought of those petitioners as his only child; he thought of them as his parents; he thought of them as worthy of honor; he thought of them as spiritual teachers; he thought of them as beautiful;[xlii] he thought of them as rare; he thought of them as people who do difficult things; he thought of them as accomplishing a lot; he thought of them as supremely helpful; he thought of them as the basis for the path to Awakening; he thought of them as teachers and instructors.

de lta bu'i thabs gzhan med na sems can gyi gan du 'gro ba dang rim gro byed pa'i tshe thams cad du gtang ba dran par bya ste/ bdag gi lus 'di ni 'di dag gi yin gyi/ bdag bde ba'i don du sa byi dor byed pa dang bsku ba la sogs pa byed pa bzhin du 'di la ci dgar spyod cig snyam du bsam mo/ / yang na rje bo mi dga' bas 'jigs pa de dga' bar 'dod pas des bsgo ba bsgrubs pa ltar yid la bya'o/ / rten gzhan med pa'i phyir bcom ldan 'das kyis rim gro mdzad pa yang dge slong nad pas nyams su blangs so/ / dge slong gi bya ba rgyas pa las ji skad du/

In the same way, if you have no other method, when you go into the presence of sentient beings, be respectful at all times,[xliii] and remember what you have given away: “This body of mine is theirs. For the sake of their happiness, let them have it do whatever makes them happy, such as cleaning the floor[xliv] or anointing.” Alternately, like a servant who is afraid of the master’s displeasure and wishes to win his trust, apply attention in order to notice things about him. For the Blessed One, when there was no one else available, took care of a sick monk and helped him. As the Miscellany for Monks (Bhikṣu-prakīrṇaka) says,

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong ma 'jigs shig / dge slong ngas khyod kyi rim gro bya'o/ / dge slong khyod kyi gos rnams tshur byin cig ngas bkru'o/ / de skad ces bka' stsal pa dang / bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong nad pa 'di'i gos mi gtsang bas 'bags pa rnams mi bkru bar gsol lo/ / bcom ldan 'das de bdag gis bkru bar 'tshal lo/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo de'i phyir khyod kyis dge slong 'di'i gos rnams khrus shig / de bzhin gshegs pas ni chu blugs so/ / de nas tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos dge slong nad pa de'i gos bkrus so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis ni chu blugs so/ /

The Blessed One declared, “Don’t be afraid, monk! Don’t be afraid, monk![xlv] Monk, I will take care of you. Monk, bring me your robes and I will wash them.” After he had spoken, the venerable Ānanda said, “Blessed One, please don’t wash the robes of this sick monk, which are sullied with filth. Blessed One, I will wash them.” The Blessed One said, “Then, Ānanda, you wash this monk’s robes. The Tathāgata will pour the water.” Then, indeed, the venerable Ānanda washed the robes of that sick monk, and the Blessed One poured the water
de bzhin du sbyar te/
de nas tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos dge slong nad pa de shin tu legs par blangs te phyi rol du phyung nas bkrus so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis ni chu blugs so zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /
Then the venerable Ānanda kindly and carefully carried that sick monk outside and bathed him. The Blessed One poured the water.”
yang smras pa/ gang dag mgu bas che nyid dang / / ma mgus mi bzad rgud 'gyur ba/ / de dag srog kyang yongs btang nas/ / mgu bar bya bar rigs pa yin/ /

And the author [Śāntideva] says, Those who, if you make them happy, you attain greatness, And if you make them miserable, harm and disaster— To satisfy them, is it not reasonable Even to give up your life?
gang dag mgu byas mang po rnams/ / grub de sems can 'di dag nyid/ / 'jig rten na ni sems can las/ / grub pa'i zhing gzhan yod ma yin/ /
By being kind to them, the sentient beings, Many have attained the goal. There is in the world no field of attainment Other than sentient beings.
'di dag yid bzhin nor bu dang / / bum bzang 'dod 'jo'i ba dang ni/ / bla ma dang ni lha 'dra ba/ / des na 'di dag mgu bar bya/ /
They are wish-fulfilling gems, wish-fulfilling vases; They are like cows who satisfy all wishes by giving milk. Therefore, one should try to make them happy Like spiritual teachers and deities.
gzhan yang g.yo med gnyen gyur cing / / phan pa dpag med mdzad rnams la/ / sems can mgu bya ma gtogs par/ / gzhan 'ga' zhig gis lan lon 'gyur/ /
Moreover, when they have been your relatives, They have sincerely conferred upon you innumerable benefits. If you give up on making them happy, What kind of recompense would that be?
ral pa'i nang gnas sems can rnams/ / 'bad pas g.yo ba med par ni/ / ji ltar bzhen bzhin mgon pos sngon/ / dbu yis bzung bar gyur pa yin/ /
Just as, previously, the lord carried The sentient beings who lived in his hair Wherever they wanted, with his head, Having become immoveable through effort.[xlvi]
gang phyir sku gtong mnar med 'jug pa la/ / de la byas pas lan lon nyid 'gyur ba/ / des ni gnod chen byed kyang de dag la/ / legs pas thams cad rab tu spyad par bya/ /

Those for whom [bodhisattvas] sacrifice their bodies and enter Avīci— For them, you should do whatever needs doing. Even if they have done you great wrong, You should act towards them only in a virtuous way.[16]
re zhig bdag gi rjer gyur nyid kyang ni/ / gang phyir rang gi sku la'ang mi gzigs pa/ / rje bo de dang de la ji ltar bdag / nga rgyal byed cing bran gyi dngos mi byed/ /
[156] How can I be conceited and not do service To all those masters for whom My own masters do only what will be beneficial And have no concern for themselves?
gang dag bde bas thub rnams dgyes 'gyur zhing / / gang la gnod na mi dgyes 'byung 'gyur ba/ / de dag dga' bas thub dbang kun dgyes shing / / de la gnod byas thub la gnod pa byas/ /
Since, if they are happy, the Sages will be glad, And if they are afflicted, the Sages will grieve, By pleasing them, all the greatest of Sages are pleased; If they are harmed, the Sages are harmed.
ji ltar lus la kun nas me 'bar ba/ / 'dod pa kun gyis yid bder mi 'gyur ba/ / de bzhin sems can gnod pa byas na yang / / thugs rje che rnams dgyes pa'i thabs med do/ /

Just as someone whose whole body was on fire Would not be made glad even by all sensual pleasures, In the same way, when sentient beings are in pain, There is no way for the greatly compassionate to be pleased.
de bas bdag gis 'gro la gnod byas pas/ / thugs rje che kun mi dges gyur pa gang / / sdig de de ring so sor bshags bgyi yis/ / mi dges gang lags de thub bzod par gsol/ /
Therefore, all the harm I have done to living beings Which causes sorrow to all those of great compassion,[xlvii] I confess all that as vile action; May the Sages forgive what has pained them!
de bzhin gshegs rnams mnyes par bgyid slad deng / / bdag nyid kun gyis 'jig rten bran du mchi/ / 'gro mang bdag 'di'i mgo la rdog bsnun nam/ / yang na gnod par byed bzod 'jig rten mgon/ /
In order to please the Tathāgatas, I become a servant of the world. May a flood of people put their feet on my head or strike me down; May the Lord of the World be satisfied.
'gro ba 'di kun thugs rje'i bdag can des/ / bdag tu mdzad pa 'di la the tshom med/ / sems can ngo bor mthong ba 'di dag ni/ / mgon de bdag nyid ci phyir gus mi byed/ /
Those whose whole personality is compassion Have made this whole world their own; there is no doubt about it. Don’t they appear in the form of sentient beings? How can I fail to respect these Lords?
'di nyid de bzhin gshegs pa mnyes byed yin/ / rang don yang dag sgrub byed 'di nyid yin/ / 'jig rten sdug bsngal sel ba'ang 'di nyid de/ / des na bdag nyid rtag tu de nyid bya/ /

Only in this way can I please the Tathāgatas. Only in this way can I bring about my own well-being. Only in this way can I destroy the suffering of the world. Therefore, let this be my only vow.[xlviii]
dper na rgyal po'i mi 'ga' zhig / skye bo mang la gnod byed kyang / / skye bo mig rgyang ring po dag / nus kyang slar gnod mi byed de/ /
When, for example, a king’s servant torments the people, The far-sighted among them can’t do anything about it,
'di ltar de gcig ma yin gyi/ / rgyal po'i mthu stobs de yi mthu/ / de bzhin gnod byed nyam chung ba/ / 'ga' yang khyad du gsad mi bya/ /
Because he is not alone; The king’s power is his to call on. In the same way, you should not despise A powerless person who is causing trouble,
'di ltar dmyal ba'i srung ma dang / / thugs rje ldan rnams de yi dpung / / des na dmangs kyis rgyal gtum bzhin/ / sems can rnams ni mgu bar bya/ /
Because he has the power of The guardians of hell and the Compassionate Ones. Therefore, you should please sentient beings, As a minister would a king with a bad temper.
rgyal po lta zhig khros na yang / / sems can mi mgu byas pa yis/ / myong bar 'gyur ba gang yin pa/ / dmyal ba'i gnod pa des byed dam/ /
[157] What could an angry king do That would be equal to the torments of hell, Which someone who has made sentient beings suffer Will indeed experience?
rgyal po lta zhig mgu na yang / / sems can mgu bar byas pa yi/ / thob par 'gyur ba gang yin pa/ / sangs rgyas nyid sbyin mi srid do/ /
What could a satisfied king give That would be equal to Buddhahood, Which someone who has made sentient beings happy Will indeed experience?
sems can mgu las byung ba yi/ / ma 'ongs sangs rgyas 'grub lta zhog / tshe 'di nyid la dpal chen dang / / grags dang skyid gyur cis ma mthong / /
Forget about attaining Buddhahood in the future! Why don’t you see that in this very life, Good fortune, fame, and favorable circumstances Come from making sentient beings happy?
mdzes pa nyid dang nad med dang / / rab dga' yun ring 'tsho ba dang / / 'khor los sgyur ba'i bde rgyas ni/ / 'khor tshe bzod pas thob par byed/ /
While still in cyclic existence, the patient person Attains physical beauty, health, joy, Long life, prosperity, And the happiness of a world-emperor.[17]
byams sems ldan la mchod byas gang / / de ni sems can che ba nyid/ / sangs rgyas dang ba'i bsod nams gang / / de ni sangs rgyas che ba nyid/ /

That those who have lovingkindness [towards sentient beings] are honorable— This is the greatness of sentient beings. That goodness comes from trusting the Buddhas— This is the greatness of the Buddhas.

de lta bas na zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las kyang / byams pa bsgoms pa'i 'bras bu brjod de/ / mchod pa tshad med rnam mang ji snyed pa/ / zhing ni bye ba khrag khrig gtams snyed du/ / skyes bu mchog la mchod pa de byas pas/ / byams pa'i sems la grangs dang char mi phod/ / ces bya ba'o/ /

Therefore the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[xlix] If they make innumerable offerings of many kinds, A hundred million hundreds of trillions of fields, Those offerings, made to the unequalled Guides,[l] Don’t add up to a small part of the mind of lovingkindness.

de lta bas na sbyin pa'i gnas chen po de lta bu dag la khengs pa rtag tu spang bar bya/ khengs pa 'di ni tshul bzhin ma yin pa yid la byed pa las byung ba'i phyir de la mi 'jug par sgrim par bya ste/ dkon mchog sprin las ji skad du/ rigs kyi bu ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid la byed pa dang bral ba yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' gcig pu lkog tu song ste/ rab tu dben par gnas shing / 'di ltar bdag ni ma 'dres par gnas pa ste/ bdag ni rab tu dben pa na gnas pa'o/ / bdag ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos 'dul ba la zhugs pa'o/ / dge sbyong ngam bram ze gzhan gang yin pa dag ni kun kyang 'dres pas gnas pa/ 'du 'dzi mang ba de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos 'dul ba las nyams pa'o snyam du sems mi skyed de/ de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid la byed pa dang bral ba yin no zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

Therefore, in this way, you should always give up arrogance towards those who are worthy of great honor. And this arrogance arises from the inappropriate application of attention. So make an effort not to engage in that. As the Cloud of Jewels says, [158] And how, noble sir, is a bodhisattva free from the inappropriate application of attention? Here a solitary bodhisattva, having gone into solitude and living completely alone, does not think, “I live without mixing with others. I live in solitude. I practice well the Teachings and the monastic code of the Tathāgata. But those other religious wanderers or Brahmins all live together with others, engage in a lot of social interactions, and are not restrained by the Teachings and the monastic code of the Tathāgata.” In this way a bodhisattva is free from the inappropriate application of attention.

yang de nyid las 'di la byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus rtsom pa ni brtson 'grus de'i ro myong bar mi byed de/ brtson 'grus des gzhan la mi smod bdag la mi stod do/ / de 'di snyam du shes rab dang ldan pa'i rang bzhin can su zhig bdag gi las la brtson pas gzhan la smod snyam du sems te/ rigs kyi bu de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' bsnyems pa med pa'i brtson 'grus can yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

Moreover, the same text says, Here bodhisattvas, in developing perseverance, do not savor the experience of that perseverance, and do not, due to that perseverance, boast about themselves and put others down. They think, “What wise person, making an effort to do her own inner work, would criticize others?” In this way, a bodhisattva is not made arrogant by perseverance.

bsod nams bsrung ba mdor bsdus pa ni 'di yin te/ byang chub tu yongs su bsngo ba gang yin pa'o/ /ji skad du 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa'i mdo las/ dge ba'i rtsa ba byang chub tu yongs su bsngos pa ni byang chub kyi snying po la 'dug gi bar du bar ma dor 'ga' yang zad par mi 'gyur ro/ / btsun pa sha ra dwa ti'i bu 'di lta ste/ dper na chu'i thigs pa rgya mtsho chen por lhung ba ni bskal pa'i mthar thug gi bar du bar ma dor zad pa med do zhes gsungs so/ /

In brief, however, protecting goodness is dedicating it to Awakening. For the noble Akṣayamati Sūtra says, When wholesome actions are dedicated to Awakening, they do not waste away until you sit upon the seat of Awakening. As, for example, Reverend Śāradvatīputra, when a drop of water has fallen into the great ocean, it does not waste away until the end of an aeon.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las longs spyod dang bsod nams bsrung ba'i le'u ste bdun pa'o// //
[sdig pa sbyang ba]
8. Clearing Away Vile Actions
lus la sogs pa gsum bsrung ba bshad zin te/ da ni dag pa brjod par bya'o/ / ci'i don du zhe na/
I HAVE NOW explained how to protect all three things: the body, [possessions, and goodness.] Now, purification needs to be explained.
lus ni rnam par sbyang byas na/ / phan pa'i longs spyod 'gyur ba ste/ / 'bras chan legs par tshos pa dang / / gzeg med lus can phan pa 'dra/ /
[17] The enjoyment of a purified body Is healthy for embodied beings, Just like well-prepared boiled rice Without husk-powder.[i]

'phags pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba'i mdo las ji skad du gang yang grong khyer chen po dag gi dur khrod chen po srog chags brgya stong du mas gang bar gyur pa der yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po des bdag gi lus chen po shi zhing dus las 'das par ston to/ / der sems can dud 'gro'i skye gnas su gyur pa de dag gis ji tsam 'dod par sha la zos nas tshe'i mthar phyin te 'chi ba'i dus su gyur cing shi nas bde 'gro mtho ris kyi 'jig rten du lha'i nang du skye ba dang / de dag gi yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba'i bar gyi rgyur 'gyur ba gang yin pa de yang byang chub sems dpa' de nyid kyi sngon gyi smon lam yongs su dag pa'i phyir te/ sems can gang dag gis bdag 'chi ba'i dus su gyur pa'i sha zos pa de dag la de nyid mtho ris su skye ba nas yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba'i bar gyi rgyur gyur cig ces gang gis yun ring po nas smon lam btab ste tshul khrims dang ldan pa de'i bsam pa grub pa dang don du gnyer ba grub pa dang smon lam grub pa yin no zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

As the noble Sūtra on the Mysteries of the Tathāgata says, [159] In the great charnel grounds that are in large cities, crowded with many hundreds of thousands of living beings, that bodhisattva manifests his own huge dead body. There, sentient beings who have been born as animals eat as much flesh as they want. Later, when their lives are over, when they die, when their time comes to die, they are born in good rebirths, in the heavens, among the gods. And this becomes a cause [of good rebirths] for them until they attain Nirvāṇa, because of the purity of that bodhisattva’s previous vow. A long time ago, he made this vow: “For all those who may eat of my dead, deceased flesh, may that be the cause of their being born in the heavens until they attain Nirvāṇa.” As he is morally disciplined, his aspiration prayer succeeds; his vow prospers.

yang de nyid las de chos kyi skus rab tu phye bas na mthong bas kyang sems can rnams kyi don byed do/ / thos pa dang reg pas kyang sems can rnams kyi don byed do/ / zhi ba'i blo gros 'di lta ste dper na/ sman pa'i rgyal po 'tsho byed kyis rtsi thams cad bsdus te rtsi shing mang po las bu mo'i gzugs bzang zhing mdzes pa blta na sdug pa legs par byas te legs par zin cing legs par byi dor byas pa de 'ong ngam 'gro'am 'greng ngam 'dug gam nyal yang rtog pa med cing rnam par rtog pa med do/ / der nad pa gang dag btsun pa btsun pa rgyal po'am rgyal po'i blon po chen po'am rgyal po'i bu'am tshong dpon nam khyim bdag gam blon po'am rgyal phran gang dag 'ong ba de dag sman pa'i rgyal po 'tsho byed kyis sman gyi bu mo de dang de dag phrad ma thag tu nad thams cad byang ste nad med cing bde ba las nyams pa med par 'gyur ro/ / zhi ba'i blo gros sman pa gzhan la med pa sman pa'i rgyal po 'tsho byed kyis 'jig rten gyi nad gso ba'i shes pa la ltos/ zhi ba'i blo gros de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' chos kyi skus rab tu phye ba yang sems can bud med dang skyes pa dang khye'u dang bu mo 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug gis yongs su gdungs pa ji snyed pa de dag gi lus la reg na/ reg ma thag tu de dag gi nyon mongs pa thams cad sel bar 'gyur ro/ / lus yongs su gdung ba dang bral bar yang shes so/ / 'di ni 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa' de nyid kyi sngon gyi smon lam shin tu yongs su dag pa'i phyir ro zhes gsungs te/ de'i don du lus sbyang bar bya'o/ / gzhan yang /

And the same text says, When someone is constituted by the Dharma body,[ii] sentient beings benefit just by looking at him. Sentient beings benefit just by hearing him, just by touching him. Śāntamati, for example, it’s like when Jīvaka, the king of physicians, collected together all kinds of medicines and made a solid mass of medicinal plant extracts in the form of a girl, lovely, pleasant to look at, well made, quite firm, well adorned. She came and went, stood up, sat down, and lay down, {without any intellect or conceptual thought.} When great men came there who were sick, kings, chief ministers,[iii] guild presidents, leading merchants, companions of kings, or vassal rulers, Jīvaka, the king of physicians, allowed them to have sex with the medicine girl. As soon as they were sexually united with her, all their illnesses were cured, and they became healthy and happy, without disease. Śāntamati, imagine if other physicians had the worldly knowledge of illness and medicine that Jīvaka had![iv] In just the same way, Śāntamati, however many sentient beings touch the body of that bodhisattva who is imbued with the power of the Dharma body, whether women, men, boys, or girls, if they are tormented by attraction, aversion, and delusion, merely by touching him all their reactive emotions are calmed, and they know that they are freed from bodily torment. This is because of the utter purity of the previous vow of that bodhisattva. Purify your body with this as your goal! And what is the problem with not purifying it?[v]
ji ltar lo thog rtswas khebs na/ / nad kyis zhum zhing rgyas mi 'gyur/ / de ltar sangs rgyas myu gu yang / / nyon mongs khebs na rgyas mi 'gyur/ /
[18] Just as, when grain is covered by grass, It becomes diseased and does not grow; In the same way, the sprout of Buddhahood Doesn’t grow if it is covered by reactive emotions.
gnyen pos bsal na 'phel bar 'gyur/ / zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /
If those are cleared away by a remedy, then it will grow. This is the intended meaning.
lus kyi dag pa gang zhe na/ sdig dang nyon mongs rnams sbyang yin/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis gsungs tshul du/ / 'bad pa med na ngan song 'gro/ /

[19] What is the purification of the body? It is clearing away vile actions and reactive emotions Through the essential meaning of the fully awakened Buddha’s teachings; [vi] But if you make no efforts, you go to the lower realms.

de la sdig pa sbyang ba ni chos bzhi bstan pa'i mdo las bstan te/ byams pa byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos bzhi dang ldan na sdig pa byas shing bsags pa zil gyis non par 'gyur ro/ / bzhi gang zhe na 'di lta ste/ rnam par sun 'byin pa kun tu spyod pa dang / gnyen po kun tu spyod pa dang / nyes pa las zlog pa'i stobs dang / rten gyi stobs so/ / de la rnam par sun 'byin pa kun tu spyod pa ni mi dge ba'i las spyod pa de la 'gyod pa mang ba yin no/ / de la gnyen po kun tu spyod pa ni mi dge ba'i las byas nas kyang dge ba'i las la shin tu brtson pa'o/ / de la nyes pa las zlog pa'i stobs ni sdom pa yang dag par blangs pas mi byed pa'i sdom pa thob pa'o/ / de la rten gyi stobs ni sangs rgyas dang chos dang dge 'dun la skyabs su 'gro ba dang byang chub kyi sems mi gtong ba ste/ de stobs dang ldan pa la brten pas sdig pas zil gyis gnon par mi nus so/ / byams pa byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos bzhi po de dag dang ldan na sdig pa byas shing bsags pa zil gyis non par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'o/ /

On this topic, clearing away vile actions is taught in the Sūtra on Four Qualities: Maitreya, a bodhisattva great being who has four qualities overcomes vile actions that have been done and accumulated. What are the four? They are: the practice of remorse; the practice of remedy; the power of resolve; and the power of reliance.[1] The practice of remorse is that you often regret whatever unwholesome actions you have done. The practice of remedy is that after you do something unwholesome, you make a greater effort to do wholesome actions. The power of resolve is that you undertake a vow, and you vow not to do that again. The power of reliance is that you go for refuge to the Buddha, the Dharma, and the community, and do not give up on the Awakening Mind. With a basis that is very strong, you cannot be overpowered by vile actions. Maitreya, a bodhisattva great being who has these four qualities overcomes vile actions that have been done and accumulated.

de la rnam par smod pa kun tu spyod pa ji ltar bsgom par bya zhe na/ gser 'od dam pa'i mdo las ji skad bstan pa lta bu ste/ sangs rgyas rkang gnyis dam pa dag / thugs brtse thugs rje ldan pa'i thugs/ / gang dag phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten na/ / bzhugs pa bdag la dgongs su gsol/ / bdag gis sngon chad sdig pa'i las/ / shin tu mi bzad gang bgyis pa/ / stobs bcu'i spyan sngar mchis nas ni/ / de dag thams cad bshags par bgyi/ /

Here, how should you cultivate the practice of remorse? As the Sutra of Golden Light[2] says, May the Buddhas, the best of bipeds Whose hearts are compassionate and merciful, Located in all ten directions, [161] Watch over me;[vii] All the cruel, vile actions I have done in the past, I confess in the presence Of those who have the ten powers.
pha ma dag tu mi 'dzin dang / / sangs rgyas rnams su mi 'dzin dang / / dge ba dag tu mi 'dzin pas/ / sdig pa bdag gis gang bgyis dang / /
Whatever vile actions I have done Heedless of my parents, Heedless of the Buddhas, Heedless of what is wholesome;
phyug pa'i rgyags pas dregs pa dang / / rigs dang longs spyod rgyags pa dang / / gzhon pa'i rgyags pas dregs pa yis/ / bdag gis sdig pa gang bgyis dang / /
[162] And whatever vile actions I have done Drunk with the intoxication of political power,[viii] Made drunk by family and possessions, Drunk with the intoxication of youth;
nyes pa'i dmigs su ma mthong bas/ / nyes pa bgyis pa'i las dang ni/ / nyes par bsags shing nyes smras pa'i/ / sdig las bdag gis gang bgyis dang / /
And whatever vile actions I have done Not seeing the danger, Through bad thoughts, words, And also deeds;

byis pa'i blo yis 'jug pa dang / / mi shes mun pa'i sems dang ni/ / sdig pa'i grogs po'i dbang gyur dang / / nyon mongs rnam par 'khrug sems dang / / rtsed mo dga' ba'i dbang nyid dang / / mya ngan dang ni nad dbang dang / / nor gyis ma chog nyes pa yis/ / bdag gis sdig pa gang bgyis dang / /

And whatever vile actions I have done Behaving like a complete fool With intentions distorted by ignorance, And due to the influence of bad friends, With intentions bewildered by reactive emotions, Under the influence of pleasure and play, Or under the influence of sorrow and disease, Or due to the fault of an insatiable desire for wealth;
'phags min skye bo 'dre ba dang / / phrag dog ser sna sgyu dang ni/ / g.yo dang dbul ba'i nyes pa yis/ / bdag gis sdig pa gang bgyis dang / /
And whatever vile actions I have done Because of social interactions with ignoble people Or because of envy and greed, Or due to dishonesty or poverty;
phongs dang rgud pa'i dus kyi tshe/ / 'dod pa rnams kyi 'jigs rgyu dang / / phyug po ma yin gyur pa yis/ / bdag gis sdig pa gang bgyis dang / /
And whatever vile actions I have done In situations of disaster and misfortune, Or caused by fear due to sensual desires, And also while lacking any political power;
g.yo ba'i sems kyi dbang nyid dang / / 'dod dang khro ba'i dbang dag dang / / bkres dang skom gyis nyen pa yis/ / bdag gis sdig pa gang bgyis dang / /
And whatever vile actions I have done Under the influence of a distracted mind, Or under the influence of sensual desires and anger And while tormented by hunger and thirst,
bza' ba dag dang btung ba dang / / bud med rgyu dang gos kyi phyir/ / nyon mongs gdung ba sna tshogs kyis/ / bdag gis sdig pa gang bgyis dang / /
And whatever vile actions I have done In order to get drink, food, and clothes And for the sake of women, On fire with various reactive emotions—
lus dang ngag dang yid kyi sdig / nyes spyad rnam pa gsum bsags ni/ / 'di 'dra'i tshul gyis gang bgyis pa/ / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
Whatever I have done badly and accumulated, In thought, word, and deed, all three, Any bad actions of these kinds, I confess them all.
sangs rgyas rnams dang chos rnams dang / / de bzhin nyan thos rnams la yang / / gus pa ma lags gang bgyis pa/ / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
And any disrespect I may have shown To the Buddhas and their teachings, And equally, to the Disciples, I confess it all.[3]
gang yang rang sangs rgyas rnams dang / / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la yang / / gus pa ma lags bgyis pa rnams/ / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
And any disrespect I may have shown To the Solitary Sages, Or to the bodhisattvas, I confess it all.
dam chos smra ba rnams la yang / / gus pa ma lags bgyis pa dang / / chos la'ang gus par ma bgyis pa/ / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
Any disrespect I may have shown To the teachers of the holy Dharma, Or to those who have abilities, I confess it all.[4]
bdag gis rtag tu mi shes pas/ / dam pa'i chos ni spangs pa dang / / pha ma rnams la ma gus dang / / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
If at any time I have ignorantly Rejected the holy Dharma, Or shown disrespect to my parents, I confess it all.
blun pa dang ni byis pa dang / / 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug dang / / nga rgyal dregs pas bsgribs bgyis pa/ / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
[Whatever I have done] out of stupidity and out of foolishness, Out of the distortions of conceit and pride, Out of attraction, aversion, or delusion, I confess it all.
bdag gis phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten du/ / stobs bcu rnams la mchod par bgyi/ / bdag gis phyogs bcu'i sems can rnams/ / sdug bsngal kun las gdon par bgyi/ /
{I make offerings to those who have the ten powers Throughout the world, in the ten directions. I will deliver from all suffering The sentient beings in the ten directions.
sems can bsam gyis mi khyab kun/ / sa bcu la ni dgod par bgyi/ / sa bcu la ni gnas nas kyang / / thams cad de bzhin gshegs gyur cig /
I will establish them in the Ten Stages, And after they have been through the Ten Stages, May they all become Buddhas.
ji srid sdug bsngal rgya mtsho las/ / de kun mthar bgyi nus srid du/ / sems can re re'i phyir yang ni/ / bskal pa bye bar spyad par bgyi/ /
May I practice for ten million aeons Until I can bring Each and every sentient being To the shore of the ocean of suffering.
gser 'od dam pa zhes bgyi ba/ / las rnams thams cad byang bgyid pa/ / zab mo dag ni ston pa 'di/ / sems can de dag bstan par bgyi/ /
The holy Sūtra of Golden Light Causes all karma to be cleared away. May I teach to all sentient beings This profound teaching.

gang gis bskal pa stong rnams su/ / sdig pa shin tu mi bzad bgyis/ / lan cig rab tu bshags pa yis/ / de dag thams cad byang bar 'gyur/ / gang gis las kyi sgrib pa rnams/ / myur du yang dag zad 'gyur ba/ / gser 'od dam pa dge ba yis/ / bshags pa 'di dag bshags nas ni/ /

Extremely cruel vile actions Done over a thousand aeons— If you confess them once, They all can be cleared away When you follow this ritual of confession, Through the goodness of the holy Sūtra of Golden Light, By which karmic distortions Can quickly come to be exhausted in the right way.
rin chen 'byung gnas mchog bcu po/ / sa bcu la ni gnas par bgyi/ / sangs rgyas yon tan snang bar bgyi/ / srid pa'i mtsho las bsgral bar bgyi/ /
You will come to abide in the Ten Stages, The ten supreme sources of precious jewels, The abilities of Buddhas will appear in you And you will be set free from the lake of cyclic existence.
sangs rgyas rgya mtsho chu bo dang / / yon tan rgya mtsho zab mo de/ / sangs rgyas yon tan bsam yas kyis/ / thams cad mkhyen du rdzogs par bgyi/ /
You will fully perfect complete knowing, Along with the inconceivable abilities of a Buddha, That deep ocean of abilities, The water of the ocean of the Buddhas.
ting 'dzin brgya phrag stong rnams dang / / gzungs rnams bsam gyis mi khyab dang / / dbang stobs byang chub yan lag gis/ / stobs bcu dam par 'gyur bar bgyi/ /
You will gain a hundred thousand meditative absorptions, And inconceivable mnemonic powers; By means of the powerful aspects of Awakening, You will gain the holy ten powers.}[5]
dgongs pa'i thugs kyis sangs rgyas rnams/ / bdag la rnam par gzigs su gsol/ / thugs rje ldan pa'i thugs kyis ni/ / nongs par rab tu gzung du gsol/ /
May the Buddhas, with attentive hearts, Gaze upon me. With hearts full of compassion, [163] May they take away my errors.
bdag gis bskal pa brgya rnams su/ / sngan chad sdig pa gang bgyis pa/ / de phyir bdag ni mya ngan sems/ / phongs dang mya ngan 'jigs pas gzir/ /
The vile actions I have done Over the past hundred aeons— Because of that, I am full of sorrow, An object of pity, moved by fear.
sdig pa'i las la 'jigs par bgyi/ / yid ni rtag tu dman par gyur/ / gang dang gang du spyod bgyid pa/ / bdag ni gang du'ang dga' ma mchis/ /
Miserable, I continually[ix] Am afraid of my vile actions. Wherever I go,[x] I have no power whatsoever.
sangs rgyas thams cad thugs rje ldan/ / 'gro ba kun gyi 'jigs sel bas/ / nongs par rab tu gzung du gsol/ / 'jigs pa dag las bdag thar mdzod/ /
All the compassionate Buddhas Take away all the fears of the world. May they take away my errors; May they set me free from danger.
bdag gi nyon mongs las rnams kyi/ / dri ma de bzhin gshegs pas sol/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyis bdag la ni/ / snying rje'i chu yis bkru bar gsol/ /
May the Tathāgatas carry away from me The results of acting out of reactive emotions. May the Buddhas wash me With the water of compassion.
sdig pa thams cad bshags par bgyi/ / sngon chad bdag gis gang bgyis dang / / de ltar bdag gi sdig pa gang / / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
I confess all the vile actions Which I have done in the past; And all the vile actions I am doing in the present, [164] I confess them all.
nongs par bgyis pa'i las rnams kun/ / slan chad mi bgyid bsdams par bgyi/ / bdag gis nongs par bgyis pa gang / / sdig de bcab par mi bgyi'o/ /
I make a vow to stop my errors, All badly done actions. Whatever I have done badly, I will not hide those vile actions.
lus kyi las ni rnam gsum dang / / ngag gi rnam pa bzhi dag dang / / yid kyi rnam pa gsum po rnams/ / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
The three unwholesome courses of bodily action, And the four of speech, And the three of mind— All that I confess.[6]
lus kyis bgyis dang ngag gi las/ / yid kyis rnam par bsams pa dang / / las rnams bcu po bgyis pa dag / de dag thams cad bdag 'chags so/ /
Whichever of the ten unwholesome courses of action I have done in word or deed Or thought about in my mind, I confess them all.
mi dge'i las bcu spangs nas su/ / dge ba bcu po bsten bgyis te/ / sa bcu la ni bdag gnas bgyi/ / stobs bcu mchog tu 'gyur bar bgyi/ /
{Guarding against the ten unwholesome courses of action, I will rely on the ten wholesome courses of action. I will abide on the Ten Stages And supremely develop the ten powers.}
bdag gi sdig pa'i las gang dag / mi 'dod 'bras bu thob bgyid pa/ / sangs rgyas spyan sngar mchis nas ni/ / de dag thams cad bshags par bgyi/ /
All my vile actions Which lead to unwanted results, Standing before the Buddhas, I confess them all.
'dzam bu'i gling 'dir gang dag gang / / 'jig rten khams ni gzhan dag tu/ / gang rnams dge ba'i las bgyid pa/ / de dag kun la yi rang ngo / /
{All the wholesome actions which have been done [by anyone], Whether here on Earth Or in other world-realms, I rejoice in them all.
lus dang ngag dang yid kyis kyang / / bdag gis bsod nams gang bsgrubs pa/ / bdag ni dge ba'i rtsa ba des/ / byang chub mchog la reg par bgyi/ /
Whatever goodness I have created In thought, word, and deed, By those wholesome actions I will reach supreme Awakening.}
srid mtsho nyam ngar byis pas blo yis ni/ / shin tu mi bzad sdig pa gang bgyis pa/ / stobs bcu mnga' ba'i spyan sngar mchis nas ni/ / sdig pa de kun so sor bshags par bgyi/ /
Whatever cruel, vile actions I have foolishly done in the dangerous lake of cyclic existence,[xi] under the gaze of those who have the ten powers, I confess them all.

skye ba nyam nga srid pa nyam nga dang / / 'jig rten nyam nga g.yo sems nyam nga bar/ / lus kyi spyod pa nyam nga sna tshogs kyis/ / bdag gis sdig pa gang bsags de 'chags so/ / byis pa blun byas nyon mongs nyam nga dang / / sdig pa'i grogs dang phrad pa nyam nga dang / / srid pa nyam nga 'dod chags nyam nga dang / / zhe sdang gti mug mun pa nyam nga dang / / dal ba'i nyam nga dus kyi nyam nga dang / / bsod nams bsgrub pa nyam nga dag gis kyang / / rgyal ba yang dag mngon sum mchis nas ni/ / sdig pa de kun so sor bshags par bgyi/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

And I confess all those vile actions I have accumulated in the dangerous situation of birth, the dangerous situation of appearing in various bodies,[xii] the dangerous situation of the world, the dangerous situation of having a distracted mind, the dangerous situation of being made foolish and stupid by reactive emotions, the dangerous situation of meeting with bad friends, the dangerous situation of fear, the dangerous situation of attraction, the dangerous situations of aversion, delusion, and darkness, the dangerous situation of having the opportunity to practice, the dangerous situation of death,[xiii] and the dangerous situation of acquiring goodness. Face to face with and surrounded by the Victors,[xiv] I confess all my vile actions to them.

khyad par du na byang chub sems dpa'i ltung ba lci ba dang yang ba rnams bshags pa ni 'phags pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa las gsungs pa gang yin pa'o/ / ltung ba lci ba yang gang yin zhe na/ spyir de las gsungs pa ni/ nye ba 'khor gal te theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la 'dod chags dang ldan pa'i ltung ba gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed byung la/ gang zhe sdang dang ldan pa'i ltung ba gang yin pa ni gcig byung na byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa brtsan par bya na/ de gnyis las gang zhe sdang dang ldan na ltung ba de ni shin tu lci'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ nye ba 'khor zhe sdang gis ni sems can yongs su gtong bar byed la/ 'dod chags ni sems can sdud par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / nye ba 'khor de la nyon mongs pa gang sems can sdud par 'gyur ba de la ni byang chub sems dpa' 'dzem pa'ang med 'jigs pa yang med do/ /

In particular, the noble Inquiry of Upāli explains the confession of grave[xv] and minor downfalls of bodhisattvas: Now, what is a grave downfall? That is said to be a shared teaching. Upāli, suppose a bodhisattva great being who is correctly practicing the Great Way were to undergo downfalls motivated by attraction as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, and another were to undergo one downfall motivated by aversion. This should be assessed according to the Way of the bodhisattvas. Of these two, the one motivated by aversion is more grave. Why is that? Upāli, aversion operates to make you give up on sentient beings. Attraction operates to bring sentient beings together. Upāli, when a reactive emotion operates to bring sentient beings together, there is no deception or danger for a bodhisattva in that
de bzhin du sbyar te/

nye ba 'khor de lta bas na khyod la 'dod chags dang ldan pa'i ltung ba thams cad ni ltung ba ma yin par bshad do zhes bya'o/ / 'di la dgongs pa gang zhe na/ sems can sdud pa nyid de sngar bye brag tu byas pa'i phyir ro/ / bstan pa 'di ni lhag pa'i bsam pa dang snying brtse ba dang ldan pa las yin te/ de nyid las de ma thag tu nye ba 'khor/ de la gang thabs la mi mkhas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de dag ni 'dod chags dang ldan pas 'jigs kyi zhe sdang dang ldan pas ni ma yin no/ / nye ba 'khor byang chub sems dpa' gang dag thabs la mkhas pa de dag ni zhe sdang dang ldan pa'i ltung bas 'jigs kyi 'dod chags dang ldan pas ni ma yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

Therefore, Upāli, I say to you that downfalls motivated by attraction are not downfalls.[xvi] What is the intended meaning here? [The statement applies only] with the previously stated qualification, “bringing sentient beings together.” This instruction is for people who have higher intention and compassion, because immediately after, the same text says: [165] Upāli, bodhisattvas who are not skilled in means are in danger from downfalls motivated by attraction.[xvii] Bodhisattvas who are skilled in means are in danger from downfalls motivated by aversion, but not from those motivated by attraction.

thabs mkhas pa yang gang zhe na/ gang dag shes rab dang snying rje gnyis kyis sems can gtong ba las zlog pa'o/ / gnyi ga ltar yang sems can gtong bar 'gyur te/ shes rab gcig pus ni sdug bsngal stong pa nyid du khong du chud pa'i phyir dang / snying rje gcig pus ni nyon mongs pa'i dbang gis ring por mi thogs par snying rje nyams par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / thabs la mkhas pa'i mdo las kyang /

Now, who has skill in means? Those who, with both wisdom and compassion, turn away from giving up on sentient beings. For giving up on sentient beings can happen in two ways. With only wisdom, it happens because of recognizing the emptiness of suffering. And with only compassion, due to the influence of reactive emotions, compassion is quickly lost. As the Skill in Means Sūtra says,[7]

rigs kyi bu dper na/ gsang sngags dang rig sngags 'dzin pa'i mi'i rgyal pos bzung ste/ thag pa lnga'i bcing bas bcings su zin kyang de gang gi tshe 'gro ba 'dod pa de'i tshe gsang sngags dang rig sngags kyi stobs bskyed pa gcig gis bcings pa thams cad gtubs te 'gro'o/ / rigs kyi bu de bzhin du/ byang chub sems dpa' thabs la mkhas pa yang gang gi tshe 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga las dga' bar myong zhing de dag dang lang long du gyur pas gnas kyang gang gi tshe 'dod par gyur pa de'i tshe shes rab kyi stobs bskyed pa dang thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi sems gcig gis 'dod pa'i yon tan thams cad bcom nas tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du skye'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Noble sir, for example, it’s like a sorcerer who is seized by a king and bound with five ropes. Whenever he wants to escape, he cuts all the bonds with the power of just one awareness mantra and departs. In the same way, noble sir, a bodhisattva who is skilled in means delights in the pleasures of the five senses and lives abiding in them. But whenever he wishes, he arouses one thought of complete knowing based on the power of wisdom, and even after enjoying all the pleasures of the senses,[xviii] is reborn at death in the world of Brahmā.

zhe sdang la yang de ltar ci'i phyir 'dod par mi byed ce na/ rang bzhin gyis kha na ma tho ba dang bcas pa'i phyir dang snying rje dang bral bas na thabs nyid mi srid pa'i phyir ro/ / yang na gzhan gyi don grub pa rang gi don las shin tu lci bar lhag par mos pa na/ khro ba la gnas pas kyang gzhan la rjes su bstan nas gdung ba sngon du 'gro bas de ma thag tu phyin chad mi byed pa'i sdom pa 'thob po/ / gnod pa las bzlog pa'i phyir khros pa la nyes pa ci yod ce na/ skabs phye na de'i bag chags gsos par 'gyur bas snying rje nyams pa'i nyes par 'gyur ro/ / de bcad na rtsa ba 'chad par 'gyur ro zhes 'og nas bstan par bya'o/ / gal te sems can de la phan du zin kyang byang chub sems dpa' snying rje nyams pas sems can gyi don chen po'i rgyun nyams par 'gyur ro/ / 'phags pa bden pa po'i le'u'i dpes ni snying rje la gnas pa yin par rig par bya'o/ / der ha cang snying rje bkag pa gang yin pa de ni 'jig rten gyi don la mkhas pas 'jig rten pa 'dun par bya ba'i phyir ro/ / zlog pa na yang gal te phan par 'dod pa'i byang chub sems dpa' la khong khro bar gyur na/ de yang byang chub sems dpa' ma yin par 'gyur zhing gnyi ga la gnod par 'gyur ro/ / 'dod chags kyang nyes pa yin te/ 'dod pa dag la brten pa'i mi/ / ldongs 'gyur pha ma gsod par 'gyur/ / 'dod bsten tshul khrims ldan pa'ang gsod/ / des na rtag tu spang bar bya/ / zhes bstan te/ bdag bde ba la chags pas ni gzhan gyi sdug bsngal yal bar 'dor bar mthong ngo zhe na/ gang gzhan gyi sdug bsngal bdag gi sdug bsngal du ma goms pa de la ni mthong ba bden te/ gang shin tu goms pa de la ni nyes pa gnyi ga mi 'byung ngo / /

Why don’t we hold the same thing about aversion? Because it is seriously reprehensible by nature, and because it is impossible for one who lacks compassion to have skillful means. But suppose you are strongly motivated to bring about benefit to others, or some very weighty benefit to yourself. And suppose that although you are overpowered by anger while scolding somebody else, immediately afterwards, you make a vow not to do the same thing again from now on. If you can prevent some harm through anger, what’s the problem? Well, there’s the problem of giving that reactive pattern an opportunity to work. There’s the problem of losing your compassion. And as we will see later on, there’s the problem of, while cutting that, cutting your own roots. Even if your anger was helpful to that sentient being, because of the loss of the bodhisattva’s compassion, great benefits to sentient beings would be lost as a consequence. [166] The allegory of the son who was[xix] full of compassion in the noble Chapter on Satyaka should be understood in this way. And this [anger] is strongly opposed to compassion; those who are knowledgeable about what benefits the world have as their goal to win over worldly people. Also, if a bodhisattva who wants to help and is trying to prevent [some harm] should develop hostility towards a genuine bodhisattva, that would be harmful to both of them.[xx] The problem with attraction is stated as follows: Those who indulge in sensual pleasures Become blind, and will kill their parents. Those who indulge in sensual pleasures also harm the morally disciplined; Therefore, always give them up. Those who do not repeatedly practice seeing others’ suffering as their own are truly seen to be attached to their own happiness and indifferent to the suffering of others. But for those who have repeatedly practiced this, both problems are impossible. As the Moon Lamp Sūtra says,[xxi]

zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las ji skad du/ kun dga' bo 'di lta ste/ dper na 'di la skyes bu la la zhig rkang pa nas spyi bo'i bar du 'bar bar gyur te rab tu 'bar zhing me lce gcig tu gyur pa de la/ skyes bu la la zhig der nye bar 'ongs te/ 'di skad du kye skyes bu tshur shog / lus la me 'bar ba ma zhi bar 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga dang phrad cing ldan par rtses shig dga' bar gyis shig dga' mgur spyod cig ces zer na kun dga' bo 'di ji snyam du sems/ skyes bu de lus la me 'bar ba ma zhi bar 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga dang phrad cing ldan par 'gyur te rtse ba dang dga' ba dang dga' mgur spyod par byed dam/

“For example, Ānanda, suppose someone was on fire from his feet to the top of his head, blazing, one single mass of flames. And suppose somebody else approached him and said, ‘Hey you, come over here! With the flames that are burning your body not extinguished,[8] obtain the pleasures of the five senses, and having them, play around, have fun, and enjoy yourself!’ Ānanda, what do you think about this? Would that person, with the flames burning his body not extinguished, obtain the pleasures of the five senses, and having them, play around, have fun, and enjoy himself?”

kun dga' bos gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo yongs su brtag pa bzung ste skyes bu de lus la me 'bar ba ma zhi bar 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga dang phrad cing ldan par 'gyur te/ rtse ba dang dga' ba dang dga' mgur spyod du zin kyang de bzhin gshegs pa sngon byang chub sems dpa'i spyad pa spyod pa na sems can rnams ngan song gsum gyis sdug bsngal bar gyur cing dbul ba dag mthong nas yid bde ba'am sems bde ba ma byung ngo zhes rgyas par gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

Ānanda said, “No indeed, Blessed One.” The Blessed One said, “Ānanda, we could suppose, hypothetically, that this person, with the flames burning his body not extinguished, might obtain the pleasures of the five senses, and having them, he might play around, have fun, and enjoy himself. But in the past the Tathāgata, while leading the bodhisattva’s way of life, seeing the wretched sentient beings suffering in the three lower realms, had neither happiness nor peace of mind.”[9][xxii] The detailed explanation follows.

'jig rten na yang bu gsal shing la bskyon pa mthong ba na pha ma la rang gi tshul dang mthun par snying rje ba'i dbang gis rang gi bde ba la mi chags par snang ngo / / dben pa zhig tu byas na khyo yod pa'am/ mgo gtsang ma rigs dang chos dang rgyal mtshan gyis bsrungs pa la yang rung ste 'dod pa la log par g.yem par mi 'gyur ro/ / sems can gyi don du 'gyur la sems can la yang mi gnod pa bsgrubs na nyes pa med do/ / yang dag par tshangs par spyod pa rnams ni don byas pa'i phyir de dag lam srid la sogs pa bzhin du ring du spang zhing mchod do/ / de lta na ni dge slong gis kyang bya bar 'gyur ro/ / de lta ma yin te/ de bzhin du tshangs par spyod pa'i rnam pas sems can gyi don bsgrub pa'i phyir ro/ / de skad du 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las/ des dus dang dus ma yin pa btang snyoms su bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / ci ste de las sems can gyi don du 'gyur ba lhag pa mthong na bslab pa dbul lo/ / bskal pa mang por goms pas bdag nyid du gyur pa'i snying rje chen po dang thabs la mkhas pa la sogs pa yongs su rdzogs pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba can gyi byang chub sems dpa' rnams la 'dod chags kyis bar du gcod par byed par 'gyur ram ci 'di ni mi srid pa nyid do/ /

[167] Also, in the world, when a father and mother see their son being impaled on a stake, then due to natural compassion, we observe that they have no desire for their own pleasure. In such a case, they would not engage in any secret sexual misconduct with anyone, whether married or unmarried, whether protected by their family, by the Dharma, or by the flag.[10] But if, when you consider the consequences, benefit to sentient beings would result, and no sentient beings are harmed, there is no problem. When women are correctly practicing celibacy, [sexual contact with them] could not possibly be beneficial; you should stay far away from them, and from those who should be revered, such as your mother, sister, and so on.[xxiii] And in the same way, a monk who behaved like this would be fallen.[xxiv] There is no other way than celibacy for him to benefit sentient beings. For the noble Akṣayamati Sūtra says, “He should be indifferent between ‘the right time’ and ‘the wrong time.’ ”[11] But if he sees a greater benefit to sentient beings, he should abandon the [monastic] training. {When bodhisattvas have developed and internalized great compassion and skill in means for many aeons, and have fully perfected their wholesome actions, it is impossible for attraction to become an obstacle for them.}

thabs la mkhas pa'i mdo las kyang bstan te/ bram ze'i khye'u skar ma lo bzhi khri nyis stong gi bar du tshangs par spyod pa'i dbang du byas nas des gom pa bdun pa la gnas te snying rje skyes nas bdag gi brtul zhugs 'di bshig ste/ sems can dmyal bar song bar gyur kyang sems can dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal de myong bar bzod kyi/ bud med 'di shir 'ong gis bde bar gyur cig ces rigs kyi bu bram ze'i khye'u skar ma de slar log ste bud med de la lag pa g.yas pa nas bzung nas sru mo khyod ci 'dod pa bya'i longs shig ces de skad ces smras so/ /

As the Skill in Means Sūtra also teaches,[12] in the story of the Brahmin youth Jyotis, who had practiced celibacy for forty-two thousand years:[13] He was seven steps away when compassion arose in him. He thought, “If I break my spiritual discipline, I may go to hell. But I can experience and patiently endure the pain of hell. May this woman not die, but be happy.” Noble sir, the Brahmin youth turned around, and holding that woman with his right hand,[14] he said, “Rise, sister.[xxv] I shall do whatever you want.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rigs kyi bu nga 'dod pa ngan pa dang ldan pa'i snying rje chen po'i sems bskyed pas kyang bskal pa khrir 'khor ba phyir bsnyil te spangs par gyur to/ / rigs kyi bu sems can gzhan gang dag sems can dmyal bar skye bar 'gyur ba des byang chub sems dpa' thabs la mkhas pa tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du skyes pa la ltos zhes gsungs so/ /

Noble sir, because I aroused a thought of great compassion, even though lowly and having to do with sensual desires, {my time in cyclic existence} was reduced by ten thousand aeons. Noble sir, take note: what would lead other sentient beings to hell can lead a bodhisattva who is skilled in means to rebirth in the world of Brahmā.

yang de nyid las/ gal te byang chub sems dpa' sems can gcig gi dge ba'i rtsa ba skye bar 'gyur ba lta na/ ltung ba ji lta bu byung ba bskal pa brgya stong du sems can dmyal bar 'tsho bar 'gyur ba de 'dra ba'i ltung ba byung yang bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' ltung ba byung ba dang sems can dmyal ba'i sdug bsngal de la spro ba nyid du bgyi ste/ sems can gcig po de'i dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su btang ba dang yongs su bri bar ni mi bgyi'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Moreover, the same text says:[15] Suppose that a bodhisattva could cause one sentient being to engage in wholesome actions, but in doing so would undergo a downfall that would lead to burning in hell for a hundred thousand aeons. Blessed One, the bodhisattva should enthusiastically undergo that downfall and experience the pain of hell, rather than sacrifice the welfare[xxvi] of that one sentient being.

yang de nyid las/ rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' thabs mkhas pa brgya la la la zhig tu sdig pa'i grogs po'i dbang gis nyes pa byung na de 'di ltar slob ste/ gal te bdag gis phung po 'di dag gis yongs su mya ngan las 'da' bar bya na ni bdag gi sems yongs su gdung ba dang ldan par yang 'gyur gyis 'di ltar bdag gis sems can yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug par gnas pa de lta bu'i go cha bgos la/ bdag gi sems la gdung bar ni mi bya'i/ ji lta ji ltar 'khor bar 'khor bar 'gyur ba de lta de ltar sems can yongs su smin par bgyi'o/ / ltung ba 'di yang chos bzhin du gso bar bya'o/ / phyis nyes par mi bya'o snyam du sems so/ / rigs kyi bu yongs su brtag pa bzung na gal te rab tu byung ba'i byang chub sems dpa' rtsa ba'i ltung ba bzhi po thams cad zhig par gyur kyang / thabs la mkhas pa 'dis sel bar byed pa lta na/ byang chub sems dpa' la ltung bar mi 'gyur bar nga smra'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Moreover, the same text says,[16] Noble sir, on the rare occasion when a bodhisattva who is skilled in means undergoes a downfall due to the influence of bad friends, that bodhisattva should train thus: “I should not bring these aggregates to Nirvāṇa.[xxvii] I should now prepare to wander in cyclic existence to the utmost limit, in order to help sentient beings to mature. My mind should not burn [with remorse]; for as long as I wander in cyclic existence [due to this downfall,] I will help sentient beings to mature. Also, I will remedy this downfall in accordance with the Dharma; and I will take a vow {not to do wrong} in the future.” [168] Noble sir, hypothetically, suppose that an ordained bodhisattva should commit all four of the root downfalls.[17] I say that if he removed them through this skill in means, that bodhisattva would be free from downfalls.

'di ni dkon mchog sprin las kyang gsal ba nyid de/ mtshams med pa byed par 'dod pa'i mi gsad par gnang ba'i phyir ro/ / nyan thos kyi 'dul ba las kyang / rtsa ba'i ltung ba'i gnas nyid la snying rje bas ri dwags la sogs pa btang bas nyes pa med par gsungs so/ / gang byang chub sems dpa' la 'dod chags skyes nas bde 'gro 'thob pa 'di ni 'dod chags yon tan can yin te khro ba ni de lta ma yin no/ /

The noble Cloud of Jewels states clearly that it is permissible to kill someone who is about to commit an action of immediate retribution. And also, in the monastic code of the disciples, a basis for a root downfall that is done out of compassion, such as to set free deer and so on, is said not to be a downfall.[18] And this is an advantage of attraction, that when a bodhisattva arouses attraction, a good rebirth may result. But the same is not true of anger.

'phags pa thabs la mkhas pa'i mdo las ji skad du/ byang chub sems dpa' dga' byed la bu mo dpal yon can gyi mchog chags par gyur pa'i dbang du byas nas/ / dga' byed smon lam phyi phyir 'debs pa ni/ / bud med gang dag chags sems kyis blta ba/ / de ni bud med lus kyang yongs spangs te/ / skyes bu spangs pa'i sems can 'gyur bar shog /

As the Skill in Means Sūtra says about the bodhisattva Priyaṃkara and the girl who was attracted to him, Dakṣinottarā,[xxviii] Priyaṃkara has a continuing vow That any woman who looks at him with thoughts of attraction Will leave behind her female state And become a male. What a lofty being![xxix]
gang gis sems can gzhan dag dmyal 'gro ba/ / des ni dpa' bo dag la chags bskyed na/ / mtho ris 'gro zhing skyes pa nyid 'gyur ba/ / de yi yon tan 'di 'dra kun dga' ltos/ /
See, Ānanda, his quality: That attraction which, towards others, would lead to hell, When it is generated towards these heroes, It leads to heaven and to being a male
de bzhin du sbyar te/ /
su zhig rtsi rgyal grags pa chen po yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams la zhe sdang skyed/ / de dag nyon mongs las kyang bde sbyin na/ / de la bkur sti byed pa smos ci dgos/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
Who would arouse aversion against bodhisattvas, Those famous medicine kings? They give happiness even to those who have that reactive emotion. How much more so to those who honor them![19]

de ltar sems can gyi don gyi thabs gzhan med na/ 'dod chags las byung ba'i nyes pa yang nyes pa ma yin par bshad do/ / thabs la mkhas pa'i mdo las kyang / smad 'tshong ma ltar don byed nas byang chub sems dpa' btang snyoms rjes su byed de sems can de 'dor ro zhes rgyas par gsungs so/ / sa thob pa pha rol tu phyin pa drug spyad pa la 'di bsam par bya'i gzhan la ni ma yin no/ / de ltar zhar la 'ongs pa yin te re zhig gzhag go/ / de'i phyir zhe sdang skabs dbye bar mi bya'o/ /

In the same way, if there is no other method of benefiting sentient beings, a fault arisen from attraction is said not to be a fault. As the Skill in Means Sūtra explains at length, a bodhisattva is like a whore, and after having benefited sentient beings, has equanimity and leaves them behind.[20] But this should be understood to refer to those who are practicing the Six Perfections and have attained the Stages, and not to others.[xxx]

nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa las kyang bka' stsal te/ shA ri'i bu byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi kha na ma tho ba chen po dang bcas pa'i ltung ba gnyis te/ gnyis gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ zhe sdang dang ldan pa dang / gti mug dang ldan pa'o/ /

Therefore, aversion should be given no opportunity. For the Inquiry of Upāli says, [169] For bodhisattvas, Śāriputra, there are two types of extremely reprehensible downfalls. What are the two? Those accompanied by aversion, and those accompanied by delusion
de bzhin du sbyar te/

shA ri'i bu de la byang chub sems dpa' dang pos thog ma'i ltung ba sde bcu las lci ba rnams bshags par bya'o/ / ltung ba yod pa sde lnga las lci ba rnams bshags par bya'o/ / shA ri'i bu bud med kyi lag nas 'dzin pa dang / mig gis blta ba dang / gnod sems kyang ltung ba ste gang zag gcig gam gnyis la yang bshags par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' mtshams med pa lnga dang ldan pa'i ltung ba dang / bud med las ltung ba byung ba dang lag pa las ltung ba byung ba dang khye'u las ltung ba byung ba dang / mchod rten las ltung ba byung ba dang / dge 'dun las ltung ba byung ba dang / de las gzhan pa'i ltung ba lci ba rnams ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das sum cu rtsa lnga la gcig pos nyin mtshan du ltung ba lci ba rnams bshags par bya'o/ /

Here, Śāriputra, the first type of downfall should be confessed honestly to a group of ten monks. The downfall with the hand[xxxi] should be confessed as grave to a group of five monks. Taking a woman by the hand, looking at her with the eyes, and the downfall of malice should be confessed as grave to one person or to two people. As for downfalls based on the five actions of immediate retribution, downfalls with women, downfalls with girls, downfalls with the hand, downfalls with stūpas, and downfalls with the religious community, as well as other grave downfalls, should be confessed as grave downfalls, both day and night, by oneself alone, to the thirty-five Buddhas, the Blessed Ones.

de la ltung ba bshags pa ni 'di lta ste/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba sangs rgyas la skyabs su mchi'o/ / chos la skyabs su mchi'o/ / dge 'dun la skyabs su mchi'o/ / de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas shAkya thub pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rdo rje snying pos rab tu 'joms pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rin chen 'od 'phro la phyag 'tshal lo/ / klu dbang gi rgyal po la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dpa' bo'i sde la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dpal dgyes la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rin chen me la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rin chen zla 'od la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mthong ba don yod la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rin chen zla ba la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dri ma med pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dpas byin la phyag 'tshal lo/ / tshangs pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / tshangs pas byin la phyag 'tshal lo/ / chu lha la phyag 'tshal lo/ / chu lha'i lha la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dpal bzang la phyag 'tshal lo/ / tsan+dan dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gzi brjid mtha' yas la phyag 'tshal lo/ / 'od dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mya ngan med pa'i dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sred med kyi bu la phyag 'tshal lo/ / me tog dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / de bzhin gshegs pa tshangs pa'i 'od zer rnam par rol pas mngon par mkhyen pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / de bzhin gshegs pa pad+ma'i 'od zer rnam par rol pas mngon par mkhyen pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / nor dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dran pa'i dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mtshan dpal shin tu yongs bsgrags la phyag 'tshal lo/ / dbang po tog gi rgyal mtshan gyi rgyal po la phyag 'tshal lo/ / shin tu rnam par gnon pa'i dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / g.yul las shin tu rnam par rgyal ba la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rnam par gnon pas gshegs pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / kun nas snang ba bkod pa'i dpal la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rin chen pad mos rnam par gnon pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rin po che pad+ma la rab tu bzhugs te ri dbang gi rgyal po la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

Here the confession ritual is: [170] I, [your name here,] take refuge in the Buddha. I take refuge in the Dharma. I take refuge in the Community. Homage to the Tathāgata, the Saint, the genuinely and fully awake Buddha Śākyamuni. Homage to Vajrapramardin. Homage to Ratnārcis. Homage to Nāgeśvararāja. Homage to Vīrasena. Homage to Vīranandin. Homage to Ratnaśrī. Homage to Ratnacandraprabhā. Homage to Amoghadarśin. Homage to Ratnacandra. Homage to Nirmala. Homage to Vimala. Homage to Śūradatta. Homage to Brahmaṇa. Homage to Brahmadatta. Homage to Varuṇa. Homage to Varuṇadeva. Homage to Bhadraśrī. Homage to Candanaśrī. Homage to Anantaujas. Homage to Prabhāśrī. Homage to Aśokaśrī. Homage to Nārāyaṇa. Homage to Kusumaśrī. Homage to the Tathāgata Brahmajyotirvikrīḍitābhijñā. Homage to Dhanaśrī. Homage to Smṛtiśrī. Homage to Suparikīrtitanāmadheyaśrī. Homage to Indraketudhvajarāja. Homage to Suvikrāntaśrī. Homage to Vicitrasaṃkrama. Homage to Vikrāntagamin. Homage to Samantāvabhāsavyūhaśrī. Homage to Ratnapadmavikrāmin. Homage to the Tathāgata, the Saint, the genuinely and fully awake Buddha Ratnapadmasupratiṣṭhitaśailendrarāja.

de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas ji snyed bzhugs te 'tsho zhing gzhes pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag bdag la dgongs su gsol/ /
May these, and however many other Tathāgatas, Saints, genuinely and fully awake Buddhas may exist, live and abide in all the world-realms—may those Buddhas, those Blessed Ones, pay attention to me!

gang bdag gis skye ba 'di dang skye ba gzhan dag thog ma ma mchis pa'i skye ba nas 'khor bar 'khor ba na/ sdig pa'i las bgyis pa dang / bgyid du stsal ba dang / bgyid pa la rjes su yi rang ba dang / mchod rten gyi dang dge 'dun gyi dang / phyogs bzhi'i dge 'dun gyi nor phrogs pa dang / 'phrog tu stsal ba dang 'phrog pa la rjes su yi rang bar gyur pa dang / mtshams ma mchis pa'i las bgyis pa dang bgyid du stsal ba dang bgyid pa la rjes su yi rang bar gyur pa dang / mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam bzung ste spyod pa dang spyod du stsal ba dang rjes su yi rang bar gyur pa dang / las kyi sgrib pa gang gis bsgribs nas sems can dmyal bar mchi ba'am/ dud 'gro'i skye gnas dang gshin rje'i yul du mchi ba'am/ yul mtha' 'khob kyi kla klo rnams su skye bar 'gyur ba'am/ lha tshe ring por skye bar 'gyur ba'am/ dbang po ma tshang bar 'gyur ba dang / log par lta ba yongs su 'dzin pa dang / sangs rgyas 'byung ba la mnyes par mi bgyid pa'i las kyi sgrib pa de dag thams cad ye shes su gyur pa/ spyan du gyur pa dpang du gyur pa tshad mar gyur pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mkhyen cing gzigs pa de dag gi spyan sngar so sor bshags so/ / mthol lo/ / mi 'chab bo/ / slan chad kyang sdom par bgyi'o/ /

In this life or in other lives, while wandering in beginningless cyclic existence, whatever wrong actions I may have done, or may have caused others to do, or may have rejoiced in; whatever property belonging to a stūpa, or belonging to the religious community,[xxxii] I may have stolen, or caused others to steal, or rejoiced in the theft of; whichever of the five actions of immediate retribution I may have done, or caused others to do, or rejoiced in the doing of; or whichever of the ten unwholesome courses of action I may have undertaken and done, or incited others to do, or rejoiced in the practice of; whatever karmic distortions there are, by which I might go to the hells, or to the animal realm, or to the world of Yama, or by which I might be born among the barbarians in a border region, or might be born among the long-lived gods, or might be born lacking one or more senses, or might hold wrong views, or might not rejoice at the arising of a Buddha—I confess all of those karmic distortions to the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, who are pristinely aware, who are witnesses, who are authorities, who know and see; I admit it and do not conceal it, and I make a vow for the future.
sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag bdag la dgongs su gsol/ /
May those Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, pay attention to me.

gang bdag gis skye ba 'di dang skye ba gzhan dang thog ma ma mchis pa'i skye ba nas 'khor bar 'khor ba'i tshe/ tha na dud 'gro'i skye gnas su gyur pa la zan chang cig tsam sbyin pa stsal ba dang / tshul khrims bsrungs par gyur pa dang / gang bdag gis tshangs par spyad par gnas pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba dang / gang bdag gis sems can yongs su smin par bgyis pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba dang / gang bdag gis byang chub kyi sems kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba dang / gang bdag gis bla na med pa'i ye shes kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag thams cad gcig tu bsdus/ gcig tu spungs btsal te/ mngon par bsdus nas/ bla ma'i yang bla ma bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu yongs su bsngo bas yongs su bsngo bar bgyi'o/ / ji ltar 'das pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis yongs su bsngos pa dang / ji ltar ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams yongs su bsngo bar 'gyur ba dang / ji ltar da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams yongs su bsngo ba de bzhin du bdag gis kyang yongs su bsngo'o/ / sdig pa thams cad so sor bshags so/ / bsod nams thams cad kyi rjes su yi rang ngo / / sangs rgyas thams cad la gsol ba gdab bo/ / bdag bla na med pa'i ye shes su gyur cig /

Whatever gifts I may have given in this life or in previous lives while wandering in beginningless cyclic existence, even so much as a mouthful of food to an animal; and whatever wholesome actions I may have done while protecting moral discipline or through the power of celibacy; and whatever wholesome actions I may have done while helping sentient beings to mature; and whatever is wholesome for me due to the Awakening Mind; and whatever wholesome actions I have that lead to the highest pristine awareness—having combined, gathered, and collected all of them together, I dedicate them to the most supreme, highest genuine full Awakening. Just as past Buddhas, Blessed Ones, dedicated goodness, and just as future Buddhas, Blessed Ones, will dedicate goodness, and just as the Buddhas, Blessed Ones of the present in all ten directions are dedicating goodness now, in the same way I also dedicate.[xxxiii] I rejoice in all the goodness [of everyone.] I request all the Buddhas [to remain in cyclic existence and teach.] May I attain the highest pristine awareness.

mi mchog rgyal ba gang dag da ltar bzhugs pa dang / / gang dag 'das pa dag dang de bzhin gang ma byon/ / yon tan bsngags pa mtha' yas rgya mtsho 'dra kun la/ / thal mo sbyar ba bgyis te skyabs su nye bar mchi/ / byang chub sems dpa'i gang dag snying rje'i stobs ldan zhing / / dpa' bo sems can rnams la phan phyir spyod byed pa/ / de dag rnams kyis skyabs med sdig byed bdag la skyobs/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag rnams la bdag skyabs mchi/

The Victors, supreme among humans, who have passed away, and equally those to come, and also those who exist now, whose praise is endless, whose abilities are like oceans[xxxiv]—with palms together, I approach them all for refuge. May those bodhisattvas who have the power of compassion, heroes who act in the world for the welfare of sentient beings, save me, a wrongdoer. I go for refuge to those great bodhisattvas.

shA ri'i bu 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa'/ sangs rgyas sum cu so lnga 'di dag la sogs pa de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi rjes su song ba'i yid la byed pas sdig pa thams cad rnam par dag par bya'o/ / de de ltar sdig pa thams cad rnam par dag pas/ sems can rnam par thar bar bya ba'i phyir de la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams zhal nye bar ston to/ / de bzhin du byis pa so so'i skye bo 'khrul pa rnams yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir tshig 'bru sna tshogs rnam par nye bar ston kyang chos kyi dbyings las mi g.yo'o/ /

Śāriputra, a bodhisattva who comes face to face with those thirty-five Buddhas in this way, and observes them attentively, clears away all vile actions. To someone who has cleared away all vile actions in this way, the Buddhas, Blessed Ones, show their faces, with the sole goal of setting sentient beings free. They show their appearance with various marks[xxxv] in order to help confused ordinary people to mature[xxxvi]
de bzhin du sbyar ro/ /

byang chub sems dpa' nyin mtshan du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag gi mtshan 'dzin pa dang yongs su brjod pa dang phung po gsum pa'i chos kyi rnam grangs klog pas ltung ba 'gyod pa las byung ba dang / ting nge 'dzin kyang thob pa gang yin pa de ni nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa thams cad kyis ltung ba 'gyod pa'i gnas rnam par sbyang bar mi nus so zhes gsungs so/ / rnam par sun 'byin pa kun du spyod pa bshad zin to/ / gnyen po kun du spyod pa bshad par bya ste/ de la mdo sde zab mo la brten pas kyang sdig pa zad par 'gyur te/ rdo rje gcod pa las ji skad du

The entire scriptural collections of the Disciples and Solitary Sages cannot clear away downfalls, the basis for regret, as well as a bodhisattva can, if that bodhisattva remembers these names, recites them day and night, reads this three-part religious discourse, is freed from regret due to downfalls, and attains stable attention. This concludes the explanation of the practice of remorse. Now, I will explain the practice of remedy. Here, through the study of profound scriptures, vile actions are destroyed. As the Diamond Sūtra (Vajra-cchedikā) says,[21]

rab 'byor rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang dag 'di lta bu'i mdo sde tshig 'di dag len pa dang / 'dzin pa dang klog pa dang / kun chub par byed pa de dag ni mnar bar 'gyur shin tu mnar bar 'gyur ro/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ rab 'byor 'di ltar sems can de dag gi tshe rabs snga ma'i mi dge ba'i las ngan song du skye bar 'gyur ba dang mthun pa byas pa gang dag yin pa'i tshe rabs snga ma'i mi dge ba'i las de dag tshe 'di la mnar bas 'byang bar 'gyur te/ sangs rgyas kyi byang chub kyang thob par 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ / stong pa nyid la mos pas kyang sdig pa dag par 'gyur te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mdzod kyi mdo las gsungs pa/

Subhūti, those gentlemen and ladies who will learn scriptures of this kind, {accept them, memorize them, read them} and fully understand them, they will be afflicted; they will be severely afflicted. Why is this? Subhūti, in previous lives those sentient beings have acted in bad ways conducive to rebirth in the lower realms. But having seen this Dharma, they will be afflicted by those actions {in this life,} get rid of them,[xxxvii] and attain the Awakening of the Buddhas. Vile actions can also be cleared away by having confidence in emptiness. For the Treasury of the Tathāgata Sūtra (Tathāgata-kośa-sūtra) says,

'od srungs gang gis pha yang yin la/ rang sangs rgyas kyang yin pa de srog bcad na de'i srog gcod pa'i nang nas ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste/ dkon mchog gsum gyi dkor rku ba 'di ni ma byin par len pa'i nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste ma yang yin la dgra bcom ma yang yin pa de la log par spyad pa 'di ni 'dod pa la log par spyod pa rnams kyi nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa la skur pa 'debs pa 'di ni rdzun du smra ba'i nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste/ 'phags pa'i dge 'dun la mi snyan pa brjod pa 'di ni phra ma'i nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste 'phags pa rnams la gnod pa 'di ni tshig rtsub po'i nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste chos 'dod pa rnams rnam par g.yeng bar byed pa 'di ni tshig kyal pa'i nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste mtshams med pa byed par shom pa 'di ni gnod sems kyi nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste/ yang dag par song ba rnams kyi rnyed pa 'phrog pa'i sems 'di ni brnab sems kyi nang na ma rungs pa'o/ / 'di lta ste lta bas gzings pa 'di ni log par lta ba'i nang na ma rungs pa ste/ 'od srungs 'di ni mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam 'di ni kha na ma tho ba chen po dang bcas pa'o/ /

[172] Kāśyapa, if someone kills his father, who is also a Solitary Sage, this is the worst form of murder. The worst form of taking what is not given is stealing the property of the Three Jewels. If someone rapes his mother, who is also a Saint, this is the worst form of sexual misconduct. The worst form of lying is falsely accusing the Tathāgata. The worst form of divisive speech is saying uncomplimentary things about the community of Noble Ones. The worst form of harsh speech is speaking to Noble Ones with contempt. The worst form of idle chitchat is distracting people who want to hear the Dharma. The worst form of malice is planning to commit the actions of immediate retribution. The worst form of covetousness is intending to steal wealth which others have obtained rightly. The worst form of wrong views is getting tangled up in views.[xxxviii] Kāśyapa, these are the worst forms of the ten unwholesome courses of action.

'od srungs gal te sems can gcig cig mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam kha na ma tho ba chen po dang bcas pa 'di dag dang ldan par gyur la/ de yang de bzhin gshegs pas rgyu dang rkyen dang ldan pa'i chos ston pa la 'jug ste/ 'di la bdag gam/ sems can nam/ srog gam/ gang zag gam/ gang byed pa'am/ gang myong ba ni gang yang med do snyam nas/ chos thams cad ni byas pa med pa dang / mngon par 'dus byas pa med pa dang / sgyu ma lta bu'i chos nyid dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa med pa'i chos nyid dang / rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba'i chos nyid la 'jug cing / chos thams cad gdod ma nas dag par yid ches te mos na/ sems can de dag ngan song du 'gro bar nga mi smra'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Kāśyapa, suppose a single sentient being were to commit all of these, the worst forms of the ten unwholesome courses of action. Suppose he were then introduced to the Tathāgata’s Dharma teaching about causes and conditions, as follows: “Here there is no self, no sentient being, no life-force, no person, no agent of actions, and no subject of experiences.” He is introduced to the way things are: not made, not compounded, and illusory; and to the way things are: free from reactive emotions. He is introduced to the natural sheer clarity of everything. He has faith and has confidence in the primordial purity of everything. I say: that sentient being will not go to the lower realms.

las kyi sgrib pa rnam par dag pa'i mdo las kyang / 'jam dpal gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' gang gis ltung ba la ltung ba ma yin par mthong ba dang 'dul ba ma yin pa la 'dul bar mthong ba dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa la rnam par byang bar mthong ba dang / 'khor ba'i khams la mya ngan las 'das pa'i dbyings su mthong ba des las kyi sgrib pa rnam par dag pa thob po zhes gsungs so/ /
