The Sūtra on Clearing Away Karmic Distortions also says: [173] Furthermore, Mañjuśrī, those bodhisattvas who see what is a downfall and what isn’t, who see what is contrary to the monastic code and what isn’t, who see reactivity and purity, who see the sphere of cyclic existence and the sphere of Nirvāṇa—they succeed in clearing away karmic distortions.

dam tshig gsum gyi rgyal po las kyang / sdig pa'i gnyen po kun du spyad par gsungs te/ mig btsums la sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' la dmigs pa'i sems kyis yi ge brgya pa lan stong phrag brgyad bzlas brjod byas na/ mig btsums bzhin du sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' mthong bar 'gyur/ sdig pa dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / yang na mchod rten la skor ba byed cing stong phrag brgyad bzlas par bya'o/ / sku gzugs dang dam pa'i chos kyi glegs bam gang yang rung ba zhig mdun du bzhag nas kyang bskor zhing lan stong bzlas par bya ste cho ga ni 'di nyid do zhes gsungs so/ /

The Rulers of the Three Sacred Commitments also explains the practice of remedying vile actions: With your eyes closed, taking as mental object the Buddhas and bodhisattvas, you should repeat the hundred-syllable mantra[22] eight thousand times. With your eyes closed, you will see the Buddhas and bodhisattvas, and you will be freed from your vile actions. Alternately, while circumambulating a stūpa, you should repeat it eight thousand times. Or, you should place in front of you a Buddha image and holy Dharma texts; then, circumambulating one thousand times, you should recite [the mantra.][xxxix] This is the ritual.

skul byed ma'i gzungs las kyang / ji srid du sdig pa byang ba'i mtshan ma mthong ba de srid du bzlas brjod bya ste/ rmi lam na zas ngan pa skyug pa dang / zho dang 'o ma la sogs pa 'thungs pa dang / skyugs pa dang / nyi ma dang zla ba mthong ba dang / nam mkha' la 'gro ba dang / me 'bar ba dang ma he dang mi nag po thub pa dang / dge slong dang dge slong ma'i dge 'dun mthong ba dang / 'o ma 'byung ba'i shing dang glang po dang khyu mchog dang / ri dang seng ge'i khri dang khang bzang gi steng du 'dzeg pa dang / chos nyan pa rmis na sdig pa dang bral bar 'gyur te/ sdig pa byang bar shes par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Or, you should recite the Dhāraṇī of Cundā[xl] (Cundā-dhāraṇī) until you see, in a dream, signs of the wasting away of vile actions. For example, if you dream of vomiting bad food, because of eating yogurt, milk, and so on, your vile actions are gone.[xli] Or if you dream of a dwarf,[xlii] the moon or the sun, flying through the sky, blazing fire, a water buffalo, defeating a dark man, seeing a community of monks or nuns, a sap-giving tree,[xliii] climbing up a mountain or onto a lion throne, or hearing the Dharma, the wasting away of vile actions is indicated.

de bzhin gshegs pa'i gzungs kyi le'u las kyang gnyen po kun du spyod par gsungs te/ dper na mi zhig ngan skyugs kyis reg pa las legs par bkrus te khrus byas nas spos kyis byugs na/ de'i dri nga ba med cing bral bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du mtshams med pa lnga byed pa'i sdig pa de byang bar 'gyur ro/ / gang yang mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam dang ldan par gyur la/ de bzhin gshegs pa la dad pa rnyed nas de bzhin gshegs pa de'i sku gzugs byed na de'i sdig pa yang mi mngon par 'gyur/ bye brag tu ni byang chub kyi sems dang ldan pa dang / bye brag tu ni khyim gyi gnas nas 'byung ba tshul khrims dang ldan pa'i sdig pa byang bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

The Chapter on the Image of the Tathāgata (Tathāgata-bimba-parivarta) also explains the practice of remedy: For example, when people who have been smeared with urine wash themselves well, bathe, and then apply perfume, the bad smell is gotten rid of and removed. In the same way, the vile actions of those who have committed the five actions of immediate retribution can be removed. When people follow the ten wholesome courses of action, develop faith in the Tathāgata, and then make images of the Tathāgata, their vile actions do not become manifest—especially if they have the Awakening Mind, and especially for morally disciplined people who have gone forth from the home life.

me tog brtsegs pa'i gzungs las kyang gsungs te/ seng ge rnam par rtse ba gang gis de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas pa lo gcig gam lo brgya'am lo stong yang rung ste/ bde ba'i yo byad thams cad kyis bsnyen bkur byas pa dang / byang chub kyi sems kyis yang dag par zin pa gang gis de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa'i phyir/ de bzhin gshegs pa yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa'i mchod rten la me tog 'ga' 'bul lam chu snyim pa gang tsam 'thor ram/ byug pa'i thig le 'dri 'am/ me tog gi nyal nyil 'phyag gam/ byug pa 'bul lam/ me tog 'bul lam/ bdug spos 'bul lam/ mar me 'bul te phul nas dga' ba'i sems kyis gom pa'i gar stabs 'ga' bor te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de la phyag 'tshal lo zhes smra ba de dag ni/ seng ge rnam par rtse ba bskal par ram bskal pa brgya'am bskal pa stong du'am/ bskal pa brgya phrag stong du yang ngan 'gro log par ltung bar 'gyur ba de'i gnas med do zhes gsungs so/ /

The Heap of Flowers Dhāraṇī (Puṣpa-kūṭa-dhāraṇī) also says: [174] Siṃhavikrīḍita,[23] someone who sees a Tathāgata face to face, and then, for a year, or a hundred years, or a hundred thousand years,[xliv] respectfully serves him with all the material supports of happiness; or someone who, after the Nirvāṇa of a Tathāgata, arouses Awakening Mind and places a single flower on a holy shrine, and offers a libation of water in worship of the Tathāgata, or sprinkles the shrine with water, or draws with a drop of colored pigment,[xlv] or removes leftover flowers, or offers ointment, flowers,[xlvi] or lamps, with a rejoicing mind, and who, whenever taking a step forward, at every step, says “Homage to the Buddha, the Blessed One”—because of this, Siṃhavikrīḍita, any doubt, skepticism, or uncertainty[xlvii] by which that person would have gone down to the lower realms for an aeon, or a hundred aeons, or a thousand aeons finds no basis.

sman gyi bla bai DUr+ya'i 'od kyi rgyal po'i mdo las kyang / gang dag yang bslab pa'i gzhi lnga po dag 'dzin pa dang / gang dag bslab pa'i gzhi bcu po dag 'dzin pa dang / gang dag byang chub sems dpa'i sdom pa bslab pa'i gzhi bzhi brgya po dag 'dzin pa dang / khyim gyi gnas nas byung ba'i dge slong gang dag bslab pa'i gzhi nyis brgya lnga bcu po dag 'dzin pa dang / dge slong ma gang dag bslab pa'i gzhi lnga brgya po dag 'dzin pa ste/ gang dag ji ltar yongs su bzung ba'i bslab pa'i sdom pa de dag gi nang nas/ bslab pa'i gzhi gang yang rung ba zhig las nyams par gyur te/ ngan 'gro ngan song gis 'jigs skrag pa de dag bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sman gyi bla baiDUr+ya'i 'od de la mchod pa rnam pa sna tshogs byed na/ de dag la ngan song gsum gyi sdug bsngal med par shes par bya'o/ / bud med gang la la bu btsa' ba'i dus na sdug bsngal ma rungs pa drag po byung ba des/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sman gyi bla bai DUr+ya'i 'od de la mchod na de myur du yongs su thar bar 'gyur/ bu yang yan lag yongs su tshang bar btsa' zhing gzugs bzang ba dang mdzes pa dang / blta na sdug pa dang / dbang po rno ba dang / blo dang ldan pa dang / nad med cing gnod pa nyung bar 'gyur ro/ / de la mi ma yin pas mdangs 'phrogs par mi nus so/ /

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo la bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo gang gi phyir nga bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sman gyi bla bai DUr+ya'i 'od de'i mchod pa rnam pa sna tshogs byed na/ de dag la ngan song gsum gyi sdug bsngal med par shes par bya'o/ / yon tan brjod par khyod dad dam yid ches sam/ yang na khyod sangs rgyas kyi spyod yul zab mo 'di la yid gnyis sam som nyi'am/ the tshom za ba med dam de nas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos 'di skad ces gsol to/ / btsun pa bcom ldan 'das bdag de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs pa'i chos rnams la yid gnyis sam som nyi'am the tshom 'tshal ba ma lags so/ / de ci'i slad du zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la sku dang gsung dang thugs kyi kun du spyod pa yongs su ma dag pa mi mnga' ba'i slad du'o/ / bcom ldan 'das gdugs dang dgung zla 'di ltar rdzu 'phrul che ba 'di gnyis ni dog sa la ltung yang gda'/ ri'i rgyal po ri rab ni gnas nas 'pho yang gda'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi bka' ni gzhan du mi 'gyur lags so/ / btsun pa bcom ldan 'das de ltar lags kyis kyang / sems can dad pa'i dbang po dang bral ba dag mchis te/ sangs rgyas rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi spyod yul 'di thos na de dag 'di snyam du sems par 'gyur te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan 'di dran pa tsam gyis ji ltar shin tu yon tan dang phan yon du 'gyur snyam nas de dag mi dad cing yid mi ches te spong bas yun ring por gnod pa dang mi sman pa dang yid mi bde ba dang rnam par ltung bar 'gyur ro/ /

Then the Blessed One said to the Venerable Ānanda,[xlix] “Ānanda, do you have faith in—do you trust—what I say in praise of the abilities of the Blessed One, the Tathāgata King Bhaiṣajyaguru of the Lapis Lazuli Radiance? Do you have any doubt, uncertainty, or skepticism about this profound sphere of activity of the Buddhas?” The Venerable Ānanda said to the Blessed One: “Revered Blessed One, there can be no doubt, uncertainty, or skepticism about the sūtras spoken by the Tathāgata. Why? Because the Tathāgata has no impurity in thought, word, or deed. Blessed One, the sun and moon in the sky, great in splendor and power, might fall to the ground. Meru, the king of mountains, might move from its place. But the words of the Buddhas cannot be inaccurate.” “Nevertheless, revered Blessed One, there are sentient beings lacking the faculty of faith who, when they hear about this sphere of activity of the Buddhas, have no faith in it. This thought occurs to them: ‘How could there be such great advantages merely from remembering the name of that Tathāgata?’ They don’t have faith in it. They don’t trust it. They reject it. That will be for their harm, unhappiness, and misery for a long time.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo de bzhin gshegs pa de'i mtshan su'i rna lam du grag par gyur pa de/ ngan 'gro ngan song du 'gro bar 'gyur ba ni gnas med de go skabs ma yin no/ / kun dga' bo sangs rgyas rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi spyod yul ni yid ches par dka'o/ / kun dga' bo khyod dad cing yid ches par gyur pa de ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mthu yin par blta'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po skye ba gcig gis thogs pa rnams ma gtogs par 'di nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyis ma yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

[175] The Blessed One said, “For those whose ears are reached by that name, there is no basis, there is no opportunity, for them to go to the lower realms. Ānanda, it is rare for someone to have faith in the Buddha sphere of activity of the Buddhas. Ānanda, you have that faith; you have that confidence. You will see the splendor of that Tathāgata. Other than those bodhisattva great beings with only one more life to go, all the Disciples and Solitary Sages cannot [see him.][l]“

yang de nyid las dad pa'i rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang dag yan lag brgyad dang ldan pa'i bsnyen gnas la nye bar gnas te/ lo gcig gam zla ba gsum du bslab pa'i gzhi rnams 'dzin cing / gang dag gi bsam pa 'di lta bus/ bdag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis nub phyogs gang na de bzhin gshegs pa tshe dpag med bzhugs pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams bde ba can du skye bar shog shig ces smon lam de lta bu btab pa dag las/ gang dag gis bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa sman gyi bla bai DUr+ya'i 'od de'i mtshan thos par gyur pa de dag 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe byang chub sems dpa' brgyad rdzu 'phrul gyis lhags nas lam ston par 'gyur te/ de dag der pad+ma tshon kha dog sna tshogs rnams las rdzus te skye bar 'gyur ro/ / gang la la dag lha'i 'jig rten du skye bar 'gyur ba de dag ni/ der skyes nas sngon gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba de zad par mi 'gyur zhing ngan 'gror 'gro bar mi 'gyur ro/ / de nas shi 'phos nas kyang mi'i 'jig rten 'dir gling bzhi pa'i dbang phyug 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal por 'gyur te/ sems can bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du ma dag dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam la 'god par 'gyur ro/ /

And the same text says, And those other faithful gentlemen and ladies who are in retreat and temporarily observing eight precepts, or are keeping precepts for one year or for three years, or those who have taken any vow of their own choosing, thinking “By this wholesome action, may we be reborn in the Realm of Bliss in the western direction, where dwells the Tathāgata Amitābha”[24]—to those of them who have heard the name of the Blessed One, the Tathāgata Bhaiṣajyaguru of the Lapis Lazuli Radiance, at the time of their death, eight bodhisattvas will miraculously appear and show them the path. Then they will be spontaneously born there, [in the Realm of Bliss,] in lotuses of various colors. Others will be born in the god realm. When they are born there, their previous wholesome actions will not decay, and they will be in no danger of falling into the lower realms. When they fall from there, here, in the human realm, they will be kings, rulers of all the continents, world-emperors. They will establish many thousands of billions of trillions of sentient beings in the ten wholesome courses of action.

yang gzhan dag ni rgyal rigs shing sA la chen po lta bu'i khyim dag tu skye bar 'gyur/ bram ze shing sA la chen po lta bu'i khyim dag dang / khyim bdag shing sA la chen po lta bu'i khyim dag dang / nor dang 'bru dang mdzod dang bang ba mang po 'byor pa'i khyim dag tu skye bar 'gyur te/ gzugs phun sum tshogs pa dang / dbang phyug phun sum tshogs pa dang / g.yog phun sum tshogs pa dang dpa' ba dang rtul phod pa dang tshan po che chen po'i stobs kyi shugs dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / bud med gang gis de bzhin gshegs pa de'i mtshan thos shing bzung ba de'i bud med kyi dngos po de tha ma yin par shes par bya'o zhes gsungs so// //

Others, again, will be born in warrior-noble families with great houses; in families of Brahmins with great houses; in families of leading merchants, with abundant wealth, with treasuries and storehouses of wealth. They will be utterly perfect in physical appearance, {plentifully endowed with political power, fine clothes, courage, fortitude, great power, and strength.}[li] The same text says, Moreover, any woman who hears or remembers the name of the Blessed One, the Tathāgata Bhaiṣajyaguru of the Lapis Lazuli Radiance, may expect that this will be her last rebirth as a woman.[lii]
bam po brgyad pa/

'jam dpal gyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi yon tan bkod pa'i rgyan las kyang / ye shes bla ma 'od kyi tog / de bzhin smon lam blo gros dang / / dbang po zhi dang 'jam dbyangs la/ / bdag ni gus pas phyag 'tshal lo/ / su zhig byang chub sems dpa' 'di dag gi ming 'dzin pa de bud med kyi dngos por mi 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

The Sūtra that is a Poetic Description of the Qualities of Mañjuśrī’s Buddha Field also says: With devotion I pay homage To Jñānottaraprabhāketu,[25] And to Praṇidhānamati,[26] [176] Śāntendriya[27] and Mañjughoṣa.[28] Any woman who remembers The names of these bodhisattvas Will not be born As a woman again.
gnyen po kun tu spyad pa mngon par bstan zin to/ /
This concludes the explanation of the practice of remedy.
da ni nyes pa las bzlog pa'i stobs brjod par bya ste/ 'phags pa sa'i snying po'i mdo las ji skad du gsungs pa lta bu ste/
Now the power of resolve needs to be explained. As the noble Kṣitigarbha Sūtra says,

srog gcod pa spong ba'i byang chub sems dpa' ni sems can thams cad la mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa yin te/ skrag par mi byed 'khrug par mi byed spu zing zhes 'gyur bar mi byed do/ / de dge ba'i las kyi rnam par smin pa de dang srog gcod pa spong ba'i 'khor lo des sngon gyi mtha'i mu nas 'gro ba lnga'i 'khor lor zhugs shing 'khor ba'i chu ngos khyer nas/ srog gcod pa'i rgyus lus dang ngag dang / yid kyi las kyi sgrib pa dang nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa dang chos kyi sgrib pa byas pa dang byed du bcug pa dang rjes su yi rang ba gang yin pa thams cad 'joms te/ ma lus par rnam par smin par mi 'gyur ba'i bar du byed do/ / de la rigs mthun pa'i lha dang mi rnams dga' bar 'gyur ro/ / nad med pa dang tshe ring bar 'gyur ro/ /

A bodhisattva great being abstains from taking life, granting freedom from fear to all sentient beings, so that they are not terrified, they are free from mental disturbance, and their hairs do not stand up. By the evolution of these wholesome actions, all those karmic distortions, reactive distortions, and distortions that block the Dharma that have arisen during all past time in the wheel of the five realms, raised up by the river of cyclic existence due to taking life—whether in thought, word, or deed, and whether he has done this himself, gotten someone else to do it, or rejoiced in it—all that harm is crushed by the wheel of abstaining from taking life, completely, so that it doesn’t evolve into anything. As a common characteristic of those [who abstain from taking life,][liii] he becomes dear to gods and humans, free from disease, and long-lived.

rigs kyi bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po gang ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ma byin par len pa spangs par gyur cing sems can thams cad la mi 'jigs pa sbyin la gzhan la 'gran pa med pa dang 'khrug pa med par rang gi rnyed pas chog shes shing / chos ma yin pa'i longs spyod mi 'dod de/ dge ba'i rtsa ba des ma byin par len pa'i rgyu las byung ba'i bar gyi las kyi sgrib pa 'joms so/ / rab tu 'joms so/ / ma lus par rnam par smin par mi 'gyur ba'i bar du byed do/ /

[177] Noble sir, moreover, a bodhisattva who, as long as life lasts, abstains from taking what is not given gives freedom from fear to all sentient beings. He lives without competitiveness or quarrels,[liv] contented with his own wealth. He does not long for enjoyments that are contrary to the Dharma. By these wholesome actions, he crushes and annihilates the karmic distortions caused by taking things not given, completely, so that they don’t evolve into anything
de bzhin du sbyar te/

dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam rnams kyis rang gi mi mthun pa'i phyogs mi dge ba rnams 'joms par gsungs so/ / de skad du zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las kyang / gnod sems spangs pas sdig pa zad par 'gyur ba 'byung ste/ ji skad du/ / 'dir ni yang dag ma lags par/ / byis pa rnams kyis mtshang brus dang / / spyod pa dag ni bzod bgyi ste/ / smod pa'ang 'dren pa dang du blang / / byang chub sems dpas gzhan dag la/ / bdag gis gnod sems bskyed pa dang / / sngon chad bdag gis sdig pa'i las/ / bgyis pa rnams ni sbyang bar bgyi/ / zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

In the same way, the text explains that all of the ten wholesome courses of action, by their evolution, destroy the unwholesome {actions that are their opposites.} In this way, the Candrapradīpa Sūtra also states that by abstaining from malice, all vile actions waste away. As it says,[lv] Here, I will endure the false slander of fools. As a guide, I will put up with censure and ridicule.[lvi] I will throw away any vile actions that I have created in the past Through malice I have felt towards other bodhisattvas.
nyes pa las zlog pa'i stobs bshad zin to/ /
The power of resolve has been explained.

rten gyi stobs brjod par bya ste/ 'dir phag gi rtogs pa brjod pa dper bya'o/ / gang dag sangs rgyas skyabs dong ba/ / de dag ngan 'gror 'gro mi 'gyur/ / mi yi lus ni spangs nas su/ / de dag lha yi lus thob po/ / zhes gsungs te/ de bzhin du chos dang dge 'dun gyi dbang du byas te gdon to/ /

But the power of reliance needs to be explained. As the Story of Sūkarika (Sūkarika-avadāna) relates, Those who go to the Buddha for refuge Do not go to the lower realms. When they leave behind human bodies, They attain divine bodies. In the same way, [the text] refers to vile actions wasting away[lvii] [through taking refuge in] the Dharma and the Community.

'phags pa byams pa'i rnam par thar pa las kyang / byang chub kyi sems kyis sdig pa rnam par dag par gsungs te/ nyes pa byas pa thams cad bsregs pas sreg pa'i bskal pa'i me lta bu'o/ / mi dge ba'i chos thams cad zad par byed pas sa'i 'og lta bu'o/ /

The noble Liberation of Maitreya speaks of clearing away vile actions through the Awakening Mind: It is like the aeonic fire,[29] because of burning up all bad actions. It is like a hole through which all unwholesome qualities drain out
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[lviii]

rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste/ dper na dngul chu'i rigs gser du snang ba zhes bya ba yod de/ de ni srang gcig gis kyang lcags srang stong gser du 'gyur ro/ / dngul chu srang gcig pa da ni lcags srang stong po des zad par byas pa'am lcags su bsgyur bar mi nus so/ / de bzhin du thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du sems bskyed pa'i dngul chu'i khams dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su bsngo ba dang ye shes kyis bzung ba gcig gis las dang nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa'i lcags thams cad zad par byas te/ chos thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi kha dog tu byed kyang / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du sems bskyed pa'i dngul chu'i khams gcig po de ni las dang nyon mongs pa'i lcags thams cad kyis kyang kun nas nyon mongs par bya ba'am zad par mi nus so/ /

[178] For example, noble sir, there is an elixir named Hāṭakaprabhāsa,[30] of which one measure transforms a thousand measures of iron into gold. And in that process, those thousand measures of iron can neither exhaust the one measure of elixir, nor turn it into iron.[31] In the same way, a single instance of the elixir of arousing the mind to complete knowing, then collecting your wholesome actions and dedicating them to pristine awareness, exhausts all the iron of the karmic and reactive distortions, and changes everything into the color of complete knowing. And all the iron of karma and reactivity can neither use up the elixir of arousing the mind to complete knowing, nor cause it to become reactive.

rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste dper na mar me gcig gis khyim mam khang bu ji lta bur bcug kyang rung ste bcug ma thag tu lo stong du bsags pa'i mun pa yang rnam par sel cing snang bar byed do/ / de bzhin du thams cad mkhyen pa'i sems bskyed pa'i mar me gcig gis kyang sems can gyi bsam pa'i thibs po ma rig pa'i mun pa dang ldan pa ji lta bu yang rung bar zhugs na zhugs ma thag tu bskal pa brgya stong brjod du med par bsags pa'i las dang nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa dang mun pa thams cad rnam par sel zhing ye shes kyi snang ba skyed do/ / rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste dper na nor bu rin po che yid bzhin gyi rgyal po'i cod pan thogs pa'i klu'i rgyal po chen po rnams la gzhan gyis gnod par bya ba'i 'jigs pa med do/ / de bzhin du byang chub kyi sems dang snying rje chen po'i nor bu rin po che'i yid bzhin gyi rgyal po'i cod pan thogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams la yang / ngan song dang ngan 'gros gnod par bya ba'i 'jigs pa med do zhes bya ba'o/ /

For example, noble sir, just as soon as a lamp is brought into a house or a hut,[lix] it dispels even the darkness of a thousand years and brings light. In the same way, the lamp that is even once arousing the Mind to complete knowing enters the mind of a sentient being that is full of the gloom of deep ignorance. It immediately dispels the darkness of karmic and reactive distortions, even if they have been present for inexpressibly many hundreds of thousands of aeons, and brings the light of pristine awareness. For example, noble sir, the great kings of serpent-spirits who wear royal wish-fulfilling gems on the cloth ornaments of their crowns[lx] are in no danger from the aggression of others. In the same way, those bodhisattvas who wear the royal wish-fulfilling gems of the Awakening Mind and of great compassion on the cloth ornaments of their crowns are in no danger from the aggression of bad rebirths and the lower realms.

'phags pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa las kyang gsungs te/ nye ba 'khor 'di la theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gal te snga dro'i dus na ltung ba byung ba yang / phyi dro'i dus na thams cad mkhyen pa'i sems dang mi 'bral bar gnas te/ de ltar na theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i tshul khrims kyi phung po mtha' med do/ /

The noble Inquiry of Upāli says, Here, Upāli, if a bodhisattva practicing the Great Way undergoes a downfall in the morning, but in the afternoon, she is not separated from the Awakening Mind, that bodhisattva’s moral discipline is limitless. If she undergoes a downfall in the afternoon, but in the evening, she is not separated from the Awakening Mind, the bodhisattva’s moral discipline is limitless.

gal te phyi dro'i dus na ltung ba byung ba yang / phye ma red kyi dus na thams cad mkhyen pa'i sems dang mi 'bral bar gnas te/ de ltar na theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i tshul khrims kyi phung po'i mtha' med do/ / gal te phye ma red kyi dus na ltung ba byung ba yang srod la thams cad mkhyen pa'i sems dang mi 'bral bar gnas te/ de ltar na tshul khrims kyi phung po mtha' med do/ / gal te srod la ltung ba byung ba yang nam phyed na thams cad mkhyen pa'i sems dang mi 'bral bar gnas te/ de ltar na tshul khrims kyi phung po mtha' med do/ / gal te nam phyed na ltung ba byung na yang tho rangs thams cad mkhyen pa'i sems dang mi 'bral bar gnas te/ de lta na theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i tshul khrims kyi phung po'i mtha' med do/ /
And the text repeats the same formula about every watch of the day and night.[lxi]

nye ba 'khor de lta na theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi bslab pa ni bcos su rung ba yin no/ / de la byang chub sems dpa' 'gyod pas kun nas ldang ba de skyes na ha cang yang mi dga' bar mi bya'o/ / nye ba 'khor de la gal te nyan thos kyi theg pa pa'i gang zag la/ ltung ba yang dang yang byung na/ / nyan thos kyi theg pa pa'i gang zag gi tshul khrims kyi phung po nyams par rig par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

This being so, Upāli, the training of bodhisattvas who are practicing the Great Way requires careful attention.[lxii] Here a bodhisattva should not develop overwhelming, excessive regret, nor feel excessively guilty. But now, if someone belonging to the Way of the Disciples undergoes downfalls again and again, the moral discipline of that disciple should be understood to be destroyed.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las sdig pa sbyang ba'i le'u ste brgyad pa'o// //
tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa rdzogs so// //
[bzod pa]
9. The Perfection of Patient Endurance

des na de ltar rgyun mi 'chad par sdug bsngal mang po dang ldan pa'i 'chal pa'i tshul khrims skye ba bsrung zhing de ltar las kyi sgrib pa'i gegs sel ba des nyon mongs pa rnam par sbyong ba la 'bad par bya'o/ / de la thog mar

THEREFORE, IN THIS way, in order to protect against the arising of immorality, which brings many forms of suffering,[i] and in order to take off the fetters of karmic distortions, you should make an effort to clear away reactive emotions. Now, in the beginning,
re zhig bzod par bya'o/ /
[20] Endure patiently.

mi bzod pa ni skyo ba ni sron mi nus pa'i phyir thos pa la sogs pa la brtson pa nyams par 'gyur zhing / thos pa dang mi ldan pas ni bsam gtan gyi thabs dang nyon mongs pa rnam par sbyong ba'i thabs kyang mi shes te/ de bas na skyo ba med par

For an impatient person who can’t endure weariness, effort in study and similar activities will decay. And someone who has not studied does not know either the methods for developing stable attention, or the methods for clearing away reactive emotions. Therefore, untiringly
thos pa btsal bar bya/
Seek learning.
shes su zin kyang 'dren mar spyod pas mnyam par gzhag dka' bar 'gyur te/ de'i phyir/
Even if you are knowledgeable, if your conduct is soiled, it will be difficult to develop stable attention. Therefore,
de nas nags su gnas par bya/ /
Then dwell in the forest.
der yang rnam par g.yeng ba zhi bar bya ba la mi brtson pas sems mnyam par 'jog par mi 'gyur bas/ /
Even if you pacify distractions there, stable attention does not develop without effort.
mnyam par gzhag la brtson bya zhing / /
Make an effort to stabilize attention.
mnyam par bzhag pa'i 'bras bu ni nyon mongs pa sbyangs pa ma gtogs pa ci yang med pas de'i phyir/
Someone who has stable attention receives no other result than clearing away reactive emotions. So,
mi sdug la sogs bsgom par bya/ /
Meditate on foulness, and so on.[1]

de ltar 'di dag ni re zhig sdig pa sbyong ba bstan pa'i tshig go/ / da ni bshad pa brjod do/ / de la bzod pa ni/ chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las/ sdug bsngal dang du len pa'i bzod pa dang chos la nges par sems pa'i bzod pa dang gzhan gyis gnod pa byas pa la ji mi snyam pa'i bzod pa'o zhes rnam pa gsum gsungs so/ / de la sdug bsngal nyams su len pa'i bzod pa'i mi mthun pa'i phyogs ni/ sdug bsngal gyis 'jigs pa nyid mi 'dod pa byung ba dang phrad pa dang / rang gi bde ba la mngon par chags pa nyid 'dod pa'i gegs byed pa dang phrad pa ste/ de dag las yid mi bde zhing / de las ni sdang ba'am zhum pa nyid do/ /

These are the instructions for clearing away reactive emotions. Now, the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together teaches that there are three types of patient endurance: “patient endurance in accepting pain, patient endurance in reflecting on the Dharma, and patient endurance in forgiving harm inflicted by others.” Here, patient endurance in accepting pain is opposed to fear of the pain of meeting the arising of what you don’t want, and to intense attachment to your own pleasure when you encounter obstacles to what you want. Both of these give rise to mental suffering, then aversion and discouragement.

de bas na zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las kyang / bde ba la mi chags pa dang / / sdug bsngal la mi skyo ba'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ / dkon mchog sprin gyi mdo las kyang / gang nang gi mya ngan dang smre sngags 'don pa dang sdug bsngal ba dang yid mi bde ba dang 'khrug pa de dag bzod cing dang du len to zhes gsungs so/ /

[180] Therefore the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says, “Not being attached to pleasure, and not hiding your face from pain.”[ii] And the Cloud of Jewels Sūtra also says, “Whatever internal sorrow, lamentation, suffering, unhappiness, and mental disturbance arise, they endure patiently and accept all of it.”

'phags pa drag shul can gyis zhus pa las kyang / khyim bdag gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' khyim pas rjes su chags pa dang khong khro ba med pas 'jig rten gyi chos brgyad la mnyam pa nyid thob par bya'o/ / des longs spyod rnyed dam chung ma dang bu rnyed dam nor dang 'bru dang rdzas rnyed kyang khengs par yang mi bya'o/ / thams cad ma 'byor yang de zhum par yang mi bya yi mug par yang mi bya'o/ / des 'di ltar brtag par bya ste/ 'dus byas thams cad ni sgyu ma'i rnam pa lta bu rnam par bsgrub pas so sor nye bar gnas pa'i mtshan nyid do/ / 'di lta ste/ pha ma dang chung ma dang bran dang las byed pa dang zho shas 'tsho ba dang mdza' bshes dang blon po dang nye du dang snag gi gnyen mtshams de dag ni las kyi rnam par smin pas grub pa yin te/ bdag dbang ba ma yin la nga yang 'di dag gi ni ma yin no zhes gsungs so/

The noble Inquiry of Ugra also says, Moreover, leading merchant, a householder bodhisattva should be free from attachment and anger and should be indifferent to the eight worldly concerns. If he gains possessions, a wife, or sons, wealth, grain, or property, he should not become pompous or exhilarated.[iii] If he doesn’t gain any of these, he should not be discouraged or depressed. And he should reflect as follows: “All conditioned things are illusory, having the characteristic of being mentally constructed. Therefore, parents, children,[iv] wife, servants, workers, employees, friends, companions, relatives, and family members—they are manifested by the evolution of karma. They are not mine, and I am not theirs.[2]

gzhan yang / gal te bcos su yod na ni/ / de la mi dga' ba ci dgos/ / de ste bcos su med na ni/ / de la mi dga' byas ci phan/ / bcos kyang yid mi bde na ni/ / khro bas rgyal bas 'thad pa'am/ / zhum pa'i phyir na spro nyams pas/ / rgud pa chen pos zin par 'gyur/ / de la yang dang yang sems pas/ / tshe yang thung bar 'gyur ba yin/ / de lta bas na goms pa las/ / gnod pa bzhin du don med spang / /

Moreover, If there is a solution, What is the point of unhappiness? {But if there is no solution, What is the point of unhappiness?}[3] Even if there is a solution, Depression drains you of joy and paralyzes you. Confused again and again by this way of thinking, Your lifespan becomes short. Therefore, through repeated practice, You should give it up—it’s as useless as it is harmful.

yid mi bde ba spang ba yang ji ltar goms par bya zhe na/ yang ba dang snyi ba'i sems spangs pa las te/ drag shul can gyis zhus pa las ji skad du/ shing bal gyi 'da' ba lta bu'i sems dang bral bar bya'o zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / 'phags pa sdong po bkod pa las kyang / bu mo khyod kyis nyon mongs pa thams cad gzhom pa'i phyir thub par dka' ba'i sems bskyed par bya'o/ / mngon par zhen pa thams cad gzhom pa'i phyir gzhan gyis mi thub pa'i sems bskyed par bya'o/ / mi mthun pa'i bsam pa can gyi sems can rgya mtsho'i glong 'khyil ba lta bu bab pa rnams la mi 'khrugs pa'i sems bskyed par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

[181] How do you actually practice letting go of unhappiness? By getting rid of a light and soft state of mind. As the Inquiry of Ugra says,[4] “Not having a mind like cotton.” The noble Array of Stalks also says,[5] “Daughter, you should develop a mind that is difficult to defeat, for the destruction of all reactive emotions; an unconquered mind, to sever all strong attachments; a mind that does not tremble when descending into the whirlpool of the ocean of beings whose intentions are disordered.”

goms par gyur na dka' ba cung zad kyang med de/ 'di ltar re zhig shin tu blun pa khur rtsa ba dang nya pa dang zhing pa la sogs pa dag kyang sdug bsngal la goms pa las 'bras bu shin tu chung ngu dang ldan pa'i dngos po la yang yun ring po nas rmad du gyur pa'i mtshan ma can gyi sems mkhrang ba dang / sgyid lug pas zil gyis mi non na/ 'khor ba'i bde ba thams cad dang byang chub sems dpa'i bde ba thams cad dang bla na med pa'i go 'phang thob pa'i 'bras bu can gyi las la smos su yod dam ci/ 'di ltar phal pa dag kyang cung zad gnod pa byed pa bdag gi nyes par byas pas bcom zhing rang nyid 'chi ba rnams la brdeg pa'i ched du/ drag tu brdegs pa myong yang g.yul du 'jug na/ dus shin tu ring por gnod pa byed pa dka' bas bsgrubs pa'i dge ba'i nor bag tsam pa'i rkun po dmyal ba nyid kyi gsod sar gsad bya'i gshed mar gyur pa srid pa'i btson ra'i srung mar nges par 'byung ba'i lam gyi phyir phyogs ma rung bar byed pa rjes su mthun pa 'dra yang gnod pa drag po byed pa gnod pa ma byas par dgrar gyur pa/ thog ma med pa'i bskal pa las dam du 'brel ba'i sha 'khon can/ nyon mongs pa'i dgra rnams la gzhom par spro ba'am sdug bsngal bzod par go ji ltar mi 'gyur te/ sa gsum las rnam par rgyal bar bya ba'i phyir chas shing bdud kyi ri khrod pa'i bdag pos zin pa'i 'gro ba gnang btson thar bar bya ba'i phyir g.yul ngor zhugs pa ni khyad par du yang 'gyur ba kho na'o/ / de la sdug bsngal chung ngu la goms par bya ba sngon du btang na/ dka' ba dang shin tu dka' ba la yang goms pa 'grub ste/ dper na goms pa'i dbang gis sems can thams cad sdug bsngal la bde bar 'du shes pa de bzhin du sdug bsngal 'byung ba thams cad la bde bar 'du shes nye bar gzhag pa goms pas bde ba'i 'du shes nyid du nye bar gnas par 'gyur ro/ / 'di'i rgyu mthun pa'i 'bras bu ni chos thams cad bde bas non pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin thob pa yin no/ / yab dang sras mjal ba'i mdo las/

With repeated practice, nothing is difficult to do.[6] Thus, even the very ignorant, such as porters, fishermen, and farmers, even for the sake of the most insignificant material results, through painful repeated practice, become bold and branded with calluses, and they are not overpowered by fatigue. How much more so in that work whose results are all forms of happiness in cyclic existence, all forms of the bodhisattva’s happiness, and the highest path of meditative absorption! In the same way, the uneducated, while doing wrong actions, due to their own previous errors, mortally wound themselves, or continue to fight in order to harm others, even when they feel the intense pain of their own injuries. But how much more appropriate would it be to endure suffering in order to make an effort to strike at your enemies, the reactive emotions, who wrong you for the longest time; those thieves who steal your wholesome actions and wealth, obtained through painful effort; those murderers in the hells whom it is lawful to kill; the guards of the prison of existence who bar the route to the gate of escape; the mighty tormentors whose enmity towards you remains firm and does not diminish throughout unlimited eons. Still more so in the battle for victory over the triple world, the struggle to set the world free from bondage to Māra, the savage who has fettered so many people! In that battle, through first repeatedly practicing enduring your own pain, you succeed through repeated practice against greater and greater difficulties. For example, just as, through habituation, it is possible to believe that the suffering of other sentient beings will bring you happiness, in the same way, by habitually generating thoughts of happiness towards everything that causes suffering, it is possible to abide in happy thoughts. As the outflowing result of this practice, you attain the meditative absorption called Everything is Covered with Happiness.[v] For the Meeting of Father and Son Sūtra says,

bcom ldan 'das chos thams cad la bde bas non pa zhes bgyi ba'i ting nge 'dzin mchis te/ ting nge 'dzin de thob pas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po dmigs pa'i dngos po thams cad la bde ba'i tshor ba sha stag myong bar 'gyur zhing sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba mi myong la sdug bsngal yang ma lags/ bde ba yang ma lags pa yang mi myong ste/ sems can dmyal ba'i gnod pas gnod par bgyis kyang bde ba'i 'du shes nye bar gnas pa dang / mi'i gnod pas gnod par bgyis kyang bde ba'i 'du shes nye bar gnas pa dang / lag pa bcad dam rkang pa bcad dam/ rkang lag bcad dam/ rna ba'am/ sna'am/ rna ba dang sna gtubs kyang bde ba'i 'du shes nye bar gnas par 'gyur ba dang / sba lcag gis gzhus sam/ sba lcag phyed tshal lam/ lcag gis gzhus kyang bde ba'i 'du shes nye bar gnas par 'gyur ba dang / btson rar bcug gam/ lcags sgrog dang shing sgrog tu bcug gam/ btson cha dam po la rgyas btab bam/ byis pa'i gtsug phud ltar bcings sam/ dugs kyi snod ltar bdugs sam/ bu ram shing brdungs pa ltar brdungs sam/ 'dam bu gzhom pa ltar bcom mam/ 'bru mar gyi mar me ltar 'bar bar byas sam/ mar gyi mar me dang / zho bskol ba ltar 'bar bar byas kyang bde ba'i 'du shes nye bar gnas par 'gyur ba dang / me'i nang du bor ram/ seng ge'i khar bstabs sam/ stag gi khar bstabs sam/

[182] There is, Blessed One, a meditative absorption called Everything is Covered with Happiness. Bodhisattvas who attain this feel only happy feelings towards all objects they are aware of, with no feelings of suffering or unhappiness. Even while feeling the pains of the torments of hell, they think only happy thoughts. Even while suffering all the harms of the human condition, such as having their hands, feet, or noses cut off, they think only happy thoughts. Even while being beaten with canes, half-canes, or whips, they have only happy thoughts. Even when thrown into prison[vi] … or while being cooked in oil, or being pounded like sugarcane, or flattened like reeds, or set on fire like an oil lamp, a butter lamp, or a yogurt lamp, they think only happy thoughts. Even while being offered in the mouth of a demon or the mouth of a lion,[vii] or being rolled up like a paintbrush,[viii]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

skam dril bya ba ltar dril tam/ byi bo'i chad pa lta bus bcad dam/ nyes pa byung ba bsgrags pa ltar bsgrags sam/ kAR+Sha pa Na tsam du gtubs sam/ 'bras phye btso ba ltar btsos sam/ glang po che rnams kyis bcom yang bde ba'i 'du shes nye bar gnas par 'gyur ba dang / mig phyung ngam/ gsal shing gi rtse mo la gzhag gam/ gsad pa'i gnas su khrid de rnam pa thams cad du mgo bcad kyang bde ba'i 'du shes nye bar gnas par 'gyur te bde ba yang ma lags mi bde ba yang ma lags pa'i 'du shes rnam pa thams cad du mi 'byung ngo / /

or being cut like a coin,[ix] or being cooked like gruel, or being crushed by elephants, they have only happy thoughts. If their bones are being pulled out, or they are impaled on stakes, or led away to be killed, or their heads are cut off, they have only happy thoughts, not thoughts of suffering, nor thoughts that are neither happy nor suffering.

de ci'i slad du zhe na/ 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po des/ yun ring po nas spyad pa spyod pa'i tshe/ smon lam 'di ltar btab ste gang gis bdag la kha zas byin pa de dag nye bar zhi ba'i bde ba thob par gyur cig / gang gis bdag la skom blud pa de dag dang / gang gis bdag la rim gror byas pa dang bkur sti byas pa dang bsti stang byas pa dang mchod pa byas pa de dag thams cad kyang nye bar zhi ba'i bde ba thob par gyur cig / gang yang bdag la gshe bar byed pa dang mi bde ba byed pa dang rdeg pa dang mtshon gyis 'debs pa dang rnam pa thams cad du srog gcod pa'i bar du byed pa de dag thams cad kyang byang chub kyi bde ba thob cing bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar gyur cig ces smon lam btab ste/ de yid la bya ba de dag dang ldan zhing / de lta bu'i las dang de lta bu'i smon lam dang ldan pas sems can thams cad kyi rjes su song ba'i bde ba'i 'du shes la brten zhing bsnyen la bsgom zhing mang du byed de/ de las de'i rnam par smin pas chos thams cad la bde bas non pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin rab tu thob po/ / gang gi tshe byang chub sems dpa' chos thams cad la bde bas non pa'i ting nge 'dzin thob par gyur pa de'i tshe bdud kyi las thams cad kyis mi 'phrogs shing mi 'khrugs par 'gyur ro zhes rgyas par gsungs so/ /

Why is this? Such bodhisattva great beings have practiced this way of life for a long time, after making this aspiration prayer: “All those who may devour me, may they attain the happiness of peace and tranquility. All those who may protect me, treat me with respect, take me as their spiritual teacher, honor me, or make offerings to me,[x] may they attain the happiness of tranquility. And also, all those who curse me, treat me badly, beat me, cut me with knives, or in any way deprive me of life—may all of them attain the happiness of full Awakening. May they awaken to highest genuine full Awakening.” With these thoughts, with these actions, with these aspiration prayers, they repeatedly practice wishing happiness to all sentient beings. They frequently repeat this wish, meditate on it, and perform it many times. As the result of the evolution of these actions, they attain the meditative absorption named Everything is Covered with Happiness. At the time when a bodhisattva attains the meditative absorption named Everything is Covered with Happiness, that bodhisattva becomes unshakeable, and cannot be held back by all the actions of Māra. And so on at length.

sbyor ba 'di ni gtong ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par byed pa dang / bya bar dka' ba'i spyod pa thams cad bsgrubs pa dang / bzod pa thams cad brtan par byed pa dang / brtson 'grus thams cad la nur ba med par byed pa dang / bsam gtan dang shes rab kyi yan lag gi tshogs thams cad la sbyor ba yin no zhes gsungs pa/ de lta bas na rtag tu dga' bar bya ste/ zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las/ gus dang bcas shing yid ni rtag tu dga' bar bya/ / zhi ba'i lta ba la ni rtag tu gnas par 'gyur/ / zhes ji skad gsungs pa lta bu'o/ / 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa'i mdo las kyang gsungs so/ /

[183] This kind of effort fully perfects all forms of renunciation, accomplishes every action that is difficult to do, makes all forms of patient endurance stable, stabilizes all forms of perseverance, and collects all aspects of meditative stability and wisdom. Therefore, you should always be joyful.[xi] As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[xii] “You should always be respectful, with a delighted mind; you should always stand in a gentle view of things.” And the Akṣayamati Sūtra says,

de la dga' ba chen po gang zhe na/ gang sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams dran pa dang rjes su dran pa dang dga' ba dang / dad pa dang mchog tu dga' ba dang sems ma gong zhing mi brdzi ba dang srid pa med pa dang / 'dod pa'i dga' ba thams cad gtong ba dang / chos kyi dga' ba thams cad kyi rten dang sems rab tu dga' ba dang / lus rab tu sim pa dang / sangs rgyas la dga' zhing yid 'phar ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la dga' zhing mos pas mtshan dang dpe byad bzang po'i rkyen tshol ba la mkhas pa dang / dge ba'i chos mnyan pas mi skyo ba dang / de kho na'i chos la brten pa'i nan tan dang / dga' ba dang mgu ba dang rangs pa dang rab tu dga' bas chos la mos pa dang / rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par sems can rnams la khong khro ba med pa'i blo dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos tshol ba la 'dun pa dang / chos la 'dun pa de yang mi 'dor ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos rgya chen po la mos shing rnam par grol ba dang / nyi tshe ba'i theg pa dang ma 'dres pa'i sems bskyed pa dang / ser sna med pas ma zhum par sems bskyed pa dang / nor gang sems kyis sbyin 'dod pa de sbyin zhing byin nas kyang 'khor gsum dag par yongs su sbyangs pa dang / sbyin pa la dga' ba dang /

[184] Here, what is {great} joy? It is delight in recollecting the qualities of the Buddha; calmness and joyousness of mind; not being depressed; not being ground down; freedom from desire;[xiii] giving up all the delights of the senses; the basis of taking delight in the Dharma; joyousness of the thoughts, great ease of the body, delight of the intellect, gladness of the mind;[xiv] taking pleasure in rejoicing in the body of the Tathāgata; skill in seeking the conditions for the major and minor marks; never getting tired of hearing about wholesome states; making an earnest effort to rely on the teachings about the way things really are; delight, calmness, and joyousness, the gladness in Dharma of the joyful; always having a mind free from enmity toward sentient beings; having sharp motivation;[xv] seeking to develop the qualities of the Buddhas, and not giving up on the motivation to develop those qualities; the freedom of being committed to the lofty qualities of the Buddhas; arousing the mind to draw away from limited Ways; arousing the mind not to shrink down into greed; wanting to give to beggars;[xvi] while giving and after giving, joyfulness in giving that is pure of the three spheres;[7]

tshul khrims dang ldan pa rnams la rtag tu dang ba dang / tshul khrims 'chal pa rjes su 'dzin cing byams pa dang / bdag gi tshul khrims yongs su dag pa dang / ngan 'gro'i 'jigs pa thams cad las shin tu 'das par dbugs 'byin pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i tshul khrims kyi bsngo ba dang / brtan zhing mi phyed pa dang / pha rol gyis ngan par brjod pa dang ngan par smras pa'i tshig gi lam la khong khro ba med pa'i sems nyid dang / bzod cing nges pa dang / nga rgyal med pa dang / bla ma la 'dud cing rim gro byed pa dang / rtag tu bzhin 'dzum pa dang / khro gnyer med pa dang / sngon du gsong por smra ba dang / tshul 'chos pa med pa dang / kha gsag med pa dang / thob kyis 'jal ba med pa dang / bsam pa dag pa dang / sems la brlang ba med pa dang / gya gyu med pa dang / thams cad la legs par lta ba dang / skyon med par lta ba dang / ltung ba mi gleng ba dang / yang dag par dga' bar 'gyur ba'i chos kyi rjes su 'jug pa dang /

always trusting the morally disciplined; delighting in being kind to the immoral; by the purity of your own moral discipline, breathing freely, beyond the reach of all bad smells;[xvii] maturity in the moral discipline of the Tathāgatas; stable unbreakability; having a mind that is not antagonized by others’ ill-spoken, unwelcome paths of speech; being well pleased with forbearance; freedom from conceit; bowing down to spiritual teachers with respect and amazement;[xviii] always having a smiling face; not frowning; courtesy and sincerity;[xix] having no hypocrisy; not engaging in flattery; {not measuring your attainment}; having pure aspirations; having a mind without harshness; not being crooked; seeing the positive side of everything; looking into your own confusion;[xx] not accusing others of downfalls; and conforming to the rules of appropriate behavior.

byang chub sems dpa' rnams la ston pa ltar phangs par 'dzin pa dang / chos rnams la bdag bzhin phangs par 'dzin pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la srog bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / bla ma la pha ma bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / sems can rnams la bu bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / mkhan po dang slob dpon la sangs rgyas bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / nan tan la yan lag gi dam pa mgo bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / pha rol tu phyin pa rnams la rkang lag bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / chos smra ba rnams la rin po che thams cad bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la yid bzhin gyi nor bu bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / rjes su bstan pa la dga' ba'i rtsed mo bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / chog shes pa la nad med pa bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / chos tshol ba la sman bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa dang / skul zhing dran par byed pa la sman pa bzhin du phangs par 'dzin pa ste/ de ltar gang dbang po thams cad la dbang po ma gong ba 'di ni dga' ba zhes bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

It is cherishing other bodhisattvas as your teachers; cherishing the teachings as yourself; cherishing the Tathāgata as your life; cherishing your spiritual teachers as your parents; cherishing sentient beings as your children; cherishing your spiritual and academic teachers as the Buddhas; cherishing effort in practice as the head, the most important body part; cherishing the perfections as hands and feet; cherishing Dharma teachers as all precious substances; {cherishing the Buddha’s teachings as wish-fulfilling gems}; cherishing the practice instructions as pleasure and play; cherishing contentment as health; cherishing the search for the Dharma as medicine; and cherishing someone who reminds you through criticism as a doctor. When every faculty is free from depression, this is called “joy.”

'di la bslabs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni/ 'phags pa sprin chen po'i mdo las/ sems can dmyal ba'i 'gro ba la dga' bar yang 'gyur ba dang / sems can dmyal ba'i 'gro ba la sems shing rtag tu bsam pa gtong ba'i ngang tshul can du'ang 'gyur ba dang / sems can dmyal ba'i tshong rdal gyi tshong par yang 'gyur ba dang / sems can dmyal ba'i 'thob pa mi gtong bar yang 'gyur ba dang / sems can dmyal ba'i me la sems rgyas par 'gyur zhes gsungs pa'i tshig 'dis brgyan par byed do/ / sdug bsngal dang du len pa'i bzod pa bshad zin to/ / 'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las kyang bzod pa rnam pa gsum bstan te/

The noble Great Cloud Sūtra (Mahā-megha) gives a poetic description of well-trained bodhisattvas: They have the discipline of being always absorbed in the thought of going to the hells. They are fond of going to the hells. They become the city merchants of going to the hells. They long for the hells, are greedy and covetous for the hells, and are familiar with the thought of hell-fire.[xxi] This concludes the explanation of the patient endurance of accepting pain. But in the noble Sāgaramati Sūtra, patient endurance is said to have three aspects:

blo gros rgya mtsho 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po thams cad mkhyen par sems bskyed pa rin po che de ltar bskyed nas/ 'phags pa ma yin pa tshul khrims 'chal pa'i sems can rnams sam/ bdud rnams sam/ bdud kyi ris kyi lha rnams sam/ bdud kyis byin gyis brlabs pa rnams sam/ bdud kyi pho nya rnams kyis gtses sam rnam par gtses sam bskyod dam kun tu bskyod dam/ dkrugs sam kun tu dkrugs sam/ spyos sam bsdigs sam brdegs kyang / byang chub tu bsam pa'i sems bskyed pa de las mi phyed pa dang / sems can thams cad rab tu thar bar byed pa'i snying rje chen pos/ / brtson 'grus brtsams pa las mi phyed pa dang / dkon mchog gsum gyi rigs mi 'chad par bya ba la brtson pa las mi phyed pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yang dag par bsgrub pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba la sbyor ba las mi phyed pa dang / mtshan dang dpe byad bzang po yongs su bsgrub par 'gyur ba'i bsod nams kyi tshogs bsags pa las mi phyed pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su sbyang ba mngon par bsgrub par brtson pa las mi phyed pa dang / lus dang srog 'dor zhing dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin par mngon par brtson pa las mi phyed pa dang / sems can thams cad yongs su smin par bya ba la mngon par brtson zhing bdag bde ba la mi chags pa las mi phyed pa ste/ de de ltar lhag pa'i bsam pa phun sum tshogs par gyur pas/ sems can thams cad kyis co dris kyang bzod/ thing slad byas pa dang / smad pa dang / bshung ba byas kyang bzod/ / sems can thams cad kyis mtshang brus sam spyos sam/ bsdigs sam/ ngan du brjod dam/ ngan du smras pa'i tshig gi lam kyang bzod/ sems can thams cad kyi gnod pa yang bzod/ sems can thams cad kyi khur yang bzod/ sgrol bas kyang skyo ba med/ zhum pa med/ kun du zhum pa med/ sgyid lug pa med/ yi chad pa med/ stobs nye bar ston par byed/ mthu skyed par byed cing brtson 'grus rtsom par byed la/ brtul bas brtul bar byed de de spro ba skyed cing rmongs pa'i sems mi 'dzin to/ / mtshang brus kyang slar mtshang mi 'bru ba dang / brdegs kyang slar mi rdeg / khros kyang slar mi khro/ / gshe ba la slar mi gshe ba ste/ de ltar sems 'grang ba'i go cha gyon no/ /

[185] Here, Sāgaramati, a bodhisattva great being, when tormented, shaken, disturbed, threatened, or beaten by sentient beings belonging to the entourage of Māra, or by deities controlled by demonic energies, or by Māra’s messengers, does not waver from the jewel of arousing the mind to complete knowing or from arousing the mind of higher intention. She does not waver from developing the perseverance of the great compassion that aims to set free all sentient beings. She does not waver from the heroism that maintains without interruption the lineage of the Three Jewels. She does not waver from applying skill in acquiring all wholesome states.[xxii] She does not waver from gathering the equipment of goodness so as to attain the perfection of the major and minor marks.[8] She does not waver from eagerness to accomplish the full purification of the Buddha field. She does not waver from applying herself to not owning anything.[xxiii] She does not waver from helping all sentient beings to mature or from not clinging to her own happiness. By completely fulfilling higher intention in this way, she is able to bear contemptuous treatment from all sentient beings; she is able to bear disrespect and criticism; she is able to bear angry words, rebukes, and ill-spoken, unwelcome forms of speech from all sentient beings. She is able to bear injuries from all sentient beings. She is able to bear the burdens of all sentient beings and bring them across. She does not get tired, is not dispirited nor depressed, and does not despair. She shows strength,[xxiv] arouses power, and develops perseverance. She is courageous, makes an effort, and keeps mental infatuation under control. Even when spoken to harshly, she does not speak harshly in return. Even when struck, she does not strike others in return. Even when others get angry at her, she does not get angry in return. Even when others berate her, she does not berate them in return.[9] In this way, she puts on the armor of inner contentment.[xxv]
'di lta ste theg pa chen po'i mdo 'di ni 'jig rten thams cad dang mi mthun pa'i theg pa'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sems can de dag ni rgyun gyi rjes su 'gro ba dag go/ /

bdag ni rgyun las ldog par rtsol bar 'dod pa'o/ / sems can de dag ni phan tshun mi mthun pa dag go/ / bdag ni sems can thams cad kyi mi mthun pa spang ba'i phyir go cha bgos pa'o/ / sems can de dag ni gnod sems la dpa' ba dag go/ / bdag ni bzod pa dang nges pa yongs su tshol ba'o/ / sems can de dag ni gcig la gcig 'drid cing yongs su 'drid par gnas pa dag go/ / bdag ni shes rab kyis ngoms pa yongs su tshol ba'o/ /

I wish to make an effort not to turn away from the continuity of this practice. Those sentient beings don’t get along with each other. I wear the armor in order to get rid of any disagreements with all sentient beings. Those sentient beings have only the courage to act out of malice. I search for patient endurance and for certainty. Those sentient beings deceive each other and spend their time on deceit. I seek satisfaction in wisdom
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gal te phyogs bcu'i rab tu dbye bas rab tu phye ba'i sems can ji snyed pa de dag thams cad/ ral gri dang shag ti dang mdung thung dang mtshon rtse gnyis pa la sogs pa lag na thogs te bdag gi phyi bzhin 'brang yang sa phyogs gang du 'greng ngam 'dug gam 'chag gam nyal yang rung ste byang chub kyi sems skye bar 'gyur ba dang / sbyin pa'i sems sam/ tshul khrims kyi sems sam/ bzod pa'i sems sam/ brtson 'grus kyi sems sam/ bsam gtan gyi sems sam/ shes rab kyi sems sam/ thos pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba'i sems skye bar 'gyur ba'i sa phyogs der bdag lus rgya shug gi lo ma'i brgya cha tsam du gtubs sam rnam par gtor ram/ rnam par bcom mam/ sems can de dag thams cad las gzhan mi byed par rgyun du gshe'am/ bsdigs sam/ smod dam/ bshung ngam/ tshig ngan pa dang / ngag rtsub po smra bar gyur kyang bdag gis sems can 'ga' la yang 'khrug pa'i sems bskyed par mi bya'o/ /

[186] Suppose there were a vast number of powerful beings, as numerous as the sentient beings in the ten directions, armed with swords, pikes, spears, double-pointed weapons, and so on,[xxvi] following right behind me. [Suppose they said that] if anyone in this place, whether standing, walking, seated, or lying down, arouses the Awakening Mind, or a thought of generosity, and so on up to: or a thought of wisdom, or arouses a thought of a wholesome action arising from study, then right here in this place they will injure and destroy that person’s body—my body—cutting it into a hundred pieces the size of jujube leaves. If all those sentient beings, impelled by the energy of harmful actions, were angry with me[xxvii] and were to censure me and condemn me, speaking ill of me with untruthful words and personal insults, or even break, injure, and destroy my body, cutting it into a hundred pieces the size of jujube leaves, I should not arouse any agitated thoughts towards those sentient beings.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sngon gyi mtha' nas 'khor ba tshad med par byas te/ gang du bdag gi lus 'di sems can dmyal bar song ngam/ dud 'gro'i skye gnas su song ngam/ gshin rje'i 'jig rten du song ngam/ mir gyur kyang rung ste/ 'dod pa'i zas kyi dri mas dri ma can du gyur nas chos thos pa dang mi ldan zhing / yang ba'i 'tsho ba'i spyod yul don med pas 'tsho ba can du 'gyur te/ yan lag dang nying lag rnam pa brgyar gshags shing gtubs te phye zhing phral la bya ba rnam pa mang po byas kyang bdag gis gzhi de las bdag gi don byas kyi/ gzhan gyi don ma byas kyi gal te sems can de dag thams cad kyis phyi ma'i mthar bdag gi lus gshegs gtubs rnam par gtor rnam par bcom pa de lta bur gyur kyang bdag gis thams cad mkhyen pa yongs su mi gtong ngo / / sems can thams cad yongs su mi gtong ngo / / dge ba'i chos 'dod pa yongs su mi gtong ngo / /

Why? During immeasurable, beginningless cyclic existence, when my body was in the hells, and among animals, and in the world of Yama, and among humans, while I was greedy for food and sensual pleasures,[xxviii] not getting to hear the Dharma, focused on the difficulty of making a living,[xxix] just surviving uselessly, my major and minor body parts were cut into a hundred pieces, broken and destroyed by various causes. And on that basis, neither my own welfare nor the welfare of others was achieved. If, from now until the end of time, all those sentient beings were to cut, break, injure, and destroy my bodies, I would not give up on complete knowing. I would not give up on all sentient beings. I would not give up on the motivation towards wholesome states.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ lus gtubs pa'i lus kyi gnod pa 'di thams cad kyis ni sems can dmyal ba pa'i sdug bsngal gyi brgya'i char yang nye bar mi 'gro ba nas rgyu'i bar du yang mi bzod do/ / bdag ni sems can dmyal bar gnas par spro'i bdag gis sangs rgyas kyi chos gtang bar ni mi bya'o/ /

Why is that? All this bodily pain and revolving through bodies does not even approach, or stand up to comparison with, one-hundredth part of the pain of the hells. And I am even able to bear living in the hells.[xxx] Now I should abandon neither the qualities of the Buddhas, nor the great compassion that takes all sentient beings as its objects
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gang gi gzhi las gnod sems byung ba'i chos de bdag gis spang bar bya'o snyam mo/ / chos de gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ lus la dga' ba dang lus la gnas pa dang lus la chags pa ste/ lus gtang na gnod sems kyang gtong ngo / / blo gros rgya mtsho de ltar chos 'grang ba la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po ni sems can thams cad kyi gnod pa bzod de mi skyo mi khro'o/ /

[187] We abandon the quality that is the basis for the arising of malice. And what is that quality? It is love of the body, regarding the body as a home, clinging to the body. If the body is given up, malice is also given up. Sāgaramati, in this way, a bodhisattva who has entered the congregation of the Dharma[xxxi] can bear the pain of all sentient beings.[xxxii]
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[xxxiii]

blo gros rgya mtsho de la thabs mkhas pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i lus gcod pa ni/ pha rol tu phyin pa drug bsgom pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ / blo gros rgya mtsho ji ltar na thabs la mkhas pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i lus gcod pa na/ pha rol tu phyin pa drug bsgom pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur zhe na/ gang lus 'dor ba dang lus yongs su gtong ba dang lus la mi lta ba 'di ni/ de'i sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / gang lus gcod pa na sems can thams cad la byams pas khyab par byed pa dang / tshor ba rnams kyis mi 'phrogs pa 'di ni de'i tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / gang lus yongs su gcod pa na gang dag de'i lus gcod pa de dag nyid rab tu thar bar bya ba'i phyir bzod cing sems kyis rma mi 'byin te/ bzod pa'i stobs nye bar ston pa 'di ni de'i bzod pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / brtson 'grus gang gis thams cad mkhyen pa de la 'dod pa mi 'dor zhing sems kyi stobs bskyed pa yang rab tu 'dzin la/ 'khor ba'i rjes su yang 'brang zhing dge ba'i rtsa ba brtsam pa yang rtsom pa 'di ni/ de'i brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / gang lus rnam par 'dor ba na thams cad mkhyen par sems bskyed pa rin po che de mi brjed cing byang chub nyid la lta ba dang / zhi ba dang rab tu zhi ba la so sor rtog pa 'di ni de'i bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / gang lus gcod pa na lus la rtswa dang rtsig pa dang shing dang rdo dang mig yor lta bur so sor rtog cing / lus la sgyu ma'i chos nyid du 'jug pa dang yang dag par na mi rtag pa nyid dang yang dag par na sdug bsngal ba nyid dang yang dag par na bdag med pa nyid dang / yang dag par na zhi ba nyid du lus la rtog pa 'di ni/ de'i shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / de bzhin du sbyar te/

Giving up the body, renouncing the body, having no regard for the body: this is their perfection of generosity. When their bodies are being cut apart, they extend lovingkindness to all sentient beings and are not restrained by sensations: this is their perfection of moral discipline. When their bodies are being cut apart, they endure patiently in order to set free the very ones who are cutting their bodies, and do not injure them even in their imagination: this is their perfection of patient endurance. That perseverance by which they do not give up their motivation for complete knowing, generate and sustain inner strength, endure cyclic existence,[xxxiv] and take up wholesome actions: this is their perfection of perseverance. The quality by which, when their bodies are being harmed, they do not become too confused to engage in the jewel of arousing the mind to complete knowing, have regard only for Awakening, and look only towards peace and tranquility: this is their perfection of meditative stability. The quality by which, when their bodies are being cut, they thoroughly understand that their bodies are like grass, sticks, walls,[xxxv] and reflected images, and by which they engage with the illusory nature of the body, and accurately reflect, with reference to their bodies, on the impermanence of being, the suffering of being, the absence of any self in being, and the peacefulness of being: this is their perfection of wisdom. And so on at length.

gzhan yang de 'di snyam du sems te/ sems can 'di ni le lo can dge ba'i chos dang bral ba ste/ de ni bdag la mtshang 'bru zhing gshe ba'o/ / bdag ni brtson 'grus brtsam par bya/ dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su btsal bar brtson pa la mi ngoms par bya ste/ sems can 'di byang chub kyi snying por sngar je 'dug par byas la/ phyis bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar bya'o/ /

Moreover, the same person also thinks: [188] This sentient being is lazy and lacking in bright qualities. He gets angry and criticizes me. We should develop perseverance! We should be insatiably devoted to searching for wholesome actions. I should help this sentient being to sit down first on the seat of Awakening, and afterwards I should fully awaken to highest genuine full Awakening …[xxxvi]
snyam du de ltar go cha gyon pa 'di ni/ de'i brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ /
Thinking this, in that way he puts on the armor. This is his perfection of perseverance.
de bzhin du sbyar te/
sems can ma dul ba/ ma zhi ba/ ma sbas pa/ nye bar ma zhi ba/ 'di lta bu 'di dag gi don du bdag gis go cha chen po bgos te/
For the welfare of such untrained, unprotected, restless sentient beings, we should put on the armor.[xxxvii]
'di ltar sems nges par sems su gzhug go snyam pa 'di ni/ de'i bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ /
This will lead to inner certainty. This way of thinking is their perfection of meditative stability.
de bzhin du sbyar te/

bdag ni chos nyid la brten par bya'o snyam nas/ de la gshe ba dang khro ba su yin zhes des yongs su tshol ba na gang gshe ba dang khro ba'i chos de mi dmigs so/ / de bdag dang gzhan mi dmigs pas dmigs par lta ba dang bral bar bzod pa 'di ni/ de'i shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'o zhes gsungs so/ /

Oh! We should rely on the way things are. Who is it that is criticizing you or getting angry at you? Even if you search for it, you don’t find any such entity. Those who get angry or have others get angry at them, when they don’t perceive either “self” or “other,” free from false views, they endure patiently. {This is their perfection of wisdom.}

bcom ldan 'das ma las kyang gsungs te/ 'di ltar bdag gis sems can thams cad kyi rtsod pa dor bar bya ba yin no/ / bdag nyid rtsod par byed dam/ bdag gang smra ba la slar smra na ni/ bdag gis ma rnyed pa dang nyes pa rnyed par 'gyur ro/ / ji ltar bdag gis ni sems can thams cad kyi zam pa lta bur bya na/ bdag gzhan la khyod ces bya ba'i tshig gam tshig rtsub po smra bar bya ba'am/ 'di ni bdag gis smra bar mi bya ste/ 'thab pa dang / rtsod pa'i nang du bdag gis bem po lta bu dang / lug ltar lkugs pa lta bur bya'o/ / gzhan gyis ngan du smras pa dang ngan du brjod pa'i tshig gi lan thos na sems kyi kun du gnod sems su mi bya'o/ / bdag gis gzhan dag la gang gzhan gyis nyes pa gzhan skyes na de ni bdag la legs pa ma yin pa dag gi cha ma yin no/ / gang bdag gis gzhan dag gi nyes pa gzhan mnyam par bsams pa de ni bdag gi cha ma yin no/ /

The Blessed [Perfection of Wisdom in Eight Thousand Lines] also says,[10] “Though I should put aside quarrels with all sentient beings, still I myself quarrel. If I reply as I am spoken to, that is a loss for me, not a gain. I should be a bridge for all sentient beings, but instead I say ‘The same to you!’ or speak harsh words to people. I shouldn’t speak like that. In strife and quarrels, I should be like an inanimate object, or as speechless as a sheep. When I hear the ill-said, unwelcome, ill-spoken words and speech of others, my mind should not hold on to anger. It is not appropriate, it is not suitable for me, that I should think about the faults of others, or believe that I should listen to talk about others’ faults.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ bdag gis bsam pa rnam par 'khrugs par mi bya'o/ / 'di ltar bdag gis ni sems can thams cad bde bar sbyar ba thams cad kyis bde bar bya zhing bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar bya ste/ mya ngan las 'das par bya ba yin na/ de la bdag gnod sems su byed dam/ shin tu nyes pa byas kyang gzhan dag la gnod sems mi bya ba yin na de la bdag gti mug tu 'gyur ram/ 'di ni bdag gis bya ba'i cha yin te/ brtul ba brtan par brtul bar bya'o/ / srog gi bar chad byed kyang bdag gis 'khrugs par mi bya'o/ / bdag gis khro gnyer can gyi bzhin dbyung bar mi bya'o zhes de ltar sems bskyed do zhes gsungs so/ /

Why is that? I must not disturb the aspiration by which I will make sentient beings happy with all forms of happiness and assistance, set them free, and help them awaken fully to highest genuine full Awakening. But I have malice towards them! I should have no malice even towards those who create severe problems for me,[xxxviii] nor become confused with respect to them. Instead, this is what I should do: I should act courageously, with firm courage. I should not be agitated even when my life is in danger. I should never have a frowning face.” This is what such a person should think.

byang chub sems dpa'i so sor thar pa las kyang / sems can gang dag khros pa de dag la dbugs 'byin to yid phebs par byed do bzod pa gsol lo rjes su mthun par byed do/ / chos kyis tshim par byed do zhes gsungs so/ /

The Vows of Individual Liberation for Bodhisattvas also says, She encourages those sentient beings who are angry, {gets them to trust her,} helps them to endure patiently, gets along with them, and satisfies them with Dharma.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las/ bzod pa'i le'u ste dgu pa'o// //
[brtson 'grus]
10. The Perfection of Perseverance

de ltar bzod pa la gnas nas thos pa la brtson 'grus rtsom ste/ gzhan du na de'i thos pa chud za ba nyid du 'gyur te/ zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las ji skad du/ ji snyed chos rnams mang po chub byas kyang / / thos pas rgyags nas tshul khrims mi srung ba/ / tshul khrims 'chal pa ngan 'gror gang 'gro ba/ / de la mang du thos pas skyob mi nus/ / zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

[189] THOSE WHO ABIDE in patient endurance in this way should develop perseverance in learning. Otherwise, their learning goes to waste. As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[i] Even if you master many teachings, If, intoxicated by learning, you don’t guard moral discipline, You cannot, through great learning, protect yourself From going to the lower realms due to being immoral.

mang du thos pa'i bsngags pa ni sred med kyi bus zhus pa'i mdo las gsungs te/ 'di ltar rigs kyi bu thos pa dang ldan na shes rab 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / shes rab dang ldan na nyon mongs pa rab tu zhi bar 'gyur ro/ / nyon mongs pa med pa la bdud kyis glags mi rnyed do zhes bya ba'o/ / de las yang drang srong chen po bla ma'i skyes pa'i rabs rgya cher mdzad nas gsungs te/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'dod pa bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa gus pa dang bcas pa rnams la 'jig rten gyi khams gzhan na bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dag zhal nye bar ston to/ / chos kyang thos par mdzad do/ / dri ma med pa'i gzi brjid byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'dod pa dag la ni chos kyi gter ri sul dang shing gi nang du bcug pa dang chos kyi glegs bam du gyur pa mtha' yas pa dag kyang lag mthil du gnas par 'gyur ro/ / dri ma med pa'i gzi brjid byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos 'dod pa rnams la sngon sangs rgyas mthong ba'i lha rnams spobs pa nye bar sgrub bo/ /

On the other hand, the Inquiry of Nārāyaṇa praises learning as follows: In this way, noble sir, if you have learning, wisdom will arise. If you have wisdom, reactive emotions will be pacified. Māra can find no entry into one who is free of reactive emotions. Also, after a lengthy birth-story about the Great Sage Uttara, the same text says: Vimalatejas,[1] to bodhisattva great beings who long for the Dharma, if they are respectful,[ii] even if they live in other world-realms, the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, show their faces and cause them to hear Dharma. Vimalatejas, for bodhisattva great beings who long for the Dharma, treasures of Dharma have been placed in mountains, caves, and trees. There are limitless Dharma doors in books in the palm of your hand. Vimalatejas, to bodhisattvas who have seen previous Buddhas and who long for the Dharma, gods provide the illumination of the Buddhas
de bzhin du sbyar te/

tshe yongs su zad na yang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams dang lha rnams tshe dang stobs nye bar sgrub po/ / de dag sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs dang lha'i byin gyi rlabs kyis 'dod na lo stong du yang gnas so/ /

[190] For those whose lifespan is exhausted, the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, and the deities provide life and strength.[iii] Through the energy of the Buddhas and through the energy of the deities, those who wish will remain for a thousand years
de bzhin du sbyar te/

bskal pa'am bskal pa'i lhag ma nas ji tsam du 'dod pa de tsam du gnas so/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos la gus pa bskyed pa rnams la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams rga ba yang sel bar mdzad do/ / nad kyang sel bar mdzad do/ / dran pa nye bar sgrub bo/ / rtogs pa dang blo gros dang spobs pa yang nye bar sgrub bo/ /

For as much as an aeon, or what is left of the present aeon, or as long as they wish, for so long they will remain. From bodhisattva great beings who arouse respect, the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, even take away old age. They take away illness. They provide mindfulness. They provide understanding,[iv] intelligence, and illumination.
de bzhin du sbyar te/

lta bar gyur pa yang sel to/ / yang dag par lta ba yang nye bar sgrub bo/ / dri ma med pa'i gzi brjid byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po chos la gus pa rnams la pha rol gyi gnod pa'i 'jigs pa thams cad mi 'byung ngo / / dri ma med pa'i gzi brjid de lta bas na byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos thos pa'i tshogs mkhas pa la mngon par brtson par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

They drive away wrong views and provide the right view. Vimalatejas, for bodhisattva great beings who have respect for the Dharma, all external dangers never arise. Therefore, Vimalatejas, a bodhisattva great being should be focused on skill in the equipment of learning.

thos pa'i rnam pa ji lta bu byang chub sems dpa'i 'dul ba la bsngags she na/ 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pas zhus pa'i mdo las/ thos pa'i rnam pa ni brgyad cu ste/ 'di lta ste/ 'dun pa'i rnam pa dang / bsam pa'i rnam pa dang / lhag pa'i bsam pa'i rnam pa dang / sbyor ba'i rnam pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyi rnam pa dang / nga rgyal med pa'i rnam pa dang / bag yod pa'i rnam pa dang / ri mor byed pa'i rnam pa dang / mthun pa'i rnam pa dang / bka' blo bde ba'i rnam pa dang / bsnyen bkur byed pa'i rnam pa dang / rna blags te nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / yid la byed pa'i rnam pa dang / mi g.yeng ba'i rnam pa dang / gnas kyi rnam pa dang / rin po cher 'du shes pa'i rnam pa dang / sman du 'du shes pa'i rnam pa dang / nyon mongs pa'i nad thams cad zhi bar byed pa'i rnam pa dang / dran pa'i snod kyi rnam pa dang / shes pa rtogs pa'i rnam pa dang / blo gros rtogs pa'i rnam pa dang / blo la 'jug pa'i rnam pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos la mi ngoms par nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / gtong ba spel pa'i rnam pa dang / dul zhing cang shes pa'i rnam pa dang / mang du thos pa la brten pa'i rnam pa dang / gus par dga' ba myong bar byed pa'i rnam pa dang / lus bde ba'i rnam pa dang / sems rab tu dga' ba'i rnam pa dang / mi skyo bar nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / don nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / chos nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / nan tan nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / gzhan gyis bstan pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / chos ma thos pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / mngon par shes pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / theg pa gzhan la 'dod pa med pa'i rnam pa dang / pha rol tu phyin pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / rin po che nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / bsdu ba'i dngos po nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / thabs la mkhas pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / tshangs pa'i gnas pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / dran pa dang shes bzhin nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / skye ba la mkhas pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / mi skye ba la mkhas pa nyan pa'i rnam pa dang / mi sdug pa'i rnam pa dang /

What kind of learning is praised in the monastic code for bodhisattvas? The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra[v] explains: [191] There are eighty aspects of learning.[2] They are:[vi] Motivation; aspiration; higher intention; practical application; magical production; immeasurable; spiritual teacher; respect; circumambulation; eloquence; courtesy; making listeners pay attention; applying attention; nondistraction; abode; conceived of as a jewel; conceived of as medicine; curing all illnesses;[vii] vessel of mindfulness; making known past lives; illuminating the mind; entering the intellect; never getting enough of listening to the Buddha’s teachings; nourishing renunciation; tamed and well bred; studying under the greatly learned; enjoying being respectful to others; bodily delight; mental delight; not getting tired of listening; listening to the Dharma; hearing about virtuous behavior;[viii] listening to the teaching of others; hearing what you haven’t heard before; hearing about the superknowledges; freedom from longing to hear about other Ways; hearing about the Perfection of Wisdom; listening to the scriptural collection of the bodhisattvas; hearing about the ways of attracting people; hearing about skill in means; hearing about the Divine Abidings; hearing about mindfulness and awareness; respect; hearing about skill with respect to arising; hearing about skill with respect to nonarising; foulness;

byams pa'i rnam pa dang / rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i rnam pa dang / mi rtag pa'i rnam pa dang / sdug bsngal ba'i rnam pa dang / bdag med pa'i rnam pa dang / zhi ba'i rnam pa dang / stong pa nyid kyi rnam pa dang / mtshan ma med pa'i rnam pa dang / smon pa med pa'i rnam pa dang / mngon par 'du mi byed pa'i rnam pa dang / dge ba'i mngon par 'du byed pa'i rnam pa dang / bden par byin gyis brlabs pa'i rnam pa dang / chud mi gzan pa'i rnam pa dang / rang dbang gi rnam pa dang / bdag gi sems srung ba'i rnam pa dang / brtson 'grus mi gtong ba'i rnam pa dang / chos la nges par rtog pa'i rnam pa dang / nyon mongs pa'i gnyen po'i rnam pa dang / bdag gi phyogs srung ba'i rnam pa dang / pha rol gyi phyogs dang nyon mongs pa tshar gcod pa'i rnam pa dang / nor bdun la brten pa'i rnam pa dang / dbul ba thams cad tshar gcod pa'i rnam pa dang / mkhas pas bsngags pa'i rnam pa dang / mkhas pa mngon par dga' ba'i rnam pa dang / 'phags pas kun shes pa'i rnam pa dang / 'phags pa ma yin pa rnams mos par byed pa'i rnam pa dang / bden pa mthong ba'i rnam pa dang / phung po'i nyes pa spang ba'i rnam pa dang / 'dus byas kyi nyes pa yongs su 'jal ba'i rnam pa dang / don la brten pa'i rnam pa dang / chos la brten pa'i rnam pa dang / ye shes la brten pa'i rnam pa dang / nges pa'i don gyi mdo sde la brten pa'i rnam pa dang / sdig pa thams cad mi bya ba'i rnam pa dang / bdag dang gzhan la phan pa'i rnam pa dang / legs par byas pa'i las kyi rnam pa dang / mi 'gyod pa'i rnam pa dang / bye brag tu 'gro ba'i rnam pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad 'thob pa'i rnam pa ste/ 'di dag ni byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi thos pa'i rnam pa brgyad cu zhes gsungs so/ /
