hearing about lovingkindness; dependent arising; impermanence; suffering; no-self; peace; emptiness, no characteristics, and no aspirations; nonaccomplishment; accomplishing what is wholesome; giving energy to sentient beings;[ix] not wasting; one’s own power;[x] protecting one’s own mind; not slacking off from perseverance; deep meditation on Dharma; remedies for reactive emotions; drawing to oneself those on one’s own side;[xi] putting an end to the reactive emotions that are the other side;[xii] gathering the Seven Riches; putting an end to all poverty; praised by the wise; celebrated by the learned; agreed on by the Noble Ones; gaining the trust of those who are not noble; seeing the truth; leaving behind the problems that come from the aggregates; considering the problems that come from conditioning; relying on the meaning; relying on the Dharma;[3] not doing anything wrong; benefiting oneself and others; good actions; having no regrets;[xiii] going towards excellence;[xiv] attaining all the virtues of a Buddha.[xv] {These are the eighty aspects of the learning of a bodhisattva.}

yang de nyid las gsungs pa/ gang chos kyi tshogs la sbyor ba de ni de'i ye shes kyi tshogs yin no/ / de la chos kyi tshogs su sbyor ba gang zhe na/ gang 'di ni don nyung ba dang bya ba nyung ba dang smra ba nyung ba dang yo byad nyung ba dang srod dang tho rangs la mi nyal zhing rnal 'byor la brtson pas/ thos pa'i don la rtogs pa dang / yang dang yang tshol ba dang / sems la rnyog pa med pa dang / sgrib pa rnams gnon pa dang / ltung ba rnams las 'byung ba shes shing 'gyod pa med pa dang kun nas ldang ba med pa dang / nan tan snying por byed pa dang / chos la gzhol pa dang / chos la 'bab pa dang / chos la bab pa dang / mthu dang ldan pa dang / ye shes tshol ba la mgo dang gos la me 'bar ba lta bu dang / de la ma chags par gnas pa dang / tshul khrims mi lhod pa dang / brtson pa mi gtong ba dang / bye brag tu 'gro ba dang / 'du 'dzi la mi dga' ba dang / gcig pur dga' ba dang / dgon pa la mngon par phyogs shing yid la byed pa dang / 'phags pa'i rigs kyis chog shes pa dang / sbyangs pa'i yon tan las mi g.yo ba dang / chos kyi dga' ba la dga' zhing mos pa dang / 'jig rten pa'i sngags dran par mi byed pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos tshol ba dang / dran pa nyams pa med pa dang / don rtogs pa'i rjes su 'gro ba dang / blo gros kyi lam dang mthun pa dang / bstan pas sdom pa dang / rkyen gyis ye shes kyi rjes su 'gro ba dang / khrel yod pa dang ngo tsha shes pas brgyan pa dang / ye shes kyi rjes su 'gro ba lhur byed pa dang / mi shes pa sel ba dang / ma rig pa dang / gti mug gi mun pa dang rab rib kyi mun pas chod pa bsal ba dang / shes rab kyi mig rnam par dag pa dang / blo shin tu rnam par dag pa dang / blo rgya che ba dang / blo ma zhum pa dang / blo ma gyes pa dang / mngon sum du shes pa dang / yon tan gzhan la rag ma lus pa dang / bdag gi yon tan mi bsnyems pa dang / gzhan gyi yon tan kun la brjod pa dang / legs par bya ba'i las byed pa dang / las kyi rnam par smin pa dang 'gal bar mi byed pa dang / las yongs su dag pa'i ye shes 'di ni/ btsun pa sha ra dwa ti'i bu byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi ye shes kyi tshogs mi zad pa zhes 'byung ngo / /

Moreover, the same text says: [192] For them, the practice of the equipment of Dharma is their equipment of pristine awareness. In this context, what is the practice of the equipment of Dharma? It is: having few goals; having few duties; speaking few words; having few possessions; staying awake from one night to the next, devoted to practice; reflecting on the meaning of what you have studied; searching again and again; a mind that is not clouded; putting a stop to the hindrances to attention; knowing that you have gone beyond downfalls; having no regrets; not getting up from your seated posture;[xvi] the essence of virtuous behavior; being bent on Dharma, being inclined to Dharma, being motivated towards Dharma; possessing valor; seeking knowledge as if your head and clothes were on fire; living like this, without attachment;[xvii] having strict moral discipline; not having laid down the yoke; going towards excellence; living alone and giving up social interactions; turning one’s attention towards the wilderness; being satisfied with the four noble traditions; not wavering from the intense practices; taking delight at living in the Dharma; forgetting about worldly tricks; seeking transcendent qualities; not losing mindfulness; following reflection on the meaning;[xviii] conforming to the path of the intellect; with constancy, and with your commitments as the conditions, going in search of knowledge; having the ornaments of a sense of shame and a sense of decency; energetically going in search of knowledge; dispersing the lack of knowledge; clearing away the diseased coating of ignorance, delusion, and darkness that obscures the eye of wisdom; utter purity of intellect; vastness of intellect; having an undaunted intellect; having an open mind;[xix] knowing by direct perception; having abilities that do not depend on others;[xx] not being proud of your own abilities; praising others’ abilities; doing good actions; not ignoring the evolution of actions; knowing the purity of action.[xxi]

ci mnyan par bya zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das kyis ye shes shin tu rgyas pa'i mdo las/ don dang bcas pa'i gzhon nu rtse ba'i bstan bcos rnams bslab par bya'o/ / don med pa rnams yongs su spang bar bya'o/ / 'di lta ste/ 'jig rten rgyang 'phen pa'i bstan bcos rnams dang / chad pa'i tshul gyi bstan bcos rnams dang / byad stems kyi bstan bcos rnams dang / smra ba'i rig pa'i bstan bcos rnams dang / gzhon nu rtse ba'i bstan bcos rnams dang / rmugs byed kyi rig pa'i bstan bcos rnams so/ /

What should you study? In the Sūtra on Vast Knowledge, the Blessed One said: You should train in beneficial treatises.[xxii] Avoid those of no benefit. Those [to avoid] are: materialist treatises; treatises on criminal justice; treatises on malicious spirits;[xxiii] treatises on linguistics; books on young men’s sports; and sex manuals.[xxiv]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de las gzhan pa gang ci yang rung ste/ rnam par thar pa dang mi mthun pa'i bstan bcos shes pa rmongs par 'gyur ba de dag thams cad byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa la yang dag par zhugs pas spang bar bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / de ltar thos pa dang ldan pa sems sbyang ba'i phyir dgon par gnas par bya'o/ /

Moreover, whatever other treatises there may be that are opposed to freedom and lead to confusion, those practicing the bodhisattva way should give up all of them. In this way, those who have studied should go off to the wilderness in order to purify their minds.

drag shul can gyis zhus pa las/ bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa ma yin pa la yang khyim gnang ba ji ltar yin zhe na/ 'bad pa dang ldan mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ / 'o na gzhan gyi chung ma la yang ltung ba med par 'gyur ro/ / de ni ma yin te/ de dag la mi nus su zin kyang rang bzhin gyis skyon du 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / khyim du gnas pa ni bcas pa'i kha na ma tho ba dang bcas pa'i phyir ro/ /

[OBJECTION:] Why, then, does the Inquiry of Ugra say that living at home is permitted even for someone who has the right aspiration? [REPLY:] Because even someone who is making an effort may be incapable. [OBJECTION:] [In that case,] adultery and so on would also not be downfalls. [REPLY:] This is not correct! Even for those who are not capable [of refraining from adultery, such actions] are reprehensible by nature, whereas the household life is reprehensible by convention.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las/ brtson 'grus kyi le'u ste bcu pa'o// //

d.crumb: 11. dgon par gnas par brjod pa zhes bya ba

f.d: [dgon par gnas par brjod pa zhes bya ba]
11. Praise of the Wilderness[i]
de ltar na drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i tshul gyis khyim gyi skyon rnams bsgoms te dgon pa la gnas par bya'o zhes bya bar gnas so/ / ji skad du zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las/ /

[193] THEREFORE, THOSE WHO have studied should meditate on the disadvantages of home life using the method in the Inquiry of Ugra, and then go off to the wilderness to purify their minds. As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[ii]
'dod pa dag ni rab tu sten byed cing / / bu dang chung ma dag la sred byed na/ / smad par bya ba'i khyim la brten pa de/ / nam yang bla med byang chub mchog mi 'thob/ /
Those who indulge in sensual pleasures, Who are subject to craving for wives and sons, Who rely on the home life, which is abhorrent, Never attain the supreme, highest Awakening.
gang dag 'dod pa lci skam me bzhin spong / / bu dang chung ma dag la sred spangs nas/ / khyim gyis skrag ste khyim nas mngon byung ba/ / de dag byang chub mchog 'di rnyed mi dka'/ /

Those who avoid sensual pleasures like a fire of dry dung,[iii] Who have given up attachment to children and wives, Who, afraid,[iv] go forth from the home life— Supreme Awakening is not difficult for them.
gang dag khyim na gnas par byed bzhin du/ / byang chub dam pa mchog 'di 'thob pa yi/ / sangs rgyas gang dag sngon chad ma byung ste/ / ma 'ongs pa na'ang mi 'byung gnas pa med/ /
There was never in the past, nor is there in the present, Nor will there ever be in the future, A Buddha who, living at home, Attained the supreme, highest Awakening.
rgyal srid mchil ma'i thal ba bzhin spangs nas/ / dben pa 'dod des dgon par gnas byed pa/ / nyon mongs spangs nas bdud ni bcom nas su/ / byang chub rdul med 'dus ma byas 'tshang rgya/ /

Those who long for solitude should Give up royal power like a drop of mucus, and live in wilderness areas. They give up reactive emotions and strike down pride;[v] They awaken to an Awakening that is unconditioned and free from dust
de bzhin du sbyar te/
rab tu byung nas chos spyod ci 'dra ba/ / zas dang skom dang de bzhin gos rnams dang / / me tog spos dang phreng ba rnams kyis ni/ / khyu mchog rnams la bsnyen bkur byas mi 'gyur/ /
The highest people, who are ordained, like the Victors, And who live the Teachings, Are not waited upon with food, drinks, and robes, Flowers, perfumes, and ornaments.
gang zhig byang chub rab tu 'dod byed cing / / 'dus byas ngan las yid byung sems can gyi/ / don du dgon par phyogs te gom bdun bor/ / 'di ni de bas bsod nams khyad par 'phags/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

And those who long for Awakening and are disenchanted with bad conditioning, In order to help sentient beings, Should turn towards the wilderness and take seven steps. This, then, is excellent goodness.
gal te skal ba mi 'dra ba'i sems can la rjes su chags pa dang 'khor 'dod pa dang rnyed pa la sogs pa 'dod pas dben pa'i phyogs na sdod na/ de'i phyir 'di las gsungs pa/

[194] Now, there are some who, due to attachment to the wrong kind of people, and due to desire for social interactions and for money and so on, delay in going to the place of solitude. For their benefit, the same text says:[vi]
'di dag bdag la gnod sems ldan pa zhes/ / mkhas pas byis pa rnams dang rtsod mi byed/ / bsti stang byas te byis pa yongs su spong / / byis pa'i chos la 'dris par yongs mi byed/ /
The wise don’t quarrel with fools, Even if they think, “They bear malice towards me”; They greet fools politely and then avoid them, And do not make friends with those who are fools by nature.
byis pa ji srid yun ring legs bsten kyang / / de dag phyir zhing mi mdza' 'gras 'gyur zhes/ / byis pa'i ngo bo nyid kyi rgyus shes nas/ / mkhas pa byis pa dag dang sten mi byed/ /
The intelligent don’t spend a lot of time with fools Once they understand the nature of their personality. Regardless of how long fools are treated well, They still act just like enemies.

byis pa rang bzhin ngo bo tha dad de/ / so so'i skye bo rnams la mdza' med ces/ / byis pa rnams kyi ngo bo nyid shes nas/ / mkhas 'dir byis pa rnams la yid mi rton/ / chos dang mthun pa'i tshig gis smras gyur kyang / / khro dang zhe sdang yid mi ches ba dag / rab tu smra ste 'di ni byis pa'i chos/ / don de rnam par shes nas yid mi rton/ /

Fools are divisive by nature; Where is there a true friend among ordinary people? When addressed with words that harmonize with the Dharma, Those who are fools by nature React with wrath, hatred, and ill-will. When you understand this truth, don’t have confidence in them!

byis pa rnams ni byis pa dag dang mtshungs/ / dper na ngan skyugs dang ni ngan skyugs bzhin/ / mkhas pa rnams ni mkhas dang lhan cig ste/ / mar dang mar gyi nying khur mtshungs pa bzhin/ / zhes bya'o/ /
Fools and fools equally go together, Like filth with filth. But the wise go together with the wise, Like clarified butter in a layer of butter.

de skad du yang de nyid las/ / gang dag dga' dang mi dga' cung zad med/ / de dag mi yi 'jig rten rtag rab bde/ / gang dag nags dang ri sul la dga' ba/ / dge sbyong nyid kyi rab bde myong bar 'gyur/ / gang dag bdag gir byed pa ci yang med/ / gang dag yongs 'dzin rnam pa kun tu med/ / bse ru lta bur 'jig rten 'dir gnas pa/ / de dag nam mkha' la ni rlung ltar 'gro/ /

[195] And the same text says:[vii] Those who have no likes and dislikes Are always blissful in the human world. Those who are delighted in a cave,[viii] Who experience the great happiness of the religious wanderer, Who have not even the thought “mine” And have no possessions of any kind— They wander in the world like the rhinoceros. They move like the wind in the sky.

gang dag 'jig rten la ni yid mi chags/ / de dag mi yi 'jig rten rab tu bde/ / dga' dang mi dga' la ni chags med pa/ / de dag 'di na rtag tu sems rlung 'dra/ / gang dag mi sdug de phrad sdug bsngal te/ / gang dag sdug de dang bral sdug bsngal yin/ / mtha' de gnyi ga rab tu spangs nas su/ / mi gang chos la dga' ba de dag bde/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Those whose minds are not attached to the world Are happy in the human world;[ix] Not attached to likes and dislikes, Their minds are always like the wind. Meeting those you don’t like is suffering. Separation from those you like is suffering. Those who are pleased with the Dharma are happy Since they have given up both extremes.
yang de nyid las/ nyes pa'i tshogs mang thams cad spangs nas su/ / rnal 'byor can ni rtag tu byed pa nyung / / rnal 'byor can brtson nam yang rtsod pa med/ / dgon par gnas pa de yi yon tan 'di/ /

Also, the same text says:[x] Having completely given up a great host of problems,[xi] They[xii] always have little to do. They never quarrel, making an effort at practice. Living in the wilderness has these advantages for them.
de ni rtag tu 'dus byas yid 'byung 'gyur/ / de ni 'jig rten ci la'ang 'dod pa med/ / zag pa dag ni rnam par 'phel mi 'gyur/ / nags na gnas pa 'di yi yon tan 'di/ /
They are always disenchanted from the conditioned And have no longing for anything in the world. Their outflows do not increase; These are advantages of living in the forest.
de ni nam yang rtsod par mi 'gyur te/ / rtag tu zhi zhing dga' la dben par rgyu/ / lus dang ngag dang yid kyang rab bsdam 'gyur/ / dgon par gnas pa 'di la yon tan mang / /

They never have any reason to quarrel, But are always pleased with tranquility, moving in solitude. They are disciplined in thought, word, and deed. Living in the wilderness has many advantages for them.
de ni thar pa'i rjes su mthun pa yin/ / de ni rnam grol zhi ba myur rtogs byed/ / nags na gnas shing rnam grol sten byed na/ / dgon gnas de la yon tan 'di kun 'byung / / zhes gsungs so/ /
For them, the current runs towards freedom; They easily attain peace and liberation. Living in the forest conduces to liberation for them. Living in the wilderness has all these advantages.

yang de nyid las/ grong dang grong khyer dag la dga' spangs la/ / rtag tu dben zhing nags khrod bsten par gyis/ / bse ru lta bur rtag tu gnyis med byos/ / ring por mi thogs ting 'dzin mchog thob 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

And it says:[xiii] If you give up going to villages and towns,[xiv] Always solitary, spending time in forest regions, If you are always alone without a companion, like a rhinoceros, [196] The supreme meditative absorption will not be delayed for long.[xv]

'phags pa yul 'khor skyong gis zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / / skyon gyis gzings pa mtha' yas ldan pa'i khyim spangs rtag tu nor mi lta/ / des shing yon tan ldan pa de dag dgon par dga' zhing dbang po dul/ /

The noble Rāṣṭrapāla Sūtra also says,[1] Having given up the home, Never worrying or thinking about that endless thicket of problems, They find delight in the wilderness, Able and heroic, with peaceful faculties.

de dag gang du'ang bud med rnams dang skyes pa dag dang 'dris mi byed/ / bse ltar gcig pur gnas shing bsam pa dri med dag la dri ma bral/ / de dag thob pa rnams kyis dga' bar mi 'gyur ma thob yid zhum med/ / 'dod pa chung ste ngan ngon tsam la dga' zhing sgyu dang tshul 'chos spongs/ /

They have no close friendships with women Nor with men, in any way. They live alone like the rhinoceros, Stainless, with pure intentions. They have no exhilaration due to gain And feel no discouragement about loss. They have few desires and are satisfied with just the bare necessities; They given up deception and hypocrisy.[xvi]

sems can don phyir brtson 'grus yid ldan sbyin dang dul ba la yang gnas/ / sangs rgyas ye shes don gnyer bsam gtan brtson 'grus yon tan pha rol phyin/ / lus dang de bzhin srog la mi lta sdug pa'i rtsa lag rnam spangs te/ / bsam pa rdo rje lta bur rab brtan rtag tu byang chub lam la sbyor/ / lus ni dum bu dum bur bcad kyang de dag sems la g.yo ba med/ / thams cad mkhyen nyid re ba phyir zhing brtson 'grus shin tu brtan 'dir rtsom/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

In order to help sentient beings, they have perseverance in their minds; They live in generosity and discipline. Aiming for the Buddha’s pristine awareness, They perfect their abilities in perseverance and meditative stability. They have no regard for their bodies, no regard for their lives; They leave behind their beloved relatives. With their minds very stable, like the vajra, They always unite with the path of Awakening. Even if their bodies were to be cut into pieces, Their minds would not move. For the sake of the hope of complete knowing, They here develop very stable perseverance.
drag shul can gyis zhus pa las kyang / bdag ni sems can dang 'dre bar mi bya'o/ / bdag gis sems can gcig gi dge ba'i rtsa ba bskyed par mi bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /
The Inquiry of Ugra also says, “I should have no social interactions with others. I should not lead just one sentient being towards wholesome actions.”[2]

gal te thos pa dang ldan pa dal ba phun sum tshogs pa 'di rnyed nas rnyed pa la sogs pa la chags pa'i sems mi sbyong na de ni lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten la slu ba gcig pur 'gyur ro/ / 'phags pa dkon mchog brtsegs pa las kyang /

Someone who has found this favorable opportunity to practice that includes hearing the Dharma, and who, due to attachment to money and so on, doesn’t purify her mind, would have lied to the world, including the gods. For the noble Heap of Jewels says,

'od srungs 'di lta ste dper na mi la la zhig rgya mtsho'i chu chen pos khyer la chus skom bzhin du 'chi ba'i dus byed pa de bzhin du 'od srungs 'di ni dge sbyong dang bram ze kha cig chos mang po blangs te kun chub par byas kyang / 'dod chags la sred pa mi sel zhe sdang la sred pa mi sel gti mug la sred pa mi sel ba de dag ni chos kyi rgya mtsho chen pos khyer la/ nyon mongs pa'i skom pas 'chi ba'i dus byed par 'gyur te/ ngan 'gror 'gro bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /

Kāśyapa, for example, suppose someone, while traveling on the vast ocean, were to die of thirst. In the same way, Kāśyapa, certain Brahmins and religious wanderers receive many teachings and understand them, but they do not remove the craving of attraction, nor the craving of aversion, nor the craving of delusion.[3] While traveling on the vast ocean of Dharma, they die of the thirst of reactivity, and they fall down into the lower realms.

de lta bas na gdon mi za bar dgon pa la gnas par bya'o/ / gnas de lta bu dag ni 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las kyang / gnas gang dag na bsod snyoms blang ba'i spyod yul dang ha cang yang mi ring ha cang yang mi nye ba dang / gnas gang dag na chu dang zhing rnyog pa med pa gtsang zhing dri ma med pa tshegs chung ba yod pa dang / gnas gang na shing phun sum tshogs pa me tog phun sum tshogs pa 'bras bu phun sum tshogs pa lo ma phun sum tshogs pa/ gcan gzan khro bo med pa phug dang ldan pa sman gshong dang ldan pa thag thug med pa 'gro na bde ba zhi ba gnyis su med pa'i gnas de 'dra ba dag na gnas so/ / de gnas de dag na gnas shing / gang des sngon blangs pa dang sngon thos pa de nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum du ha cang yang mi che ha cang yang mi chung ba dang / dbang po mi rgod cing phyi rol du ma song ba'i sems dang dad pas nye bar 'tsho zhing tshig nye bar bzung ste/ mtshan mar 'dzin cing gnyid kyis ma log par kha ton byed do/ /

Therefore, you should definitely go to the wilderness. {As the noble Cloud of Jewels says,}[xvii] [197] You should live in places with sources of alms-food that are neither too far away nor too close, with drinking water that is pure, clear, uncontaminated, easy to get, and pleasing to drink.[xviii] You should live in places with plenty of trees, with plenty of flowers, with plenty of fruit, with plenty of leaves, with no wrathful beasts of prey, with caves,[xix] with mountain peaks,[xx] easy to move around in, peaceful, incomparable. Those are the kinds of places you should live in. While living in that kind of place, whatever you have previously learned, you should recite three times during the day and three times during the night, neither too loudly nor too softly, with your senses not too excited, with your mind not distracted, supported by calmness,[xxi] understanding the text, enunciating, not led astray by sleepiness.

gal te dge slong dgon pa pa'i drung du rgyal po'am blon po'am de ma yin pa gzhan bram ze'am rgyal rigs sam grong pa'am yul gyi mi dag 'ongs na/ des de dag la gus par legs par 'ongs so zhes brjod par bya ste/ des rgyal po chen po ji ltar stan bting ba la bzhugs shig ces de skad byas nas gal te 'dug na gnyi ga yang 'dug par bya'o/ / de ste mi 'dug na yang gnyi ga mi 'dug par bya'o/ / gal te dbang po rgod par gyur na rgyal po chen po gang khyod kyis sa phyogs na dge slong dang bram ze rnams tshul khrims dang ldan pa yon tan dang ldan pa mang du thos pa dag mi rgod dang spre'u rnams kyis ma gtses par gnas pa de ni rnyed pa legs par rnyed do zhes bstan par bya'o/ / de ste brtan zhing dul ba dbang po rab tu zhi ba zhig yin te chos bstan par rung na de la chos sna tshogs bstan par bya'o/ / de ste chos sna tshogs bstan pa la mi dga' na de la skyo ba dang mthun pa'i chos bstan par bya'o/ / de ste skyo ba dang mthun pa'i chos bstan pa la yang mi dga' na de la de bzhin gshegs pa'i che ba rgya che ba dag bstan par bya'o/ / bram ze dang rgyal rigs dang grong pa dang yul gyi mi dag 'ongs na yang ci rigs par bya ba dag bya'o/ / de de ltar mang du thos pas chos nyan pa rnams kyi sems mgu bar byed nus pa yin te/ sems can de dag kyang de la dga' ba dang dad pa dang rangs pa 'thob par 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so// //

If a king approaches a forest monk, or else a king’s minister, or some other Brahmin, warrior-noble, city-dweller, or country person, he should respectfully say to them, “Welcome!” And he should say, “Your Majesty, sit wherever you wish.” If the king sits down, both should sit down. Similarly, if he doesn’t sit down, neither should sit down. If he is distractible, the monk should say,[xxii] “It is a gain for you, Your Majesty, it is a great gain for you, that in this area morally disciplined, able, and greatly learned religious wanderers and Brahmins live safe from attack by bandits, tribal peoples, and the like.”[xxiii] If he is steady, disciplined, of calm faculties, and capable of hearing Dharma teachings, then the monk should give him a varied Dharma teaching. If he doesn’t want a varied teaching, then he should be given a hasty Dharma teaching.[xxiv] If he doesn’t want a hasty teaching, then the monk should teach him about the most exalted greatness of the Tathāgata. Similarly, if Brahmins, warrior-nobles, city-dwellers, or country people approach, the monk should act accordingly. As he is greatly learned in this way, he is able to satisfy the minds of those who listen to the Dharma. In his presence, these sentient beings feel pleasure, trust, and joy.[xxv]
bam po dgu pa/

khyim bdag drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / khyim bdag gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' rab tu byung ba dgon pa la gnas pas 'di ltar bdag ci'i phyir dgon pa la gnas/ dgon pa na gnas pa 'ba' zhig ni dge sbyong ma yin te/ 'di na ma byang ba ma sbas pa ma zhi ba ma dul ba mi 'grus pa rab tu mi brtson pa/ 'di lta ste ri dwags dang spre'u dang bya mang po dang chom rkun dang / gdol pa dag kyang mang du gnas te/ de dag kyang dge sbyong gi yon tan dang ldan pa ma yin pas/ gang gi phyir bdag dgon pa la gnas pa 'di lta ste/ dge sbyong gi don de yongs su rdzogs par bya'o snyam du brtag par bya'o/ /

[198] The Inquiry of Ugra also says,[4] Moreover, leading merchant, an ordained bodhisattva who lives in the wilderness should carefully consider as follows: “For what purpose do I live in the wilderness? Merely living in the wilderness does not make someone a religious wanderer. There are many who live here who are not trained, {who are not peaceful, who are not guarded,}[xxvi] who are not disciplined, who do not practice, who do not make an effort: for example, deer, monkeys, flocks of birds, bandits, and untouchables. They do not have the qualities of religious wanderers. But as for me, I should accomplish the goal for which I live in the wilderness: that is, the goal of the religious life
de bzhin du sbyar te/

khyim bdag gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' rab tu byung ba dgon pa na gnas pas bdag ci'i phyir dgon par 'ongs snyam du brtag par bya ste de yang 'di ltar bdag ni 'jigs shing skrag pa'i phyir dgon par 'ongs so/ / ci zhig gis 'jigs shing skrag ce na/ 'du 'dzis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / 'grogs pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug gis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / nga rgyal dang rgyags pa dang / 'chab pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / chags pa dang phrag dog dang ser snas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / gzugs dang sgra dang dri dang ro dang reg byas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / phung po'i bdud kyis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / nyon mongs pa'i bdud kyis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / 'chi bdag gi bdud kyis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / lha'i bu'i bdud kyis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / mi rtag pa la rtag par phyin ci log pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / sdug bsngal la bde bar phyin ci log pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / bdag med pa la bdag tu phyin ci log pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / mi gtsang ba la gtsang bar phyin ci log pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / sems dang yid dang rnam par shes pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / sred pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / 'khor bas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / sgrib pa dang chod pa dang kun nas ldang bas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / 'jig tshogs la lta bas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / bdag tu 'dzin pa dang / bdag gir 'dzin pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / rgod pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / 'gyod pa dang the tshom gyis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / sdig pa'i grogs pos 'jigs shing skrag go/ / rnyed pa dang bkur stis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / mi dge ba'i bshes gnyen gyis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / ma mthong bar mthong ngo snyam du 'dzin pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / ma thos par thos so snyam du 'dzin pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / ma dran par dran no snyam du 'dzin pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / bye brag ma phyed par bye brag phyed do snyam du 'dzin pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / mi shes par shes so snyam du 'dzin pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / dge sbyong gi dri mas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / gcig la gcig gnod par sems pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / 'dod pa'i khams dang gzugs kyi khams dang gzugs med pa'i khams kyis 'jigs shing skrag go/ / srid pa'i 'gro ba thams cad du 'chi 'pho dang skye bas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / sems can dmyal ba dang dud 'gro'i skye gnas dang yi dwags kyi yul du 'gro bas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / mi khom pas 'jigs shing skrag go/ / mdor na mi dge ba'i chos thams cad yid la byed pas 'jigs shing skrag ste/ bdag de lta bu'i 'jigs shing skrag pas 'jigs nas dgon par 'ongs so/ /

Moreover, leading merchant, an ordained bodhisattva who lives in the wilderness should carefully consider as follows: “For what purpose did I come to the wilderness?” And the bodhisattva should investigate as follows: “I came to the wilderness because I was afraid of danger. Of what dangers was I afraid? I was afraid of the dangers of social interactions; afraid of the dangers of company; afraid of the dangers of attraction, aversion, and delusion; afraid of the dangers of pride, intoxication, hypocrisy, and feverish desire; afraid of the dangers of avarice, envy, and greed; afraid of the dangers of forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and touchables; afraid of the dangers of the sense of “I” and the sense of “mine”; afraid of the dangers of the Māra of the aggregates; afraid of the dangers of the Māra of the reactive emotions; afraid of the dangers of the Māra of death; afraid of the dangers of the Māra who is a divine being; afraid of the dangers of erroneously taking what is impermanent to be permanent; afraid of the dangers of erroneously taking what is nonself to be a self; afraid of the dangers of erroneously taking what is impure to be pure; afraid of the dangers of erroneously taking what is suffering to be happiness; afraid of the dangers of mind, intellect, and consciousness; {afraid of the dangers of craving; afraid of the dangers of cyclic existence;} afraid of the dangers of the hindrances to attention, the distortions, and being overwhelmed by reactions; afraid of the dangers of the false view of a real self;[xxvii] afraid of the dangers of bad friends; afraid of the dangers of money and prestige; afraid of the dangers of untimely speech;[xxviii] afraid of the dangers of thinking I have seen what I have not seen; afraid of the dangers of thinking I have heard what I have not heard; afraid of the dangers of thinking I have remembered what I have not remembered; afraid of the dangers of thinking I have discerned what I have not discerned; afraid of the dangers of the impurities of religious wanderers;[xxix] afraid of the dangers of mutual hatred; afraid of the dangers of the desire-realm, the realm of form, and the formless realm; afraid of the dangers of birth in any of the realms of existence; afraid of the dangers of the hells, the animal realm, and the world of the ancestors;[5] {afraid of the dangers of lacking the opportunity to practice;} in brief, afraid of the dangers of applying attention to any bad things. It was because I was afraid of dangers and terrors of these kinds that I went to live in the wilderness.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/
khyim bdag gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' rab tu byung ba 'jigs shing skrag nas/ dgon pa la gnas pas 'di la gang cung zad 'jigs pa skye ba de dag thams cad ni bdag tu 'dzin pa las skyes so/ /
[199] Moreover, leading merchant, an ordained bodhisattva who lives in the wilderness and who is frightened or afraid should train as follows: “Whatever fears arise, they all arise from self-grasping
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[xxx]

bdag tu mngon par chags pa dang / bdag tu yongs su 'dzin pa dang / bdag gi gzhi dang bdag la sred pa dang / bdag tu 'du shes pa dang / bdag tu smra ba nye bar len pa dang / bdag tu lta ba dang / bdag gi gnas dang / bdag tu yongs su rtog pa dang / bdag bsrung ba las skyes te/ gal te bdag dgon pa la gnas la bdag tu 'dzin pa yongs su ma spangs/ bdag tu mngon par chags pa dang / bdag tu yongs su 'dzin pa dang / bdag gi gzhi dang / bdag la sred pa dang / bdag tu 'du shes pa dang / bdag tu smra ba nye bar len pa dang / bdag tu lta ba dang / bdag gi gnas dang / bdag tu yongs su rtog pa dang / bdag srung ba yongs su ma spangs na ni/ bdag dgon pa la gnas pa don med par 'gyur ro snyam du sems par bya ste/ bdag tu 'du shes pa la ni dgon pa la gnas pa don med do/ / gzhan du 'du shes pa la yang med do/ /

If I, living in the wilderness, did not give up self-grasping, nor attachment to self, nor a sense of self-ownership, nor the motivation [based on a sense] of self, nor the craving for a self, nor the conception of a self, nor attachment to a doctrine of self, nor a false view of self, nor taking the sense of self to be a basis, nor postulating a self, nor self-protection, then living in the wilderness would be useless to me.” For, leading merchant, someone who has a conception of “self” or a conception of “other” does not truly live in the wilderness
de bzhin du sbyar te/
khyim bdag dgon pa la gnas pa zhes bya ba ni chos thams cad la mi brten par gnas pa'o/ / chos thams cad la mi 'dzin par gnas pa'o/ / mtshan ma thams cad la mi chags par gnas pa'o/ /
Leading merchant, the term “living in the wilderness” means living in the nonorigination of everything; living free from attachment to anything;[xxxi]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gzugs thams cad la mi brten par gnas pa'o/ / sgra dang dri dang ro dang reg pa thams cad la mi brten par gnas pa'o/ / chos thams cad mnyam pa nyid dang mi 'gal bar gnas pa'o/ / sems shin tu zhi bas shin tu sbyangs par gnas pa'o/ / 'jigs pa thams cad spangs pas mi 'jigs par gnas pa'o/ / nyon mongs pa thams cad las rnam par grol bas chu bo las rgal bar gnas pa'o/ / brten par gnas pa'o/ / ngan ngon gyis chog shes par 'dzin cing 'dod pa chung bas 'phags pa'i rigs rnams la rab tu dga' bar gnas pa'o/ / dgang sla zhing gso sla bas chog par 'dzin par gnas pa'o/ / shes rab kyi phyir tshul bzhin la sbyor bas thos pa la gnas pa'o/ / rnam par thar pa'i sgo stong pa nyid dang mtshan ma med pa dang smon pa med pa la so sor rtog pas thar par gnas pa'o/ / bcings pa bcad pas rnam par grol bar gnas pa'o/ / rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba dang mthun pas ma dul ba rnams nye bar zhi bar gnas pa'o/ / shin tu rnam par dag pas bya ba byas par gnas pa'o/ /

{living without relying on any forms; living without relying on any sounds, scents, tastes, and touchables; living in the equality and nonopposition of everything; living with a mind that is highly trained by being very peaceful; living fearlessly, by giving up all fears; living having crossed over the river, by being free from all reactive emotions;[xxxii] being satisfied with the bare necessities and having few desires, living joyfully with the noble traditions; being easily filled and easily nourished, living in satisfaction; living in what one has learned, by engaging with what is suitable for the sake of wisdom; living in freedom due to individually understanding each of the doors to freedom, which are emptiness, no characteristics, and no aspirations; living in freedom, having cut the fetters; living at peace with those who are not disciplined, in accordance with dependent arising;[xxxiii] living while acting in a completely pure way.}

khyim bdag 'di lta ste dper na/ dgon pa la rtswa dang shing gel pa dang nags tshal gnas kyang 'jigs pa med cing mi skrag skrag par mi 'gyur ro/ / khyim bdag de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' rab tu byung ba dgon pa la gnas pas kyang lus la rtswa dang shing gel pa dang sman dang rtswig pa dang shing dang mig yor lta bu dang sgyu ma dang mtshungs pa'i 'du shes bskyed par bya ste/ 'di la su zhig 'jigs par 'gyur 'di la su zhig skrag par 'gyur snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o/ / des 'jigs shing skrag par lta na/ 'di ltar lus 'di la ni bdag gam sems can nam srog gam skye ba'am gso ba 'am skyes bu 'am gang zag gam shed las skyes pa'am shed bu med de/ 'di ltar 'jigs pa zhes bya ba 'di ni/ yang dag pa ma yin pa kun brtags pa yin gyi bdag gis ni yang dag pa ma yin pa kun brtags pa de la brtag par mi bya'o snyam du lus la tshul bzhin du brtag par bya'o/ / des ji ltar dgon pa la rtswa dang shing gel ba dang sman dang nags tshal gnas pa rnams nga'i ba med pas yongs su 'dzin pa med pa de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' yang nga'i ba med pa yongs su 'dzin pa med pas chos thams cad dgon pa nyid do snyam du shes nas nye bar bsgrubs te gnas par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ dgon pa la gnas pa de ni nyon mongs pa gcod pa ste nga'i ba med pa yongs su 'dzin pa med pa'o/ /

Leading merchant, it’s like this: for example, grass, bushes, plants, and trees live in the wilderness, but they are not afraid, frightened, or terrified, and feel no terror. In just the same way, leading merchant, an ordained bodhisattva living in the wilderness should conceive of the body as being like grass, bushes, plants, trees, sticks, or walls,[xxxiv] merely having the appearance of a person. The bodhisattva should ask, “Who here is afraid? Who here is terrified?” And the bodhisattva who is afraid of danger or frightened should carefully consider the body appropriately, as follows: “In this body there is no soul, no sentient being, no life-force, no living thing, no person, and no human being. What is called ‘fear’ is an inaccurate postulation, and I should not postulate such an inaccurate postulation.” In this manner, just as grass, bushes, plants, and trees live in the wilderness with no sense of “mine” and with no possessiveness, in just the same way, the bodhisattva should live with no sense of “mine” and with no possessiveness, knowing “Everything is wilderness.” Why is this? To live in the wilderness is to cut off the reactive emotions,[xxxv] with no “mine” and no possessiveness
de bzhin du sbyar te/

khyim bdag gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' rab tu byung bas sangs rgyas kyis dgon pa la gnas par bka' stsal par shes nas dgon pa la gnas par bya ste/ der dge ba'i chos thams cad yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba nye bar brtan nas/ phyis grong dang grong khyer dang grong rdal dang ljongs dang yul dang pho brang 'khor dag tu zhugs te chos bstan par bya'o/ /

Moreover, leading merchant, an ordained bodhisattva, knowing that the Buddha endorsed living in the wilderness, should live in the wilderness, for there all bright qualities are fully developed. [The bodhisattva should think,] “Afterwards, well supported by these wholesome actions, I will enter villages, cities, markets, kingdoms, and capital cities, and teach the Dharma.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

khyim bdag gal te byang chub sems dpa' rab tu byung ba lung dang kha ton mnod pa'i phyir tshogs kyi nang du 'jug na des der gus pa dang bcas par bya ste/ slob dpon dang mkhan po rnams dang / gnas brtan dang bar ma dang dge sbyong gsar bu rnams la zhe sa dang bcas par bya'o/ / tshul mkhas par bya'o/ / snyom las med par rang gis bya ba dang gzhan la gdung ba med par bya'o/ / des bsnyen bkur la gdu bar mi bya'o/ / des 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten dang / bdud dang bcas pa dang / tshangs pa dang bcas pa dang / dge sbyong dang bram ze'i skye dgu dang bcas pa dang / lha dang mi dang lha ma yin du bcas pas mchod pas/ sbyin gnas su gyur pa de yang sems can thams cad la gang las kyang rim gror bya ba bdag gir mi mdzad na/ bdag cag ma bslabs pa slob 'dod pa rnams lta ci smos te/ bdag gis sems can thams cad la bsnyen bkur bya'i/ gang las kyang bsnyen bkur bya ba bdag gir mi bya'o snyam du brtag par bya'o/ /

[200] Leading merchant, if an ordained bodhisattva enters a crowd for the purpose of receiving teachings[xxxvi] or for recitation, he should be respectful there. He should be courteous to spiritual and academic teachers, and to elder, middle-rank, and junior monks. He should not be lazy, but should do things himself and not cause distress to others. And he should not be attached to service, but should carefully consider as follows: “Even the Tathāgata, the Saint, genuinely and fully awake, who was worshipped by the entire world, with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, with its religious wanderers, Brahmins, and various creatures,[xxxvii] and was worthy of honor from all sentient beings, did not regard service from anyone at all as his due. How much less so should we, who are untrained and want to train? We[xxxviii] will be at the service of all sentient beings, and will provide service and assistance to others; we will not regard service and assistance as our due from anyone.”

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ khyim bdag dge sbyong bsnyen bkur la gdu ba ni yon tan gyi chos rjes su gzung ba chud gzon pa yin te/ des gang dag sdud pa de dag kyang 'di snyam du sems te/ bdag cag ni bsnyen bkur gyi phyir sdud kyi chos kyi phyir ni ma yin no snyam mo zhes gsungs so/ /

Why is this? Leading merchant, when a monk is attached to service, his abilities and virtues are wasted. Those whom he brings together will think, “This monk brings us together for the sake of service, {and not for the sake of the Dharma.}”

yang de nyid las/ khyim bdag gal te byang chub sems dpa' dgon pa pa chos nyan par 'dod dam/ mkhan po dang slob dpon la lta bar 'dod nas/ nad 'dri ba'i phyir grong gi gnas su 'ongs nas/ des dgongs su slar ldog par bya ba'i phyir 'gro ba'i sems bskyed par bya'o/ / de gal te lung mnod pa dang kha ton bya ba gzhan la rag las te gtsug lag khang na gnas na yang / des dgon pa la gzhol ba'i sems kyis/ gang dngos po thams cad la dgon par 'du shes pa dang chos tshol bas mi ngoms pa de nyid dgon pa la gnas pa yin no snyam du bsam par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text says, Leading merchant, if a forest bodhisattva goes to a village with its beds and seats[xxxix] in order to hear the Dharma, or in order to see spiritual or academic teachers, or in order to inquire about an illness,[xl] he should arouse his mind to return in the evening. Now, if he is dependent on others for teaching or recitation, then while living in a monastery, he should develop the intention to go to the wilderness. And he should think, “Conceiving of everything as wilderness and insatiably seeking the Dharma: this is living in the wilderness.”

'phags pa rin po che'i phung po'i mdo las kyang / gal te dge slong dgon pa pa 'bras bu ma thob pa so so'i skye bo'i drung du sdig sbrul dang gcan gzan gtum po dag 'ongs na des de la 'jigs pa dang skrag par mi bya'i/ des 'di snyam du bdag thog ma nyid nas lus dang srog bor te dgon pa'i gnas su 'ongs kyang 'di la bdag gis 'jigs par mi bya skrag par mi bya'i/ byams pa'i sems bskyed par bya zhe sdang rnam par spang bar bya 'jigs pa spang bar bya'o snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o/ / gal te de ltar byas nas sbrul dang gcan gzan de dag gis srog gcod cing za na yang des 'di snyam du gcan gzan 'di dag la bdag gis zang zing tsam gyis tshim par byed mi nus kyi/ de dag gis bdag gi sha zos nas bde ba la reg par gnas par 'gyur la/ bdag gis kyang snying po med pa'i lus las snying po blangs par 'gyur ba ni bdag gis rnyed pa legs par rnyed do/ /

The noble Multitude of Jewels Sūtra also says,[xli] If a monk living in a wilderness region who is an ordinary person and has not yet attained the result should be approached by fierce wild animals,[xlii] he should not be frightened or afraid. And he should arouse his mind as follows: “When I entered into the wilderness life, I gave up my body and life. Here I should not be frightened or afraid, but rather I will arouse lovingkindness, give up aversion, and remove fear. If, when I have done this, those fierce wild animals should kill me and eat me, then I should arouse my mind as follows: ‘It is a gain for me, it is a great gain for me, that I will receive the value of this valueless body. I cannot satisfy these fierce wild animals by giving them my food. When they have eaten my flesh, they will feel happy.’ ”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gal te dgon pa'i gnas de na gnas pa na mi ma yin pa 'ongs na mdog sdug kyang rung mi sdug kyang rung / de la chags par mi bya khong khro bar mi bya'o/ / gal te sngon sangs rgyas mthong ba'i lha dag dge slong dgon pa pa'i gan du 'ongs te dri ba yongs su 'dri na/ de la dge slong dgon pa pa des ji ltar thos pa bzhin du lha de dag la chos bshad par bya'o/ / ci ste lha de dag zab mo'i dri ba yongs su dris te dge slong dgon pa pa des lan mi thebs pa lta na/ des nga rgyal med par byas la 'di skad ces ma bslabs pa la brnyas par mi bya ste sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa la lung mnos nas 'bad de khong du ma chud pa'i chos rnams khong du chud par gyur pa de'i tshe de'i dus na dris pa thams cad kyi lan gdab par bya'o/ / bdag ni chos nyan pa yin gyi khyed spobs par gyis shig ces brjod par bya ste/ 'od srungs dge slong dgon pa pa de ltar lha de dag la go bar bya'o/ /

[201] Now if, while he is living there in that wilderness region, non-humans approach him, whether beautiful or ugly, he should not fall in love with them nor oppose them. If deities who have seen previous Buddhas should approach a wilderness-dwelling monk and ask him a question, then that wilderness-dweller should teach them Dharma as he has learned it, as best he can, to the best of his ability. But now, if they should ask deep questions that the wilderness-dwelling monk is not able to answer, he should humbly reply, “Those who are untrained should not be humiliated. I will apply myself, I will make an effort, in the Buddha’s religion. The time and the occasion will come when I will have studied and understood the teachings, and then I will answer all these questions. But please see that we are merely students of the Dharma.”[xliii]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

dgon pa'i gnas de na gnas pa des rtswa dang shing gel ba dang sman dang nags tshal de dag ji ltar 'byung ba dang ji ltar 'jig par 'gyur ba dang / ji ltar phyi rol gyi dngos po 'di dag bdag po med pa/ g.yo ba med pa/ byed pa med pa/ rgyu dang rkyen tshogs pa las 'byung gi / rgyu dang rkyen ma tshang na mi 'byung ba ste/ 'di la don dam par skye ba dang 'gag pa'i chos gang yang med do snyam du mtshan mar gzung bar bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

While living in that wilderness region, he should understand the nature of grass, bushes, plants, and trees. In what way do they exist? Just as those external things have no owner, no “mine,” no possessiveness, and similarly, no effort and no work; they arise and cease, but they do not produce anything or destroy anything; in just the same way, this body is like grass, sticks, bowls, or reflections; it has no owner, no “mine,” no possessiveness, no effort, and no work;[xliv] it arises from a collection of causes and conditions, and when the causes and conditions fail, it ceases. And ultimately, there is nothing here at all that arises or ceases.

yang gsungs pa/ dgon pa'i gnas de na gnas pa na 'di ltar sems bskyed par bya ste/ 'di ltar bdag ni lam ring po nas 'dir 'ongs la gcig pu gnyis su med pa ste/ legs par byas pa'am nyes par byas pa bskul ba'i grogs ni gang yang med kyi/ lha dang klu dang gnod sbyin dang dri za dang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das gang bdag gi sems kyi bsam pa shes pa dag yod de/ bdag dgon pa'i gnas na gnas la mi dge ba'i sems kyi dbang du song na de dag dbang du 'gyur ro/ / bdag lam ring po nas 'ongs shing gcig pu gnyis su med de/ rten pa med bdag gi med yongs su 'dzin pa med la/ gal te 'dod pa la rnam par rtog pas rnam par rtog / gnod sems kyi rnam par rtog pas rnam par rtog / 'tshe ba'i rnam par rtog pas rnam par rtog gam/ mi dge ba gzhan la rnam par rtog pas rnam par rtog par gyur na/ gang 'du 'dzi dang 'du ba la mngon par dga' ba'i sems can rnams dang bye brag med par 'gyur te/ bdag gis lha dang klu dang gnod sbyin dang dri za rnams la bslus par 'gyur zhing / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyang mi mnyes par byas par 'gyur gyis/ ci nas kyang bdag la lha rnams 'phya bar mi 'gyur ba dang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyang dgyes par 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

And the same text says, While living there in that wilderness region, he should think: “As I have come to the wilderness alone, without a second, I have no companion who might encourage me to act well or to act badly. However, there are gods, serpent spirits, and forest spirits,[xlv] and the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, who know my state of mind. They are my witnesses.[xlvi] [They know whether,][xlvii] while living in this wilderness region, I am being overpowered by unwholesome thoughts. But if I, after coming here from far away, alone, without a second, without restraint, with no ‘mine,’ with no possessiveness, should think thoughts of sensual desire, or should think thoughts of malice or harming others, or should think about other unwholesome things, then I would not be different in any way from those who engage in society and social interactions. I would have lied to those gods, serpent spirits, and forest spirits,[xlviii] and the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, would be displeased.[xlix] Why would the gods not ridicule me? I should act in such a way as to please the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones.”
bslab pa kun las btus pa las/ dgon par gnas par brjod pa zhes bya ba'i le'u ste bcu gcig pa'o// //
[sems yongs su sbyang ba]
12. Preparing the Mind
de ltar dgon pa la gnas nas
[202] WHILE LIVING IN the wilderness in this way,
mnyam par gzhag pa la sbyar bar bya ste/
[20c] Make an effort to stabilize attention.

bcom ldan 'das ma las/ des sems can de dag gi don du bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pas sems g.yeng bar mi 'gyur ro/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar de 'di snyam du sems g.yeng ba la ni 'jig rten pa'i bsam gtan bskyed pa'ang dkon na/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub lta ci smos/ de lta bas na bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs ma rgyas kyi bar du sems mi g.yeng bar bya'o snyam du sems so zhes gsungs so/ /

For the Blessed Lady says, With undistracted minds, they practice the perfection of meditative stability solely for the benefit of those sentient beings. Why is this? Because they think, “For someone whose mind is distracted, even worldly attainment in meditation is difficult. How much more so highest genuine full Awakening! Therefore, I should have an undistracted mind, until I awaken to highest genuine full Awakening.”

yang de nyid las/ rab 'byor gzhan yang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po sems dang po bskyed pa nas nye bar bzung ste/ bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod cing rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa nyid dang ldan pa'i yid la byed pas bsam gtan la snyoms par 'jug ste/ de mig gis gzugs rnams mthong yang mtshan mar mi 'dzin cing mngon rtags su mi 'dzin pa yin no/ / gang gi phyir mig gi dbang po sdom pas ma bsdams par gnas te/ brnab sems dang yid mi bde ba dang sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos gzhan la yang sems rjes su 'jug pa de dag sdom par byed mig gi dbang po srung bar byed do/ / de bzhin du rna bas sgra thos pa dang / snas dri tshor ba dang / lces ro myang ba dang / lus kyis reg bya la reg pa dang / yid kyis chos rnam par rig pa na mtshan mar mi 'dzin cing mngon rtags su mi 'dzin pa yin no/ / gang gi phyir yid kyi dbang po sdom pas ma bsdams te sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos rnams la rjes su 'jug pa de dag sdom par byed yid kyi dbang po srung bar byed do/ / de 'gro'am 'greng ngam 'dug gam nyal lam smra'am mi smra yang rung ste/ mnyam par gzhag par gnas pa dang zhi bar gnas pa mi 'dor ro/ / de lag pa mi rgod pa dang / rkang pa mi rgod pa dang / mu cor mi smra ba dang / tshig 'chal pa med pa dang / dbang po mi g.yeng ba dang / mi rgod pa dang / yab yab po ma yin pa dang / gzu lums can ma yin pa dang / lus 'khrul pa med pa dang / sems 'khrul pa med pa dang / lus zhi ba dang / ngag zhi ba dang / sems zhi ba dang / dben yang rung mi dben yang rung ste spyod lam bcos pa med pa yin no/ /

And the same text says, Alternately, Subhūti, bodhisattva great beings who have just aroused the [Awakening] Mind for the first time, by practicing the perfection of meditative stability, and through applications of attention that have to do with knowing that is complete in all respects, attain meditative stability. When they see forms with their eyes, they do not grasp at signs and do not grasp at characteristics. Because of this, they live disciplined, with the discipline of the sense of sight, so that they deal in a disciplined way with covetousness, unhappiness, or any other vile, unwholesome states that might reach the mind. In just the same way, when they hear sounds with their ears, smell scents with their noses, taste flavors with their tongues, feel touchable things with their bodies, or are conscious of experiences with their minds, they do not grasp at signs and do not grasp at characteristics. Because of this, their minds are disciplined against indiscipline, and whatever vile states might reach the mind, they deal with them in a disciplined way. They protect their minds. Whether they are walking, standing, seated, or lying down, whether they are talking {or remaining silent,} they do not abandon[i] the state of stable attention.[ii] They do not fidget with their hands, feet, or face; they do not speak in an incoherent way;[iii] their faculties are not distracted; they are not excited and not dull, not trembling, not indolent,[iv] not agitated in body, not agitated in mind; peaceful in body, peaceful in speech, peaceful in mind; and whether they are alone or not, their behavior is natural
de bzhin du sbyar te/

chog shes pa dang / gso sla ba dang / dgang sla ba dang / 'grogs na bde ba dang / cho ga dang spyod yul bde ba dang / 'du 'dzi'i nang na yang spyod yul dben pa dang / rnyed pa dang ma rnyed pa la yang mnyam zhing 'gyur ba med pa yin/ khengs pa med cing 'dud pa dang / de bzhin du bde ba dang sdug bsngal ba dang / bstod pa dang smad pa dang / snyan pa dang mi snyan pa dang / 'tsho ba dang 'chi ba yang mnyam zhing 'gyur ba med pa yin/ khengs pa med cing 'dud pa dang / de bzhin du dgra dang mdza' bo dang / yid du 'ong ba dang yid du mi 'ong ba dang / 'phags pa dang 'phags pa ma yin pa dang / sgra dang gzugs sdug pa dang mi sdug pa rnams la yang mnyam zhing 'gyur ba med pa yin/ khengs pa med cing 'dud pa yin/ rjes su chags pa dang mi mthun pa dang bral ba yin no/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar chos thams cad rang gi mtshan nyid kyis stong zhing byung ba med pa dang rdzogs pa med pa dang / mngon du grub pa med par mthong ba'i phyir ro zhes rgya cher gsungs so/ /

[203] They are contented, easy to nourish and easily satisfied, delightful to spend time with,[v] having a spiritual way of life, oriented towards spiritual matters. Even in social interactions, they are oriented towards solitude. In gain and loss, they are the same, not changing, not elated, and not depressed. In the same way, in pleasure and pain, in praise and criticism, in fame and obscurity, in life and death, they are the same, not changing, not elated, not depressed. They are the same towards both friends and enemies, both the beautiful and the ugly, both the noble and the ignoble. Towards liked and disliked forms and sounds,[vi] they are the same, not changing, not elated, and not depressed. They are no longer concerned with whether others agree or disagree.[vii] Why is this? Because they see everything as empty of its own characteristic, not arising, not ceasing, not real.[viii] And so on at length.

de la yid zhum na dga' ba bsgom pas gzengs bstod par bya'o/ / rgod par gyur na mi rtag pa yid la bya bas rab tu zhi bar bya'o/ / gnyi ga'i gnyen po'i don du ni/ 'phags pa yul 'khor skyong gis brjod pa'i tshigs su bcad pa dran par bya ste/ sangs rgyas 'jig rten phan pa drang srong che/ / bskal pa bye mang brgya lam 'byung bar 'gyur/ / da lta dal ba dam pa rnyed pa la/ / gal te thar 'dod bag med spong bar gyis/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de bzhin du/ 'di ni sgyu ma lta bur bden pa min/ / 'dus byas rmi lam mtshungs par brtags nas ni/ / 'di ni rtag tu sdug pa thams cad dang / / myur du 'bral bar mi 'gyur gang yang med/ / pha rol phyin dang sa dang stobs rnams la/ / rtag tu brtson par gyis la 'bad par gyis/ / rdul med byang chub sangs rgyas ma gyur par/ / brtson 'grus nams kyang nyams par gyur ta re/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Now, if your mind is downcast, charge it up by cultivating joy. But if it is excited, calm it down by applying attention to impermanence. And as a remedy for both, you should remember this verse, spoken by the noble Rāṣṭrapāla:[1] In the course of many billions[ix] of aeons, A Buddha arises, a great sage, for the welfare of the world. Today, this sacred opportunity has been found; Abandon heedlessness if you want to be free! In the same way, Look at all of these conditioned things as like an illusion, deceptive, like a dream. Soon you will be separated from all that is dear to you; there is nothing permanent here. Always work hard, making an effort at the Perfections, the Stages, and the Powers. Do not slack off from your perseverance until you awaken to {dustless} supreme Awakening!

'phags pa rgya cher rol pa'i mdo las kyang / srid gsum rga dang nad kyi sdug bsngal 'bar/ / 'di ni 'chi med rab 'bar mgon med pa/ / srid las 'byung la 'gro ba rtag tu rmongs/ / bum par chud pa'i bung ba 'khor ba bzhin/ /

The noble Detailed Explanation of the Play also says,[2] The threefold world blazes with the sufferings of old age and disease, Burning with the fire of death,[x] lacking a guardian. Trying to escape from existence, but always confused, [204] Living beings roam around like a bee in a jar.[3]
srid gsum mi brtan ston ka'i sprin dang 'dra/ / 'gro ba'i skye 'chi gar la lta dang mtshungs/ / 'gro ba'i tshe 'gro nam mkha'i glog 'dra ste/ / ri gzar 'bab chu lta bur myur mgyogs 'gro/ /
srid sred ma rig dbang gis skye bo rnams/ / mi dang lha gnas ngan song lam gsum po/ / 'gro ba lnga po dag tu mi mkhas 'khor/ / dper na rdza mkhan 'phang lo 'khor ba bzhin/ /

Through the power of ignorance and the thirst for existence, We are born on earth, in the city of the gods, and the three lower realms, Revolving through the ever-recurring five realms unknowingly, As if going around on a potter’s wheel.
rtag tu gzugs sdug mchog dang sgra snyan dang / / dri zhim ro mchog reg pa bde byed pa/ / dus ngan rnyi la 'gro ba 'di dag thogs/ / dper na rngon pa'i rnyi la spre'u thogs bzhin/ /

This trap of a world[xii] is sprinkled With the most alluring sights and most lovely sounds, With sweet scents, delicious tastes, and the best pleasures of touch, Like a monkey tied to a hunter’s game trap.
'dod pa'i yon tan mya ngan gnod pa mang / / 'jigs bcas rtag tu dgra byed nyon mongs bcas/ / ral gri'i so 'dra dug sdong lo ma mtshungs/ / ngan skyugs snod ltar 'phags pa'i skye bos spangs/ /

The pleasures of the senses lead to many sorrows and disasters; They are dangerous, always causing enmity, associated with reactivity, Like a sword’s blade or the leaf of a poison tree,[xiii] Rejected by the noble like a chamber-pot.
'dod pa'i yon tan 'jigs bcas nyon mongs bcas/ / rtag tu dran pa brjed byed mun pa byed/ / rtag tu 'jigs pa'i rgyu byed sdug bsngal rtsa/ / srid pa'i sred pa'i 'khri shing 'phel bar byed/ /
ji ltar me 'bar 'obs nas 'jigs bcas pa/ / de ltar 'dod 'di 'phags pa'i skye bos rig / 'dam rdzab che 'dra ral gri gshegs gnas 'dra/ / ral gri'i so la sbrang rtsis bskus dang mtshungs/ /
Noble people know that, just as burning fire-pits are dangerous,[4] So are sensual pleasures. They are like a great quagmire, like swords and spears,[xiv] Like honey smeared on a razor-blade.
ji ltar sbrul gyi mgo dang ngan skyugs snod/ / de ltar 'dod 'di mkhas pa rnams kyis reg / bya sha kham bu 'dra zhing gsal shing 'dra/ / ro la khyi ltar dgra dang bcas pa yis/ /
The wise know that sensual pleasures Are like a serpent’s head, like a chamber-pot, Like an impalement stake, like a bird’s egg, Like a dog, with no hands, mouth full of enmity.[xv]
'dod pa'i yon tan 'di dag chu zla 'dra/ / gzugs brnyan mtshungs shing brag ca 'dra ba dang / / mig yor 'dra zhing gar la lta 'dra dang / / rmi lam mnyam par 'phags pa'i skyo bos rig /
Noble people know that sensual pleasures Are like the moon reflected in water, Like visual distortions,[5] like echoes, like illusions, Like a stage in a theatre, like dreams.
'dod pa'i yon tan skad cig ya ma brla/ / sgyu ma smig rgyu 'dra zhing rdzun pa can/ / chu bur dbu ba lta bur yang dag min/ / yongs su brtags las byung bar mkhas pas rtogs/ /
[205] The wise are awake to sensual pleasures Being momentary and worthless, deceptive like illusions and mirages, Unreal like foam and water bubbles, Arising from conceptual construction.
na tshod thog mar gzugs mchog 'dzin pa'i tshe/ / phangs shing sdug 'dod 'di ni byis pa'i spyod/ / rga na sdug bsngal gzi brjid lus bcom nas/ / rnam par spangs te ri dgas klung skam bzhin/ /

At first, when young[xvi] and handsome, those who live foolishly Are desired, esteemed, and held dear, But when energy and appearance are destroyed by the pains of old age and disease, People abandon them like deer leaving a dried-up stream.
nor 'bru dam pa rdzas mang stobs ldan tshe/ / phangs shing sdug 'dod 'di ni byis pa'i spyod/ / nor nyams sdug bsngal bar ni gyur pa'i tshe/ / rnam par spangs te mi yis 'brog stong bzhin/ /

When those who live foolishly have the best of wealth and grain, When they have property and power, they are desired, esteemed, and held dear, But when they have lost their wealth and gotten into difficulties, People abandon them as empty.[xvii]
ji ltar me tog shing dang 'bras bcas shing / / de ltar sbyin 'dod mi la dga' bar byed/ / nor nyams rga bas nyen cing spong byed pa/ / de dag dga' bar mi 'gyur bya rgod bzhin/ /

Like flowering or fruit-bearing trees, They enjoy generosity and delight others in that way; But when their wealth fails and they are tormented by old age, They become beggars and are disliked as much as vultures.
rdzas ldan gzugs mchog ldan tshe dpon po bzhin/ / phrad na sdug cing dbang po dga' bar byed/ / rga na sdug bsngal nyen cing nor zad pa/ / de tshe 'dod par mi 'gyur 'chi bdag bzhin/ /

When they are mighty and have wealth, power, and the finest appearance, They are pleasing to meet and delight the senses, But when they are tormented by the pains of old age and disease And have lost their wealth, then they are disliked as much as the Lord of Death.
rga bas rga byas na tshod yal gyur na/ / sdong po gnam lcags kyis ni bcom pa bzhin/ / rga bas 'khogs na 'jigs bcas khang rul 'dra/ / rga las 'byung ba thub pa myur du smros/ /

When they are withered by old age, with their time of life run out, They become just like trees struck by lightning, Or like dangerous houses, decrepit with old age. Sage, tell us quickly how to be saved from old age!
bud med skyes pa'i tshogs rnams rga bas skyems/ / 'khri shing sA la'i nags la rlung dmar bzhin/ / rga bas brtson 'grus rtsal dang shugs 'phrog ste/ / dper na skyes bu 'dam du bying ba bzhin/ /
Old age withers crowds of men and women Just like a root-creeper withers a thick Sal tree.[xviii] Old age takes away perseverance, liveliness, and strength Just like when someone is stuck in mud.
rga bas gzugs sdug gzugs ni mi sdug byed/ / rga bas gzi brjid 'phrog cing mthu stobs 'phrog / rga bas bde ba 'phrog cing brnyas par byed/ / rga bas 'chi byed rga bas mdangs kyang 'phrog /
Old age turns beauty into ugliness, Steals away energy, strength, and power; Old age always steals happiness and causes humiliation, Takes away vitality and leads to death.
nad brgya mang dang nad 'thibs sdug bsngal gyis/ / 'gro ba gtses te mi yis ri dwags bzhin/ / rga dang na bas bcom pa'i 'gro ltos la/ / sdug bsngal gyis ni 'byung ba myur shod cig /

From many hundreds of illnesses, from the severe pain of disease, Let living beings go for refuge to you, like deer from a fire.[xix] Look upon living beings, overcome by old age and disease; [206] Quickly, teach salvation from suffering!
dper na dgun smad rlung dang kha ba che/ / rtsi shing gel pa nags sman mdangs kyang 'phrog / de ltar nad 'di 'gro ba'i mdangs 'phrog cing / / dbang po gzugs dang stobs ni nyams par byed/ /

Just as the snow in winter[xx] takes away The vitality of grass, bushes, trees, and plants, In the same way, disease takes away the vitality of living beings And causes their faculties, beauty, and strength to decay.
nor 'bru nor chen tha mar zad par byed/ / nad ni rtag tu 'gro ba brnyas par byed/ / gnod pa byed cing sdug la sdang bar byed/ / yongs su gdung byed mkha' las nyi ma bzhin/ /

In the end, it exhausts even great wealth of money and grain; Disease always humiliates living beings. It causes obstacles, creates hatred among dear ones And produces anguish; it acts like the sun does to fog.
'chi dang 'pho dang 'chi 'pho dus byed pa/ / phangs shing sdug pa'i skye bo rtag tu 'bral/ / phyir mi 'ong zhing phrad par 'gyur ma yin/ / shing las lo 'brul 'dra zhing rlung rgyun mtshungs/ /

Death, passing away, perishing, dying, Separates people from their possessions and dear ones, Who will never meet or see each other again, Like a tree’s leaves and fruits that are carried away by a river.[xxi]
'chi ba dbang yod pa dag dbang med byed/ / 'chi bas 'phrog byed chu bos shing ded bzhin/ / mi ni gnyis min grogs med gcig pur 'gro/ / rang las 'bras bu ldan pas dbang yang med/ /
Those in the power of death are powerless, Carried away like sticks in a river. People depart alone, friendless, solitary, Followed by the results of their own actions, with no control.

'chi bas srog chags brgya phrag mang 'dzin te/ / 'byung po'i tshogs la rgya mtsho'i chu srin bzhin/ / klu la mkha' lding glang chen seng ge 'dra/ / rtsa rtsi 'byung po'i tshogs la me dang mtshungs/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Death devours many hundreds of living beings Just as a saltwater crocodile[xxii] does to schools of beings in the ocean; Just as a garuḍa kills a snake, or a lion kills an elephant, It burns the herd of beings like grass and plants.

rgyal po la gdams pa'i mdo las kyang / rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na phyogs bzhi nas ri chen po sra ba/ brtan pa/ snying po dang ldan pa/ ma zhig pa/ ma gas pa/ 'phan med pa/ shin tu mkhregs pa gcig tu stug po bzhi/ gnam la reg cing sa zlog ste/ rtswa dang shing gel pa dang yal ga dang lo ma thams cad dang / sems can srog chags 'byung po thams cad phye mar 'thag cing 'ong ba de dag las ni/ mgyogs par 'bros pa'am/ stobs kyis bzlog pa'am/ nor gyis bzlog pa'am/ rdzas dang sngags dang sman rnams kyis bzlog par sla ba ni ma yin no/ / rgyal po chen po de bzhin du/ 'jigs pa chen po bzhi po 'di dag 'ong ste/ de dag las mgyogs pas 'bros pa'am/ stobs kyis bzlog pa'am/ nor gyis bzlog pa'am/ rdzas dang sngags dang sman rnams kyis bzlog par sla ba ma yin no/ /

The Sūtra of Advice to a King (Rāja-avavādaka Sūtra) also says,[6] [207] For example, Your Majesty, suppose that from all four directions, four {huge} mountains were approaching, solid, substantial, unbreakable, indestructible, with no holes, totally closed up, each one single solid mass, touching the clouds and grinding against the earth, crushing the grass and sticks, tree-branches, leaves and flowers, and all sentient beings, creatures and living beings. It would not be easy to defend against them with speed or strength, or to turn them back with wealth, mantras, or herbs. In the same way, Your Majesty, four great dangers are coming. It is not easy to defend against them with speed or strength, or to turn them back with wealth, mantras, or herbs.

bzhi gang zhe na/ rga ba dang / nad dang / 'chi ba dang / rgud pa'o/ / rgyal po chen po rga ba ni dar la bab pa 'joms shing 'ong / nad ni nad med pa 'joms shing 'ong / rgud pa ni phun sum tshogs pa thams cad 'joms shing 'ong / 'chi ba ni srog 'joms shing 'ong ste/ de dag las ni mgyogs pas 'bros pa'am/ stobs kyis bzlog pa'am/ nor gyis bzlog pa'am/ rdzas dang sngags dang sman rnams kyis zhi bar sla ba ma yin no/ /

What are the four? They are old age, disease, death, and bad rebirth.[xxiii] Old age is coming, Your Majesty, crushing youth. Disease is coming, Your Majesty, crushing health. Death is coming, Your Majesty, crushing life. Bad rebirth is coming, Your Majesty, crushing all good fortune.[xxiv] {It is not easy to defend against them with speed or strength, or to turn them back with wealth, mantras, or herbs.}

rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste/ dper na ri dwags kyi rgyal po seng ge ri dwags kyi tshogs kyi nang na bzhugs nas ri dwags bzung ste ji ltar 'dod pa bzhin du bya ba byed do/ / ri dwags de ni stobs po che'i kha mi bzad pas bzung bas dbang med par 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po chen po de bzhin du 'chi bdag gi gsal shing gis zug ste/ rgyags pa dang ni bral/ mgon ni med skyabs ni med/ dpung gnyen ni med/ gshis ni 'jigs/ tshigs ni 'bye 'bral/ sha dang khrag ni skam/ lus ni nad kyis gdungs skom ni skom/ bzhin ni 'gyur/ rkang lag ni g.yo ba/ las ni mi nus/ mthu ni med/ kha chu dang snabs dang gcin dang ngan skyugs kyis ni lus la gos/ mig dang rna ba dang sna dang lce dang lus dang yid kyi dbang po dag ni 'gag / skyigs bu ni 'byung / sgra ngar ngar po ni 'thon/ sman pas ni bor/ sman dang kha zas dang bza' ba dang thug pa thams cad kyis ni kles la bor te/ 'gro ba gzhan dag tu 'gro bar mal gyi tha ma la ni nyal/ thog ma med pa'i skye ba dang rga ba dang na ba dang 'chi ba'i 'khor ba'i rgyud du ni nub/ srog ni cung zad cig las/ gshin rje'i mis ni 'jigs skrag / byur gyi dbang du ni song / / dbugs rgyu ba ni chad/ kha dang sna ni gdangs/ so ni gtsigs/ sbyin pa sbyin no zhes de skad gsol ba ni 'debs/ las kyi srid pa nas yang srid pa la ni 'jug / gcig pu gnyis su med cing grogs ni med de/ 'jig rten 'di ni 'dor/ 'jig rten pha rol du ni 'gro/ / skyas chen po ni 'debs/ mun pa chen por ni zhugs/ g.yang sa chen por ni ltung / khrod stug por ni 'jug / dgon pa chen por ni 'gro/ / rgya mtsho chen pos ni khyer/ las kyi rlung gis ni bdas/ sa tshugs med pa'i phyogs su ni 'gro/ / g.yul ngo chen por ni 'jug / gdon chen pos ni zin/ nam mkha' la ni 'chel/ pha ma dang phu nu dang / sring mo dang bu dang bu mos ni bskor/ dbugs ni 'chad/ nor la bgo bsha' bya zhes ni zer/ kyi hud ma kyi hud pha kyi hud bu zhes ni zer/ skra ni zhig ste/ sbyin pa dang dka' thub dang chos 'ba' zhig grogs su gyur pa na chos ma gtogs par skyabs gzhan med/ mgon gzhan med gnas gzhan med dpung gnyen gzhan med do/ /

rgyal po chen po de'i tshe de'i dus na/ chos ni gling dang gnas dang mgon dang skyabs dang dpung gnyen dang ston par 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na/ grang bas nyen pa la me dang / mes rab tu gdungs bar gyur pa la me gsod pa dang / tsha bas nyen pa la bsil ba dang / 'gron po ngal ba la grib ma dang rlung bsil ba dang / lam du zhugs pa la bzhon pa dang / nyal ba la mal 'jam po dang / skom pa la chu grang mo dang / shin tu bkres pa la zas bzang po dang / mya ngan gyis non pa la dbugs 'byin pa dang / gdungs pa la sim par byed pa dang / dgon par lam stor ba la lam mtshon par byed pa dang / nad kyis btab pa la sman pa dang sman dang nad g.yog byed pa dang / chus khyer ba la gzings dang / 'dam du bying ba la 'ju sa dang / rgal dka' ba la zam pa dang / nyam nga ba la 'bab stegs dang / mun khung na sgron me dang / rgya mtsho chen po la gru dang / lhags pas nyen pa la rlung med pa'i gnas dang / yul gzhan du 'gro ba'i lam rgyags dang / dbul po la nor dang / byed par 'dod pa la grogs dang / gcad par 'dod pa la lag ca dang / gzhig par 'dod pa la rdo rje dang / g.yul ngor zhugs pa la go cha dang / 'jigs pa la stobs dang ldan pa'i grogs dang / 'thab pa la dpung gnyen dang / dog pa la go 'byed pa dang / mu ge la nor dang ldan pa dag mgon dang skyabs dang gnas dang rten du 'gyur ba de bzhin du/ rgyal po chen po 'chi bdag gi gsal shing gis zug ste/ rgyags pa dang ni bral/ mgon ni med/ skyabs ni med/ dpung gnyen ni med/

Your Majesty, at that time, Dharma becomes a place of safety, a place of rest, a refuge, a friend to help, {and a teacher. Your Majesty,} for example, it is like a fire for someone who is suffering from the cold. For someone in agony due to fire, it is like putting out the fire. It is like coolness for someone pained by heat. It is like a cool shady grove for a weary traveler.[xxxvii] {It is like a mount for someone on the road. It is like a soft bed for someone who is lying down.} It is like cool water for the thirsty. It is like good food for the hungry. {It is like encouragement for someone overcome by sorrow. It is like serenity for those in agony. It is like showing the path to those who have lost their way in the wilderness.} It is like doctors, medicine, and nursing care for the sick. {It is like a boat for those traveling by water. It is like something to hold on to for someone sinking into mud. It is like a bridge for someone who needs to make a difficult crossing. It is like something to prevent falling for someone who is afraid of heights. It is like a lamp in a dark cave. It is like a ship on the great ocean. For someone pained by the bitingly cold wind, it is like a shelter from the wind. For someone going to another country, it is like provisions for the journey. It is like wealth for the poor. It is like a friend for someone who wishes to get something done. It is like a tool for someone who wishes to cut something. It is like a vajra for someone who wishes to tear something apart. It is like armor for someone on a battlefield.} It is like powerful friends for the fearful. {It is like a friend to help for someone who is in a fight. It is like an opportunity for someone who is in a tight spot. It is like a wealthy man in a famine.} Just as [all these things respectively] become {a guardian,} a refuge, {an abode, and a support} to the wise,[xxxviii] in the same way, Your Majesty, people who have been pierced by the impalement stake of the Lord of Death, having lost their intoxication, with no guardian, with no refuge, with no friend to help[xxxix]

gshis ni 'jig / tshigs ni 'bye 'bral/ sha dang khrag ni skam/ lus ni nad kyis gdung / skom ni skom/ bzhin ni 'gyur/ rkang lag ni g.yob/ las ni mi nus/ mthu ni med/ kha chu dang snabs dang gcin dang ngan skyugs kyis ni lus la gos/ mig dang / rna ba dang / sna dang / lce dang lus dang yid kyi dbang po dag ni 'gag / skyigs bu ni 'byung / sgra ngar ngar po ni 'thon/ sman pas ni bor/ sman dang kha zas dang bza' ba dang / thug pa thams cad kyis ni kles la bor te/ 'gro ba gzhan dag tu 'gro bar mal gyi tha ma la ni nyal/ thog ma med pa'i skye ba dang rga ba dang 'chi ba'i 'khor ba'i rgyud du ni nub/ srog ni cung zad cig las/ gshin rje'i mis ni 'jigs skrag / byur gyi dbang du ni song / dbugs rgyu ba ni 'chad/ kha dang sna ni gdangs/ so ni gtsigs/ sbyin pa ni sbyin no zhes de skad gsol ba ni 'debs/ las kyi srid pa nas yang srid pa la ni 'jug / gcig pu gnyis su med cing grogs ni med de/ 'jig rten 'di ni 'dor/ 'jig rten pha rol du ni 'gro/ / skyas chen po ni 'debs/ mun pa chen por ni zhugs/ g.yang sa chen por ni ltung / khrod stug por ni 'jug / dgon pa chen por ni 'gro/ / rgya mtsho chen pos ni khyer/ las kyi rlung gis ni bdas/ sa tshugs med pa'i phyogs su ni 'gro ba na

{ with their vitals pierced, with their joints leaking, with their flesh and blood drying up, tormented and thirsty, with their faces changing, with their hands and feet shaking, unable to do anything, powerless, their bodies smeared with saliva, mucus, urine, and feces, with their faculties of sight, hearing, smell, taste, touch, and introspection stopped, hiccupping, with their voices wheezing, given up on by the healer, unable to make use of any kind of medicine, food, soup, or nourishment, lying on their final beds, about to go to other lives, sinking into the beginningless cyclic continuum of birth, old age, disease and death, with only a little life left, frightened by the fear of Yama’s men, under the power of the night of death, breathing their last breaths in and out, with their teeth clenched, saying entreatingly “I have given gifts!”, entering the next life from the life in which they have acted, solitary, alone, and friendless, leaving this world and going to the next, walking on the great path, entering the great dreary forest, falling down into the great abyss, entering the great darkness, being washed away by the great ocean, driven by the winds of karma, going to a region where there are no signposts }
chos ma gtogs par mgon gzhan med/ skyabs gzhan med/ dpung gnyen gzhan med do/ /
—for them, there is no guardian, there is no refuge, there is no friend to help, other than Dharma.[xl]
rgyal po chen po chos ni de'i tshe de'i dus na/ gling chen po dang gnas dang mgon dang skyabs dang dpung gnyen dang ston par 'gyur ro/ /
Your Majesty, at that time, Dharma becomes a place of safety, a place of rest, a refuge, a friend to help, and a teacher.

rgyal po chen po de'i tshe/ 'di snyam du sems te/ kyi hud gang du 'gro bar 'gyur/ phyogs gar 'gro bar 'gyur/ gang du yongs su 'dzin par byed par 'gyur/ bdag gi mar ni su zhig 'gyur snyam pa las/ des sems can dmyal bar skye bar mthong bar 'gyur na 'di lta ste/ mnar med pa dang / tsha ba dang / rab tu tsha ba la sogs pa'i sems can dmyal ba rnams su lo mang po lo brgya phrag mang po lo brgya stong phrag mang por sdug bsngal chen po sdug bsngal mi bzad pa drag pa rtsub pa yid du mi 'ong ba'i tshor ba myong ste/ ji srid du sems can dmyal ba myong bar 'gyur ba'i sdig pa mi dge ba'i las thams cad kyi thams cad du zad cing byang bar ma gyur pa de srid du 'chi ba'i dus byed par mi 'gyur ro/ / de dud 'gro'i skye gnas su skye ba mthong bar gyur na/ 'di lta ste/ rgya mtsho chen po'i nang du nya rlon dang nya rlon mid la sogs pa srog chags gcig gis gcig gsod pa dang 'tshe ba dang dbang med par skye'o/ / bdag yi dwags kyi nang du skye bar mi 'gyur ram snyam na/ 'di lta ste/ lo mang po dang lo brgya phrag mang po dang lo brgya stong phrag mang por chu'i sgra yang mi thos na mthong ba lta ci smos par 'gyur ro/ /

Your Majesty, at that time, the dying person thinks: “Oh no! Where will I go? To what place will I go? What [body] will I take up? Who will be my mother?” This person then will see birth in the hells, which means, for example, the Avīci Hell, the Heating Hell, the Extreme Heating Hell, and so on. In the hells, this person spends many years, many hundreds of years, many thousands of years, in great pain, unbearable pain, and experiences fierce, harsh, dreadful sensations. And as long as all those vile actions which are to be experienced in hell have not been exhausted and cleared away, the person does not die. This person will also see birth as an animal, which means, for example, as a fish or a saltwater crocodile in the great ocean, where the living beings harm and kill each other and are born powerless. The dying person thinks, “Or could I be born among hungry ghosts?” This means, for example, for many years, for many hundreds of years, for many hundreds of thousands of years, not even hearing the word ‘water,’ much less seeing any.

rgyal po chen po de lta bas na khyod kyis mi rtag par blta zhing zad pa dang dengs par blta bar bya ste/ 'chi bas 'jigs skrag par bya'o/ / chos kyis rgyal srid gyis shig / chos ma yin pas ni mi bya'o/ / khyod chos dang mthun par gyis shig / chos ma yin pa dang mthun par ni mi bya'o/ /

[208] Therefore, Your Majesty, you should keep impermanence in mind. You should keep decay and destruction in mind. You should be afraid of the danger of death. You should rule only with Dharma, not contrary to Dharma.[xli] {You should act only in accordance with Dharma, not in a way opposed to Dharma.}

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ rgyal po chen po khyod kyi lus 'di/ 'di ltar legs par yongs su bsrungs legs par yongs su btsas pa yang 'chi ba'i dus byed par 'gyur ro/ / yon tan thams cad dang ldan zhing shin tu yun ring por bza' ba dang / bca' ba dang myang ba dang ngoms par 'gyur ba bsod pa dang gtsang ma mang pos tshim par byas te bskyed bskyed pa yang tha ma'i mal na 'dug pa'i tshe/ sman pas bor zhing sman dang kha zas dang bza' ba dang thug pas kyang kles la bor nas bkres pa dang skom pas nyen cing yid mi bde bar 'chi ba'i dus byed par 'gyur ro/ /

Why is this? Your Majesty, your body, which has been well protected for a long time, which has been gratified and entertained for a long time with pure, good-quality hard food, soft food, and sauces, will die miserably, pained by hunger and thirst.[xlii]

rgyal po chen po 'di ltar khyod kyis lus bkrus shing bskus te bdug pas bsgos me tog dri zhim pos bsgos kyang / gdon mi za bar 'chi ba'i dus su rang bzhin gyis lhan cig skyes pa'i dri nga ba 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /
In the same way, Your Majesty, your body, which has been bathed and smells of skin creams, perfumes, incense, flowers, and fragrances, will soon give off a stench.
