rgyal po chen po 'di ltar gos yul ka shi pa'i ras dang / srin bal dang / du gu la dang / dar dang / 'dab ma dang / bal dang / gso ras la sogs pa'i gos kyi bye brag gis g.yogs kyang tha ma'i mal na 'dug pa'i tshe/ snum rnam pa mang po dang chus reg cing gos dri ma can gon zhing 'chi ba'i dus byed par 'gyur ro/ /

In the same way, your body is clothed with luxury garments from Kāśi and in the style of Kāśi,[7] made of Dukūla fabric, silk cloth, and woven silk; but it will die lying on the final bed, covered with clothes soiled with sweat and various liquids.

rgyal po chen po khyod de ltar bud med kyi nang na 'dug btsun mo'i 'khor gyi nang na 'dug ste/ bud med kyi tshogs kyis bskor zhing gar dang glu dang rol mo dang sil snyan byed/ pheg rdob pi bang dang gling bu len/ rnga rdung zhing yid bde bar rtse dga' zhing dga' mgur spyod pa yang 'chi bas 'jigs skrag nas shin tu yid mi bde zhing 'chi ba'i dus byed par 'gyur ro/ /

In the same way, Your Majesty, when you go to the harem, you are surrounded by a crowd of women and serenaded with various songs, musical instruments, and dances, and you happily play around, have fun, and enjoy yourself; but you will die in great pain and suffering, afraid of the danger of death.

rgyal po chen po 'di ltar khyod kyi khyim gyi nang na spos dri zhim po'i bsku bas ni bskus/ gtan pa ni bcug / skar khung ni legs par bcad/ byug pa mang pos ni byugs/ 'bru mar dri zhim po dang ldan pa'i mar me ni 'bar/ dar gyi lda ldi mang po ni bres/ me tog dri zhim po'i sil ma mang pos ni chal bar bkram/ pog phor nas ni bdugs/ khri'i rtsa ba gser dang dngul dang bai DUr+ya las ni byas/ pa ti ka dang / dre'u rdog gi stan dang / stan nang tshangs can dang / za 'og gi stan dang / yul ka ling ka'i stan dang / steng du gding ba dang / de'i steng du gding bas ni bkab/ g.yas g.yon du dar mang po'i sngas ni bzhag pa'i khri la nyal ba yang bya rog dang bya rgod dang / wa dang / ro dang / sha dang / rus pa dang / skra dang / khrag dang / zhag dang / chu ser dang rnag gi gnas mchog tu 'jigs su rung ba'i dur khrod chen por bor nas lus g.yo ba med cing sa la nyal du gdon mi za'o/ /

In the same way, Your Majesty, you lie down in houses anointed with ointments, with bolts well fastened, with the windows well covered, shining with many kinds of scents, incense, flowers, oils, and ointments, decorated with collections of unattached threads and strips of cloth, strewn with loose flowers, perfumed with jars of scents, with beds made up with footrests of woven cloth, long woolen quilts, very soft blankets, other textile garments, coverlets of woven cloth, and pillows. But your body will lose the power of movement and lie helpless on the earth in the supremely terrifying charnel-ground, home to jackals, crows, vultures, dead bodies, flesh, bones, hair, blood, and marrow.

rgyal po chen po 'di ltar yang khyod glang po che'i bya la kha'am rta'i rgyab bam shing rta la zhon te/ dung dang rnga dang rdza rnga dang / 'khar rnga dang / rol mo'i sil snyan gyi bye brag len pa dang / gdugs dang rgyal mtshan dang ba dan dang rnam par rgyal ba'i ba dan ni bsgreng / bsil yab nor bu'i yu ba can dang / rnga yab dang shing tA la las byas pa ni g.yob cing / glang po che dang rta pa dang dpung bu chung du ma ni phyi bzhin 'brang / rgyal bu dang bram zes bslab pa phog pa'i blon po dang mdun na 'don pa dang skye bo thal mo sbyar ba brgya stong du mas ni phyag bya zhing rgyal bar spyon cig rgyal bar spyon cig ces snyan pa brjod de phyir 'byung myong ba yang ring por mi thogs par g.yo ba med cing mal du shi nas mi bzhis bteg ste/ pha dang ma dang phu nu dang sring mo dang chung ma dang bu pho dang bu mo dang / bran pho dang bran mo dang / las byed pa dang / zho shas 'tsho ba dang / chal za ba dang / blon po dang / grong khyer ba'i skye bo dag mya ngan gyi dbang du song ste/ lag pa bteg nas brang rdung zhing mchog tu snying rje bar/ kyi hud bu kyi hud mgon po kyi hud phu bo kyi hud jo bo zhes ngu zhing / zham 'bring ba dang grong khyer pa'i skye bo dag gis 'jigs pa dang bcas par mthong ste/ grong khyer gyi lho phyogs kyi sgor phyung nas/ sa'i 'og tu bcug gam/ 'brog dgon par sa'i nang du bcug kyang / bya rog dang bya rgod dang wa la sogs pas zos shing / rus pa de dag mes bsregs sam chur bskyur ram sa'i 'og tu bcug kyang rlung dang nyi ma dang char pas phye mar byas te/ phyogs phyogs su gtor zhing de nyid du rul par 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po chen po de ltar sems can thams cad kyi lus kyang 'di bzhin du 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po chen po 'du byed thams cad ni de ltar mi rtag pa de ltar mi brtan pa zhes rgya cher gsungs so/ /

[209] In the same way, Your Majesty, when you go out, you are carried in chariots, on horseback, or by a formation of elephants, while conch-shells are being blown and kettle-drums are being beaten, with a parasol held above you,[8] being fanned with a yak-tail fan. You are followed by many elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry, and you are saluted with hundreds of thousands of acts of homage. But soon you will be carried out through the city gate by four men on a bier, held up with their right hands. Your mother and father, brothers and sisters, wives, sons and daughters, friends, male and female servants, workers and employees, with their hearts full of sorrow, waving their arms and beating their breasts, feeling extreme pity, will cry out: “Alas, son! Alas, lord! Alas, father! Alas, husband!” Your [body] will be seen by the citizens in a degrading position, taken to the charnel ground, and then it will be eaten by crows, vultures, dogs, jackals, and other animals. Your bones will be burned by fire, or buried in the earth, or moistened with water, or reduced to powder by wind, heat, and rain; they will be scattered in all directions, and decay. {Your Majesty, the same things will happen to the bodies of all sentient beings.} Your Majesty, all conditioned things are impermanent in this way, are subject to change in this way. And so on at length.

de la nyon mongs pa ni gtsor 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug rnams te/ de dag gi nang nas gang la mchog tu gnod par byed pa'i gnyen po gang yin pa de thog mar bsgom zhing de'i gzhi yang yongs su spang bar bya'o/ / de la re zhig 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las/

The principal reactive emotions are attraction, aversion, and delusion. Whichever one of these is causing you the greatest harm is the one whose remedy you should cultivate first, and whose causes you should give up. On this topic, the noble Cloud of Jewels says:

de 'dod chags kyi gnyen po la brten cing 'dod chags skye ba'i rkyen rnams yongs su spong ngo / / 'dod chags kyi gnyen po de ni gang / 'dod chags skye ba'i rkyen de dag ni gang zhe na/ mi sdug pa bsgom pa ni 'dod chags kyi gnyen po'o/ / yul gyi bzang mo ni 'dod chags skye ba'i rkyen no/ /

He takes the remedy for attraction, and gives up the conditions for the arising of attraction. And what is that remedy for attraction? And what are those conditions for the arising of attraction? The meditation on foulness is the remedy for attraction. A beautiful local girl is a condition for the arising of attraction.

mi sdug pa bsgom pa de yang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ lus 'di la skra dang spu dang sen mo dang so dang rdul dang / dri ma dang / pags pa dang sha dang rus pa dang rgyus pa dang rtsa dang mkhal ma dang snying dang mchin pa dang glo ba dang rgyu ma dang gnye ma dang pho ba dang sul mang dang long ka dang mcher pa dang phyi sa dang mchil ma dang rngul dang snabs dang ngar snabs dang zhag dang chu ser dang rkang dang tshil dang mkhris pa dang bad kan dang rnag dang khrag dang klad pa dang klad rgyas dang gcin dag yod de/ dngos po de dag la byang chub sems dpa' yongs su rtog pa'i rang bzhin can yin te/ yongs su rtog pa'i rang bzhin can de 'di snyam du byis pa blun po mi gsal ba mi mkhas pa de yang dngos po 'di dag shes nas 'dod chags kyi sems mi skye na shes rab dang ldan pa'i rang bzhin can lta smos kyang ci dgos snyam ste/ de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' mi sdug pa mang du bsgom pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

[210] And what is this meditation on foulness? It is as follows: In this body, there are head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, dirt and impurity, skin, flesh, bones, muscles, veins, kidneys, heart, spleen, lungs, small intestines, rectum, stomach, abdomen, large intestines, liver, feces, tears, sweat, mucus, mucus of the nose, fat, saliva, bone-marrow, fatty tissue, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, brain, meninges, and urine. The bodhisattva carefully considers these things, and carefully considering them, thinks, “Even a deluded, unworthy, bad,[xliii] foolish person who had thought about these things would not arouse thoughts of attraction; how much less so a wise person!” The bodhisattva often meditates on foulness in this way.

bcom ldan 'das ma las kyang / gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pa na/ lus 'di yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes so/ / rab 'byor 'di lta ste dper na ba lang gi shan pa'am ba lang gi shan pa'i slob mas ba lang bsad de gri rnon pos bag bzhir gshegs nas 'greng ngam 'dug ste so sor rtog go/ / rab 'byor de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pa na yang / lus 'di la yod pa ni sa'i khams dang chu'i khams dang me'i khams dang rlung gi khams so zhes lus 'di la khams kyis yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du so sor rtog go zhes bya ba nas/

The Blessed Lady also says, Moreover, Subhūti, a bodhisattva great being, when practicing the perfection of wisdom, knows this body as it actually is. For example, Subhūti, suppose a butcher or a butcher’s assistant first killed a cow, and with a sharp knife, cut it into four pieces, and then, while standing or seated, examined them. In just the same way, Subhūti, a bodhisattva practicing the perfection of wisdom knows the elements of the body as they actually are: “There are in this body the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/
The same text also says,

rab 'byor 'di lta ste dper na/ chun pa'i rdzas/ 'bras sA lu dang / 'bru dang / til dang / 'bras dang / mon sran sde'u dang / mon sran gre'u dang / nas dang / gro dang / sran chung dang / yungs kar dang / 'bru sna tshogs kyis gang ba de dag la/ skyes bu mig dang ldan pas brtags na/ 'di ltar 'di dag ni 'bras sA lu'o/ / 'di dag ni 'bru'o/ / 'di dag ni til lo/ / 'di dag ni 'bras so/ / 'di dag ni mon sran sde'u'o/ / 'di dag ni mon sran gre'u'o/ / 'di dag ni nas so/ / 'di dag ni gro'o/ / 'di dag ni sran chung ngo / / 'di dag ni yungs kar ro zhes bya bar shes so/ / rab 'byor de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po yang / shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pa na/ lus 'di la rkang mthil yan chad klad rgyas man chad sen mo dang spu dang pags pa la thug pa mi gtsang ba rnam pa sna tshogs kyis gang ba ste/ lus 'di la yod pa ni skra dang / spu dang klad pa dang klad rgyas dang mig gi rngu ma dang rna spabs kyi bar dag go zhes snga ma ltar yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du so sor rtog go/ /

For example, Subhūti, suppose that a farmer’s bag[xliv] was full of various grains, such as rice, hill-rice, sesame seeds, husked rice, kidney-beans, beans, barley, wheat, lentils, and mustard-seeds, and a person with good eyes were to examine it and know, “This is rice, this is hill-rice, these are sesame seeds, this is husked rice, these are kidney beans, these are beans, these are barley, these are wheat, these are lentils, and these are mustard-seeds.”[9] In just the same way, a bodhisattva great being who is practicing the perfection of wisdom examines this very body as it actually is, from the soles of the feet to the top of the head,[xlv] bounded by the head-hairs, the skull, the nails, the body-hairs, and the skin, full of various types of impurity: “There are in this body head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, and so on up to: skull, meninges, the dirt of the eyes and the wax of the ears.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rab 'byor gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' dur khrod du song ste/ dur khrod du bor ba ro'i gnas su bskyal ba shi nas zhag gcig lon pa'am/ shi nas zhag gnyis lon pa'am/ shi nas zhag gsum lon pa'am/ shi nas zhag bzhi lon pa'am/ shi nas zhag lnga lon pa'am/ rnam par bam pa'am/ rnam par bsngos pa'am/ rnam par rnags pa'am/ rnam par 'bus gzhigs pa'i ro sna tshogs mthong na/ de lus 'di yang de lta bu'i rang bzhin can no/ / de lta bu'i chos can no/ / chos nyid 'di las ma 'das pa'o zhes lus 'di la yang de dang sbyor ro/ / rab 'byor de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pa na/ de lus la lus kyi rjes su lta zhing gnas so/ /

[211] Moreover, Subhūti, when a bodhisattva who goes to the charnel-ground[10] sees various forms, dead bodies that have been thrown away in the charnel-ground, on the corpse-bed,[xlvi] dead for one day, or dead for two days, or for three, or four, or five days, corpses swollen by putrefaction, blue-black corpses, putrefied corpses, or corpses that have burst open,[xlvii] the bodhisattva brings up this very body in that context: “This body has the same qualities, has the same nature, and is not excluded from that reality.” Subhūti, in this way, a bodhisattva great being practicing the perfection of wisdom lives seeing the body as the body
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gzhan yang gang gi tshe shi ba'i ro dur khrod du bor ba/ shi nas zhag drug lon pa'am/ shi nas zhag bdun lon pa'am/ bya rog gis btogs pa'am/ ne'u le'am/ bya rgod dam/ khyi'am/ ce spyang ngam/ de las gzhan pa srog chags rnam pa sna tshogs kyis za ba mthong na de lus 'di yang de lta bu'i rang bzhin can/ de lta bu'i chos can no/ / chos nyid 'di las ma 'das pa'o zhes lus 'di yang de dang sbyar ro/ /

Moreover, when the bodhisattva sees dead bodies discarded in the charnel-ground, dead for six days,[xlviii] {or dead for seven days,} being eaten by crows, ospreys,[xlix] vultures, dogs, jackals, or various other species of animals, the bodhisattva brings up this very body in that context: {238} “This body has the same qualities, has the same nature, and is not excluded from that reality.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/
gzhan yang gang gi tshe shi ba'i ro dur khrod du bor na/ rnam par zos pa/ mi gtsang ba/ dri nga ba mthong na/ de lus 'di yang de dang sbyar ro zhes bya ba snga ma bzhin no/ /

Moreover, when the bodhisattva sees dead bodies discarded in the charnel ground, split into pieces, filthy and foul-smelling, the bodhisattva brings up this very body in that context, and so on as before …
gzhan yang gang gi tshe/ dur khrod na keng rus dang / sha dang khrag ra ri chags pa chu rgyus brang breng thogs pa mthong na/ de lus 'di yang de dang sbyar ro zhes bya ba snga ma bzhin no/ /

Moreover, when the bodhisattva sees, in the place where corpses are thrown, dead bodies, skeletons smeared with flesh and blood, barely held together by tendons, the bodhisattva brings up this very body in that context, and so on as before.
gzhan yang gang gi tshe/ dur khrod na keng rus su gyur pa sha dang khrag dang chu rgyus med pa mthong na/ de lus 'di yang zhes bya ba snga ma bzhin no/ /

Moreover, when the bodhisattva sees, in the place where corpses are thrown, dead bodies that have become skeletons, having lost their flesh, blood, tendons, and ligaments, the bodhisattva brings up this very body, as before.

gzhan yang gang gi tshe dur khrod na rus pa phyogs dang phyogs mtshams su 'thor ba 'di lta ste/ rje ngar gyi rus pa yang gzhan na/ brla'i rus pa yang gzhan na/ 'dong mo yang gzhan na/ sgal tshigs kyang gzhan na/ rtsib ma yang gzhan na/ mjing tshigs kyang gzhan na/ dpung pa'i rus pa yang gzhan na 'dug pa mthong na/ de lus 'di yang de lta bu'i rang bzhin can no/ / de lta bu'i chos can no/ / chos nyid 'di las ma 'das pa'o zhes lus 'di yang de dang sbyar ro/ /

[212] Moreover, when the bodhisattva sees, in the place where corpses are thrown, bones scattered in all directions —foot-bones here, ankle-bones there, long-bones over here, a pelvic bone over there, here a spine, there rib-bones, neck-bones here, arm-bones there—the bodhisattva brings up this very body in that context: “This body has the same qualities, has the same nature, and is not excluded from that reality.”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rab 'byor gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pa na/ dur khrod na rus pa lo du ma lon pa rlung dang nyi mas gdungs pa dkar ba dung lta bu mthong na/ de lus 'di yang de lta bu'i rang bzhin no/ / de lta bu'i chos can no/ / chos nyid 'di las ma 'das pa'o zhes lus 'di yang de dang sbyar ro/ /

Moreover, {Subhūti, when a bodhisattva great being who is practicing the perfection of wisdom} sees, in the place where corpses are thrown, bones that have been there for many years, parched by the wind, the color of conch-shells, the bodhisattva brings up this very body in that context, as before: “This body has the same qualities, has the same nature, and is not excluded from that reality.”

rab 'byor gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la spyod pa na/ dur khrod na rus pa lo du ma lon pa thi ba'i mdog ltar sngo ba sob sob por gyur pa zegs pa sa la rdul dang mtshungs shing mnyam par gyur pa mthong na/ de lus 'di yang de lta bu'i rang bzhin no/ / de lta bu'i chos can no/ / chos nyid 'di las ma 'das pa'o zhes lus 'di yang de dang sbyar ro zhes gsungs so/ /

Moreover, Subhūti, when a bodhisattva great being who is practicing the perfection of wisdom sees bones that have been in the charnel-ground for many years, which have turned blue like the color of a pigeon, have become spongy, or have disintegrated into dust,[l] the bodhisattva brings up this very body in that context: “This body has the same qualities, has the same nature, and is not excluded from that reality.”

'di ni re zhig 'dod chags la kun du spyod pa'i gnyen po mdor bsdus pa'o/ / zhe sdang gi gnyen po ni byams pa dang mi sdug pa'i sems can mi mthong ba'am de dang lhan cig tu zas la sogs pa don gcig pas dga' ba skye'o/ / de la gzhan la bde ba 'dod pa dang don du gnyer ba dang mos pa dang mngon par dga' ba ni byams pa ste/ 'dod pa la 'dod chags dang lan du phan 'dogs pa'i rgyu dag las nyon mongs pa can ma yin pa'i chags pa zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go/ / de ni rnam pa gsum ste/ 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las/ sems can la dmigs pa'i byams pa ni sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi'o/ / chos la dmigs pa'i byams pa ni spyod pa la zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi'o/ / dmigs pa med pa'i byams pa ni mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa thob pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi'o zhes gsungs so/ /

This, in brief, is the practice that is the remedy for attraction. The remedy for aversion is lovingkindness. And in the case of sentient beings you don’t like, either don’t look at them, or arouse delight together with them in regards to the same object, such as food and so on. Here wishing for, aiming at, being committed to, and rejoicing in the happiness of others is lovingkindness. This is a form of love that is not defiled by sexual attraction or by expecting something in return. The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra describes three kinds: “the lovingkindness of beginner bodhisattvas, which takes sentient beings as its object; the lovingkindness of bodhisattvas with practice experience, which takes simple entities as its object; and the objectless lovingkindness of the bodhisattvas who have attained the acceptance of the nonarising of everything.”[11]

yang sangs rgyas la dmigs pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' la dmigs pa dang / nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas la dmigs pa dang / sems can la dmigs pa'o/ / de la sems can la dmigs pa ni gang thog mar snying du sdug pa'i sems can la phan pa dang bde ba nye bar bsgrub par bsam par goms par byed cing de dang mthun pa'i byams pa nye bar bsgrub po/ / de'i 'og tu 'dres pa rnams la'o/ / de'i 'og tu tha mal pa rnams la'o/ / de'i 'og tu nye 'khor ba rnams la'o/ / de'i 'og tu rang gi grong na gnas pa rnams la'o/ / de bzhin du gzhan gyi grong pa nas phyogs gcig gi bar du mos par byas te khyab par byas nas rdzogs par byas te gnas so/ / phyogs bcur yang de bzhin no/ /

[213] Alternately, there are: the form of lovingkindness that takes Buddhas as its objects; the form that takes bodhisattvas as its objects; the form that takes Disciples and Solitary Sages as its objects; and the form that takes sentient beings as its objects. In the case of the form that takes sentient beings as objects, you start with someone who is dear to your heart, and develop in meditation the thought of providing benefits and happiness for that person. Next, develop lovingkindness towards someone similar to the first person; then towards your friends; then towards people towards whom you feel indifferent; then towards those nearby; then towards your fellow villagers; and then towards those living in another village. In the same way, focus attention and radiate lovingkindness in one direction, and rest there; do the same for all ten directions.

sangs rgyas la sogs pa la dmigs pa la ni sbyor ba 'di med de/ de ni rdo rje rgyal mtshan gyi yongs su bsngo ba las/ de byang chub sems dpa'i spyad pa spyod pa na/ gzugs yid du 'ong ba'am yid du mi 'ong ba gang ji snyed cig mthong ba dang / de bzhin du sgra dang dri dang ro dang reg bya dang chos yid du 'ong ba'am/ yid du mi 'ong ba'am kha na ma tho ba med pa dag la bde ba rgya che ba 'od gsal ba'am/ gang gis yid bde ba skye ba dang / bde ba bsgrub pa dang / dad pa skye ba dang / dga' ba 'byung ba dang / mchog tu dga' ba la gnas pa dang / mgu ba 'byung ba dang / yid mi bde ba ldog pa dang / sems dge ba 'byung ba dang / sems las su rung bar 'gyur ba dang / bsam pa mnyen par 'gyur ba dang / dbang po rab tu tshim par 'gyur ba'i bde ba de myong ba na/ sangs rgyas thams cad la 'di ltar yongs su bsngo ste/ yongs su bsngo ba 'dis

In the case of the meditations that take Buddhas and so on as their objects, these preliminaries are unnecessary. The dedication section of the Vajra Flag Sūtra says, While practicing the bodhisattva’s way of life, whatever forms he sees, whether attractive or repulsive; and also, whatever sounds, scents, tastes, touchables, or experiences he encounters, whether attractive or repulsive, or irreproachable, pure, beautiful, lofty, or luminous—gladness arises; happiness descends; calmness arises; pleasure is born; joyfulness abides; delight appears; suffering ceases; mental health appears; the mind becomes fit for work; the heart softens; the senses experience pleasure, and he feels happiness. This he dedicates to all the Buddhas with the following dedication, in great measure:[li]

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de dag de bas kyang sangs rgyas kyi gnas pa'i bde ba bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang ldan par gyur cig / sangs rgyas kyi ting nge 'dzin gyi bde ba mtshungs pa med pas legs par zin par gyur cig / sangs rgyas kyi bde ba mtha' yas pas rgya cher brtan par gyur cig / sangs rgyas kyi rnam par thar pa'i bde ba tshad med pa dang ldan par gyur cig / sangs rgyas kyi cho 'phrul gyi bde ba dpag tu med pas legs par zin par gyur cig / sangs rgyas kyi gnas pa chags pa med pa'i bde ba bsam gyis mi khyab pas legs par yongs su zin par gyur cig / sangs rgyas kyi khyu mchog tu gyur pa'i bde ba bsnyen par dka' ba rgyun mi 'chad par gyur cig / sangs rgyas kyi stobs kyi bde ba dpag tu med pas shin tu bde bar gyur cig / tshor ba thams cad zhi bar mi skye ba'i bde bas 'gyur ba med par bde bar gyur cig / de bzhin gshegs pa'i bde ba'i chags pa med par gnas par rtag tu mnyam par gzhag pa gnyis su kun du mi spyod pas rnam par mi 'khrugs par bde bar gyur cig /

[214] May those Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, have the inconceivable happiness of the abodes of the Buddhas. May they securely possess the unmatched happiness of the meditative absorptions of the Buddhas. May they be greatly supported by endless happiness. May they have the measureless happiness of the liberation of the Buddhas. May they securely possess the immeasurable happiness of the miracle powers of the Buddhas. May they securely possess the inconceivable happiness of freedom from attachment, the abode of the Buddhas. May they be presented with[lii] the happiness, so difficult to find, of the majesty of the Buddhas. May they be utterly delighted with the measureless happiness of the powers of the Buddhas. May they be unchangingly happy through the happiness of the peaceful nonarising of all feelings.[liii] May they be happy and undisturbed, living without attachment and continuously in meditative absorption, practicing nonduality, with the happiness of the Tathāgatas.

byang chub sems dpas de ltar dge ba'i rtsa ba de de bzhin gshegs pa rnams la yongs su bsngos nas byang chub sems dpa' rnams la yongs su bsngo ste/ gang 'di bsam pa yongs su ma rdzogs pa rnams kyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par bya ba dang / thams cad mkhyen pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa yongs su ma dag pa rnams yongs su dag par bya ba dang / pha rol tu phyin pa thams cad yongs su ma rdzogs pa yongs su rdzogs par bya ba dang / byang chub kyi sems bskyed pa rdo rje lta bu'i gnas su bya ba dang thams cad mkhyen pa las phyir mi ldog pa'i go cha rgyun mi gcad pa dang / byang chub kyi sgo'i dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams bskyed pa dang / 'gro ba thams cad la mnyam pa nyid du gnas pa'i smon lam chen po yongs su rdzogs par bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa'i gnas pa thams cad rtogs par bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa'i dbang po thams cad mngon par shes pa rno bar bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du reg par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ /

After dedicating that wholesome action to the Tathāgatas, in the same way, he dedicates it to the bodhisattvas. He dedicates so that those who have not yet fulfilled their intentions may fulfill them. He dedicates so that those who are not yet pure, but have the higher intention for complete knowing, may be purified. He dedicates so that those who are not yet perfected may fully develop all the Perfections; so that they may have the resolve of arousing Awakening Mind that is like a vajra; so that they may not stop the ceaseless preparation for complete knowing; so that they may seek to emulate the wholesome actions of the bodhisattvas;[liv] so that they may fulfill the great vow that is based on the equality of all living beings; so that they may attain all the abodes of the bodhisattvas; so that they may have the acute higher knowledge of all the faculties of the bodhisattvas; so that they may touch complete knowing through all the bodhisattvas’ wholesome actions.

de de ltar byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi don du dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su bsngos nas/ sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa la spyod pa dang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas thams cad la dge ba'i rtsa ba de 'di ltar yongs su bsngo ste/ sems can gang la la dag se gol cig gtogs pa srid du sangs rgyas kyi sgra nyan pa'am/ chos kyi sgra nyan pa'am/ 'phags pa'i dge 'dun la bsnyen bkur byed pa de dag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba de/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu yongs su bsngo'o/ / sangs rgyas rjes su dran pa yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / chos rjes su dran pa la sbyor bar bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / 'phags pa'i dge 'dun la gus par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sangs rgyas mthong ba dang mi 'bral bar bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems yongs su dag par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos rab tu rtogs par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / yon tan dpag tu med pa bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / mngon par shes pa thams cad kyi dge ba yongs su dag par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / chos la yid gnyis zlog pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ /

After dedicating that wholesome action for the benefit of the bodhisattvas in this way, he dedicates the same wholesome action to all the Disciples and Solitary Sages and to all those practicing the religion of the Buddhas. He dedicates that wholesome action so that any sentient beings who, for even as long as the sound of one finger-snap lasts,[lv] hear the word “Buddha,” or hear the word “Dharma,” or act respectfully towards the community of Noble Ones, will reach highest genuine full Awakening. He dedicates so that they may fully develop the recollection of the Buddhas. He dedicates so that they may practice the recollection of the Dharma. He dedicates so that they may behave respectfully towards the Community of Noble Ones. He dedicates so that they may soon have the good fortune to see a Buddha.[lvi] He dedicates so that they may purify their minds. He dedicates so that they may fully understand the teachings of the Buddhas. He dedicates so that they may attain immeasurable abilities. He dedicates so that they fully purify their skill in all forms of higher knowing. He dedicates so that they may put an end to all doubts about the Dharma.

ji ltar sangs rgyas kyi bsten pa la zhugs pa rnams dang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas rnams la yongs su bsngo ba de bzhin du/ byang chub sems dpa' de sems can thams cad la dge ba'i rtsa ba de yongs su bsngo ste/ gang 'di sems can dmyal ba pa'i lam las bzlog pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / dud 'gro'i skye gnas rnam par gcad pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / gshin rje'i 'jig rten nye bar gcad pa'i bde ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / ngan song ma lus pa thams cad kyi 'gro bar skye ba rnam par gcad pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ /

[215] Just as he dedicates to the Disciples and Solitary Sages and to those practicing the religion of the Buddhas, in the same way that bodhisattva dedicates that wholesome action to all sentient beings. Specifically, he dedicates in order to turn them back from the road to the hells. He dedicates in order to cut off animal wombs. He dedicates for the happiness of destroying the world of Yama. He dedicates in order to cut off all bad rebirths without exception.
de bzhin du sbyar te/

sems can de dag bla na med pa'i byang chub la mos pa rnam par spel ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi sems kyi lhag pa'i bsam pa thob par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad mi spong ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi shin tu bde ba bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad shin tu rnam par dag par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad ye shes mtha' yas pa rtogs par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ /

And he dedicates for all sentient beings so that they may develop their motivation for highest Awakening. He dedicates so that they may gain higher intention, the mind of complete knowing. He dedicates so that they may not reject any of the Buddha’s teachings. He dedicates so that they may attain the sublime happiness of complete knowing.[lvii] He dedicates so that all of the innumerable sentient beings may be purified. He dedicates so that all sentient beings may attain limitless pristine awareness
de bzhin du sbyar te/
byang chub sems dpa' thams cad mkhyen pa nyid la dmigs pa dang ldan pa/ sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde ba'i sems dang ldan pa dang /
the bodhisattva, motivated by complete knowing, thinking of the welfare and happiness of all sentient beings[lviii]
de bzhin du sbyar te/
'gro ba thams cad yongs su bskyab pa'i yid dang ldan pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba la rtag tu brtson pa/ rgyags pa dang bag med pa bzlog pa dang /
in order to save the entire living world, with a mind always working hard at wholesome actions, having completely stopped intoxication and heedlessness
de bzhin du sbyar te/

nyon mongs pa thams cad la rgyab kyis phyogs pa/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi rjes su slob pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi lam dang zhe ma 'gras pa/ ye shes kyi sa la brten pa/ mkhas pa dang 'grogs par dga' ba dang /

turning his face away from all reactive emotions, intending to do all the forms of training of the bodhisattvas, with no obstructions on his path to complete knowing, practicing the Stages to pristine awareness, delighting in living together with the learned
de bzhin du sbyar te/
bung ba ltar dge ba'i rtsa ba sogs pa 'gro ba thams cad la skyob pa'i rgyu dang ldan pa/ 'dus byas thams cad la mngon par zhen pa med pa
storing up wholesome actions like a honeybee, with a personality oriented towards the entire living world, unattached to conditioned things

de'i/ gos dang zas dang na ba'i gsos sman dang yo byad dang 'ong ba dang 'gro ba dang / lus kyi bsnyen bkur dang / 'dug pa la sogs pa rten pa'i gnas la 'jug pa'i las dang / spyod lam gyi gnas dang / spyod lam rnam par mi 'khrugs pa dang / lus kyi las dang / ngag gi las dang / yid kyi las legs par spyad pa dang / dbang po drug sdom pa dang / rang gi lus g.yogs pa dang / mnye ba dang bkru ba'i las dang / zos pa dang / 'chos pa dang / myangs pa dang / bskum pa dang / brkyang ba dang / lta ba dang / rnam par lta ba dang / gnyid kyis log pa dang / gnyid kyis ma log pa dang / rang gi lus su gtogs pa'i bsnyen bkur ci gang yang rung ste/ de thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du yongs su ma bsngos pa cung zad kyang med do zhes bya ba nas/

Whatever he has, such as robes, alms-food, shelter, or medicine for the sick; and whatever bodily actions he engages in, such as going and coming, standing up and sitting down, any type of practice or movement based on bodily posture; stillness in bodily posture; whatever is well done in thought, word, and deed; the discipline of the six senses; all actions, such as clothing, anointing or bathing the body, eating, drinking, chewing, retraction or extension of limbs, looking ahead, looking around, sleeping and waking, any movements or acts of respect pertaining to his own body— does not have anything at all of these types that is not dedicated to complete knowing, …

rang gi ba rnams dang de las gzhan dud 'gro'i skye gnas su song ba rnams la/ 'bras chan pho tshum gang ngam zan chang cig tsam yongs su gtong ba yang skye ba de dang de dag tu de dag nyid la phan pa dang de dag nyid yongs su dgrol ba'i phyir de thams cad yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can de dag dud 'gro'i skye gnas de dang sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho dang sdug bsngal nye bar len pa de dang sdug bsngal gyi phung po de dang sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba de dang / sdug bsngal nye bar bsags pa de dang / sdug bsngal mngon par 'du byed pa dang / sdug bsngal gyi gzhi dang / sdug bsngal gyi rtsa ba de dang / sdug bsngal gyi gnas de las rnam par bzlog pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / de la dmigs pas sems can thams cad la dmigs par byed do/ / sems can rnams la mngon du byed do/ / yid la byed do/ / 'di lta ste thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du yongs su sngo bar byed pas dge ba'i rtsa ba de la mngon du 'gro bar byed do/ / byang chub tu sems bskyed pas rab tu 'dzin to/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba de la sbyor ro/ / 'khor ba'i dgon pa las rnam par zlog go/ / sangs rgyas kyi bde ba sgrib pa med pa mngon du byed do/ / 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho las 'byin to/ / sangs rgyas kyi chos dang ldan pa'i byams pas khyab par byed do zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

[216] If he gives so much as one mouthful of porridge or other food to dogs[lix] or to other animals, he dedicates that so that those very animals may have good rebirths, so that they may benefit, so that they may be set free. He dedicates so that they may turn away from animal wombs, from that ocean of suffering,[lx] {from that appropriation of suffering, from that mass of suffering, from that sensation of suffering, from that accumulation of suffering, from that fabricated suffering,} from that basis of suffering, from that root of suffering, from that place of suffering. He takes them as objects, and takes all sentient beings as objects and pays attention to them, and with respect to that wholesome action, puts them first: that is, he dedicates it to complete knowing. He arouses and takes hold of the Awakening Mind and brings up that wholesome action in that context. He turns his face away from the dreary forest of cyclic existence and towards the undistorted happiness of the Buddhas. He rises up from the sea of cyclic existence. He radiates lovingkindness in accordance with the Buddhas’ teachings. And so on.
gser 'od dam pa las gsungs pa'i byams pa dang snying rje'i snying po can gyi tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag gus pa thams cad kyis bsams te/ tha na tshig gis kyang bsgom par bya'o/ /
Attend carefully to these verses from the Sūtra of Golden Light, sources of lovingkindness and compassion, and then meditate on them by, at least, reciting them:[12]
gser 'od dam pa'i rnga chen sgra yis ni/ / stong gsum 'jig rten 'jig rten gsum 'di na/ / ngan song sdug bsngal gshin rje'i sdug bsngal dang / / dbul ba'i sdug bsngal sdug bsngal zhi bar shog /

May this supreme drum of Golden Light Pacify all forms of suffering in the three-thousand-fold world-system: The sufferings of the hells, the suffering of the world of Yama, And the sufferings of poverty here in these three worlds.
rnga bo che yi sgra skad 'di yis ni/ / 'jig rten phongs pa thams cad zhi gyur cig / ji ltar thub dbang 'jigs med 'jigs zhi ltar/ / sems can 'jigs med 'jigs dang bral bar shog /

May that drum’s resonant sound Pacify all the misfortunes in the world. May sentient beings indeed be fearless and unharmed, Just like the greatest of sages, those fearless ones whose fears have all been calmed.
ji ltar 'khor bar kun mkhyen thub dbang po/ / 'phags pa'i yon tan kun dang ldan pa ltar/ / skye dgu ting 'dzin byang chub yan lag gi / yon tan ldan zhing yon tan rgya mtshor gyur/ /

Just as they possess all the abilities of the Noble Ones, With oceans of complete knowing about cyclic existence, In the same way, may all creatures have oceans of abilities, And have abilities, stable attention, and all the aspects of Awakening.[lxi]
rnga bo che yi sgra skad 'di yis ni/ / sems can thams cad tshangs pa'i dbyangs ldan gyur/ / sangs rgyas byang chub dam pa mchog reg shog / chos kyi 'khor lo dge ba skor gyur cig /

By the resonant sound of that drum, may all sentient beings Have voices like the Brahmā gods. May they touch Buddhahood, the best and highest Awakening. [217] May they turn the pure wheel of the Dharma.
bskal pa bsam gyis mi khyab bzhugs par shog / 'gro la phan phyir chos ni ston gyur cig / nyon mongs 'joms 'gyur sdug bsngal sel bar shog / 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug zhi gyur cig /

May they remain for inconceivably many aeons And teach the Dharma for the benefit of the world. May they strike down emotional reactions and clear away[lxii] all forms of suffering; May they pacify attraction, aversion, and delusion.
sems can gang dag ngan song sar gnas te/ / rus pa dang ni lus gdungs rab 'bar ba/ / de dag rnga chen bsgrags pa thos gyur nas/ / sangs rgyas phyag 'tshal lo zhes tshig smra shog /
As for those sentient beings who remain in the hells, Their bones and bodies blazing, in agony, May they hear what the drum proclaims, and then May they join in, saying: “Homage to the Buddha!”
sems can kun gyi skye ba brgya dag dang / / skye ba stong phrag bye ba skye dran shog / thub pa'i dbang po rtag tu dran gyur cig / de dag gis ni rgya chen gsung thos shog /
May sentient beings remember all their past lives, During hundreds, or thousands, or tens of millions of lives. May they constantly recollect the greatest of sages; May they hear their lofty speech.
rnga bo che yi sgra skad 'di yis ni/ / sangs rgyas rnams dang rtag tu 'grogs rnyed gyur/ / sdig pa'i las rnams rnam par spong bar shog / bya ba dge ba rnams ni spyod gyur cig /
And by the resonant sound of that drum May they always get to meet with Buddhas. May they give up vile actions, And may they perform wholesome, good actions
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[lxiii]
zhing rnams kun na srog chags thams cad kyang / / 'jig rten dag na sdug bsngal kun zhi gyur/ / sems can dbang po ma tshang yan lag nyams/ / de kun da ltar dbang po tshang bar shog /

May all forms of suffering be pacified, Everywhere in the world, for all those who breathe. As for those beings whose senses are defective or who lack limbs, May they all have intact senses and be complete in body.
gang dag nad btab nyam chung lus nyams dang / / phyogs bcu dag na skyabs med gyur pa rnams/ / de kun myur du nad las thar gyur cig / nad med stobs dang dbang po rnyed par shog /
As for those who are sick and weak, with ruined bodies, Defenseless, lying down in all directions, May they all quickly be set free from their sickness And may they gain healthy, strong faculties.

gang dag rgyal po chom rkun shor bas bsdigs bsad 'os/ / sdug bsngal rnam pa sna tshogs brgya yis phongs gyur pa/ / sems can nyam thag gyur cing sdug bsngal de dag kun/ / 'jigs mchog mi bzad brgyad po de las thar gyur cig /

As for those who are threatened by rulers, thieves, and tribal peoples,[lxiv] Condemned to die, in hundreds of different dangers, faced with disaster, All those sentient beings who have met with suffering and disaster, [218] May they be freed from those hundreds of supremely terrifying dangers.[lxv]

gang dag brdegs shing bcings dang bcings pas gzir/ / phongs pa sna tshogs dag na gnas gyur cing / / nyon mongs stong phrag du mas dkrugs nas kyang / / 'jigs pa mi bzad mya ngan sna tshogs rnyed/ / de dag thams cad bcings las grol gyur cig / mnar ba dag ni brdegs las thar bar shog / gsad bya rnams kyang srog dang ldan gyur shog / phongs gyur thams cad 'jigs pa med par shog /
sems can gang dag bkres sred skom gyis gzir/ / de dag zas skom sna tshogs rnyed par shog / long bas gzugs rnams sna tshogs mthong gyur cig / 'on pas yid 'ong sgra rnams thos par shog /
As for those sentient beings who are tormented by hunger and thirst, May they receive various kinds of food and drink. May the blind see different forms, And may the deaf hear enchanting sounds.
gcer bu rnams kyis sna tshogs gos rnyed gyur/ / sems can dbul pos gter rnams rnyed par shog / nor 'bru rin chen sna tshogs mang po yis/ / sems can thams cad bde dang ldan par shog /
May the naked get various clothes, And may poor sentient beings receive a treasury of wealth. With abundant wealth and grain, and various precious substances, May all sentient beings be happy.
gang yang sdug bsngal tshor bas gnod ma gyur/ / sems can thams cad blta na sdug pa dang / / gzugs bzang mdzes shing tshul du shis par shog / rtag tu bde ba du ma sogs gyur cig /

May no one have any painful feelings, But may all sentient beings feel pleasure.[lxvii] May they be good-looking, beautiful, with lovely appearance;[lxviii] May many forms of happiness always accrue to them.

yid kyis zas skom rab 'byor bsod nams dag / bsams ma thag tu de dag grub gyur cig / rdza rnga pheg rnga pi bang sgra snyan dang / / chu mig mtshe'u dang rdzing bu lteng ka dag / gser gyi pad+ma ut+pal pad+ma can/ / zas skom gos nor mu tig nor bu dbyig / rgyan gser rin chen sna tshogs bai DUr+ya/ / de dag bsams ma thag tu grub gyur cig /

Just by wishing, may they receive Food and drink, and abundant goodness, Earthen drums, small drums, lutes, and stringed instruments, Fountains, ponds, and pools, and lotus-ponds With blue and yellow lotuses:[lix] Food and drink, clothing, pearls, and gemstones, gold, lapis lazuli, and various precious substances. May they receive these as soon as they think about them.[lxx]
de bzhin du sbyar te/
'jig rten gang na'ang sdug bsngal sgra mi 'byung / / sems can gcig kyang mi 'phrod mthong ma 'gyur/ / de dag thams cad kha dog rgya chen dang / / phan tshun du ni 'od byed gyur par shog /
May even the word ‘suffering’ not arise anywhere in the world; May not even one sentient being have a hostile appearance, But may they all be of grand appearance And mutually illuminate each other.
mi yi 'jig rten phun sum tshogs gang yod/ / de dag bsams pas skye bar de dag gyur/ / bsam pa thams cad bsams ma thag tu yang / / bsod nams 'bras bu yongs su rdzogs par shog /

Whatever there is that is perfectly complete in the human world, May that appear for them just by wishing. May all their aspirations be completely fulfilled as soon as they are formed As the results of their goodness.
spos dang phreng ba dag dang byug pa dang / / gos dang phye ma me tog sna tshogs dag / ljon shing dag las dus gsum 'bab par shog / sems can mtha' dag len cing dgar gyur cig /
May perfume, garlands and ointments, Clothing, aromatic powder, and various flowers Rain down three times a day from trees; May those sentient beings accept them and rejoice!
de bzhin gshegs pa bsam yas thams cad dang / / rdzogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' nyan thos dang / / rdul bral dri med brtan pa'i chos la yang / / phyogs bcu rnams su mchod pa byed par shog /
May they make offerings to the inconceivable Tathāgatas [219] In the ten directions, Along with the bodhisattvas and the Disciples, And to the Dharma from which Awakening arises.[lxxi]
'gro ba dman pa thams cad spong gyur cig / mi khom brgyad po dag las 'das par shog / dal ba'i rgyal po dam pa thob gyur cig / rtag tu sangs rgyas 'grogs pa thob par shog /

May sentient beings avoid all bad rebirths And go beyond the eight states with no opportunity to practice; May they meet with the supreme royal Victors:[lxxii] May they always get to meet with Buddhas.[lxxiii]
de bzhin du sbyar te/
rtag tu mthon po'i gnas su skye bar shog / nor dang 'bru yi mdzod rnams 'byor gyur cig / snyan dang grags dang gzugs dang kha dog gis/ / bskal pa du mar legs par brgyan par shog /
May they always be high-born, With treasuries of wealth and grain; For many aeons, may they be well ornamented With sound and voice, with color and physical beauty.
bud med thams cad rtag tu por gyur te/ / dpa' zhing rtul phod mkhas shing gsal bar shog / de kun rtag tu byang chub phyir spyod gyur/ / pha rol phyin pa drug la spyod par shog /
May all women always become men, Heroic and brave, learned and clear-minded. May they all practice for the sake of Awakening; May they always practice the six perfections.

phyogs bcu dag na rin chen shing dbang drung / / sangs rgyas bder bzhugs rin chen bai DUr+ya'i/ / khri la bzhugs pa dag ni mthong gyur cig / chos bstan pa yang bdag gis de thob shog / ces bya ba'o// //
May they see the Buddhas in the ten directions seated in bliss, In the best jeweled trees, On precious lapis lazuli thrones, And may they hear teachings that make things clear to them.[lxxiv]
bam po bcu pa/
This, in brief, is lovingkindness, The remedy for acts of aversion.[lxxv]
gti mug gi phra rgyas kyi gnyen po ni rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba la blta ba'o/ /
The remedy for the underlying pattern of delusion [220] Is the view of dependent arising.

de la rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba ni/ / sA lu ljang pa'i mdo las bstan pa ste/ de la nang gi rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba rgyu dang 'brel pa gang zhe na/ gang 'di ma rig pa'i rkyen gyis 'du byed rnams zhes bya ba nas skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi zhes bya ba'i bar du'o/ / gal te ma rig pa ma byung na 'di snyam du bdag gis 'du byed kyang ma mthong zhing / de bzhin du skye ba ma byung du zin na rga shi'i bar du yang mi mthong ba zhig na/ 'on kyang ma rig pa yod pa las 'du byed rnams mngon par 'grub par 'gyur ba nas skye ba yod pa las rga shi'i bar du mngon par 'grub par 'gyur ro/ / de la ma rig pa yang 'di snyam du bdag gis 'du byed rnams mngon par bsgrub po snyam du mi sems so/ / 'du byed rnams kyang 'di snyam du bdag cag ni ma rig pas mngon par bsgrub po snyam du mi sems pa nas/ de bzhin du skye ba yang 'di snyam du bdag gis rga shi mngon par bsgrub po snyam du mi sems shing / rga shi yang 'di snyam du bdag ni skye bas mngon par bsgrub po snyam du mi sems pa'i bar du ste/ 'on kyang ma rig pa yod pa las 'du byed rnams mngon par 'grub cing / 'byung bar 'gyur ba nas/ de bzhin du skye ba yod pa las rga shi'i bar du mngon par 'grub cing 'byung bar 'gyur te/ de ltar na nang gi rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba'i rgyu dang 'brel par blta'o/ /

On this topic, dependent arising is explained in the Rice Sheaf Sūtra (Śāli-stambha-sūtra):[13] Here, what is the causal relation in internal dependent arising? It is: With ignorance as condition, conditioning; and so on up to: with birth as condition, old age and death. If there were no ignorance, conditioning would not be seen; and in the same way, up to: If there were no birth, old age and death would not be seen. But when there is ignorance, conditioning comes into existence; and in the same way, up to: When there is birth, old age and death come into existence. Here ignorance does not think: “I will bring conditioning into existence.” And conditioning also doesn’t think: “I was brought into existence by ignorance.” And in the same way, up to: Birth doesn’t think: “I will bring old age and death into existence.” And old age and death do not think, “We were brought into existence by birth.” Nevertheless, when there is ignorance, conditioning comes into existence and manifests; and in the same way, up to: When there is birth, old age and death come into existence and manifest. This is how you should understand the causal relation in internal dependent arising.

nang gi rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba rkyen dang 'brel ba ji ltar lta zhe na khams drug 'dus pa'i phyir te/ khams drug po gang dag 'dus pa'i phyir zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ sa dang chu dang me dang rlung dang nam mkha' dang rnam par shes pa'i khams 'dus pa las nang gi rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba rkyen dang 'brel par blta'o/ / de la nang gi rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba'i sa'i khams gang zhe na/ gang 'di 'dus nas lus kyi sra ba'i dngos po mngon par 'grub par byed pa 'di ni sa'i khams zhes bya'o/ / gang lus sdud pa'i bya ba byed pa 'di ni chu'i khams zhes bya'o/ / gang lus kyi zos pa dang 'thungs pa dang 'chos pa dang myangs pa rnams 'ju bar byed pa 'di ni me'i khams zhes bya'o/ / gang lus kyi dbugs phyi nang du rgyu ba'i bya ba byed pa de ni rlung gi khams zhes bya'o/ / gang lus kyi nang sbubs yod par byed pa 'di ni nam mkha'i khams zhes bya'o/ / gang mdung khyim gyi tshul du lus kyi ming dang gzugs kyi myu gu mngon par 'grub par byed pa rnam par shes pa lnga'i tshogs su gtogs pa dang zag pa dang bcas pa'i yid kyi rnam par shes pa 'di ni rnam par shes pa'i khams zhes bya'o/ / rkyen 'di dag med par lus skye bar mi 'gyur gyi nam nang gi sa'i khams tshang zhing de bzhin du chu dang me dang rlung dang nam mkha' dang rnam par shes pa'i khams rnams kyang tshang bar gyur la/ thams cad 'dus pa de las lus mngon par 'grub par 'gyur ro/ /

How should the relation of conditions in internal dependent arising be understood? Through the coming together of six elements. What are the six elements that come together? The relation of conditions in internal dependent arising should be understood through the coming together of the earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements. [221] Here, in internal dependent arising, what is the earth element? That which, by adhering together, brings about the solidity of the body is called “the earth element.” That which performs the function of cohesion in the body is called “the water element.” That which digests what the body eats, drinks, and consumes[lxxvi] is called “the fire element.” That which performs the function of breathing in and breathing out in the body is called “the wind element.” That which makes the body porous is called “the space element.” That which brings name and form into existence like a bundle of reeds,[14] and is connected with the five forms of [sensory] consciousness and mental consciousness that has outflows, is called “the consciousness element.” In the absence of these conditions, the body does not arise. When the internal earth-element is complete, and in the same way, the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements are also complete, then through the coming together of them all, the body arises.

de la sa'i khams kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis lus kyi sra ba'i dngos po mngon par bsgrub po snyam du mi sems so/ / chu'i khams kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis lus sdud pa'i bya ba 'di bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / me'i khams kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis lus kyis zos pa dang 'thungs pa dang 'chos pa dang myangs pa rnams 'ju bar bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / rlung gi khams kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis lus kyi dbugs phyi nang du rgyu ba'i bya ba bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / nam mkha'i khams kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis lus kyi nang skabs yod par bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / rnam par shes pa'i khams kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis lus kyi ming dang gzugs mngon par bsgrub po snyam du mi sems so/ / lus kyang 'di snyam du bdag ni rkyen 'di dag gis bskyed do snyam du mi sems mod kyi/ 'on kyang rkyen 'di dag yod na lus skye bar 'gyur ro/ / de la sa'i khams ni bdag ma yin/ sems can ma yin/ srog ma yin/ skye ba po ma yin/ shed las skyes pa ma yin/ shed bu ma yin/ bud med ma yin/ skyes pa ma yin/ ma ning ma yin/ nga ma yin/ bdag gi ma yin/ gzhan su'i yang ma yin no/ / de bzhin du sa'i khams dang / chu'i khams dang / me'i khams dang / rlung gi khams dang / nam mkha'i khams dang / rnam par shes pa'i khams kyang bdag ma yin/ sems can ma yin/ srog ma yin/ skye ba po ma yin/ shed las skyes pa ma yin/ shed bu ma yin/ bud med ma yin/ skyes pa ma yin/ ma ning ma yin/ nga ma yin/ bdag gi ma yin/ gzhan su'i yang ma yin no/ /

Here the earth element does not think, “I bring about the solidity of the body.” The water element does not think, “I perform the function of cohesion in the body.” The fire element does not think, “I digest what the body eats, drinks, and consumes.” The wind element does not think, “I perform the function of breathing in and breathing out in the body.” The space element does not think, “I make the body porous.” {The consciousness element does not think, “I bring the name and form of the body into existence.” The body does not think, “I am produced by these conditions.” [lxxvii]}[15] Nevertheless, when these conditions are present, the body arises. Here the earth element is not a self, not a sentient being, not a life-force, not a living being, not a human, not a human being, not a woman, not a man, not an intersex person; it is not I, not mine, and not anyone else’s at all. The water element, the fire element, the wind element, the space element, and the consciousness element are the same way: each is[lxxviii] not a sentient being, not a life-force, not a living being, not a human, not a human being, not a woman, not a man, not an intersex person; it is not I, not mine, and not anyone else’s at all.

de la ma rig pa gang zhe na/ khams drug po 'di dag nyid la gang gcig pur 'du shes pa dang / ril por 'du shes pa dang / rtag par 'du shes pa dang / brtan par 'du shes pa dang / ther zug tu 'du shes pa dang / bde bar 'du shes pa dang / bdag tu 'du shes pa dang / sems can dang / srog dang / skye ba po dang / gso ba dang / skyes bu dang / gang zag tu 'du shes pa dang shed las skyes pa dang / shed bur 'du shes pa dang / nga zhes bya ba dang bdag gi zhes bya bar 'du shes pa ste/ 'di lta bu la sogs pa mi shes pa rnam pa sna tshogs pa 'di ni ma rig pa zhes bya'o/ /

[222] Here, what is ignorance? It is conceiving of these six elements as one thing; conceiving of them as a whole; conceiving of them as stable; conceiving of them as eternal; conceiving of them as happy; conceiving of them as a self; conceiving of them as a sentient being, as a life-force,[lxxix] as a human, and as a human being; conceiving of them as “I” and as “mine.” These and other various forms of not knowing are called “ignorance.”

de ltar ma rig pa yod pas yul rnams la 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug 'jug ste/ de la yul rnams la 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug gang yin pa 'di ni ma rig pa'i rkyen gyis 'du byed rnams zhes bya'o/ /
[223] When this kind of ignorance is present, attraction, aversion, and delusion operate towards objects. Attraction, aversion, and delusion towards objects: these are called “conditioning.”[lxxx]
dngos po so sor rnam par rig pa ni rnam par shes pa'o/ /
Specifically recognizing things is consciousness.
rnam par shes pa dang lhan cig byung ba nye bar len pa'i phung po bzhi po 'di dag ni ming dang gzugs so/ /

The four nonmaterial appropriated aggregates that are born together with consciousness are called “name.”[lxxxi] “Form” refers to the four great elements. Taken together as one, this is “name and form.”[lxxxii]
ming dang gzugs la brten pa'i dbang po rnams ni skye mched drug go/ /
The sense-faculties based on name and form are the six sense-spheres.
chos gsum 'dus pa ni reg pa'o/ /
Contact is the coming together of three entities.
reg pa myong ba ni tshor ba'o/ /
The experience of contact is feeling-tones.
tshor ba la zhen pa ni sred pa'o/ /
Clinging to feeling-tones is craving.
sred pa 'phel ba ni len pa'o/ /
When craving becomes extensive, it is grasping.
len pa las skye ba yang srid pa skye ba'i las ni srid pa'o/ /
Action born from craving that generates rebirths is becoming.
rgyu de las phung po 'byung ba ni skye ba'o/ /
The arising of the aggregates caused by that is birth.
skyes nas phung po smin pa ni rga ba'o/ /
The maturation of the aggregates {after birth} is old age.
rgas nas phung po 'jig pa ni 'chi ba'o/ /
The destruction of the aggregates {due to old age} is death.
'chi ba na rmongs pa mngon par chags pa dang bcas pa'i nang gi yongs su gdung ba ni mya ngan to/ /
The internal agony of someone dying who is attached and deluded is sorrow.
mya ngan las byung ba'i tshig tu smre ba ni smre sngags 'don pa'o/ /
Crying out {due to sorrow} is lamentation.
rnam par shes pa lnga'i tshogs dang ldan pa'i mi bde ba myong ba ni sdug bsngal lo/ /
Bad feelings involving the five senses is pain.
yid la byed pa dang ldan pa yid kyi sdug bsngal ni yid mi bde ba'o/ /
Mental pain that involves the application of attention is suffering.
gzhan yang 'di lta bu la sogs pa nye ba'i nyon mongs pa gang yin pa de dag ni 'khrug pa zhes bya'o/ /
Secondary reactive emotions that are dependent in the same way are mental disturbances
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[lxxxiii]

de la mun pa chen po'i phyir ma rig pa'o/ / mngon par 'du byed pa'i phyir 'du byed rnams so/ / rnam par rig pa'i phyir rnam par shes pa'o/ / rten pa'i phyir ming dang gzugs so/ / skye ba'i sgo'i phyir skye mched drug go/ / reg pa'i phyir reg pa'o/ / myong ba'i phyir tshor ba'o/ / skom pa'i phyir sred pa'o/ / nye bar len pa'i phyir len pa'o/ / yang srid pa skyed pa'i phyir srid pa'o/ / phung po 'byung ba'i phyir skye ba'o/ / phung po smin pa'i phyir rga ba'o/ / 'jig pa'i phyir 'chi ba'o/ / mya ngan byed pa'i phyir mya ngan to/ / tshig gis smre ba'i phyir smre sngags 'don pa'o/ / lus la gnod pa'i phyir sdug bsngal lo/ / sems la gnod pa'i phyir yid mi bde ba'o/ / nyon mongs pa'i phyir 'khrug pa'o/ /

(It is called) ignorance in the sense of making a great blindness, (mental) formations in the sense of formation, consciousness in the sense of causing to know, name-and-form in the sense of mutual support, six (sense) entrances in the sense of entrance doors, (sensual) contact in the sense of contacting, feelings in the sense of experiencing, desire in the sense of thirsting, grasping in the sense of grasping, becoming in the sense of giving birth to repeated becoming, birth in the sense of manifestation of the aggregates, decay in the sense of maturing of the aggregates, death in the sense of perishing, grief in the sense of grieving, lamentation in the sense of verbal lamentation, suffering in the sense of bodily torment, depression in the sense of mental torment, anxiety in the sense of subtle defilement.

gzhan yang de kho na mi rtogs shing log par rtogs pa'i mi shes pa ni ma rig pa'o/ / de ltar ma rig pa yod pa na 'du byed rnam pa gsum mngon par 'grub ste/ bsod nams su nye bar 'gro ba dang / bsod nams ma yin par nye bar 'gro ba dang / mi g.yo bar nye bar 'gro ba ste 'di ni ma rig pa'i rkyen gyis 'du byed rnams zhes bya'o/ / bsod nams su nye bar 'gro ba'i 'du byed rnams las bsod nams su nye bar 'gro ba'i rnam par shes pa nyid du 'gyur/ / bsod nams ma yin par nye bar 'gro ba'i 'du byed rnams la bsod nams ma yin par nye bar 'gro ba'i rnam par shes pa nyid du 'gyur/ mi g.yo bar nye bar 'gro ba'i 'du byed rnams las mi g.yo bar nye bar 'gro ba'i rnam par shes pa nyid du 'gyur te 'di ni 'du byed kyi rkyen gyis rnam par shes pa zhes bya'o/ / ming dang gzugs kyang de bzhin no/ / ming dang gzugs rnam par 'phel ba skye mched drug gi sgo nas bya ba byed pa rnams 'byung ste/ de ni ming dang gzugs kyi rkyen gyis skye mched drug ces bya'o/ / skye mched drug po dag las reg pa'i tshogs drug 'byung ste/ de ni skye mched drug gi rkyen gyis reg pa zhes bya'o/ / ji lta bur reg pa 'byung ba de lta bur tshor ba 'byung ste/ de ni reg pa'i rkyen gyis tshor ba zhes bya'o/ / tshor ba'i bye brag de dag myong ba dang / mngon par dga' ba dang lhag par zhen pa dang / lhag par zhen nas 'dug pa de ni tshor ba'i rkyen gyis sred pa zhes bya'o/ / myong ba dang mngon par dga' ba dang lhag par zhen pa dang lhag par zhen nas 'dug pa las bdag sdug pa'i ngo bo dang bde ba'i ngo bo dang 'bral bar ma gyur cig snyam du mi gtong ba dang phyir zhing don du gnyer ba 'di ni srid pa'i rkyen gyis len pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar don du gnyer ba nas yang srid pa skyed pa'i las lus dang ngag dang yid kyis kun nas slong ba de ni len pa'i rkyen gyis srid pa zhes bya'o/ / las de las skyes pa'i phung po rnams grub pa gang yin pa de ni srid pa'i rkyen gyis skye ba zhes bya'o/ / skyes nas mngon du grub pa'i phung po rnams kyi 'phel ba dang yongs su smin pa las 'jig par 'gyur ba de ni skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi zhes bya'o/ /

[224] Moreover, not knowing, not perceiving the way things are, but perceiving incorrectly, is ignorance. When there is this kind of ignorance, the three types of conditioning are brought into existence: directed towards goodness, directed towards vile actions, directed towards the imperturbable.[16] These are called “conditioning having ignorance as a condition.” From conditioning directed towards goodness comes only consciousness directed towards goodness. From conditioning directed towards vile actions comes only consciousness directed towards vile actions. From conditioning directed towards the imperturbable comes only consciousness directed towards the imperturbable. This is called “consciousness having conditioning as a condition.” The same applies to name and form. Through the growth of name and form, functioning occurs by means of the six sense-spheres. These are called “the six sense-spheres having name and form as a condition.” From the sense-spheres, six types of contact occur. These are called, “contact having the six sense-spheres as a condition.” Whatever type of contact arises, the same type of feeling-tones occur. These are called “feeling-tones having contact as a condition.” When someone who feels these savors them especially, exults in them, gets attached to them, and seizes hold of them, this is called “craving having feeling as a condition.” Savoring them, exulting in them, and being attached to them leads to the thought, “May I not be separated from the forms that I like, from pleasant forms.” The person does not let go and tries harder and harder to get them. This is called “grasping having craving as a condition.” Trying to get them in this way leads to actions of body, speech, and mind that give rise to rebirth. These are called “becoming having grasping as a condition.” Generated by those actions, aggregates come into existence. This is called “birth having becoming as a condition.” The aggregates brought into existence at birth grow and mature, and then are destroyed. This is called “old age and death having birth as a condition”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ltar rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i yan lag bcu gnyis po 'di dag ni gcig gi rgyu gcig gcig gi rkyen gcig / rtag pa ma yin mi rtag pa yang ma yin/ 'dus byas ma yin 'dus ma byas ma yin/ rgyu med pa ma yin rkyen med pa ma yin/ myong ba yod pa ma yin/ zad pa'i chos ma yin/ 'jig pa'i chos ma yin/ 'gog pa'i chos ma yin te/ thog ma med pa'i dus nas zhugs pa rgyun ma chad par rlung gi rgyun bzhin du rjes su zhugs mod kyi/ 'on kyang yan lag bzhi po 'di dag ni rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba'i yan lag bcu gnyis po de bsdu bar bya ba'i rgyur 'gyur ro/ /

In this way, this twelvefold dependent arising, {successive causality,} successive conditionality, is not permanent, not impermanent, not compounded, not uncompounded,[lxxxiv] not sentient, not subject to destruction, not subject to cessation, not subject to being stopped. It has been unfolding from beginningless time, and proceeds uninterruptedly like the flow of a river.[lxxxv] [225] In this twelvefold dependent arising, four aspects operate causally to bring things together.

bzhi gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ ma rig pa dang sred pa dang las dang rnam par shes pa'o/ / de la rnam par shes pa ni sa bon gyi rang bzhin gyis rgyu byed do/ / las ni zhing gi rang bzhin gyis rgyu byed do/ / ma rig pa dang sred pa ni nyon mongs pa'i rang bzhin gyis rgyu byed do/ / de la las dang nyon mongs pa dag ni sa bon rnam par shes pa bskyed do/ / de la las ni sa bon rnam par shes pa'i zhing gi bya ba byed do/ / srid pa ni sa bon rnam par shes pa brlan par byed do/ / ma rig pa ni sa bon rnam par shes pa 'debs te rkyen de dag med na sa bon rnam par shes pa mngon par 'grub par mi 'gyur ro/ / de la las kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis sa bon rnam par shes pa'i zhing gi bya ba bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / sred pa yang 'di snyam du bdag gis sa bon rnam par shes pa brlan par bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / ma rig pa yang 'di snyam du bdag gis sa bon rnam par shes pa gdab po snyam du mi sems so/ / sa bon rnam par shes pa yang 'di snyam du bdag ni rkyen 'di dag gis bskyed do snyam du mi sems te 'on kyang sa bon rnam par shes pa las kyi zhing la brten pa sred pa'i rlan gyis brlan pa ma rig pas btab pa skye ba na/ skye ba'i gnas nying mtshams sbyor ba ma'i mngal de dang der ming dang gzugs kyi myu gu mngon par 'grub ste/ ming dang gzugs kyi myu gu de yang bdag gis ma byas gzhan gyis ma byas gnyi gas ma byas/ dbang phyug gis ma byas dus kyis ma bsgyur rang bzhin las ma byung byed pa la rag las pa ma yin rgyu med pa las kyang ma skyes te/ 'on kyang pha dang ma phrad pa dang dus dang ldan pa dang rkyen gzhan tshogs na bdag po med pa'i chos bdag gi med pa 'dzin pa med pa nam mkha' dang mtshungs pa/ sgyu ma'i mtshan nyid kyi rang bzhin dag la rgyu dang rkyen ma tshang ba med pa'i phyir skye gnas su nying mtshams sbyor ba ma'i mngal de dang der myong ba dang ldan pa'i sa bon rnam par shes pa ming dang gzugs kyi myu gu mngon par sgrub po/ /

Which four? They are ignorance, craving, action, and consciousness. Of these, consciousness is a cause because it has the nature of a seed. Action is a cause because it has the nature of a field. Ignorance and craving are causes because they are by nature reactive. Actions and reactive emotions generate the seed of consciousness. Action functions as a field for the seed of consciousness. Craving moistens the seed of consciousness. Ignorance sows the seed of consciousness. In the absence of these conditions, the seed does not come into existence. Here action does not think, “I function as a field for the seed of consciousness.”[lxxxvi] Craving does not think, “I moisten the seed of consciousness.” Ignorance also does not think, “I sow the seed of consciousness.” And the seed of consciousness does not think, “I am produced by these conditions.” Nevertheless, wherever ignorance sows the seed of consciousness in the field of action, the moisture of craving flows forth, and a collection of sense-spheres arises, it grows in the mother’s womb, and the sprout of name and form comes into existence. And that sprout of name and form is not made by itself, not made by another, not made by both, not created by God or anyone else, not transformed over a period of time, not produced by any single cause, and not arisen without a cause. Nevertheless, when the mother and father come together, when the other conditions come together, when the menstrual blood unites with the seed of consciousness cast off during enjoyment,[lxxxvii] the seed that will become the sprout of name and form comes into existence in the mother’s womb. It comes into existence in relation to entities with no owner, with no “mine,” with no possessiveness, with no enemy, similar to space, illusory by nature, because the causes and conditions are complete.

'di lta ste/ mig gi rnam par shes pa ni rgyu lnga las 'byung ste/ lnga gang zhe na/ mig la brten pa dang gzugs dang snang ba dang nam mkha' dang de bskyed pa'i yid la byed pa brten nas mig gi rnam par shes pa 'byung ngo / / de la mig ni mig gi rnam par shes pa'i rten gyi bya ba byed do/ / gzugs ni mig gi rnam par shes pa dmigs pa'i bya ba byed do/ / snang ba ni mngon pa'i bya ba byed do/ / nam mkha' ni mi sgrib pa'i bya ba byed do/ / de bskyed pa'i yid la byed pa ni sems pa'i bya ba byed do/ / rkyen de dag med na mig gi rnam par shes pa 'byung bar mi 'gyur gyi/ nam nang gi skye mched mig ma tshang bar ma gyur la/ de bzhin du gzugs dang snang ba dang / nam mkha' dang de skyed pa'i yid la byed pa dag kyang ma tshang bar ma gyur te/ thams cad 'dus pa de las mig gi rnam par shes pa 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

For example, it’s like visual consciousness, which arises from five causes. What are the five? With the eye, and form, and light, and space, and the attention generated from these as conditions, visual consciousness arises. In this case, the eye functions as the basis for visual consciousness. Form functions as the object. Light performs the function of illumination. Space performs the function of nonobstruction. The attention generated from these performs the function of being aware. When these conditions are absent, visual consciousness does not arise. When the internal sense of sight is complete, and in the same way, form, light, space, and the attention generated from these are complete, then, by the coming together of all of them, visual consciousness arises.

de la mig ni 'di snyam du bdag gis mig gi rnam par shes pa'i rten gyi bya ba bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / gzugs kyang 'di snyam du bdag gis mig gi rnam par shes pa'i dmigs pa'i bya ba bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / snang ba yang 'di snyam du bdag gis mig gi rnam par shes pa'i mngon pa'i bya ba bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / nam mkha' yang 'di snyam du bdag gis mig gi rnam par shes pa'i mi sgrib pa'i bya ba bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / de bskyed pa'i yid la byed pa yang 'di snyam du bdag gis mig gi rnam par shes pa'i sems pa'i bya ba bya'o snyam du mi sems so/ / mig gi rnam par shes pa yang 'di snyam du bdag ni rkyen 'di dag gis bskyed do snyam du mi sems te 'on kyang rkyen 'di dag yod pa las mig gi rnam par shes pa skye bar 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du dbang po lhag ma rnams la yang ci rigs su bya'o/ /

In this case, the eye does not think, “I function as the basis for visual consciousness.” Form also does not think, “I function as the object of visual consciousness.” Light also does not think, “I perform the function of illumination.” Space also does not think, “I perform the function of nonobstruction for visual consciousness.” The attention generated from these also does not think, “I perform the function of being aware of visual consciousness.” And visual consciousness does not think, “I am produced by these conditions.” Nevertheless, when these conditions are present, visual consciousness manifestly arises. The rest of the senses should be understood in the same way, as appropriate.
de la chos gang yang 'jig rten 'di nas 'jig rten pha rol tu mi 'pho mod kyi/ rgyu dang rkyen ma tshang ba med pa'i phyir las kyi 'bras bur mngon par yang yod do/ /
[226] Here nothing whatsoever transmigrates from this world to the next world. However, when the causes and conditions are complete, the results of action are recognized.
de bzhin du sbyar te/

'di lta ste dper na rab tu phyis pa'i me long gi dkyil 'khor la bzhin gyi gzugs brnyan snang ba yang bzhin me long gi dkyil 'khor du ma 'phos mod kyi/ rgyu dang rkyen ma tshang ba med pa'i phyir bzhin du mngon pa yang yod do/ /

de bzhin du 'di nas kyang su yang shi 'phos pa med la gzhan du yang ma skyes te/ rgyu dang rkyen rnams ma tshang ba med pa'i phyir las kyi 'bras bur mngon pa yang yod do/ / 'di lta ste dper na/ zla ba'i dkyil 'khor ni dpag tshad bzhi khri nyis stong nas 'gro ste/ 'on kyang snod chung ngu chus gang bar zla ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi gzugs brnyan snang ba yang zla ba'i dkyil 'khor ni gnas de nas ma 'phos te/ snod chung ngu chus gang ba'i nang du song ba yang med mod kyi rgyu dang rkyen ma tshang ba med pa'i phyir zla ba'i dkyil 'khor du snang ba yang yod do/ /

{Nothing whatsoever dies here and is born elsewhere, but when the causes and conditions are complete, the results of action are recognized. For example, it’s like this: The disk of the moon is forty-two thousand leagues away. Nevertheless, a reflection of the disk of the moon can appear in a small container full of water. Even though the disk of the moon does not move from its place, and it doesn’t enter the small container full of water, because the causes and conditions are complete, there is an image of the disk of the moon.

de bzhin du 'di nas kyang su yang shi 'phos pa med la/ gzhan du yang ma skyes mod kyi rgyu dang rkyen rnams ma tshang ba med pa'i phyir las kyi 'bras bur mngon pa yang yod do/ / 'di lta ste dper na/ me ni rgyu dang rkyen ma tshang na mi 'bar gyi rgyu dang rkyen tshogs pa las 'bar ro/ /

In the same way, nothing whatsoever dies here and is born elsewhere, but when the causes and conditions are complete, the results of action are recognized.} For example, it’s like this: when the fuel is incomplete,[lxxxviii] fire does not burn, {but when the causes and conditions come together, it does burn.}

de bzhin du bdag po med pa'i chos bdag gi med pa 'dzin pa med pa nam mkha' dang mtshungs pa sgyu ma'i mtshan nyid kyi rang bzhin dag la rgyu dang rkyen rnams ma tshang ba med pa'i phyir skye ba'i gnas nying mtshams sbyor ba ma'i mngal de dang der sa bon rnam par shes pa las dang nyon mongs pa rnams kyis bskyed pa ming dang gzugs kyi myu gu mngon par sgrub po/ /

It’s the same way with the seed of consciousness that is produced by action and reactive emotions: wherever a collection of sense-spheres arises in the mother’s womb, the sprout of name and form comes into existence in relation to entities with no owner, with no “mine,” with no possessiveness, with no enemy, similar to space, illusory by nature, because the causes and conditions are complete.

de la nang gi rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba rnam pa lnga ste/ lnga gang zhe na/ rtag par ma yin pa dang / chad par ma yin pa dang / 'pho bar ma yin pa dang / rgyu chung ngu las 'bras bu chen por 'byung ba dang / de dang 'dra ba'i rgyud du'o/ /

Here internal dependent arising should be understood as having five aspects. What are the five? They are: not through eternity; not through annihilation; not through transmigration; from small causes, large results are brought into existence; and the continuation of what is similar.

ji ltar rtag par ma yin no zhe na/ gang gi phyir tha ma 'chi ba'i phung po rnams kyang gzhan la skye ba'i char gtogs pa rnams kyang gzhan te/ tha ma 'chi ba'i phung po gang yin pa de nyid skye ba'i char gtogs pa rnams ma yin gyi/ tha ma 'chi ba'i phung po rnams kyang 'gags la skye ba'i char gtogs pa'i phung po rnams kyang 'byung bas de'i phyir rtag par ma yin no/ /

How is it not through eternity? Because the aggregates at the time of death are different from the ones that occur at birth. The aggregates at the time of death are not the same as those that occur at birth, but rather, when the aggregates at the time of death cease, the aggregates that occur at birth become manifest. Therefore, it is not through eternity.

ji ltar chad par ma yin zhe na/ tha ma 'chi ba'i phung po rnams 'gags pa las skye ba'i char gtogs pa'i phung po rnams 'byung ba ma yin 'gags pa las kyang ma yin gyi tha ma 'chi ba'i phung po rnams kyang 'gags la de nyid kyi tshe skye ba'i char gtogs pa'i phung po rnams srang mda'i mthon dman bzhin du 'byung bar 'gyur te de'i phyir chad par ma yin no/ /

How is it not through annihilation? It is not the case that the aggregates that occur at birth become manifest after the aggregates at the time of death have ceased; nor do they become manifest before those have ceased. Rather, while the aggregates at the time of death are ceasing, the aggregates that occur at birth are becoming manifest, like the arms of a balance rising and falling. Therefore, it is not through annihilation.
ji ltar 'pho bar ma yin zhe na/ sems can gyi ris mi 'dra ba nas skal ba mnyam pa'i skye bar skye ba mngon par 'grub pas de'i phyir 'pho bar ma yin no/ /
{How is it not through transmigration?} From dissimilar classes of sentient beings, different aggregates come into existence in another life.[lxxxix] Therefore, it is not through transmigration.
ji ltar rgyu chung ngu las 'bras bu chen po 'byung zhe na/ las chung ngu byas pa las 'bras bu chen po'i rnam par smin pa myong ste de'i phyir rgyu chung ngu las 'bras bu chen po mngon par 'grub po/ /

[227] How is it that, from small causes, large results are brought into existence? When a small action is done, a large result of evolution is experienced. Hence, from small causes, large results are brought into existence.
ji ltar myong bar 'gyur ba'i las byas pa de lta bur myong bar 'gyur ba'i rnam par smin pa myong bas de'i phyir de dang 'dra ba'i rgyud du'o/ /
The way in which the action you do is experienced is the way in which the result of evolution is experienced. Therefore, it is the continuation of what is similar.

btsun pa shA ri'i bu rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba bcom ldan 'das kyis yang dag par gsungs pa 'di gang la la zhig gis yang dag pa'i shes rab kyis 'di ltar yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rtag par rgyun du srog med pa dang srog dang bral ba dang / ji lta ba nyid dang / ma nor ba dang / ma skyes pa dang / ma byung ba dang / ma byas pa dang / 'dus ma byas pa dang / thogs pa med pa dang / dmigs pa med pa dang / zhi ba dang / 'jigs pa med pa dang / mi 'phrogs pa dang / mi zad pa dang / rnam par ma zhi ba'i rang bzhin du mthong ba dang / med pa dang / gsog dang / gsob dang / snying po med pa dang / nad dang / 'bras dang / zug rngu dang / sdig pa dang / mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / stong pa dang bdag med par yang dag par rjes su mthong ba de ni/ ci bdag sngon gyi dus na byung ba zhig gam 'on te ma byung ba zhig snyam du sngon gyi mtha' la mi rtog go/ / ma 'ongs pa'i dus na cir 'gyur ci lta bur 'gyur zhes ma 'ongs pa'i mtha' la mi rtog go/ / 'di ci zhig 'di ci lta bu zhig ci zhig yod cir 'gyur sems can 'di dag gang nas 'ongs 'di nas shi 'phos nas gang du 'gro bar 'gyur zhes da ltar byung ba la yang mi rtog go zhes bya ba'o/ /

Reverend Śāriputra, anyone who sees dependent arising as it was accurately proclaimed by the Blessed One, as it actually is, with correct wisdom, in this way: always continuing, with no life-force, free from life-force; and sees it as it is: not mistaken, not born, not become, not made, not compounded, not obstructed, with no referent, peaceful, free from fear, greatly beneficial, indestructible, not stopping, with no essence; and who reflects on its deceptiveness, insubstantiality, voidness, lack of essence, misery, impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self—that person does not wonder about the past, thinking “Did I exist in the past, or perhaps, did I not exist? Who was I in the past?”[xc] And that person does not wonder about the future, thinking “Will I exist in the future? Or perhaps, will I not exist in the future? Who will I be?” And that person does not wonder about the present, thinking “What is this? How is this? Where did these sentient beings come from, and when they die, where will they go?”[xci]

'phags pa sa bcu'i mdo las kyang gsungs te/ de la ma rig pa dang sred pa dang len pa ni nyon mongs pa'i lam gyi rgyun mi 'chad pa'o/ / 'du byed dang srid pa ni las kyi lam gyi rgyun mi 'chad pa'o/ / lhag ma rnams ni sdug bsngal gyi lam gyi rgyun mi 'chad par rab tu rnam par phye'o/ /
