The noble Sūtra on the Ten Stages also says,[17] [228] Here ignorance, craving and attachment are the continuity of the path of reactivity. Conditioning and becoming are the continuity of the path of karma. The rest are the continuity of the path of suffering.
de bzhin du sbyar te/

ma rig pa'i rkyen gyis 'du byed rnams zhes bya ba gang yin pa de ni sngon gyi mtha' la ltos pa'o/ / rnam par shes pa nas tshor ba'i bar de ni da ltar byung ba la ltos pa'o/ / sred pa nas srid pa zhes bya ba'i bar de ni phyi ma'i mtha' la ltos pa ste/ de phan chad yang de dag rab tu 'byung ngo / /

Now, when it is said, “With ignorance as condition, conditioning,” this refers to a previous life. From consciousness up to feeling refers to the present life. From craving up to becoming refers to a future life. What follows is the unfolding of that
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de 'di snyam du sems te/ ldan pa las ni 'dus byas 'byung ngo / / bral ba las ni 'dus byas mi 'byung ngo / / tshogs pa las ni 'dus byas 'byung ngo / / ma tshogs pa las ni 'dus byas mi 'byung ngo / / ma la de ltar bdag gis 'dus byas nyes pa mang po'i skyon chags pa 'di lta bu 'di shes par byas la/ 'du ba 'di dang tshogs pa 'di'i rgyun gcad par yang bya'o/ / sems can yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir 'du byed rnams shin tu zhi bar bya ba thob par yang mi bya'o snyam mo zhes gsungs ste/ / 'di ni gti mug sbyang ba mdor bsdus pa'o/ /

Such a person thinks, “From attachment, the conditioned unfolds; from detachment, it does not unfold. From accumulation, the conditioned unfolds; from not accumulating, it does not unfold. Well! Since we know that the conditioned has so many problems, we will cut off attachment and accumulation. But we will not completely pacify everything conditioned, so as to help sentient beings to mature.” In brief, this is clearing away delusion.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las/ sems yongs su sbyang ba'i le'u ste bcu gnyis pa'o// //

f.d: [dran pa nye bar gzhag pa]
13. The Applications of Mindfulness

de ltar sems las su rung nas dran pa nye bar gzhag pa la 'jug ste/ de la mi sdug pa'i skabs nas lus dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bshad zin to/ / de nyid dbye ba'i bag tsam zhig chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las gsungs te/ rigs kyi bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' ni 'di ltar lus 'di ni rkang pa dang / rkang sor dang / byin pa dang / brla dang / dku do dang / lto ba dang / lte ba dang / sgal tshigs dang / snying dang / rtsib logs dang / sog pa dang / lag pa dang / lag ngar dang / dpung pa dang / thal gong dang / mjing pa dang / 'gram pa dang / dpral ba dang / mgo dang / mgo'i thod pa 'dus pa tsam ste/ las 'byung ba'i byed pa pos bsags pa/ nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa dang kun du rtog pa dang / rnam par rtog pa tha dad pa brgya stong gi gnas su gyur pa'o/ / 'dir khams kyi rdzas mang po 'dus pa ni 'di lta ste/ skra dang kha spu dang sen mo dang so dang rus pa dang pags pa dang sha dang sha'i spri dang rgyus pa dang tshil dang zhag dang chu ser dang mcher pa dang gcin dang phyi sa dang / pho ba dang long ka dang khrag dang snabs dang mkhris pa dang / rnag dang mchil ma dang klad pa dang klad rgyas rnams te/ de ltar rdzas mang po 'dus pa yin no/ / 'di la lus zhes ji skad du bya snyam du lus dran pa nye bar 'jog go/ / de la so sor rtog pa na 'di snyam du sems te/ lus 'di ni nam mkha' dang mtshungs so snyam nas de lus la nam mkha' ltar dran pa nye bar 'jog go/ / de thams cad nam mkha' ltar mthong ngo / / de lus yongs su shes pa'i phyir gang du yang dran pa nye bar mi 'jog go/ / rnam par mi 'jog go/ / rnam par mi 'phro'o zhes bya ba'o/ /

WHEN THE MIND is suitable for work in this way, engage in the applications of mindfulness. It is said that the application of mindfulness to the body begins after the meditation on foulness. This is explained through an abbreviated analysis[i] in the Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together: [229] Moreover, noble sir, a bodhisattva applies mindfulness to the body in this way: “This body is a mere collection of feet, toes, lower legs, thighs, hips, belly, navel, backbone,[ii] heart, ribs, shoulder-blades,[iii] hands, forearms, arms, shoulders, neck, chin, forehead, head, and skull, collected together by the agency of the karma relation, the locus of hundreds of thousands of different reactive emotions,[iv] postulations, and conceptual fictions. In it, many substances are brought together: namely, head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, bone, skin, flesh, epidermis, muscle, fat, fatty tissue, lymph, spleen, urine, feces, stomach,[v] blood, phlegm, bile, pus, saliva, and brain. In this way it is a conglomeration of many substances. Reflecting “Here, what is the body?,” she thinks: “This body is like space.” She applies mindfulness to the body, which is like space, and sees “All of this is space.” Because she thoroughly knows the body, she no longer spreads mindfulness out, nor disperses it, nor churns out thoughts.

yang gsungs pa/ lus 'di ni sngon gyi mtha' nas kyang ma 'ongs/ phyi ma'i mthar yang mi 'gro / sngon gyi mtha' dang phyi ma'i mtha' la yang mi gnas te/ gzhan du na yang dag pa ma yin pa phyin ci log las byung ba/ byed pa po dang tshor ba po med pa/ thog ma dang tha ma dang dbus med pa/ rtsa ba gnas pa med pa/ bdag po med pa nga'i ba med pa yongs su 'dzin pa med pa ste/ tshogs zhes bya ba dang lus zhes bya ba dang longs spyod ces bya ba dang gnas zhes bya ba dang rten zhes bya ba dang tshang zhes bya ba dang / skye mched ces bya ba ni glo bur gyi tha snyad rnams kyis tha snyad btags pa'o/ / lus 'di ni snying po med pa ste/ pha dang ma'i khu ba dang khrag las byung ba mi gtsang ba rul ba rang bzhin gyis dri mi zhim pa/ 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug dang 'jigs pa dang sgyid lug pa'i rkun pos dkrugs pa/ rtag tu 'jig pa 'bral ba 'brul ba rnam par 'thor ba rnam par 'joms pa'i chos can/ nad tha dad pa brgya stong gi tshang ngo snyam du lus la dran pa nye bar 'jog go zhes bya ba'o/ /

And the same text says: This body does not come from the past, nor transmigrate into the future, nor continue to exist from the past into the future. Other than that which has arisen from unreal delusion, it has neither an agent nor a subject of experiences. It has neither beginning, nor middle, nor end, no established root,[vi] no owner, no “mine,” and no possessiveness. Through adventitious social conventions, it is conventionally designated as “body,” “physique,” “enjoyment,” “basis,” “embodiment,” “corpse,” or “sphere.” This body is valueless, arising from the blood and semen of the mother and father, having an impure, putrid, foul-smelling nature, disturbed by those thieves, attraction, aversion and delusion, fear and discouragement. It is always subject to decay, fall, destruction, scattering, and dispersion. It is a nest of hundreds of thousands of different diseases.[vii]

'phags pa gtsug na rin po che'i mdo las kyang / kye ma'o lus 'di ni mi rtag pa'i rnam pa ste ring por mi gnas pa tha mar 'chi ba yin par shes nas lus kyi phyir mi mthun pa'i 'tsho ba mi spyod cing snying po len to/ / de snying po gsum len te/ gsum gang zhe na/ lus kyi snying po dang / longs spyod kyi snying po dang / 'tsho ba'i snying po'o/ / de lus mi rtag go snyam nas sems can thams cad kyi bran dang slob mar khas blangs te ci bya'o cog la 'bad pa yin/ lus mi rtag go snyam nas lus kyi nyes pa yon po dang g.yo dang tshul 'chos pa thams cad mi byed do/ / lus mi rtag go snyam nas srog la bag mi ston par 'gyur te srog gi phyir yang sdig pa'i las mi byed do/ / lus mi rtag go snyam nas longs spyod la spyod pa sred cing chags par mi byed de de bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtong ba yin no/ / rigs kyi bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' lus la lus kyi rjes su lta ba'i dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bsgom pa/ bdag gi lus de la sems can thams cad kyi lus nye bar 'dogs shing bdag gis sems can thams cad kyi lus sangs rgyas kyi sku'i gnas la gnas par bya'o snyam ste/ ji ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku zag pa med pa ltar rang gi lus kyi chos nyid la yang de bzhin du rtog go/ / de zag pa med pa'i chos la mkhas pas sems can thams cad kyi lus kyang de'i mtshan nyid du rab tu shes so zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

The noble Sūtra on the Jewel at the Crown of the Head also says, [230] “Oh no! This body does not last very long, ending in death.” Those who know this do not live with trouble[viii] because of the body, and receive its value. They receive the value of three things. What are the three? The value of the body, the value of possessions, and the value of life. Thinking “The body is impermanent,” they become servants and students of all sentient beings, eagerly striving to do whatever needs to be done. Thinking “The body is impermanent,” they do not engage in failings related to the body, such as crookedness, dishonesty, and hypocrisy. Thinking “The body is impermanent,” while living and breathing,[ix] they do not carry out vile actions even if their lives are at risk. Thinking “The body is impermanent,” they do not cling to craving for possessions. They become self-sacrificing, as it were, in every way. Moreover, noble sir, the bodhisattva, while cultivating, in relation to the body, the application of mindfulness that observes the body, connects the bodies of all sentient beings to his own body. And he thinks, “I should help all the kinds of sentient beings to attain the bodies of Buddhas.” Just as the body of a Tathāgata has no outflows, in the same way, he thoroughly considers how his own body actually is. Skilled in the way things actually are, the absence of outflows, he knows that the bodies of all sentient beings also have that characteristic.

khyim bdag dpas byin gyis zhus pa las kyang / 'di lta ste lus 'di mthar gyis 'grub pa dang mthar gyis 'jig pa dang rdul phra rab bstsags pa dang khong stong dang gye gu can dang bu ga dgu dang spu'i khung bu nas zag pa dang / grog mkhar ltar sbrul gdug pa'i gnas su gyur pa dang / ma skyes dgra'i spre'u ltar grogs la 'khu ba dang / bshes gnyen ngan pa ltar 'drid pa'i bdag nyid can dang / dbu ba rdos pa ltar rang bzhin gyis nyam chung ba dang / chu'i chu bur ltar byung nas 'jig cing 'ju ba dang / smig rgyu ltar slu ba'i bdag nyid can dang / chu shing ltar bshig na snying po med pa dang / sgyu ma ltar slu ba'i bdag nyid can dang / rgyal po ltar bsgo blag mang ba dang / dgra ltar glags lta ba dang / rkun po ltar yid brtan du mi rung ba dang gshed ma ltar rjes su chags pa med pa dang / mi mdza' ba ltar mi phan par 'dod pa dang / gsod pa ltar shes rab kyi srog gi bar chad byed pa dang / grong stong ltar bdag dang bral ba dang / rdza mkhan gyi snod ltar mthar 'jig pa dang / rdzing ltar mi gtsang ba sna tshogs kyis yongs su gang ba dang / sbang ma'i snod ltar mi gtsang ba zag pa dang /

The Inquiry of Vīradatta also says, [231] That is, the body comes together in regular stages and is destroyed in regular stages. It is a combination of atoms, full of holes, crooked, dripping from nine orifices and from its hair-pores. It is like an anthill that has become the home of venomous snakes. It is an unborn enemy.[1] It is like a monkey, harming its friends.[2] It is like a bad friend, inherently deceitful. It is like a ball of foam, naturally weak. It is like a water-bubble, which arises, bursts, and vanishes.[x] It is like a mirage, inherently deceptive. It is like a plantain tree, which, if split open, has no core. It is like an illusion, inherently fraudulent. It is like a king, giving orders all the time. It is like an enemy, looking for an opportunity. It is like a thief, not trustworthy. It is like an executioner, with no kindness.[xi] It is like an unfriendly person, wishing you harm. It is like a killer, creating obstacles to the life of wisdom. It is like an empty town, having no self. It is like a pottery vessel, breaking up in the end. It is like a basket full of various kinds of filth.[xii] It is like a distillation vessel, flowing with impurity
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rma ltar bskyod mi bzod pa dang / zug rngu ltar gnod pa'i bdag nyid can dang / khang rnying ltar bcos legs bya zhing brten pa dang / gru rnying ltar bcos legs bya zhing spyad pa dang / bum pa so ma btang ba ltar nan tan gyis bag bya dgos pa dang /

It is like a wound that cannot stand to be touched. It is like a thorn whose nature is piercing. It is like an old house that you can sustain only through repairs. It is like an old boat that can carry you only when repaired. It is like a jar of unbaked clay that must be protected with effort
de bzhin du sbyar te/

chu 'gram gyi shing ltar g.yo zhing 'gul ba dang / chu klung chen po'i rgyun ltar mthar 'chi ba'i rgya mtsho la thug pa dang / glo bur ba'i khyim ltar sdug bsngal thams cad kyi gnas su gyur pa dang / mgon med pa'i gnas khang ltar yongs su gzung ba med pa dang / btson srung ltar gsug gis bsgrub par bya ba dang /

It is like a tree at the water’s edge, unsteady and shaking. It is like the flow of a great river, ending in the ocean of death. It is like a guest-house, a dwelling place for all forms of suffering. Like a house with no proprietor, it is unowned. It is like a spymaster, whose success is obtained through bribes
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[xiii]
byis pa chung ngu ltar rtag tu yongs su bskyang dgos pa'o zhes gsungs so/ /
It is like a small child, always needing to be taken care of.
yang gsungs pa/ 'di ltar mi gtsang phung po'i lus la ni/ / gzugs kyi nga rgyal can gang gces 'dzin pa/ / byis pa'i blo can de ni mngon bzhin du/ / mi shes ngan skyugs bum pa thogs shing 'gro/ /

And the same text says, In this way, someone who is very proud of this body, Which is a mass of filth, imagining that it is handsome, Is manifestly foolish, like someone Who mindlessly goes around carrying a pot full of feces.
de yi sna nas rnag gi rnam pa 'dzag / kha nas dri mi zhim pa rtag tu 'byung / / skye bo'i kha 'gram mig ni srin bu bzhin/ / de la su zhig chags shing gces par byed/ /

From its nose, a kind of pus trickles down; From its mouth, a disgusting smell always arises. In the same way, sticky matter comes from the eye.[xiv] This body, like a worm—who could have attraction or pride towards it?
dper na byis pa sol ba thogs nas su/ / 'di ni dkar por bya zhes bdar byed kyang / / dkar po'i dngos por mi 'gyur zad par 'gyur/ / byis blo phyin ci log tu mngon par rlom/ /

For example, a fool who was carrying some charcoal Might rub it and try to turn it white. The charcoal would be wasted, and it would not turn white. The intellect of a fool is full of inaccurate conceits.
de ltar mi gang gtsang sbra'i blo gros ldan/ / nga yi lus 'di gtsang mar bya zhes te/ / bskus phyis 'bab stegs brgyar ni khrus byas kyang / / 'chi bdag dbang gis zad 'gyur gtsang mi 'gyur/ /

In the same way, a person who cares about ritual purity, Wanting to make the body clean, Might proudly bathe at a hundred fords; But through the power of death, the body goes unclean to its destruction.

byang chub sems dpa' de ltar lus la 'jig pa dang / bu ga dgu'i sgo nas 'dzag par brtag par bya ba nas byang chub sems dpa'i lus la srin bu'i rigs brgyad khri bzhi stong gi gnas su brtag par bya ba'i bar du'o/ /

Similarly, A bodhisattva should carefully consider this perishable body, leaking from nine orifices. A bodhisattva should carefully consider this body, the home of eighty-four thousand species of worms
de bzhin du sbyar te/
…[xv]

byang chub sems dpa' lus la spyang ki dang ce spyang dang khyi dang rjen sha za ba gzhan gyi zas su brtag par bya/ byang chub sems dpa' lus la rus pa dang rgyus pa'i bog res sbrel bas 'khrul 'khor lta bur brtag par bya/ byang chub sems dpa' lus la zas dang skom las byung ba ste rang gi kha na las pa ma yin par brtag par bya'o zhes te rgya cher ni de nyid las shes par bya'o/ /

A bodhisattva should carefully consider this body as food for others, for wolves, jackals, dogs, and other carnivores. A bodhisattva should carefully consider this body, which is like a machine, a mechanical construct of interconnected bones and muscles. A bodhisattva should carefully consider this body, which is not independent, originating from food and drink. [232] And so on at length. This is how you should understand [the application of mindfulness to the body.]

tshor ba dran pa nye bar gzhag pa ni/ re zhig 'phags pa gtsug na rin po che'i mdo las ji skad du/ rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' tshor ba rnams la tshor ba'i rjes su lta ba'i dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bsgom pa ni tshor ba bde bar gnas pa'i sems can rnams la snying rje chen po thob par 'gyur ro/ / de 'di ltar gang la tshor ba med pa de ni bde ba yin no zhes slob ste/ des sems can thams cad kyi tshor ba spang ba'i phyir tshor ba rnams la tshor ba'i rjes su lta ba'i dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bsgom mo/ / de sems can rnams kyi tshor ba 'gog pa'i phyir go cha bgos kyang bdag gi tshor ba 'gog par yang mi byed do/ / des tshor ba gang ci myong yang tshor ba de dag thams cad snying rje chen pos yongs su bzung zhing myong bar byed do/ / de nam bde ba'i tshor ba myong ba'i tshe na 'dod chags la spyod pa'i sems can rnams la snying rje chen po rnyed de bdag gi 'dod chags kyi cha bag la nyal ba yang yongs su spong ngo / / nam sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba myong ba'i tshe na zhe sdang la spyod pa'i sems can rnams la snying rje chen po rnyed de bdag gi zhe sdang gi bag la nyal yang yongs su spong ngo / / nam bde ba yang ma yin sdug bsngal yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba myong ba'i tshe na gti mug la spyod pa'i sems can rnams la snying rje chen po rnyed de bdag gi gti mug gi bag la nyal yang rab tu spong ngo / / bde ba'i tshor ba la rjes su chags par mi 'gyur te rjes su chags pa legs par 'joms par yang byed do/ / sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba la khong khro bar yang mi 'gyur te/ khong khro ba legs par 'joms par yang byed do/ / sdug bsngal ba yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba la ma rig pa dang ldan par mi 'gyur te ma rig pa legs par 'joms par yang byed do/ / des tshor ba gang ci myong ba de dag thams cad kyang mi rtag par shes shing myong bar byed do/ / sdug bsngal du shes shing myong bar byed do/ / bdag med par shes shing myong bar byed do/ / de bde ba'i tshor ba la ni mi rtag par shes par 'gyur ro/ / sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba la ni zug rngur shes par 'gyur ro/ / sdug bsngal yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba la ni zhi bar shes par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar na gang bde ba de ni mi rtag pa'o/ / gang sdug bsngal ba de ni sdug bsngal ba nyid do/ / gang bde ba yang ma yin sdug bsngal ba yang ma yin pa de ni bdag med pa'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

As for the application of mindfulness to feelings, the noble Sūtra on the Jewel at the Crown of the Head says, [233] Here, noble sir, bodhisattvas cultivating[xvi] the application of mindfulness to feelings attain great compassion for those sentient beings who dwell in pleasant feelings. And they train thus: “Where there are no feelings, this is happiness.” They cultivate the application of mindfulness to feelings so that all sentient beings will give up feelings, and put on the armor so that all sentient beings will stop feeling. But they do not themselves stop feeling. Whatever feelings they have, they accept and experience them all with great compassion. When they feel pleasant feelings, they attain great compassion for those sentient beings who act out of attraction, and they themselves give up the underlying tendency to attraction. When they feel painful feelings, they attain great compassion for those sentient beings who live in aversion, and they give up the underlying tendency to aversion. When they experience feelings that are neither painful nor pleasant, they attain great compassion for those sentient beings who live in delusion, and they give up the underlying tendency to delusion.[3] They do not get attached to pleasant feelings, and so they defeat attachment. They do not oppose painful feelings, and so they defeat opposition. They do not ignore feelings that are neither painful nor pleasant, and so they defeat ignorance. Whatever feelings they experience, they experience them and know them as impermanent; they experience them and know them as suffering; they experience them and know them as nonself. They experience pleasant feelings as impermanent, painful feelings as a thorn, and feelings that are neither painful nor pleasant as peaceful. Here, what is pleasant is impermanent; what is painful is suffering;[xvii] and what is neither painful nor pleasant is without self.
'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las kyang / sdug bsngal gyi tshor bas reg na ngan song dang mi khom par skyes pa'i sems can thams cad la snying rje chen po bskyed do/ /

The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra also says, When touched by painful feelings, they arouse great compassion for all sentient beings who have been born in the lower realms or without the opportunity to practice
de bzhin du sbyar te/

tshor ba ni mngon par zhen pa'o/ / tshor ba ni yongs su 'dzin pa'o/ / tshor ba ni nye bar len pa'o/ / tshor ba ni dmigs pa'o/ / tshor ba ni phyin ci log go/ / tshor ba ni rnam par rtog pa'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /
Feeling is attachment; feeling is possessiveness; feeling is appropriation; feeling is dualistic thinking; feeling is error; feeling is postulation.

chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las kyang / tshor ba myong bar rab bstan pa/ / tshor ba las gzhan tshor ba po/ / gud na yod pa ma yin na/ / gang gis de ni tshor bar 'gyur/ / byang chub ci 'dra de bzhin du/ / zhi zhing dag la 'od gsal bar/ / tshor ba 'di la mkhas pa rnams/ / dran pa de ltar nye bar gzhag / ces gsungs so/ / de ni tshor ba dran pa nye bar gzhag pa mdor bsdus pa'o/ /

And so on. The Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together also says, We say “the experience of feeling.” By whom is it experienced? No subject exists separately, Distinct from feeling. It is similar to Awakening, Peaceful, pure, and radiant; This is how the clear-sighted Should apply mindfulness to feeling. This is, in brief, the application of mindfulness to feeling.

sems dran pa nye bar gzhag pa ni dkon mchog brtsegs pa las ji skad du/ de 'di ltar sems yongs su tshor te/ 'dod chags par 'gyur ba'am zhe sdang bar 'gyur ba'am gti mug par 'gyur ba'i sems de dag gang yin/ ci 'das pa'am ma 'ongs pa'am da ltar byung ba zhig yin/ de la sems 'das pa gang yin pa de ni zad pa'o/ / ma 'ongs pa gang yin pa de ni ma phyin pa'o/ / da ltar byung ba ni gnas pa med do snyam mo/ / 'od srungs sems ni nang na yang med phyi rol na yang med gnyi ga na yang med cing mi dmigs so/ / 'od srungs sems ni gzugs med pa/ bstan du med pa/ thogs pa med pa/ rten med pa/ snang ba med pa/ rnam par rig pa med pa/ gnas med pa'o/ / 'od srungs sems ni sangs rgyas thams cad kyis kyang ma gzigs mi gzigs gzigs par mi 'gyur ro/ / log par zhugs pa'i 'du shes las chos rnams 'byung ba ma gtogs par/ / sangs rgyas thams cad kyis kyang ma gzigs mi gzigs gzigs par mi 'gyur ba gang yin pa de'i rgyu ba ci 'dra bar rig par bya zhe na/ 'od srungs sems ni sgyu ma dang mtshungs te yang dag pa ma yin pa kun du rtog pas skye ba rnam pa mang po yongs su 'dzin to/ /

The application of mindfulness to mind is taught as follows in the noble Heap of Jewels: [234] They look for mind in this way: “Attracted, averse, or deluded—which is it? Is it past, future, or present? Here, what is in the past has perished. What is in the future has not yet come. The present does not remain.” For, Kāśyapa, mind is not apprehended either internally, or externally, or outside of both.[xviii] Kāśyapa, mind is nonphysical, cannot be shown, does not create physical resistance, cannot be represented,[xix] and has no abode. Kāśyapa, all the Buddhas have not seen mind; they don’t see it and will not see it. When something has not been seen, is not being seen, and will not be seen by all the Buddhas, apart from things that arise due to inaccurate conceptions, what sort of appearance would that be understood to have? Kāśyapa, mind is like an illusion; people grasp on to many aspects that arise from inaccurate postulation
de bzhin du sbyar te/

'od srungs sems ni 'bab chu'i rgyun dang mtshungs te mi gnas pa skyes nas 'jig cing dengs pa'o/ / 'od srungs sems ni rlung dang mtshungs te ring du 'gro zhing gzung du med par rgyu ba'o/ / 'od srungs sems ni mar me'i 'od 'phro ba dang mtshungs te rgyu dang rkyen las byung ba'o/ / 'od srungs sems ni nam mkha' dang mtshungs te nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa glo bur ba rnams kyis nye bar nyon mongs pa'o/ / 'od srungs sems ni glog dang mtshungs te skad cig gcig tu 'jig cing mi gnas pa'o/ /

Kāśyapa, mind is like the flow of a river, not remaining the same; as soon as it arises, it ceases and dissipates. {Kāśyapa, mind is like the wind; it goes far away and cannot be grasped.} Kāśyapa, mind is like the flame of a lamp; it proceeds by means of causes and conditions. Kāśyapa, mind is like lightning, gone in a moment, not persisting. Kāśyapa, mind is like the sky, obscured by adventitious reactive emotions[xx] {and secondary reactive emotions.}
de bzhin du sbyar te/
'od srungs sems ni sdug bsngal thams cad bskyed pa'i phyir mi mdza' ba dang mtshungs so/ / 'od srungs sems ni dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad 'jig par byed pa'i phyir bye ma'i khang pa dang mtshungs so/ /
Kāśyapa, mind is like a bad friend, producing all kinds of suffering.[xxi] {Kāśyapa, mind is like a sand-castle, causing all your wholesome actions to cease.}
'od srungs sems ni sdug bsngal ba la bde bar 'du shes pa'i phyir nya'i mchil pa dang mtshungs so/ / 'od srungs sems na bdag med pa la bdag tu 'du shes pa'i phyir rmi lam dang mtshungs so/ /
Kāśyapa, mind is like a fish-hook, because it conceives of what is suffering as happiness. {Kāśyapa, mind is like a dream, because it conceives of what has no self as self.}
'od srungs sems ni mi gtsang ba la gtsang bar 'du shes pa'i phyir sbrang ma sngon po dang mtshungs so/ / 'od srungs sems ni gnod pa rnam pa mang po byed pas phyir rgol ba dang mtshungs so/ /
In the same way, it is like a blue-fly, conceiving of what is impure as pure. Kāśyapa, mind is like an attacker, inflicting all kinds of harm.[xxii]

'od srungs sems ni rtag tu klan ka tshol ba'i phyir gnod sbyin mdangs 'phrog pa dang mtshungs so/ / 'od srungs sems ni rtag tu glags lta bas dgra dang mtshungs so/ / 'od srungs sems ni dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad rku bas chom rkun dang mtshungs so/ /
Mind is like a vigor-stealing spirit, always looking for weak points. In the same way, it is like a thief, stealing all your wholesome actions.[xxiii]
'od srungs sems ni rjes su chags pa dang khong khro ba dang ldan pas rtag tu mtho dman can no/ / 'od srungs sems ni gzugs la dga' bas phyi byi zhi la'i mig dang mtshungs so/ /
{Kāśyapa, mind is always lowly due to having anger and attachment.} Kāśyapa, mind is like the eye of a bird,[xxiv] delighting in forms.

'od srungs sems ni sgra la dga' bas g.yul gyi rnga dang mtshungs so/ / 'od srungs sems ni phag mi gtsang ba'i dri la dga' ba bzhin du dri la dga'o/ / 'od srungs sems ni ro la dga' zhing zas kyi lhag ma za ba'i bran mo dang mtshungs so/ / 'od srungs sems ni reg pa la dga' bas sbrang ma 'bru mar gyi snod la chags pa dang mtshungs so/ /

Kāśyapa, mind is like a battle-drum, delighting in sounds. Kāśyapa, mind delights in smells, just like a pig in the midst of filth. Kāśyapa, mind delights in tastes, like a female servant who eats leftovers. Kāśyapa, mind delights in touch, like a fly in a vessel of grain-oil.

'od srungs sems ni kun du btsal yang mi rnyed do/ / gang mi rnyed pa de ni mi dmigs pa'o/ / gang mi dmigs pa de ni 'das pa yang ma yin ma 'ongs pa yang ma yin da ltar byung ba yang ma yin no/ / gang 'das pa yang ma yin ma 'ongs pa yang ma yin da ltar byung ba yang ma yin pa de ni dus gsum las yang dag par 'das pa'o/ / gang dus gsum las yang dag par 'das pa de ni yod pa yang ma yin med pa yang ma yin no zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

Kāśyapa, when you look for mind, you don’t find it. What is not found is not apprehended. What is not apprehended is neither past, nor future, nor present. What is neither past, nor future, nor present transcends the three times. What transcends the three times neither exists nor doesn’t exist. [235] And so on.

'phags pa gtsug na rin po che'i mdo las kyang / de sems kun du tshol bas na sems nang na yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / sems phyi rol na yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / sems phyi nang na yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / phung po rnams la yang sems yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / khams rnams la yang sems yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / skye mched rnams la yang sems yang dag par rjes su mi mthong / des sems yang dag par rjes su mi mthong bas/ sems gang las byung zhes sems kyi rgyun kun du tshol zhing de 'di snyam du sems te/ dmigs pa yod pa las sems 'byung bar 'gyur ro snyam mo/ / de yang 'di snyam du sems te/ ci dmigs pa de yang gzhan la sems de yang gzhan nam/ 'on te dmigs pa gang yin pa de nyid sems yin gal te dmigs pa yang gzhan la sems de yang gzhan na ni/ sems de gnyis su 'gyur ro/ / 'on te dmigs pa gang yin pa de nyid sems yin na ni sems kyis sems de nyid ji ltar mthong bar 'gyur te/ sems kyis sems mthong bar mi rung ngo / / 'di lta ste dper na ral gri'i so de nyid kyis ral gri'i so de nyid gcad par mi nus pa dang sor mo'i rtse mo de nyid kyis sor mo'i rtse mo de nyid la reg par mi nus pa de bzhin du sems de nyid kyis kyang sems de nyid mthong bar mi nus so snyam mo/ /

The noble Sūtra on the Jewel at the Crown of the Head also says, Those who look for the mind don’t see mind internally, don’t see mind externally,[xxv] {don’t see mind both internally and externally} don’t see mind in the aggregates, don’t see mind in the components, and don’t see mind in the sense-spheres. Not seeing mind, they don’t look for the continuity of mind, asking, “From where does mind arise?” They think, “When there is an object, mind arises. Is mind distinct from its object? Or are mind and its object the same? Well, if mind is distinct from its object, then the object will be mindless.[xxvi][4] Now if mind and its object are the same, then how does mind perceive mind? Mind does not perceive mind. For example, a sword-edge cannot cut that very same sword-edge; a fingertip cannot touch that very same fingertip; mind cannot see that very same mind
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rigs kyi bu gzhan yang gang mgyogs pa rab tu mgyogs pa mi gnas par rgyu ba spre'u dang rlung dang 'dra ba 'bab chu'i rgyun dang 'bru mar gyi mar me dang 'dra ba rgyang ring por 'gro ba/ lus med pa/ yul la brkam pa/ skye mched drug la spyod pa/ gzhan dang gzhan gyi shes pa dang ldan pa'i sems/ gnas pa/ rtse gcig pa/ mi 'phro ba/ rnam par mi 'phro ba/ zhi gnas la rtse gcig pa/ g.yeng ba med pa 'di ni sems gnas pa zhes bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

[236] Moreover, noble sir, it runs this way and that way,[xxvii] unstable and wandering, like a monkey or the wind …[xxviii] {like the flow of a river or an oil lamp.} traveling far away, bodiless, lightly roaming around, moving to and fro among objects, operating among the six sense-spheres, thinking about one thing after another. When this mind becomes stable and one-pointed, not churning out thoughts,[xxix] with no distractions from one-pointed resting meditation, this is called “mindfulness of mind.”[xxx]

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las kyang / bdag gis rnam par bsgrub par bya ba la brtson par bya ste sems kyi chos nyid 'di yang mi 'dor ro snyam mo/ / de la sems kyi chos nyid ni gang rnam par bsgrub pa ni gang zhe na/ sems ni sgyu ma lta bu ste 'di la gang yang sbyin pa de ni sems kyi chos nyid ces bya'o/ / gang yang bdog pa thams cad yongs su btang ste sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad yongs su dag par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo ba 'di ni rnam par bsgrub pa zhes bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra also says, I should practice conceptual construction, and I should not lose touch with the way mind really is. Here, what is the way mind really is? What is conceptual construction? Mind is like an illusion: this is called “the way mind really is.” Now, giving away everything that exists and dedicating that for purifying all the Buddha-fields: this is called “conceptual construction.”

chos rjes su dran pa ni re zhig de nyid las ji skad du/ byang chub sems dpa' chos la chos kyi rjes su lta zhing gnas pa ni gang las sangs rgyas kyi chos med pa dang / gang las byang chub med pa dang / gang las lam med pa dang / gang las thar pa med pa dang / gang las nges par 'byung ba med pa'i chos de gang yang mi mthong ngo / / des chos thams cad 'byung bar shes nas sems can rnams la sgrib pa med par shes par bya ba'i phyir snying rje chen po'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo thob par 'gyur ro/ / de chos thams cad dang nyon mongs pa thams cad la yang sgyu mar 'du shes pa thob ste/ chos 'di dag ni nyon mongs pa med pa ste 'di dag ni nyon mongs pa dang bcas pa ma yin pa'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar de dag ni nges pa'i don la rtog pa ste/ nyon mongs pa rnams la ni tshogs med/ phung por gyur pa med/ 'dod chags kyi dngos po med/ zhe sdang gi dngos po med/ gti mug gi dngos po med pa ste/ nyon mongs pa 'di dag nyid rtogs pa'i phyir byang chub po/ / nyon mongs pa'i ngo bo nyid gang yin pa byang chub kyi ngo bo nyid kyang de yin no zhes de ltar dran pa nye bar 'jog go zhes gsungs so/ /

The same text explains the application of mindfulness to experience[5] as follows: When bodhisattvas rest and look at experience, they don’t see any experience at all. Therefore, there are no virtues of a Buddha. Therefore, there is no Awakening. Therefore, there is no path. Therefore, there is no liberation. Therefore, there is no salvation. Knowing that all experience has no salvation, they attain the meditative absorption of great compassion known as “Undistorted.” They attain a conception of all experience and all reactive emotions as fictitious. Experience is free from reactive emotions; it has no reactive emotions. This is how they reflect on the definitive meaning.[xxxi] “Reactive emotions have no coming together, no aggregation. There is no entity of attraction, no entity of aversion, and no entity of delusion. Because of waking up to these very reactive emotions, there is Awakening. The essence of reactive emotions is the essence of Awakening.” This is how they apply mindfulness.

'phags pa gtsug na rin po che las kyang / rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' chos rnams la chos kyi rjes su lta ba'i dran pa nye bar gzhag pa la gnas pa 'di snyam du sems te/ skye ba na chas rnams kho na skye/ 'gag pa na chos rnams kho na 'gag ste/ 'di la bdag gam sems can nam srog gam skye ba po'am gso ba'am skyes bu'am gang zag gam shed las skyes pa'am shed bu'am gang skye ba'am rga ba'am 'chi ba'am/ 'pho ba'am skye bar 'gyur ba gang yang med do/ / 'di ni chos rnams kyi chos nyid do/ / gal te bsgrubs na ni grub po/ / gal te ma bsgrubs na ni mi 'grub ste/ dge ba yang rung mi dge ba yang rung mi g.yo ba yang rung ste ji ltar bsgrubs pa de lta bur 'grub mod kyi/ chos rnams la sgrub par byed pa yang med la/ chos rnams rgyu med par yang gang yang mi skye'o snyam mo zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ / yang de nyid las/ de gang cung zad chos zab mo la so sor rtog kyang thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi byang chub kyi sems rjes su dran pa de yang mi 'dor zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Sūtra on the Jewel at the Crown of the Head also says, [237] Noble sir, here a bodhisattva resting in the application of mindfulness that observes experience thinks as follows: “When arising, experiences just arise. When ceasing, experiences just cease. Here in this body there is no sentient being, or life-force, or one who is born, or one who is nourished, or person, or someone, or human, or human being, or anyone who is born, or gets older, or dies, or is reborn. That’s how experiences really are: If they are produced, they arise; if they are not produced, they do not arise. However they are produced, whether wholesome, unwholesome, or neutral, that’s how they arise. Experiences have no producer, and they never arise without any cause.” The same text says, No matter how deeply they look into the teachings, they never give up the recollection of the mind of Awakening to complete knowing.

'phags pa rgya cher rol pa las kyang / / 'du byed mi rtag brtan pa ma yin te/ / rdza so ma btang lta bur 'jig pa'i bdag / gzhan gyi rdzas ni brnyan po byas dang mtshungs/ / bye ma'i grong khyer lta bur ring mi thogs/ /

The noble Detailed Explanation of the Play also says,[6] Compounded things are impermanent and unstable, Perishable by nature, like an unbaked clay pot. Like something borrowed from another person,[xxxii] Like a city made of sand, they don’t last very long.
'du byed 'di dag 'jig pa'i chos can te/ / dbyar gyi zhal zhal ji ltar 'gogs pa bzhin/ / chu ngogs bye ma yod pa 'dra ba ste/ / rkyen la rag las rang bzhin nyam chung bar/ /
Compounded things are subject to destruction, Like plaster washed away in the rainy season. They are like a sandy riverbank, Dependent on conditions, weak by nature.
'du byed mar me'i 'od 'gro 'dra ba ste/ / myur du 'byung zhing 'gag pa'i chos can yin/ / rlung dang mtshungs par ring du mi gnas la/ / sbu ba lta bur nyam chung snying po med/ /
Compounded things are like the flame of a lamp, Quickly arising and ceasing, Unsteady like the wind, [238] Weak, with no core, like a ball of foam.
'du byed g.yo ba med cing stong pa ste/ / brtags na chu shing dag gi phung po 'dra/ / sgyu ma lta bur sems ni rmongs par byed/ / lag bcangs stong pas byis pa 'drid dang mtshungs/ /
Compounded things are motionless and empty; When examined, they are like a mass of plantain trees, Like an illusion, confusing the mind, Like an empty fist or the idle taunts of fools.
'dus byas gyur pa thams cad rgyu dag dang / / rkyen rnams kyis ni rab tu 'byung ba ste/ / gcig gis gcig rgyu byas te brten nas byung / / byis pa'i skye bos 'di 'dra 'di ma rtogs/ /
Compounded things proceed by means Of causes and conditions, Mutual causality and dependent arising; Foolish people don’t realize this.
dper na gres ma mun dza brten byas la/ / brtsal ba'i stobs kyis thag par 'gyur ba dang / / zo chun rgyud mo 'khor 'byung bcas pa yang / / de dag re res 'grub par 'gyur ba med/ /
For example, by the power of effort, Muñja grass and balbaja grass can be woven together into a rope; A water-wheel turns, but The individual parts can’t turn by themselves.
de ltar srid pa'i yan lag kun 'grub pa/ / gzhan dang gzhan tshogs pa la brten nas ni/ / de dag so so re re 'grub ba ni/ / sngon gyi mtha' dang phyi ma'i mtha' mi dmigs/ /
In the same way, all the aspects of being Exist in dependence on the combination of the others; From the most distant past to the farthest future, One of these existing by itself is not apprehended.
sa bon yod na myu gu ji bzhin te/ / sa bon gang yin de nyid myu gu min/ / de las gzhan min de yang ma yin te/ / de ltar rtag min chad min chos nyid de/ /
When there is a seed, there will be a sprout; The seed is not the same as the sprout. It is neither the same nor different. [239] Similarly, the way things are is not eternal and not annihilated.
ma rig pa ni 'du byed rkyen yin te/ / 'du byed de yang yang dag nyid du med/ / ma rig pa dang 'du byed de dag kyang / / rang bzhin stong ste g.yo ba med pa yin/ /
rgya las rgya yi 'bur ni snang mod kyi/ / rgyu de 'phos par dmigs pa'ang yod ma yin/ / de la de med gzhan las ma yin te/ / de ltar 'dus byas rtag med chad pa med/ /

Although a seal produces a seal impression, We don’t apprehend that the seal transmigrates.[7] It isn’t there [in the impression,] but nor are they wholly different. In the same way, composite things are not annihilated and not eternal.
mig dang gzugs la brten pa byas nas su/ / mig gi rnam par shes pa 'dir byung yang / / mig ni gzugs la brten pa ma yin la/ / gzugs kyang mig las 'pho ba yod ma yin/ /
In this world, with the eye as its condition, Visual consciousness arises from form. Form is not based on the eye, and Form does not transmigrate into the eye.
'di dag bdag med mi sdug chos can yin/ / de dag bdag dang sdug par brtags pa ste/ / nor pa yang dag ma yin brtags yin yang / / de las mig gi rnam par shes pa 'byung / /
These things are selfless and impure, But they are imagined to be “self” and pure. From these, visual consciousness arises As an inaccurate, unreal postulation.
rnam par shes pa 'gags nas 'byung gyur te/ / mkhas pas skye dang 'jig pa rnam par mthong / / gang du ma song gang nas 'ong ba min/ / rnal 'byor pas ni stong pa sgyu ltar mthong / /
dper na gtsub shing dang ni gtsub stan dang / / lag pas brtsal ba byas pa gsum tshogs pa/ / de la brten nas me ni 'byung 'gyur te/ / byung nas ring por mi thogs 'gag par 'gyur/ /
For example, a fire-stick, the fire-stick support, and Effort with the hand: from the combination of all three, Fire arises dependently, And ceases easily at any time.
de nas mkhas pa la las brtags byas te/ / 'di ni gang nas 'ongs la gar song zhes/ / phyogs dang phyogs mtshams kun du brtags byas na/ / de ni 'ong ba'am 'gro ba mi dmigs so/ /
After that, some learned people wonder, “Where did it come from?” or “Where does it go?” When you analyze all the directions and intermediate directions, You find no going or coming.

phung po dag dang skye mched khams rnams kyi/ / rkyen ni ma rig pa dang sred dang las/ / de dag tshogs pa sems can zhes brjod kyang / / de ni dam pa'i don du dmigs su med/ / ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

The aggregates, sense-spheres, and components Have ignorance, craving, and karma as their conditions.[xxxiii] The collection of these is called “a sentient being,” But in ultimate truth, no such thing is apprehended.[xxxiv]
mchu dang lkog ma rkan la brten nas ni/ / lce bsgyur ba las yi ge'i sgra 'byung yang / / lkog mar brten nas ma yin rkan las min/ / re re la ni yi ge dmigs su med/ /
Syllables are conditioned by the throat, lips, and palate, And by bending or not bending the tongue. But syllables are not individually apprehended Either in the throat or in the palate.
tshogs pa de la brten nas ngag de ni/ / yid kyi blo yi dbang gis 'byung mod kyi/ / yid dang ngag ni mi snang gzugs med de/ / nang dang phyi rol na yang dmigs su med/ /
Conditioned by the whole collection, Speech arises by the power of mind and intellect. Mind and speech have no visible form And are not apprehended either inside or outside.
mkhas pas ngag skad sgra dang dbyangs rnams kyi/ / skye dang 'jig la rnam par brtags byas na/ / de tshe ngag kun brag ca lta bu dang / / skad cig pa dang snying po med par mthong / /
The wise see with insight the arising and ceasing Of voice, sound, speech, and articulation As momentary and dependent in this way; [241] All speech is like an echo.
dper na shing dang rgyud la brten byas la/ / lag pas rtsol ba byas pa gsum tshogs na/ / sgra snyan pi bang gling bu la sogs pa/ / de dag las ni sgra yang 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

Similarly, with a stringed instrument, a bow, and effort with the hand, When these three come together, sound is produced, Arising from that; Or from lutes, bells, or various other musical instruments.
de nas mkhas pa la las brtags byas te/ / 'di ni gang nas 'ongs la gar song zhes/ / phyogs dang phyogs mtshams kun tu brtags byas na/ / sgra yi 'ong ba'am 'gro ba mi dmigs so/ /
Now, some learned people wonder, “Where did it come from?” or “Where does it go?” But in any direction, the path of the going or coming Of sound is not found.
de ltar rgyu dag dang ni rkyen rnams las/ / 'du byed gyur pa thams cad byung ba ste/ / yang dag mthong ba'i rnal 'byor pa yis ni/ / 'du byed stong pa g.yo ba med par mthong / /
In this way, all compounded things Proceed by means of causes and conditions; But spiritual practitioners who see them as they actually are See compounded things as empty and motionless.

phung po dag dang skye mched khams rnams ni/ / nang yang stong la phyi rol stong pa ste/ / thams cad bdag gis dben zhing gnas med la/ / chos kyi mtshan nyid nam mkha'i ngo bo nyid/ / chos kyi mtshan nyid 'di 'dra 'di dag ni/ /

The aggregates, sense-spheres, and components Are empty internally and empty externally; Beings are without any “self” and have no abode.[xxxv] They have as their distinguishing characteristic The essence of entities, space.[xxxvi]

The Explanation by the Lord of the World (Loka-nātha-vyākaraṇa) also says, Things are empty and nameless; Why do you ask for names? In emptiness there are no gods anywhere, Nor serpent-spirits, nor ogres,[8] No humans nor nonhumans; But they all exist!
ming gis ming nyid stong pa ste/ / ming ni ming gis yod ma yin/ / ming med pa yi chos rnams kun/ / ming gis yongs su brjod par byas/ /
Name-ness is empty of names; In a name, no name can be found. All entities are nameless, But illuminated by a name.
The essence of a name, indeed, Is not seen, nor is it heard, Nor arises, nor ceases; So of what are you asking for the name?
bslab pa kun las btus pa las dran pa nye bar gzhag pa'i le'u ste bcu gsum pa'o/ /
[lus yongs su dag pa]
14. Purifying the Body
dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bshad zin to// //
[242] THE APPLICATIONS OF mindfulness have been explained.

When the mind is ready in this way, then someone who has the method of full Awakening, in order to lift the rest of the living world out of the ocean of suffering, and to have power over everything in the three times and to the limits of space, should now engage the emptiness of everything.[i]

de ltar sems 'os su gyur nas yang stong pa nyid la 'jug par bya ste/ gang zag stong pa nyid ni de ltar shin tu grub pa yin no/ / de'i phyir rtsa ba chad pas nyon mongs pa thams cad kun du mi 'byung ngo / /
In this way the emptiness of the person is attained; and then, because the root has been cut, reactive emotions do not function.

'phags pa de bzhin gshegs pa gsang ba'i mdo las ji skad du/ zhi ba'i blo gros 'di lta ste/ dper na shing rtsa ba nas bcad na yal ga dang lo ma dang yal ga phra mo thams cad skam par 'gyur ro/ / zhi ba'i blo gros de bzhin du 'jig tshogs la lta ba nye bar zhi na nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa thams cad zhi bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

As the noble Mysteries of the Tathāgata Sūtra says, For example, Śāntamati,[1] if the root of a tree is cut, all the branches, leaves, and flowers[ii] dry up. In just the same way, Śāntamati, if you pacify the false view of a real self, all reactive emotions are pacified.
stong pa nyid bsgom pa'i phan yon ni mu med do/ / re zhig zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las ji skad du/
The praiseworthy aspects of meditation on emptiness are limitless. As the Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[iii]

de ni nam yang bde gshegs rnams kyi bslab mi 'dor/ / dpa' bo de ni nam yang bud med dbang mi 'gro/ / de ni bde gshegs rnams kyi bstan la dga' ba rnyed/ / 'di ni chos kyi rang bzhin rab tu zhi ba shes/ /

He who knows the nature of things as utterly peaceful Never abandons the training of the Well-Gone Ones. [243] A hero, he never goes under the power of women. He delights in the religion of the Well-Gone Ones.

de 'dir ring po mi thogs rkang gnyis dbang por 'gyur/ / de ni bde ba sbyin par byed pa'i sman par 'gyur/ / de ni sdug bsngal rnams kyi zug rngu kun du 'byin/ / de ni chos kyi rang bzhin rab tu zhi ba shes/ /
He who knows the nature of things as utterly peaceful Will soon become the best of bipeds; He will become a doctor, a physician, a giver of happiness. For all those in pain, he pulls out the thorn.

mi yi zla ba de ni bzod pa'i stobs kyis 'phags/ / de ni rdo dbyug dag gis bsnun kyang 'khrugs mi 'gyur/ / de yi yan lag nying lag bcad kyang 'khrugs pa med/ / de ni chos kyi rang bzhin rab tu zhi ba shes/ /

He who knows the nature of things as utterly peaceful Is ennobled by the power of patient endurance, a moon among people. Even if beaten with clods and sticks, he is not angry. Even if cut from limb to limb, he is not enraged.[2]

de ni nam yang ngan 'gror skye bar 'gyur ma yin/ / rtag tu gzugs mdzes shing ni mtshan dang ldan par 'gyur/ / des ni rtag tu mngon shes lnga po 'di dag bsgom/ / dpa' de 'dir rtag bde gshegs rnams kyi mdun na gnas/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

bcom ldan 'das ma las kyang / shA ri'i bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po sangs rgyas kyi sku yongs su bsgrub par 'dod pa dang / skyes bu chen po'i mtshan sum cu rtsa gnyis dang dpe byad bzang po brgyad cu thob par 'dod pa dang / skye ba thams cad du skye ba dran pa dang byang chub kyi sems chud mi za ba dang byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mi brjed pa thob par 'dod pa dang / sdig pa'i bshes gnyen dang sdig pa'i grogs po thams cad yongs su spong bar 'dod pa dang / sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen thams cad mnyes par bya bar 'dod pa dang / bdud kyi ris kyi lha thams cad gdul bar 'dod pa dang / sgrib pa thams cad rnam par sbyang bar 'dod pa dang / chos thams cad la bsgrib pa med pa thob par 'dod pas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la bslab par bya'o/ / shA ri'i bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po phyogs bcu dag na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das gang dag bzhugs pa de dag bdag gis bsngags pa brjod do snyam na shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la bslab par bya'o/ / shA ri'i bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po sems bskyed pa gcig gis shar phyogs su 'jig rten gyi khams gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed 'da' bar 'dod pa dang /

[244] And so on. The Blessed Lady also says, Moreover, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being who wishes to develop the body of a Buddha; who wishes to attain the thirty-two major and eighty minor marks of a great person; who wishes in all lives to remember past lives, not to let the Awakening Mind go to waste, and not to forget the bodhisattva’s way of life; who wishes to give up all bad friends and bad companions; who wishes to please all the Buddhas, bodhisattvas, and spiritual teachers; who wishes to subdue all Māras and the gods on Māra’s side; who wishes to clear away all distortions and attain freedom from distortion with respect to everything, should train in the Perfection of Wisdom. Moreover, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being who thinks, “I should praise the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, who are in the ten directions,” should train in the Perfection of Wisdom. Moreover, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being who wishes, by just a single thought, to traverse world-realms in the eastern direction that are as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River
de bzhin du sbyar te/
phyogs bcu thams cad 'da' bar 'dod pas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la bslab par bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa rgya cher gsungs so/ /
and in the same way, who wishes to traverse all ten directions, should train in the Perfection of Wisdom. And so on at great length.

de la ji ltar chos thams cad bdag med kyang las dang 'bras bur 'brel pa mi 'gal ba dang / rang bzhin med kyang ji ltar mthong bzhin pa'i chos thams cad mi 'gal ba de ltar ni/ yab dang sras mjal ba'i mdo las bstan te/ rgyal po chen po skyes bu 'di ni khams drug pa/ reg pa'i skye mched drug pa/ yid kyi nye bar spyod pa bco brgyad pa'o/ / rgyal po chen po skyes bu 'di ni khams drug pa zhes gang smras pa de ci la brten te smras she na/ rgyal po chen po khams drug ni 'di dag go/ / drug gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ sa'i khams dang / chu'i khams dang / me'i khams dang / rlung gi khams dang / nam mkha'i khams dang / rnam par shes pa'i khams dang / rgyal po chen po de dag ni khams drug ste/ skyes bu 'di dag ni khams drug pa'o zhes gang ngas smras pa de ni de la brten te smras so/ / skyes bu 'di ni reg pa'i skye mched drug pa'o zhes gang smras pa de ci la brten te smras she na/ rgyal po chen po reg pa'i skye mched drug ni 'di dag ste/ drug gang zhe na/

The Meeting of Father and Son explains how the absence of self in everything does not contradict the connection between action and its results, and how the absence of intrinsic nature does not contradict all things being just as they appear: [245] “Your Majesty, a person is six elements, six spheres of contact, eighteen types of sensory response. Your Majesty, when it is said “a person is six elements,” what does that refer to?[iv] There are six elements. They are: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, and the consciousness element. Your Majesty, these are the six elements …[v] {As for what I said, ‘These people are the six elements,’ this is what I was referring to. When it was said, ‘The person is six spheres of contact,’ what does that refer to?} What are the six spheres of contact?

gzugs rnams la lta ba'i phyir mig reg pa'i skye mched dang / sgra rnams la nyan pa'i phyir rna ba reg pa'i skye mched dang / dri rnams la snom pa'i phyir sna reg pa'i skye mched dang / ro rnams la myang ba'i phyir lce reg pa'i skye mched dang / reg bya rnams la reg pa'i phyir lus reg pa'i skye mched dang / chos rnams rnam par shes pa'i phyir yid reg pa'i skye mched do/ / rgyal po chen po de dag ni reg pa'i skye mched drug ste/ skyes bu 'di dag ni reg pa'i skye mched drug pa'o zhes gang ngas smras pa de ni de la brten te smras so/ /

The sphere of visual contact, for seeing forms; the sphere of auditory contact, for hearing sounds; the sphere of olfactory contact, for smelling scents; the sphere of gustatory contact, for experiencing tastes; the sphere of somatic contact, for feeling touchables; the sphere of mental contact, for being conscious of experiences. Your Majesty, these are the six spheres of contact …

rgyal po chen po skyes bu 'di ni yid kyi nye bar spyod pa bco brgyad pa'o zhes gang smras pa de ci la brtan te smras she na/ rgyal po chen po yid kyi nye bar spyod pa bco brgyad ni 'di dag ste/ bco brgyad gang zhe na/
Your Majesty, there are eighteen types of sensory response.[vi] What are the eighteen?

'di la mig gis gzugs mthong na yid bde ba dang yid mi bde ba dang btang snyoms su 'gyur bar gzugs la nye bar spyod do/ / de bzhin du rna ba la sogs pa la yang brjod par bya'o/ / rgyal po chen po de la gang dag yid bde bar nye bar spyod pa drug dang / gang dag yid mi bde bar nye bar spyod pa drug dang / gang dag btang snyoms su nye bar spyod pa drug po de dag gcig tu bsdus na yid kyi nye bar spyod pa bco brgyad du 'gyur ro/ /

Here a person sees forms with the eye, and then [the mind] responds with happiness, unhappiness, and indifference. The same can be said with respect to the ear and so on. Therefore, because there are three types, happiness and so on, for each of the six sense faculties, there are eighteen types of sensory response”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rgyal po chen po nang gi sa'i khams gang zhe na/ gang ci yang rung ste/ lus 'di la nang gi khong na sra ba dang mkhrang ba'i rnam pa dang nye bar gyur pa dang zin pa'o/ / de yang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ skra dang spu dang / sen mo dang zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / rgyal po chen po phyi rol gyi sa'i khams gang zhe na/ gang ci yang rung ste/ phyi rol gyi sra ba dang mkhrang ba'i rnam pa dang / nye bar ma gyur pa dang ma zin pa 'di ni phyi rol gyi sa'i khams zhes bya'o/ / rgyal po chen po de la nang gi sa'i khams 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong / 'gag pa'i tshe gang du yang sogs par mi 'gyur ro/ /

“Your Majesty, what is the internal earth element? Whatever in this body is solid or has become solid and is grasped. What is that? It is, for example, head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, and so on. This is called the internal earth element. Your Majesty, what is the external earth element? Whatever on the outside is solid or has become solid and is[vii] not grasped, this is the external earth element. Here, Your Majesty, when the internal earth element arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere; when it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere as a collection.”

rgyal po chen po bud med nang du bdag ni bud med do zhes rtog pa'i dus de yod do/ / de nang du bud med ces brtags nas phyi rol du skyes pa la skyes pa zhes rtog go/ / de phyi rol du skyes pa la skyes pa zhes brtags nas chags par gyur te phyi rol gyi skyes pa dang phrad par 'dod do/ / skyes pa yang nang du bdag ni skyes pa'o zhes rtog ste de nang du bdag ni skyes pa zhes brtags nas phyi rol du bud med la bud med ces rtog go/ / phyi rol du bud med la bud med ces brtags nas chags par 'gyur te/ phyi rol gyi bud med dang phrad par 'dod do/ / phrad par 'dod pas phrad par 'gyur ro/ / phrad pa'i rkyen gyis mer mer po skye bar 'gyur ba'i dus de yod do/ / rgyal po chen po de la kun du rtog pa gang yin pa dang / gang kun du rtog pa po gang yin pa de gnyis ka yang med do/ / bud med la ni bud med med do/ / skyes pa la ni skyes pa med do/ / de ltar med cing yang dag pa ma yin par kun du rtog pa skye ste/ kun du rtog pa de yang ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ / kun du rtog pa ji lta ba bzhin du phrad pa dang mer mer po yang ngo bo nyid kyis med do/ / gang ngo bo nyid kyis med pa de ji ltar sra ba skyed par 'gyur/ rgyal po chen po de ltar kun du rtog pa shes par byas nas sra ba nyid rtog par bya ste/ ci nas sra ba ni skye ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong bar shes par bya'o/ /

“Your Majesty, there are times when a woman internally thinks ‘I am a woman.’ After thinking internally ‘I am a woman,’ she thinks, about an external man, ‘A man!’ After thinking, about an external man, ‘A man!’, she becomes passionate and longs for sexual union with an external man. A man also thinks internally ‘I am a man,’ as before.[viii] Because of their mutual desire for sexual union, they have sex. With sexual union as a condition, an embryo arises. Here, Your Majesty, that postulation and the one who postulates both do not exist. In the woman, no woman can be found. In the man, no man can be found. Inaccurate postulation arises with no referent. That postulation also has no intrinsic nature. Just as the postulation is, so is the union also. The embryo also does not exist by having intrinsic nature. And how can that which does not exist by having intrinsic nature give rise to solidity? Your Majesty, once you know postulation, you should understand hardness. When hardness arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere; when it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere as a collection.”

rgyal po chen po 'di ltar gang lus 'di dur khrod kyi mthar 'gyur ba'i dus de yod do/ / de'i sra ba de 'jig cing 'gag par 'gyur ba'i tshe/ shar phyogs su mi 'gro/ lho phyogs dang / nub phyogs dang / byang phyogs dang / steng dang 'og dang / phyogs mtshams rnams su yang mi 'gro ste/ rgyal po chen po nang gi sa'i khams ni de ltar blta'o/ /

[246] “Your Majesty, there are times when this body ends up in the charnel-ground. When its solidity softens and is destroyed, it does not go to the east, or the south, or the west, or the north, or up, or down, or to the intermediate directions. Your Majesty, this is how you should understand the internal earth element.”

rgyal po chen po 'jig rten gnas pa 'di nam mkhar gyur pa la/ tshangs pa'i gzhal med khang rin po che sna bdun gyi rgyu las grub pa la gnas pa'i dus de yod do/ / rgyal po chen po de'i sra ba de 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ngo / / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed kyi lha rnams kyi gzhal med khang rin po che sna bdun gyi rgyu las grub pa byung yang rgyal po chen po de'i sra ba de 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ngo / / khor yug dang khor yug chen po'i ri rdo rje'i rgyu las grub pa sra zhing brtan la lhun stug pa rnams gnas par gyur kyang de dag gi sra ba de 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ngo / / ri'i rgyal po ri rab dag dang / gnya' shing 'dzin dag dang / mu khyud 'dzin dag dang / gshol mda' 'dzin dag dang / rdo rje 'dzin dag dang / seng ldeng can dag dang / rnam par 'dud dag dang / ri rta rna dag dang / blta na sdug dag dang / blta na sdug chen po dag dang / ther sgre dag dang / spos kyi ngad ldang dag dang / gangs kyi ri dag dang / de ma yin pa'i ri nag po'i bar dag gnas pa dag dang / thams cad dang ldan pa'i stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams gnas pa dag dang / rngams su dpag tshad brgyad khri bzhi stong yod la rgyar dpag tshad drug khri yod pa'i sa chen po gnas par gyur kyang rgyal po chen po sra ba de 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ngo / /

“Your Majesty, there are times when this world goes up into the sky and stands on the palace of the Brahmā gods, which is made of great gems.[ix] Your Majesty, when that hardness arises, it does not come from anywhere.[x] There are the Cakravāla and Mahācakravāla mountains, firm, substantial, massive, made of diamond. When the hardness of those arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere. There are also the Mounts Meru, the kings of mountains; the Yugaṃdharā, Nimiṃdharā, Īśādhārā, and so on up to the Black Mountains.[xi] And there is the whole three-billion-fold world-realm. And there is this Great Earth, eighty-four thousand leagues in height and eight million six hundred thousand leagues in extent.[xii] Even that solidity, when it comes together, does not come from anywhere.”

rgyal po chen po 'jig rten 'di 'jig par 'gyur ba'i tshe sa chen po 'di mes tshig pa'am/ chus bshig pa'am/ rlung gis gtor bar 'gyur ba'i dus de yod do/ / de mes tshig na ni du ba yang mi mngon thal ba'i lhag ma yang mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / 'di lta ste dper na/ mar ram 'bru mar mes bsregs na du ba yang mi mngon zhing thal ba'i lhag ma yang mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du stong gsum gyi stong chen po 'jig rten gyi khams 'di mes tshig pa'i tshe du ba yang mi mngon zhing thal ba'i lhag ma yang mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / chus bshig pa'i tshe/ yang lhag ma ci yang mi mngon par 'gyur te/ 'di lta ste dper na lan tshwa chu'i nang du zhu ba ni lhag ma cung zad mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'di yang chus bshig pa'i tshe lhag ma cung zad kyang mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / rlung gis gtor ba'i tshe yang lhag ma cung zad kyang mi mngon par 'gyur te/ 'di lta ste dper na rnam par 'thor rlung gis bdas pa'i bye'u ni lhag ma cung zad kyang mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'di yang rlung gis gtor ba'i tshe lhag ma cung zad kyang mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po chen po de ltar sa'i khams de 'byung ba yang stong / sa'i khams 'jig pa dang 'byung ba yang ngo bo nyid kyis stong ngo / / rgyal po chen po'i sa'i khams ni tha snyad tsam ma gtogs par sa'i khams nyid du mi dmigs te/ tha snyad de yang bud med ma yin/ skyes pa ma yin gyi/ rgyal po chen po de ltar yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin gyi shes rab kyis rtogs shig /

“Your Majesty, there are times when this world is destroyed, and this Great Earth is either burned by fire, or smashed by water, or scattered by wind. When it is burned by fire, no smoke appears. As, for example, when clarified butter or vegetable oil is burned by fire, neither smoke nor ashes can be discerned; in just the same way, when this three-billion-fold world-realm is burned by fire, neither smoke nor any remainder of ashes can be discerned. Similarly, it is like when salt is dissolved by water, or when a bird is struck by a hurricane wind: nothing left of the Earth can be discerned.[xiii] Here, Your Majesty, the arising of the earth element is empty, and its ceasing is empty. The arisen earth element is also empty. For, Your Majesty, the earth element is not apprehended as the earth element except in virtue of social convention. And this “social convention” is not a woman and is not a man. Your Majesty, you should understand it as it actually is with correct wisdom in this way.”

rgyal po chen po de la chu'i khams ni rnam pa gnyis te/ nang dang / phyi rol gyi'o/ / nang gi chu'i khams gang zhe na/ gang ci yang rung ste lus 'di la nang gi khong na chu dang chu'i rnam pa dang chu nyid dang / rlan pa dang / rlan pa'i rnam pa dang rlan pa nyid dang gsher ba nyid dang / nye bar gyur pa dang zin pa'o/ /

[247] “{Your Majesty, here the water element has two aspects: internal and external. What is the internal water element?}[xiv] Whatever in this body, internal and personal, is water or has become water; wetness, liquid, liquidity, fluidity, appropriated and grasped.

de yang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ mchi ma dang / rdul dang / mchil ma dang / snabs dang / chu ser dang / tshil dang / mkhris pa dang / ngar snabs dang / rnag dang / khrag dang / 'o ma dang / gcin dang / gzhan yang gang lus 'di'i nang gi khong na/ chu dang chu'i rnam pa dang chu nyid dang rlan pa dang rlan pa'i rnam pa dang rlan pa nyid dang gsher ba nyid dang / nye bar gyur pa dang zin pa 'di ni nang gi chu'i khams zhes bya'o/ / de bzhin du sbyar te/
Now, what is that? It is, for example: tears, sweat, mucus, saliva, fatty tissue, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, milk, urine, and so on. This is called the internal water element …

rgyal po chen po'i sdug pa mthong na mchi ma 'byung ba dang / sdug bsngal gyis nyen pa dang chos kyi shugs kyis mchi ma 'byung ba dang rlung gis btab bam/ rnam pa gzhan dag gis kyang mchi ma 'byung ste/ dpyad byas pas kyang nang gi chu'i khams 'phel bar 'gyur ba'i dus de yod de/ rgyal po chen po chu'i khams de 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ngo / /

Your Majesty, there are times when people see their dear ones and shed tears, or when people are struck by suffering or moved by the Teachings and shed tears, or when the wind irritates the eyes and tears flow …[xv] {When analyzed, there are also times when the internal water element increases.} Your Majesty, when the water element arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere.

rgyal po chen po gang nang gi chu'i khams de yongs su skam par 'gyur ba'i dus de yod de/ de yongs su skam zhing 'gag pa'i tshe gang du yang mi 'gro'o/ / rgyal po chen po gang nang gi me'i khams shas che bar gyur na/ des nang gi chu'i khams yongs su gdung bar 'gyur ba'i dus de yod de/ gdungs pa'i tshe gang du yang mi 'gro'o/ / rgyal po chen po de bzhin du nang gi chu'i khams 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong ngo / / 'gag pa'i tshe gang du yang mi 'gro'o/ /

Your Majesty, there are times when the internal water element dries up. When it dries up and ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere[3] …[xvi] {Your Majesty, there are times when the internal fire element increases, and the internal water element is stricken by it. When it is stricken, it doesn’t go anywhere. Your Majesty, in this way the internal water element, when it arises, doesn’t come from anywhere; when it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere.}”

rgyal po chen po gang 'jig rten 'di chags par 'gyur ba'i dus de yod de/ 'jig rten gyi khams 'di chags par 'gyur ba'i tshe/ nam mkha' 'di la kun du sprin shin tu stug po'i tshogs sum cu rtsa gnyis 'khrigs par 'gyur te/ de dag 'khrigs pas thams cad dang ldan pa'i stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'di thams cad g.yogs par 'gyur te/ de las bskal pa bar ma lnga'i bar du gshol mda' tsam gyi char gyi rgyun 'bab po/ / bskal pa bar ma lnga'i bar du glang po che'i pho mtshan tsam gyi char 'bab po/ / bskal pa bar ma lnga'i bar du rgyun mi 'chad pa'i char 'bab po/ / bskal pa bar ma lnga'i bar du thigs pa chen po'i char 'bab po/ / des sa chen po 'di nas tshangs pa'i 'jig rten gyi bar du chus khyab par gang bar 'gyur te/ rgyal po chen po chu'i phung po chen po de 'byung ba'i tshe'ang gang nas mi 'ong ngo / /

“When this world is forming, thirty-two masses of clouds occur. They become dense and cover the entire three-billion-fold world-realm. Then, for five intermediate aeons, a stream of rain falls from Mt. Īṣādhāra.[xvii] For five intermediate aeons, rain falls like the urine of an elephant. For another five, rain falls interruptedly. For another five, rain falls in huge drops. Due to this, the space from this Great Earth up to the Brahmā world becomes completely full of water. Your Majesty, when that vast mass of water arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere.”

rgyal po chen po gang 'jig rten 'di 'jig par 'gyur ba'i dus de yod de/ 'jig rten gyi khams 'jig par 'gyur ba'i tshe/ nyi ma gnyis 'jig rten du 'byung bar 'gyur te/ nyi ma gnyis 'jig rten du byung bas chu mig dang chu bran rnams skam par 'gyur ro/ /

[248] “Your Majesty, there are times when this world is being destroyed, and when a second sun appears in the world. Due to the appearance of the second sun in the world, the springs, ponds, and small rivers dry up.

de nas nyi ma gsum 'jig rten du 'byung ste/ nyi ma gsum 'jig rten du byung ba na chu mig chen po dang chu klung chen po rnams skam par 'gyur ro/ / de nas nyi ma bzhi 'jig rten du 'byung ste/ nyi ma bzhi 'jig rten du byung bas gang nas chu klung chen po bzhi po de dag 'bab pa'i mtsho chen po ma dros pa de de yang thams cad kyi thams cad du skam par 'gyur thim par 'gyur te med par 'gyur ro/ /
Then a third sun appears, and the big springs and great rivers dry up. A fourth sun appears, and the great lake Anavatapta completely dries up.[xviii]

de nas nyi ma lnga 'jig rten du 'byung ste/ nyi ma lnga 'jig rten du byung bas rgya mtsho chen po yang dpag tshad gcig tsam gyi chu yongs su zad cing yongs su 'grib par 'gyur ro/ / dpag tshad gnyis dang / dpag tshad gsum dang / bzhi dang / lnga dang / bcu dang / nyi shu dang / sum cu dang / bzhi bcu dang / dpag tshad lnga bcu tsam gyi chu yongs su zad cing yongs su 'grib par 'gyur ba nas/ dpag tshad bzhi khri'i bar gyi chu las par 'gyur ba dang / shing ta la gnyis tsam nas mchan khung nub tsam dang / ba lang gi rjes kyi chu tsam gyi bar du las par 'gyur ba'i dus de yod do/ /

{Then five suns arise in the world.} Due to the appearance of the fourth sun, the water of the great ocean is destroyed to the depth of a league. Then two leagues are destroyed, then three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, and fifty leagues, and so on until the remaining water is only forty thousand leagues deep. This continues until the water is as deep as the height of two Tāla trees; until it is as deep as the length of a stick;[xix] until only the depth of water in a cow’s footprint is left.

rgyal po chen po gang rgya mtsho chen po de las zil pa phram phrum tsam las par 'gyur ba'i dus de yod do/ / rgyal po chen po gang rgya mtsho chen po de la mdzub mo snubs pa tsam gyi chu'ang ma las par 'gyur ba'i dus de yod do/ / rgyal po chen po de tsam du yang chu'i khams de 'gag pa'i tshe yang gang du yang mi 'gro ste/ shar phyogs dang / lho phyogs dang nub phyogs dang byang phyogs dang steng dang 'og dang / phyogs mtshams rnams su mi 'gro'o/ /

Your Majesty, there are times when, in the great ocean, only scattered drops of water are left … Your Majesty, there are times when there is not even enough water left in the great ocean to moisten your thumb. Your Majesty, that water element, when it ceases, doesn’t go anywhere …[xx] {It doesn’t go east, south, west, north, up, down, or to the intermediate directions.}

rgyal po chen po chu'i khams de ni skye ba yang stong / 'jig pa yang stong / gnas pa'i tshe yang chu'i khams de rang bzhin gyis stong ste/ rgyal po chen po chu'i khams de ni tha snyad tsam ma gtogs par chu'i khams kyis stong zhing mi dmigs pa ste/ tha snyad de yang bud med ma yin/ skyes pa ma yin no zhes bya ba snga ma bzhin no/ /

Your Majesty, the arising of the water element is empty; its ceasing is also empty. Also, while it exists, the water element is empty of intrinsic nature. Your Majesty, the water element is not apprehended as the water element except in virtue of social convention. And that social convention is not a woman and is not a man, as before …”

me'i khams ni rnam pa gnyis te/ nang gi dang / phyi rol gyi'o/ / nang gi me'i khams gang zhe na/ gang ci yang rung ste/ lus 'di la me dang me'i rnam pa dang / dro ba dang dro ba'i rnam pa dang / nye bar gyur pa dang zin pa'o/ /
“{The fire element has two aspects: internal and external.} What is the internal fire element? Whatever in this body is fire, has become fire, has become heat, appropriated and grasped.

de yang gang zhe na/ gang gis lus 'di gdung ba dang / kun du gdung ba dang yongs su gdung ba dang / gang gis zos pa dang 'thungs pa dang / 'chos pa dang myangs pa rnams bde zhing legs par zhu bar 'gyur ba dang / gang gi shas che na/ rim mo rim mo zhes bya ba'i grangs su 'gro ba dang zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ /

What is that? That through which this body is hot, is heated; or that by which what is eaten, drunk, and consumed[xxi] is digested easily and well. And that due to the excess of which a person is called “feverish” goes on the list.[xxii]

phyi rol gyi me'i khams gang zhe na/ gang phyi rol gyi me dang me'i rnam pa dang / dro ba dang dro ba'i rnam pa dang / nye bar ma gyur pa dang ma zin pa ste/ de dag ni mi dag gtsub shing dang ldan pa dang rtswa dang ldan pa'am/ ba lang gi lci ba'i sbur ma'am shing bal gyi 'da' ba dang ldan par byas shing me 'byin te/ de byung nas grong yang tshig grong gi phyogs kyang tshig / grong khyer ram grong khyer gyi phyogs sam yul lam yul gyi phyogs sam/ gling ngam/ rtswa'i gtos sam/ nags sam/ shing ngam/ rtswa'am/ ba lang gi lci ba dag sreg cing 'gro ba dang zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / rgyal po chen po de la phyi rol gyi me'i khams ni 'byung ba'i tshe'ang gang nas kyang mi 'ong / 'gag pa'i tshe yang gang du yang mi 'gro ste/ de ni rang bzhin dang bral ba'i phyir med pa/ las yod par 'gyur zhing yod par gyur nas kyang med par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ /

What is the external fire-element? Whatever on the outside is fire or has become fire, {is heat or} has become heat, not appropriated and not grasped.[xxiii] Now what is that? It’s what people seek to bring out with fire-sticks, grass, cow-dung, chaff, or cotton.[xxiv] When it has arisen, it burns a village,[xxv] {or part of a village, or a city, or part of a city, or a region, or part of a region.} or an island, or a pile of grass, or a forest, or wood, or cow-dung,[xxvi] and goes on burning. Here, Your Majesty, when the internal[xxvii] fire element arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere. When it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere.[xxviii] It doesn’t exist, then it exists; and having existed, it disappears again, because it has no intrinsic nature …”
de la nang gi rlung gi khams gang zhe na/ gang lus 'di la rlung dang rlung gi rnam pa dang / yang ba nyid dang g.yo ba nyid dang / nye bar gyur pa dang zin pa'o/ /
“{Here what is the internal wind element?} In the same way, whatever in this body is wind or has become wind, lightness and mobility,[xxix] {appropriated and grasped.}

de yang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ gyen du 'gro ba'i rlung dang / thur du 'gro ba dang / thad kar 'gro ba dang / rgyab tu 'gro ba dang / rgyab na gnas pa dang / lto na gnas pa dang / 'chad par byed pa dang / 'gas par byed pa dang / gzer ba dang / 'dar bu dang / sna skad dang / rlung skran dang / dbugs 'byung ba dang / rngub pa dang ldan pa dang / yan lag dang yan lag la gnas pa'i rlung dag dang zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / phyi rol gyi rlung de yang shar phyogs kyi rlung yod do/ / lho phyogs dang / nub phyogs dang / byang phyogs kyi rlung yod do/ / rdul dang bcas pa dang / rdul med pa dang chung ba dang che ba'i rlung yod do/ / kun du khyab pa'i rlung dang / rnam par 'thor ba'i rlung dang / tshub ma'i rlung dag kyang yod do/ /

Now, what is that? It is, for example: the upward-going winds, the downward-going winds, those based in the ribs,[xxx] those based in the back, those going to the belly, swordlike, razorlike, and needlelike winds, shivering,[xxxi] swellings below the navel,[xxxii] rheumatism, the in-breath and the out-breath, and winds that stay in the limbs. Externally, there are east winds, south winds, west and north winds, with dust or without dust, small and great winds,[xxxiii] {all-pervading wind, scattering wind, and storm winds.}”

rgyal po chen po rlung gi phung po chen po langs na shing dag kyang gcog / rtsig pa'i kha dag dang ri'i rtse mo dag kyang bsnyil zhing bsnyil nas rmeg med par 'gyur ba dag dang / yang sems can dag gos kyi mtha' ma'am sbud pa'am rlung g.yab dag gis rlung g.yob pa'i dus de yod do/ / gzhan yang gang tshul 'di dang 'dra ba de ni phyi rol gyi rlung gi khams zhes bya ba la sogs pa snga ma bzhin no// //

[249] “Your Majesty, there are times when a great mass of wind arrives and knocks down the tallest trees, and even knocks down the tops of walls and mountain peaks, and after knocking them down, disperses without a trace. Also, what sentient beings seek with the edge of a robe, or with a bellows, or with a fan, is called the external wind element. When it arises … and so on as before.[xxxiv]”
bam po bcu gcig pa/

nang gi nam mkha'i khams gang zhe na/ gang ci yang rung ste/ lus 'di la nang gi khong na nye bar gyur pa dang / zin pa dang / nam mkha' dang nam mkha'i rnam pa nang zhes bya ba'i grangs su 'gro ba/ ma gang ba dang pags pa dang sha dang khrag gis gang bar bya ba ma yin pa'o/ / de yang gang zhe na/ lus 'di la mig gi nang zhe'am/ rna ba dang / sna'i nang zhe'am/ kha'am kha'i nang zhe'am/ kha'i sgo zhe'am/ lkog ma zhe'am/ mid pa zhe'am/ gang nas kyang mid pa dang / gang du gnas pa dang / gang gis zos pa dang 'thungs pa dang 'chos pa dang myangs pa rnams thur du rgyu bar byed pa dang / gzhan yang gang lus 'di la nang gi khong na nye bar gyur pa dang / zin pa dang / phung por gyur pa'am khams su gyur pa'am skye mched du gyur pa dag ni nam mkha'i dang / nam mkha'i rnam pa dang / ma gang ba dang pags pa dang sha dang khrag gis gang bar bya ba ma yin pa nang gi grangs su 'gro ba khong stong dang bu ga zhes bya ba dag ste/ de dag ni nang gi nam mkha'i khams zhes bya'o/ / phyi rol gyi nam mkha'i khams gang zhe na/ gang ci yang rung ste/ phyi rol gyi nam mkha' dang nam mkha'i rnam pa dang / ma gang ba dang / gzugs su gyur pas gang bar bya ba ma yin pa/ ma 'dres pa khong stong dang bu gar gyur pa 'di ni phyi rol gyi nam mkha'i khams zhes bya'o/ /

“What is the internal space element? Whatever in this body is space or has become space, internal and personal, appropriated and grasped, goes on the list: what is not full, not filled up with skin, flesh, and blood. Now, what is that? In this body, the eye-socket, or the mouth, or the opening of the mouth, or the throat, or the esophagus; {the empty cavities and holes} where what is ingested remains, or where what is eaten, drunk, consumed, and savored flows downward,[xxxv] are the internal space element. What is the external space element? Whatever externally is not full, not filled by forms, not mixed, existing as a receptacle or perforated, this is called the external space element.”

rgyal po chen po gang las kyi rkyen gyis skye mched rnams 'byung ba'i dus de yod do/ / de dag nam mkha'i khams la kun nas skor bar byed do/ / de nang gi nam mkha'i khams zhes bya ba'i grangs su 'gro yang de ni gang las kyang ma 'ongs so/ / rgyal po chen po gzugs zhig na thams cad nam mkha' 'gyur ba'i dus de yod do/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ nam mkha'i khams ni zad mi shes pa'i phyir ro/ / de lta na nang gi nam mkha'i khams ni gnas shing mi g.yo ba'o/ / rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na/ 'dus ma byas de ni mya ngan las 'das pa'i dbyings te/ de bzhin du nam mkha'i khams kyang thams cad du song bar blta bar bya'o/ /

“Your Majesty, there are times when, with karma as a condition, the sense-spheres manifest, and they move around in the space element. The internal space-element goes on the list, but it does not come from anywhere. There are times when form ceases and everything becomes space.[xxxvi] Why is this? The space element is indestructible, stable, and unmoving. Your Majesty, just as the expanse of Nirvāṇa is uncompounded, in the same way, the space element should be seen as all-pervasive.”
