rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na/ mi zhig gis thang la khron pa'am rdzing bu'am khron ring ngam rdzing zhig brkos na/ rgyal po chen po 'di ji snyam du sems/ de'i nam mkha' de ga las 'ongs/ gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni gang las kyang ma mchis so/ / rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na/ me des khron pa nas rdzing gi bar de dag phyir bkang na rgyal po chen po de ji snyam du sems/ de'i nam mkha' de gang du song / gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni gang du yang ma mchis te/ de'i slad du zhe na/ nam mkha'i khams ni 'gro ba'am 'ong bar nye bar gnas pa ma lags/ bud med kyi dngos po dang skyes pa'i dngos por nye bar gnas pa ma lags pa'i slad du'o/ / bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po de ltar na phyi rol gyi nam mkha'i khams ni mi g.yo mi 'gyur ba'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ nam mkha'i khams ni nam mkha'i khams kyis stong zhing nam mkha'i khams dang bral ba ste/ nam mkha'i khams ni bud med kyi dngos por nye bar mi gnas/ skyes pa'i dngos por nye bar mi gnas kyis/ de ltar yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag pa'i shes rab kyis rtogs shig /

“Your Majesty, for example, suppose someone in a sandy place were to dig a small pool, or a pool, or a well, or a lotus-pond. Your Majesty, what do you think about this? The space there: where did it come from?” [250] He replied, “Not from anywhere, Blessed One.” “Your Majesty, for another example, suppose that person filled up the small pool … or the lotus-pond. Your Majesty, what do you think about this? That space: did it go anywhere?” He replied, “Blessed One, it didn’t go anywhere. What is the reason? The space element has nothing to do with coming or going. It has nothing to do with femininity or masculinity.” The Blessed One said, “For, Your Majesty, the external space element is unmoving and unchanging. Why is this? The space element is empty of being the space element. The space element is deprived of ‘being the space element.’ It has nothing to do with masculinity or femininity. It should be seen as it actually is with correct knowledge in this way.”

rgyal po chen po de la rnam par shes pa'i khams gang zhe na/ mig gi dbang po ni bdag po/ / gzugs ni dmigs pa/ gzugs so sor rnam par rig pa ste/ sngon po rnam par rig pa'am/ ser po dang dmar po dang khra bo rnam par rig pa'am/ ring po dang thung ngu dang / sbom po dang phra mo rnam par rig pa ste/ rgyal po chen po de ltar gang ci yang rung / kha dog dang dbyibs rnam par rig pa 'di ni mig gi rnam par shes pa'i khams zhes bya'o/ / de bzhin du gang ci yang rung / rna ba'i dbang po ni bdag po nas/ yid kyi dbang po ni bdag po/ / chos ni dmigs pa ste/ sgra rnam par rig pa'am/ dri rnam par rig pa'am/ ro rnam par rig pa'am/ rig pa rnam par rig pa'am/ chos rnam par rig pa 'di ni/ rna ba'i rnam par shes pa'i khams nas yid kyi rnam par shes pa'i khams kyi bar te/ de ltar dbang po drug ni bdag po/ / yul drug ni dmigs pa yin la/ yul rnam par rig pa 'di ni rnam par shes pa'i khams zhes bya'o/ /

“Here what is the consciousness element? That which presides over the sense of sight,[xxxvii] the recognition that takes forms as its objects, {individually recognizing forms, recognizing blue, or yellow, or red, long and short, coarse and subtle,}[xxxviii]—Your Majesty, in this way, whatever it is that recognizes colors and shapes, that is the visual consciousness element. {In the same way, whatever it is that presides over the sense of hearing … presides over introspection, having experiences as its objects; recognizes sounds, or recognizes scents, or recognizes tastes, or recognizes touchables, or recognizes experiences, this is the auditory consciousness element, and so on up to: the introspective consciousness element.} In this way, that which presides over the six senses, representing the six sense-objects and recognizing objects, this is called ‘the consciousness element.’ ”

rgyal po chen po rnam par shes pa'i khams de ni dbang po la mi brten/ yul rnams las ma 'ongs/ bar gyi dbus na mi gnas te/ de ni nang na yang ma yin/ phyi rol na yang ma yin/ gnyi ga med par yang ma yin no/ / rnam par shes pa'i khams de ni dngos po so sor rnam par rig nas 'gag ste/ de 'byung ba'i tshe gang nas kyang ma 'ongs/ 'gag pa'i tshe gang du yang mi 'gro'o/ / rnam par shes pa'i khams de 'byung ba yang stong / 'jig pa yang stong ste/ rnam par shes pa'i khams de 'byung ba yang rang bzhin gyis stong ngo / / rgyal po chen po de ltar na/ tha snyad ma gtogs par rnam par shes pa'i khams de ni rnam par shes pa'i khams nyid kyis stong ste/ tha snyad de yang skyes pa ma yin/ bud med ma yin gyi/ de ni de ltar yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag pa'i shes rab kyis rtogs shig /

“Now, Your Majesty, this consciousness element is not based in the sense-faculty; it does not come from objects; it does not stand in between. It is not internal, not external, and also it isn’t neither. Your Majesty, the consciousness element recognizes an object and then disappears. When it arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere; when it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere. Here the arising of the consciousness element is empty; its disappearance is empty; and the arisen consciousness element is also empty of intrinsic nature. Your Majesty, the consciousness element is empty of being the consciousness element, and is not apprehended except in virtue of social convention. And that social convention is not a woman, is not a man. You should understand it as it actually is with correct wisdom in this way.”

rgyal po chen po de la mig gi skye mched gang zhe na/ de ni 'byung ba chen po bzhi dang ba ste/ 'di ltar sa'i khams dang / chu'i khams dang / me'i khams dang / rlung gi khams so/ / de la sa'i khams dang ba ni skye mched ma yin no/ / chu'i khams dang ba yang ma yin no/ / me'i khams dang ba yang ma yin no/ / rlung gi khams dang ba yang mig gi skye mched ma yin no/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sa'i khams dang ba ni chos gang la yang skye mched dam skye mched thob par bya bar nye bar mi gnas so/ / de bzhin du rlung gi khams kyi bar dang ba ni tshes gang la yang skye mched dam skye mched thob par bya bar nye bar mi gnas so/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ chos de dag ni sems pa med cing byed pa med la ci la yang mi nus pa ste/ rgyal po chen po chos rnams ni re re nas btsal na tha snyad tsam ma gtogs par mig gi skye mched mi dmigs so/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ sa'i khams dang ba ni sa'i khams dang bas stong / rlung gi khams dang ba'i bar ni rlung gi khams dang bas stong ste/ chos gang dag rang bzhin gyis stong pa de dag la dang ba'am 'khrugs par 'gyur ba'ang ga la yod de/ gang la yang dang ba'am 'khrugs pa mi dmigs pa de dag ji ltar gzugs la lta bar 'gyur/ de ltar mig gi skye mched ni mig gi skye mched kyi rang bzhin gyis shin tu stong ste/ de ni 'ong ba dang 'gro ba med pa'i phyir sngon gyi mtha' yang mi dmigs phyi ma'i mtha' yang mi dmigs so/ / rang bzhin med pa'i phyir de la gnas pa yang mi dmigs so/ / gang rang bzhin gyis med pa de ni bud med kyang ma yin skyes pa yang ma yin no/ / gang bud med kyang ma yin skyes pa yang ma yin pa de ni des rlom sems su lta ga la 'gyur te/ rgyal po chen po rlom sems ni bdud kyi spyod yul lo/ / rlom sems med pa ni sangs rgyas kyi spyod yul lo/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ chos thams cad ni rlom sems dang bral ba'o/ /

[251] “Here, Your Majesty, what is the visual sense-sphere? It is [said to be] the clarity of the four great elements. These are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the wind element. Here the clarity of the earth element is not the visual sense-sphere; and the clarity of the water element, the clarity of the fire element, and the clarity of the wind element also are not the visual sense-sphere. Why is this? The clarity of the earth element is not a sense-sphere for anything at all, and has nothing to do with perceiving. And so on up to: the clarity of the wind element is not a sense-sphere for anything at all, and has nothing to do with perceiving. Why is this? These entities are unconscious and inactive,[xxxix] like Nirvāṇa. Your Majesty, if you search through entities one by one, then except in virtue of social convention, you don’t apprehend any visual sense-sphere. Why is this? The clarity of the earth element is empty of the clarity of the earth element, and so on up to: the clarity of the wind element is empty of the clarity of the wind element. And when things are empty of intrinsic nature, how can they have any clarity or agitation? And when, in certain things, no clarity or agitation is apprehended, how can those things see forms? In this way, the visual sense-sphere is utterly empty of any intrinsic nature of the visual sense-sphere. Because it has no coming or going, it is not apprehended in the past, and also is not apprehended in the future; and because it has no intrinsic nature, its present existence is also not apprehended. And that which intrinsically cannot be found is not a woman and is not a man.[xl] Therefore, what is reification?[xli] Indeed, Your Majesty, reification is the domain of Māra; nonreification is the domain of the Buddhas. Why is this? Because all things are free from reification
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rgyal po chen po de la rna ba'i skye mched nas lus kyi skye mched kyi bar gang zhe na/ gang 'byung ba chen po bzhi dang ba'o/ / rgyal po chen po de ltar na chos thams cad kyi bar ni/ rnam par thar pa la mngon par phyogs pa chos kyi dbyings su nges pa/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas klas pa/ gdags su med pa/ tha snyad med pa/ brjod du med pa/ brjod par bya ba ma yin pa'o/ / rgyal po chen po gang la dbang po rnams thogs par 'gyur ba de ni yul rnams zhes bya ste/ mig gis gzugs rnams la thogs par 'gyur ba de'i phyir gzugs rnams ni mig gi yul zhes bya'o/ / de bzhin du rna ba'i sgra rnams zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / de la mig gzugs rnams la thogs so zhes bya ba 'di ni 'bab pa'i thogs par 'gyur bar bstan te/ 'di ltar mig ni gzugs rnams la rnam pa gsum du 'bab ste/ mthun pa rnams la sdug pa'i 'du shes kyis 'bab pa dang / mi mthun pa rnams la khong khro ba'i 'du shes kyis 'bab pa dang / mthun pa yang ma yin mi mthun pa yang ma yin pa rnams la btang snyoms kyi 'du shes kyis 'bab pa/ / de bzhin du yid ni chos rnams la zhes bya ba la sogs pa ste/ yul de dag ni yid kyi spyod yul zhes bya ba ste/ de la yid spyod cing rnam par spyod pas de'i phyir yid kyi spyod yul zhes bya'o/ /

“Here, Your Majesty, what is the auditory sense-sphere? It is [said to be] the clarity of the four great elements … Your Majesty, in this way, all things are turned toward freedom, fixed in the realm of totality, reducible to the space element,[xlii] unfindable,[xliii] free from social convention, inexpressible, ineffable. Your Majesty, where the senses make contact, those are called ‘objects.’ The eye makes contact with forms; therefore, forms are called ‘objects of vision.’ In the same way, the ear with sounds, and so on. Here ‘the eye makes contact with forms’ is explained to mean contact in the sense of ‘alighting upon.’ In this manner, the eye alights on forms in three ways: it alights on agreeable objects, conceiving of them as beautiful; it alights on disagreeable objects, conceiving of them as hostile; it alights on objects that are neither agreeable nor disagreeable with indifference. It’s the same for the mind in relation to experiences, and so on. Those objects are called ‘the domain of mind.’ Those things towards which the mind acts and responds are called for that reason ‘the domain of mind.’ ”

rgyal po chen po yid de mthun pa'i gzugs rnams la rjes su chags par spyod pa des ni de'i 'dod chags skye bar 'gyur/ mi mthun pa'i gzugs rnams la khong khro bar spyod pa des ni de'i zhe sdang skye bar 'gyur/ mthun pa yang ma yin mi mthun pa yang ma yin pa rnams la rmongs par spyod pa des ni de'i gti mug skye bar 'gyur te/ de bzhin du sgra dang dri dang ro dang reg bya rnams la yang chos rnam pa gsum gsum la dmigs pa myong bar 'gyur te snga ma bzhin no/ / rgyal po chen po de la dbang po rnams ni sgyu ma lta bu yul rnams ni rmi lam lta bur shes par bya'o/ / rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na mi zhig nyal ba'i rmi lam na yul gyi bzang mo dang lhan cig tu yongs su spyod par rmis la/ de nyal ba las sad nas bud med yul gyi bzang mo de rjes su dran par gyur na/ rgyal po chen po 'di ji snyam du sems/ rmi lam na mthong ba'i yul gyi bzang mo de yod dam gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni ma mchis so/ / bka' stsal pa rgyal po chen po 'di ji snyam du sems skyes bu gang rmi lam na yul gyi bzang mo mthong ba'i bud med de dang lhan cig tu rtse ba dang dga' ba dang / mngon par zhen par 'gyur ba de mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can yin nam gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags te/ de ci'i slad du zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das rmi lam ni mthong ba'i yul gyi bzang mo de ni shin tu ma mchis shing mi dmigs na/ de dang lhan cig tu yongs su spyod pa lta ga la mchis te gzhan du na gang de la zhen pa'i mi de ni shin tu phongs shing dub pa'i skal ba can du 'gyur ro/ /

[252] “Your Majesty, when it operates towards forms that are cherished as agreeable to the mind, attraction arises. When it operates towards forms that are opposed as disagreeable to the mind, aversion arises. When it operates in a confused way towards those that are neither agreeable nor disagreeable, delusion arises about them. In the same way, as regards sounds, {scents, tastes, and touchables,} it experiences objects in three ways,[xliv] as before.” “Here, Your Majesty, the senses are like illusions, and their objects are like dreams. For example, Your Majesty, suppose that a sleeping man, in a dream, played around with a woman, a local beauty, and when he awoke from his sleep, he would remember that woman, the local beauty. What do you think about this, Your Majesty? The woman, the local beauty in the dream—does she exist?” He replied, “No indeed, Blessed One.” The Blessed One said, “What do you think about this, Your Majesty? A man who would remember a woman, a local beauty, from a dream, and who would be emotionally involved with amusing himself with her—would he be one of the wise?” He replied, “No indeed, Blessed One. Why is that? For, Blessed One, the local beauty in the dream is utterly nonexistent and is not apprehended, so how could there be such a thing as playing around with her? Otherwise, that man who would get emotionally involved with her would end up with weariness and disappointment.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po de bzhin du byis pa so so'i skye bo thos pa dang mi ldan pa yang mig gis gzugs mthong na yid bde bar 'gyur ba rnams la mngon par zhen par 'gyur te/ de mngon par zhen nas rjes su chags par 'gyur ro/ / rjes su chags par gyur nas yongs su chags par 'gyur ro/ / yongs su chags par gyur nas 'dod chags las byung ba'i lus kyis ni rnam pa gsum ngag gis ni rnam pa bzhi yid kyis ni rnam pa gsum mngon par 'du byed de/ las mngon par 'du byas pa de yang thog ma nyid nas zad cing 'gags la bral zhing rnam par 'gyur ba ste/ shar phyogs su brten te gnas pa ma yin/ lho phyogs dang nub phyogs dang byang phyogs dang / steng dang / 'og dang / phyogs mtshams rnams su brten te gnas pa ma yin/ 'di na ma yin pha bi na ma yin par bar ma dor ma yin te/ dus gzhan na 'chi ba'i dus dang tshod nye bar gnas pa'i tshe/ srog gi dbang po 'gags te tshe yongs su zad cing de dang skal ba 'dra ba'i las rnams kyang zad nas rnam par shes pa tha ma 'gags pa'i tshe/ 'di lta ste dper na nyal nyal ba las sad pa'i yul gyi bzang mo dang 'dra bar yid kyis dmigs par 'gyur ro/ / rgyal po chen po de la rnam par shes pa tha ma'i dbang dang las dmigs pa de dang rkyen gnyis kyis skye ba'i char gtogs pa'i rnam par shes pa dang po 'byung ste/ yang na ni sems can dmyal bar/ yang na ni dud 'gro'i skye gnas su/ yang na ni gshin rje'i 'jig rten du/ yang na ni lha ma yin gyi ris su/ yang na ni mi'i nang du/ yang na ni lha'i nang du skye bar 'gyur te/ rnam par shes pa dang po skye ba'i char gtogs pa de/ de 'gags ma thag tu bar ma chad par/ gang la rnam par smin pa myong bar 'gyur ba mngon pa'i sems kyi rgyud skal ba 'dra bar 'byung ngo / /

[253] The Blessed One said, “In just the same way, Your Majesty, a foolish, untrained ordinary person sees forms with the eye that are sources of mental pleasure, and becomes emotionally involved with them. Being emotionally involved, he becomes attached. Being attached, he is strongly attracted. Being strongly attracted, he performs actions born from attachment: three kinds with the body, four kinds with speech, three kinds with the mind.[4] And after performing these actions, he is ruined, is destroyed, dies, and is transformed. In the eastern direction, he has no stable place to stand; nor in the south, nor the west, nor the north, nor up, nor down, nor in the intermediate directions; not here, nor far away, nor in between the two. Now, while he is dying, at the time of death, when the life-faculties are stopping due to the exhaustion of the life-span and the running out of the karma in the category of his karmic fortune, [those pleasurable forms] come to mind—just as, for example, the local beauty might come to the mind of the man after waking. Your Majesty, by the dominant influence of the last moment of consciousness, and with that action as object, through two conditions at the time of birth, the first moment of consciousness arises: perhaps in the hells, perhaps in an animal womb, perhaps in the world of Yama, perhaps in a titan’s body, perhaps among humans, or perhaps among the gods. And from that first moment of consciousness at the time of birth, as soon as it ceases, immediately a similar mental series unfolds, in which the experiencing of the result of evolution can be discerned.”

de la gang rnam par shes pa tha ma 'gag pa de ni 'chi 'pho zhes bya ba'i grangs su 'gyur ro/ / gang rnam par shes pa dang po 'byung ba de la ni skye ba zhes bya'o/ / rgyal po chen po de lta na chos gang yang 'jig rten 'di nas 'jig rten pha rol du 'pho ba'ang med la 'chi 'pho dang skye bar mngon pa'ang yod de/ rgyal po chen po rnam par shes pa tha ma de skye ba'i tshe yang gang nas kyang mi 'ong / / 'gag pa'i tsho gang du yang mi 'gro'o/ / las kyang skye ba'i tshe gang nas kyang mi 'ong 'gag pa'i tshe gang du yang mi 'gro'o/ / rnam par shes pa dang po skye ba'i tshe yang gang nas kyang mi 'ong 'gag pa'i tshe yang gang du yang mi 'gro'o/ /

[254] “Here the enumeration goes: The ceasing of the final consciousness is death. When the first moment of consciousness becomes manifest, that is birth. For, Your Majesty, there is nothing that goes from this world to the next that produces death and birth. Here, Your Majesty, the last moment of consciousness, when it arises, doesn’t come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere. Also, when karma arises, it doesn’t come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere. The first moment of consciousness, when it arises, doesn’t come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it doesn’t go anywhere.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ ngo bo nyid med pa'i phyir te/ rnam par shes pa tha ma ni rnam par shes pa tha mas stong / las ni las kyis stong / rnam par shes pa dang po ni rnam par shes pa dang pos stong / 'chi 'pho ni 'chi 'phos stong / skye ba ni skye bas stong la/ las rnams 'bras bu med par mi 'gyur zhing rnam par smin pa myong bar mngon pa yang yod de/ de la ming gi brda tsam ma gtogs par byed pa po'am za ba po gang yang med do/ /

Why is that? Because it has no intrinsic nature. The last moment of consciousness is empty of the last moment of consciousness. Action is empty of action. The first moment of consciousness is empty of the first moment of consciousness. Death is empty of death. Birth is empty of birth. And actions are discerned not to be barren; the result of evolution is experienced. And here, there is no agent, nor any subject of experience, otherwise than through verbal designation.”

rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na/ mi zhig nyal ba'i rmi lam na dgra dang 'thab pa zhig rmis la/ nyal ba las sad nas de nyid dran par gyur na/ rgyal po chen po 'di ji snyam du sems rmi lam du rmis pa'i dgra de'am dgra de dang 'thab pa yod dam/ gsol pa bcom ldan 'das de ni ma mchis so/ / bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po 'di ji snyam du sems 'o na skyes bu gang rmi lam gyi dgra la mngon par zhen pa'am/ dgra dang 'thab par 'gyur ba de mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can yin nam/ gsol pa bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags te/ de ci'i slad du zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das rmi lam na mthong ba'i dgra de nyid kyang shin tu ma mchis shing mi dmigs na de dang 'thab pa lta ga la mchis te gzhan du na gang de la mngon par zhen pa'i mi de ni phongs shing dub pa'i skal ba can du 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po de bzhin du byis pa so so'i skye bo thos pa dang mi ldan pa yang mig gis gzugs mthong na yid mi bde bar 'gyur ba rnams la yang mngon par zhen par 'gyur te mngon par zhen nas khong khro bar 'gyur ro/ / khong khro bar gyur nas zhe sdang bar 'gyur/ zhe sdang bar gyur nas zhe sdang las byung ba'i las lus kyis ni rnam pa gsum ngag gis ni rnam pa bzhi yid kyis ni rnam pa gsum mngon par 'du byed de snga ma bzhin no/ /

“For another example, Your Majesty, suppose that a sleeping man, in a dream, were to fight with an enemy, and when he awoke from his sleep, he remembered doing so. What do you think about this, Your Majesty? The enemy in the dream, or the fight with that enemy—do they exist?” He replied, “No indeed, Blessed One.” The Blessed One said, “What do you think about this, Your Majesty? A man who would become emotionally involved with an enemy in a dream, or the fight with that enemy—would he be among the wise?” He replied, “No indeed, Blessed One. Why is that? For, Blessed One, the enemy in the dream is utterly nonexistent;[xlv] how could there be any such thing as a fight with him? Otherwise, the man who would get emotionally involved with that would end up with weariness and disappointment.” The Blessed One said, “In just the same way, Your Majesty, a foolish untrained ordinary person sees forms with the eye that are sources of unhappiness, and becomes emotionally involved with them. Being emotionally involved, he opposes them. Opposing them, he gets very angry. Being very angry, he performs actions born from anger … and so on as before,[xlvi] {three kinds with the body, four kinds with speech, three kinds with the mind.}.”

rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste/ dper na/ mi zhig gnyid kyis log pa'i rmi lam na 'dres non par rmis te 'jigs pas shin tu rmongs par 'gyur la/ nyal ba las sad nas 'dre dang shin tu rmongs par gyur pa de dran par gyur na/ rgyal po chen po de ji snyam du sems rmi lam na mthong ba'i 'dre de dang shin tu rmongs par gyur pa de yod dam/ gsol pa bcom ldan 'das de ni ma mchis so/ / bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po 'di ji snyam du sems 'o na de ltar rmi lam na mthong ba'i 'dre de la mngon par zhen cing shin tu rmongs par 'gyur ba'i mi de mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can yin nam/ gsol pa bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags te/ de ci'i slad du zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das rmi lam gyi 'dra de ni shin tu ma mchis shing mi dmigs na shin tu rmongs pa lta ga la mchis te/ gzhan du na gang de la mngon par zhen pa'i mi de ni phongs shing dub pa'i skal ba can du 'gyur ro/ /

“For another example, Your Majesty, suppose that a sleeping man, in a dream, were to be attacked by a goblin,[xlvii] and frightened, became confused. When he awoke from his sleep, he would remember the goblin and his confusion. What do you think about this, Your Majesty? The goblin in the dream, and the man’s confusion: do they exist? …”[xlviii] {He replied, ‘No indeed, Blessed One.’ [The Blessed One] said: ‘What do you think about this, Your Majesty? A man who would get emotionally involved with that goblin and became confused—would he be among the wise?’ He replied, ‘No indeed, Blessed One. What is the reason? Blessed One, when the goblin in the dream is completely nonexistent and is not apprehended, how could the confusion exist? Otherwise, the man who would get emotionally involved with that would end up with weariness and disappointment.’}

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po de bzhin du byis pa so so'i skye bo thos pa dang mi ldan pa yang mig gis gzugs mthong na btang snyoms su 'gyur ba rnams la yang mngon par zhen par 'gyur te/ mngon par zhen nas shin tu rmongs par 'gyur ro/ / shin tu rmongs nas kun nas nyon mongs par 'gyur ro/ / kun nas nyon mongs nas gti mug las byung ba'i las lus kyis ni rnam pa gsum ngag gis ni rnam pa bzhi yid kyis ni rnam pa gsum mngon par 'du byed de zhes bya ba la sogs pa snga ma bzhin no/ /

The Blessed One said, “In just the same way, Your Majesty, a foolish untrained ordinary person sees forms with the eye that are objects of indifference, and becomes emotionally involved with them. Being emotionally involved, he is deluded. Deluded, he performs actions born from delusion”[xlix]… {he becomes totally reactive, and having become reactive,” and then “three kinds with the body, four kinds with speech, three kinds with the mind,} and so on as before.

rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na mi zhig nyal ba'i rmi lam na yul gyi bud med bzang mo glu len pa'i glu snyan pa dang pi bang len pa'i sgra snyan pa nyan cing de glu dang rol mo'i sgra des yongs su spyod pa rmis la/ nyal ba las sad nas glu dang rol mo'i sgra de nyid dran par gyur na/ rgyal po chen po 'di ji snyam du sems rmi lam na mthong ba'i yul gyi bud med bzang mo dang / glu dang rol mo'i sgra de yod dam/ gsol pa bcom ldan 'das de ni ma mchis so/ /

“Your Majesty, for example, suppose that a sleeping man, in a dream, saw a local beauty singing, and heard the honeyed sounds of her songs and her lute. Suppose that he enjoyed that singing, and when he woke up, remembered it. What do you think about this, Your Majesty? {Do the local beauty, her singing, and the sound of her musical instrument exist?”} {He replied, “No indeed, Blessed One.”}

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po 'o na rmi lam na mthong ba'i yul gyi bud med bzang mo de glu dang rol mo'i sgra la mngon par zhen pa'i mi de mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can yin nam/ gsol pa bcom ldan 'das de ni ma lags te/ de ci'i slad du zhe na/ rmi lam na mthong ba'i yul gyi bud med bzang mo de ni shin tu ma mchis shing mi dmigs na/ de'i glu dang rol mo'i sgra lta ga la mchis te/ gzhan du na gang de la zhen pa'i mi de ni phongs shing dub pa'i skal ba can du 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po de bzhin du byis pa so so'i skye bo thos pa dang mi ldan pa yang rna bas sgra thos na yid du 'ong ba rnams la mngon par zhen par 'gyur te zhes bya ba la sogs pa snga ma bzhin no/ / de bzhin du dri la sogs pa la yang rnam pa gsum gsum du rig par bya'o/ /

The Blessed One said, “Your Majesty, a man who would become emotionally involved with the local beauty, her singing, and the sound of her musical instrument—would he be among the wise?” He replied, “No indeed, Blessed One.[l] For what reason? When the local beauty seen in the dream is completely nonexistent and is not apprehended, how could her singing and the sound of her musical instrument exist? Otherwise, the man who would become emotionally involved with that would end up with weariness and disappointment.” The Blessed One said, “In just the same way, Your Majesty, a foolish untrained ordinary person hears sounds with the ears that are sources of mental pleasure, and becomes emotionally involved with them” … and so on as before. “In the same way, in the case of scents and so on, there are three types, experienced in three ways”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

rgyal po chen po khyod kyis ji ltar na bdag lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten gyi mig dang / sgron ma dang / mar me dang / snang ba dang / gru dang / ngogs dang / 'bab stegs dang / 'dren pa dang / yongs su 'dren pa dang / ston pa dang / ded dpon dang / sngon du 'gro bar 'gyur snyam pa dang / bdag grol nas dgrol bar bya'o/ / rgal nas bsgral bar bya'o/ / dbugs phyin nas dbugs dbyung bar bya'o/ / yongs su mya ngan las 'das nas yongs su mya ngan las 'da' bar bya'o snyam du yid la gzhag par bya'o/ /

[255] “Here, Your Majesty, with what should you become emotionally involved?[li] You should think, ‘For the world, including the gods, may I become an eye; I have become a torch, a butter-lamp, and a light. [May I become] a shore, a landing-place for boats,[lii] a guide, a leader, a teacher and a caravan-leader. May I swiftly go ahead. Once I am free, may I set others free; once I am full of courage, may I encourage others; once I have reached Nirvāṇa, may I bring others to Nirvāṇa.’ ”

rgyal po chen po dbang phyug lta zhig ni sngon myong bar gyur pa'i mtha' yang mi mngon te/ rgyal po chen po de ltar dbang po rnams ni sgyu ma lta bu ste chog mi shes so/ / tshim par mi 'gyur ba'o/ / yul rnams ni rmi lam lta bu ste tshim par mi nus pa ngoms par mi nus pa'o zhe'o/ / de la 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po grags pa mtha' yas kyi gtam rgyud las mtho ris nas lhung ste/ de'i tshe rgyal po chen po dang grong khyer bas bskor ba las 'di skad 'byung ste/ 'di lta ste/ dper na/ mar gyi gong bu'am/ mar gsar gyi gong bu bye ma tsha ba la gzhag pa ni 'ju zhing mi gnas so/ / de bzhin du rgyal po chen po grags pa mtha' yas kyang bying zhing mi gnas par gyur to/ / de nas rgyal po chen po dga' byed kyis/ rgyal po chen po grags pa mtha' yas de ltar bying ba de la 'di skad ces smras so/ / rgyal po chen po grags pa mtha' yas kyis legs par brjod pa ji skad cig gsungs zhes mchi na bdag gis 'jig rten pa rnams la ji skad cig lung bstan par bgyi/

“Your Majesty, as for the previous experience of political power, it has no evident limit.[liii] For, Your Majesty, the senses are like illusions, unsatisfactory and unsatisfiable. Objects are like dreams, not able to satisfy you, not able to make you content. On this, there is the story of when the world-emperor Anantayaśas[5] fell from heaven. The kings and citizens gathered around. For example, when a ball of clarified butter or fresh butter is thrown down onto heated sand, it sinks down and does not stay. In just the same way, King Anantayaśas was also sinking down and not staying. Then King Priyaṃkara approached the sinking King Anantayaśas and said: ‘Your Majesty, what do we tell the world? What should be said about King Anantayaśas?’

des smras pa/ rgyal po chen po grags pa mtha' yas ni gling chen po bzhir rgyal srid kyi dbang phyug la dbang byas shing bsam pa yid bzhin du grub la don med par ma gyur pa'ang myong / shing thams cad na dus ma yin par yid bzhin du 'bras bu chags pa dang / gnod pa thams cad rgyun chad pa dang / sems can thams cad kyi yid la bsams pa don yod pa dang / spos chu'i char dbab pa dang / lha'i yid bzhin gyi gos kyi char dbab pa dang / dbyig gi char dbab pa dang / gser gyi char dbab pa dang / rin po che sna tshogs kyi char dbab pa dang / yo byad thams cad kyi char dbab pa yang myong bar gyur nas/ gling chen po bzhi dag tu gnas te gling chen po bzhi'i rgyal srid kyi dbang phyug la dbang byas nas/ brgya byin gyi stan phyed mnan pa la 'dod pa chen pos ma btang ste/ 'dod pas ma ngoms bzhin du 'chi ba'i dus byas so zhes rgyal po chen po khyod kyis lung ston cig / de bas na rgyal po chen po khyod kyi dbang po rnams ni sgyu ma lta bu/ yul rnams ni rmi lam lta bu'o zhes de ltar rig par byas nas sems nges par gzhag par bya ste/ gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog par bya'o/ /

[256] “He replied, ‘Tell them that King Anantayaśas exercised royal sovereignty over all four continents; that he experienced all his vain desires;[liv] that he had the fruits of all trees out of season and relief from all bodily distress; that he fulfilled all the vain desires of sentient beings; that he experienced the rain of scented water, the rain of whatever divine clothes he wanted, the rain of jewels, the rain of gold, the rain of precious substances and the rain of all valuable things;[lv] and that after he lived in and reigned over all four continents, and sat with Śakra on his throne, he died without letting go of intense desire, not satisfied with sensual pleasures. Your Majesty, this is what you should say.’ After saying this, King Anantayaśas died”…[lvi] {Therefore, Your Majesty, your senses are like illusions and their objects are like dreams. Once you understand this, you should have inner certainty, and you should not engage in other methods.}

rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste dper na/ smig rgyu'i rang bzhin ni ma byung mi 'byung da ltar yang med do/ / de bzhin du gzugs dang tshor ba dang 'du shes dang 'du byed dang rnam par shes pa'i rang bzhin yang ma byung mi 'byung da ltar yang med do zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / yang de nyid las gsungs pa/ 'di ltar de bzhin gshegs pas kun rdzob dang don dam pa gnyis thugs su chud de shes par bya ba yang kun rdzob dang don dam pa'i bden pa 'dir zad do/ / de yang bcom ldan 'das kyis stong pa nyid du rab tu gzigs rab tu mkhyen legs par mngon du mdzad pas de'i phyir thams cad mkhyen pa zhes bya'o/ / de la kun rdzob ni 'jig rten gyi spyod par de bzhin gshegs pas gzigs so/ / don dam pa gang yin pa de ni brjod du med pa ste/ shes par bya ba ma yin pa/ rnam par shes par bya ba ma yin pa/ yongs su shes par bya ba ma yin pa/ ma bstan pa/ rab tu ma bstan pa/ ma thos pa/ thos par ma byas pa/ ma shes pa/ rnam par ma shes pa/ ma bstan pa/ ma mthong ba/ ma btags pa/ 'dzin du ma bcug pa/ rtogs par ma byas pa/ thob par ma byas pa/ ma thob pa/ nye bar ma bsnyen pa/ ma bor ba/ ma bzhag pa/ ma spangs pa/ bya ba med pa/ byed pa med pa/ rab tu zhi ba med pa/ ma smad pa/ ma bstod pa/ thogs pa ma yin pa/ ma thogs pa ma yin pa/ bde ba ma yin pa/ sdug bsngal ba ma yin pa/ snyan pa ma yin pa/ mi snyan pa ma yin pa/ gzugs ma yin pa/ gzugs med pa ma yin pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa dang /

“Your Majesty, for example, the intrinsic nature of a mirage[lvii] was not, will not be, and does not exist now. In just the same way, Your Majesty, the intrinsic nature of form, feeling, conceptions, conditioning and consciousness was not, will not be, and does not exist now.” The same text also says, What can be known is as follows: namely, the conventional and the ultimate. The Blessed One saw and knew these fully as emptiness, and made them known fully as emptiness. Therefore he is said to “know completely.” Here the Tathāgata saw the conventional as due to the practices of the world. But that which is ultimate is inexpressible, incomprehensible, not perceptible with the senses, not explained, not shown,[lviii] not something you get, not something you don’t get, neither happiness nor suffering, neither fame nor obscurity, neither form nor the formless … And so on.
gang gi bde bar gshegs la 'gro ba rnams/ / bde ba'i don du dad pa skye 'gyur ba/ / rgyal bas 'gro ba rnams kyi don slad du/ / 'jig rten phan phyir kun rdzob de bstan to/ /
In order to help living beings, The Victor taught the conventional for the welfare of the world, Through which, when they meet the Well-Gone One, Living beings trust him, are happy and gain benefits.

sems can tshogs kyi 'gro drug gang bstan pa/ / sems can dmyal dang dud 'gro yi dwags dang / / lha min ris dang mi dang lha yi rnams/ / mi yi seng ges kun rdzob btags pa mdzad/ / rigs dmar de bzhin mtho ba'i rigs rnams dang / / phyug po'i khyim dang dbul ba'i rigs rnams dang / / zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ /

The lion among humans makes known the conventional, Speaking to all the classes of sentient beings in the six realms: Hell-beings and animals and hungry ghosts, Those in titan bodies, humans and gods, High families and low families, Rich families and poor families. And so on.

yang gsungs pa/ gang bcom ldan 'das kyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu lung bstan pa'i chos de gang zhig / ci gzugs sam/ 'on te tshor ba'am/ 'on te 'du shes sam/ 'on te 'du byed dam/ 'on te rnam par shes pa zhig bcom ldan 'das kyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu lung bstan snyam nas/ de dag 'di snyam du sems te/ gzugs ni bcom ldan 'das kyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu lung ma bstan pa nas/ rnam par shes pa'i bar du ma yin no/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ gzugs kyang ma skyes pa/ byang chub kyang ma skyes pa ste/ ji ltar ma skyes pas ma skyes par mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar bya/ de bzhin du rnam par shes pa'i bar du shes par bya'o/ /

Now, the same text says: “What is this entity that the Blessed One expounded as ‘highest genuine full Awakening?’ Was it form, or feelings, or was it conceptions, or perhaps conditioning, or maybe consciousness, that the Blessed One expounded as ‘highest genuine full Awakening?’ ” They then thought, “It is not form, and so on up to: it is not consciousness, that the Blessed One expounded as ‘highest genuine full Awakening.’ Why is that? Form is not arisen; Awakening is not arisen. How does something that has not arisen fully Awaken to that which has not arisen?” And similarly, up to consciousness
de bzhin du sbyar te/

de ltar chos thams cad mi dmigs na/ 'di la sangs rgyas ni gang / byang chub sems dpa' ni gang / byang chub ni gang / lung bstan pa ni gang / gzugs ni gzugs kyis stong pa nas rnam par shes pa'i bar du'o/ /

“When, in this way, nothing can be apprehended, what here is the Buddha? What is Awakening? What is a bodhisattva? What is expounding? Form is empty of form, and so on up to: consciousness is empty of consciousness ”
de bzhin du sbyar te/
de dag ni tha snyad tsam ming tsam brda tsam kun rdzob tsam brjod pa tsam gdags pa tsam ste/ de la mkhas pa rnams kyis mngon par zhen par bya ba'i mi cha'o zhe'o/ /
“These are mere social convention, mere names, merely an agreement, merely conventional, merely nominal. It is not appropriate[lix] that the wise should get emotionally involved with them.”

yang de nyid las 'di skad ces gsungs te/ 'phrul dga'i lha rnams kyis gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa'i don bdag cag gis 'tshal ba ltar na/ chos thams cad ni yang dag pa'i mtha' dang / sgrib pa ma mchis pa'i mtha' dang / mtha' yas pa'i mtha' dang / mi gnas pa'i mtha' zhes bya ba la sogs pa dang / bcom ldan 'das chos thams cad rang bzhin ma yin pa ni byang chub lags par rig par bgyi'o/ / tha na mtshams med pa rnams kyang byang chub po/ / de ci'i slad du zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das byang chub ni rang bzhin ma mchis pa ste/ mtshams med pa rnams kyang rang bzhin ma mchis pa lags pas de'i slad du mtshams med pa rnams kyang byang chub ces bgyi'o/ / bcom ldan 'das gang su dag yongs su mya ngan las 'das par 'tshal ba de dag ni gnod par 'gyur ba'i chos can te/ de ci'i slad du zhe na/ gal te 'khor bar zhugs pa zhig mchis na ni mya ngan las 'das pa yang 'tshal bar 'gyur na zhes bya ba'o/ /

Similarly, in the same text, the gods who delight in emanations[6] said: “Blessed One, this is how we understand the meaning of what the Blessed One has said: Everything is the real goal,[lx] the final goal, the undistorted goal, the nonabiding goal … Blessed One, everything should be understood as Awakening, as having no intrinsic nature. Even the actions of immediate retribution are also Awakening. For what reason? Blessed One, Awakening has no nature,[lxi] and the five actions of immediate retribution have no nature. Therefore it is said: ‘The actions of immediate retribution are Awakening.’ Thus, Blessed One, those who desire liberation are laughed at.[lxii] Why is this? If someone were in cyclic existence, then that person could seek Nirvāṇa.”

gzhan 'phrul dbang byed kyi lha rnams kyis gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das 'phrul dga'i lha rnams kyis yang dag pa'i mtha' zhes gang smras pa de la bdag cag gis ni yang dag pa yang ma dmigs na de'i mtha' lta smos kyang ci 'tshal/ de ci'i slad du zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das gang la la zhig gis yang dag par dmigs na ni/ mtha' yang des dmigs par 'gyur te/ de ni gnyis kyis spyod pa'o zhes so/ /

{The gods controlling others’ emanations said:} Blessed One, the gods who delight in emanations spoke of a “real goal.” But on this topic, we do not apprehend anything real; how could that possibly have any goal! For, Blessed One, anyone who apprehends something real will also apprehend it to have a goal, and then acts on the basis of both of those.

de nyid las 'di skad du/ mi mjed kyi bdag pos ston pa la bstod pa/ / ji ltar mi zhig rmi lam bkres gyur pas/ / kha zas ro brgya zos pas 'grangs 'gyur ba/ / de la bkres med zas med sems can med/ / rmi lam de 'drar chos rnams thams cad gzigs/ /

Similarly, in the same text, Brahmā Sahāṃpati[7] praised the Teacher in a hymn, as follows: Just as a person in a dream, overcome by hunger, Could eat food of a hundred tastes and be satisfied, But neither the hunger, nor the food, nor the sentient being exists— [258] You see everything as like that dream.
mi zhig yid du 'ong ba'i tshig smras na/ / dga' bar 'gyur yang tshig la 'pho ba med/ / tshig nyid med cing dgar 'gyur dngos kyang med/ / de mkhyen de la the tshom yang mi mnga'/ /

If someone says enchanting words, Though delightful, that voice does not transmigrate, The words themselves don’t exist, and delight also has no substance; You know this and have no doubts about it.[lxiii]
pi wang sgra snyan mnyan na rnar snyan te/ / sgra de rang bzhin gang yang yod ma yin/ / de ltar mkhas pas phung po 'di gzigs na/ / phung po'i rang bzhin gang yang dmigs mi mnga'/ /

Just as, when one hears the enchanting, sweet sound of the lute, That sound does not exist essentially, In the same way, when the wise look for the aggregates, They do not apprehend any intrinsic nature of the aggregates.[lxiv]
ji ltar mi yis dung gi sgra thos te/ / sgra 'di gang las byung zhes brtags byas kyang / / rang bzhin stong pa'i dngos de mi dmigs pa/ / mi dbang khyod kyis de bzhin chos kun gzigs/ /

Just as someone might hear the sound of a conch shell And wonder, “Where does this sound come from?” It is something empty of intrinsic nature that is not apprehended.[lxv] Best of men, you see all things in this way.
ji ltar mi zhig bsod pa'i kha zas la/ / yan lag srog phan ji ltar 'gyur brtags na/ / dngos med yan lag srog kyang de bzhin te/ / drang srong chen pos de bzhin chos kun gzigs/ /

Just as someone understands, about good-quality food, That its parts nourish life, Though the parts have no substance, and neither does life, In the same way, that is how the Great Sage sees all things.[lxvi]
ji ltar mi zhig nam mkha'i 'ja' mthong na/ / yan lag gzhigs brtags rang bzhin med phyir stong / / 'ja' 'drar yan lag de dag stong pa nyid/ / drang srong che khyod de bzhin chos kun gzigs/ /

Just as someone sees a rainbow in the sky And, analyzing it into parts, understands it as empty because of having no intrinsic nature, Just like the rainbow, those parts are also empty; That is how you, Great Sage, see all things.
grong khyer mchog kyang yan lag rnams gzigs na/ / grong khyer rang bzhin de bzhin ming mi dmigs/ / grong khyer ji bzhin de ltar yan lag stong / / mi dbang khyod kyis de bzhin chos kun gzigs/ /

When the parts of a great city are seen, No intrinsic nature corresponding to the name “city” is apprehended. Just like the city, all the parts are also empty. Best of men, you see all things in this way.
skyes bu dga' bar rnga zhig brdungs bgyis na/ / dga' ba skyes kyang sgra yi rang bzhin stong / / ji ltar sgra bzhin de yi yan lag stong / / mi dbang khyed kyis de bzhin chos kun gzigs/ /

When a kettle-drum is struck for the delight of people, [259] Delight arises, but the sound is empty of intrinsic nature. Just like the sound, the parts are empty. Best of men, you see all things in this way.[lxvii]
skyes bus ji skad rnga de brdungs pa'i tshe/ / sgra ni phyogs su mi 'gro 'byung ba med/ / phyogs su de bzhin 'gag par mi 'gyur te/ / mi dbang khyed kyis de bzhin chos kun gzigs/ /
skyes bus ji ltar rnga de brdungs pa'i tshe/ / thogs pa med cing snyan pa'i rang bzhin te/ / sgra 'drar de yi yan lag de rang bzhin/ / mi dbang khyod kyis chos kun de ltar gzigs/ /

When someone strikes a kettle-drum, There is no physical resistance, and hearing has no intrinsic nature;[lxviii] The parts have the same nature as the kettle-drum that is struck. Best of men, you see all things in this way.
skyes bus ji ltar rnga de brdungs pa'i tshe/ / sgra de 'jig rten dga' byar rtog pa med/ / sgra 'drar de yi yan lag de rang bzhin/ / mi dbang khyod kyis chos kun de ltar gzigs/ /
When someone strikes a kettle-drum, The sound does not think, “I bring delight to the world”; The parts have the same nature as the sound. Best of men, you see all things in this way.[lxix]
skyes bus ji ltar rnga de brdungs pa'i tshe/ / g.yo ba med cing zhi ba'i dngos kyang med/ / sgra 'drar de yi yan lag de rang bzhin/ / mi dbang khyod kyis chos kun de ltar gzigs/ /
When someone strikes a kettle-drum, It does not move, but also, is not something peaceful. The parts have the same nature as the sound. Best of men, you see all things in this way.
skyes bus ji ltar rnga de brdungs pa'i tshe/ / sgra de rang dbang ma byung yan lag min/ / ji ltar sgra bzhin khyod kyi yan lag stong / / mi dbang khyod kyis chos kun de ltar gzigs/ / zhe'o/ /

When someone strikes a kettle-drum, The sound doesn’t arise independently and isn’t a part of something. Just like the sound, the parts of you are empty.[lxx] Great seer, you see everything in this way.[lxxi]
yang gsungs pa/ byams pa dge bsgoms sems can dmigs pa yin zhes 'dren pas bka' stsal pa/ / sems can rnam par bshig cing 'gro ba thams cad sems can med par mkhyen/ /

And the same text says: The Teacher proclaimed the beautiful meditation on lovingkindness, Taking sentient beings as objects. Any sentient being who clearly perceives it knows That in the whole world, there are no sentient beings.

de ltar rkang gnyis dam pa rnyog pa mi mnga' the tshom bral thugs ldan/ / des na bde gshegs rnams brtags blo mnga' mchod 'os khyod la mchod par 'tshal/ / bde bar gshegs pas sdug bsngal phyogs bcur gnas pa kun du mi dmigs kyang / /

In the same way, best of bipeds, you are clear And your mind is free from doubts. Therefore, to you, worthy of offerings, To the Well-Gone One whose mind perceives clearly, we should make offerings. Well-Gone One, you do not see any suffering [260] In the ten directions.[lxxii]
lha yi lhar gyur khyod kyis sems can rnams la snying rje bgyi bar gsungs/ / de ltar rgyal mchog bdag cag rgyal ba'i dgongs pa ji bzhin 'tshal/ /
God among gods, you proclaimed Compassion for sentient beings. In this way, we act in accordance with the Victor’s intentions, As commanded by the Victor, the bull among men.

des na rkang gnyis gtso bo mi mchog mchod 'os khyod la mchod par 'tshal/ / thub pa khyod kyis sems can dang ni bsal bgyi sdug bsngal ma gzigs la/ / dgyes pa skyes nas rab tu dgyes pa'i thugs kyis mi dgyes rnam par bsal/ /

Therefore, we should make offerings to you, Best of bipeds, the best of men. Śākyamuni, you clear away the suffering of sentient beings So they have none, So joy arises for them, and with rejoicing minds They do not even hear about displeasure.
de ltar sangs rgyas tshul ni bsam gyis mi khyab tshul 'di ji bzhin 'tshal/ / des na mi mchog khyod la mchod nas mnyes pa'i 'bras bu thob par bgyi/ /

This is how you know and carry out the method of the Buddhas, The method that the intellect can’t figure out. Therefore, we should make offerings to you, the most excellent of men, And then take delight in the results.

thub pas sku ni rnam par spangs pas sku btsal mdzad na ma bsnyengs kyang / / de ltar 'dren pa dran pa ma gsung ma lags bsnyel ba yong mi mnga'/ / bde bar gshegs pas lus la song ba'i bsgom pa bsgom par gyis zhes gsungs/ /

You, Sage, completely gave up the body, And knowing the body, were unafraid. Guide to mindfulness, you have not spoken in this way;[lxxiii] You will not become forgetful. The Well-Gone One has taught, “Practice meditation on the body.”

sangs rgyas tshul 'di rig nas bde bar gshegs pa skyob la mchod par bgyis/ / sdug bsngal zhi bya phyir ni zhi gnas lhag mthong lam yang bsgoms zhes gsungs/ / bcom ldan gang gis 'gro ba nyon mongs bag chags dri ma de dag zhi/ /

When we know this method of the Buddhas, We make offerings to the Holy One.[lxxiv] “To pacify suffering, develop the path [261] Of resting meditation, and insight,” Said the Blessed One, who pacified the stains, the underlying patterns Of the reactive emotions of living beings.
thub pa zhi gnas lhag mthong dri ma thams cad stong pa ste/ / 'di la lha tshogs gang du'ang the tshom ma mchis skyon bral khyod la mchod/ /
The Sage, resting meditation, insight, and the stains: All are empty. Here, with no doubts in their minds, Crowds of gods make offerings to you, the Guide.

yang gsungs pa/ mig ni mig gi rang bzhin dang bral ba/ khams ni khams kyi rang bzhin dang bral ba'i slad du ste/ chos gang la rang bzhin ma mchis pa de ni dngos po ma mchis pa'o/ / gang la dngos po ma mchis pa de ni yongs su ma grub pa'o/ / gang yongs su ma grub pa de la ni skye ba ma mchis so/ / gang skye ba ma mchis pa de la ni 'gag pa ma mchis so/ /

And so on. The same text says: The eye is empty of any intrinsic nature of eye.[lxxv] {because the element does not have the intrinsic nature of the element.} An entity that has no intrinsic nature is not a substance. Something that is not a substance is not produced.[lxxvi] Something that is not produced does not arise. {Something that does not arise has no ceasing.}
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gang dus gsum du mi dmigs pa de ni mig ma lags dbang po ma lags so/ / gang mig ma lags shing dbang po ma lags pa de'i tha snyad ji ltar 'tshal bar bgyi/ 'di lta ste dper na/ chad pa stong pa ni rdzun pa yang dag pa ma lags pa ma mchis pa ste/ 'di ltar ming du gdags par bas kyi don dam par ni stong par yang mi dmigs chad par yang mi dmigs so/ / de bzhin du mig dang dbang po yang chad pa stong pa ltar rdzun zhing ma mchis la yang dag pa ma lags pa ste/ gsob gsog log pa slu ba'i chos can byis pa 'drid pa glen pa rmongs par bgyis pa ste/ 'di ltar ming du gdags par bas kyi don dam par ni mig kyang mi dmigs zhes bya ba'o/ /

Something that is not apprehended in any of the three times is not the sense of sight.[lxxvii] How do we know that it is a social convention? For example, consider a deceptive empty fist; and so on up to: a mere name; but, indeed, ultimately, neither “fist” nor “empty” is apprehended.[lxxviii] In the same way, the eye and the sense of sight are like an empty fist: false, unreal, insignificant, misleading, deceptive, enticing fools, confusing the dim-witted, and so on up to: mere names.[lxxix]

yang de nyid las gsungs pa/ rmi lam char chen 'bab pa ltar/ / de bzhin zag pa rnams 'byung bar/ / zag pa 'byung ba mkhas pa po/ / dpa' bo chen po khyod kyis bstan/ / rmi lam dag na mgo bcad bzhin/ / khyod kyis zag pa zad pa gzigs/ / de ni mkhas pa rnams la bstan/ / thams cad gzigs la phyag kyang 'tshal/ / zhes so/ /

The same text says: The appearance of the outflows Is like a great rain in a dream. Great hero, wise one, you taught The arising of the outflows. You see the cessation of the outflows As like a beheading in a dream. You taught this to all the wise; Homage to you, all-seeing one!

'di nyid las mi'am ci'i rgyal po ljon pas zhus nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ stong pa nyid dang lung bstan pa/ / bdag gis ma 'tshal zhes smras pa/ / gal te 'ga' zhig mi stong na/ / rgyal bas de lung bstan mi gsungs/ / ci phyir zhe na 'di lta bur/ / rang gi rang bzhin gnas gyur nas/ / 'gyur ba med cing ther zug ste/ / de la 'phel med 'grib pa med/ / dper na rang bzhin stong pa yi/ / me long dkyil 'khor yongs dag la/ / gzugs brnyan snang ba de bzhin du/ / ljon pa chos rnams shes par gyis/ / chos kyi dbyings ni 'gyur med na/ / mchod pa'i yan lag 'gyur gang zhes/ / yan lag rnams la rtag byos la/ / ljon pa mchod pa 'di la spyod/ / g.yo ba ma mchis bgyi ba rnams/ / bstan pa ma 'tshal zhes smras pa/ / shing rta'i yan lag 'dus pa dang / / shing rta'i bya ba bzhin du rtogs/ / ngas ni las kyi rnam pa bstan/ / byed po phyogs bcu rnams na med/ / shing rnams rlung gis bsgul ba las/ / me 'byung 'gyur ba ji bzhin no/ / bdag cag me 'di bskyed bya zhes/ / rlung dang shing la sems pa med/ / 'on kyang me ni 'byung ba ltar/ / las kyi byed pa de bzhin no/ / gang yang bsod nams tshogs dang ni/ / byang chub yang dag bsgrub pa dang / / legs spyod yod min zhes zer ba/ / de tshul yang dag mnyan par byos/ / mi yi tshe tshad lo brgya ni/ / 'tsho ba yin zhes ji skad brjod/ / lo la phung po spungs pa med/ / sgrub pa de yang de dang mtshungs/ / zhes so/ /

And in the same text, when Druma, the king of half-humans, asked him, the Blessed One replied: [262] You have said, “I do not know emptiness and its explanation.” If anything were nonempty, the Victor would not explain it. Why is this? It would be stable, self-existent, always the same, unchanging. It would have no development and no abandonment, no effect and no cause. In a well-polished round mirror, an image is seen that is empty of intrinsic nature: Druma, know these entities to be just the same way. The realm of totality is unchanging. Druma, reflect on the parts of this offering. When you have analyzed the parts, which of them are unchanging? You do not understand what I have proclaimed About “immobility” and “function.” Reflect on the collection of the parts of a cart And on its function! I have taught the aspects of action, But no agent exists in the ten directions. It’s just like when trees, agitated by the wind, Produce fire: The wind and the trees do not think, “We should generate this fire.” However, fire arises. The performance of action is similar. You also ask about this: There is no accumulation of goodness, but for the one who acts well, there is the genuine attainment of Awakening. You have heard this correctly. As it is said, the human lifespan is one hundred years, but there is no piled-up mass of years. This attainment is also like that.

bcom ldan 'das ma las kyang / tshe dang ldan pa rab 'byor ci chos ma skyes pa skye 'am 'on te skyes pa skye/ rab 'byor gyis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu kho bo ni chos ma skyes pa skye bar yang mi 'dod skyes pa skye bar yang mi 'dod do zhes gsungs so/ / 'phags pa chos yang dag par sdud pa las kyang / rigs kyi bu de bzhin nyid ces bya ba de ni stong pa nyid kyi tshig bla dwags te stong pa nyid ni mi skye mi 'gag go/ / smras pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang 'di skad du chos thams cad ni stong pa'o zhes gsungs te/ de bas na chos thams cad ni mi skye mi 'gag go/ / byang chub sems dpa' rtsom pa med kyis smras pa/ rigs kyi bu de de bzhin no/ / ji ltar khong du chud pa bzhin te/ chos thams cad ni mi skye mi 'gag go smras pa/ gang 'di bcom ldan 'das kyis 'dus byas kyi chos thams cad ni skye'o 'gag go zhes gsungs na de bzhin gshegs pas 'di ci las dgongs te gsungs/ smras pa rigs kyi bu 'jig rten gnas pa skye ba dang 'gag pa la mngon par chags pas de la de bzhin gshegs pas thugs rje chen pos 'jig rten dngang ba'i gnas bsal ba'i phyir tha snyad kyi dbang gis skye'o 'gag go zhes gsungs te/ 'di la chos gang yang skye ba dang 'gag pa med do zhes gsungs so/ /

The Blessed Lady also says, “Venerable Subhūti, is it an unarisen entity or an arisen entity that arises?” [263] “Venerable Śāriputra, I do not assert either the arising of an unarisen entity, or the arising of an arisen entity.” The Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together also says, “Noble sir, the term ‘the way things really are,’ ‘the way things really are,’[8] stands for emptiness. And this emptiness does not arise and does not cease.” He said, “If things are empty in this way, as the Blessed One said, then all things will not arise and will not cease. A bodhisattva has no objects in mind.”[lxxx] He said, “Noble sir, this is how you awaken: All things do not arise and do not cease.” He said, “What was the intended meaning of the Tathāgata’s statement that ‘Compounded things arise and cease’?” He said, “Noble sir, those who live in the world are attached to arising and ceasing. Given this, the greatly compassionate Tathāgata, in order not to frighten people, says, by the power of social convention: ‘They arise and cease.’ But there is nothing here that arises or ceases.”

yang de nyid las/ bcom ldan 'das de la mig gis gzugs rnams la sgra mi 'byin/ rna bas sgra rnams dang / snas dri rnams dang / lces ro rnams dang / lus kyis reg bya rnams dang / yid kyis chos rnams la sgra mi 'byin pa de ni chos so/ / de la ji ltar na mig gis gzugs rnams la sgra mi 'byin zhe na/ phrad pa ma mchis pa'i slad du'o/ / mig ni gzugs la phrad par mi bgyid pa nas/ rna bas sgra la ma lags/ snas dri la ma lags/ lces ro la ma lags/ lus kyis reg bya la ma lags/ yid kyis chos kyi bar la phrad par mi bgyid do/ / gang phrad par mi bgyid pa de ni sgra mi 'byin pa'o/ /

The same text also says, Here, Blessed One, the eye does not strike forms,[lxxxi] nor the ear sounds; and so on up to: the mind does not strike experiences; this is the Teaching. Here, why does the eye not strike forms? Because they do not touch. The eye does not touch forms[lxxxii] … the mind does not touch experiences. When something doesn’t touch, it doesn’t strike.

bcom ldan 'das gnyis su ma mchis na chos la sgra 'byin pa ma mchis pa'o/ / bcom ldan 'das chos thams cad ni gnyis su ma mchis pa ste gcig gis gcig ma 'tshal rnam par ma 'tshal/ mi rtog rnam par mi rtog / 'byung bar mi bgyid 'jig par mi bgyid/ 'bri bar mi bgyid/ 'phel bar mi bgyid/ chags par mi bgyid mi chags par mi bgyid/ 'khor bar mi bgyid/ yongs su mya ngan las 'da' bar mi bgyid de/ 'di dag ni su'i yang ma lags/ 'di dag gi su yang ma lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das chos 'di dag ni skyo bar yang mi bgyid chags par yang mi bgyid do/ / bcom ldan 'das chos 'di dag ni kun nas nyon mongs par yang mi 'gyur rnam par byang bar yang mi 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das bdag gis de ltar 'tshal to/ / bdag gis de ltar rtogs so/ /

Blessed One, one entity alone doesn’t touch; and, Blessed One, everything is alone.[9] Moreover, entities do not know, are not conscious, do not think, do not postulate; they do not originate or cease to be; they neither diminish nor increase; they are neither attracted nor repelled; they neither wander in cyclic existence nor attain Nirvāṇa; they do not belong to anyone, and nothing belongs to them. Blessed One, entities are not agitated and not reactive, and they are not purified. Thus I know, Blessed One, thus I awaken.

bcom ldan 'das gang bdag 'di ltar 'tshal 'di ltar rtogs so zhes de ltar mchi ba de ni skye mched rnams kyis 'gyur ba'o/ / bcom ldan 'das skye mched rnams ni 'di snyam du 'di dag ni bdag gi 'gyur ba'o snyam du mi sems so/ / gang de ltar 'tshal ba de ni su dang yang mi rtsod do/ / gang mi rtsod pa de dag ni dge sbyong gi chos kyi rjes su 'jug pa'o/ / gang dge sbyong gi chos kyi rjes su 'jug pa de ni gang nas kyang 'jug par mi bgyid mi 'jug par yang mi bgyid/ sbyor bar yang mi bgyid mi sbyor ba yang mi bgyid/ 'gro bar yang mi bgyid sdod par yang mi bgyid 'bri bar yang mi bgyid 'phel bar yang mi bgyid de/ thams cad chos kyi tshul du mthong ngo / / thams cad rnam par grol ba'i tshul du mthong ngo / / chos kyi dbyings nyid du mthong ngo / / de ltar thams cad 'byung bar mthong ste/ gang 'byung ba de yang yang dag par rjes su mi mthong ngo / / gzhan du na ming tsam dang btags pa tsam dang tha snyad tsam du mthong ba ni ma mchis pa ma lags so/ / ming de yang ming ma mchis pa'o/ / btags pa yang btags pa ma mchis pa'o/ / tha snyad kyang tha snyad ma mchis pa'o/ /

[264] Furthermore, Blessed One, it is not that I say “Thus I know, thus I awaken”; this is a disturbance of the sense-spheres. And, Blessed One, the sense-spheres do not think, “This disturbance is ours.” Those who know this do not quarrel with anyone. Those who do not quarrel with anyone follow the path of a religious wanderer.[lxxxiii] {Those who follow the path of a religious wanderer neither enter anywhere nor do not enter, do not connect with anything or disconnect from anything, neither go nor remain seated, do not increase or decrease. They see the way of everything, the way of the liberation of everything. They see the realm of totality. In this way, they see the arising of everything. At the same time, correctly, they don’t see anything that arises. Moreover, they see that as mere name, mere representation, and mere social convention; it’s not that it doesn’t exist. Yet it is also not the case that that name exists. Representation does not exist as representation; social convention does not exist as social convention.}

chos mthong bas sangs rgyas mthong ngo / / sangs rgyas mthong bas sems can thams cad mthong ngo / / sems can thams cad mthong bas rgyu dang rkyen mthong ngo / / rgyu dang rkyen mthong bas stong pa nyid mthong ngo / / stong pa nyid mthong ba ni mthong ba ma mchis pa'o/ / bcom ldan 'das chos thams cad ma mthong ba ni yang dag pa mthong ba'o zhes gsungs so/ / gnas med pa kun rdzob tu ji ltar rung zhe na/ ji ltar mi rung ste/ ji ltar sdong po med na skyes bur 'khrul pa bzhin no/ / gang la brten nas skyes bur 'khrul par 'gyur ba stong pa nyid du smra ba la sdong po de don dam par ji ltar grub/ chos thams cad ni rtsa ba med pa ste/ yang dag par na rtsa ba mi 'thad pa'i phyir ro/ / de skad du 'phags pa dri ma med par grags pas bstan pa las kyang /

By seeing the Dharma, they see the Buddha. By seeing the Buddha, they see all sentient beings. By seeing all sentient beings, they see causes and conditions. By seeing causes and conditions, they see emptiness.[lxxxiv] Seeing emptiness is not seeing. Blessed One, not seeing anything is seeing everything; it is correct seeing. [Objection:] How is it reasonable that the conventional has no basis? [Reply:] Well, why is it unreasonable? It’s just like human confusion, which has no referent. How could a teacher of emptiness accept, as ultimately established, any basis for human confusion? All things are rootless, since no real root is apprehended. As the noble Holy Teaching of Vimalakīrti says,[10]

yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun du rtog pa'i rtsa ba gang yin/ smras pa yang dag pa ma yin par kun du rtog pa'i rtsa ba ni phyin ci log gi 'du shes so/ / smras pa phyin ci log gi 'du shes kyi rtsa ba gang yin/ smras pa phyin ci log gi 'du shes kyi rtsa ba ni rten med pa'o/ / smras pa rten med pa'i rtsa ba gang yin/ smras pa 'jam dpal gang rten med pa de'i rtsa bar 'gyur ba ci zhig yod/ de ltar chos thams cad ni rten med pa'i rtsa ba la gnas pa'o zhes gsungs so/ / 'di ni sems sbyang bar 'dod pas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa bsgom par bya ba mdor bsdus pa ste/ bsgoms nas kyang nyon mongs pa'i dgra dang 'thab pa la mkhas par bya'i rang gi khyim na dpa' bar ni mi bya'o/ / 'phags pa chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu ste/

[MAÑJUŚRĪ]: What is the root of inaccurate postulation? [VIMALAKĪRTI]: The false concept is the root. [MAÑJUŚRĪ]: What is the root of the false concept? [VIMALAKĪRTI]: Baselessness is the root. [MAÑJUŚRĪ]: What is the root of baselessness? [VIMALAKĪRTI]: Mañjuśrī, something that is baseless does not have any root.[lxxxv] So all things rest on the root that is baseless. In brief, this is the Perfection of Wisdom that you should meditate on in order to purify your mind. When you have meditated on it, develop skill in fighting the enemy, reactive emotions; don’t be like someone who is a “hero in his own house”! As the noble Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together says,

stong pa nyid smra ba ni mi gnas pa'i phyir 'jig rten gyi chos rnams kyis mi 'phrogs te/ rnyed pas dga' ba yang med ma rnyed pas mi dga' ba yang med/ grags pas yi sos pa yang med ma grags pas sro shi ba yang med/ smad pas zhum pa yang med bstod pas dga' bar sems pa yang med/ bde bas chags par 'gyur ba yang med sdug bsngal bas yid 'byung bar 'gyur ba'ang med/ gang de ltar 'jig rten gyi chos rnams kyis mi 'phrogs pa de ni stong pa nyid shes pa ste/ de ltar mi 'phrogs pas stong pa nyid khong du chud par bya'o zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin du stong pa nyid smra ba ni gang du yang chags pa'am mi chags pa med do/ / gang la chags pa dang gang la mi chags pa de stong pa nyid du shes pa stong pa nyid du mthong ngo / / gang gi chos gang la chags pa dang chags pa med pa des ni stong pa nyid du shes so/ / de bzhin du gang la la 'thab cing rtsod par byed pa de ni stong pa nyid mi shes te/ de gang dang 'thab cing rtsod par byed pa de stong pa nyid du shes de stong pa nyid du mthong ngo zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ /

A teacher of emptiness is not based anywhere, and so is unmoved by worldly concerns. She does not get excited about gain or discouraged by loss. She does not become proud due to fame, and does not cringe due to obscurity. She does not become depressed due to criticism or attached to praise. She is not attracted by pleasure or repelled by pain. Someone who is not moved by the worldly concerns in this way knows emptiness.[lxxxvi] In this way, a teacher of emptiness has no passion or repulsion towards anything. When there is something that might attract her, she knows that as empty and sees it as empty. Someone who is attracted or repelled by something does not know emptiness. Someone who has any dispute or quarrel with anyone does not know emptiness. She knows that as empty, sees that as empty. [265] And so on.
'di ni sems sbyang ba mdor bsdus pa'o/ /
This, in brief, is the purification of the mind.
Now, when you see the Dharma, the highest purification of what is defiled by the five types of impurity that are censured by the spiritual teacher is similar[lxxxvii] …

gang la 'bad pa byas na myur du sems dag par 'gyur zhe na/ bdag bstod pa dang gzhan la brnyas pa spang bas so/ / 'di nyid kyi rtsa ba ni bdag dang sems can du lta ba ste/ de yang 'di goms par byas na yang sla bar 'gyur te/ gzhan la gus par bya ba dang bdag khyad du bsad pa de ltar bsgom par bya'o/ /

What is it that, if you make an effort at it, leads quickly to the purification of the mind? It is giving up both self-conceit and despising others. The root of both is the false view of a self or a sentient being. And by repeated practice, you can easily weaken both the one and the other. You should develop respect for others and kill your sense that you are special[lxxxviii] by meditating as follows:
gal te sems can phung po rnams/ / rnam pa kun du mnyam gnas na/ / gcig la bdag dang gzhan nyid du/ / 'gal bar 'byung ba ji ltar 'gyur/ /
If a sentient being, and if the aggregates, Rest stable in every way, Then one’s “other” and “self” Are contradicted; how could they arise?
de ni dmigs pa med par yang / / thog med rtogs pa goms pa yis/ / lus can dag ni kun du spyod/ / goms na dga' ba ci zhig yod/ /
Embodied beings live that way, Though [these concepts] have no referent, Due to repeated practice for beginningless aeons. With repeated practice, what is difficult?[lxxxix]
de ltar goms pa'i bdag nyid du/ / mtshungs na ci phyir bde ba'i rgyu/ / gzhan la gus byas btang nas ni/ / rang sdug 'gyur ba gzhan 'dod byed/ /
Someone who rejects respect for others, Which equally, by the power of repeated practice, Can be a source of happiness, Wishes for what is opposed to her own happiness.
yid bzhin nor bu'i gtam brjod las/ / gus par bya ba'i rgyu yod do/ / bdag la gus byed skal ngan gyi/ / skye bo las 'dir bde ba'ang med/ /
The causes of respect are said to be Like a wish-fulfilling gem, But I do not have the happiness that comes from treating Karmically unfortunate people with respect.
de ltar bdag la chags ldan pa/ / brlang zhing nga rgyal ser sna can/ / kun las 'phags pa'i tshul lta bu/ / de las zlog ste bsgom par bya/ /
Therefore, when I feel, towards another sentient being Rough, greedy, or proud, for example, Through self-cherishing,[xc] I should transform that into its opposite through meditation.
bdag la gus par byed pa 'di/ / bstod smad la sogs chus bcus pas/ / 'phel te dmyal ba'i tshil zhag gis/ / btab pas dmyal ba'i me bzhin no/ /
When it is sprinkled with praise and criticism, Self-conceit grows, Just as the fires of hell grow [266] When sprinkled with the fat of hell-beings.[xci]
re zhig dgra la sems med phyir/ / bdag la bstod do snyam mi srid/ / bdag la gzhan dga' grags snyam pa/ / 'di ni bdag gi blo gros 'khrul/ /
Because sound is mindless, It is impossible for it to praise me. “Another is pleased with me;” This is my own intellectual confusion.
de mgu ba la bdag dga' ba/ / de ni rtag tu spyir 'gyur mod/ / de bdes bya ba med ce na/ / dga' des bdag la ci zhig bya/ /
His contentment has nothing in common With my pleasure. Assuming that his happiness has no effect on me, If he is contented, what is that to me?
gzhan nam yang na bdag la'ang rung / / gzhan dgas bdag la ci zhig bya/ / 'di ni gzhan gyi dga' bas bdag / lus kyis bde ba 'dod ma yin/ /
Whether he is pleased with me or with someone else, What does another’s joy matter to me? Through the contentment of someone else I do not have even an atom of bodily pleasure.
de ltar shes nas gzhi med kyi/ / rnam par rtog pa spang bar bya/ / ma grags smad dang ma bkur ba/ / de lta don med shes par bya/ /
When you know this, you should give up Conceptual thinking that does not remove obstacles. You should know in this way That infamy, criticism, and lack of prestige have no results.
phyag 'tshal sogs pas chos mi 'gyur/ / tshe dang nad med stobs mi 'gyur/ / co 'dri byed pa'i tshe na ni/ / gzhan gyis lus sgyur byed dang mtshungs/ /
Praise and the rest do not lead To religion, long life, health, or strength. If others laugh at you, The same is true of the changes in their bodies.
dga' 'am 'on te mi dga' yang / / rnyed dang ma rnyed mtshungs par 'gyur/ / de ltar don med rnam spang ste/ / ri dang mtshungs pa'i yid du bya/ /
Excitement and discouragement, Gain and loss, are the same.[xcii] In this way, give up what is pointless And develop a mind like a mountain![11]

'dris pa spangs pas sems myur du dag par 'gyur ro/ / 'dir yang bsam par bya ste/ / mtshan mar 'dzin pa las byung ba'i/ / ngo shes pas ni yang dang yang / / rjes su chags pa skye bar byed/ / de la khong khro 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

When you give up praise, your mind quickly becomes pure. On this you should also reflect: Grasping over and over again at signs That arise from recognition Generates attachment; From this, also, hostility arises.

gang la rjes chags khong khro yod/ / des ni sdig pa bzlog ma yin/ / phrag dog ser sna lhan cig tu/ / skur pa 'debs pa sna tshogs 'byung / / rnyed la sogs pa 'dod pa dag / nga rgyal la sogs mang po 'byung / /

Someone who has hostility and attachment Has not turned away from wrong action. Those who desire money and so on Make various false accusations [267] And develop jealousy and greed; Pride and the rest grow greatly.

des na 'bad pa thams cad kyis/ / thub pas 'dris pa yongs su spang / / 'dra phyir 'di ni gzhan yin yang / / 'khrul pas de ni 'di'o zhes/ / rgyun rgyud bzhin du rtog de'i phyir/ / stobs kyis de nyid la gnas bya/ /

Therefore, through all efforts, A sage should give up praise. Because it is similar, though distinct, Through confusion, it is thought “That is this,” Like a continuous stream.[12] Through power, I stand in the way things are.
'dra ba 'di ni dngos med de/ / khyed la sdug bsngal bskyed par 'gyur/ / nga dang de dag thams cad kyang / / ring por mi thogs med par 'gyur/ /
That which is similar is not a substance, But will generate suffering! Both I and all of these, Not long from now, will cease to exist.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las lus yongs su dag pa'i le'u ste bcu bzhi pa'o// //

d.crumb: 15. longs spyod dang bsod nams dag pa

f.d: [longs spyod dang bsod nams dag pa]
15. Purifying Possessions and Goodness
AFTER [THE DISCUSSION of] self-purification in this Training Anthology, purifying possessions is not combined [in the same chapter,] but is read separately here.[i]
yang dag 'tsho ba sbyangs pa yis/ / longs spyod dag par shes par bya/ /
[21ab] You should know that possessions are purified By making right livelihood pure.

khyim bdag drag shul can gyis zhus pa las ji skad du/ khyim bdag 'di la byang chub sems dpa' khyim pa chos kyis longs spyod tshol gyi chos ma yin pas ni mi tshol lo/ / mthun pas tshol gyi mi mthun pas ma yin no/ / yang dag pas 'tsho ba yin gyi log pas 'tsho ba ma yin no zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

As the noble Inquiry of Ugra says,[1] Leading merchant, here a householder bodhisattva seeks possessions in ways that are in accordance with the Dharma, not contrary to the Dharma; honestly, not dishonestly; and practices right livelihood, not wrong livelihood.

'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las kyang / byang chub sems dpa' ni sbyin par byed pa dang sbyin pa'i bdag po mthong na spyod lam mi 'chos so/ / ji ltar na spyod lam mi 'chos she na/ gnya' shing gang tsam du blta ba dang / skyo bar blta ba dang / sgrib pa med par blta bas gom pas bags kyis dal nas dal nas 'dor zhing 'debs pa ma yin te/ de ltar na lus kyis tshul 'chos pa mi byed do/ / ngag gis tshul 'chos par mi byed do/ /

The noble Cloud of Jewels also says, [268] When they see donors and patrons, bodhisattvas don’t fabricate their bodily posture. How is it that they do not fabricate their bodily posture? They don’t walk with small steps, raising and lowering their feet slowly, with their gaze extending only the length of a yoke, with a confident gaze, with an effortless gaze.[ii] In this way they do not engage in gift-seeking with the body.

ji ltar ngag gis tshul 'chos par mi byed ce na/ byang chub sems dpa' ni rnyed pa'i rgyu rnyed pa'i phyir gcom bskyungs shing smra ba ma yin 'jam por smra ba ma yin dga' bar smra ba ma yin/ rjes su 'brang ba'i tshig brjod pa ma yin te/ de ltar na ngag gis tshul 'chos pa mi byed do/ /

How is it that they not engage in gift-seeking in speech? Bodhisattvas do not, for the sake of getting things, in order to get things, speak slowly, gently or affectionately, or utter words that conform with others.[iii] {In this way they do not engage in gift-seeking in speech.}

ji ltar na sems kyis tshul 'chos par mi byed ce na/ byang chub sems dpa' ni sbyin pa byed pa'am sbyin pa'i bdag pos rnyed pa bstan na/ tshig gis 'dod pa chung bar ston cing sems kyis 'dod pa bskyed pa ma yin no/ / rigs kyi bu 'di lta ste/ tshig gis 'dod pa chung la sems kyis rnyed pa 'dod pa 'di ni nang gi gdung ba yin te/ de ltar na sems kyis tshul 'chos pa mi byed do/ / de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' tshul 'chos pa dang kha gsag gi rnyed pa dang bral ba yin no/ /

How is it that they do not engage in gift-seeking in mind? When bodhisattvas are offered valuable things by donors and patrons, they do not make a show of having few desires while mentally arousing eager desire. Noble sir, having few desires in your speech, but having lust for gain in the mind, is burning inside. Noble sir, in this way, bodhisattvas do not get things through gift-seeking or flattery for gain.

ji ltar na gzhogs slong gi rnyed pa dang bral ba yin zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' ni sbyin pa byed pa'am sbyin bdag mthong na bdag gos kyis phongs so bdag lhung bzed kyi phongs so/ / bdag na ba'i gsos sman gyis phongs so zhes gzhogs slong mi byed cing / sbyin pa byed pa'am sbyin pa'i bdag po la mi slong zhing tshig tu mi brjod de/ de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' gzhogs slong gi rnyed pa dang bral ba yin no/ /

{How is it that bodhisattvas do not ask for things?}[iv] When bodhisattvas see donors, they don’t say: “I need a robe. I need a bowl. I need medicine for the sick.” They do not beg those donors for anything; they do not utter any words. In this way, bodhisattvas do not get things through asking for them.

ji ltar na thob kyis 'jal ba'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' ni sbyin pa byed pa dang sbyin pa dag mthong na bdag la sbyin pa'i bdag po che ge mo zhig gis dngos po che ge mo zhig byin te/ de la bdag gis kyang phan pa che ge mo zhig byas so/ / 'dis kyang bdag la 'di ni tshul khrims dang ldan par rig ste mang du thos pa'o 'dod pa chung ba'o zhes 'di dang 'di byin no/ / bdag gis kyang de la snying rje ba'i sems nye bar gzhag ste blangs so zhes de skad kyi tshig mi brjod do/ / de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' thob kyis 'jal ba'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin no/ /

{How is it that they do not get things by using clever words to extract wealth?} When bodhisattvas see donors and patrons, they do not say, “A certain patron provided me with a certain item, and I did a certain service for him. He said that I was ‘morally disciplined,’ and gave me this and that; he said I was ‘learned’ and ‘of few desires.’ Arousing compassion for him, I accepted his gifts.” {They do not utter words of this kind. In this way, bodhisattvas don’t get things by using clever words to extract wealth.}

ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' mi rigs par btsal ba'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin zhe na/ rigs kyi bu byang chub sems dpa' ni lus la rma byung ba dang sems la rma byung bar rnyed pa tshol ba ma yin no/ / de la lus kyi rma ni 'di lta ste/ rnyed pa'i rgyu rnyed pa'i phyir brgyug pa dang kun du brgyug pa dang / tshul khrims 'chal pa la spyod pa'o/ / sems kyi rma ni 'di lta ste/ rnyed pa la smon pa dang tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa gzhan gyi rnyed pa dag la gnod sems mang ba ste/ de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' mi rigs par btsal ba'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin no/ /

[269] {How is it that bodhisattvas do not get things by seeking them dishonestly? Noble sir, bodhisattvas don’t seek to get things through bodily and mental ruin.} Here “bodily ruin” means: for the sake of getting things, in order to get things, running this way and that way, and immoral behavior. “Mental ruin” means: asking for alms, and having great malice towards celibate practitioners who do receive gifts. In this way, bodhisattvas do not get things by seeking them dishonestly.

ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' chos ma yin pa'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin zhe na/ rigs kyi bu 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa' srang la sgyu med pa dang btsal ba la sgyu med pa dang yid brtan pa la gnod par byed pa med pa dang g.yos rnyed pa mi sgrub pa ste/ de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' chos ma yin pa'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin no/ /

{How is it that bodhisattvas do not get things in ways that are contrary to the Dharma?} Noble sir, bodhisattvas do not get things through false weights, or by cheating in measures, or by exploiting the trust of others, or fraudulently. In this way, bodhisattvas do not get things in ways that are contrary to the Dharma.

ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' yongs su ma dag pa'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin zhe na/ 'di la byang chub sems dpa' gang mchod rten gyi dang 'dres pa'am chos kyi dang 'dres pa'am/ dge 'dun gyi dang 'dres pa'am ma byin pa ma gnang ba de dag mi len cing bdag gir mi byed/ chags pa'i sems mi skyed de/ de ltar na byang chub sems dpa' yongs su ma dag pa'i rnyed pa dang bral ba yin no/ /

{How is it that bodhisattvas do not get things in impure ways?} They do not receive or appropriate wealth that is mixed with stūpa property, or that is mixed with property belonging to the Dharma, or that is mixed with property belonging to the religious community, or that has not been given, or that is forbidden.[v] {They don’t arouse thoughts of desire for these things.} In this way, bodhisattvas do not get things in impure ways.

ji ltar na byang chub sems dpa' rnyed pa la zhen pa med pa yin zhe na/ rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' rnyed pa rnyed kyang bdag gir mi byed/ nor du mi rtsi/ tshogs su mi byed cing / dus dus su dge sbyong dang bram ze dang pha ma dang mdza' bo dang blon po dang gnyen bshes dang snag gi gnyen mtshams dag la gtong zhing dus dus su bdag kyang yongs su spyod la yongs su spyod pa'i tshe chags pa med pa dang zhen pa med par yongs su spyod do/ / rnyed pa ma rnyed na yang skyo ba'i sems mi skyed cing yongs su yi mi 'chad de/ sbyin pa byed pa dang sbyin bdag rnams ma dad par mi 'dzin pa yin te zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

{How is it that bodhisattvas are free from attachment to getting things?} Noble sir, even when bodhisattvas receive things, they do not think of them as their own, are not greedy for them,[vi] do not hoard them. At the proper time, they give them away to religious wanderers and Brahmins, to their parents, friends, councillors, acquaintances, and family members. At the proper time, they consume these things themselves, but do so with no attraction, wholly unattached. And when they do not get anything, they have no distressed thoughts about getting things, and are not tormented. They do not arouse distrustful thoughts towards donors and patrons. And so on.
