Here also, the bodhisattva’s purification of possessions, like the purification of the body, should be for the benefit of others. As the Holy Teaching of Vimalakīrti says, “Moreover, Reverend Śāriputra, those who enter this house, as soon as they enter, are not troubled by reactive emotions. This is the second astonishing and wonderful thing.”[2] And the same text says: [270] From that food, the whole assembly was satisfied, and the food did not run out. And those bodhisattvas, Disciples, Śakra and Brahmā gods, guardian kings, and other sentient beings who ate that food felt bliss descending into their bodies that was like the bliss of the bodhisattvas in the world-realm called Sarvasukhamaṇḍita.[3] From all their pores, a perfume wafted that was like the scent of the trees in the world-realm called Sarvagandhasugandhā.[4] And it also says: Reverend Ānanda, if monks who have not yet reached the certainty of liberation eat this food, it will be digested when they reach the certainty of liberation … When sentient beings who have not yet aroused Awakening Mind eat this food, it will be digested when they arouse Awakening Mind. When those who have aroused Awakening Mind eat this food, it will not be digested until they have attained patient endurance.[5] And so on.[vii]
stong pa snying rje'i snying po can/ / spyod pas bsod nams dag par 'gyur/ /
[21cd] The purification of goodness Happens through motions whose nature is emptiness and compassion.

'phags pa nam mkha'i mdzod kyi mdo las gsungs pa/ 'di lta ste/ ngar 'dzin pa rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin no/ / nga yir 'dzin pa rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin/ rgyu rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin/ lta ba rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin/ mtshan ma rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin/ tha dad pa rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin/ rnam par smin pa la mi re ba rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin/ nam mkha' dang mtshungs pa'i sems rnam par dag par sbyin pa de sbyin no/ / rnam par dag pa brgyad po 'di dag gi sgo nas sbyin pa de sbyin no/ / ji ltar nam mkha' mtha' med pa bzhin du sems can mtha' med par byas te sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' rgya che zhing sgrib pa med pa de bzhin du byang chub tu bsngos te sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' la gzugs med pa de bzhin du gzugs thams cad la mi gnas par sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' la tshor ba med pa de bzhin du tshor ba thams cad dang bral bar sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' la 'du shes med pa de bzhin du 'du shes thams cad kyi mdud pa med par sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' 'dus ma byas pa de bzhin du 'dus byas thams cad med par sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' mtshan nyid rnam par rig pa med pa de bzhin du rnam par shes pa la mi gnas par sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad la khyab pa de bzhin du sems can thams cad la byams pas khyab par sbyin pa de sbyin/

For the noble Gaganagañja Sūtra says, That is, they give gifts that are pure, free from any sense of self. They give gifts that are pure, free from any sense of “mine.” They give gifts that are pure, free from ulterior motives. They give gifts that are pure, free from false views. They give gifts that are pure, free from signs. They give gifts that are pure, free from distinctions. They give gifts that are pure, free from any hope for results. They give gifts that are equal and pure like the sky.[viii] Just as space has no limits, they give gifts with no limits in their minds. Just as space is vast and has no distortions, they give gifts and dedicate [the goodness] to Awakening. Just as space has no form, they give gifts independently of all forms. Just as space has no subject of experiences, they give gifts free from all feelings. Just as space has no conceptions, they give gifts free from the knots of conceptions. Just as space is unconditioned, they give gifts free from all conditioning. Just as space has no awareness of characteristics, they give gifts that do not depend on consciousness.[ix] Just as space pervades all Buddha-fields, in the same way, they give while radiating lovingkindness to all sentient beings …
[271] Just as space is always clear, they give gifts from the natural purity of mind.[x]

ji ltar nam mkha' sems can thams cad kyi go skabs 'byed pa de bzhin du sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho bar sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar nam mkha' la nga'i ba med pa de bzhin du sems can thams cad yid la byed pa thams cad dang bral bar sbyin pa de sbyin/ ji ltar sprul pas sprul pa la sbyin pa sbyin pa lta bur rnam par mi rtog cing lhun gyis grub ste sems dang yid dang rnam par shes pa dang bral zhing chos thams cad la re ba med pa de ltar rnam par shes pa dang bral ba'i phyir sgyu ma'i mtshan nyid kyi ngo bo nyid rnam par dag par byang chub sems dpas sbyin pa de sbyin te/ rigs kyi bu gang de lta bur sbyin pa yongs su gtong ba de ni/ shes rab kyi ye shes kyis ni sems can thams cad kyi nyon mongs pa yongs su 'dor zhing thabs kyi ye shes kyis ni sems can thams cad mi gtong ba ste/ rigs kyi bu de lta bur gtong ba'i sems ni byang chub sems dpas sbyin pa nam mkha' dang mtshungs pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ /

Just as space has room for all sentient beings, they give gifts that provide livelihood for all sentient beings.[xi] {Just as space has no sense of ‘mine,’ they give gifts that are free from acts of attention towards any sentient beings.} Just as a magical illusion gives a gift to another magical illusion, spontaneously, with no conceptual thought, having no mind or mental consciousness and with no longing for anything, in the same way, through the disappearance of duality, bodhisattvas give gifts that have the distinguishing characteristics of illusion and have no intrinsic nature whatsoever. Noble sir, a bodhisattva who gives generously in this way, giving up all the reactive emotions of sentient beings through the pristine awareness of wisdom and, through the pristine awareness of skillful means, not giving up on sentient beings, has generosity that is like space.

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las kyang / sems can thams cad la gnod pa'i sbyin pa med pa nas/ ji skad smos pa las bri ba'i sbyin pa med pa'i bar dang / sems can thams cad la sbyin gnas ma yin no zhes brnyas pa'i sbyin pa med pa'i bar dang / de bzhin du sbyar te/ smre ba'i sbyin pa med do/ / slong ba rnams la gnod pa'i bar gyi sbyin pa med do/ / bsting ba dang brid pa'i sbyin pa med do/ / rgyab kyis phyogs pa'i sbyin pa med do/ / bor ba'i sbyin pa med do/ / brnyas pa'i sbyin pa med do/ / rang gis lag ma dar pa'i sbyin pa med do/ / de bzhin du sbyar te/ mi rung ba'i sbyin pa med do/ / dus ma yin pa'i sbyin pa med do/ / dug dang mtshon cha sbyin pa med do/ / sems can rnams la rnam par 'tshe ba'i sbyin pa med do zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra also says, Don’t give sentient beings anything that would harm them.[xii] And so on up to: as it says, don’t give too little. And so on up to: don’t give contemptuously to those who are worthy of honor. Don’t give while moaning about it. Don’t give what would be harmful to beggars. Don’t give while sneering, with abusive derision. Don’t give with your face turned away. Don’t give what has been thrown away.[xiii] {Don’t give contemptuously.} Give with your own hands … Don’t give improper things; don’t give at the wrong time; don’t give poisons or weapons; don’t give anything to sentient beings that would injure them.

drag shul can gyis zhus pa'i mdo las/ des gzhan dag la chang yang sbyin te/ des 'di snyam du 'di ni sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'i dus yin te/ gang ci 'dod pa de la de sbyin pa'i dus la bab kyi bdag gis 'di ltar bya ste/ gang dang gang la 'di ltar chang yang byin nas gang 'di 'khrul pa med pa'i spyod pa la de dang de dag dran pa dang shes bzhin yang dag par 'dzin du gzhug go snyam pa'i 'du shes bskyed par bya'o zhes gang gsungs pa ni/ chang gi sgo nas kyang byang chub sems dpa' la re thag chad de khong khro ba lci bar 'gyur bas/ 'dis sems can bsdu ba nyams par 'gyur te/ gzhan dad par bya ba'i thabs su 'gyur bas chang sbyin no zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ / mtshon cha la sogs pa yang gal te gnod par mi 'gyur ba lta na lci yang brtags te/ byin na ltung ba med par 'di nyid kyis mngon no/ / mdo sde las ni spyir bkag pa gsungs so/ / sbyin pa rnam par dag pa'i phyogs tsam zhig bshad zin to/ / tshul khrims rnam par dag pa ni/ 'phags pa nam mkha' mdzod kyi mdo las gsungs te/ sems can rnam par dag pa'i phyir byang chub kyi sems dang mi 'bral ba dang / tshad mar gyur pa rnam par dag pa'i phyir nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi sems med pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / gzhan yang tshul khrims rnam par dag pa ni nam mkha' dag pa ste/ tshul khrims de yang dag pa'o/ / nam mkha' dri ma med pa ste tshul khrims de yang dri ma med pa'o/ / nam mkha' zhi ba ste tshul khrims de yang zhi ba'o/ / nam mkha' mi mthong ba ste tshul khrims de yang mi mthong ba'o/ / nam mkha' mi dma' ba ste tshul khrims de yang mi dma' ba nas/ nam mkha' mi chod mi phyed pa ste tshul khrims de yang mi chod mi phyed pa la sogs pa'i bar du'o/ / nam mkha' la zhe 'gras pa med de/ sems can thams cad la zhe 'gras pa med pa'i bzod pa yongs su dag pa dang / nam mkha' ni mnyam par sbyor ba ste sems can thams cad la sems mnyam pa'i bzod pa yongs su dag pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ /

On the other hand, the Inquiry of Ugra says, Now is the time for the perfection of generosity. Now is the time to give others whatever they want. I will act as follows: To drunkards, I will give strong drink. {As for those who act without confusion,} I will lead them to mindfulness and awareness.[6] If people lose confidence in a bodhisattva over alcohol, their anger will be a grave matter, and it will interfere with [the bodhisattva’s work of] bringing people together. Hence, as a skillful means, you should give liquor in order to win the trust of others. This is the meaning. As for weapons and so on, if giving them would produce major [good] consequences and their use would do only minor harm, there is no downfall. Therefore, [giving weapons] is possible.[xiv] But in the sūtras, this is forbidden in general. This concludes the explanation of the direction to go in order to purify generosity. [272] The noble Gaganagañja Sūtra explains the purity of moral discipline in this way: “In order to purify the mind,[xv] not losing the Awakening Mind; in order to purify your epistemic authority, not having the mindset of the Disciples and Solitary Sages”; and so on. Moreover, on the purity of moral discipline: The sky is pure; that moral discipline is pure. The sky is stainless; that moral discipline is stainless. The sky is peaceful; that moral discipline is peaceful. The sky is not arrogant; that moral discipline is not arrogant.[xvi] {The sky is invisible; that moral discipline is invisible.} The sky is tranquil;[xvii] that moral discipline is tranquil. And so on up to: the sky is unbreakable and indestructible; that moral discipline is unbreakable and indestructible … The sky has no enemy; those whose minds have no enmity towards any sentient beings have the purity of patient endurance. The sky is impartial; those whose minds see all sentient beings as equal have the purity of patient endurance …

'di lta ste dper na shing sA la chen po'i tshal yod par la la zhig 'ongs te shing sA la bcad na/ de la shing sA la bcad pa'i lhag ma rnams 'di snyam du 'di dag ni bcad do/ / bdag gis bcad do snyam du mi sems te/ de dag la rjes su chags pa yang med do/ / khong khro ba yang med do/ / mi rtog rnam par mi rtog yongs su mi rtog go/ / de bzhin du gang bzod pa ni byang chub sems dpa'i bzod pa nam mkha' dang mtshungs par yongs su dag pa'i mchog go zhes so/ /

For example, suppose there was a large grove of śāla trees, and someone came there and cut down one śāla tree. In this case, the rest of the trees do not think: “This one is cut; we are uncut.” They have no attachment or hostility, no conceptual thought, no postulation, and no assumptions. The patient endurance that is like this is the bodhisattva’s highest sky-like patient endurance.

'phags pa gtsug na rin po che'i mdo las/ rgya cher smos te gsungs pa 'di ni brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa zhes bya'o/ / de'i yongs su dag pa gang zhe na/ gang lus la mig yor dang gzugs brnyan du shes pa/ tshig brjod du med par shes pa/ sems can la shin tu nye bar zhi bar shes pa'o/ / de bzhin du byams pa chen po'i go cha bgos/ snying rje chen po'i gnas la gnas te/ rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i stong pa nyid kyi rnam pas mngon par bsgrubs pas bsam gtan du byed do/ / de la rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ sbyin pa ma tshang ba med pa nas thabs ma tshang ba med pa'i bar dang / byams pa chen po dang snying rje dang dga' ba dang btang snyoms ma tshang ba med pa dang / bden pa shes pa la 'jug pa ma tshang ba med pa dang / byang chub kyi sems sems can la lta ba ma tshang ba med pa dang / bsam pa dang lhag pa'i bsam pa'i sbyor ba ma tshang ba med pa dang / sbyin pa dang snyan par smra ba dang don spyod pa dang don mthun pa ma tshang ba med pa dang / dran pa dang shes bzhin ma tshang ba med pa dang / dran pa nye bar gzhag pa dang yang dag par spong ba dang / rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa dang / dbang po dang stobs dang byang chub kyi yan lag dang 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad pa ma tshang ba med pa dang / zhi gnas dang lhag mthong ma tshang ba med pa dang / de bzhin du sbyar te/ rang bzhin gyis nye bar zhi ba la las dang nyon mongs pa rnams kyis nye bar ma zhi ba dang / chos nyid kyis btang snyoms pa/ sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la lta ba/ rang gi mtshan nyid kyis bems po dang / byin gyi rlabs bya ba'i phyir rnam par 'gro ba med pa dang / rang gi ngang gis mi ldog pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi bya ba la rtag tu brtson pa dang / nye bar zhi bas bsil bar gyur pa dang / sems can yongs su smin par bya ba la rtag tu 'bad pa ste/ 'di ni rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i stong pa nyid ces bya ba nas/ rigs kyi bu 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i spyod pa yongs su dag pa'o zhes bya ba'i bar du'o/ / 'dis shes rab yongs su dag pa yang rig par bya ste/ bsod nams thams cad la yang de bzhin no/ /

After a lengthy explanation, the noble Sūtra on the Jewel at the Crown of the Head says: This is called perseverance.[xviii] Its bodily purification is knowing the body as an illusion and a reflected image, knowing its inexpressibility in words. [Its] mental [purification is] knowing utter tranquility. In the same way, wearing the armor of lovingkindness, resting stably on the foundation of great compassion, having attained the emptiness that has what is best in all respects, they meditate stably. [273] Here, what is the emptiness that has what is best in all respects? That which does not lack generosity, and so on up to: does not lack skillful means. It does not lack great lovingkindness,[xix] {compassion,} joy, and equanimity. It does not lack the entry into knowing what is true. It does not lack the Awakening Mind that is oriented towards sentient beings. It does not lack the putting into practice of aspiration and higher intention. It does not lack generosity, speaking gently, meaningful conduct, and practicing what you preach.[7] It does not lack mindfulness and awareness. It does not lack the applications of mindfulness, the right efforts, the bases of miracle powers, the faculties, the powers, the aspects of awakening, and the eightfold path.[8] It does not lack resting meditation and insight meditation … Essentially tranquil, but not tranquil due to karma and reactive emotions; aiming at all the qualities of the Buddhas; material in virtue of its own characteristic;[xx] heroic in carrying out commitments; not engaged in its own taste, but always engaged in the activities of a Buddha;[xxi] having become cool through tranquility; always burning to help sentient beings to mature; this is called “emptiness that has what is best in all respects” … Noble sir, this is the purification of the practice of the perfection of meditative stability. The purification of wisdom should be understood in the same way, and similarly for all forms of goodness. In the same way, the noble Holy Teaching of Vimalakīrti also says,[xxii] The domain in which you turn all the wheels of the Dharma and manifest great liberation, but do not give up on the bodhisattva’s way of life—this also is a domain of the bodhisattvas.[9]
bslab pa kun las btus pa las/ longs spyod dang bsod nams dag pa'i le'u ste bco lnga pa'o// //
[bzang spyod cho ga]
16. The Ritual of Good Conduct
da ni gsum char gyis 'phel ba yang brjod par bya ste/ ci'i don du zhe na/
NOW, THE ENHANCEMENT of three things needs to be explained. What does this mean?
gzung bar bya ba rab mang la/ / 'di ni nyung na 'dis ci bya/ / shin tu ngoms pa bskyed ma yin/ / de phyir 'di ni 'phel bar bya/ /
[22] Those who are to receive are very numerous, And this is small; what use is it? It does not give rise to deep fulfillment; Therefore, it must be enhanced.
shin tu ngoms pa ni sangs rgyas nyid de/ de ni nyan thos dang thun mong ba'i dag pa tsam gyis sems can rnams la mi bskyed do zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go/ /
“Deep fulfillment” is Buddhahood; and sentient beings don’t attain it by purification alone, which is shared with Disciples. This is the meaning.
lus 'phel bya ba gang zhe na/ le lo med dang stobs bskyed yin/ /
[23ab] What is the enhancement of the body? [274] The enhancement of power and diligence.

de la 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las stobs gsungs te/ gang byang chub sems dpa'i stobs la stobs kyis brdzi ba'i sems can de ni sems can gyi ris na med do zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / de bskyed pa ji lta bu zhe na/ gang 'phags pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba'i mdo las kyang ma skyes dgras/ 'phags pa lag na rdo rje'i stobs mthong nas ngo mtshar du gyur ces zhus nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa/ rgyal po chen po byang chub sems dpa' chos bcu dang ldan na stobs 'di lta bu thob ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ rgyal po chen po 'di la byang chub sems dpa' lus dang srog ni yongs su gtong gi dam pa'i chos ni yongs su mi gtong ba dang sems can thams cad la 'dud cing nga rgyal 'phel bar mi byed pa dang / sems can mthu chung ba rnams la bzod cing khong khro bar mi byed pa dang / sems can bkres pa rnams la kha zas bzang po mchog sbyin pa dang / sems can 'jigs pa rnams la mi 'jigs pa sbyin pa dang / sems can nad pa rnams la yang dag pa'i gso bar bya bar spro ba dang / sems can dbul po rnams la longs spyod dag gis tshim par byed pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten la rdo thal gyis skud pa dang / sems can rnams la kun tu dga' bar 'gyur ba'i tshig sgrogs pa dang / sems can dbul po sdug bsngal ba ngal ba chad pa rnams kyi khur khyer ba ste/ rgyal po chen po byang chub sems dpa' chos bcu po de dag dang ldan na stobs 'di lta bu 'thob po zhes bya ba'o/ /

On this topic, the noble Cloud of Jewels says about power: “In the whole class of sentient beings, no sentient being exists that, by its power, could overcome the power of a bodhisattva.” And so on. How do you enhance power?[i] In the noble Mysteries of the Tathāgata Sūtra, when Ajātaśatru saw a display of power by the noble Vajrapāṇi,[1] he was astonished, and asked about it. The Blessed One said, [275] Your Majesty, if a bodhisattva has ten qualities, he attains power like that. What are the ten? Here, Your Majesty, a bodhisattva gives up body and life, but does not give up the holy Dharma. A bodhisattva bows down to all sentient beings and does not nourish conceit. A bodhisattva is patient towards weak sentient beings and does not show any hostility. A bodhisattva gives the very best choice food to hungry sentient beings, and gives safety to frightened sentient beings. The bodhisattva becomes eager to truly heal sick sentient beings; fully satisfies poor sentient beings with possessions; applies white plaster[ii] to a stūpa of the Tathāgata; speaks delightful words to sentient beings; shares possessions with sentient beings who are tormented by poverty; and carries the burden of tired and fatigued sentient beings.[iii] Your Majesty, these are the ten.

le lo med pa bskyed pa gang zhe na/ gang brtson 'grus bskyed pa ste/ 'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu ste/ blo gros rgya mtsho byang chub sems dpa' rtag tu brtul ba brtan par brtson 'grus brtsom par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' gces pa mi 'dor bar mos pa drag po bya'o/ / blo gros rgya mtsho brtson 'grus brtsams pa rnams la ni bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub dka' ba ma yin no/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ blo gros rgya mtsho gang na brtson 'grus yod pa de na byang chub yod do/ / le lo can la ni byang chub shin tu ring zhing rnam par ring ngo / / le lo can rnams la ni sbyin pa med pa nas shes rab kyi bar du med do/ / le lo can rnams la ni gzhan gyi don med do zhes bya'o/ /

What is enhancing diligence? It is enhancing perseverance. As the Sāgaramati Sūtra says, Sāgaramati, bodhisattvas should develop perseverance and always have firm courage. Bodhisattvas should have sharp motivation and not lay down their burden. Sāgaramati, for bodhisattvas who have developed perseverance, highest genuine full Awakening is not difficult. Why is this? Sāgaramati, where there is perseverance there is Awakening. For the lazy, Awakening is very far away, extremely far away. Lazy people do not have generosity, and so on up to: lazy people do not have wisdom; lazy people do not have the highest goal.[iv]
zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las kyang / / ut+pal chu nang ji bzhin du/ / de nas mthar gyis rnam par 'phel/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ / 'di ni lus 'phel ba mdor bsdus pa'o/ /
The Candrapradīpa Sūtra also says,[v] “Just like a blue lotus in water, they grow in regular stages.” And so on. This, in brief, is the enhancement of the body.
stong dang snying rje'i snying po can/ / sbyin pas longs spyod 'phel bar 'gyur/ /
[23cd] Possessions are enhanced through generosity, Whose nature is emptiness and compassion.

rdo rje gcod pa las/ byang chub sems dpa' gang mi gnas par sbyin pa sbyin pa de'i bsod nams kyi phung po tshad gzung bar sla ba ma yin no zhes ji skad du gsungs pa bzhin no/ / shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa chen po las kyang / shA ri'i bu gzhan yang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po/ sems can thams cad la sbyin pa chung ngu zhig byin la/ thabs mkhas pas rnam pa thams cad mkhyen par yongs su bsngos pas grangs med dpag tu med par bya bar 'dod pas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la bslab par bya'o/ / gser dang dngul dang skyed mos tshal dang rgyal srid la sogs pa'i yo byad kyi bar gyis sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa yid bzhin du yongs su rdzogs par byed par 'dod pas shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa la bslab par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni snying rje med par ci yang mi spyod do zhes brjod par bya'o/ / 'di ni longs spyod 'phel ba mdor bsdus pa'o// //

As the Diamond Sūtra says, “When bodhisattvas give gifts without being attached, their mass of goodness is not easily measured or grasped.”[2] The Larger Sūtra on the Perfection of Wisdom also says, [276] Moreover, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being, while giving even a small gift to sentient beings, by dedicating that with skillful means to the knowing that is complete in all respects, and wishing to do immeasurable and innumerable deeds, should train in the perfection of wisdom. In the same way, anyone who wishes to fulfill the wishes of all sentient beings, with such assistance as gold, silver, pleasure gardens, kingdoms, and so on, should train in the perfection of wisdom. And we say: Bodhisattvas don’t do anything without compassion. This, in brief, is the enhancement of possessions.[vi]
bam po bcu gnyis pa/
bsod nams 'phel ba ni spel ba rnams kyi rtsa ba yin pa des na de'i don du grabs bsham pa brjod par bya'o/ /
Enhancing goodness is the root of all forms of enhancement. Therefore, the [verse] explains the preparations for that goal:
brtson dang bsam pa brtan pa yang / / dang por nan tan byas nas ni/ / snying rje mdun du gzhag nas su/ / dge ba spel la nan tan bya/ /
[24] Making an earnest effort with respect to what has been done and so on, With firm diligence and firm intention, Putting compassion foremost, Make an earnest effort to enhance goodness.

sems sbyang ba'i phyir brtson 'grus dang por dus su bsgom pa sbyor ba rtsom pa'i tshe yang sngon du byed pas brtan par bya ba'i phyir tshigs su bcad pa'o/ / 'thab pa'i dus nye bar 'gyur ba'i tshe mtshon cha la mkhas pa la gus pa bzhin du sbyor ba dang dus mnyam du brtan par bya'o zhes lhod par bzlog pa'i phyir dang po zhes bya ba smos so/ /

In order to purify the mind, one must first develop perseverance, before the time of actually undertaking strict practice, so that it can be made stable.[vii] This is what the verse means. At times of impending battle, for example, people work hard, paying close attention to skill in weapons, so as to make that skill stable for the time when it will be needed, and so as to prevent any slacking off.

de la brtson pa brtan par byed pa ji lta bu zhe na/ ji ltar 'phags pa nor bzang byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa rjes su bstan pa de ni rjes su rnam par sems/ sngon gyi mtha'i mur thug pa'i lus mang po yang dag pa'i spyod pa nyams su ma blangs par chud zos pa la bsam pas ni lus kyi stobs rab tu brtan par byed/ sngon gyi mtha'i mur thug pa'i lus dang sems yongs su dag kyang don med par 'khor ba'i sems kyi rgyud du gyur pa la bsam pas ni sems dang yid la bya ba shin tu tshar gcod/ sngon gyi mtha'i mur thug pa'i las yang dag pa ma yin pas 'jig rten gyi don du g.yen spyo ste don med par sha thang ba la bsam pas ni da ltar byung ba'i don shin tu gces pa la legs par bsgrub par rnam par sems/ sngon gyi mtha'i mur thug pa'i yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun du rtog pas kun nas bslang ba'i phyin ci log gi kun du rtog pas yang dag par brtan pa'i yid la byed pa'i bsam pas ni byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa thams cad yang dag pa'i rtog pas mngon par 'du byas pa'i stobs yang dag par bskyed/ 'das pa'i lus kyis bdag gi don gyi sbyor ba la rtsom pa'i yul la yongs su bsam pas ni sems can thams cad kyi sbyor ba las khyad par du 'phags par lhag pa'i bsam pa'i stobs rab tu brtan par byed/ 'das pa'i 'dod pa yongs su tshol ba'i spyod pa ro med pa la yongs su bsam pas ni sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad thob pa'i sbyor bas dbugs phyin pa chen po 'thob pa'i dbang po'i shugs drag po rnam par 'phel bar byed/ 'das pa'i dus kyi bsam pa phyin ci log dang ldan pa'i sbyor ba la yongs su bsam pas ni da ltar byung ba'i dus su phyin ci log med pa dang ldan pa'i yang dag pa'i lta ba dang byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam la yi dam bca' bas sems kyi rgyud yongs su rgyas par byed/

Here, how do you make diligence stable? As when the noble Sudhana approached the noble Maitreya, unable to lead the right way of life:[viii] [277] [278] From the most remote past, bowing down with the body.[ix] From the most remote past, making bodily strength stable by bringing attention to the body. From the most remote past, keeping mind and attention in check by bringing attention to the unnecessary thoughts and actions of cyclic existence, so as to purify the body and mind. Discovering a high level of competence for the purpose at hand by bringing attention to the flow of unhelpful actions that have no purpose and are related to worldly tasks. Setting up sufficient strength to accomplish right intention in all aspects of a bodhisattva’s way of life by bringing attention to those thoughts that manifest false conceptual thinking and have been set up by past inaccurate postulations. Making the power of higher intention firm by the excellence of attention that, reflecting on all sentient beings, shows the inappropriateness of past effort whose goal was your own bodily welfare. Bringing attention to the fact that past bodily behavior didn’t lead to true enjoyment. Increasing the energies of the faculties, so that you are greatly encouraged, in order to make an effort to attain all the qualities of a Buddha. By bringing attention to the efforts based on wrong intentions that resulted from your past errors, purifying your personality through undertaking the bodhisattva vow that results from the non-erroneous right views that you have now.

sngon gyi mtha'i brtson 'grus brtsams pa mi cha la don ma yin pa dang / yongs su ma grub pa'i brtson 'grus nyams su blangs pa la yongs su bsam pas ni da ltar byung ba'i dus su sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su bsdu ba la sta gon du gnas pa'i brtson 'grus chen po rtsom pa'i rnam par gnon pas lus dang sems kyi gzengs mtho ba yang dag par bskyed/ sngon gyi mtha'i mur thug pa'i 'gro ba lnga'i rgyud kyi ngan song du bdag dang gzhan bor ba la brtags pas lus 'tsho ba med pa yongs su bzung ba la yang dag par bsam pas ni sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yongs su bsgrub pa dang 'gro ba thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen thams cad bsnyen bkur bar nus pa'i lus yongs su bzung bas dga' ba dang mchog tu dga' ba'i shugs drag po rgya chen po rnam par 'phel bar byed/ da ltar byung ba'i skye ba mngon par 'grub pa'i rga ba dang na ba dang 'chi ba dang mya ngan gyi 'byung gnas su 'gyur te 'du ba dang 'bral ba'i gter du gyur pa'i lus kyang / phyi ma'i mtha'i bskal pa'i mur thug pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad pa la brtson pa dang sems can yongs su smin par bya ba dang sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su bsdu bas brtson pa dang de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhal blta zhing zhing thams cad du rgyu ba dang / chos smra ba thams cad la rim gro bya ba dang de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi bstan pa yongs su bzung ba la brtson pa dang chos thams cad yongs su btsal ba'i grogs su gyur pa dang dge ba'i bshes gnyen thams cad mthong bar bya ba dang sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yang dag par bsdu ba la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam dang ye shes kyi rgyu dang rkyen du gyur pa la bltas shing dge ba'i rtsa ba'i dbang po dang shugs bsam gyis mi khyab pa rnam par 'phel bar byed cing 'phags pa byams pa'i drung du song ba bzhin no/ /

Arousing exaltation of body and mind through the courage of developing great perseverance by engaging in the approach to the qualities of a Buddha right now, by bringing attention both to the present undertaking of what is noble, and to the task of developing the perseverance that you did not have in the past. By bringing attention to the entire universe of sentient beings who, from the most remote past, have been in the five realms, thrown down into the lower realms, unable to help themselves or others and with no livelihood, and by taking hold of the body so that you are able to win the favor of all spiritual teachers, provide livelihood for all sentient beings, and[x] {through right intention} attain all the qualities of a Buddha, increasing the energies of extensive delight and joy. By looking at the body, which has come into being in this present life with the aspects of old age, disease, sorrow, and death, which has become the locus of coming together and coming apart; and by seeing what arises from these causes and conditions— living the bodhisattva’s way of life from the most remote past into the most remote future, helping sentient beings to mature, upholding the Dharma of the Buddhas, seeing the Tathāgatas, traversing all Buddha fields, serving all teachers of the Dharma, paying attention to the religion of the Tathāgatas, becoming a companion in searching for all the teachings, seeing all spiritual teachers, gaining all the qualities of a Buddha, the bodhisattva vow and pristine awareness—increasing the energies of the faculties of inconceivable wholesome actions.

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las kyang / byang chub sems dpa' ni gcig pu gnyis su med cing grogs med pa bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu go cha gyon te/ de brtson 'grus kyi stobs kyis yongs su zin pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pas/ pha rol gyi skabs mi 'byed par bdag nyid byed do/ / rang gi stobs kyis 'phags so/ / de de ltar go cha sra ba bgos pas sems can thams cad kyis yongs su thob par bya ba gang ci yin pa de bdag gis thob par bya'o/ / gang 'phags pa thams cad dang theg pa la gsar du yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis thob par mi 'gyur ba de bdag gis yongs su thob par bya'o/ / sbyin pa ni bdag gi grogs ma yin gyi bdag ni sbyin pa'i grogs so/ / tshul khrims dang bzod pa dang brtson 'grus dang bsam gtan dang shes rab ni bdag gi grogs ma yin gyi/ bdag ni tshul khrims dang bzod pa dang brtson 'grus dang bsam gtan dang shes rab rnams kyi grogs yin no/ / pha rol tu phyin pa rnams kyis bdag la bsnyen bkur mi bya'i/ bdag gis pha rol tu phyin pa rnams la bsnyen bkur bya'o/ / de bzhin du bsdu ba'i dngos po rnams dang dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad la yang sbyar ro/ / ji tsam du bdag gcig pu gnyis su med cing grogs med par rdo rje'i rang bzhin gyi sa'i dkyil 'khor la gnas te/ bdud stobs dang bcas pa btul nas sems kyi skad cig gcig dang ldan pa'i shes rab kyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar bya'o zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Teaching of Akṣayamati Sūtra also says, [279] A bodhisattva, alone, without a second, without a companion, puts on the armor for highest genuine full Awakening. By undertaking the power of perseverance, and through higher intention, she does not make others do things, but takes on tasks herself through the power of her own strength. Wearing this solid armor in this way, she thinks, “Whatever needs to be done for all sentient beings, I will do it. Whatever all the Noble Ones and all the bodhisattvas who are newly practicing the Way will not get done, I will get done. I do not have generosity as a companion; I am now a companion of generosity. I do not have moral discipline, patient endurance, perseverance, meditative stability, and wisdom as companions; I am now a companion of moral discipline, patient endurance, meditative stability, and wisdom. I should not be served by the perfections; rather, I should serve the perfections. The same applies to the ways of bringing people together, and also to all wholesome actions … And so on up to: Alone, without a second, without a companion, I should sit on the great adamantine disk, and after vanquishing Māra, with his vehicle[xi] and all his power, with wisdom coming together in a single moment of mind, I should awaken to highest genuine full Awakening.

'phags pa rdo rje rgyal mtshan gyi mdo las kyang / 'di lta ste/ dper na lha'i bu nyi ma 'char ba na dmus long gi nyes pas mi 'dug go/ / dri za'i grong khyer gyi nyes pas mi 'dug go/ / gling bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi sa'i rdul gyi nyes pas mi 'dug go/ / lha ma yin gyi dbang po sgra gcan gyi nyes pas mi 'dug go/ / du ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi nyes pas mi 'dug go/ / 'dzam bu'i gling gi nye ba'i nyon mongs pa'i nyes pas mi 'dug go/ / grib ma tha dad pa'i nyes pas mi 'dug go/ / ri mi mnyam pa'i nyes pas mi 'dug go/ /

The noble Vajra Flag Sūtra also says, Indeed, prince, when the sun rises, [to people who are] blind from birth, it doesn’t appear. When a city of gandharvas gets in the way, it doesn’t appear. When the dust of the earth of this four-continent world-realm gets in the way, it doesn’t appear. When Rāhu, king of the titans, gets in the way, it doesn’t appear.[3] When a disk of smoke gets in the way, it doesn’t appear. When various disturbances of the earth get in the way, it doesn’t appear. When various shadows get in the way, it doesn’t appear. When rugged mountains get in the way, it doesn’t appear.

de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po dran pa dang shes bzhin can sems zab cing rgya che ba rnam par ma zhum pa yon tan gyi spyod pa dang ye shes kyi spyod pa mthas gtugs pa ni sems can 'khu ba'i ngang tshul can gyi nyes pas mi ldog go/ / sems can dmu rgod kyi nyes pas mi ldog go/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su bsngo ba med par mi gnas so/ / sems can dang lta ba'i snyigs ma'i nyes pas mi ldog go/ / sems can sems 'khrugs pa rnams dang ring bar mi 'gyur ro/ / sems can sems ma rung bar gyur pas byang chub kyi go cha rgyun gcod par mi byed do/ / sems can gyi 'thab pa'i rnyog pa rnams kyis 'gro ba thams cad yongs su bskyab pa'i smon lam rgyun gcod par mi byed do/ / ji tsam du byis pa'i skye bo dang 'grogs pa dang sems can gzhan gyi nyes pa rnams kyis skyo bar mi byed do/ /

[280] In the same way, as for a bodhisattva great being who has mindfulness and awareness, with a mind that is broad and deep, undaunted, having come to the end of the practice of abilities and the practice of pristine awareness—even when the hostility[xii] of sentient beings gets in the way, the bodhisattva doesn’t turn away from them, and does not get separated from dedicating wholesome actions. When the muddiness of sentient beings’ false views gets in the way, the bodhisattva doesn’t turn away from them. When sentient beings have angry thoughts, the bodhisattva doesn’t go far away from them. When sentient beings’ thoughts are inappropriate, that does not break the continuity of the bodhisattva’s armor of Awakening.[xiii] The muddiness of the depravity of sentient beings doesn’t cause the bodhisattva to fall away from the vow to save all living beings … And so on up to: The bodhisattva, when paying attention to foolish people,[xiv] is not disgusted by the problems of others.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ni 'di lta ste/ 'gro ba thams cad rnam par dag par gdul ba'i phyir sgrib pa med pa'i dkyil 'khor du 'char ro/ / de bzhin du sbyar te/ gang sems can de dag thams cad kyi sdug bsngal gyi phung po dang / sgrib pa sna tshogs dang las nye bar gnas pa'i sgrib pa gang dag gis de dag sangs rgyas mthong bar mi 'gyur ba dang / chos nyan par mi 'gyur ba dang dge 'dun shes par mi 'gyur ba de dag gis de dag gi sgrib par 'gyur ba de dag gi las rnam pa gsum bsags pa'i sdug bsngal gyi phung po rang gi lus 'dis blang bar bya'o/ / sems can dmyal bar skye ba de dag dang ngan song gi sa la gnas pa'i sems can de dag thams cad de nas shi 'phos par gyur cig / bdag gis sdug bsngal gyi phung po chen po 'di blang bar bya'o/ / brtson par bya'o/ / spro bar bya'o/ / mi ldog par bya'o/ / mi 'bros par bya'o/ / mi skrag par bya'o/ / mi 'jigs par bya'o/ / phyir mi ldog par bya'o/ / sgyid mi lug par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ bdag gis ni sems can thams cad kyi khur bskur bar bya'o/ / bdag ni 'dod dgar byed pa ma yin te/ bdag ni sems can thams cad bsgral ba'i smon lam can yin gyi bdag gis sems can yongs su smin par bya'o/ / bdag gis 'gro ba thams cad bsgral bar byas te/ skye ba'i dgon pa dang / rga ba'i dgon pa dang / nad kyi dgon pa dang / 'chi 'pho dang skye ba'i dgon pa dang / ngan song thams cad kyi dgon pa dang / mi khom pa'i dgon pa dang / 'du byed thams cad kyi dgon pa dang / lta ba thibs po thams cad kyi dgon pa dang / dge ba'i las chud za ba'i dgon pa dang mi shes pa kun nas langs pa'i dgon pa de dag thams cad las/ bdag gis sems can thams cad yongs su thar bar bya'o/ / srid pa'i dra bar chud pa/ ma rig pa'i sgrib pas bsgribs pa/ srid pa'i sred pa dang ldan pa/ mthar rab tu 'jig par 'gyur ba/ sdug bsngal gyi gzeb tu bcug pa/ 'khor ba'i btson ra na gnas pa/ mi mkhas pa/ dam bcas pa dang 'gal ba/ the tshom za bar gyur pa/ rtag tu yid gnyis za ba/ mi bde ba mthong ba/ 'byung ba la mi mkhas pa/ srid pa'i rgya mtsho klong 'khyil ba'i dkyil 'khor na gcig pu rgyu ba'i sems can thams cad bla na med pa'i ye shes kyi rgyal srid la dgod pa'i phyir bdag gis spyod pa spyad par bya'o/ / bdag ni bdag 'ba' zhig yongs su thar bar bya ba la brtson pa ma yin gyi/ bdag gis sems can 'di dag thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi sems kyi gzings kyis 'khor ba bgrod dka' ba las bsgral bar bya'o/ / g.yang sa chen po las dbyung bar bya'o/ / gnod pa thams cad las yongs su thar bar bya'o/ / 'khor ba'i rgyun las bsgral bar bya'o/ /

Why is this? The monastic code, which is for the purification of all living beings, rises up like an undistorted disk … As for the mass of suffering and the various distorting actions that all sentient beings have produced, those distorting actions because of which they do not see the Buddhas, do not hear the Dharma, and do not know the religious community—with my own body, I will accept that mass of suffering, heaped up by three kinds of distorting actions.[4] Wherever those sentient beings have been born, in the hells, or on the ground of any of the lower realms, may they all pass away from there. I take ownership of this great mass of suffering. I will strive—I can do it.[xv] I will not turn away. I will not protect myself. I will not be afraid. I will not fear. I will not turn back. I will not shrink from the task. Why is this? I will certainly carry the burdens of all sentient beings. This is not something I do because I want to. I have vowed to save all sentient beings. I will set all sentient beings free.[xvi] I will completely save all sentient beings from the wilderness of birth, from the wilderness of old age, from the wilderness of disease, from the wilderness of death and rebirth, from the wilderness of all downfalls,[xvii] from the wilderness of all the lower realms, from the wilderness of all cyclic existence,[xviii] from the wilderness of the thicket of false views, from the wilderness of the destruction of their wholesome states, from the wilderness that arises from not knowing—from all these, I will set all sentient beings free. All sentient beings are caught in the net of craving, covered with the distortions of ignorance, having the craving for existence, headed for destruction in the end, locked up in the cage of suffering, living in the prison {of cyclic existence,} lacking in intelligence, holding contradictory theses, full of doubts, always of two minds, visibly showing their lack of peace, not skilled at getting free, moving around alone in a whirlpool in the ocean of existence … I will practice in order to establish them all in the royal sovereignty of the highest pristine awareness. I am not merely intent on my own freedom. With the boat of the Mind for complete knowing, I will get them out of the ravine of cyclic existence. I will lift them up out of the great abyss. I will set them free from all misfortunes. I will bring them across the torrent of cyclic existence.

bdag nyid kyis sems can thams cad kyi sdug bsngal gyi phung po khas blangs so/ / ji tsam gyis 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gtogs pa'i ngan song thams cad kyi sdug bsngal gyi gnas myong bar spro bar bya'o/ / bdag gis dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams kyis sems can thams cad mi dor bar bya'o/ / bdag ngan song gcig tu yang phyi ma'i mtha'i mu'i bskal par gnas par brtson par bya'o/ / ngan song gcig la ji lta ba bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gtogs pa'i ngan song ma lus pa thams cad du gnas pa'i sems can thams cad yongs su thar bar bya ba'i phyir yang de bzhin no/ /

I myself have taken hold of the mass of suffering of all sentient beings—so much so that I am able to experience all the places of suffering included in all the lower realms of all the world-realms. And I should not leave all sentient beings destitute of wholesome actions. I will strive to abide for aeons, to the most remote future, in just one lower realm; and as in that one lower realm, so in all the lower realms without exception that are included in all the world-realms, in order to set free all sentient beings.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ bdag gcig pu sdug bsngal bar gyur pa ni bla'i/ bdag gi sems can thams cad ngan song gi sar rab tu ltung ba ni de lta bu ma yin te/ bdag gis 'dir bdag nyid gtar bcug la sems can dmyal ba dang dud 'gro'i skye gnas dang gshin rje'i 'jig rten gyi dgon pa las 'gro ba thams cad blu bar bya'o/ / bdag ni sems can thams cad kyi don du sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba'i phung po thams cad bdag nyid kyi lus 'dis myong bar bya'o/ / sems can thams cad kyi ched du bdag nyid sems can thams cad kyi gnya'o/ / bden par smra ba yid ches su rung ba mi slu ba bya bar spro ste bdag gis sems can thams cad yongs su mi gtong ngo / / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ bdag ni sems can thams cad la dmigs nas thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi sems bskyed pa ste/ 'di ltar 'gro ba thams cad yongs su thar bar bya ba'i phyir bdag dga' ba 'dod pa ma yin par bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu yang dag par zhugs so/ / bdag ni 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga'i dga' ba myong bar bya ba ma yin/ 'dod pa'i yul bsten pa'i phyir ma yin/ bdag ni 'dod pa'i khams su gtogs pa'i dga' ba bkod pa gzhan dang gzhan sgrub pa'i phyir ma yin par byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi dga' ba 'di ni dga' ba ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di lta ste 'dod pa bsten pa 'di ni bdud kyi spyod yul lo/ /

Why is this? Better, indeed, that I alone should suffer, so that all these sentient beings should not fall into the lower realms. I will give myself there as a rope to break their fall.[xix] All living beings must be redeemed from the wilderness of the hells, animal wombs, and the world of Yama. For the benefit of sentient beings, I will experience the whole mass of painful sensation with this, my own body. And, for the sake of all sentient beings, I can be, towards all sentient beings, truthful, trustworthy, and honest.[xx] I don’t give up on any sentient being. Why is this? I have aroused the Mind for complete knowing in relation to all sentient beings: that is, to set all living beings free. I have not set out towards highest genuine full Awakening out of desire for pleasure, nor in order to experience the delights of the five senses, nor in order to indulge in the objects of sensual desire. I do not lead the bodhisattva way of life in order to obtain any of the various pleasures belonging to the world of desire. Why is this? Because all the pleasures of the world are not [really] pleasurable. Indulging in objects of sensual desire: this is the domain of Māra.

'di lta ste 'dod pa bsten pa'i lam 'di ni blo ngan pas bsten pa'o/ / nye bar bsten pa 'di ni sangs rgyas thams cad kyis ma bsngags pa'o/ / de'i phyir nye bar bsten pa 'di ni sdug bsngal gyi phung po thams cad 'byung ba nyid yin te/ de nyid las sems can dmyal ba dang dud 'gro'i skye gnas dang gshin rje'i 'jig rten rnams 'byung ngo / / sems can rnams 'thab pa dang rtsod pa dang mtshang 'bru ba dang 'gyed pa dang / 'khrugs pa dang / kun du 'khrugs pa rnams 'byung ngo / / sems can de dag gis 'dod pa bsten na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams las thag ring du 'gyur ro/ / 'dod pa 'di dag ni mtho ris su skye ba'i bar chad du yang 'gyur na bla na med pa'i ye shes kyi rgyal srid/ sems can thams cad kyi grub pa dang bde ba la lta smos kyang ci dgos te/ de ltar bdag gis 'dod pa skyon tshad med pa dang ldan la rab tu 'bar zhing kun du rab tu 'bar bar mthong gis/ de lta bas na bdag gzhi de la mi spyod par nan tan bya'o/ /

That road is followed by those of little intelligence. Indulging in sensual pleasures: this is criticized by all the Buddhas. And it is from this very indulgence that the whole mass of suffering arises. From this alone come the hells, animal wombs and the world of Yama. The strife, wars, quarrels, and anger of sentient beings happen due to this alone. The Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, are far away from those sentient beings who indulge in sensual pleasures. These sensual pleasures function as obstacles even to rebirth in the heavens; how much more so to the majesty of the highest pristine awareness, and to the peace of meditation for all sentient beings. Seeing in this way the measureless disadvantages, lowly and burning,[xxi] of sensual pleasures, therefore I will abstain from them
de bzhin du sbyar te/

ji lta ji ltar sems can thams cad shin tu bde ba dang / myong ba med pa'i bde ba nas thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi bde ba'i bar du thob par 'gyur ba de lta de ltar/ bdag kha lo sgyur ba/ yongs su 'dren pa bdag sgron ma 'dzin pa/ bdag zhi ba'i 'gro ba ston pa/ bdag dal ba'i 'gro ba thob pa/ bdag thabs shes pa/ bdag don la mkhas pa/ bdag 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho nas thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi grus yul chen po la gnas pa/ bdag yongs su bsngo ba la mkhas pa/ pha rol ston pa bdag gis de lta de ltar dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad yongs su bsngo bar bya'o/ /

The way in which I should dedicate this wholesome action is in such a way that all sentient beings will obtain limitless happiness, happiness they have never felt before, and so on up to: the happiness of complete knowing. I am the helmsman, the leader, and the torch-bearer. I show the path to peace. I have obtained the opportunity to practice. I am skilled in means. I know how to help. In the ocean of cyclic existence, I stand in the ship of complete knowing, on the mainland. I am skilled in dedicating [goodness.] I show the farther shore.[xxii] This is how I will dedicate my roots of good.
de bzhin du sbyar te/

gling bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams snang bar bya ba'i phyir gling bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams na sems can ji snyed pa de snyed kyi nyi ma 'char ba ma yin gyi gling bzhi pa snang bar bya ba'i phyir nyi ma gcig po 'di kho na 'char ro/ / gang gis de dag nyin mo'i grangs su shes par 'gyur ba dang rang gi bya ba yongs su thob par 'gyur ba dang / lo tog yongs su smin par byed par 'gyur ba dang / nyin gcig bzhin du skyed mos tshal dang grong khyer rnams su dga' zhing rtse la dga' mgur spyod pa myong bar 'gyur ba dang / phyogs mthong bar 'gyur ba dang / grong dang grong khyer dang grong rdal dang / yul 'khor dang rgyal po'i pho brang 'khor rnams su 'ong ba dang 'gro bar 'gyur ba'i snang ba gling bzhi par skyes pa'i sems can re re'i lus las 'byung ba ma yin no/ /

Right now, in this four-continent world-realm, it is not the case that as many suns rise as there are sentient beings, so as to illuminate the four-continent world-realm. Instead, only one sun rises to illuminate for them the four continents. Nor do those sentient beings of the four continents emit light from their own individual bodies, by which they could count the days, or do their own work, or ripen the crops, or, day in and day out, experience pleasure, amusement, and enjoyment in pleasure-gardens and cities, or see in all directions, or move around in villages, cities, markets, countries, and capital cities, or which they could use in practical tasks.[xxiii]
de bzhin du sbyar te/

lha'i bu nyi ma 'char ba na nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gcig pu gnyis su med par gling bzhi pa'i khams kyi sems can rnams la snang bar 'byung ngo / / de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i rtsa ba bsgrub cing dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su bsngo ba yang 'di ltar sems bskyed de/ sems can 'di dag la ni gang gis 'di dag bdag yongs su skyob par 'gyur ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba de med na/ gzhan skyob par lta smos kyang ci dgos/ bdag ni sems can thams cad kyi ched du dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams yang dag par bsgrub par bya'o/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su bsngo bar bya'o/ / 'di lta ste/ sems can thams cad thar bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad la snang bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad shes par bya ba dang / sems can thams cad bsgral bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad yongs su bzung ba dang / sems can thams cad yongs su bsgrub pa dang / sems can thams cad rab tu tshim par bya ba dang / sems can thams cad kyi the tshom bcad pa'i phyir/ bdag nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor lta bur byas te/ gzhan la mi ltos par bya/ gzhan la skabs phye zhing sems can la go cha dor bar mi bya/ sems can thams cad kyi thad du sems can bskyab pa'i brtson pa las ldog par mi bya/ sdug bsngal thams cad bsal ba'i yongs su bsngo ba las ldog par mi bya/ dge ba'i rtsa ba chung ngu yongs su bzung bar mi bya/ yongs su bsngo ba chung ngus chog par mi bsam mo zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /

Instead, when the sun-god rises, in a single sun-disk, without a companion, illumination appears for all sentient beings in the four-continent world-realm. In just the same way, a bodhisattva great being who is carrying out wholesome actions, when dedicating a wholesome action, should arouse the following thought: “Those sentient beings do not have any wholesome actions by which they could save themselves; how much less so [could they save] others? I am now gathering wholesome actions for the sake of all sentient beings. I dedicate this wholesome action to free all sentient beings, to provide light for all sentient beings, to teach all sentient beings, to liberate all sentient beings,[xxiv] to uphold all sentient beings, to develop all sentient beings fully, to gain the trust of all sentient beings,[xxv] to delight all sentient beings, to cut through the doubts of all sentient beings. For aeons, I should be like the disk of the sun. I should expect no help from anyone else. I shouldn’t make room for someone else and then remove the armor that is for sentient beings. And in the presence of all sentient beings, I should not stop my efforts to save all sentient beings. I should not cease destroying all forms of suffering through practicing dedication. I should not be possessive about small wholesome actions, nor be satisfied with a small dedication.

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pas zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / de bskal pa 'di snyed cig tu go cha bgo'o/ / bskal pa 'di snyed cig tu go cha mi bgo'o/ / zhes bskal pa bgrangs pas byang chub mi tshol gyi bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i go cha gyon par byed do/ / gal te 'khor ba'i sngon gyi mtha' ji tsam pa de tsam la nyin zhag gcig tu gyur la/ nyin zhag gi tshul de lta bu'i nyi ma bco lngas zla ba phyed du gyur la/ nyi ma sum cus zla ba gcig tu gyur te/ zla ba bcu gnyis kyis lo gcig tu gyur la/ lo bgrang ba 'dis lo 'bum la byang chub kyi sems gcig bskyed cing / de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas gcig mthong la/ 'jug pa 'di dang bgrang ba 'dis gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi sems bskyed pa dang de bzhin gshegs pa mthong bas sems can gcig gi sems dang spyod pa shes par gyur la/ 'jug pa 'di dang bgrangs pa 'dis de snyed kyi sems bskyed pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa mthong bas sems can thams cad kyi sems dang spyod pa rnams shes par gyur kyang / mi zhum pa'i go cha 'di ni byang chub sems dpa'i go cha mi zad pa zhes gsungs so/ / de bzhin du sbyin pa la sogs pa dang byang chub kyi phyogs dang skyes bu chen po'i mtshan rnams la yang sbyar ro/ /

And so on. The noble Inquiry of Akṣayamati Sūtra also says, They do not seek Awakening by an enumeration of aeons, thinking, “For this many aeons I will wear the armor, for that many aeons I will wear the armor.” Rather, they wear the armor for inconceivably long, as long as [the time since] the most remote past in cyclic existence. “Suppose that in the course of one day and night, or in the same way, during a fortnight of fifteen days, or a month of thirty days, or a year of twelve months, or for some number of years, and so on up to: in the course of one hundred thousand years, I were to arouse Awakening Mind once, and see one Tathāgata, a Saint, genuinely and fully Awake. Suppose that through this intentness of purpose, by this enumeration, through arousing the Awakening Mind and seeing Tathāgatas on occasions as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, I could come to know the thoughts and actions of a single sentient being. Then through that very intentness of purpose, by this enumeration, each through that number of occasions of arousing the Mind and seeing a Tathāgata, I will discern the thoughts and actions of all sentient beings.” This is the undaunted armor of a bodhisattva, the indestructible armor. The same method should be used in relation to generosity, the marks of a great person, and whatever is conducive to Awakening.

'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las kyang / 'di la byang chub sems dpa' sems can dmu rgod sems can gdul dka' bar rig ste/ de rnams kyis yi chad nas 'di lta bu'i dmu rgod 'di lta bu'i gdul dka' ba'i sems can 'di dag gis chog go zhes te/ gzhi de las yongs su skyo zhing rgyab kyis phyogs par 'gyur te/ gang na sems can 'di lta bu dag gi ming yang mi thos pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dag par smon lam ni 'debs so/ / sems can gyi don la ma phyogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni yongs su dag pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams su yang skye bar mi 'gyur te/ de la byang chub sems dpa' shes rab can ni 'di ltar sems can gyi khams thams cad na sems can gang rnams ngan pa brtson 'grus chung ba blun po glen pa lug ltar lkugs pa'i rang bzhin can yongs su mya ngan las mi 'da' ba'i chos can/ sems can gyi khams ma lus pa 'di las bsnyigs pa sangs rgyas thams cad dang byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis spang bar gyur pa yod pa de dag bdag gi sangs rgyas kyi zhing du 'dus par gyur la/ bdag gis de dag byang chub kyi snying po la 'dug tu bcug ste/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya bar bya'o snyam du sems bskyed de/ byang chub sems dpa' de ltar sems pa'i sems bskyed pa re re la yang bdud kyi gnas thams cad rab tu g.yo'o/ / sangs rgyas thams cad kyang de'i bsngags pa gsung bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs so/ / de ltar re zhig bsod nams mngon par spel bar 'dod pas brtson pa brtan par bya'o/ / da ni bsam pa brtan par bya ba brjod par bya ste/ brtan par bya ba 'dis ci bya snyam du rtog pa bsal ba'i phyir/ 'phags pa chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las gsungs pa/ bcom ldan 'das bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa ni chos rnams kyi rtsa ba ste/ gang la bsam pa ma mchis pa de la sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad ring ba lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa la ni/ gal te sangs rgyas mi bzhugs na yang nam mkha'i dkyil dang rtsig pa dang shing rnams las chos 'byung ngo / / byang chub sems dpa' bsam pa dag pa la ni rang gi yid kyi spyod pa nyid las gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa 'byung ngo / / bcom ldan 'das de bas na byang chub sems dpa' bsam pa phun sum tshogs par bgyi'o/ /

The noble Cloud of Jewels also says, A bodhisattva who knows how unruly sentient beings are, and how difficult sentient beings are to tame, should not think: “I’ve had enough of these sentient beings, so unruly, so difficult to tame!” Nor should the bodhisattva, distressed for that reason, turn away from them and make a vow to be reborn in the pure world-realm, where even the name of such sentient beings is not heard. For those who turn their face away from sentient beings, there is no rebirth in the pure world-realm of the bodhisattvas. In such a case, a wise bodhisattva should think as follows: “As for those sentient beings in this realm of sentient beings who may be inferior,[xxvi] blind, profoundly retarded, deaf, or mute, not destined for Nirvāṇa, all the chaff of the realm of sentient beings,[xxvii] who are rejected by all the Buddhas and bodhisattvas—may there be a multitude of them in my Buddha-field. Having set them all on the seat of Awakening, I should help them to awaken fully to highest genuine full Awakening.” For every time a bodhisattva arouses the Mind while reflecting in this way, all the abodes of Māra shake, and all the Buddhas speak her praises. And so on, up to: Those wishing to enhance goodness should make their intention stable. The meaning of “making intention stable” will now be explained. The Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together offers an explanation to remove the doubt, “What’s the point of making this stable?”[xxviii] It is as follows: Blessed One, correct intention is the root of all the virtues of a Buddha. When people do not have intention, all the virtues of a Buddha are far away from them. Blessed One, for someone who has intention, if Buddhas are not present, Dharma teachings are produced from the sky, from walls, and from trees. For bodhisattvas whose intention is pure, all the admonitions and practice instructions are produced from the dialogue in their own minds. Therefore, Blessed One, a bodhisattva should have intention.

bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na gang la rkang pa mchis pa de la 'gro ba mchis so/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du gang la bsam pa mchis pa de la sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams mchis so/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste dper na/ yan lag gi dam pa mgo gang la mchis pa de la 'tsho ba mchis so/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du bsam pa gang la mchis pa de la sangs rgyas kyi byang chub mchis so/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na gang la 'tsho ba mchis pa de la rnyed pa mchis so/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du gang la bsam pa mchis pa de la sangs rgyas kyi rnyed pa mchis so/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na zhugs shing mchis na zhugs 'bar gyi zhugs shing ma mchis na zhugs mi 'bar ro/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du bsam pa mchis pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de la sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams 'bar gyi bsam pa ma mchis pa la mi 'bar ro/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na sprin chags na char 'bab kyi sprin ma chags na char mi 'bab po/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du bsam pa ma mchis na sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams 'byung gi bsam pa mchis na mi 'byung ngo / / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na zhugs shing gang rtsa ba nyams pa de las me tog dang 'bras bu rnams mi 'byung ngo / / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du gang bsam pa log par zhugs pa de las dge ba'i chos thams cad mi 'byung ngo / / bcom ldan 'das de bas na byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi byang chub tshol bas rang gi bsam pa shin tu bzung ba dang shin tu bsrung ba dang shin tu sbyang bar bgyi'o zhes bya ba'o/ /

[285] For example, Blessed One, those who have feet can walk. In the same way, Blessed One, those who have intention can have the qualities of the Buddhas. For example, Blessed One, those who have heads[xxix] are able to live. In the same way, Blessed One, those who have intention can have the Awakening of the Buddhas. For example, Blessed One, those who are alive can make gains. In just the same way, Blessed One, those who have intention can gain Buddhahood. For example, Blessed One, if there is firewood, there can be a fire, but without firewood, there can be no fire.[xxx] In just the same way, Blessed One, in the bodhisattvas who have intention, all the qualities of a Buddha can blaze, but without intention, they do not. For example, Blessed One, when there are rain-clouds, rain falls, and when there are not, it does not fall. In just the same way, Blessed One, in those who have intention, the virtues of a Buddha unfold.[xxxi] For example, Blessed One, when the root of a tree is rotten, flowers and fruits no longer grow. In just the same way, Blessed One, in those whose intention is rotten, all wholesome states no longer arise. Now therefore, Blessed One, bodhisattvas who have as their goal the Awakening of the Buddhas should make their intentions firmly held, well protected, well purified, and well guarded.[xxxii]

bsam pa zhes bya ba 'di ji lta bu zhe na/ 'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las/ bsam pa de yang ma byas pas na bcos ma ma yin no/ / g.yo med pas na ma byas pa'o/ / rab tu rtogs pas na g.yo med pa'o/ / sgyu med pas na rab tu rtogs pa'o/ / dag pas na sgyu med pa'o/ / drang bas na dag pa'o/ / gya gyu med pas na drang ba'o/ / gsal bas na gya gyu med pa'o/ / mi mnyam pa med pas na gsal ba'o/ / sra bas na mnyam pa med pa'o/ / mi phyed pas na sra ba'o/ / mkhrang bas na mi phyed pa'o/ / mi g.yo bas na mkhrang ba'o/ / mi gnas pas na mi g.yo ba'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / 'di nyid yon tan lhag pa thob par bya ba'i phyir zhugs pa ni lhag pa'i bsam pa zhes bya'o/ /

What does this term “intention” mean? The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra teaches, When this intention is not fabricated, it is not contrived. When it is sincere,[xxxiii] it is not fabricated. When it is fully known, it is sincere. When it is without illusion, it is fully known. When it is pure, it is without illusion. When it is straight, it is pure. When it is not crooked, it is straight. When it is clear, it is not crooked. When it has no unevenness, it is clear. When it is firm, it has no unevenness. When it is indestructible, it is firm. When it is stable, it is indestructible. When it is unmoving, it is stable. When it abides nowhere,[xxxiv] it is unmoving. And so on. This exactly, as well as the unfolding of greater and greater mastery of abilities, is called “higher intention.”

de nyid las ji skad du/ bye brag tu 'gro ba'i phyir rgyal ba'i lhag pa'i bsam pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa dang / yang lhag pa'i bsam pa zhes bya ba ni 'byung po rnams lus nges pa'o/ / sems can thams cad la byams pa'o/ / 'phags pa rnams la phan par sems pa'o/ / 'phags pa ma yin pa la snying rje ba'o/ / bla ma la rim gro byed pa'o/ / dpung gnyen med pa rnams la dpung gnyen no/ / skyabs med pa rnams la skyabs so/ / gling med pa rnams la gling ngo / / mgon med pa rnams la mgon no/ / grogs med pa rnams la grogs so/ / gya gyu can rnams la drang ba'o/ / dmu rgod rnams la gsal ba'o/ / g.yo can rnams la g.yo med pa'o/ / sgyu can rnams la sgyu med pa'o/ / byas pa mi gzo ba rnams la byas pa gzo ba'o/ / 'khu ba rnams la byas pa tshor ba'o/ / mi phan pa rnams la phan 'dogs pa'o/ / log par zhugs pa la bden pa'o/ / pho thegs can la nga rgyal med pa'o/ / legs par byas pa rnams la mi smod pa'o/ / gzhan gyi 'khrul pa la mi rtsod pa'o/ / log par zhugs pa rnams la kun du srung ba'o/ / thabs kyi dge ba spyod pa thams cad la nyes par mi lta ba'o/ / sbyin pa'i gnas rnams la rim gro byed pa'o/ / bstan pa la mthun par 'dzin pa'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

de ltar brtson pa dang bsam pa la brtan par byas nas/ snying rje mdun du bzhag nas su/ /dge ba spel la nan tan bya/ /chos yang dag par sdud pa'i mdo las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu ste/ de nas bcom ldan 'das la byang chub sems dpa' spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpas chos shin tu mang po la bslab par mi bgyi'o/ / bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpas chos gcig rab tu gzung zhing rab tu rtogs par bgyis na/ bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad de'i lag mthil du mchis pa lags so/ / chos gcig pu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ snying rje chen po'o/ / bcom ldan 'das snying rje chen pos ni sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi lag mthil du mchis pa lags so/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po'i 'khor lo rin po che gang du mchi ba der dpung gi tshogs thams cad mchi'o/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i snying rje chen po gang du mchi ba der sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad mchi'o/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na gdugs shar na sems can rnams kyi bya ba thams cad shin tu mang bar 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du snying rje chen po gang du shar bar gyur pa der byang chub byed pa'i chos kyi bya ba gzhan rnams kyang shin tu mang bar 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na yid kyis byin gyis brlabs pa'i dbang po thams cad ni rang rang gi yul 'dzin pa la 'jebs par 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du snying rje chen pos byin gyis brlabs pa'i byang chub par byed pa'i chos rnams rang rang gi bya ba la rab tu 'jebs par 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das 'di lta ste/ dper na srog gi dbang po mchis na dbang po gzhan rnams 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin du snying rje chen po mchis na byang chub par byed pa'i chos gzhan rnams kyang 'byung bar 'gyur zhes bya ba'o/ /

In this way, with stable effort and intention, you should put compassion first, and then make an effort to increase goodness. As the noble Sūtra on Chanting the Dharma Together says, [287] Then the bodhisattva great being Avalokiteśvara said to the Blessed One, “Blessed One, bodhisattvas should not train in too many qualities. Blessed One, bodhisattvas should serve and understand one quality well, and then all the qualities of the Buddhas will be in the palms of their hands. What is that one quality? It is great compassion. Blessed One, through great compassion, all the qualities of the Buddhas are in the palms of bodhisattvas’ hands. For example, Blessed One, wherever the wheel-treasure of a world-emperor goes, his massed forces will go. In just the same way, Blessed One, wherever there is great compassion, there are all the qualities of a Buddha. For example, Blessed One, when the sun rises, sentient beings engage in abundant activities. In just the same way, Blessed One, when great compassion rises, all the other qualities that lead to Awakening become abundantly active. For example, Blessed One, all the sense-faculties, having mind as their basis, abundantly grasp their own objects. In just the same way, Blessed One, all the other qualities that lead to Awakening, having great compassion as their basis, abundantly perform their own functions. For example, Blessed One, when life is present, the other faculties operate. In just the same way, Blessed One, when great compassion is present, all the other qualities that lead to Awakening operate.

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las kyang / btsun pa sha ra dwa ti'i bu 'di lta ste/ dper na dbugs 'byung ba dang rngub pa ni/ skyes bu'i srog gi dbang po'i sngon du 'gro ba'o/ / de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' theg pa chen po bsgrub pa'i snying rje chen po yang sngon du 'gro ba'o/ / de bzhin du sbyar te/ 'di lta ste/ dper na tshong dpon nam khyim bdag bu gcig pa la snying thag pa nas sdug par 'dzin pa de bzhin du/ byang chub sems dpa' snying rje chen po la gnas pa yang sems can thams cad la snying thag pa nas sdug par 'dzin pa yin no zhes gsungs so/ / 'di ji ltar bsgom par bya zhe na/ rang gis sngon myong ba dang myong bar 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal dang 'jigs pa rnam pa du ma rang gis shin tu mi 'dod pa bsgoms te/ byams pa dang ldan pas sdug pa la sogs pa la byams pa bzhin du bsgom par bya ba'am da ltar byung ba'i sdug bsngal gyis nyen pa rnams dang sdug bsngal chen po'i rgya mtsho 'khor ba yun ring po dus tshigs med pa na sdug bsngal dang ldan pa rnams la bsgom par bya'o/ /

The noble Akṣayamati Sūtra also says, For example, Reverend Śāradvatīputra, in the case of a person’s life, breathing in and out comes first. In just the same way, Reverend Śāradvatīputra, for a bodhisattva practicing the Great Way, compassion comes first … For example, suppose that a guild president or a leading merchant were to love his only child with love that goes down to the marrow.[xxxix] In just the same way, a bodhisattva who has attained great compassion loves all sentient beings with a love that goes down to the marrow. How do you develop this? Meditate on various kinds of fear and suffering, extremely unwelcome to you, that you have experienced in the past or that you are experiencing now. Next, if you have done lovingkindness practice, begin with those dear to you, as in lovingkindness meditation, and proceed from there. Or reflect on the vast sea of suffering, pain, and sickness presently experienced by those attached to the unending calamity of cyclic existence.

'phags pa sa bcu pa las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu ste/ de 'di snyam du sems te/ kye ma'o byis pa so so'i skye bo 'di dag ni mi shes pa rmongs pa dag ste/ de dag gi lus grangs med pa 'gags la 'gag par 'gyur zhing 'gag bzhin te/ de ltar mchi yang lus la yid 'byung ba mi skyed cing / sdug bsngal gyi 'khrul 'khor je bas je 'phel du byed/ 'khor ba'i rgyud las mi ldog phung po'i gnas mi 'dor/ / khams kyi sbrul dag gis skyo bar mi 'gyur/ dga' ba'i 'dod chags kyis rmongs pa rtogs par mi byed/ skye mched kyi grong stong pa la mi lta/ ngar 'dzin pa dang nga yir 'dzin pa'i phra rgyas mi spong / nga rgyal dang lta ba'i zug rngu mi 'byin/ 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug gi me lce 'bar ba zhi bar mi byed/ ma rig pa'i mun pa mi sel/ sred pa'i rgya mtsho mi skems/ stobs bcu'i ded dpon yongs su mi tshol zhing bdud kyi bsam pa thibs po'i rjes su song ba ste/ 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho rnam par rtog pa rnam pa sna tshogs kyi chu srin 'dzin khris dkrugs pas yongs su g.yengs pa ngo mtshar che ste/ ma la bdag gis sems can de ltar sdug bsngal gyis nyam thag pa/ mgon med pa/ dpung gnyen med pa/ skyabs med pa/ gnas med pa/ gzhi med pa/ rten med pa/ long bar gyur pa/ ma rig pa'i sgo nga'i sbubs dang spris g.yogs pa/ mun pas zil gyis non pa de dag gi don du gcig pu gnyis su med par gyur nas/ bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs bsag par bya ba rnam pa ji lta bus sems can de dag shin tu rnam par dag pa 'thob par 'gyur ba nas/ stobs bcu'i stobs kyis ye shes chags pa med pa'i bar gyi mthar thug pa 'thob par 'gyur ba'i rnam pa de lta bu'i bsod nams dang ye shes kyi tshogs bsag par bya'o snyam mo zhes bya'o/ /

As the noble Sūtra on the Ten Stages says,[5] [288] [289] Oh no! It is astonishing how ignorant and confused these foolish ordinary people are. Innumerable bodies of theirs have been destroyed, are being destroyed, and will be destroyed; but while perishing in this way, they don’t develop disenchantment towards the body.[xl] They cause the machine of suffering to grow more and more; do not turn away from the great dangers of the torrent of cyclic existence; do not get out of the abode of the aggregates; do not become disgusted with those snakes, the components; do not awaken from the blindness of attraction to pleasure; do not carefully examine the empty town of the six sense-spheres; do not get rid of the reactive patterns of attachment to a sense of self and a sense of “mine”; do not pull out the arrow of pride and false views; do not calm the blazing flames of attraction, aversion, and delusion;[xli] do not dispel the darkness of ignorance and delusion; do not dry up the ocean of craving; and do not seek for the caravan-leader with the ten powers. They enter Māra’s impenetrable forest of hope. In the ocean of cyclic existence, agitated by various bad forms of mistaken conceptual thought and grasping, they swim around.[xlii] Without any refuge, hurrying in this way, they experience many forms of suffering: namely, the mental disturbances of birth, old age, disease and death, sorrow and lamentation, pain and suffering.[xliii] Oh! For the benefit of these sentient beings—tormented by suffering, with no guardian, with no friend to help, with no refuge, with no place to rest, with nothing to resort to, blind, covered by the eggshell of ignorance, overwhelmed by darkness—I alone, without a second, will endure while gathering such equipment of goodness and pristine awareness that, when that equipment of goodness and pristine awareness is ready, these sentient beings will attain limitless purity.[xliv]

yang de nyid las gsungs pa/ kye ma'o sems can 'di dag ni 'khor ba'i mya ngan gyi lam du zhugs pa/ sems can dmyal ba dang dud 'gro'i gnas dang gshin rje'i 'jig rten gyi g.yang sa la mngon du phyogs pa/ lta ba ngan pa'i dra ba nyam nga bar zhugs pa gti mug gi thibs pos kun nas yog pa/ log pa'i lam du zhugs pa/ ldongs par gyur pa/ yongs su 'dren pa med pa zhes bya ba nas/ de bzhin du sbyar te/ 'khor ba rgyun gyis bdas pa/ srid pa'i klung du zhugs pa/ shugs drag pos bdas te blta ba'i mthu med pa 'dod pa dang gnod sems dang rnam par 'tshe ba'i rnam par rtog pa mang po'i rjes su zhugs pa/ 'jig tshogs la lta ba chu srin chen pos zin pa/ 'dod pa thibs po'i klong du zhugs pa/ dga' ba can dang 'dod chags kyi dkyil du kun du thogs pa/ nga'o snyam pa'i nga rgyal gyi thang la 'khyams pa/ dpung gnyen med pa/ skye mched kyi grong nas ma 'phags pa/ sgrol ba la mkhas pa dang bral bar gyur pa yin gyi/ de dag bdag gis snying rje chen po dang dge ba'i rtsa ba'i stobs kyis bton te/ thams cad mkhyen pa'i gling 'tshe ba med pa rdul med pa 'jigs pa dang skrag pa thams cad med pa la rab tu dgod par bya'o/ / kye ma'o sems can 'di dag ni sdug bsngal ba dang yid mi bde ba dang 'khrug pa mang po mang ba/ sdug pa dang mi sdug pa dang 'brel pa/ mya ngan dang smre sngags 'don pa dang bcas pa'i rjes su rgyu ba/ sred pa'i sgrog tu bcug pa/ khams gsum pa'i ma rig pa'i thibs pos kun nas khebs pa yin gyi/ de dag bdag gis khams gsum pa'i gnas thams cad la dben pa/ mya ngan las 'das pa la rab tu dgod par bya'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / de ltar brtson pa dang bsam pa dang snying rje gcig gis gcig brtan par byas pa de dag gi bsod nams mngon par spel ba rtsom mo/ / de la re zhig

Similarly, the same text says: Oh no! These sentient beings are now on the road in the vast and dreary forest of cyclic existence, with their faces turned towards falling into the hells, animal wombs, and the world of Yama; caught in the net of worthless views and deceit; surrounded by the thicket of delusion; on the wrong road; blind and lacking guides … carried along by the torrent of cyclic existence; seized by a strong current; unable to see; walking on the precipice of sensual desire, malice, doubt, violence, and mistaken conceptual thoughts;[xlv] seized by the great crocodile of the false view of a real self;[xlvi] inside the whirlpool,[xlvii] the thicket, of sensual desire; stuck in the middle of attraction and pleasure; wandering on the vast plain of the conceit that “I am”;[xlviii] with no friend to help; not leaving the village of the sense-spheres; lacking the equipment of goodness[xlix]—through the power of[l] great wholesome actions, I will pull them out, and place them on the fortunate island of jewels, which is complete knowing, dustless, and safe from all troubles. Oh no! These sentient beings are locked up, bound by many forms of pain and suffering, many forms of mental disturbance, partiality, hostility, likes, and dislikes; anxious because of sorrow and lamentation; bound by the fetter of craving; surrounded by the thicket of illusion, deception, and ignorance;[li] in the prison of the three worlds. I will establish them far away from all the three worlds, in the city of fearlessness, in the pacification of all forms of suffering, in undistorted Nirvāṇa.[lii] And so on. In this way, you should undertake to increase goodness through effort, intention, and compassion, which stabilize each other. On this topic,
bzang po spyod pa'i cho ga bzhin/ / phyag 'tshal la sogs gus par bya/ /
[25ab] You should perform the ritual of Good Conduct, [290] Performing the reverence and so on with respect.

drag shul can gyis zhus pa las/ nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum du/ gtsang ba dang gos gtsang ma bgos te phung po gsum pa bklag par bya'o zhes gsungs so/ / de la phung po gsum ni sdig pa bshags pa dang / bsod nams kyi rjes su yi rang ba dang / sangs rgyas la bskul ba zhes bya ba ste bsod nams kyi phung po yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de la phyag 'tshal ba ni sdig pa bshags pa'i nang du 'dus te sangs rgyas la phyag 'tshal nas sdig pa bshags so zhes nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa las bstan pa'i phyir ro/ / gsol ba gdab pa ni bskul ba dang don gcig pa'i phyir ro/ / mchod pa ni 'byor pa med pa'i phyir mi rtag pas ma smos so/ / yid dang ngag ni mdo sde gzhan las grags pa'i phyir ma bshad de/ / tshig gsum ni gtso bo yin par shes par bya'o/ / de la phyag 'tshal ba ni sangs rgyas thams cad la phyag 'tshal lo zhes bya ba lta bu ste/ tshigs su bcad pa bzhi pa dang / ji ltar ston pa'i bstod pa dang / bzang po spyod pa la sogs pa'i tshigs su bcad pa rnams kyis so/ /

For the noble Inquiry of Ugra states that three times a day and three times a night, clean and wearing clean clothes, you should read out loud the “three collections.”[6] Here the confession of vile actions, rejoicing in goodness, and asking the Buddhas to teach are called the “three collections,” because of the mass of goodness [that results from them.] In this context, reverence is included in the confession of vile actions, since the Inquiry of Ugra says, “After reverentially saluting the Buddhas, confess.” “Requesting teachings” and “asking the Buddhas to teach” are synonyms. Since making offerings is not relevant, it is not mentioned, due to impermanence.[liii] Since it is well known from other sūtras that you should use both thought and speech, this is not stated explicitly. Of the three, though, speech is most important. Here the homage is, “Reverential salutations to all Buddhas.” However, according to the noble Akṣayamati Sūtra, you should read the confession of your own and others’ wrong actions in the context of the equipment of goodness,[liv] with four verses, and as sung in the hymns, or using the verses in the noble Good Conduct.[7]
