mchod pa ni 'phags pa dkon mchog sprin gyi mdo las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu ste/ rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa' me tog gi rnam pa'am 'bras bu'i rnam pa nga yir bya ba med pa yongs su gzung ba med pa gang yin pa de rnams nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams la 'bul lo/ / dge ba'i rtsa ba de yang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu yongs su bsngo'o/ / de bdug pa'i shing ngam spos kyi shing ngam rin po che'i shing ngam dpag bsam gyi shing ngam me tog gi shing ngam 'bras bu'i shing nga yir bya ba med pa yongs su gzung ba med pa gang yin pa de lta bu de dag kyang nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams la 'bul lo zhes bya ba'o/ / dam tshig gsum bkod pa'i rgyal po las kyang thang las skyes pa'i rin po che'i ri rnams dang chu las skyes pa'i rin po che'i ri rnams dang thang las skyes pa'i rin po che la sogs pa phyogs bcu na rnam par gnas pa nga yir bya ba med pa yongs su gzung ba med pa rnams 'bul lo zhes gsungs so/ / phyogs 'dis sman thams cad dang bcud kyis len thams cad dang chu thams cad dang kha na ma tho ba med pa'i chu'i dkyil 'khor dang gser gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad dang / 'jig rten gyi khams chags pa rnams na ro dang reg pa mchog tu phun sum tshogs pa'i sa zhag dang bdud rtsi'i sbu gu dang ma rmos ma btab pa'i 'bras sA lu dang byang gi sgra mi snyan gyi gling dang 'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dag pa rnams na yod pa mchog tu nyams dga' ba'i longs spyod rnams 'bul lo/ /

As for making offerings, the noble Cloud of Jewels says, Here[lv] a bodhisattva, three times at night and three times during the day, offers the flowers or fruits that are unowned and not possessed to the Buddhas and bodhisattvas.[lvi] As for those incense trees, or perfume trees, or jewel trees, or wish-granting trees,[lvii] that are unowned and not possessed, the bodhisattva also offers those three times at night and three times during the day to the Buddhas and bodhisattvas. The noble Rulers of the Three Sacred Commitments also says, [291] It is said: I should give away all the jeweled mountains arising from dry land, and the jeweled mountains arising from the water, and all the jewels located in each of the ten directions that are unowned and not possessed; and in each direction, all the medicines, and all the alchemical elixirs, and all the waters, and all the spheres of water, and all the spheres of gold; and those foods in the world-realms[lviii] which have the very best taste and texture: edible mushrooms from the early Earth,[lix] nectar-giving plants, wild or cultivated rice, and whatever are the most pleasing foods in all the Uttarakuru continents in the pure world-realms.

'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las 'di skad du/ de mdo sde rnams las mchod pa dang rim gro bya ba rgya chen po gang yin pa de lta bu dag nyan cing / de dag snying thag pa nas lhag pa'i bsam pa mchog gis sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' rnams la yongs su bsngo'o zhes bya ba dang / de bzhin du mchod pa dang rim gro sna tshogs bya ba rjes su sems so zhes gsungs so/ / bshags pa ni sngar brjod pa nyid do/ /

And as the noble Cloud of Jewels says, They hear the lofty worship and prayers to the Tathāgatas in the scriptures, and out of aspiration for those, with the finest in higher intention, they dedicate to the Buddhas and bodhisattvas. Thus, they reflect on various forms of worship and prayers. Confession has been explained previously.

'phags pa blo gros mi zad pa'i mdo las ni/ bdag dang gzhan gyi sdig pa bshags pa ni bsod nams kyi tshogs su brjod do/ / rjes su yi rang ba ni bzang po spyod pa'i tshigs su bcad pa'am/ zla ba sgron ma'i rjes su yi rang ba'i le'u las so/ / gsol ba gdab pa ni bzang po spyod pa nyid kyis so/ / yongs su bsngo ba ni mtha' dag bzang po spyod pa nyid du rdzogs pa'am/ rdo rje rgyal mtshan gyi yongs su bsngo ba yang yin par blta'o/ /

But in the noble Akṣayamati Sūtra, confession of one’s own and others’ vile actions is said to be included in the equipment of goodness. Do the rejoicing using the verse from the Good Conduct, or using the chapter on rejoicing in the Candrapradīpa.[8] Asking the Buddhas to teach uses only the Good Conduct. But when you have found the fortunate opportunity, do the dedication using only the noble Good Conduct; or you should look at the dedication in the Vajra Flag Sūtra.

yang na sa bcu pa las gsungs pa'i smon lam chen po rnams te/ 'di lta ste/ sangs rgyas ma lus pa la mchod pa dang / rim gro lhag ma med pa mtha' dag bya ba'i phyir rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa/ mos pa rgya chen po rnam par dag pa chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar sangs rgyas 'byung ba bgrangs pa thams cad la mchod pa dang rim gro chen po bya ba rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po dang po mngon par bsgrub po/ /

Alternatively, [recite] the great vows proclaimed in the Sūtra on the Ten Stages. These are:[9] [292] They fulfill the first great vow, worship and prayers, which is: for the sake of offering worship and prayers universally to all Buddhas without exception, having what is best in all respects and lofty and pure religious commitment, exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of arisings of Buddhas.

'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis gsungs pa'i chos kyi tshul yang dag par bzung ba dang / sangs rgyas thams cad kyi byang chub yang dag par yongs su bzung ba dang / yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad kyi bstan pa yongs su bsrung ba'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar sangs rgyas 'byung ba bgrangs pa thams cad kyis dam pa'i chos yongs su bzung ba rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po gnyis pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

They fulfill the second great vow, upholding the holy Dharma, which is: having the Dharma eye proclaimed by all the Tathāgatas;[lx] upholding all the Buddhas and bodhisattvas;[lxi] protecting the religion of all the genuinely and fully awake Buddhas; exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of false imaginings and the full range of arisings of Buddhas.

'di lta ste/ 'jig rten gyi khams rab 'byam ma lus pa thams cad du sangs rgyas 'byung ba thams cad kyi dga' ldan gyi pho brang na bzhugs pa thog mar mdzad de/ 'pho ba dang gshegs pa dang / lhums na bzhugs pa dang / bltam pa dang / gzhon nu rol pa dang / btsun mo'i 'khor gyi nang na bzhugs pa dang / mngon par 'byung ba dang / dka' ba spyad pa dang / byang chub kyi snying por gshegs pa dang / bdud 'dul ba dang / mngon par rdzogs par byang chub pa dang / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bar bskul ba dang / yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa chen po ston pa'i drung du 'gro zhing mchod pa dang chos kyis yang dag par bsdu ba'i sbyor ba sngon du 'gro bas thams cad dus gcig tu bsgrub pa'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyi mthas klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar sangs rgyas 'byung ba bgrangs pa thams cad kyi gan du 'gro ba rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po gsum pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

[293] They fulfill the third great vow, approaching great Nirvāṇa, which is: in all world-realms {in the universe,} going through all the stages of the life of a Buddha: after living in the mansion in the Tuṣita heaven, and so on, then death, transmigration, abiding in the womb, birth, childhood, playing around, living among female company, leaving home, living through difficulties, approaching the seat of Awakening, overcoming Māra, Awakening, the request to teach, turning the great wheel of Dharma, and approaching great Nirvāṇa; through worship and through Dharma, correctly bringing together and putting into practice the preliminaries so as to attain everything in a single moment;[lxii] exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of arisings of Buddhas.

'di lta ste/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa thams cad shin tu rgyas pa/ che ba/ tshad med pa/ tha mi dad pa/ pha rol tu phyin pa thams cad kyis bsdus pa/ sa yongs su sbyong ba/ yan lag dang / nye ba'i yan lag tu bcas pa bsgrub pa dang / mtshan nyid 'dra ba dang / mi 'dra ba dang / 'du ba dang / rgyas pa dang bcas pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i spyod par gyur pa'i sa'i lam thams cad ji lta ba bzhin du ston pas pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su sbyang bar bya ba'i gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa rab tu sbyin pas brtan pa'i sems bskyed pa mngon par bsgrub pa'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar spyod pa/ bgrangs pa thams cad du rgyun mi 'chad par mngon par bsgrub pa'i smon lam chen po bzhi pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

They fulfill the fourth great vow, fulfilling their arousing of Awakening Mind, which is: being well equipped with all the Perfections, and the vast, extensive, measureless, and unbroken aspects of the bodhisattvas’ way of life; training in all the Stages; attaining the major and minor aspects, and so on up to: all aspects of the bodhisattvas’ way of life, including those that are as if having characteristics, those that are as if not having characteristics, contraction, and expansion; instruction in the paths of the real, genuine Stages, preparing the Perfections, spiritual advice, practice instructions, encouragement, and assistance; in order to fulfill their arousing of Awakening Mind, exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of practices.

'di lta ste/ sems can gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad gzugs can dang / gzugs med pa dang / 'du shes can dang / 'du shes can ma yin pa dang / 'du shes med 'du shes med min dang / sgo nga las skyes pa dang / mngal nas skyes pa dang / drod gsher las skyes pa dang / rdzus te skyes pa dang / khams gsum du gtogs pa/ 'gro ba drug tu 'dus pa/ skye ba thams cad du gtogs pa/ ming dang gzugs kyis bsdus pa'i sems can ma lus pa thams cad yongs su smin par bya bar sangs rgyas kyi chos la gzud pa dang 'gro ba bgrangs pa thams cad gcad pa dang thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes la rab tu dgod pa'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa bskal pa bgrang bar sems can gyi khams bgrangs pa thams cad yongs su smin par bya ba rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po lnga pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

They fulfill the fifth great vow, helping the whole realm of sentient beings to mature, which is: with respect to the whole realm of sentient beings—embodied and formless; with concepts, with no concepts, and those included in neither category; born from eggs, born from a womb, born from warmth and moisture, and magically appearing; included in the three worlds, coming together in the six realms, included in all the places of rebirth, having name and form—in order to help them to mature, help them enter into all the qualities of the Buddhas, cut off the whole list of rebirths, and establish them in complete knowing, exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of sentient beings.

'di lta ste/ 'jig rten gyi khams shin tu rgyas pa dang / tha gru che ba dang / tshad med pa dang / phra ba dang / rags pa dang / snrel zhi dang / spyi'u tshugs dang / ngos phyal ba dang / 'jug pa'i khyim can dang / mig 'phrul ltar rnam par phye ba dang / phyogs bcu rnam pa tha dad pa rnam par 'byed pa la 'jug pa la ma lus pa/ ye shes kyi khong du chud par bya zhing mngon du 'gyur bar bya ba'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar 'jig rten gyi khams bgrangs pa thams cad du 'jug pa rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po drug pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

They fulfill the sixth great vow, entering a variety of world-realms, which is: going into and living in all the world-realms without exception: which are vast, huge, very extensive,[lxiii] immeasurable, subtle, and lofty, some of which are inverted, some upside down, and some level; and, in order to grasp and directly perceive pristine awareness, analyze how [they are like] optical illusions, and analyze the full variety of everything in the ten directions, exhausting the vast realm of totality and {the realm of} space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of world-realms.

'di lta ste/ zhing thams cad zhing gcig dang / zhing gcig zhing thams cad du yang dag par gzhol bar bya ba yongs su sbyong ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing tshad med pa dag 'od dang rnam par bkod pa'i rgyan gyis rab tu brgyan pa dang / yongs su dag pa'i lam dang ldan pas nyon mongs pa thams cad bsal ba dang / sems can ye shes kyi 'byung gnas tshad med pas rab tu gang ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi yul rgya chen po la yang dag par gzhol ba dang / sems can gyi bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag par bstan cing shin tu tshim par bya ba'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar sangs rgyas kyi zhing bgrangs pa thams cad yongs su skyong ba rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po bdun pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

[294] They fulfill the seventh great vow, purifying all Buddha-fields, which is: in order to satisfy sentient beings, showing them, according to their aspirations, the purification of all fields as one field, and each field as all fields, in a single collection:[lxiv] the immeasurable, resplendent array of Buddha-fields, adorned with ornaments, endowed with the path of purification for removing all reactive emotions, completely full of innumerable sentient beings who have aspects of pristine awareness, the collection of all[lxv] the lofty domains of the Buddhas, exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of Buddha-fields.

'di lta ste/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang bsam pa dang sbyor ba gcig par bya ba dang / 'gran zla med pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba bsag par bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad dang dmigs pa gcig pas mnyam pa nyid du bya ba dang / rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par byang chub sems dpa' dang 'grogs shing mi 'bral bar bya ba dang / sangs rgyas 'byung ba ci dgar bstan par bya ba dang / rang gi sems bskyed par de bzhin gshegs pa'i mthu ye shes kyi mthu khong du chud par bya ba dang / ma nyams shing rjes su 'gro ba'i mngon par shes pa rab tu thob par bya ba dang / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad rnam par rgyu bar bya ba dang / 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad du snang ba thob par bya ba dang / skye ba thams cad du rang gi lus rjes su 'gro bar bya ba dang / theg pa chen po bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang ldan par bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad par bya ba'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar spyod pa bgrangs pa thams cad du theg pa chen po la 'dzud pa rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po brgyad pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

They fulfill the eighth great vow, entering the Great Way, which is: for the sake of putting into practice the single intention of all bodhisattvas, having no rival at gathering wholesome actions, equally having the same object as all bodhisattvas, always having attention on the Buddhas and bodhisattvas and never losing it, manifesting the arising of a Buddha whenever they wish, arousing their own minds to master the power and pristine awareness of the Tathāgatas, practicing without interruption in order to attain higher knowing, traveling through all the world-realms, attaining the radiance of all religious assemblies, undergoing all forms of rebirth in their own bodies, having the inconceivable Great Way, and distinguishing between the various aspects of the bodhisattvas’ way of life, exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of aspects of the way of life.

'di lta ste/ phyir mi ldog pa'i 'khor lo la yang dag par gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa spyad par bya ba dang / lus dang ngag dang yid kyi las don yod par bya ba dang / mthong ma thag tu sangs rgyas kyi chos nges par thob par bya ba dang / dbyangs brjod ma thag tu ye shes khong du chud par bya ba dang / dad par gyur ma thag tu nyon mongs pa ldog par bya ba dang / sman gyi rgyal po lta bu'i lus thob par bya ba dang / yid bzhin gyi nor bu lta bu'i lus thob par bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po'i spyod pa spyad pa'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar spyod pa bgrangs pa thams cad don yod par rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po dgu pa mngon par bsgrub po/ /

[295] They fulfill the ninth great vow, having an unfailing voice,[lxvi] which is: for the sake of mounting on the wheel that does not turn back and practicing all aspects of the bodhisattvas’ way of life, having unfailing action in thought, word and deed, definitely attaining all the qualities of a Buddha immediately as soon as they see him, mastering pristine awareness immediately as soon as he speaks, turning away from reactive emotions as soon as they feel confidence in him, fulfilling the supreme intention of the great Bhaiṣajyarāja,[lxvii] attaining a body like a wish-fulfilling gem, and practicing all aspects of the bodhisattvas’ way of life, exhausting the vast realm of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of aspects of the way of life.

'di lta ste/ 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas par bya ba dang / byis pa'i lam gcig dang tha mi dad par byis pa'i lam thams cad du skye ba dang / byang chub kyi snying por gshegs pa dang chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba dang / yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa chen po bstan par bya ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi yul chen po mthu dang ye shes kyi rjes su 'gro bas sems can gyi khams thams cad kyi bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du/ sangs rgyas 'byung bar dal ba/ dal ba la rtogs par byed/ zhi bar byed/ thob par byed cing bstan par bya ba dang / gcig mngon du yang dag par rtogs pas chos kyi dbyings thams cad mya ngan las 'das pas rgyas par bya ba dang / dbyangs gcig brjod pas sems can gyi khams thams cad kyi sems tshim par bya ba dang / yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa chen po bstan kyang spyod pa'i stobs rgyun mi gcad pa dang / ye shes chen pos chos thams cad 'byung bar byed pa bstan par bya ba dang / chos shes par bya ba dang / rdzu 'phrul dang sgyu ma'i mngon par shes pas 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad rgyas par bya ba'i phyir/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas par rgya che ba/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthas gtugs pa/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa/ bskal pa bgrang bar mngon par rdzogs par byang chub pa bgrangs pa thams cad du theg pa chen po mngon par bsgrub pa rgyun mi 'chad pa'i smon lam chen po bcu po mngon par bsgrub ste/ smon lam bcu po 'di dag mngon par bsgrub po/ / zhes bya ba'o/ /

[296] They fulfill the tenth great vow, fulfilling the Great Way, which is: for the sake of awakening to highest genuine full Awakening in all world-realms, so that through a single path for the foolish from which they do not turn back, all foolish ordinary people will be born and grow up, leave home, display miracles, reach the seat of Awakening, turn the wheel of Dharma, and show great Nirvāṇa; for the sake of attaining the power and pristine awareness of the great domains of the Buddhas, showing the whole realm of sentient beings, in accordance with their intentions, the arising of Buddhas in each moment, and causing them to attain the peace of Awakening; for the sake of shaking with one Awakening the magical productions in the whole ream of totality;[lxviii] for the sake of satisfying the inner aspirations of all sentient beings with one utterance of speech; for the sake of not interrupting the power of the way of life that manifests great Nirvāṇa; for the sake of showing the removal of everything at the stage of great pristine awareness; and for the sake of shaking all world-realms with the higher knowing that consists of growth in knowing Dharma, exhausting the vast ream of totality and the realm of space, remaining to the most remote future time, and pacifying the full range of aeons and the full range of Awakenings.

'di bsgom pa'i tshe thams cad la yang yongs su bsngo'o zhes bya bar sbyar ro/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi rnam par thar pa las gang gsungs pa de yang 'di ltar bya ste/ dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di sems can thams cad g.yang sa'i 'jigs pa dang bral bar bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad kyi rgyun las byung ba'i 'jigs pa rab tu zhi bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad kyi rmongs pa'i 'jigs pa bzlog pa'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad kyi bcing ba'i 'jigs pa bcad pa dang / sems can thams cad kyi srog 'chad par byed pa'i 'jigs pa rnam par bzlog pa dang / sems can thams cad kyi yo byad dang bral ba'i 'jigs pa bsal ba dang / sems can thams cad kyi 'tsho ba med pa'i 'jigs pa nye bar zhi bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad kyi tshigs su bcad pa med pa'i 'jigs pa las shin tu bzla ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ /

You should practice by meditating on this and dedicating the goodness to everyone. And you should practice in accordance with what is said in the noble Liberation of Avalokiteśvara: [297] I dedicate this wholesome action to drive away all sentient beings’ fear of heights. I dedicate to pacify all sentient beings’ internally generated fears and put a stop to their confused fears. I dedicate it to cut through all sentient beings’ fear of bondage; to stop all sentient beings’ fears of approaching deadly dangers; to take away all sentient beings’ fears of the lack of food; to pacify all sentient beings’ fears about their livelihood; to lead all sentient beings beyond the fear of disgrace.

sems can thams cad kyi 'khor ba'i 'jigs pa nye bar zhi bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad 'khor gyi nang du bag tsha ba'i 'jigs pa dang bral bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad 'chi ba'i 'jigs pa las shin tu bzlog pa dang / sems can thams cad ngan 'gro'i 'jigs pa las rnam par bzlog par bya ba dang / sems can thams cad yang ba'i 'gro ba mun pa mun nag can bzlog pa la snang bar bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ / sems can thams cad ris mi mthun pa dang phrad pa'i 'jigs pa dang shin tu bral bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad kyi sdug pa dang bral ba'i 'jigs pa 'gag pa dang / sems can thams cad kyi mi sdug pa dang 'grogs pa'i 'jigs pa bsal ba dang / sems can thams cad lus la yongs su gnod pa'i 'jigs pa dang shin tu bral bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad sems la yongs su gnod pa'i 'jigs pa las thar bar bya ba dang / sems can thams cad sdug bsngal dang yid mi bde ba dang 'khrugs pa las yang dag par bzla ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o zhes bya ba'o/ /

I dedicate it to pacify all sentient beings’ fears due to cyclic existence; to drive away all sentient beings’ shyness in assemblies; to lead all sentient beings past the fear of death; to stop all sentient beings’ fears of bad rebirths; and to make a light that will not fail sentient beings in darkness or in danger. I dedicate to drive away completely all sentient beings’ fears that result from paying attention to inappropriate things; to put a stop to all sentient beings’ fears of separation from those they love; to take away sentient beings’ fears of having to spend time with those they don’t like; to remove all sentient beings’ fears of bodily torment; to set all sentient beings free from fear of mental torment; and to lead sentient beings completely beyond all pain, suffering, and disturbances of the mind.

mdor na bzang po spyod pa las tshigs su bcad pa gnyis 'byung ba 'di ni yongs su bsngo ba bla na med pa ste/ 'jam dpal dpa' bos ji ltar mkhyen pa dang / / kun du bzang po de yang de bzhin te/ / de dag gi ni rjes su bdag slob cing / / dge ba 'di dag thams cad yongs su bsngo/ / dus gsum gshegs pa rgyal ba thams cad kyis/ / bsngo ba gang la mchog tu bsngags pa des/ / bdag gis dge ba 'di dag thams cad kyang / / bzang po spyod pa mchog phyir bsngo bar bgyi/ / zhes bya ba'o/ /

In brief, the highest dedication of all is this one, in verse, from the noble Good Conduct: Just as the hero Mañjuśrī[lxix] knows, And Samantabhadra likewise: I, while training, Pay homage to them with all this that is wholesome. Using whatever dedication is most highly praised By the Victors of past, present, and future, I dedicate all this that is wholesome To supreme good conduct.
bslab pa kun las btus pa las le'u bcu drug pa'o// //
bam po bcu gsum pa/

d.crumb: 17. phyag 'tshal ba la sogs pa'i phan yon

f.d: [phyag 'tshal ba la sogs pa'i phan yon]
17. Benefits of Reverential Actions
phyag 'tshal ba la sogs pa bshags pa des bsod nams 'phel bar 'gyur bar ci mngon zhe na/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs kyi mdo las shes te/ de las 'di skad du/
[298] WAYS OF ACTING reverentially, and so on, have already been explained. [It is said that] “this enhances goodness”—but how do we know? From the noble Avalokanā Sūtra. For it says:
ngas ni gang dag bstan pa yi/ / mi khom brgyad po de dag spong / / sangs rgyas 'byung ba rab mdzes pa/ / mnyes par byed 'di dal ba gcig /
Those whom I teach Leave behind the eight states with no opportunity to practice And gain this single opportunity to practice: The arising of a sublime Buddha.
mdog ldan gzugs ni phun sum tshogs/ / mtshan gyis legs par brgyan pa dang / / mthu dang stobs dang ldan par 'gyur/ / le lo can du de mi 'gyur/ /
Handsome and physically attractive, Ornamented with the marks of a great person, They have stamina and strength And don’t fail due to laziness.
de ni phyug cing nor cher 'gyur/ / bsod nams ldan zhing brdzi ba med/ / 'jig rten sgron ma mnyes byas nas/ / yang dang yang du bsti stang byed/ /
They are rich, with great wealth, Have goodness, and are not to be scorned. They make the Light of the World glad And then pay homage to him again and again.
tshong dpon khyim ni rgyas pa dang / / phyug po rnams su skye bar 'gyur/ / dpa' zhing sbyin pa'i bdag por gyur/ / lhug par gtong zhing ser sna med/ /
They are born rich, In the prosperous families of guild presidents, And those heroes become philanthropists, Giving gladly, with no greed.
ris bskor rgya mtsho tshun chad kyi/ / sa kun la ni de brten zhing / / de ni mnga' bdag gling bzhi yi/ / dbang phyug rgyas pa chos ldan 'gyur/ /
They may become righteous kings, Powerful lords of the four continents,[i] And rule the entire great earth With its rings of oceans and mountains.
'khor los sgyur ba rdzu 'phrul che/ / rin chen bdun dang ldan par 'gyur/ / rgyal srid gnas nas sangs rgyas la/ / yang dang yang du bsti stang byed/ /
They become magnificent world-emperors, Possessing the seven treasures, And, established in royal power, They pay homage to the Buddhas again and again.
'di nas shi 'phos mtho ris su/ / song nas sangs rgyas bstan la dang / / lhun po'i steng gi dbang phyug po/ / lha yi dbang po brgya byin 'gyur/ /
When they pass away from there, they go To heaven, trusting the Victor’s religion. They become Śakra, king of the gods, Lord at the peak of Mount Meru.
'jig rten mgon gyi mchod rten la/ / mi gang skor ba byed pa yi/ / bsngags pa bskal pa bye bar yang / / brjod pas zad par bya mi nus/ /
As for those who circumambulate A stūpa of the Lord of the World, No one could fully praise this practice in words, [299] Even in millions of aeons.
su zhig byang chub sems bskyed nas/ / ston pa'i mchod rten phyag 'tshal ba/ / de ni bskal pa bye bar yang / / nam yang long zhing 'theng mi 'gyur/ /
Those who arouse Awakening Mind And then revere a stūpa of the Teacher Will never be crippled or blind, Even in millions of aeons.
mchod rten bskor ba byas nas ni/ / brtson 'grus brtan zhing mthu brten la/ / brten zhing rnam par gnon brtan dang / / de ni myur du mkhas par 'gyur/ /
Heroes firm in perseverance, Firm in strength, and firm in courage, Those who have circumambulated stūpas Quickly become skillful.

gang zhig sangs rgyas bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong la/ / bskal pa bye ba gzhal byas bsti stang byas pa bas/ / gang zhig phyi ma mi bzang bskal pa 'di la ni/ / mchod rten phyag 'tshal de yi bsod nams shin tu che/ /
Suppose someone were to honor a hundred thousand million billion Buddhas For ten million aeons; Anyone who reveres a stūpa now, in this terrifying final period of an aeon, Gains more goodness.

sangs rgyas dam pa sbyin gnas mtshungs pa med gyur pa/ / spyod pa dam pa spyad nas khyad par brnyes gyur pa/ / mi yi khyu mchog de la 'dir ni mchod byas na/ / rnam par smin pa dam pa mtshungs med rang bzhin 'gyur/ /

For the Buddha is supreme, unequalled, and worthy of honor, Having lived the best life, having an extraordinary way of life. If people make offerings here To him, the bull among men, The result of evolution of that action Is the best, and unequalled in nature.
mi yi nang nas shi 'phos nas/ / sum cu gsum du 'gro bar 'gyur/ / der ni rin chen sna tshogs kyi/ / gzhal med khang pa thob par 'gyur/ /
When they pass away from among humans, They go among the thirty-three gods, And there gain flying palaces Made of various precious substances.
mchod rten phreng ba 'dir phul na/ / khang bzangs dag dang khang brtsegs pa/ / lha yi bu mos bsnyen pa rnams/ / sum cu rtsa gsum spyod par 'gyur/ /
Those who offer garlands of flowers to stūpas Are born among the thirty-three gods, And live in lofty mansions, Served by bands of celestial nymphs.
yan lag brgyad ldan chus gang zhing / / gser gyi bye ma bdal gyur pa/ / bai DUr+ya dang shel dag gi/ / lha yi rdzing bu thob par 'gyur/ /
They will have divine lotus-ponds Filled with water that is [the best] in the eight respects, Resting on golden sand, With crystals of lapis lazuli.
der ni lha yi dga' spyad nas/ / mkhas pas tshe tshad rdzogs par 'gyur/ / lha yi 'jig rten shi 'phos nas/ / mi nang longs spyod ldan par 'gyur/ /
After enjoying this divine delight, The wise will live out their lives And when they pass away from the god realm, [300] Become wealthy humans.
mchod rten phreng ba 'bul byed pa/ / tshe rabs bye ba stong rnams dang / / khrag khrig dag ni brgya bgrangs pa/ / kun du bkur sti byas par 'gyur/ /
Throughout hundreds of millions of billions of lives Those who give garlands to stūpas Will be honored from all directions.
mchod rten bye ba 'bul byed pa/ / de ni 'khor los sgyur rgyal 'gyur/ / brgya byin lha yi dbang phyug 'gyur/ / tshangs pa'i 'jig rten tshangs par 'gyur/ /
Those who give garlands to stūpas[ii] Become world-emperors; They become Śakra, king of the gods, And Brahmā gods in the Brahmā world.
'jig rten mgon po skyob pa la/ / dar gyi dbul ba phul byas na/ / lha yi dag dang mi rnams kyi/ / don rnams thams cad 'grub par 'gyur/ /
As for those who give gifts of colored cloth To the Savior, the Lord of the World, All their goals prosper, Both divine and human.[iii]
'jig rten mgon po skyob pa la/ / phreng ba'i khang pa byas nas ni/ / de yi g.yog 'khor mi byed cing / / rgyal po 'byor pa chen por 'gyur/ /
And those who build pavilions[iv] At places with sacred relics of the Lord of the World, They become magnificent kings Whose retinues are indivisible.[v]
'phags pa rnams kyis gang spangs pa/ / sdig pa'i las ni spong bar byed/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis bshad pa yi/ / dge ba'i las la rten par byed/ /
They give up the wrong actions that the Noble Ones give up, and rely on good actions as explained by the fully Awake Buddhas.
lha 'am 'on te klu rnams sam/ / 'jig rten dag ni gang mkhas pa/ / de dag dga' zhing mgu ba dang / / bsti stang byas shing bsngags par 'gyur/ /
Gods, serpent-spirits, And those in this world who are wise See them as dear, empathize with them, Honor and praise them.
brtan pa de ni gar skyes par/ / bsod nams gzi yis shin tu brjid/ / yul 'khor dag dang grong khyer dang / / rigs der bsti stang byas par 'gyur/ /
The families where these heroes are born, Shining with splendor and goodness, Are honored [301] In kingdoms and cities.
gang gis spos chu yungs 'bru tsam blangs te/ / bcom ldan mchod rten la ni bdug byed pa/ / de yi phan yon brjod kyis sems dang zhing / / rdul dang dri ma spangs la mnyan par gyis/ /
As for those who apply perfume to stūpas, Even an amount the size of a tiny mustard-seed, They hear me being praised, and trusting in me, They abandon dust and impurity.
de ni bsod nams ldan zhing phyogs kun rgyu/ / nad med gyur cing blo brtan bag yod ldan/ / spyad pa rnam par spyod tshe mya ngan 'dul/ / skye bo mang po dga' zhing yid du 'ong / /
They have goodness and move in every direction, Healthy and firm of mind, not heedless. Free from sorrow, they follow the spiritual life And become dear and agreeable to the multitude.
rgyal srid thob nas rgyal ba mchog bkur 'gyur/ / mthu chen rab mkhas 'khor los sgyur 'gyur te/ / gser gyi mdog ldan mtshan gyi go cha can/ / 'jig rten kun na yid 'ong dri ldan thob/ /
They gain political power and pay honor to the best of Victors, Becoming wise and mighty world-emperors. Golden-colored and with various marks, They gain enchanting scents everywhere in the world.
bcom ldan mchod rten gos kyis dkris byas na/ / de ni btsas ma thag tu gos mchog thob/ / lha yi khyad 'phags dar gos rab bzang rnyed/ / btsas ma thag tu de lus shin tu bde/ /
Those who decorate a stūpa of the Lord with robes As soon as they are born, receive the best garments, Divinely excellent and radiant, like those of Indra, And are happy, with healthy bodies.
gang zhig gos kyis bcom ldan mchod rten dang / / 'dren pa mtshungs med rnams la mchod byed pa/ / de 'dir mtshungs pa med pa'i lus 'thob ste/ / sum cu rtsa gnyis mtshan gyi me tog rgyas/ /
Those who offer robes at stūpas To the peerless Guides Have, in this world, incomparable bodies [302] Possessing the thirty-two marks.[vi]
bcom ldan mchod rten gos kyis dkris byas na/ / lag mthil nas ni mu tig phreng mdzes pa/ / sna tshogs dag dang seng ge'i phreng ba dang / / gser skud rab mdzes bskal pa mtha' yas 'byung / /

Those who wrap robes around a stūpa of the Blessed One Have pearl necklaces in the palms of their hands; For endless aeons, they variously display Lion-vine ornaments and beautiful cords of gold thread.
'jig rten sangs rgyas 'gyur zhes mos bskyed de/ / bcom ldan mchod rten ba dan phul byas na/ / de ni skye bo mang po'i mchod 'os 'gyur/ / byang chub spyod mchog dam pa zhi ba spyod/ /

Those who give flags to stūpas of the Blessed One, thinking “Through this, may the world become Buddhas!” Are worthy of offerings from the multitude And will lead the highest way of life, that of the Victors.[vii]
Their bodies are golden in color And they receive radiant robes, Of cotton and well-blended wool, Of fine dukūlaka fabric and also of the best silk.[viii]
rdul bsal sems can mchog la rgyal mtshan phul/ / ring por mi thogs nor mang rnyed par 'gyur/ / shes rab mtha' yas mdzod ni mang ldan yang / / sems chung mi 'gyur dman pa'i sems mi 'gyur/ /

Those who give flags to the highest of sentient beings clear away dust, And soon obtain abundant wealth. Their storehouses are full and their wisdom is endless; Others serve them, and they are not dejected.[ix]
de ni gzhan la gnod pa'i sems mi skyed/ / sems ni rab dang rtag tu bag yod ldan/ / de la me dang dug dang mtshon mi tshugs/ / skye bo tshogs chen gyis ni blta bar 'gyur/ /
sangs rgyas mchod rten mar me gcig phul na/ / 'di nas bzung ste srid pa'i rtse mo'i bar/ / sangs rgyas zhing ni 'dzam gling gser gyis gang / / de 'dra'i dpal de zad par bya mi nus/ /
bcom ldan mchod rten mar me phul byas na/ / de yi lus ni mdog ngan yong mi 'gyur/ / gzugs mchog sra zhing lag pa gzu ba 'dra/ / snang ba thob nas 'jig rten kun du rgyu/ /

Those who give oil-lamps to stūpas of the Buddha Have bodies that are beyond all criticism, And their lives are stable, well-protected, and out of all danger.[x] They attain brightness and then travel throughout the world.
gal te khrag khrig brgya stong sangs rgyas zhing / / yungs 'bru dag gis byur bur gang gyur pa/ / bgrang ba dang ni gzhal zhing brjod par nus/ / bde gshegs mar me gcig phul de lta min/ /

Suppose ten million billion Buddha-fields Were full, right up to the top, with mustard-seeds. It would still be possible to count, measure, or express [their number.] Not so for [the goodness gained by] anyone who places one lamp before the Tathāgatas.

rgyan gyis brgyan pa'i gzugs mdzes blta sdug pa/ / su zhig bcom ldan mchod rten 'bul byed pa/ / de 'dir lus ni mtshungs pa med 'gyur te/ / gang gis rgyal ba'i sku ni rab 'bar ba/ / sum cu rtsa gnyis mtshan gyi go bgos 'gyur/ / khyad par 'phags pa'i gzugs dang gser 'dra dang / / 'dzam gling gser ltar rab mdzes blta na sdug / mtshan gyi me tog rgyas pas mngon du gang / /

Those who give parasols to stūpas of the Blessed One, Decorating them with whatever is appealing and radiant, Have in this world incomparable bodies With the thirty-two marks of a great person, Like the shining body of the Victor, Whose excellent form is like gold, Appealing and radiant like gold from the Jambu River, Strewn with the flowers that are the marks.

mngon par shes pa 'thob cing dbang cher grags/ / byang chub spyod mchog dam pa zhi ba spyod/ / de ni nams kyang longs spyod 'grib mi 'gyur/ / lhas kyang bsti stang bya zhing mchod par 'os/ / brtan pa 'dod pa'i longs spyod gzhar mi dga'/ / tshul khrims rnam dag rab mkhas tshangs par spyod/ / yi dam bcas nas nags dang nags 'dab song / / mngon shes 'thob cing khyad par 'thob par 'gyur/ /

They obtain the superknowledges, and their names are renowned; They lead the best way of life. They do not lack for anything. [304] The gods regard them as teachers and make offerings to them. Being wise, they do not delight in sensual pleasures; Their moral discipline is pure and they live wholesome, celibate lives. They live in forests and groves, stabilizing attention, And are intent on meditative stability, attaining excellence.
bcom ldan mchod rten rnams la gdugs 'bul ba/ / ji lta bur yang byang chub sems mi 'dor/ / byams la gnas shing mi dman sems su 'gyur/ / de yi shes pa rnams kyang nyams pa med/ /
Those who give parasols to stūpas of the Blessed One Never forget what they know; Nor do they ever abandon the Awakening Mind. They dwell in lovingkindness, and their minds do not become lowly.
rol mo sgra yis mi mchog mchod byas na/ / mya ngan med cing dbang ldan rgyal por 'gyur/ / mi yi 'jig rten yid 'ong sgra ldan 'gyur/ / de sgra yan lag tshang zhing dag par 'ong / /
Those who offer worship in song to the bull among men Are never pierced by the arrow of sorrow;[xi] They will have enchanting voices in the human world, And their voices will be pure, without flaws.
bcom ldan mchod rten rol mo'i sgra byas na/ / shes bzhin ldan zhing mig ni rnam dag 'gyur/ / rna ba rnam par dag cing sems kyang dag / sna yi dbang po mchog dang ldan par 'gyur/ /
de yi lce ni rab mdzes blta na sdug / thog mar rab mnyen mdzes shing sgra yid 'ong / / dper na lha yi rin chen byi ru 'dra/ / sgra skad yan lag bye ba dpag med 'byin/ /

Their tongues are very beautiful and appealing to look at, Supple and pliant,[xii] radiant, making enchanting sounds, Like the red leaves of the gods, Producing ten million types of excellent sounds beyond measure.
bcom ldan mchod rten rol mo'i sgra byas na/ / nams kyang sbrul du mi 'gyur lce med min/ / zhar ba sgur po ya yo can mi 'gyur/ / lus ni khyad par 'phags shing shin tu mdzes/ /
Those who offer songs at stūpas of the Blessed One Never become snakes or lack tongues, Nor lame, humpbacked, or crooked, But will have extraordinary, radiant bodies.
bcom ldan mchod rten rol mo'i sgra byas na/ / lha 'am klu 'am mi 'am lto 'phye che/ / su yang de la ma dad skyed mi 'gyur/ / dbugs phyin thob nas 'jig rten kun du rgyu/ /
No one, whether gods, serpent-spirits, humans, or great snakes, Will ever mistrust Those who offer songs at stūpas of the Blessed One; Inspired, they travel through the whole world.
bcom ldan mya ngan 'das pa'i mchod rten phyags/ / bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du/ / yan lag ma smad khyad 'phags lus thob cing / / mdzes la mtshan gyis go char byas par 'gyur/ /

[305] Those who clean a stūpa of a Blessed One who has entered Nirvāṇa For a hundred thousand million trillion aeons Have extraordinary bodies with irreproachable limbs; They are lovely, having the marks of a great person.
bcom ldan mya ngan 'das pa'i mchod rten phyags/ / lha yi tsan+dan khyad 'phags rab mdzes pa'i/ / gzhal med khang mchog yid 'ong dri ldan 'thob/ / de ni de la nam yang sred mi skyed/ /

Those who clean a stūpa of a Blessed One who has entered Nirvāṇa Receive the best of palaces, enchantingly perfumed, Extraordinary and divine, of radiant sandalwood. They never arouse craving at any time.
rgyal ba'i mchod rten spos byug phul byas na/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi bstan pa 'jig 'gyur tshe/ / 'dzam bu'i gling du skye bar mi 'gyur zhing / / de ni de tshe mtho ris bdag por 'gyur/ /

As for those who give fragrant oil to stūpas of the Victor, They are never present on Earth When the religion of the best of Victors is being destroyed, But they are living in the heavens at those times.
rgyal ba'i mchod rten spos byug phul byas na/ / dri mi zhim dang mi gtsang smad pa rnams/ / rtag tu spong zhing tshul khrims phung por gnas/ / de ni rtag tu tshangs spyod mchog 'di spyod/ /
Those who apply fragrant oil to stūpas of the Victor Always avoid stinking, impure, disgusting sensual pleasures; Grounded in moral discipline, They always lead this, the best celibate life.
rgyal ba'i mchod rten spos byug phul byas na/ / 'di nas shi 'phos mtho ris lha dbang 'gyur/ / ring por mi thogs don stong rnams la rtog / lha rnams la ni rgya chen don kyang byed/ /

Those who apply fragrant oil to stūpas of the Victor, When they pass away from here, become kings of the gods in the heavenly realm; They quickly take the measure of a thousand benefits, And enjoy the extensive well-being of the deities.
rgyal ba'i mchod rten spos byug phul byas na/ / khyad 'phags tshig ldan sgra dbyangs yid 'ong 'gyur/ / skye bo mang po'i yid 'ong dga' zhing bkur/ / de yi kha bzhin rtag tu gsal bar 'gyur/ /
Those who apply fragrant oil to stūpas of the Victor Speak excellently, with enchanting voices, And are beloved and charming, honored by the multitude. They have happiness and are always confident.
rgyal ba'i mchod rten spos byug phul byas na/ / de ni ngan song sa rnams ma lus spong / / de bzhin gshegs dang nye ba 'thob par 'gyur/ / dad pa thob cing rtag tu bde ba dga'/ /
Those who apply fragrant oil to stūpas of the Victor Completely leave behind the lower realms And are seated before the Tathāgatas; [306] They earn people’s trust and are always happy and amiable.
bcom ldan mchod rten ba rgya bsal byas na/ / de ni mi khom brgyad po kun spong zhing / / de ni dal 'gyur de ni khyad par 'phags/ / de ni sangs rgyas mtshungs med mchod par byed/ /

Those who remove cobwebs[xiii] from stūpas of the Blessed One Leave behind all the states with no opportunity to practice And have to an exceptional degree the eight aspects of the opportunity to practice. They make peerless offerings to the Buddhas.
bcom ldan mchod rten ba rgya bsal byas na/ / bag yod blo gros brtan la dpa' bor 'gyur/ / 'dod pa'i yon tan dag la dga' mi bskyed/ / mi dman sems kyis mngon par 'byung bar 'gyur/ /

Those who remove cobwebs from stūpas of the Blessed One Are heroes, firm of mind and free from heedlessness. They take no delight in sensual pleasures And with their minds not cast down, are definitely on the path to liberation.
bcom ldan mchod rten ba rgya bsal byas na/ / de ni nams kyang byang chub sems mi 'dor/ / tshul khrims skyon med shin tu bsdams par 'gyur/ / rnam dag 'dod chags bral ba'i chos kyang 'thob/ /

Those who remove cobwebs from stūpas of the Blessed One Never forget the Awakening Mind And are well disciplined, with unbroken moral discipline. They attain the freedom from attraction that is religious and pure.
bcom ldan mchod rten ba rgya bsal byas na/ / de ni mdog ngan dus rnams rtag tu spong / / 'chal ba'i shes rab ma lus rnam par spong / / shes rab rgya chen gyur nas spyod la gnas/ /
Those who remove cobwebs from stūpas of the Blessed One Give up abusive speaking in all situations, Completely go beyond the lack of wisdom, And, rich in wisdom, dwell in this way of life.
bcom ldan mchod rten ba rgya bsal byas na/ / kha zas gtsang ma dag kyang rnyed 'gyur zhing / / khyad 'phags kha dog ldan zhing blta sdug pa/ / reg dang ldan zhing rab mdzes gos rnams 'thob/ /
Those who remove cobwebs from stūpas of the Blessed One Obtain pure food, and Receive excellent, colorful clothes, Pleasant to touch and very good-looking.
dad pa'i shugs bskyed bcom ldan mchod rten la/ / me tog skam po nyal nyil phyags byas na/ / 'dod pa smad pa sdug bsngal bye ba spong / / stobs bcu mnga' ba'i ded dpon mnyes par byed/ /

Those who pick up, from stūpas of the Victors, Dried-out, leftover garlands, arouse joyful energy, and then Withdraw from lowly sensual pleasures, leave behind ten million forms of pain,[xiv] [307] And please the caravan-leaders who have the ten powers.
mchod rten me tog rnying pa su 'phyag pa/ / de ni mdzes shing rnam dag lus su 'gyur/ / skye bo mang pos mchod 'os blta 'os 'gyur/ / de la rgyal po gnod par sems mi 'gyur/ /
Those who remove withered flowers from stūpas Are handsome and pure of body, Attractive to look at and worthy of reverence from the multitude. The king will not be angry at them.
bcom ldan mchod rten dag la snga rabs mis/ / me tog phul ba skam po phyags byas na/ / ngan song sa yi lam ngan thams cad gcod/ / byang chub sems dpa' tshul khrims phung por gnas/ /
Those who take away, from stūpas of the Victors, {Dried-out} flowers previously donated by others Block all the paths to the lower realms[xv] And are bodhisattvas who live in moral discipline.
mchod rten me tog rnying pa su 'phyag pa/ / bag yod mya ngan rnams dang skyon rnams spong / / nad rnams du ma ma lus rnam par spong / / bskal pa mtha' yas rnams su dbugs 'byin 'thob/ /
Those who remove withered flowers from stūpas With no heedlessness, leave behind sorrows and problems And completely leave behind many diseases. For endless aeons they are inspired.
mchod rten me tog rnying pa su 'phyag pa/ / sbyin gnas mtshungs med sems rgyas 'thob par 'ong / / mtshungs med thob cing lha mis mchod 'os 'gyur/ / rnam dag lus ldan rgyan gyis brgyan par 'gyur/ /

Those who remove withered flowers from stūpas Become Buddhas, incomparably worthy of honor, Having attained what is unequalled, they receive offerings from gods and humans. They are ornamented and pure of body.
lha yi me tog rab mdzes man+dar/ / mtshungs med pa ta la yang su 'bul dang / / mchod rten me tog nyal nyil su 'phyag pa/ / de dag rnam smin 'dra ste mchog tu 'gyur/ /

Compared with those who give radiant divine flowers, Trumpet-flowers, or those of the coral tree, Those who remove leftover garlands from stūpas Receive the best result of evolution; theirs is unequalled.
'jig rten sangs rgyas 'gyur byar mos bskyed de/ / ston pa'i mchod rten thal sbyar phyag 'tshal ba/ / 'jig rten dag na bla mar bkur sti bya/ / de ni mdzes shing blta na sdug par 'gyur/ /

Those who bow with hands together to a stūpa of the Lord, Arousing the motivation “May the world become Buddhas!” Are honored in the world and treated as spiritual teachers. They are handsome and attractive to look at.
de 'dir rgyal srid thob nas lha klu mi/ / lto 'phye che dang 'jig rten thams cad 'dud/ / stong gi 'jig rten khams kun rgyas par 'gyur/ / dbang phyug nyid du dbang thob rgyal srid bsten/ /
The whole world prostrates to their royal sovereignty; Gods, titans, serpent-spirits, and humans, The flowering world-realm with all its thousands.[xvi] Even lords serve the power of their rule.
de yi yul la sems can gang gnas pa/ / de kun sangs rgyas ye shes rdzogs par 'god/ / des ni ngan song sa yang rnam par spong / / de dag rnams kyis don mchog dam pa byed/ /

They will establish in the clear pristine awareness of the Buddhas All the sentient beings who live in their kingdoms; After those beings have left behind the lower realms, [308] They will confer on them the highest and best benefit.
bsod nams blo gros dran ldan mchod 'os 'gyur/ / dbugs phyin thob nas 'jig rten kun du rgyu/ / de yi g.yog 'khor yid 'ong sgra skad ldan/ / bsam pa ji bzhin de dag dga' ba bskyed/ /

They will be served by others, have lovely voices, Have goodness, and be mindful and worthy of reverence. Inspired, they will travel through the world, And always, in accordance with their intention, give rise to supreme delight.
gsal snyan ngag gis sems can go bar byed/ / de srog dbang phyug sus kyang phan mi byed/ / skye bo tshogs chen dag gis blta 'os 'gyur/ / de yi g.yog kyang dbyangs ldan yan lag dag /

They receive service and are pure of complexion;[xvii] With calm, honeyed words, they help sentient beings to understand. No one has lordship over them; They are worthy to be looked at by the multitude.
sangs rgyas mchod rten thal sbyar phyag 'tshal ba/ / sbyin dang snyan par smra dang don spyod dang / / don mthun pa dag skye bo mang la byed/ / spyos shing brgyad kyang khro ba'i dngos mi bskyed/ /
Those who bow with hands together to a stūpa of the Buddha Rejoice in giving; they love to benefit others. They have empathy with the multitude; As they are not bad-tempered, they do not get angry.
sangs rgyas mchod rten thal sbyar phyag 'tshal ba/ / mtho ris 'jig rten gnas shing lha dbang 'gyur/ / mir gyur na yang mi yi rgyal po 'os/ / de ni nam yang yongs su nyams mi 'gyur/ /
Those who, with hands together, reverentially salute a stūpa, When they arrive in the heavens, become kings of the gods; They become human, kings among men, And never suffer loss at any time.
sangs rgyas mchod rten thal sbyar phyag 'tshal ba/ / de ni nam yang ngan song phyis mi ltung / / 'jig rten 'dir de rtag tu 'dod pa spong / / nor can nang na phyug cing nor mang 'gyur/ /

Those who, with hands together, reverentially salute a stūpa of a Buddha Never fall to the lower realms; In this world, they avoid lowly sensual pleasures, And become rich and wealthy, with full storehouses.
yon tan ldan la tshig gcig su smra ba/ / de ni nam yang mi rigs bsngags mi spyod/ / mi yi 'jig rten gnas min spyod mi 'gyur/ / de la sems can mi ngoms dga' bar 'gyur/ /

Those who say a single word in praise of the one who has abilities[1] Never speak unreasonable words.[xviii] And, in the human realm, have no inappropriate anger. [309] Sentient beings are satisfied and rejoice in them.[xix]
* zhes gsungs so/ /

Those who, with lofty minds, take up a handful of flowers, And, trusting him, strew them before the Lord of the World, Have goodness in the human realm, And, standing in safety, show respect to the Victor. They have no sorrows or problems, hardness of heart, or impurity; They have matchless energy and well-formed limbs. To the multitude, they are delightful to look at, And avoid frightful sensual pleasures and their horrifying hostility.

snying rje chen po pad ma dkar po'i mdo las kyang / kun dga' bo nga 'dug pa la mngon sum du bsti stong byed pa dang bla mar byed pa nas mchod par byed pa'i bar lta zhog / gang ba yongs su mya ngan las 'das nas ring bsrel yungs 'bru tsam la bsti stong byed pa lta yang zhog / nga'i phyir mchod rten byas pa la gang bsti stong byed pa lta yang zhog ste/ kun dga' bo gang dag kha cig sangs rgyas la dmigs nas tha na sangs rgyas la dmigs pa'i sems kyis me tog gcig nam mkha' la 'dor na/ bsod nams kyi phung po de'i rnam par smin pa dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag thams cad kyi 'bras bu mya ngan las 'das pa yin te/ tha ma mya ngan las 'das par nga smra'o/ / kun dga' bo gang dag kha cig sangs rgyas la dmigs nas tha na sangs rgyas la dmigs pa'i sems kyis me tog gcig nam mkha' la 'dor na/ de'i rnam par smin pa gang yin pa de ni/ kun dga' bo gal te sems can 'ga' zhig bskal pa gcig tu 'khor ba la 'di ji srid par kun du brgyug cing 'khor yang / 'khor ba'i sngon gyi mtha' mi shes pa bzhin du bsod nams mngon par 'du bya ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba mngon par 'du byas pa de'i mtha' de ni brgya byin nyid rnams kyis rnyed par sla ba ma yin no/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kun dga' bo 'di ltar sangs rgyas la phul ba'i yon tan ni 'khor ba na spyod pa'i bde ba thams cad kyi mthas gtugs par sla ba ma yin te/ gzhan du na dge ba'i rtsa ba de'i 'bras bu mya ngan las 'das pa nyid 'bras bu yin pas tha ma mya ngan las 'da' bar nga smra'o/ /

The noble Lotus of Great Compassion Sūtra (Mahā-karuṇā-puṇḍarīka-sūtra) also says, Consider, Ānanda, those who show respect to me face to face; consider those who make offerings to relics of my body, even those the size of a mustard seed; consider those who perform acts of respect to stūpas that have been made in my name. Ānanda, suppose that someone, thinking of the Buddha, throws even as little as a single flower into space. Suppose that person were to wander in cyclic existence for as many aeons as there have been in beginningless cyclic existence, whose most remote past time cannot be discerned, and during that whole time, were to be a Śakra, a Brahmā god, a world-emperor: even so, the mass of goodness which is the result of evolution of that could not come to an end.[xx] Consider someone who, thinking of the Buddha, throws even as little as a single flower into space; or sentient beings who, even while dreaming, thinking of the Buddha, will throw even as little as a single flower into space. That wholesome action will eventually lead to Nirvāṇa, I say.[xxi]

kun dga' bo gang dag kha cig mngon du bsti stang byed pa lta yang zhog / gang nga'i sku gdung dang ring bsrel yungs 'bru tsam la sku gdung gi mchod pa byed pa lta yang zhog / gang nga'i phyir mchod rten byas pa rnams la bsti stang byed pa lta yang zhog / gang sangs rgyas la dmigs nas tha na me tog gcig nam mkha' la 'dor ba yang lta yang zhog ste/ kun dga' bo gal te sems can mya ngan las 'das pa'i skal pa med pa zhig gis sangs rgyas la dmigs nas tha na me tog gcig nam mkha' la 'dor na yang kun dga' bo dge ba'i rtsa ba de'i 'bras bu de yang mya ngan las 'das pa'i 'bras bu yin te/ mya ngan las 'das pas klas pa dang mya ngan las 'das pa'i mthas gtugs par nga smra'o zhes gsungs so/ /

klu'i rgyal po rgya mtshos zhus pa chen po las kyang / klu'i bdag po byang chub sems dpa' chos brgyad dang ldan na/ rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par sangs rgyas dang phrad pa 'thob po/ / brgyad gang zhe na/ sems can sangs rgyas kyi gzugs la lta ba yang dag par 'dzin du 'jug pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa la rim gro byed pa dang / rgyun mi 'chad par de bzhin gshegs pa'i bsngags pa brjod pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku gzugs byed pa dang / sems can thams cad de bzhin gshegs pa la blta ba yang dag par 'dzin du 'jug pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing gang na de bzhin gshegs pa'i sgra grag pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing der smon lam 'debs pa dang / rgyun zhum pa med pa dang / rgyun rgya chen por gyur nas sangs rgyas kyi ye shes tshol ba'o zhes gsungs so/ / bsod nams 'phel bar 'dod pa la sangs rgyas dang 'phrad pa ci dgos she na/ de'i mtha' ni thams cad mkhyen pa ma yin pas mi shes te/ 'phags pa sdong po bkod pa las ji skad bsngags pa lta bu'o/ /

And the Greater Inquiry of Sāgara, the King of Serpent-Spirits says, Ruler of snakes, bodhisattvas who have eight qualities always get to meet Buddhas. What are the eight? Encouraging sentient beings by showing them images of a Buddha; making statues of the Tathāgata;[xxii] frequently speaking in praise of the Tathāgata; encouraging all sentient beings by showing them the Tathāgata; in whatever Buddha-field the fame of the Tathāgata is heard, making an aspiration prayer in that Buddha-field; having a personality that is not lazy; with lofty personality, longing for the pristine awareness of the Buddhas. [310] For one who wishes to enhance goodness, how much more so should one practice so as to meet a Buddha, whose abilities one could not fully understand without complete knowing. The noble Array of Stalks offers this praise:[2]
bskal pa bye ba phrag brgyar yang / / sangs rgyas sgra ni rab bkod na/ / the tshom thams cad gcod pa'i mchog / mthong bar 'gyur ba smos ci dgos/ /
Even in billions of aeons, The word “Buddha” is very rare. How much more so the best of all sights, Cutting through all desires!
chos kun rtogs par thugs chud cing / / 'jig rten gsum gyi bsod nams stegs/ / sems can thams cad rnam sbyong ba/ / 'jig rten sgron ma mthong ba legs/ /
It is good to see the Light of the World, Who has gone to the destination of all qualities, A ford of goodness for the threefold world, Cleansing all sentient beings.
bsod nams che las grub pa'i zhing / / ye shes dkyil 'khor rab shar ba/ / 'jig rten dpag med snang bar mdzad/ / bsod nams phung po rnam par 'phel/ /
This is great goodness, A field of joy, a disk of pristine awareness; He makes manifest a measureless world, Causing a mass of goodness to grow,
sdug bsngal dra ba gcod mdzad cing / / ye shes phung po sbyong ba yi/ / rgyal ba gang gis mnyes byas pa/ / de dag ngan 'gro'i 'jigs pa med/ /
Cutting the net of suffering, Purifying a mass of pristine awareness. Those who meet the Victor here[xxiii] Are in no danger of the lower realms.
rkang gnyis dam pa mthong na ni/ / sems rgya chen po skye 'gyur zhing / / shes rab stobs ni 'od gsal ba/ / grangs med pa yang skye bar 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
On seeing the best of bipeds, The mind becomes spacious; An incalculable power of wisdom arises, Shining like the moon.
yang de nyid las/ sems can kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / brtan zhing thugs rje che ldan la/ / chos kyi 'khor lo rab bskor ba/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyang 'byung / /
And the same text also says,[3] For the benefit of all sentient beings The Tathāgatas arise, Greatly compassionate heroes Who turn the wheel of Dharma.
don kun brtson pa'i sangs rgyas la/ / bskal pa bye ba phrag brgyar yang / / lus can dag ni thams cad kyis/ / lan du phan gdags ji ltar nus/ /
Even in billions of aeons, How could all embodied beings Pay back the Buddhas, Who are devoted to the welfare of sentient beings?
ngan song gsum po mi bzad du/ / bskal pa bye bar bsreg bla yi/ / chags pa thams cad rnam bzlog pa/ / ston pa mi mthong de lta min/ /
Better to burn for ten million aeons In the three horrifying lower realms Than to fail to see the Teacher Who puts an end to all attachment.
'jig rten ji snyed thams cad kyi/ / ngan song 'gro ba so so der/ / shin tu yun ring gnas bla yi/ / sangs rgyas mi thos de lta min/ /
Better to live for a long time In each of the lower realms In all the many worlds Than not to hear about the Buddhas.
ci yi phyir na ngan song du/ / yun ring gnas par 'dod ce na/ / gang phyir rgyal ba'i dbang po dag / mthong na ye shes 'phel phyir ro/ /
Why would anyone choose To live in the lower realms for a long time? Because seeing the supreme Victor Enhances pristine awareness;
'jig rten dbang phyug rgyal mthong na/ / sdug bsngal thams cad rgyun chad 'gyur/ / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas spyod yul gyis/ / ye shes la yang 'jug par 'gyur/ /
Those who see the Victor, the Lord of the World, Cut through all forms of suffering. They enter into pristine awareness, [311] The domain of the fully Awake.
mi mchog sangs rgyas mthong na ni/ / sgrib pa thams cad zad par 'gyur/ / gang gis byang chub thob 'gyur ba'i/ / bsod nams dpag tu med pa 'phel/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
After seeing the Buddha, the foremost among humans, They throw away all distortions, And measureless goodness grows, Through which they gain Awakening.

bsod nams rab tu 'phel bar bya ba la sangs rgyas dang phrad pa ni de ltar dgos pa yod do/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi sku gzugs tsam mthong ba yang de tsam du 'bras bu dpag tu med na/ rang gi ngo bo mthong ba lta smos kyang ci dgos/ dad pa'i stobs bskyed pa la 'jug pa'i phyag rgya'i mdo las/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang la la zhig gis/ bskal pa gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi rdul snyed kyi rang sangs rgyas dag la nyin gcig bzhin du lha'i zas ro brgya dang ldan pa byin pa dang de bzhin du lha'i gos rnams sbyin pa byin pa bas/ 'jam dpal rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gzhan gang zhig gis sangs rgyas ri mor bris pa'am gzugs su byas pa mthong na/ 'di ni de bas ches bsod nams grangs med pa bskyed na/ thal mo sbyar ba 'am me tog gam bdug pa'am spos sam mar me 'bul ba lta ci smos te/ 'di ni de bas ches bsod nams grangs med pa bskyed do zhes gsungs so/ /

Such is the method for enhancing goodness by meeting a Buddha. And if even seeing a mere image of the Tathāgatas can have a measureless result, how much more would seeing their own form do? The noble Sūtra on the Posture of Beginning to Generate the Power of Faith says, Mañjuśrī, suppose a gentleman or a lady were to give food of a hundred tastes and divine clothing every day to Solitary Sages as numerous as the particles of dust in all the world-realms, and continue to give in this way for aeons as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River. Mañjuśrī, suppose another gentleman or lady were to see a Buddha image made by painting or plastering. From this, incalculably more goodness flows than from the previous case. How much more so for those who place their hands together in reverence, or give a flower, or give incense or perfumes or lamps! From this, incalculably more goodness flows than from the previous case.

byang chub sems dpa'i sde snod las kyang / bsod nams spel ba'i thabs gsungs te/ gang de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten 'phyag pa de smon lam rnam par dag pa mchog bzhi 'thob ste/ bzhi gang zhe na/ gzugs la smon lam rnam par dag pa mchog dang / mnyam par gzhag pa brtan pa la smon lam rnam par dag pa mchog dang / de bzhin gshegs pa mthong ba la smon lam rnam par dag pa mchog dang / mtshan phun sum tshogs pa la smon lam rnam par dag pa mchog ces bya ba'o/ / yang de nyid las/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten rnams la me tog 'bul ba'am spos ris 'dri na ma tshang ba med pa brgyad 'thob ste/ brgyad gang zhe na/ gzugs ma tshang ba med par 'gyur ba dang / longs spyod ma tshang ba med pa dang / g.yog 'khor ma tshang ba med pa dang / tshul khrims ma tshang ba med pa dang / ting nge 'dzin ma tshang ba med pa dang / thos pa ma tshang ba med pa dang / shes rab ma tshang ba med pa dang / smon lam ma tshang ba med pa zhes gsungs so/ /

The noble Scriptural Collection for Bodhisattvas also describes skillful means for enhancing goodness, as follows: Those who clean a stūpa of the Tathāgata attain four aspects of supreme purity of the vow. What are the four? The supreme purity of the vow as to form; the supreme purity of the vow as to carrying it out with firmness;[xxiv] the supreme purity of the vow as to seeing the Tathāgatas; the supreme purity of the vow as to having the marks. Further, the same text says, [312] Those who lay down flowers and apply perfume at a stūpa of the Tathāgata will have eight things that have no defects. What are the eight? Their physical appearance has no defects. Their possessions have no defects. Their retinue has no defects. Their moral discipline has no defects. Their stable attention has no defects. Their learning has no defects. Their wisdom has no defects. Their vows have no defects.

rin po che'i phung po'i mdo las kyang / gang dag srid pa gsum du gtogs pa'i sems can de dag thams cad so so nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten 'phang du 'di lta ste/ ri'i rgyal po ri rab lta bu byed la de dag la yang so so nas gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed kyi bskal par bsti stang bya ba thams cad kyis bsti stang byed pa bas byang chub sems dpa' gang thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi sems dang ma bral bas me tog gcig 'dor na/ de ni bsod nams kyi phung po snga ma bas bsod nams ches mang du bskyed do zhes gsungs so/ /

And the noble Multitude of Jewels says, Suppose that all the sentient beings in the threefold world were each individually to have stūpas of the Tathāgata made, of such a form, and as high as Meru, king of mountains.[xxv] And suppose they were to honor them all individually with all forms of honor for aeons as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River. Alternately, suppose that a bodhisattva who had not lost the Mind of complete knowing were to strew even one flower. The goodness that would flow from this would be greater than the previous mass of goodness.

yang de nyid las/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams na sems can gang dag yod pa de dag thams cad theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs par gyur la/ thams cad 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal srid dang ldan par gyur te/ 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po re res kyang mar me'i snod rgya mtsho chen po tsam byas te/ ri rab tsam gyi mar me'i snying pos mar me bus la/ so so nas de lta bu'i mar me'i mchod pas de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten rnams la mchod pa bas/ byang chub sems dpa' khyim gyi gnas nas 'byung ba gang gis mar me'i snying po 'bru mar gyis bskus te de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten gyi drung du 'dzin na/ ras 'bru mar gyis bskus pa'i mar me 'di la snga ma'i mar me phul ba des brgya'i char yang mi phod pa nas rgyu'i bar du yang mi bzod do/ / 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po de dag gis sangs rgyas la sogs pa'i dge slong gi dge 'dun la bde bar sbyar ba thams cad kyis phu dud byed pa bas/ byang chub sems dpa' khyim gyi gnas nas mngon par byung ba gang gis bsod snyoms blangs te/ lhung bzed du chud pa de gzhan dag dang bgo bsha' byas te zan de ni de bas ches mang zhing ches rin che'o/ / gang yang rgyal po chen po de dag gis ri rab tsam gyi gos kyi phung po sangs rgyas la sogs pa dge slong gi dge 'dun la phul ba bas/ byang chub sems dpa' khyim gyi gnas nas mngon par byung ba gang gis phyi rol du byung ste/ sangs rgyas la sogs pa theg pa chen po la yang dag par zhugs pa'i dge slong gi dge 'dun dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten la chos gos gsum phul na/ dge slong gi chos gos byin pa 'dis gos sbyin pa snga ma de zil gyis non par 'gyur ro/ /

The same text says, Suppose now that all the sentient beings in this three-million-fold world-realm were practicing the Great Way. Suppose each of them had the royal power of a world-emperor. And suppose each of these world-emperors were to have a lamp-vessel made that was the size of the great ocean, and lighting a wick the size of Mount Meru, were to perform a lamp-offering with these at stūpas of the Tathāgata. And suppose that an ordained bodhisattva were to dip a wick into oil, light it, and place it at a stūpa of the Tathāgata. The previous lamp-offering does not reach even a hundredth part of that wick dipped in oil; and so on up to: it will not even bear comparison … Suppose now that those world-emperors were to honor a Buddha and his community of monks with all the material supports needed for happiness. And suppose that an ordained bodhisattva, after going on alms-round and receiving alms-food, were to share it out with others and eat it together. Compared to the first, [the result of] this gift of food is more, and more valuable. Alternately, suppose those world-emperors were to give a pile of robes the size of Mount Meru to a Buddha and his community of monks. And suppose an ordained bodhisattva were outwardly to give a three-piece monastic robe to a Buddha and his community of monks that were practicing the Great Way, or to a stūpa of the Tathāgata. That monk’s gift of a robe is superior to the previous pile of robes.

yang rgyal po de dag re res 'dzam bu'i gling thams cad me tog gis mdzes par byas te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten la phul ba bas/ byang chub sems dpa' khyim gyi gnas nas byung ba gang gis tha na de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten la me tog gcig phul na sbyin pa 'di la sbyin pa snga ma bas des brgya'i char yang mi phod pa nas rgyu'i bar du yang mi phod do zhes gsungs so/ /

[313] Alternately, suppose that each of those emperors were to decorate the entire Earth with flowers and offer it at a stūpa of the Tathāgata. And suppose that an ordained bodhisattva were to lay down even so little as a single flower at a stūpa of the Tathāgata. The previous gift does not reach even a hundredth part of this gift, and so on up to: it will not even bear comparison.

mthar gyis yang dag par 'phags pa'i le'u las kyang bstan te/ phan yon bzang po bzhi po 'di dag mthong nas byang chub sems dpa' de bzhin gshegs pa mchod pa la spro bar 'gyur te/ bzhi gang zhe na/ bdag gis sbyin gnas kyi mchog la mchod pa byas par 'gyur ba dang / bdag mthong nas gzhan dag kyang de bzhin du slob par 'gyur ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pas byang chub kyi sems brtan par 'gyur ba dang / mngon sum du mthong bas skyes bu chen po'i mtshan sum cu rtsa gnyis kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba sogs par 'gyur ba ste/ bzhi po 'di dag go zhes so/ /

The noble Chapter on the Gradual Ascent (Anupūrva-samudgata-parivarta) also explains, Seeing these four valuable advantages, a bodhisattva becomes eager to make offerings to the Tathāgatas. What are the four? Offerings will have been made to me, and I am worthy of offerings to the highest degree. And after seeing me, the bodhisattva will train others in the same way. And after having made offerings to the Tathāgata, the bodhisattva’s Awakening Mind will become stable. And through seeing the thirty-two marks of a great person face to face, wholesome actions will be accumulated. These are the four.

'di ni de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa dang rim gro byed pa bla na med pa ste/ blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las ji skad du/ blo gros rgya mtsho gsum po 'di dag ni de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa dang rim gro byed pa bla na med pa'o/ / gsum gang zhe na/ gang byang chub tu sems bskyed pa dang / gang dam pa'i chos yongs su 'dzin pa dang / gang sems can rnams la snying rje chen po bskyed pa'o zhes gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

The best occasions for making offerings to the Tathāgata[xxvi] are as declared in the noble Sāgaramati Sūtra: Sāgaramati, there are three unsurpassed occasions for making offerings to the Tathāgata. What are the three? When you arouse Awakening Mind; when you uphold the holy Dharma; and when you arouse thoughts of great compassion for sentient beings.

'phags pa dkon mchog sprin las kyang bstan te/ rigs kyi bu byang chub sems dpa' chos bcu dang ldan na mngal gyi dri mas mi gos par skye'o/ / bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gzugs byed pa dang / mchod rten zhig pa 'chos pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten dag la spos kyi byug pa 'bul ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku gzugs dag la khrus kyi spos chu 'bul ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten dag la phyag dar dang skyang nul bya ba 'bul ba dang / pha ma la lus kyi rim gro byed pa dang / mkhan po dang slob dpon dag la lus kyi rim gro byed pa dang / tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams la lus kyi rim gro byed pa dang / de yang zang zing med pa'i sems kyis te zang zing dang bcas pas ma yin pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba de yang 'di ltar/ dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis sems can thams cad mngal gyi dri mas ma gos par skye bar gyur cig ces yongs su bsngo zhing de yang bsam pa thag pa nas sems pa ste/ rigs kyi bu chos bcu po de dag go zhes bya ba'o/ /

The noble Cloud of Jewels also teaches, Noble sir, bodhisattvas who have ten qualities are born unsmeared with the impurity of the womb. What are the ten? They are: making images of the Tathāgata; repairing decayed stūpas; offering fragrant unguents at stūpas of the Tathāgata; offering fragrant water for bathing statues of the Tathāgata; doing cleaning and plastering at stūpas of the Tathāgata; serving their mothers and fathers with bodily actions; serving their spiritual and academic teachers with bodily actions; serving their companions in the celibate life with bodily actions; and doing all this with a mind free from the desires of the flesh, not having desires of the flesh. And they dedicate the goodness that results as follows: “Through this wholesome action, may all beings be born unsmeared with the impurity of the womb.” They think this with keen aspiration. Noble sir, these are the ten qualities.

rjes su yi rang ba'i phan yon ni shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las gsungs te/ gang theg pa la dang po yang dag par zhugs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi sems bskyed pa de la rjes su yi rang bar bgyid/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyad pa spyod pa rnams kyi sems bskyed pa de la rjes su yi rang bar bgyid/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po phyir mi ldog pa rnams kyi phyir mi ldog pa'i chos de nyid la rjes su yi rang bar bgyis na/ bcom ldan 'das rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo de'i bsod nams kyi phung po ji snyed cig bskyed par 'gyur/ de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis lha'i dbang po brgya byin la 'di skad ces bka' stsal to/ / kau shi ka stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams ni srang tshad kyis gzhal bas tshad gzung bar nus kyi/ kau shi ka byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po'i rjes su yi rang ba'i mdo las skyes pa'i sems bskyed pa de dag gi bsod nams ni tshad gzung bar mi nus so/ / de skad ces bka' stsal pa dang / bcom ldan 'das la lha'i dbang po brgya byin gyis 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das sems can gang dag byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po sems dang po bskyed pa nas nye bar bzung ste/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa'i bar la rjes su yi rang ba las skyes pa'i bsod nams 'di ltar dpag tu med do zhes bya ba mi nyan pa dang ma 'tshal ba dang rjes su yi rang bar mi bgyid pa dang mi sems pa de dag ni bdud kyis byin gyis brlabs pa lags so/ / sems can de dag ni bdud kyi phyogs su 'gyur ba lags so/ /

The advantages of rejoicing are stated in the noble Perfection of Wisdom: [314] “Suppose that someone were to rejoice in the arousing of Awakening Mind by the bodhisattva great beings who are practicing the way for the first time; and also rejoice in the arousing of Awakening Mind by those leading the bodhisattvas’ way of life; and also rejoice in the irreversibility of the irreversible bodhisattva great beings. Blessed One, for the gentleman or lady who does this, how much of a mass of goodness would be generated?” After this question was asked, the Blessed One replied as follows to Śakra, king of the gods: “Kauśika, it might be possible to measure the weight of this three-million-fold world-realm. However, Kauśika, it is not possible to measure the goodness of the bodhisattva great being who rejoices in those acts of arousing Awakening Mind.” When this was said, Śakra, king of the gods, said to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, those who do not hear about and do not know about the measureless goodness that accompanies rejoicing in the arousing of Awakening Mind for the first time by the bodhisattva great beings, and so on up to rejoicing in the highest genuine full Awakening of those who awaken, and do not focus attention on that rejoicing—we should understand that they are controlled by the energy of Māra. Those sentient beings, Blessed One, will be on the side of Māra.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ kau shi ka byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa pa'am rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa pa'am nyan thos kyi theg pa pa'i rigs kyi bu'am rigs kyi bu mo gang dag gis sems bskyed pa la rjes su yi rang ba de dag gis myur du de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams mnyes par byed par 'gyur gyi mi mnyes par byed par mi 'gyur ro/ / de ltar rjes su yi rang ba'i mod las skyes pa'i sems bskyed pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba de dag gis gang dang gang du skye ba de dang der phu dud du bya bar 'gyur bla mar bya bar 'gyur ri mor bya bar 'gyur mchod par bya bar 'gyur rjed par 'gyur gsol bar 'gyur ro/ / de dag ni yid du mi 'ong ba'i gzugs rnams mthong bar mi 'gyur ro/ / de dag ni yid du mi 'ong ba'i sgra rnams thos par mi 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du dri dang ro rnams ma yin zhing reg bya rnams reg par mi 'gyur ro/ / de dag ni ngan song du skye bar mi 'gyur bar shes par bya'o/ / de dag ni mtho ris su skye bar shes par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar sems can de dag gis sems can grangs med pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba sems can de dag thams cad la bde ba skyed pa dag la rjes su yi rang ba'i phyir te/ de dag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas nas sems can grangs med pa dpag tu med pa dag yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba'i bar du byed par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'o/ /

The Blessed One replied, “Kauśika, those gentlemen or ladies belonging to the bodhisattva way, or belonging to the way of the Solitary Sages, or belonging to the way of the Disciples, who rejoice in these acts of arousing Awakening Mind, will quickly please the Tathāgatas, the Saints, the genuinely and fully Awake Buddhas.”[xxvii] The Blessed One said, “In this way, whoever performs wholesome actions consisting of rejoicing in acts of arousing the Awakening Mind will be honored, treated as a spiritual teacher, esteemed, revered, praised in song, and honored. Such people will not see unpleasant forms, nor hear unpleasant sounds; nor will they experience unpleasant scents, tastes, or touchables. We should not expect that such people would be born in the lower realms, but that they will be born in the heavens. Why is this? Because they have rejoiced in the wholesome actions of innumerable sentient beings, which bring happiness to all sentient beings. After they have awakened to highest genuine full Awakening, they will lead uncountable, innumerable sentient beings to Nirvāṇa.”

yang de nyid las/ rab 'byor stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed na sems can gang dag yod pa de dag thams cad bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub la gnas par gyur la/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub la gnas nas kyang bskal pa gang gA'i klung gi bye ma snyed du dmigs pa'i 'du shes kyis/ bsam gtan bzhi pa la snyoms par 'jug pa bas/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa 'di dang thabs mkhas pas zin pa gang gis/ 'das pa dang ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi tshul khrims dang ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab dang rnam par grol ba dang / rnam par grol ba'i ye shes mthong ba'i phung po dang / rang sangs rgyas kyi tshul khrims dang ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab dang / rnam par grol ba dang / rnam par grol ba'i ye shes mthong ba'i phung po dang / nyan thos kyi tshul khrims dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab dang / rnam par grol ba dang / rnam par grol ba'i ye shes mthong ba'i phung po thams cad gcig tu bsdus te/ bzlums shing gzhal la/ ma lus pa la rjes su yi rang ba'i mchog gis rjes su yi rang ba dang / gtso bo dang dam pa dang rab dang phul dang gya nom pa dang bla ma dang bla na med pa dang bla ma'i bla ma dang mnyam pa med pa dang / mi mnyam pa dang mnyam pa dang dpe zla med pas rjes su yi rang la rjes su yi rang ba'i mod las skyes pa'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po yang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu yongs su bsngo na/ rab 'byor rjes su yi rang ba'i mod las skyes pa'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po 'di la/ byang chub sems dpa' dmigs pa can gyi bsam gtan bzhi'i bsod nams mngon par 'du byed pa snga ma des brgya'i char yang nye bar mi 'gro ba nas rgyu'i bar du yang mi bzod do zhes gsungs so/ / tshul 'di nyid ni yongs su bsngo ba la yang gsungs so/ / gsol ba gdab pa'i phan yon ni drag shul can gyis zhus pa las/ chos yongs su gzung bar bya ba'i phyir sangs rgyas kyi zhing gzhal du med grangs med pa rnams su tshe yongs su bsgyur ro zhes gsungs so/ /
