mi 'jigs sbyin pas sems can bskyab pa dang / / srog chags gsod las bzlog par byas pa dang / / 'jigs pa skyabs tshol rnams la skyabs byas pas/ / mi 'jigs sbyin pa'i 'od zer de grub po/ /

By granting safety, by being a refuge for sentient beings, By saving living beings from being killed, And by granting refuge to those seeking a refuge from danger: In this way, the ray Granting Safety is perfected.
bde ba kun byed 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / nad pa na ba gang dag des reg pa/ / rnam pa kun du nad kyi sdug bsngal thar/ / bsam gtan ting 'dzin bde ba rnams kyang 'thob/ /

They give off the ray Bringing All Forms of Happiness. The sick and diseased who are touched by that Are cured of every kind of sickness and suffering And attain the happiness of meditative stability and meditative absorption.
nad gsos 'bras bu sman dang rtsa ba dang / / rin chen bcud len spos dang byug pa dang / / bu ram sbrang rtsi 'o ma mar dag dang / / 'bru mar zas skom byin pas de thob po/ /

By giving roots, fruits, and medicinal herbs that cure illnesses, Jewels, alchemical elixirs, perfumed ointments, Sugarcane juice, milk, honey, clarified butter, oils, [339] And food and drink, it is attained.
sangs rgyas ston pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / tshe zad tha mar gang dag des bskul ba/ / sangs rgyas rjes dran sangs rgyas mthong bar 'gyur/ / de dag shi 'phos sangs rgyas bzhugs shing 'gro/ /
They emit the ray Showing the Buddhas. Those at the end of life who are impelled by it Recollect, and come to see, a Buddha. When they have passed away, they go to the field of that Buddha.
'chi ba'i dus su sangs rgyas dran byas te/ / dga' byed rgyal ba'i sku gzugs bstan byas shing / / 'chi kar sangs rgyas skyabs su gtang brjod pas/ / sangs rgyas ston pa'i 'od zer de thob po/ /

By leading people to recollect the Buddhas as they are dying, By showing them delightful images of the Victors, By teaching them to go to the Buddha for refuge during the dying process, Showing the Buddhas is attained.
chos rab brjod pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sems can gang dag 'od des bskul byas pa/ / chos nyan klog cing yi ger 'dri bar byed/ / de dag rtag tu chos la dga' mos 'gyur/ /
They emit the ray Proclaiming Dharma. Sentient beings who are impelled by that radiance Read Dharma, listen to it, and write it down; They always take delight in Dharma.
chos kyi mu ge byung tshe chos brjod de/ / chos tshol rnams kyi bsam pa rdzogs byas shing / / 'dun pa bskyed de chos la brtson gyis zhes/ / brjod pas chos rab brjod pa de thob po/ /

By teaching Dharma when there is a famine of Dharma And fulfilling the hopes of those who seek the Dharma, By teaching people to arouse their motivation, and then Make an effort to practice, Proclaiming Dharma is attained.
sangs rgyas sras rnams yongs su bskul ba'i phyir/ / dbyangs dang ldan pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / 'jig rten gsum na sgra rgyun ji snyed pa/ / kun kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung du thos/ /
They emit a ray called Melodious In order to urge on the heirs of the Buddhas, Who then hear all the forms of sound in the threefold world As the voices of Tathāgatas.
gsang bstod sgra yis drang srong che bstod de/ / rgyal ba'i gsung sgra don du sil snyan dang / / sgra chen dril bu sbyin rnams 'gro kun la/ / rab tu bsngags pas dbyangs ldan 'od grub po/ /

By praising the great seers with raised voices, Through gifts of musical instruments and large bells, By making the voices of the Victors resound through the whole living world,[lviii] The Melodious radiance is attained.
'chi med sbyin pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sems can gang dag 'od des bskul byas pa/ / bag med spyod pa thams cad rab spangs te/ / yon tan kun la brtson pa nyams su len/ /
They emit the ray Granting the Deathless. Sentient beings impelled by that radiance Give up all heedlessness for a long time And engage in spiritual practice to develop all abilities.
'dus byas rtag tu bde ba med pa ste/ / sdug bsngal 'tshe ba du mas yongs su gang / / 'gog pa rtag tu bde zhing zhi spyod ces/ / brjod pas 'chi med sbyin pa de thob po/ /

By teaching that conditioned existence is full of many disasters And forms of suffering, and is never peaceful, By teaching the lasting peace of the happiness of peaceful cessation, Granting the Deathless is attained.
khyad par ldan pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sems can gang dag 'od des bskul byas pa/ / rgyal ba rnams kyi tshul khrims khyad par dang / / ting 'dzin khyad par shes rab khyad par thob/ /

They emit the ray Excellent. Sentient beings who are impelled by that radiance Hear about[lix] the excellence in moral discipline, excellence in stable attention, [340] And the excellence in wisdom of the Victors.
thub chen rgyal po khrims kyi mchog gyur cing / / ting 'dzin mchog dang shes rab mchog gyur ces/ / byang chub don du bstod cing bsngags brjod pas/ / des na khyad par ldan pa'i 'od grub po/ /

By praising and extolling, for the sake of Awakening, The great kings of sages as supreme in moral discipline, Supreme in stable attention, and supreme in wisdom: In this way, the Excellent radiance is attained.
rin chen bkod pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sems can gang dag 'od des bskul byas pa/ / rin chen mi zad gter rnams thob gyur nas/ / drang srong che la rin chen dam pas mchod/ /

They emit the ray Marvelous Display of Jewels. Sentient beings who are impelled by that radiance Gain inexhaustible treasures of jewels, and then Make offerings of the best of jewels to the great seers.
rgyal dang rgyal ba'i mchod rten rin chen phul/ / skye bo nyon mongs rin chen rnams kyis bsdus/ / rgyal ba rnams la rin chen rab phul bas/ / rin chen bkod pa'i 'od zer grub par gyur/ /
By donating jewels to Victors and stūpas of Victors, By bringing together the entire people[lx] with jewels, By making gifts of jewels to the Victors, The ray Marvelous Display of Jewels is attained.
spos rab snang ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sems can gang dag 'od des bskul byas pas/ / mi la med spos yid 'ong tshor gyur nas/ / sangs rgyas yon tan rnams la nges par 'gyur/ /
They emit the ray Radiant with Fragrance. Sentient beings who are impelled by that radiance Smell an enchanting, superhuman fragrance, And thereupon are confirmed in the abilities of Buddhas.[lxi]
mi dang lha yi spos dang byug pa yis/ / mi yi gtso la mchod pa rab byas te/ / spos las rgyal ba'i gzugs dang mchod rten dag / byas pas spos rab snang ba de grub po/ /
By offering fragrant unguents, both human and divine, To the leaders of men, And by making stūpas and images of Victors out of incense, Radiant with Fragrance is perfected.[lxii]
sna tshogs bkod pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / rgyal mtshan ba dan gdugs mchog sna tshogs dang / / sil snyan bsgrags shing spos kyi bdug pa yis/ / pho brang dam pa mdzes byas me tog bkram/ /

They emit the ray Marvelous Display of Many Colors, Together with various of the finest flags made of the cloth of Indra, Serenaded with musical instruments, perfumed with fragrance, Decorated with pure, divine, supreme flowers.[lxiii]
sil snyan dag gis rgyal ba rnams bsu zhing / / me tog bdug pa bdug spos phye ma dang / / rgyal mtshan ba dan gdugs mchog rnams kyis mchod/ / des na sna tshogs bkod pa grub par gyur/ /

By welcoming the Victors with musical instruments, By offering flowers, unguents, perfumes and powders, The finest parasols, flags, and cloth canopies: In this way, Marvelous Display of Many Colors is perfected.
shin tu dang byed 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sa rnams lag mthil bzhin du gnas par byed/ / mchod rten drang srong gnas rnams sbyang byas pas/ / des na shin tu dang byed 'od grub po/ /

When they emit the ray Gaining Trust, It is as if the Earth rests on the palms of their hands. By cleaning stūpas and the dwelling-places of seers: In this way, the radiance Gaining Trust is attained.
sprin dang ldan pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / spos kyi char 'bebs sprin rnams kun du gnas/ / mchod rten 'khor sar spos kyi chus btang pas/ / sprin dang ldan pa'i 'od de rab tu 'thob/ /
When they emit the ray Cloudbringer, Clouds rain down perfume {everywhere.} By sprinkling perfumed water on the ground near stūpas,[lxiv] The radiance Cloudbringer is attained.
lhab lhub bkod pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / gcer bu gos gyon rgyan dang ldan par 'gyur/ / gos dang bgo ba rgyan phreng sna tshogs dag / sbyin pa byas pas lhab lhub bkod pa grub/ /
They emit the ray Marvelous Display of Decorations:[lxv] The naked become well dressed. By donating various clothes, adornments, and necklaces, [341] The Decoration ray is perfected.
ro mchog ldan pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / bkres pa kha zas ro mchog thob par 'gyur/ / zas dang skom dang ro mchog sna tshogs rnams/ / byin pas ro mchog ldan pa'i 'od grub po/ /
When they emit the ray Finest Flavor, The hungry receive nourishment of the finest flavors. By giving varied food and drink of the finest flavors, The radiance Finest Flavor is attained.
nor rnams ston pa'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / dbul po dag gis rin chen gter rnams 'thob/ / dkon mchog gsum la gter gzhi mi zad pa/ / dbul ba byas pas nor ston 'od thob po/ /
They emit the ray Showing Prosperity: The poor receive precious treasures. By giving inexhaustible storehouses of treasure To {the poor} as well as the Three Jewels, Showing Prosperity is attained.
mig rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / de tshe long bas sna tshogs gzugs rnams mthong / / rgyal ba dag dang rgyal ba'i mchod rten la/ / mar me phul bas mig sbyong 'od zer grub/ /
They emit the ray Purifying the Eye: The blind then see various forms. By offering lamps to the Victors and to stūpas of the Victors, The ray Purifying the Eye is perfected.
rna ba rnam sbyong 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / rna ba nyams pas sgra mang thos par 'gyur/ / rgyal ba rnams dang rgyal ba'i mchod rten la/ / sil snyan phul bas rna sbyong 'od grub po/ /
They emit the ray Purifying the Ear. Those whose ears are damaged Hear many sounds. Through offerings of song[lxvi] to Victors and to stūpas of the Victors, The ray Purifying the Ear is attained.
sna rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sngon chad ma tshor dri zhim tshor bar 'gyur/ / rgyal ba rnams dang rgyal ba'i mchod rten la/ / spos rab phul bas sna sbyong 'od zer grub/ /

When they emit the ray Purifying the Nose, Wonderful fragrances, never experienced before, are perceived. Through offerings of perfume to Victors and to stūpas of the Victors, The ray Purifying the Nose is perfected.
lce rnam sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sgra snyan yid 'ong rnams kyis sangs rgyas bstod/ / mi snyan bslang bar smra ba rnams spongs te/ / 'jam par smras pas lce sbyong 'od zer grub/ /
They emit the ray Purifying the Tongue: The Buddhas are praised with lovely, enchanting songs. By speaking mildly, refraining from harsh, ill-spoken words, The ray is perfected.
lus rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / dbang po nyams pa dbang po ldan par 'gyur/ / rgyal ba rnams dang rgyal ba'i mchod rten la/ / lus btud byas pas lus rnams sbyong ba thob/ /
They emit the ray Purifying the Body: The disabled become able. By doing prostrations to Victors and stūpas of the Victors, Purifying the Body is attained.
sems rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / smyos pa thams cad sems dang ldan par 'gyur/ / ting 'dzin dbang rjes sems 'gro byas pas na/ / sems rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer de grub po/ /
They emit the ray Purifying the Mind: The insane all become mentally healthy. By practicing putting the mind into meditative absorption,[lxvii] The ray Purifying the Mind is perfected.
gzugs rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / mi dbang rnams kyi bsam yas sku mthong ste/ / sku gzugs ri mo sna tshogs mang po dang / / mchod rten brgyan byas gzugs sbyong 'od grub po/ /
They release the ray Purifying Forms: The inconceivable forms of the best of humans are seen. By cleaning various images everywhere, And by decorating stūpas, it is gained.
sgra rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / sgra ni sgra min stong par rab tu shes/ / rkyen las byung bas brag ca 'dra'o zhes/ / sgra rnams bstan pas 'od zer de grub po/ /
They emit the ray Purifying Sounds: People know clearly that sound is nonsound; it is empty. By teaching that sound arises from conditions, just like an echo, The ray is completed.
dri rnams sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / dri nga thams cad dri zhim mchog tu 'gyur/ / spos rab mchog chus rgyal ba'i mchod rten dag / khrus byas byang chub zhing gi 'od de yin/ /

They emit the ray Purifying Scents: All bad smells become good smells. By bathing Victors and stūpas of the Victors with the most excellent perfumes, [342] [This ray is attained;] it is the radiance of the Bodhi tree.
ro bro sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / dug can dug med ro'i mchog tu 'gyur/ / sangs rgyas nyan thos bcas dang pha ma la/ / ro mchog thams cad phul ba'i 'od de yin/ /
They emit the ray Purifying Tastes: Poisonous foods become free from poison, with the best flavors. This ray [arises] from giving all the best flavors To a Buddha with his disciples, and to parents.
reg rnam sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / reg na rtsub pa 'jam zhing bde bar 'gyur/ / mdung thung rtse gsum ral gri mda' chen char/ / phreng ba 'jam pa pad+ma ut+pal 'gyur/ /
They emit the ray Purifying Touchables. Touchable objects that are rough become soft and pleasant. The rains of spears, tridents, swords, and maces[11] Become soft flowers, blue and white lotuses.
bcos bu'i ras mang 'jam zhing reg bde rnams/ / rgyal ba rnams kyi gshegs shul bting bkram ste/ / me tog byug pa na bza' 'jam rnams dang / / phreng ba bla re phul ba'i 'od de yis/ /
By spreading many colored cloths and soft touchables On the paths followed by the Victors, And offering flowers, ointments, robes, soft things, Garlands, and cushions, the ray can be produced.
chos rnam sbyong ba'i 'od zer rab gtong zhing / / 'jig rten phan mdzad rgyal ba thams cad kyi/ / spu rnams kun nas chos rnams bsam mi khyab/ / byung ba thos nas mos pa thams cad tshim/ /

They emit the ray Purifying the Dharma.[12] From all the hairs of the Victors who act for the welfare of the world, Inconceivable teachings arise; Those who hear them are satisfied and have all forms of confidence in the Victors.
rkyen las byung bas ma skyes ngo bo nyid/ / rgyal ba rnams kyi sku ni chos sku ste/ / chos nyid nam mkha' bzhin du gnas so zhes/ / brjod pas chos rnam sbyong ba thob par 'gyur/ /

By pointing out that what arises from conditions does not arise through any intrinsic nature, That the Dharma bodies are unarisen bodies,[lxviii] That the way things are always abides in the sky, Purifying the Dharma is attained.
'od zer sgo mo de dag la sogs pa/ / drang srong rnams kyi spu yi sgo gcig nas/ / 'od zer gang gA'i bye ma snyed 'byung ste/ / kun la sbyor ba tha dad tshul can no/ /
As the seers create the ray called Facing Happiness[lxix] From each of their pores, They emit rays like the Ganges sands, All various applications of action.
ji ltar sku yi spu yi sgo gcig nas/ / 'od zer gang gA'i bye ma snyed 'byung ba/ / ma lus spu rnams kun nas de bzhin te/ / drang srong ting 'dzin rnam 'phrul 'di 'dra'o/ /
Just as, from a single hair-follicle, they emit Rays like the Ganges sands, In the same way, all the hairs without exception show The seers’ miracle of meditative absorption.
yon tan gang gis 'od zer gang 'grub pa'i/ / yon tan de grogs sngon chad gang gyur pa/ / de dag nyid las 'od zer rab 'byung ste/ / drang srong ye shes rnam 'phrul 'di 'dra'o/ /

Those who were previously the [bodhisattvas’] companions In practicing the ability through which the ray was perfected, The seers perform a miracle of pristine awareness And emit the ray towards those very beings.
de dag bsod nams sngon grogs gang yin la/ / rjes su yi rang gsol ba sus btab dang / / gang gis mthong ste dge ba bsags gyur pa/ / de dag kun gyis 'od zer de dag shes/ /
Those who were previously their companions in goodness, Those who rejoiced in them or asked them for teachings, And those whom they saw piling up what is good: They all experience that ray.
gang dag bsod nams byas shing dge bsags dang / / gang dag yang yang sangs rgyas rnams mchod cing / / sangs rgyas yon tan 'dun te don gnyer ba/ / de dag kun la 'od zer de dag bskul/ /

And those who pile up what is good and perform good actions, Those who make offerings to the Buddhas again and again, Those who seek the abilities of Buddhas and are motivated to attain them: [343] They are all impelled by that ray.
dper na dmus long nyi ma mi mthong yang / / de med ma yin 'jig rten kun du 'char/ / mig dang ldan pas shar bar shes gyur nas/ / kun kyang rang rang so so'i las la 'jug /

Those who are blind from birth do not see the sun, And it’s not that it doesn’t exist: it’s visible throughout the world. Those who have eyes know that it rises, Each having put into practice his own qualities.
de bzhin skyes chen 'od zer de dag kun/ / rab tu byung yang log pas nyen gyur cing / / mos nyams phal pa rnams kyis mi mthong ste/ / blo gros yangs pa rnams la de dag mod/ /
In the same way, the rays of great persons exist, But … of corrupt motivation don’t see it, but as for those of vast intelligence, they do.
dper rgyan nor bu bzhon pa gzhal med khang / / bcud kyis len dang rin chen byug pa spos/ / de dag skye bo che la yod mod kyi/ / phongs par gyur pa rnams la de dag med/ /
Jewelry, gems,[lxx] the celestial mansions of the gods, Alchemical elixirs and fragrant ointments Also exist for high-status people, But those who lead difficult lives don’t have them.
de bzhin skyes chen 'od zer de dag kun/ / de dag yod kyang log pas nyen gyur cing / / mos pa nyams pa rnams kyis mi mthong ste/ / blo gros yangs pa rnams la de dag mod/ /
In the same way, the rays of great persons exist, But others do not see them, Those who are struck by falsehood and lacking in religious commitment. Those of lofty minds are rare.[lxxi]
gang dag 'od zer dbye ba 'di thos nas/ / dad cing mos la dang ba skyes gyur nas/ / bdag ni yon tan che rgyur mi 'gyur zhes/ / de dag dogs dang som nyi mi bskyed do/ /
People who, on hearing this enumeration of rays, Have faith, confidence, and trust in it Should have no doubt or uncertainty That they will become leaders of great abilities.[lxxii]
de dag g.yog 'khor bkod pa rnam 'phrul pa/ / ting 'dzin dam pa mngon par grub byed cing / / phyogs bcu kun du do zla med rnams kyi/ / zham ring sangs rgyas sras rnams ston par byed/ /
They will attain marvelous retinues, miracles, The highest meditative absorptions, And, heirs of the Buddhas, they will show Their unrivaled retinue to all ten directions.
'od bkod de dag pad+ma sna tshogs pa/ / stong gsum tshad tsam byin gyis brlab byas nas/ / skyil krung bcas pa'i lus kyis kun khyab ste/ / ting 'dzin rnam par 'phrul pa 'di 'dra'o/ /
Seated on lotuses of many colors, Three thousand in number, with marvelous displays of rays, Sitting in lotus position,[lxxiii] they clearly show This miracle of meditative absorption.
de dag zhing bcu'i rdul snyed pad+ma gzhan/ / 'khor dang bcas pas byin gyis brlab byas shing / / sangs rgyas sras kyis thams cad yongs su bskor/ / de dag ting 'dzin ting 'dzin med par gnas/ /

Their surrounding companions are seated on lotus flowers As numerous as the elementary particles in ten Buddha-fields; They are attended by all the heirs of the Buddhas, Both those who dwell in meditative absorption and those who do not.[13]
drang srong de yis sems can gang dag rnams/ / yongs su smin byas sangs rgyas legs bsgrubs pas/ / de dag pad+ma chen po de bskor zhing / / kun kyang thal mo sbyar nas lta zhing 'khod/ /

Those among the seers whom they have helped to mature, Sentient beings whom they have established in the qualities of the Buddhas, Surround those great lotuses and all [344] Look up with their hands together in reverence.
gang dag ting 'dzin gnas par rab zhugs pa/ / skyes chen rnams kyi chos nyid 'di yin te/ / rang gi slob mas kun kyang yongs bskor nas/ / skar ma'i tshogs kyis zla ba bskor ba bzhin/ /
Those who are resting in meditative absorption, Great beings whose nature it is to do so, They are all also surrounded by their own students, Just as the assembled stars are the retinue of the moon.
de dag ji ltar phyogs gcig rab 'jug cing / / zham 'bring sangs rgyas sras rnams ston byed pa/ / de bzhin gshegs rnams ma lus kun du ston/ / ting 'dzin rnam par 'phrul pa 'di 'dra'o/ /

Just as they engage in one direction And display the Buddhas’ heirs as their attendants, The Tathāgatas show such a display everywhere without exception; Such is that miracle of meditative absorption.
de dag phyogs kyi dra ba khyab gnas pa'i/ / ting 'dzin dam pa mngon par sgrub byed cing / / kha cig mnyam gzhag kha cig ldan par yang / / phyogs rnams kun du rang gi lus ston to/ /

They abide pervading the net of all space And cause others to attain the supreme meditative absorption. Some also have a certain meditative absorption such that They show their own body in all directions.
de dag shar gyi phyogs su mnyam gzhag cing / / nub kyi phyogs su dpa' bo rnam par ldang / / nub kyi phyogs su mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / bdag nyid chen po shar gyi phyogs nas ldang / /
They enter meditative absorption in the east, And these heroes re-emerge in the west. They enter meditative absorption in the west, and Those great ones emerge in the east.
de bzhin phyogs bcu rnams su rab tu 'jug / gzhan gyi phyogs su mnyam par bzhag gyur la/ / ye shes yon tan phyug po gzhan nas ldang / / drang srong ting 'dzin rnam 'phrul 'di 'dra'o/ /

In the same way, they enter meditative absorption in the ten directions And appear in other directions. Others emerge rich in the abilities of pristine awareness; The seers’ miracle of meditative absorption is like this.
shar phyogs sangs rgyas zhing rnams gang yin pa/ / grangs med ma lus dag na rang byung ba/ / de dag spyan sngar zhabs drung de dag rnams/ / zhi ba'i ting nge 'dzin la rnam par snang / /
In the sight of their attendants, they appear In peaceful meditative absorption In all the countless naturally arisen Buddha fields, Without exception, that are in the east.
phyogs der mnyam par gzhag pa brtan byas nas/ / dpa' bo nub kyi zhing khams ma lus par/ / rnam par ldang zhing mngon sum rgyal kun la/ / mchod pa du ma rab tu byed par snang / /
After stabilizing their meditative absorption in that direction, Those heroes re-emerge in all the Western field-realms, See all the Victors, And manifest many offerings to them.
nub phyogs sangs rgyas zhing rnams gang yin pa/ / grangs med ma lus dag na bzhugs sangs rgyas/ / de dag spyan sngar zhabs drung de dag rnams/ / zhi ba'i ting nge 'dzin la gnas par snang / /
In the sight of their attendants, they appear Abiding in peaceful meditative absorption In all the western Buddha-fields without exception In which Buddhas exist.
phyogs der mnyam par gzhag pa brtan byas nas/ / dpa' bo shar gyi zhing rnams ma lus par/ / rnam par ldang zhing mngon sum rgyal kun la/ / mchod pa du ma rab tu byed par snang / /
After stabilizing their meditative absorption in that direction, The heroes emerge in all the eastern fields, See all the Victors, And manifest a collection of many offerings to them.
de bzhin phyogs bcu dag gi zhing rnams su/ / phyogs rnams ma lus kun du brtan la 'jug / kha cig mnyam gzhag kha cig langs gyur cing / / 'jig rten sgron ma rnams mchod byed par snang / /
In the same way, they engage in a stable way In all the fields in the ten directions, Some absorbed in meditation, and some standing up, Manifesting offerings of lamps to the world.
de dag mig gi lam la mnyam gzhag cing / / gzugs kyi lam nas bdag nyid chen po ldang / / gzugs rnams bsam gyis mi khyab ston pa na/ / de la lhar bcas 'jig rten rmongs par 'gyur/ /
They are absorbed in meditation in the path of the eye And those great ones emerge in the path of form. When they show inconceivable forms, The whole world, including the gods, is astonished at them.
gzugs kyi lam la mnyam par bzhag gyur la/ / mi ni ma skyes ma byung rang bzhin te/ / stong pa byed pa med par rab ston cing / / mig gi lam nas dran ldan rnam par ldang / /
They enter meditative absorption in the path of form And teach emptiness and inactivity, That a person is not born and does not intrinsically arise, And, mindful, emerge in the path of the eye.
de dag rna ba'i lam la mnyam gzhag cing / / sgra yi lam nas bdag nyid chen po ldang / / gang la lhar bcas 'jig rten rmongs gyur pa/ / sgra dang skad rnams lan la rab tu zhugs/ /
They are absorbed in meditation in the path of the ear And those great ones emerge in the path of sound. Those who astonish the world, including the gods, Return to abide in sound and speech.
sgra yi lam la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / rna ba ma skyes ma byung rang bzhin te/ / stong pa byed pa med par rab ston cing / / rna ba'i lam nas dran ldan rnam par ldang / /
They enter meditative absorption in the path of sound And teach emptiness and inactivity, That the ear is not born and does not intrinsically arise, And, mindful, emerge in the path of the ear.
de dag sna yi lam la mnyam gzhag cing / / dri yi lam nas bdag nyid chen po ldang / / gang du lhar bcas 'jig rten rmongs gyur pa/ / dri mchog dam pa 'jug par rab tu zhugs/ /

They enter meditative absorption in the path of the nose And those great ones emerge in the path of smell. Those who astonish the world, including the gods, Abide experiencing the best and most excellent scents.
dri yi lam la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / sna ni ma skyes ma byung rang bzhin te/ / stong pa byed pa med par rab ston cing / / sna yi lam nas dran ldan rnam par ldang / /
They enter meditative absorption in the path of smell And teach emptiness and inactivity, That the nose is not born and does not intrinsically arise, And, mindful, emerge in the path of the nose.
de dag lce yi lam la mnyam gzhag cing / / ro mchog kun gyi lam nas rnam par ldang / / gang du lhar bcas 'jig rten rmongs gyur pa/ / bdag nyid chen po ro mchog rnam par ldang / /

They are absorbed in meditation in the path of the tongue And emerge in the path of the finest flavors. Those who astonish the world, including the gods, The great ones emerge among the finest flavors.
ro mchog rnams la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / lce ni ma skyes ma byung rang bzhin te/ / stong pa byed pa med par rab ston cing / / lce yi lam nas dran ldan rnam par ldang / /

They enter meditative absorption in the path of the finest flavors And teach emptiness and inactivity, That the tongue is not born and does not intrinsically arise, And, mindful, emerge from the path of the tongue.
de dag lus kyi lam la mnyam gzhag cing / / reg pa'i lam nas bdag nyid chen po ldang / / gang du lhar bcas 'jig rten rmongs gyur pa/ / 'jig rten bde ba bskyed pa'i reg la bzhugs/ /

They are absorbed in meditation in the path of the body, And the great ones emerge in the path of touchables. Those who astonish the world, including the gods, Rest knowing they are arousing the world to happiness.
reg pa'i lam la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / lus ni ma skyes ma byung rang bzhin te/ / stong pa byed pa med par rab ston cing / / lus kyi lam nas dran ldan rnam par ldang / /

They enter meditative absorption in the path of touchables And teach emptiness and inactivity, That the body is not born and does not intrinsically arise, And, mindful, emerge from the path of the body.
de dag sems kyi lam la mnyam gzhag cing / / chos kyi lam nas bdag nyid chen po ldang / / gang du lhar bcas 'jig rten rmongs gyur pa/ / chos la gnas pa'i 'jug par rab tu zhugs/ /

They are absorbed in meditation in the path of the mind And emerge in the path of objects of thought. Those who astonish the world, including the gods, Rest while engaged in abiding in objects of thought.
chos kyi lam la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / sems ni ma skyes ma byung rang bzhin te/ / ston pa byed pa med par rab ston cing / / sems kyi lam nas dran ldan rnam par ldang / /

They enter meditative absorption in the path of objects of thought And teach emptiness and inactivity, That the mind is not born and does not intrinsically arise, And, mindful, emerge from the path of the mind.
de dag byis pa'i lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / lang tsho shugs la gnas pa rnams las ldang / / lang tsho shugs gnas rnams la mnyam gzhag cing / / rgas shing 'khogs pa'i lus las rnam par ldang / /
They are absorbed in meditation in the bodies of children And emerge established in youthful vigor. While young, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in old and decrepit bodies.

rgas shing 'khogs pa'i lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / dad pa'i dge bsnyen ma yi lus las ldang / / dge bsnyen dad pa'i lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / dad pa'i dge bsnyen lus las rnam par ldang / / dad pa'i dge bsnyen lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / dge slong ma yi lus las rnam par ldang / /

In decrepit old bodies, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of faithful laywomen. In the bodies of faithful laywomen, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of faithful laymen. In the bodies of faithful laymen, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodily form of nuns.

dge slong ma yi lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / dge slong mang du thos pa'i lus las ldang / / dge slong mang thos lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / slob dang mi slob lus las rnam par ldang / / slob dang mi slob lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / rkyen gyis sangs rgyas lus las rnam par ldang / / rkyen gyis sangs rgyas lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / sangs rgyas sku mchog rab las rnam par ldang / /

In the bodily form of nuns, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of very learned monks. In the bodies of very learned monks, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of those still training and those who have finished training. In the bodies of those still training and those who have finished training, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of Solitary Sages.[lxxiv] In the bodies of Solitary Sages, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the supreme, highest bodies of Buddhas.

sangs rgyas sku mchog rab la mnyam gzhag cing / / lha yi lus gzugs las ni rnam par ldang / / lha yi lus gzugs la ni mnyam gzhag cing / / rdzu 'phrul chen po klu yi lus las ldang / / rdzu 'phrul klu yi lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / rdzu 'phrul gnod sbyin lus las rnam par ldang / / 'phrul chen gnod sbyin lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / 'byung po kun gyi lus las rnam par ldang / / 'byung po kun gyi lus la mnyam gzhag cing / / spu yi sgo gcig nas ni rnam par ldang / / spu sgo gcig la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / spu sgo thams cad las ni rnam par ldang / /

In the supreme, highest bodies of Buddhas, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodily form of gods. In the bodily form of gods, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of serpent-spirits of great power. In the bodies of serpent-spirits of great power, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of forest spirits of great power. In the bodies of forest spirits of great power, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the bodies of all kinds of spirits. In the bodies of all kinds of spirits, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in a single hair-follicle. In a single hair-follicle, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in all hair-follicles.

spu sgo kun la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / skra rtse gcig gi khyon las rnam par ldang / / skra rtse gcig gi khyon la mnyam gzhag cing / / skra rtse kun gyi khyon las rnam par ldang / / skra rtse kun gyi khyon las mnyam gzhag cing / / phra rab rdul gyi rdul las de dag ldang / / rdul gcig la ni mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / ma lus rdul rnams kun las rnam par ldang / / rdul rnams ma lus kun la mnyam gzhag cing / / rgya mtsho rdo rje'i gzhi las rnam par ldang / / rgya mtsho rdo rje'i gzhi la mnyam gzhag cing / / nor bu'i shing thog dag las rnam par ldang / /

In all hair-follicles, they are absorbed in meditation, And emerge on the tip of one hair. On the tip of one hair, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge on the tips of all hairs. On the tips of all hairs, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge on one elementary particle. On one elementary particle, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge on all elementary particles without exception. On all elementary particles without exception, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge on the adamantine floor of the ocean. On the adamantine floor of the ocean, they are absorbed in meditation [345] And emerge on the fruits of a jewel tree.

shing thog dag la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / rgyal ba rnams kyi 'od zer sgo nas ldang / / rgyal ba'i 'od zer sgo la mnyam gzhag cing / / rgya mtsho'i chu yi chu klung rnams las ldang / / rgya mtsho'i chu klung rnams la mnyam gzhag cing / / bdag nyid chen po me yi lam las ldang / / me yi lam la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / rlung gi lam las dran ldan rnam par ldang / /

On the fruits of a jewel tree, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge from the doors of the rays of the Victors. In the doors of the rays of the Victors, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the oceans, waters, and rivers. On the oceans, waters, and rivers, they are absorbed in meditation And those great ones emerge in the paths of fire. In the paths of fire, they are absorbed in meditation; Those who practice recollection emerge in the path of wind.

rlung gi lam la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / bdag nyid chen po sa yi gzhi las ldang / / sa yi gzhi la mnyam par bzhag gyur cing / / lha kun gzhal med khang las rnam par ldang / / lha kun gzhal med khang la mnyam gzhag cing / / dran ldan de ni mkha' las rnam par ldang / / yon tan mtha' yas bsags pa de dag gi / ting 'dzin rnam thar de dag bsam mi khyab/ / rgyal ba kun gyis bskal pa bsam yas su/ / bshad pa mdzad kyang zad par mdzad mi spyod/ / 'gro las rnam smin bsam gyis mi khyab ste/ / rgyal ba kun gyis de dag gsungs pa ni/ /

In the path of wind, they are absorbed in meditation; Those great ones emerge on the Earth’s surface. On the Earth’s surface, they are absorbed in meditation And emerge in the palaces of all the gods. In the palaces of all the gods,[lxxv] they are absorbed in meditation; Those who practice recollection emerge in the sky. Their meditative absorption and liberation become inconceivable; Inconceivable is their accumulation of abilities. Even if they were to expound them for inconceivably many aeons, All the Victors could not exhaust them. These inconceivable results of the evolution of action Have been proclaimed to the world by all the Victors.
lha klu'i rnam 'phrul sangs rgyas rnam 'phrul dang / / bsam byed bsam gtan rnam 'phrul bsam mi khyab/ / de dag la yang dpes ston brjod par bya/ / de dag 'dra ba'i dpe lta cang med de/ /

The miracles of gods and serpent-spirits, the miracles of Buddhas, And the miracle of meditative stability of meditators, are inconceivable. They should be explained through an example, But there is no example similar to them at all.
mkhas shing rig pa'i skye bo dpe rnams kyis/ / bstan na myur du don rnams shes par 'gyur/ / rnam thar brgyad kyi dbang la gnas pa yi/ / nyan thos gcig tu gyur nas mang por 'gyur/ /
When knowledgeable and intelligent people Are taught through examples, they understand quickly. Standing in the power of the eight liberations, A disciple, having been one, becomes many;
mang por gyur nas phyir yang gcig 'gyur te/ / mkha' la bsam gtan 'cha' zhing 'bar bar byed/ / smad nas me 'bar stod nas chu yi rgyun/ / stod nas me 'bar smad nas chu yi rgyun/ /

Having been many, becomes one again, Meditates and shines in the sky. From his lower parts, fire blazes; from his upper parts, water flows. From his upper parts, fire blazes; from his lower parts, water flows.
'gro dang 'greng dang nyal dang 'dug pa dang / / lus 'phrul skad cig gcig la bsam mi khyab/ / de ni snying rje che dang mi ldan zhing / / byang chub mi tshol 'jig rten yal 'dor yang / /
Walking, standing, lying down, and sitting, His body [illegible] in one moment, inconceivable. If they did not have great compassion, They would not seek awakening, and would abandon the world.

lus kyi rnam 'phrul bsam yas ston byed na/ / 'jig rten phan 'dod ci phyir ston mi byed/ / nyi zla mkha' las rnam par rgyu 'dod cing / / phyogs rnams kun gyi chu yi ngogs dag dang / / mtsho mtshe'u mtsho bran snod dang rin chen dang / / rgya mtsho chu klung rnams dang gzugs brnyan ston/ / de bzhin gzugs rnams bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ / skyes bu dpa' bo phyogs bcu kun du ston/ /

What inconceivable bodily miracle do they not show, Seeking to benefit the world? The moon and the sun traveling through the sky Shine in all directions, In springs, lakes, pools, wells, ponds, [346] In vessels and jewels, in oceans and rivers. In the same way, the heroes among men Show inconceivable forms in all ten directions.
ting 'dzin rnam thar kun gyi tshul la mkhas/ / de la de bzhin gshegs pa rang byung dbang / /
Of all those who know the methods of meditative absorption and liberation, The Tathāgata is the naturally arisen witness.

dang ba'i mtsho la yan lag bzhi pa'i dmag / de dag so so'i rang gi gzugs brnyan mthong / / ral gri mda' chen gzhu dang mda' rnams dang / / go gyon bzhon dang theg par bcas su mthong / / gang gi gzugs gang gnas gang cha byad gang / / de dang de dag de ltar chu las mthong / / 'on kyang chu la byams sdang rnam rtog med/ / drang srong ting 'dzin rnam 'phrul 'di 'dra yi/ /

In a clear lake, an army of four divisions Can individually see their own images, Including their swords, large arrows, silk bows, and arrows, Armor, mounts, and vehicles. What their forms are, those who are present, and their styles of dress: All this can they see in the water. Nevertheless, the water has no thoughts of kindness or anger. The miracle of meditative absorption of the seers is like this.
rgya mtsho'i lha mo sgra ldan zhes bya ba/ / sems can rgya mtshor ji snyed skyes rnams kyi/ / skra yi yan lag dbyangs kyi tshul mkhas te/ / rang gi skad kyis 'gro kun tshim par byed/ /
The sea-goddess named Rutāvati[15] Knows the methods of tonal color, And satisfies all the sentient beings who arise in the ocean With all kinds of sounds through her own voice.
sgra ldan chags sdang gti mug ldan de yang / / skad rnams kun gyi sgra yi tshul mkhas na/ / gzungs dang chos kyi stobs la dbang thob rnams/ / lhar bcas 'jig rten ci phyir mgu mi byed/ /

If Rutāvati, who has attraction and aversion, Knows the methods of imitating all forms of sound, How could one who has gained control of mnemonic powers And the power of Dharma not satisfy the world, including the gods?

tam bu ra yi chung ma dbyangs ldan ma/ / tshangs pa'i bu mo yid la byung ba de/ / bden dang dam bcas mi tshe dga' rnams kyi/ / sems dang yid dang kha yi sgor 'jug ste/ / dbyangs ldan chags bcas zhe sdang can de yang / / brtul zhugs grub mthun dbyangs kyi yan lag gis/ / yid 'ong skad kyis 'jig rten mgu byed na/ / ye shes yon tan phyug rnams cis mi byed/ /

A woman with a sweet voice who plays the tamboura Gives the impression of being a daughter of Brahmā, And affects the doors of the mind, intellect, and face With the delights of human life, a sense of truth and commitment. If even those musicians who have attraction and aversion, Through disciplined practice, attain the various aspects of harmonious melody, How would those rich in the abilities of pristine awareness Not delight the world in one enchanting moment?

rig sngags tshul mkhas sgyu ma'i mkhan po ni/ / sna tshogs gzugs mang mtha' yas ston pa byed/ / nyin mtshan yud dang zla ba lo brgya dang / / khyim bzang rgyas pa shin tu mdzes pa ston/ / 'dod chags sdang ldan sgyu ma'i mkhan po yang / / sgyu ma'i 'phrul gyis 'jig rten mgu byed na/ / bsam gtan mngon shes rnam thar rab bslabs pa/ / spyod tshul mkhas rnams ci phyir mgu mi byed/ /

An illusionist who knows the methods of sorcery Shows endlessly varied forms, For a night and day, for one moment, for months, for a hundred years, Abundantly radiating again. If an illusionist who has attraction and aversion Can satisfy the world with feats of magic, As for those well trained in meditative stability, the superknowledges, and freedom, And knowing the methods of practice, whom would they not please?
lha dang lha min dbang po 'thab pa'i tshe/ / rgyal ldan lha yis lha min pham byas na/ / de dag 'jigs pas gdugs bcas bzhon bcas shing / / theg bcas dmag bcas go gyon bzhin du 'byer/ /

When the rulers of the gods and titans are fighting, And the titans are defeated by the victorious gods, Out of fear, they flee, with their mounts and parasols, With their armor, vehicles, and armies.
'dod chags sdang ldan lha dbang de dag kyang / / lus kyi rnam 'phrul bsam yas ston byed na/ / dbang phyug rdzu 'phrul dbang gnas dpa' ba rnams/ / lus kyi rnam 'phrul ci phyir ston mi byed/ /
If even the kings of gods, who have attraction and aversion, Show inconceivable bodily miracles, Why would the heroes who have mastery over the Lord’s miracle powers Not show bodily miracles?
rdo rje 'chang ba'i glang po sa srung bu/ / dbang po'i 'khor gyur rdzu 'phrul chen po de/ / mgo bo sum cu rtsa gsum mngon sprul zhing / / mgo rnams kun la'ang mche ba drug drug ste/ /
The elephant guardian of the one who holds the vajra, Part of the king’s retinue, performs a great miracle: He manifests thirty-three heads, And on each of these, there are six tusks.
mche ba de dag so so re re la'ang / / rdzing bu chus gang bdun bdun sprul pa byed/ / rdzing bu re re'ang pad+ma sna tshogs pa/ / rnam par bkod pa bdun bdun sprul pa byed/ /
On each and every one of these tusks, Seven pools of water miraculously appear. And in each of those ponds, seven arrangements Of various lotuses miraculously appear.
pad+ma re la'ang lha yi bu mo dag / sgyu rtsal kun shes bdun bdun sprul pa byed/ / de dag rtsed mo glu gar tshul la mkhas/ / sum cu rtsa gsum dbang po de dang rtse/ /

On each of these lotuses, seven divine maidens Who are skilled in all forms of illusion miraculously appear. They are experts in the methods of entertainment, song, and dance. The elephant’s body is also changed
glang po de yang lus ni bsgyur byas te/ / lha rnams kun dang 'grogs shing bde bar byed/ / spyod pa'i tshul dang longs spyod kun kyang mthun/ / glang po mchog gi rnam 'phrul de ltar snang / /

Into the mountain peak of the thirty-three kings of gods, Delighting all the gods and their companions And harmonizing the methods of action and enjoyment. Such is the miracle manifested by that supreme elephant.
glang po chags sdang gti mug ldan de yang / / 'di 'dra'i rdzu 'phrul rab tu ston byed na/ / shes rab thabs kyis stobs la sbyangs pa rnams/ / ting 'dzin brgya yi rnam 'phrul cis mi byed/ /

If the elephant, even though it has attraction, aversion, and delusion, Shows this kind of miracle power, Then why would those trained in the power of wisdom and skillful means Not perform hundreds of miracles of meditative absorption?
sgra gcan ji ltar 'dod bzhin lus sprul te/ / rdo rje'i gzhi la rkang pa 'jog byed cing / / rgya mtsho lte bar phyin pa tsam du ston/ / ri rab rtse dang nyid kyi mgo yang snyoms/ /
Whenever he wishes, Rāhu[16] creates a magically produced body And places his foot on the adamantine ocean floor. The ocean only comes up to his navel; His head is as high as Mt. Meru.
sgra gcan chags sdang gti mug ldan de yang / / 'di 'dra'i rdzu 'phrul kun du ston byed na/ / 'jig rten sgron ma bdud rnams rab 'byam pa/ / rdzu 'phrul mtha' yas ci ste ston mi byed/ /
If even Rāhu, who has attraction, aversion, and delusion, Shows such miracle power, Why would the destroyer of Māra, the light of the world, Not show endless miracle powers?
brgya byin rnam 'phrul bsam yas pa la ltos/ / lha dang lha min dbang po g.yul 'gyed tshe/ / lha min bye ba 'byer ba ji snyed pa/ / de snyed brgya byin rang gi lus las sprul/ /

Behold the inconceivable miracles of Śakra! When the kings of gods and titans send in their armies, For each of the many quadrillions of titans, [347] Śakra magically produces the same number [of illusions] from his own body.

lha min dbang dang lha min phal kun gyis/ / brgya byin rang rang mdun du 'dug par shes/ / de ni rdo rje 'chang bas gzung ngo zhes/ / lha min dbang po kun kyang mgo myos gyur/ / 'jigs par byed pa'i mig stong rab bstan te/ / rdo rje me lce 'bar ba thogs byed cing / / lus la go bgos gzi brjid bsnyen dka' ba'i/ / brgya byin mthong nas lha min dbang po 'byer/ /

Each of the kings of titans and ordinary titans Thinks that Śakra stands in front of him, And that he has been seized by the holder of the vajra. All the kings of titans are overwhelmed by fear As he shows his thousand terrifying eyes, Wielding a vajra blazing with light. When they see Śakra, his body in armor and unconquerable in his splendor, The kings of titans flee.[lxxvi]
de yang bsod nams phal pa'i mthu stobs kyis/ / lha rgyal don du rnam par 'phrul byed na/ / 'gro ba ma lus kun gyi skyabs gyur pa/ / bsod nams mi zad rnams lta cis mi 'phrul/ /

If, through the power of minor goodness, Śakra performs such a miracle for the sake of the victory of the gods, As for the saviors of all living beings without exception, Whose goodness is inexhaustible: what miracle could they not perform? …[lxxvii]
lha la skul ma 'debs pa'i lha yi rnga/ / lha las rnam par smin pas grub gyur pa/ / lha rnams bag med gnas par shes gyur nas/ / rnga de nam mkha' las ni sgra sgrogs te/ /

The divine drum which, when beaten, incites the gods Is attained as a result of the evolution of the gods’ actions. When it is realized that the gods are living heedlessly, That drum urges them, in a voice from the sky:
'dod pa thams cad mi rtag ther zug min/ / tha shal mi brtan dbu ba'i ngo bo nyid/ / sgyu ma smig rgyu chu zla mtshungs 'dra zhing / / srid pa thams cad rmi lam sprin dang mtshungs/ /

“All sensual pleasures are impermanent, not perpetual. They are inferior and unstable, having the nature of bubbles. All existence is like an illusion, a mirage, The moon in water, a dream, and a cloud.
bag med thams cad dgra bcas mya ngan can/ / 'chi ba'i lam yin mi 'chi'i lam ma yin/ / ji snyed su dag bag med gnas gyur pa/ / de dag 'chi bdag chu srin chen pos zin/ /

All heedlessness is full of enmity and sorrow; It is the road to death, not to the deathless. All those who live heedlessly, whoever they are, Will be seized by the great crocodile, the Lord of Death.
sdug bsngal rtsa ba yongs 'dzin thams cad yin/ / skye ba thams cad 'phags pa rnams kyis smad/ / 'dod pa'i yon tan rnams kyi yul la rmongs/ / chos kyi stobs la rtag dga' gyis zhes bskul/ /

The root of suffering is all forms of possessiveness. All forms of birth are criticized by the Noble Ones. You are ignorant about the objects of the pleasures of the senses. You should always rejoice in the power of the Dharma!”
rnga des bskul nas brgya byin lha rnams dang / / lha yi 'dun sa chos bzang 'dug nas su/ / gtam gang zhi zhing 'dod chags bral mthun pa/ / chos kyi gtam de lha rnams kun la brjod/ /

Śakra and the gods, urged on by that drum, Depart from their divine assembly and remain in the auspicious Dharma. This discourse about Dharma, peaceful speech That is harmonious with freedom from attraction, is spoken to all the gods.
rnga de gzugs med bstan du mi rung yang / / de ltar rnga sgras don chen rab byed na/ / bsam pa ji bzhin gzugs ni yongs ston rnams/ / 'gro ba kun gyi don chen cis mi byed/ /

If that drum, which is not a suitable teacher since it has no form, Can be greatly beneficial through its sound in this way, Then how would those who manifest whatever forms they wish to Not bring about great benefits for sentient beings?
lha dang lha min dbang po g.yul 'gyed tshe/ / lha yi bsod nams khyad par mthu stobs kyis/ / lha la skul ma 'debs pa'i lha yi rnga/ / lha rnams ma 'jigs shig ces sgra 'byin te/ /
When the kings of gods and titans send their armies to battle, Through the power of the greater good karma of the gods, The divine drum is beaten to incite the gods: “Gods, fear not!”
rnga yis bskul nas lha rnams rab dga' zhing / / skrag pa med de stobs kyang skyes par gyur/ / lha min dbang po skrag pas nyen pa rnams/ / 'jigs nas dmag bcas de yi mod la 'byer/ /
Śakra And the gods, urged on by the drum, joyful And fearless, become powerful. The lords of the titans are stricken with fear, And due to this fear, they and their armies immediately run away.
de ltar rnga skad 'byin pa'i rnga 'dra ba/ / 'gro ba kun gyi skyabs dang dpung gnyen po/ / nyon mongs bdud bcom snying rje che ldan rnams/ / zhi ba'i sgra bsgrags nyon mongs sel bar byed/ /

Such is the sound of this drum. Like the drum, Those who are refuges for all living beings, who are helpful friends, Destroyers of the demons of reactive emotions, who have great compassion, By speaking peacefully, clear away reactive emotions.
dbang po lha yi bu mo dgu bcu gnyis/ / dbang po'i sprul pas kun kyang dga' bar 'gyur/ / gcig kyang bdag dang brgya byin rtse bar shes/ / gcig ltar lha mo kun kyang de bzhin no/ /

The ninety-two goddesses who attend on the king [of the gods] Also rejoice in the miracles of the king. As one of them plays around with Śakra, He does just the same with each and every one of the others.
lha mo kun dang dga' bar gnas snang zhing / / chos bzang 'dun sa na yang de bzhin 'dug / lha rnams kun la chos rab ston snang zhing / / brgya byin skad cig gcig la rnam par 'phrul/ /
The goddesses all show how delighted they are, But even so, they remain followers of the auspicious Dharma. In a single moment, Śakra performs a miracle, Manifesting Dharma teachings to all the gods.
brgya byin chags sdang gti mug ldan pa yang / / sprul pas rang gi 'khor rnams dga' byed na/ / 'gro don mi skyo sbyor rnams ci yi phyir/ / rdzu 'phrul stobs kyis 'jig rten mgu mi byed/ /

If Śakra, despite having attraction, aversion, and delusion, Delights his own retinue with miracles, Why would those who never tire of bringing about the welfare of living beings Not delight the world with their miracle powers?
bdud kyis dkrugs ma 'gro ba'i dbang sgyur ba/ / de yi dbang du sems can 'di kun 'dong / / las dang nyon mongs kun du zhugs pa yis/ / so so'i skye bo thams cad bdud des bcings/ /

Māra has the power to change and disturb all living beings. All these sentient beings who abide in desire, Karma and reactive emotions are within his power. All ordinary people are fettered by that Māra.
chags sdang gti mug ldan pa'i bdud de yang / / 'gro ba thams cad dbang du 'gyur byed na/ / dbang bcu dbang thob rnams la ci rob ste/ / 'gro ba thams cad rang gi phyogs ma bzhag /

If even Māra, who has attraction, aversion, and delusion, Can bring all sentient beings under his power, Why would those who attain mastery of the ten powers Not bring all living beings into their corner?
stong gsum gnas kyi bdag po tshangs pa yang / / stong gsum tshangs gnas ji snyed yod pa na/ / de dag kun na 'dug par rab snang zhing / / tshangs pa'i sgra dbyangs shin tu yid 'ong sgrogs/ /

The enchanting voices of the Brahmā gods Resound throughout the three thousand abodes of the Brahmā lords, As numerous as those three thousand Brahmā abodes are, Manifesting throughout, wherever they are.
tshangs de 'jig rten pa yi tshangs lam gyi/ / bsam gtan mngon shes rnam par 'phrul byed na/ / 'jig rten rab 'das bla na med pa yi/ / bsam gtan rnam thar gnas pa cis mi 'phrul/ /

If a Brahmā, through the worldly Brahmā path of meditative stability And the superknowledges, can perform miracles, As for those who abide in the supreme, transcendent meditative stability And freedom, what miracle would they not perform?
dbang phyug chen po'i shes pa'i rnam 'phrul ltos/ / rgya mtsho'i sprin gyis char thigs rab bkye ba/ / skad cig gcig la thams cad bgrang bar byed/ / thigs 'ga'i zer kyang ma shes de med na/ /

Behold the miracle of the great knowledge of Īśvara! As raindrops fall from the clouds that arise from the ocean, In a single moment, he stops the fall of all of them. If his beams do not fail to notice even a single drop,i then as for
bslabs pa bskal pa bsam yas rab bslabs te/ / byang chub bla med ye shes thob pa rnams/ / ci phyir skad cig gcig la sems kyis ni/ / 'gro ba ma lus kun gyi sems mi shes/ /

Those who are well trained, having trained during inconceivably many aeons, And who attain the highest pristine awareness of Awakening, Why would they, in a single moment of thought, Not know the minds of all living beings without exception?
sems can las smin bsam gyis mi khyab pas/ / 'jig rten 'di kun rlung las yongs su byung / / rgya mtsho ri dang lha yi gzhal med khang / / rin chen rnam phyes sa bon bkram pa'ang byung / /

Through the inconceivable maturation of the actions of sentient beings, This whole small world arises from small causes. The oceans, mountains, and the immeasurable mansions of the gods Also arise from divided jewels or strewn seeds.
rlung las byung gyur sprin gyis char 'bebs shing / / slar yang rlung nyid kyis ni sprin zhi byed/ / 'jig rten gyi ni lo tog rlung gis bskyed/ / 'gro ba kun gyi bde mang rlung gis byas/ /
A cloud, arising from the wind, gives rain And then again later, the wind dissipates the cloud. A harvest for the world is generated by the wind, And the wind brings happiness to the whole world.
rlung des pha rol phyin la ma bslabs shing / / sangs rgyas yon tan rnams la ma bslabs par/ / 'jig rten rnam smin bsam mi khyab ston na/ / mchog thob pa dag ci ste ston mi byed/ / ces bya ba'o/ /

If that wind, untrained in the perfections And untrained in the abilities of Buddhas, Shows such an inconceivable result of evolution to the world, As for those who have attained what is supreme, what would they not show?
bslab pa kun las btus pa las dkon mchog gsum rjes su dran pa'i le'u ste bco brgyad pa'o// //
[bsod nams spel ba]
19. Enhancing Goodness
bsod nams 'phel ba'i don du rgyu gzhan yang bya ste/ gang zhig dus rnams kun du sems can don bya ba 'di yin no/ / 'di ni dkon mchog sprin las/
[348] YOU SHOULD ALSO practice another cause of enhancing goodness, which is this: to benefit sentient beings in all situations. As the noble Cloud of Jewels says,

de de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten nam de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku gzugs la me tog gam bdug pa'am spos gsol na/ sems can thams cad kyi ngang tshul ngan pa'i dri nga ba bsal ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i tshul khrims kyi dri bro bar yongs su bsngo'o/ /

[349] When they offer flowers, incense, or perfume to a stūpa of a Tathāgata or to an image of a Tathāgata, they dedicate it to removing the stench of immorality from all sentient beings, and to attaining the moral discipline of a Tathāgata.

de phyag dar dang zhal zhal byed na sems can thams cad kyi spyod lam mi sdug pa med par 'gyur ba dang spyod lam mdzes pa phun sum tshogs par yongs su bsngo'o/ / de me tog gi gdugs gsol na sems can thams cad kyi nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa'i gdung ba med par bya ba'i phyir yongs su bsngo'o/ /

When cleaning or anointing them, they dedicate it so that all sentient beings would move away from unpleasant behavior and fulfill pleasant behavior. While setting up a flower parasol, they dedicate it to relieving the burning of all reactive emotions.[i]

de gtsug lag khang gi nang du 'gro na 'di ltar sems can thams cad mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer du gzud do snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de phyir 'byung na 'di ltar sems can thams cad 'khor ba'i btson ra nas gdon to snyam du sems bskyed do/ /

When they enter a monastery, they think, “May I cause all sentient beings to enter the city of Nirvāṇa.” When leaving, they think, “May I release all sentient beings from the prison of cyclic existence.”

de gnas khang gi sgo 'byed na 'di ltar 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes kyi bde 'gro thams cad kyi sgo dbye'o snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de sgo gcod na 'di ltar ngan 'gro thams cad kyi sgo rnams bcad do snyam du sems bskyed do/ /

When opening the door of their residence, they think, “May I open the door for all beings to the heavens and Nirvāṇa, and to transcendent pristine awareness.”[ii] While closing the door, they think, “May I close for all sentient beings all the doors to the lower realms.”

de 'dug na 'di ltar sems can thams cad byang chub kyi snying po la 'god do snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de glo g.yas pas nyal na 'di ltar sems can thams cad sangs rgyas kyi mya ngan las 'da' bas yongs su mya ngan las 'da'o snyam du sems bskyed do/ /
When sitting down, they think, “May I place all sentient beings on the seat of Awakening.” When lying down on the right side, they think: “May I cause all sentient beings to enter Nirvāṇa.”[1]

de de nas ldang na 'di ltar sems can thams cad nyon mongs pa kun nas ldang ba rnams las bslang ngo snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de lus kyi ched la 'gro na 'di ltar sems can thams cad skyes bu chen po'i 'gros su 'gro bar gyur cig snyam du sems bskyed do/ /

When standing up again, they think, “May I help all sentient beings to rise above being overwhelmed by reactive emotions.” While walking for the sake of their bodies,[iii] they think, “May all sentient beings walk with the gait of great persons.”

de de ltar 'dug na 'di ltar sems can thams cad kyi 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug gi zug rngu 'byung ngo snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de bkru bshal byed na 'di ltar sems can thams cad kyi nyon mongs pa'i dri ma'i skyon rnams bkru'o snyam du sems bskyed do/ /

When sitting down there, they think, “May all sentient beings pull out the arrows, which are attraction, aversion, and delusion.” While washing up, they think, “May I wash away from all sentient beings the impurities of the reactive emotions.”

de lag pa bsnyal na 'di ltar sems can thams cad kyi nyon mongs pa'i dri nga ba rnams bsal lo snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de rkang pa 'khru na 'di ltar sems can thams cad kyi nyon mongs pa'i rdul rnam pa sna tshogs bsal lo snyam du sems bskyed do/ /

While washing their hands, they think, “May I remove from all sentient beings the bad odors of the reactive emotions.” While washing their feet, they think, “May I remove from all sentient beings the dust of many kinds of reactive emotions.”

de gdong 'khru na 'di ltar sems can thams cad kyi chos thams cad kyi sgo yongs su sbyang ngo snyam du sems bskyed do/ / de so shing za na 'di ltar sems can thams cad kyi dri ma rnam pa sna tshogs bsal lo snyam du sems bskyed do/ /

While washing their faces, they think, “May I purify all the Dharma doors for all sentient beings.”[2] While brushing their teeth,[3] they think, “May I remove from all sentient beings the impurities of various types of reactive emotions.”

de lus kyi g.yo ba thams cad sems can thams cad la phan pa dang bde bar yongs su bsngo'o/ / de de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten la phyag 'tshal na 'di ltar sems can thams cad lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten gyis phyag bya bar shog cig snyam du sems bskyed do zhes ji skad gsungs pa lta bu'o/ /

They dedicate all their activities to the welfare and happiness of all sentient beings. And while performing reverential actions at a stūpa of a Tathāgata, they think, “May all sentient beings become worthy of reverence to the world, including the gods.”

yang na shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu ste/ shA ri'i bu gzhan yang gcan gzan khro bo'i dgon par song na/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos 'jigs par mi bya skrag par mi bya dngang bar mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'di ltar des sems can thams cad kyi don du thams cad yongs su gzung ba'i phyir te/ des 'di snyam du gal te gcan gzan dag gis bdag zos na 'di ltar sbyin pa de byin par gyur cig / bdag gi sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub la yang shin tu nye bar 'gyur ro/ / ji ltar bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa'i tshe/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing de na dud 'gro'i skye gnas su song ba'i sems can yong ye med par 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o snyam du sems bskyed do/ /

Alternately, as the noble Perfection of Wisdom says, Moreover, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being who enters a forest inhabited by fierce wild animals should not be afraid, should not be terrified, should not be overcome by terror. Why is that? She has given everything away for the benefit of all sentient beings.[iv] And she should think: “If the fierce wild animals should eat me, I give this to them as a gift. My perfection of generosity will be fulfilled, and Awakening will be near at hand. And I shall practice in such a way that, when I have attained highest genuine full Awakening, in that Buddha-field, beings in the animal realm will be completely absent, will not be heard of.”

shA ri'i bu rkun po'i dgon par song na byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos 'jigs par mi bya skrag par mi bya dngang bar mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de dag ni bdog pa thams cad yongs su gtong ba la mkhas pa yin te/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos lus kyang yongs su btang ba yin/ yo byad dang 'tshog chas kyang yongs su btang ba yin te/ des 'di snyam du gal te sems can de dag gis bdag gi yo byad dang 'tshog chas rnams phrogs na de dag la sbyin pa de byin par gyur cig / gal te de dag gis bdag gi srog bcad par gyur kyang de la bdag gis zhe sdang dang khong khro ba bskyed par mi bya/ bdag gis de dag la lus dang ngag dang yid kyis kyang nyes par mi bya'o/ / de ltar na de'i tshe sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa dang / tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang / bzod pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur zhing / bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub la shin tu nye bar 'gyur te/ ji ltar bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa'i tshe/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing de na nyes pa 'di dang gzhan yang yong ye rnam pa thams cad du mi 'byung zhing med par 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o/ / de ltar bsgrub po snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o/ /

[350] Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being who enters a forest inhabited by bandits should not be afraid, should not be terrified, should not be overcome by terror. Why is that? Because those bodhisattvas are skilled at giving up everything they have. The bodhisattva should have given up the body, as well as possessions and personal belongings. And he should think: “If they steal my possessions and personal belongings, I give that property to them as a gift. If some of them should deprive me of life, I should arouse neither aversion nor anger towards them, and towards them I should also commit no offense in thought, word, or deed. In this way, at this time, I will fulfill the perfection of generosity, the perfection of moral discipline, and the perfection of patient endurance, and Awakening will be near at hand. And I will practice in such a way, I will succeed in such a way, that when I have attained highest genuine full Awakening, in that Buddha-field these and other problems will not exist at all in any way, will not be heard of.”

shA ri'i bu chu'i dgon par phyin na/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos 'jigs par mi bya skrag par mi bya dngang bar mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams ni mi 'jigs pa'i chos can yin te/ des 'di snyam du bdag gis sems can thams cad kyi sred pa thams cad gcod par bslab par bya'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos skrag par mi bya'o/ / gal te bdag skom pas 'chi ba'i dus byas par gyur na sems can thams cad la snying rje chen po'i sems bskyed par bya ste/ kye ma 'di ltar 'jig rten na chu'i dgon pa 'di lta bu snang bas sems can 'di dag ni bsod nams chung ba dag ste/ ji ltar bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa'i tshe/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing de na chu'i dgon pa yong ye rnam pa thams cad du mi 'byung ba dang mi snang bar 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o de ltar bsgrub po/ / ji ltar yan lag brgyad dang ldan pa'i chu rnyed par 'gyur ba de ltar bsod nams kyi las la sems can rnams sbyar bar bya'o/ / ji ltar de'i tshe brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ba de ltar sems can thams cad kyi don du brtson 'grus brtan pa brtsam par bya'o snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o/ /

Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being who enters a dangerous place with no water should not be afraid, should not be terrified, should not be overcome by terror. Why is that? Because bodhisattva great beings have the quality of courage. And she should think: “I should train to cut through all the craving of all sentient beings. A bodhisattva great being should not succumb to terror. Even if I die of thirst, nevertheless, right now I will arouse this thought of great compassion towards sentient beings: ‘Oh no! Those poor sentient beings, with only a little goodness! They are such that in the world there are dangerous places with no water, like this one.’ And I will practice in such a way, I will succeed in such a way, that when I have attained highest genuine full awakening, in that Buddha-field, dangerous places with no water will not be heard of at all anywhere. And I will help sentient beings to make a connection with goodness, so that they will obtain drinking water with the eight good qualities. I will develop perseverance firmly in this way so that, right now, the perfection of perseverance will be fulfilled.”

shA ri'i bu gzhan yang bkres pa'i dgon par song na/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos 'jigs par mi bya skrag par mi bya dngang bar mi bya'o/ / des 'di ltar 'dis go cha bgo ste/ ji ltar bdag bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pa'i tshe/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing de na bkres pa'i dgon pa 'di lta bu yong ye rnam pa thams cad du mi 'byung ba dang / mi snang bar 'gyur ba dang sems can de dag thams cad bde bar 'gyur zhing bde ba la dbang ba dang / bde ba dang ldan par 'gyur ba de ltar brtson 'grus brtan po brtsam par bya ste/ de ltar rang gi sangs rgyas kyi zhing yongs su sbyang bar bya'o/ / ji ltar na sems can de dag gang ci sems par 'gyur ba dang yid kyis gang dang gang 'dod pa de dang de 'byung bar 'gyur ba/ 'di lta ste dper na sum cu rtsa gsum pa'i lha rnams kyi yid la bsam pa thams cad 'grub pa dang / yid la bsam pa thams cad 'byung ba bzhin du de ltar bya'o/ / ji ltar sems can de dag chos dang ldan pa'i bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ba dang / sems can thams cad thams cad du thams cad las 'tsho ba'i yo byad dang bral bar mi 'gyur ba de ltar brtson 'grus brtan po brtsam par bya'o snyam du sems bskyed par bya'o zhes bya'o/ /

Moreover, Śāriputra, a bodhisattva great being who enters a dangerous place with no food should not be afraid, should not be terrified, should not be overcome by terror. And he should put on the armor as follows: “I will develop perseverance firmly in such a way, and I will purify my Buddha-field in such a way, so that when I have attained highest genuine full Awakening, in that Buddha-field, dangerous places with no food, like this one, will not exist at all anywhere, will not be heard of. Those sentient beings will only be happy, provided with happiness, filled with all forms of happiness. And I will practice in such a way that whatever those sentient beings wish for, whatever they desire in their minds, that very thing will appear. For example, with the thirty-three gods, whatever they have in mind appears; whatever they have in mind arises. And I will undertake perseverance in such a way that the spiritual aspirations of those sentient beings will be completely fulfilled, and all sentient beings will lack nothing and have all the necessities of life, all of them, always, in every way.”
de ltar
Therefore, this:
dus rnams rtag tu sems can gyi don bya ba
[26a] In all postures, for the benefit of sentient beings;[v]
'di ni bsod nams 'phel ba'i rgyu ste/ zhib tu ni spyod yul yongs su dag pa'i mdo las blta bar bya'o/ /
is a cause of enhancing goodness. But, for the detailed explanation, see the noble Sūtra on Purifying the Domain (Gocara-pariśuddhi-sūtra).
gzhan yang /
Moreover,
chos kyi sbyin pa zang zing med/ /
[26b] giving Dharma, with no ulterior motive
bsod nams 'phel ba'i rgyur 'gyur te/ / lhag pa'i bsam pa bskul ba'i mdo las ji skad gsungs pa lta bu ste/
is a cause of enhancing goodness. As the noble Sūtra on Exhortation to Higher Intention says,

byams pa gang zhig thob pa dang bkur sti mi 'dod par chos kyi sbyin pa byin na/ chos kyi sbyin pa zang zing med pa'i phan yon nyi shu ste/ nyi shu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ dran pa dang ldan pa yin/ blo dang ldan pa yin/ blo gros dang ldan pa yin/ mos pa dang ldan pa yin/ shes rab dang ldan pa yin/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i shes rab rjes su rtogs par 'gyur ba yin/ 'dod chags chung ba yin/ zhe sdang chung ba yin/ gti mug chung ba yin/ bdud kyis de la glags mi rnyed pa yin/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyis dgongs pa yin/ mi ma yin pa rnams kyis de srung ba yin/ lha rnams de'i lus la mdangs 'jug pa yin/ mi mdza' ba rnams kyis de la glags mi rnyed pa yin/ de mdza' bo rnams dang mi phyed pa yin/ tshig gzung bar 'os pa yin/ mi 'jigs pa thob pa yin/ yid bde ba mang ba yin/ mkhas pas bsngags pa yin/ de chos kyi sbyin pa de rjes su dran par 'gyur ba yin te/ byams pa phan yon nyi shu po de dag go zhes bya ba'o/ /

[351] Maitreya, for those who, not longing for money or prestige, give gifts of Dharma with no ulterior motive, there are twenty benefits. What are the twenty? As follows: they become mindful; they become clever; they become intelligent; they become knowledgeable; they become self-controlled; they become wise; they penetrate to transcendent wisdom; they have little attraction, aversion, or delusion; Māra finds no opportunity in them; the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, take note of them; nonhumans protect them; gods instill vitality into their bodies; enemies find no opportunity in them; their friends become inseparable from them; their speech becomes agreeable; they attain the fearlessnesses; they are frequently glad; they are praised by the wise; and, for them, that gift of Dharma is something to remember. Maitreya, these are the twenty benefits.

shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa las kyang gsungs te/ gal te kun dga' bo khyod kyis nyan thos kyi theg pa'i gang zag rnams la nyan thos kyi sa'i chos bstan la/ chos bstan pa des kyang gang dag stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi sems can de dag thams cad dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas par gyur kyang / da dung nyan thos khyod kyis nga la nyan thos kyi bya ba byas par mi 'gyur ro/ / kun dga' bo gal te khyod kyis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po la/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang ldan pa'i tshig gcig cig bstan nam bshad na/ de ltar na nyan thos kyis nga mnyes par byas par 'gyur ro/ /

But the noble Perfection of Wisdom says, “Ānanda, suppose you were to teach people belonging to the Way of the Disciples about the stages of the disciples, and suppose that through that Dharma teaching you were to cause all the sentient beings in the three-billion-fold world-realm to see Sainthood face to face. Even then you would not have done what my disciples should do. Now, Ānanda, suppose you were to teach or make clear to a bodhisattva great being even a single word having to do with the perfection of wisdom. In that way you would serve me as a disciple.”

chos bstan pa snga mas gang dag stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi sems can de dag thams cad dgra bcom pa nyid thob par gyur la/ dgra bcom pa de dag gi sbyin pa las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po dang / tshul khrims las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po dang / bsgoms pa las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po gang yin pa de la kun dga' bo ji snyam du sems/ bsod nams kyi phung po mang ba yin nam/ gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das mang lags so/ / bde bar gshegs pa mang lags so/ /

“As for those sentient beings in the three-billion-fold world-realm who would attain Sainthood, and the quantity of goodness belonging to those Saints that consists of generosity, the quantity of goodness that consists of moral discipline, and the quantity of goodness consisting of meditation, what do you think about that, Ānanda? Would that be a large mass of goodness?” He said, “Large, Blessed One; large, Well-Gone One.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo de lta bas kyang su zhig byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams la shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang ldan pa'i chos ston na/ nyan thos kyi theg pa'i gang zag de bsod nams kyi phung po ches mang du bskyed do/ / kun dga' bo de bas kyang gang su zhig byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po rnams la shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dang ldan pa'i chos tha na nyi ma gcig ston na de bsod nams kyi phung po ches mang du bskyed do/ / kun dga' bo nyi ma gcig lta zhog la tha na snga dro'am/ kun dga' bo snga dro lta zhog la tha na chu tshod gcig nas skad cig gcig ces bya'o/ /

[352] The Blessed One said, “Ānanda, a greater mass of goodness than that flows forth, when someone belonging to the Way of the Disciples teaches bodhisattva great beings Dharma having to do with the perfection of wisdom. Ānanda, a greater mass of goodness than that also flows forth when a bodhisattva great being teaches another bodhisattva Dharma having to do with the perfection of wisdom, even for only so much as one day. Leave aside one day, Ānanda: even so much as a morning. Leave aside a morning, Ānanda: even so much as a single period of twenty-four minutes. And so on up to: even so much as a single moment of communication ”
de bzhin du sbyar te/

kun dga' bo 'di ni byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de'i chos sbyin pa ste/ nyan thos kyi theg pa thams cad dang rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa'i gang zag thams cad kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba zil gyis mnan pa'o/ / kun dga' bo byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di lta bu dang ldan pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba 'di lta bu sems pa la ni gnas ma yin zhing go skabs med de/ gang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub las phyir ldog pa de ni gnas med do zhes bya ba'o/ /

“Ānanda, this gift of Dharma by that bodhisattva great being exceeds the wholesome actions of all the people who belong to the Way of the Disciples and all the people who belong to the Way of the Solitary Sages. For a bodhisattva great being who has done such a wholesome action and is paying attention to such a wholesome action, it is not possible, Ānanda, there is no opportunity, for that bodhisattva great being to turn back from highest genuine full Awakening. Such an event could not occur.”

chos kyi sbyin pa ji ltar sbyin par bya zhe na/ 'phags pa dam pa'i chos pad+ma dkar po'i mdo las gsungs pa/ mkhas pa dus su sems par byed pa na/ / khang bur zhugs te de bzhin sgo bcad nas/ / chos 'di thams cad la ni tshul bzhin blta/ / langs nas zhum pa med pa'i sems kyis shod/ /

How should the gift of Dharma be given? As the noble Lotus Sūtra describes, A learned person enters a small hut at the proper time, And closing the door, reflects, Sees with insight the whole Dharma from the ground up, And then, rising up, should teach it with an undaunted mind.
mkhas pa bde la rtag tu gnas par 'gyur/ / bde la 'dug nas de bzhin chos kyang ston/ / gtsang zhing yid du 'ong ba'i sa phyogs su/ / yangs pa'i stan ni rab tu bshams bting ste/ /
He is established in happiness and always clear-sighted; Thus, seated in happiness, he proclaims the Dharma. In a clean and beautiful place, Where a broad seat has been well set up and laid out,
bzang po'i tshon gyis legs par kha bsgyur ba/ / chos gos gtsang ma de ni rab bgos nas/ / rngul gzan nag po de bzhin bshams byas la/ / sham thabs che tshad legs par rab bgos nas/ /
After putting on a clean robe, Well colored and with clear colors, And similarly, laying out a black traveling cloak [353] And wearing large and appropriate lower garments,[vi]
bcos bu'i ras rnams sna tshogs legs bting ba/ / rkang rten bcas pa'i khri la rab 'dug cing / / rkang pa legs par bkrus te steng 'dzegs nas/ / gdong dang bzhin gyi mdangs ni rab snum zhing / /
Ascending with well-washed feet And with his head and face well oiled, He sits on a seat with a footstool, With cotton cloths of many colors well spread out.
chos kyi stan de la ni rab 'dug nas/ / sems can lhags pa rtse gcig gyur rnams la/ / gtam mang sna tshogs mang po smra ba dang / / dge slong dag dang dge slong ma rnams dang / /
Sitting down there on the Dharma seat, Seeing with insight that the assembled sentient beings Are paying attention, He tells many and various stories To the monks, and to the nuns as well.[vii]
dge bsnyen rnams dang dge bsnyen ma dag dang / / rgyal po dag dang rgyal bu rnams la yang / / mkhas de rtag tu phrag dog med par ni/ / sna tshogs don ldan snyan pa'i gtam yang ston/ /
And to the lay men and lay women And to kings and princes That wise one, without envy, Also teaches various beneficial and pleasing stories.
le lo dag kyang rnam par rab spangs nas/ / skyo ba yi ni 'du shes bskyed mi bya/ / mkhas pas mi dga' thams cad rnam par spang / / byams pa'i stobs ni 'khor la bsgom par bya/ /
He should also ward off laziness And not think of himself as tired; That learned man should give up all dislike And in assemblies, should cultivate the power of lovingkindness.
nyin mtshan du yang chos mchog rab tu bsgom/ / mkhas pa de ni bye ba khrag khrig dpes/ / 'khor rnams mgu zhing de bzhin dga' bar byed/ / de la nam yang 'dod pa cung zad med/ /

That learned man should speak about[viii] the supreme Dharma day and night, Using a quadrillion examples, And, in this way, should please and satisfy the assembly,[ix] But should have no desire to get anything by doing so.
zas dang skom dang bza' dang bca' ba dang / / gos dang mal cha chos gos rnams dang ni/ / na ba'i gsos sman dag kyang mi bsam ste/ / 'khor rnams la ni ci yang mi bslang ngo / /
He should not think about food, drinks, edible or consumable items, Clothes, seats, beds, robes, Or medicine for the sick; [354] He should discern nothing but the assembly.
gzhan du mkhas pa rtag tu bdag nyid dang / / sems can 'di dag sangs rgyas 'grub par shog / phan phyir 'jig rten chos gang bstan pa de/ / bdag gi bde ba'i yo byad kun snyam sems/ / zhes bya'o/ /
Otherwise, the clear-sighted one should always reflect: “May I and these sentient beings become Buddhas. This is all I need to be happy: That I teach this Dharma for the benefit of the world.”
yang de nyid las/ chos kyi rnam grangs 'di rab tu ston pa na/ chos kyi dga' ba snyoms pa byed de tha na 'ga' tsam la yang chos kyi dga' bas lhag par phan 'dogs par mi byed do zhes gsungs so/ /
The same text says: “No greater assistance is given to anyone than that which is done out of love of the Dharma, even if it is very small.”[x]
zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las kyang / chos kyi sbyin pa'i ched kyi phyir/ / gal te khyod la gsol 'debs na/ / rab rgyas dag gis ma brlabs zhes/ /
The noble Candrapradīpa Sūtra also says,[xi] If you are asked to give a gift of Dharma, ***
thog mar tshig de brjod par bya/ / khyod ni shes shing mkhas yin na/ / bdag nyid chen po'i mdun du ni/ / bdag gis ji ltar bshad nus zhes/ / khyod kyis de skad brjod par bya/ /
You should say these words first: “Since you are learned and intelligent, Great ones, how can I speak in your presence?”
'phral du brjod par mi bya yi/ / snod la brtag pa byas nas bya/ / gal te snod ni shes gyur na/ / gsol ma btab kyang bshad par bya/ /
You should not be in a hurry to speak, But do so after considering the vessel. If you recognize a suitable vessel, Then you should teach even if not asked to do so.
'khor ni mang po 'khor nang du/ / gal te ngang tshul ngan mthong na/ / khyod kyi yo byad bsnyungs mi bshad/ / sbyin pa'i bsngags pa brjod par bya/ /
If you see many immoral people in the assembly, Do not teach severe austerity;[4] you should speak in praise of generosity.
gal te 'dod pa chung gyur te/ / tshul khrims dag par gnas yin na/ / khyod kyis byams pa'i sems bskyed la/ / yo byad bsnyungs pa'i gtam gyis shig /
If they should be of few desires, pure, established in moral discipline, [355] Then, arousing thoughts of lovingkindness, you should discuss severe austerity.
