gal te sdig 'dod nyung gyur cing / / tshul khrims ldan pa mang gyur la/ / gnyen po rnyed pa de yi tshe/ / tshul khrims bsngags pa brjod par bya/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
If those of wrongful desires are few, and the morally disciplined are abundant, Then, if you can find the remedy, you should speak in praise of moral discipline.
'phags pa blo gros rgya mtshos zhus pa'i mdo las kyang / 'di lta ste/
And the noble Sāgaramati Sūtra says, Sāgaramati, the Dharma teacher should recite well these mantra words, as follows:

sha me sha ma ba ti/ sha mi ta sha tru aM ku re/ maM ku re/ mA ra dzi te/ ka ro ti/ ke yU re/ U ko hA ya ti/ bi sha tha ni rma le/ ma lA pa na ye/ u kha re/ kha ro gra se/ gra sa ne/ he mU khI/ pa rA mu khI/ A mA khI/ sha mi tA ni/ sarba gra ha ban+d+ha nA ni/ ni gr-i hI twa/ sarba pa ra pra bA di na bi muk+tA mA ra pra shAs+thA pi tA/ bud+d+ha mu drA/ sa mung+g+ha ti tA sarba mA ra/ a tsa li ta pa da pa ri shud+d+he/ bi gats+tshan+tu/ sarba mAr karma Ni/

same, samavati, śamitaśatru, aṅkure, maṅkure, mārajite, karāḍe, keyūre, oghavati, ohokayati, viśaṭhanirmale, malāpanaye, okhare, kharograse, grasane, hemukhī, parāṅmukhī, āmukhī, śamitāni sarvagrahabandhanāni, nigṛhītāḥ sarvaparapravādinaḥ, vimuktā mārapāśāḥ, sthāpitā buddhamudrāḥ, samuddhātitāḥ sarvamārāḥ, acalitapadapariśuddhyā vigacchanti sarvamārakarmāṇi.

blo gros rgya mtsho sngags kyi tshig 'di dag ni bdud tshar gcad pa'i tshig nyon mongs pa bsal ba'i tshig ste/ de dag chos smra ba des legs par kha ton du byas la chos kyi khri la 'dug ste/ byang chub kyi rnam pas mngon par sgrub pa'i byams pas 'khor thams cad la khyab par byas la/ bdag la sman pa'i 'du shes bskyed de/ chos la sman gyi 'du shes dang / chos nyan pa la nad pa'i 'du shes dang / de bzhin gshegs pa la skyes bu dam pa'i 'du shes dang / chos kyi tshul la yun ring du gnas pa'i 'du shes bskyed la/ sngags kyi tshig 'di dag mngon du byas te/ de chos kyi gtam byed na/ de'i khor yug dpag tshad brgya tshun chad du bdud kyi ris kyi lha rnams mtho btsam par bya ba'i phyir 'ong bar mi 'gyur ro/ / gang dag 'ong ba de dag gis kyang bar chad byed par mi nus so zhes gsungs so/ /

And when the occupant of the teacher’s seat has recited these words well, the one seated on the teacher’s seat should radiate lovingkindness, generated with the aspect of Awakening, throughout the whole assembly. She should think of herself as a doctor, of the Dharma as medicine, of those listening to the Dharma as sick people, of the Tathāgata as a holy person, and of the way of the Dharma as something that should remain for a long time.[5] After arousing these thoughts and reciting these mantra words, she should discourse about the Dharma. In such a case, neither Māra nor the deities in Māra’s retinue will approach within a hundred leagues of her to cause confusion. And even those who do approach will not be able to find an opportunity in her to create obstacles.
yang de nyid las gsungs pa/ chos smra bas gtsang sbra dang / kun du spyod pa gzob pa dang / legs par bkrus pa dang / legs par gos bgo bar bya'o zhes so/ / de ltar chos kyi sbyin pa dang / /
[356] The same text says, “The Dharma teacher should be clean, of pure behavior, well bathed, dressed in clean clothes.” Such is the gift of Dharma.
byang chub sems ni mdor bsdu na/ / bsod nams 'phel ba'i rgyu yin no/ /
[26cd] In brief, Awakening Mind is the cause of enhancing goodness.

dkon mchog za ma tog gi mdo las ji skad du 'jam dpal 'di lta ste/ dper na spos kyi shing ljon pa sna tshogs ni khams bzhis bzung nas rnam par 'phel lo/ / 'jam dpal de bzhin du tshogs sna tshogs bsags pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba yang byang chub kyi sems kyis bzung zhing thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du yongs su bsngos na rnam par 'phel lo zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ / phyogs 'di ni las dang po pa rnams 'phral du byang chub sems dpa'i bslab pa dran par bya ba'i phyir bstan te/ rgya cher ni sangs rgyas kyi yul nyid yin no/ / 'dir/ bslab pa ji ltar brjod pa 'di'i/ /

As the noble Casket of Jewels Sūtra says, Indeed, Mañjuśrī, just as, when the four elements come together, various kinds of fragrant trees grow, in just the same way, Mañjuśrī, when a bodhisattva has gathered the various forms of equipment, wholesome actions grow, united with the Awakening Mind and dedicated to complete knowing. This is taught for beginners getting started, so that they can remember the training of bodhisattvas immediately. But the details are known by the Buddhas alone. On this topic, as has been said about that training:
'grub pa yang dag spong rnams te/ / bag yod pa dang ma bral zhing / / dran pa dang ni shes bzhin dang / / tshul bzhin du ni sems pas so/ /
[27] The accomplishment of the right efforts, Not being separated from heedfulness, With mindfulness, with awareness, And with appropriate reflection.

de la sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos ma skyes pa rnams mi bskyed pa'i phyir 'dun pa skyed do 'bad do brtson 'grus rtsom mo sems rab tu 'dzin to yang dag par rab tu 'jog go zhes bya ba 'dis ni bsrung ba'o/ / sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos skyes pa rnams spang ba'i phyir 'dun pa skyed ces bya ba 'dis ni dag pa'o/ / dge ba'i chos ma skyes pa rnams bskyed pa'i phyir 'dun pa skyed pa dang / skyes pa rnams gnas pa dang 'phel bar bya ba'i phyir zhes bya ba 'dis ni 'phel ba bstan to/ / de dag kyang rtag tu bag yod pa dang ma bral bar bya ste/ de ni dge ba thams cad kyi rtsa ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Here, you generate motivation so that vile, unwholesome states that have not yet arisen do not arise; you strive, develop perseverance, take hold of your mind, and correctly make vows. In this way, you protect. You generate motivation to give up those which have arisen. In this way, you purify. You generate motivation for the arising of wholesome states that have not yet arisen, and so on up to: you generate motivation for continuing and for developing further those that have arisen. In this way, you enhance. And these things should always be done while established in heedfulness, because that is the root of all wholesome actions.

zla ba sgron ma'i mdo las ji skad du/ tshul khrims thos dang gtong dang de bzhin bzod/ / dge ba'i chos su brjod pa ji snyed pa/ / kun gyi rtsa ba bag yod 'di yin te/ / gter 'thob byed ces bde bar gshegs pas bstan/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

As the noble Candrapradīpa Sūtra says,[xii] Moral discipline, learning, renunciation, and patient endurance as well, All those that are known as wholesome states: Heedfulness is the root of all of them. The Well-Gone One taught that it is like finding a treasure.

bag yod pa zhes bya ba 'di ji lta bu zhe na/ 'dod pa las nyams pa dang mi 'dod pa byung bar dogs pa sngon du 'gro bas gzob pa lhur len pa ste/ 'di lta ste/ dper na rgyal po drag po khro zhing mgu dka' ba'i bran sman gyi 'bru mar gyis gang ba'i snod thogs te/ stegs 'dred pa la 'gro bas bya ba bzhin no/ /

[357] What is this quality called “heedfulness”? It is the advance intention to proceed carefully, out of concern about the loss of what you want and the arrival of what you don’t want. For example, it’s like a servant of a king who is fierce, wrathful, and difficult to please,[xiii] carrying a vessel of medicinal oil over slippery steps.

de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba'i mdo las gsungs te/ de la bag yod pa gang zhe na/ gang 'di dbang po sdom pa'o/ / de mig gis gzugs rnams mthong na mtshan mar mi 'dzin cing mngon rtags su mi 'dzin pa nas/ yid kyis chos rnams rnam par shes na mtshan mar mi 'dzin cing mngon rtags su mi 'dzin pa yin te/ chos rnams kyi ro myang ba dang nyes dmigs dang 'byung ba yang yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu shes pa ste/ 'di ni bag yod pa zhes bya'o/ / gzhan yang bag yod pa ni gang rang gi sems 'dul ba dang / gzhan gyi sems rjes su srung ba dang / nyon mongs pa la dga' ba sel ba dang / chos la dga' ba'i rjes su 'jug pa la sogs pa 'di ni bag yod pa zhes bya'o/ / gsang ba pa'i bdag po su dad pa dang ldan zhing bag yod pa dang ldan pa des ni brtson 'grus gang gis bag yod par byed pa dang dad par byed pa'i chos de dag yang dag par sgrub par 'gyur ba'i brtson 'grus dang ldan par bya'o/ / gsang ba pa'i bdag po su dad pa dang bag yod pa dang brtson 'grus dang ldan pa des ni/ dran pa dang shes bzhin gang gis byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos rnams chud za bar mi 'gyur ba'i dran pa dang shes bzhin dang ldan par bya'o/ / gsang ba pa'i bdag po su dad pa dang bag yod pa dang / brtson 'grus dang dran pa dang shes bzhin dang ldan pa des tshul bzhin du sbyor ba la brtson par bya'o/ / gsang ba pa'i bdag po tshul bzhin la brtson pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni gang yod pa de yang yod par rab tu shes so/ / gang med pa de yang med par rab tu shes zhes bya ba nas/ kun rdzob tu mig la sogs pa yod do zhes bya ba'i bar du'o/ /

For the noble Sūtra on the Mysteries of the Tathāgata says, Here, what is heedfulness? It is the discipline of the sense-faculties. When someone, having seen forms with the eye, does not grasp at signs, does not grasp at secondary characteristics, and so on up to: having become conscious of objects of thought with the mind, does not grasp at signs, does not grasp at secondary characteristics, but with respect to all experiences that arise, discerns as they actually are enjoyment, and distress, and salvation: this is called heedfulness. Moreover, heedfulness is taming one’s own mind, protecting the minds of others, not preparing to take delight in reactive emotions, turning towards the delights of the Dharma, and so on up to: This is called “heedfulness.” Lord of Mysteries, those who have faith and heedfulness should practice with suitable perseverance, through which the virtues developed through the practice of heedfulness and the practice of faith can be acquired. Lord of Mysteries, those who have faith and heedfulness and perseverance should practice mindfulness and awareness, through which they will not lose any of the virtues that are conducive to Awakening. Lord of Mysteries, those who have faith, heedfulness, perseverance, mindfulness, and awareness should engage in appropriately applied spiritual practice. Lord of Mysteries, a bodhisattva who is practicing appropriately discerns, of what is, that it is, and of what is not, that it is not. And so on, up to “The eye exists conventionally.”

de bzhin du de nyid las/ sems can don brtson byang chub sems dpa' ni/ / tshul bzhin nyid kyis dben sems gang yin dang / / rtag tu bag yod 'chi med rgyu yin te/ / yongs su 'dzin med bde ba kun gyi rgyu/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

As the same text says, Always being heedful is the root of the deathless For one devoted to the welfare of sentient beings; and Awakening Mind, That which is appropriate, and the mind of solitude. Nonpossessiveness is the root of all happiness.[xiv]
yang smras pa/ bdag gzhan mnyam nyid goms byas pas/ / byang chub sems ni brtan par 'gyur/ / bdag dang gzhan nyid ltos pa ste/ / pha rol tshu rol ji bzhin rdzun/ /

And he, [Śāntideva,] says: By continually meditating on the equality of self and others, Awakening Mind should become stable. Selfhood and otherness are mutually dependent; [358] Both sides are deceptive.
ngogs de rang gis pha rol min/ / gang la ltos te tshu rol 'gyur/ / bdag nyid rang gis ma grub na/ / gang la ltos te gzhan du 'gyur/ /
When that side is not intrinsically other, By what standard is there otherness? Since selfhood is not established intrinsically, With respect to what could an other exist?
gal te de la sdug bsngal bas/ / bdag la mi gnod phyir mi srung / / ma 'ongs sdug bsngal khyod la ni/ / gnod mi byed pas ci ste srung / /
If, thinking, “I am not hurt by that suffering,” You do not protect [someone else,] You are not hurt by future suffering; Why do you protect against that?
de tshe'ang bdag nyid yin snyam pa'i/ / rnam rtog de ni log pa ste/ / gang phyir 'chi ba gzhan nyid la/ / der skye ba yang gzhan nyid yin/ /
“It will also be just me then as well” Is a mistaken construction, For it is one thing that dies And something else entirely that is born there.[6]
gal te gzhan zhig der skyes na/ / bsod nams kyis ni ci zhig dgos/ / ci phyir gzhon tshe lus rgas pa/ / bde bar bya phyir nor sogs byed/ /
[Objection:] If it is something else that is born, What is the use of goodness? [Reply:] To the young person, what is the use Of the pleasure of the aged body due to accumulated wealth?
mngal na gnas pa zhig pa las/ / byis par gyur pa gzhan yin la/ / byis pa zhig nas gzhon nu nyid/ / de zhig nas ni dar la bab/ /
de zhig nas ni rgas gyur te/ / lus ni ji ltar gcig par 'dod/ / de ltar skad cig so so bas/ / lus gzhan sen mo skra tshogs bzhin/ /
The old person arrives when that ceases. How is there thought to be one body? And thus, in each moment, There is another body, as with hair, nails, and so on.
ci ste byis pa'i tshang bor nas/ / byis pa gzhon nu nyid gyur na/ / gang zhig gnas skabs bral gnas pa/ / lus kyi rang bzhin brjod par gyis/ /
[Objection:] Given that, by leaving childhood behind, The child goes to adolescence, That which remains, over and above these states, Should be called the intrinsic nature of the body.
lus ni sku gzugs 'dra zhe na/ / mar me thal ba la de med/ / gal te rags spangs phra dngos su/ / de la rnam par gnas she na/ /
[Reply:] If the body is a particular shape that appears, Then it is not present in the zygote, nor in the ashes.[xv] If it is there as something subtle That is not a bulky physical object,
rang nyid bstan pa tsam 'gyur bas/ / de ni lus zhes brjod mi bya/ / de la bdag ni bsam pa med/ / snang ba'i lus ni 'jig dang ldan/ /
Then obviously, it cannot be pointed out, And it would not be called a “body.” I’m not worried about that view,[xvi] But the body we see is destructible,
gnas skabs rnams dang 'brel gyur pa/ / kun rdzob nyid du snang ba yin/ / lung gis kyang ni de yod na/ / rigs pa dang ni lung gis bzlog /
And its relation with the states [359] Can be seen to be merely conventional. [If you say that] it exists on the basis of [non-Buddhist] scriptures,[7] It is ruled out by reason and scripture,
'di ltar yon tan ma gtogs par/ / gtso bo yod pa ma yin la/ / gtso bo gsum yang yod ma yin/ / de bzhin yon tan yod na yang / /
Since no prime matter exists Over and above the strands, And there are not three forms of prime matter. The same is true also for the strands:
de ni so so rnam gsum bdag / 'gro ba lhag ma rnam pa dgur/ / sems pa med pa gos la sogs/ / de bde'i bdag nyid ji lta bu/ /
If each of them is threefold, The world would be of nine types. How can nonsentient things such as clothes and so on Have the nature of pleasure and the rest?
snam sogs las skyes bde sogs min/ / snam sogs las ni bde sogs yin/ / snam bu la sogs rgyu med phyir/ / med na de bde ga la yod/ /
It is not that clothes and the like arise from pleasure, But pleasure arises from clothes and so on. Since clothes and so on are not causes, they don’t exist. Where does the pleasure come from?
de ltar lung dang rigs pa yis/ / 'dus byas thams cad mi rtag pa/ / de yi rgyu 'bras 'brel ba ni/ / mngon sum yin pas mi gnod do/ /
Therefore, on the basis of scripture and reasoning, All conditioned things are impermanent. The causal relation among those entities Is not refuted, since we perceive it;
de ni rang gi rgyud las mthong / / rtag pa la ni ji lta bur/ / phra rab rdul yang gcig min te/ / phyogs kyi dbye ba mi 'thad phyir/ /

You can observe it in your own stream of consciousness; But if things were permanent, how could this be? An atom is also not a single thing, Since spatial differentiations are incompatible with [being unitary].[8]
mar me'i 'bru mar zad 'gyur ba/ / zad 'gyur tshe na mngon pa med/ / de ltar dngos po zad par yang / / skad cig re re mi mngon no/ /
Lamp-oil is consumed But we don’t see it being consumed. In the same way, we don’t see Existing things ceasing in each moment.
rgyud dang tshogs zhes bya ba yang / / phreng ba dmag la sogs bzhin rdzun/ / de la goms pas ngar 'dzin na/ / gzhan la ci phyir skye mi 'gyur/ /

A stream of consciousness and a collection Are not real, like a queue, an army, and so on. Identification of them as self arises due to repeated practice. [360] Why can’t it arise in relation to others?
de phyir skye mched tshogs bzhin du/ / 'gro ba gcig tu shes par bya/ / ma byung nyid nas sdug bsngal de/ / gzhan gyi bdag las phyir bzlog bya/ /
Therefore, living beings should be understood in the same way, As like a collection of sense-spheres. Since that suffering is unowned, It should be prevented, for yourself and for others.[xvii]
de yang mi rigs 'gyur zhe na/ / gzhan la'ang rang gi bdag nyid med/ / bdag gzhan mi rigs gang yin de/ / ci rigs par ni bzlog bya yin/ /

If you admit that this is unreasonable, That there is no sense of self with respect to others, Any way of thinking about yourself or others that is unreasonable Should be given up to the best of your ability.[9]
snying rjes sdug bsngal mang gyur pas/ / ci phyir nan gyis skyed ce na/ / 'gro ba'i sdug bsngal brtag byas na/ / ji ltar snying rje sdug bsngal mang / /
You may ask: If compassion leads to so much pain, Why produce it through effort? But when you consider the suffering of the world, How can the pain of compassion be called great?[10]
de ltar rgyud ni goms gyur pa/ / gzhan gyi sdug bsngal zhi dga' bas/ / pad+ma'i nags su ngang pa ltar/ / mnar med par yang 'jug par 'gyur/ /

Those who have developed their personalities in this way, So that others’ suffering is as important to them as what they hold dear,[xviii] Dive down into the Avīci hell Like wild geese into a cluster of lotus blossoms.
sems can rnam par grol ba na/ / dga' ba'i rgya mtsho gang yin pa/ / de nyid kyis ni chog min nam/ / ro med thar pas ci zhig bya/ /
Those who feel joy like the ocean When sentient beings find freedom, Aren’t they the very ones who attain it? What would be the point in freedom without sweetness?
de ltar gzhan gyi don byas pas/ / rlom sems dang ni ngo mtshar med/ / gcig tu gzhan don la dga' bas/ / rnam smin 'bras bu re ba med/ /
When they act for the benefit of others, They are neither intoxicated nor proud, With no hope for the results of evolution of the action, Craving only the well-being of others.[11]
phyogs bcu'i sems can phun tshogs de'i/ / bdag gi yin par gdon mi za/ / gzhan bde bdag gir 'du shes pas/ / bdag la phrag dog go skabs med/ /
The achievements of the sentient beings in the ten directions Are theirs as well, beyond all doubt; And they leave no opening for envy, [361] Since they think of others’ happiness as their own.
sdig pa bshags par bya ba dang / / bsod nams rjes su yi rang dang / / sangs rgyas bskul dang gsol gdab pa/ / gzhan dang bdag gi phyir byed do/ /
They confess their vile actions For the sake of themselves and others equally. Rejoicing in goodness, And also requesting the Buddhas to teach,
yongs su bsngo ba de bzhin te/ / bye brag med par rab tu 'jug / de ltar sems can khams bzhin du/ / bsod nams mtha' yas rab tu 'byung / /
And dedication, are performed in the same way, With no discrimination. The goodness that unfolds from that Is endless, like the realm of sentient beings.
lam 'di dam pa mchog yin te/ / bde ba mtha' yas dus ston bzang / / byang chub sems dpa'i ded dpon ches/ / gang zhig dga' ba 'phel ba yin/ /
This is the supreme path, A festival of the endless happiness of peace, Increasing the delight of The great caravan of bodhisattvas.
lag na rdo rje bsel mchog rnams/ / bdud kyi gcan pa skrag byed cing / / sangs rgyas phyag brnyan rnams kyis kyang / / rtag tu yongs su bsrung ba yin/ /
It is continually protected By the servants of the Buddha, Led by Vajrapāṇi, the captain of the guard,[xix] Who terrify the soldiers of Māra.
rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rgyal ba'i sras/ / byang chub sems kyi shing rtar zhugs/ / lha la sogs pas stod byed cing / / lam de nas ni 'gro bar byed/ /
The royal heirs of the Fully Awakened Ones, Riding in the chariot of Awakening Mind, Travel by that road, Being praised by gods and the like.
de ltar sems can rnams la bdag / goms byas tshul gyis sgro btags te/ / bdag gzhan sdug bsngal zhi bya'i phyir/ / bdag la sogs pa rnam kun gtang / /
Therefore, in order to relieve your own and others’ suffering, You should, by repeated practice, Extend the identification of self to others And give up your body and so on, in every way.
gang zhig sred pas yongs zin pa/ / de yi sdug bsngal zhir mi 'gyur/ / 'gyur bas rnam par chud zos nas/ / de ni 'di ltar sdug bsngal skyed/ /
The suffering of those who are grasped by craving Will not be relieved, Since their dedication [of goodness] is perishable And they keep giving rise to more suffering.
'jig rten sdug bsngal mes gdungs na/ / rang gi bde la dgar ci yod/ / kun nas tshig par gyur pa yi/ / lus la'ang bde ba ci zhig yod/ /

When the world is being tormented by the fire of suffering, How can you take delight in your own pleasure? When someone is being burned all over, Will that person be happy if one fingernail is not burning?
bdag la chags par byed pa ni/ / sdug bsngal kun gyi rtsa ba mchog / de ltar sems can thams cad la/ / bdag nor gtang zhing de gzhom mo/ /
Attachment to a sense of self Is the basic source of all forms of suffering. It is just this that I will strike down, [362] Giving up my own welfare for sentient beings.
rten cing 'brel 'byung bsam pa yis/ / bdag la ma chags dran byas te/ / 'bad pa kun gyis de'i pho nya/ / dam pa shes khe 'dod pham bya/ /
Every effort should be made to defeat The desire for reputation, its principal messenger, Through generating mindfulness of how the self really is[xx] By reflecting on dependent arising.
gang gis 'jigs pas de mi gtong / / de ma byin na 'jigs pa yin/ / 'di ltar bdag gi lus dang sems/ / skad cig re res 'gro ba nyid/ /
I won’t give it up out of fear of something, But that very thing is still frightening when I don’t give it away, Since my body and mind Depart in each moment.
gal te mi rtag dri 'bab pa'i/ / lus kyis rtag cing dri med pa'i/ / byang chub thob par 'gyur na ni/ / de ni rin med rnyed min nas/ /
If Awakening, which is permanent and pure, Could be attained by An impermanent, impure body, Wouldn’t I have attained it?[xxi]
rtsi sman gzugs dang 'dra bar ni/ / 'jig rten chos la mi sems pas/ / da ltar bdag kyang gtang byos la/ / sems can kun gyi don du spyod/ /
In this way, you should give up your body And then live to benefit all sentient beings, As medicine does,[xxii] Not thinking about worldly things.
sems can kun phyir blon por ni/ / rang gi shes rab bkol bar bya/ / rigs pas nor de bsrung byas te/ / sems can rnams la mkho bar spyad/ /
You should apply your own wisdom As a counselor to benefit all sentient beings, And after protecting your wealth appropriately, Use it to help sentient beings.
bdag gi lus dang gzhan lus la/ / sdug bsngal mang sel sdug bsngal gang / / de bya bde ba'ang de bzhin te/ / bde ba mang byed bskyed par bya/ /
You should undergo any pain That does not lead to suffering here and now in your own body or those of others, And in the same way, produce the happiness That leads to much happiness.[xxiii]
sems can longs spyod gegs byed phyir/ / bsgribs te nyon mongs sbyangs byas te/ / 'jig rten 'tsho ba'i 'bab stegs nas/ / sbrul gyi ro bsal bzhin du bya/ /
Because they interfere with sentient beings’ enjoyment, Reactive emotions should be cleared away through effort, Like the corpses of snakes from a ford That provides a good livelihood for the world.
bsod nams zhing 'di dag gyur na/ / phun sum lo tog 'bras bu che/ / bde ba'i mu ges gdungs pa yi/ / 'gro ba dag ni tshim par 'gyur/ /
This pure field of goodness, Once the great fruit of attainment grows, Will satisfy the whole world, Now tormented by a famine of happiness.
'thob dang bkur sti lus la sogs/ / skyo la bdag gis btang min nam/ / ci phyir da dung 'khrug par byed/ / bdag gis rdzun du de smras sam/ /
Haven’t I given away money, prestige, And my body to others? Why would I now quarrel? Or was I telling lies?
rang don gnod byed la sdang na/ / 'o na snying rje gang du 'byung / / gal te gzhan don 'jig pa la/ / snying rje med pa'ang su zhig 'khrug /

If I feel aversion even towards those who destroy their own welfare, For whom will I feel compassion? Why would someone get angry, even towards a person with no sympathy, [363] If he destroyed [not that someone’s, but] other people’s welfare?
gla rtsi bu ram shing la sogs/ / bdag pos mi shes bzhag nyes te/ / longs spyod du ni mi rung bas/ / spyod brgyad la sogs 'os yin bden/ /
Truly, the sugarcane, the musk tree, and others like them Patiently endure abuse, And cannot be used When their owner plants them in the wrong place,[xxiv]
bdag po la ni phan 'dod nas/ / rim gro bya bar sems pa med/ / de la bskul ba'ang mi byed de/ / longs spyod phyir yang 'gro mi byed/ /
Do not expect anything in return, And do not desire to benefit their owner. They do not accuse him Or approach him in order to be enjoyed.
ma rmos ma btab rgyal sras rnams/ / de dag rjes 'brangs nyer song ste/ / sna tshogs mi bzad khams rnams dang / / dbang po kun gyi sman chen 'gyur/ /
The heirs of the Victors, sown in unploughed ground, Remembering and recollecting those beings Who have all kinds of objects and realms And who are gravely ill in all their faculties,
de dag shes byas dran byas te/ / khro ba dang ni gnod byed kyang / / sdug bsngal rnams la zhim pa yi/ / rang bzhin mi 'dor bde bar byed/ /
Teach and remind even angry people And those who do harm; Never giving up their sweet nature, They make those who suffer happy.
sa dang chu dang me dang rlung / / nam mkha' zhes bya khams lnga po/ / sems can ji srid gnas srid du/ / kun gyi don ni byed pa ste/ /
The five elements, known as Earth, water, fire, wind, and space, As long as there still are any sentient beings, Promote the welfare of all of them.
nyes spyod kun gyis de dag ni/ / sems can don las mi ldog go/ / de bzhin bdag gis khams drug po/ / 'di dag don med mi bya'o/ /
They do not cease benefiting sentient beings Despite all their ruinous actions. I will do the same, And never harm any of the six elements.[12]
nam mkha'i mtha' ni ji tsam par/ / 'jig rten mtha' ni srid gyur pa/ / de srid 'jig rten don byed pas/ / ye shes sngon btang gnas par bgyi/ /
Up to the very limits of space, As long as the world exists, So long will I remain, Benefiting the world and following pristine awareness.[13]
bya ba bsrungs na bdag la ni/ / bdag gis mi dri nan gyis su/ / slob dpon bdag gis rtag par bdag / slob ma mchog bzhin bslab par bya/ /
Guarding my actions with all my strength, I should always be a good student, Studying with my teacher, myself, [364] Even if I don’t ask myself for teachings.
bdag gi bla ma bdag 'dra bar/ / bdag gi bag nyal skyon sus shes/ / bdag sdug bsngal dang bdag 'jigs pas/ / su zhig de ltar sdug cing 'jigs/ /
Who is hurt by my pain? Who is frightened by my fear? Who knows my problems and reactive patterns As well as my spiritual teacher, myself?
skyo bar mi 'gyur 'gros mi 'gyur/ / snying rje yi yang yul gyur cig / rtag tu nye bar gnas gyur pa/ / slob ma bdag 'dra ga la yod/ /
And how could there be a student as good as myself? I am far from indifferent, and won’t run away; I am an object of compassion, And I am always close by.
nyon mongs kyis smyo gti mug ldongs/ / g.yang sa mang po'i lam du ni/ / gom pa re re rdeg 'cha' ba/ / bdag dang gzhan rtag mya ngan gzhi/ /
Driven insane by reactive emotions and blinded by delusion, On a path with many sheer cliffs, Stumbling at every step, I myself and others are always in a lamentable state.
'gro ba rnams ni sdug bsngal mtshungs/ / de bas 'khrul pa btsal mi rigs/ / 'di la yon tan mthong na ni/ / ngo mtshar chen po bya ba'i rigs/ /
Therefore, it is not reasonable to investigate the stumbles Of people involved in the same disaster; But it is reasonable to marvel greatly When abilities are seen.
nyes pa rgya mtsho bdag gcig pu/ / blang bar nus pa ma yin pas/ / 'di na bdag la gzhan yang dgos/ / nyes las thar byed gzhan gang yin/ /
I alone cannot remove The great ocean of [my own] problems. I need the help of others. What time do I have for other people’s problems?
pha rol bskul la mkhas pa po/ / gsol ba ma btab phan byed kyi/ / tshig ni spyi bos blang bar bya/ / bdag ni kun gyi slob par bya/ /
I will respectfully receive the words Of those who are skilled at advising others And who help even when not asked to do so; I will become a student of everyone.
nyon mongs dgra ni mang po dang / / gcig pu bdag ni g.yul 'gyed tshe/ / de na gcig dang 'thab pa na/ / gzhan ni bdag gi bde ba 'joms/ /
I alone am in a battle With many enemies, the reactive emotions, Where, when I fight with just one, Others easily strike me down.
sdang ngam mi sdang gyur kyang rung / / de na la la rgyab nas sam/ / gzhan nas 'jigs pa sgrogs byed pa/ / de ni bdag la srog phangs sbyin/ /
Here, anyone who warns me About danger from the rear or anywhere else, Whether that person is hostile or friendly, [365] Is an ally who saves my life.[xxv]
Blue like a swarm of bees, Wearing monastic robes And garlands of fragrant, Many-colored flowers in full bloom,
Traversing the oceans of Buddha-fields Simultaneously in all directions, Powerful, worthy of honor, Destroying all the Māras,

Bearer of the water which, when released, Relieves the torments of the hell-beings and hungry ghosts, Working for the benefit of worthy sentient beings Who are in the dense forest of cyclic existence,
Wearing the ornaments of the powers On which living beings can feast their eyes, Wise, of youthful appearance, Astonishing the world,
The welfare of the whole world rolled up into one, He is known as Mañjuśrī: I salute him reverentially With my whole body, again and again.
He is the great lake that brings rejoicing To those tormented by many forms of suffering, The great cloud who fills up The hells of thirst of the threefold world,
A wish-fulfilling tree for all ten directions, Bearing many fruits that the world desires. He is honored by the lotus eyes of the world And is very glad when they attain what they seek.
He is praised by hundreds of bodhisattvas Whose hairs stand up with astonishment. I salute Mañjuśrī reverentially With deeper and deeper prostrations.
sdug bsngal kun gyi sman pa mchog / bde ba'i dga' ston rab tshogs zhing / / rnam pa kun du nyer 'tsho ba/ / 'jam dbyangs khyod la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Physician for all forms of suffering, Donor of a great sacrifice of happiness, Sustainer of many forms of life, Reverential salutations to you, Mañjuśrī!

de ltar bde bar gshegs kyi sras/ / rnam kun rmad du byung rnams kyi/ / spyod pa nye bar bkod pa yi/ / dge ba bdag gis gang bsags pa/ / bde gshegs go 'phang mtha' yas ni/ / nam mkha'i mtshams par dbang mdzad pa/ / de yi bde ba mtha' yas rnams/ / lus can dag gis thob par shog /

Whatever good I may have gained by collecting the practices Of the heirs of the Victors, who are exceptionally marvelous in every way, Through that, may embodied beings have endless happiness, Including the state of the Well-Gone Ones, whose sovereignty is as vast as endless space.
bsod nams spel ba rdzogs so// //
bslab pa kun las btus pa zhes bya ba byang chub sems dpa'i 'dul ba mdo sde du ma las btus pa/ slob dpon zhi ba'i lhas mdzad pa rdzogs so// //
['gyur byang]
{Colophon:}

rgya gar gyi mkhan po dzi na mi tra dang / dA na shI la dang / zhu chen gyi lo tsA ba ban de ye shes sdes bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa// // slad kyi kha che'i paN+Di ta ti la ka ka la sha dang / lo tsA ba dge slong blo ldan shes rab kyis sri mda'i dgon par zhu thug legs par byas pa'o//

{The Indian scholars Jinamitra and Dānaśīla, and the editor-in-chief, Lotsawa Bande Ye shes sde, translated and edited this text, transmitting it for all time. Afterwards, the Kashmiri scholar Tilakakalaśa and Lotsawa Venerable Blo ldan shes rab performed additional editing at Sri mda monastery.}
